description:
I was looking for a quick bite to eat between appointments in the city and in San Rafael and was lucky to find Plow. Breakfast or brunch was on my mind and I saw the positive Yelp reviews at Plow and thought I would check it out and oh my goodness I am happy that I did! 

I ordered " the plow " it came with two small lemon ricotta pancakes. I have to pause and mention that there is a tight team of 3 guys working and one is making ricotta fresh right there on the line. Talk about high-end pancakes! One guy is working on the potatoes, one is working on the meats, it is a friendly, swift and delicious team of chefs. The menu is expansive and they have such unique breakfasts, large portions and such high quality. 

The plow also comes with crispy Neueske bacon, two eggs (I chose over medium) cooked absolutely perfectly, a hash of deep-fried country potatoes which were still soft and buttery inside but nice and crispy on the outside, caramelized onion and bacon tossed together, it was really a step above the norm. 

Everyone works as a friendly well-oiled machine, they all have their pace down and it works wonderfully for all of us. The service is lovely, they don't bother you but they check in with you which is nice, not overt or pushy which many places as packed as this can tend to be. I can't wait to go back.
author: Kelly T.

description:
It takes a lot to get me to write a review, especially less than favorable, but I really don't appreciate how they treat customers sometimes. 

Getting off of a night shift and being one of the first people in the (empty) restaurant only to have the hostess to tell you to wait outside because your other person is parking is absurd.

The food is decent but overpriced, which tends to be most places in SF.

YMMV
author: Jonathan K.

description:
Food is on point, but is it worth the wait? 

This place definitely lives up to the hype. The downside being the wait. It's definitely easier to get in with a group of 2. Groups of 4 will be waiting a little longer. You put your name on a list and you have to be there when they call it out. No phone calls, which sucks. We walked around the area and grabbed coffee next door. The coffee shop has games so it wasn't too hard to kill time. 

THE PLOW - so much food! I hope you have a big stomach or you'll be taking left overs. The pancakes are on the small side, but still packs some great flavors. The sausages are smaller too, but you honestly don't need more food. Eggs great. Potatoes were amazing. Crispy and perfect. 

Everyone should try this place at least once! Then you can decide if it's worth it enough to wait in line again.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Such a simple and homey brunch place on Potrero Hill! I can definitely see why lines are out the door (even on a weekday) for The Plow! Parking is readily available right outside the restaurant, and it's free for up to two hours. 

I have been to The Plow twice, and I definitely had a better experience the second time. I ordered the plow breakfast, which came with 2 eggs, 2 ricotta pancakes, potatoes, and breakfast meats--pretty much everything you'll ever want or need in the morning. For breakfast meats, I would highly recommend their homemade pork sausage; I chose the chicken apple sausage the first time, and it definitely wasn't as good. The ricotta pancakes were fluffy and the potatoes were super crispy. 

Be aware that this place has crazy lines, and they don't take reservations! We went on a weekday at around 10:30am for 2 people and there was already a 20 minute wait.
author: Sandra S.

description:
My friend and I knew that the wait would take awhile judging from the crowd of people chilling near the entrance. We arrived at 1:15pm, and got seated at 2pm. Luckily, there was a coffee shop a few stores down which was very convenient for us to get a coffee while we wait.

We had outdoor seating which wasn't bad at all since it was sunny. Since I couldn't choose between salty or sweet, I ordered the plow which gives you the best of both worlds (lemon ricotta pancakes, choice of meat, choice of eggs, and potatoes). You get your choice of eggs and meat so I went with scrambled eggs and pork sausage. The scrambled eggs and ricotta pancake were both very light and fluffy, the pork sausages were decent, and the potatoes were straight up delicious. A combo of food put into one delicious dish.

The servers are really attentive and your glass of water will never be empty. The friendly servers were a big plus on a Sunday afternoon to finish off my weekend.

I can't wait to explore the other items on the menu next time!
author: Julian Y.

description:
Long wait but delicious! Shared a combination plate called "The Plow" and an order of their seasonal french toast (peaches), and it was definitely a good amount of food. I really like their potatoes! I don't know what they do to it, but it was sooo delicious! I don't usually choose potatoes as the highlight of a dish but for this sampler plate, the potatoes definitely were my favorite part. The lemon ricotta pancakes were also delicious. 

We sat at the outdoor seats, which was fine on a nice day but I would definitely bundle up or dress in layers since SF weather is sometimes unpredictable. It wasn't difficult to flag a server down. Everyone was very friendly!

Would definitely come back to try the rest of the menu or to just order the Plow again. Definitely thinking about the potatoes again...
author: Sara T.

description:
Oh, Plow... how I waited and waited and waited and wanted so badly to love you. My friends and I came around 10:30am on a Saturday as a party of 5 and waited WAY OVER 2 hours. We were quoted 1.5 hours - 2 hours and called pretty frequently to check in on our table. 

This is the part that irks me the most about my experience.. at one point maybe 1.5 hours in, they told us to come back in 15 minutes. We came back in around 10 minutes and they told us "oh sorry, we just gave your table away". Sorry, but WHAT???? You would think that a place this popular can figure out their reservations and their waiting system but NOPE. So if you come here, you better just wait right outside the restaurant....... They call your name once or twice and if you're not there they just skip right over you even if they tell you to come back at a certain time. Truly unlike anything else I've ever experienced before, but maybe I'm spoiled after being in Chicago and NY for a while now as they have their lines and reservation systems all figured out..

Service was good from one person, but rude from another. Honestly, at this point I was pretty hangry though. So maybe the service wasn't THAT bad, it just came across as horribly rude when we asked for more water and were ignored. Also the host just wasn't pleasant to my party at all. 

Ordered the Plow which comes with two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes, and your choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I got the chicken apple sauage which I really liked and the plow potatoes are SOOOO good. The lemon ricotta pancakes were also SOOOOOO good. (But was it because I was starving after waiting close to 2.5 hours for a table and the food?) 

I would come back, but I would never wait more than 30 minutes for the food. 3 stars because this restaurant needs to work on their service and their queue, but the food is pretty good.

TL;DR: Wait outside the restaurant otherwise your table will be given away and you'll wait outside forever and be even more starving than you already were.

Also their place is tiny, so if you want to get seated as quickly as possible then come by yourself or with one other person. They have like one or two tables that can accommodate parties over 4 people.
author: Carol L.

description:
This place is one of my favorite brunch places in the city! However, it must be on the list of every one else too as the wait here is ridic and I can't do it any longer. I can't wait over 1 hour for those lemon ricotta pancakes and home made pork sausages no matter how delicious they are and how harmoniously they go together.

How do you eat at Plow and not agonizingly have to wait for grub on a weekend? Start waiting in line before they open. I unexpectedly had to work a graveyard shift and would miraculously be in the city semi-awake at 7am on a Saturday so to Plow we went. They don't open until 8am on the weekends (Yelp hours were wrong) so we walked over to Farley's a half block away to get some caffeine and lined up around 7:40 am and managed to get in on the first seating. If you come at 8am, I think that might be too late.

The Plow was just as yummy as I remembered. Their pastry apple bread was solid and a nice prelude to our breakfast. Unfortunately I always get the same thing when I come here so I can't speak for much of the rest of the menu.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
"The Plow" is the obvious go-to brunch meal. A hearty plate filled with two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, choice of protein (I chose pork sausage patties), and eggs! Everything was delicious and service was quick and attentive. 

We waited for two hours and I honestly wouldn't wait again. Looking at the menu it doesn't look like anything else was enticing either. Also sitting at the counter there was this pungent smell that was bothersome.

Luckily we had a pre-snack before eating here so if I was really hangry this rating would've been lower lol.

In concloosh- if you can avoid a long wait time, come here and order The Plow!
author: Catherine T.

description:
I had the best pancakes I've ever had here: the lemon ricotta pancake is one of a kind and perfect. Get the Plow platter if you're not vegetarian, you can also just get it as a side. I'm still dreaming about how good these pancakes were- not too sweet at all, just like the other reviews noted. 

I had the breakfast sandwich with avocado and potatoes. The potatoes are also delicious!! No wonder this place usually has an incredibly long line. We were really lucky with seating and were seated right away. Definitely don't go with a big group! 

Would love to come here again.
author: Ayumi W.

description:
I went here for brunch with my friend on a Saturday morning at around 10:30 am. We had heard a lot of hype about this place so we decided to check it out. We were quoted a 1 hour and 30 minute wait time, but we ended up waiting about an hour. I would not come here super hungry (maybe grab a coffee while waiting). 

We both got The Plow ($17.50)- which basically comes with a little bit of everything! The potatoes were SO SO good and perfectly seasoned and crispy. The lemon ricotta pancakes....they were incredibly fluffy and just the right amount of sweet to balance out the savory aspects of the dish. The eggs and apple sausage were also good. I do wish they added a couple more sausages to finish off the dish. 

We also got the Buttermilk Biscuit ($5) while we were waiting for our main dishes, which was a bit dry but the the honey butter helped. 

Overall, I would come here again, but maybe on a weekday when it's not as busy.
author: April L.

description:
You must make Plow a staple brunch spot while visiting SF . After researching reviews we decided on going to Plow for breakfast as I read great reviews and also heard they had the "best potatoes " in the city . The reviews were all spot on .
I dined here on a Tuesday around 9:30am in Oct and while the place was small and packed we managed to sit down right away outside but there was also counter seating where you can watch the Chefs perform their magic . 

I order the "Plow Breakfast " which came with the lemon ricotta pancakes , organic fresh eggs cooked to order , Plow potatoes and choice of bacon , house made pork sausage patties or apple sausage. I opted for the house made pork sausage patties and they were great . If I would of changed anything about them o would of made them a little more seasoned . 

The pancakes were light but flavorful and a nice lemon touch but not over the top. They were a nice size .The maple syrup was authentic and complemented the pancakes nicely . They also had pumpkin pancakes as a choice as well . 
We enjoyed one of the home made biscuits with butter ($5) . You can tell they are made with love and from scratch . 

The highlight of the entire breakfast were the potatoes though . They were perfectly seasoned , crispy and crunchy on the outside and light on the inside . I never quite had breakfast potatoes like this but I can see why people line up for this country style breakfast spot. Hey there early though because around 10 or so when we were leaving there was a line starting to form .

The staff here was very friendly , patient and accommodating . I even saw one of the waitresses bring a table a ricotta pancake on the house just because they had ordered pumpkin pancakes . Food was fresh , hot and fairly quick to arrive . The meal was quite filling and I left a very satisfied customer .
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
My friend and I came in for brunch on a sunday ~ 12, and I expected a wait and while we were told 2 hours initially, but it only ended up being 40 minutes. So be prepared to wait, it's definitely worth it!
The space isn't too large, there aren't that many tables which makes me understand why the wait can be super long. But, there is a long wait for a reason - this place is phenomenal! I got the fried egg sandwich which came with potatoes and It tasted incredible, and my friend loved his prosciutto toast as well. The service here is good, the foods amazing and the people who work here are really sweet, so i'd highly recommend this place!
author: Noor H.

description:
IT'S SO WORTH IT.  Do not doubt, believe and be blessed!  Got here at 8:30am on a Sunday and there was already an hour wait.  We went to a neighboring cafe for some coffee while we waited, but the large mug of black coffee on an empty stomach set me up with raging anxiety and nausea by the time we got back (woohoo! Adventure...)

Even with all the shenanigans besetting my poor bod, this meal is by far the best brunch I've had in a looong time.  I ordered **The Plow ** ($17.50), recommended to me by my breakfast bud as a sampling of Plow's hit items.  Eggs, choice of meat (I had chicken apple sausage), crispy potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes.  Sounds standard, but oh my god - they are out of this world.

I identify as a huge tater lover, and I was still intrigued by this hype over their potatoes.  Best way to describe it: you know the crispy skin on peking duck?  These potatoes had that kind of delicate crisp to them!  HNGH.  Nom nom.

Their lemon ricotta pancakes are smol, light, and fluffy -- finally, a pancake that doesn't weigh you down!  The sausages were v flavorful and juicy, but not at all greasy - *praise*.  Best of all the parts were so well proportioned to each other!  AMAZING.

Keep in mind I felt all these lovey dovey things towards the food while having an anxiety-crippled appetite, so the food really is THAT good. @Plow, TAKE MY MONEY.  I'll be back.  And you should try waiting for and eventually eating at this place too :3
author: Joyce C.

description:
This review is for the dish, THE PLOW. Wow easily hands down in the top 3 brunch dishes I've had in the city.

The potatoes are the best. If you don't order the plow but another dish you can order the potatoes on the side.

You can choose your egg option (scrambled, poached, etc etc), meat options include bacon, house made pork sausage, chicken apple sausage.

I went with scrambled eggs and pork sausage. I did not regret it one bit.... it was delicious. Standard are the potatoes and ricotta pancakes... which are sooo fluffy, soft and good.

The plow was perfect for me, someone who couldn't decide if they wanted eggs, meat, pancakes or potatoes for brunch- I could have them all!!

Parking isn't a problem but THE LINE. It's normally a 2 hour wait so come and put your name down and come back...

Outdoor seating is limited for those with dogs, which can have you waiting longer for an outside table than inside table since most folks prefer either and they do first come first serve.

Service is friendly and it's sort  of cool to be able to sit at the counter and watch all the cooks bust out 10 orders of THE PLOW all at once!
author: Karen H.

description:
TIP: There will be a long wait FYI. I recommend going early, putting your name is and walking around to the coffee shops and book store. There is only about 3 blocks of shops, but it is really cute. You can get mimosas while you wait though!

Vibes (5/5): located in an adorable part of town, Plow has outdoor and indoor seating and a great vibe. Biggest reason for coming. 

Food (4.5/5): the food was great, but nothing special. We got the plow and the bfast sandwich. I like the bfast sandwich more. I will say the lemon pancakes were a standout. Very tasty. 

Service (4/5): it was good, nothing standout. 

Would I do back? Yesssssss. I just love the area and this place. 

Ranking for my notes, not for the stars. 
5- Amazing, top of the line- standout 
4- Very good
3- Not good
2- Horrible
1- Very bad
author: Tina L.

description:
Another solid spot for brunch in SF, as long as you're willing to wait. Food is 5 stars but I'm taking away one star for the perpetually long wait.

I've tried to come once before, but when we were told the wait would be around 1.5 hours, my friend and I bounced and ate at a place nearby with a much shorter wait. One year later, I decide to challenge the wait at Plow again.

My friend came around 10:15 on a Saturday to put her name down and was told to check back in 2 hours or so. When the three of us came back around noon, they had already called our name but bumped us to the top of the list. We were seated shortly after that.

I can see why they have such a long wait; it's a small space with seating for maybe 30 people? Definitely don't recommend coming here with a big group.

As a first timer, I knew I had to get their namesake dish: The Plow ($17.50). It comes with two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, Plow potatoes, and your choice of pork sausage, bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I don't know why more brunch places don't offer this, but it's the person brunch platter for people who prefer mostly savory dishes with a small bit of sweet on the side.

I've heard such good things about their lemon ricotta pancakes, so I knew I *had* to try them out. Almost everything was perfect about this platter: the eggs were perfectly scrambled, the potatoes were roasted just right, and OMG THE PANCAKES. They were so light with a nice lemon flavor that wasn't overpowering. The pancakes themselves aren't too sweet so you can control the sweetness with the syrup. The Plow platter comes with two mini pancakes, but I might need to order a whole side of these to myself next time! My only complaint was that the pork sausage wasn't that great.

It was so nice to come here with my girlfriends and catch up on life. So glad I finally got to check this place out, and I will be back!
author: Dianna H.

description:
After hearing about this place for years as a not-to-miss SF brunch experience, my curiosity of their "amazing" potatoes overcame my weariness of SF lines. There were over 20 tables ahead of me when I put my name down but luckily not everyone is as willing to wait and we were seated after about 45 minutes of waiting. We ordered the Plow, which comes with chicken sausage/homemade sausage patty, eggs, breakfast potatoes and....lemon ricotta pancakes. I will try the homemade sausage patty next time since the chicken apple sausage was fairly ordinary. I will come back to this place just for the lemon ricotta pancakes and breakfast potatoes. Though the pancakes are small, they're just lovely - fragrant and fluffy with a little bit of crispy edge. The breakfast potatoes are amazing - the seasoning is spicy and earthy and they're crunchy on the outside and tender on the inside.

I really enjoyed the smoked salmon eggs benedict - the eggs were perfectly poached and the hollandaise sauce was creamy but not overly heavy. I also appreciated that they toasted the english muffin so the muffin didn't dissolve to mush as we broke open the egg yolk. I was tempted to lick the plate. One interesting thing was that I tasted the vinegar flavour from the cooked egg, which my boyfriend didn't notice so I'm curious if that was a one-off experience.
author: Aileen C.

description:
In the wise words of one Oprah Winfrey....Yeeeeees! Potrero Hill strikes again!(Oprah didn't make the strikes again reference...that's all me) And to think I almost skipped this one. Breakfast at Plow is bomb.com

These guys are not inventing the wheel here, but there is something to be said about the finest execution of fresh ingredients. 

FOOD

Breakfast sandwich - the perfect example of simple but great. I can eat this for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. A sandwich featuring eggs, avocado, cheese, bacon, and frisée. The acme bun absolutely puts this over the top. Actually I've never heard of acme before this, but it seems identical to a brioche. Is there a better sandwich bread than a soft warm brioche? No....no there is not my friend.

Lemon ricotta pancakes - I've had this version a few places before this, but non have I enjoyed more. In my previous experience, they tend to be heavy on the ricotta and light on the lemon. There's no hiding the lemon here! Plow has achieved the perfect balance. These melt in your mouth pancakes are perfection.

Plow potatoes - get.this.NOW! This is the potato mountaintop. If these are not the best breakfast potatoes you've ever had, I would really appreciate it if you would inbox me the name of one better. That's like finding out there's a second heaven! 

I swear there's something in the air in this neighborhood. Another one of my breakfast favs, which shall remain unnamed, just so happens to be a few blocks away. Plow is an instant catapult into my go to places. Already plotting my return....
author: Donald S.

description:
Finalllly tried Plow and it is a solid 3.5 stars from me! I came for a Monday brunch at 12 pm and there was a 45 minute wait for a party of 3. Parties of 2 definitely get seated faster than parties of 3-4.

I ordered the plow, which comes with eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, rosemary potatoes, and your choice of chicken apple sausage or pork sausage patties (but you already knew that) for $17. I was pleasantly surprised with the lemon ricotta pancakes and the potatoes! I fell in love with both of those. The lemon ricotta pancakes were so creamy with a hint of lemon, and the potatoes were super crunchy and had the perfect amount of seasoning. I never finish my potatoes bc they are so filling, but I almost finished these! The thing I was most disappointed in was the meat... I ordered the pork sausage patties after seeing many yelp photos and I was sad to bite into a dry, flavorless sausage patty! :( Maybe next time i'll try the chicken apple sausage. I also thought the price point was a little high, but hey, we're in San Francisco so anything goes!
author: Tara A.

description:
I legit think I could write a million 5 star reviews about Plow and it's quality of food. No joke. 

Yesterday was no exception to my other 5 star reviews as it continues to be my favorite plate of brunch food in all the land. If you don't know what I'm talking about, it's called "the plow". Just order it, no further explanation needed. 

The sleeper item on the menu has to be the biscuit. It's flaky, full of butter and just heavenly. 

Be prepared to wait but, wait you will. Otherwise you're a damn fool.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
I sat at the bar for brunch and like that you can watch them cook.

Of course the wait was long. I believe I waited just under an hour since it was a little less crowded during Christmas weekend.

I got the plow so I can have my mix of savory and sweet. The savory items were fine. Nothing special... pretty much things you can find anywhere. About the lemon ricotta pancakes, I love lemon ricotta desserts/pancakes in general. I found these kind of a letdown. The hype isn't real in my opinion, but I seem to be the outlier.
author: Sophia L.

description:
The wait here can be quite long, especially if you come close to noon. It was nearly 2 hours for my table on a Sunday at ~11:30AM. That being said, the food is quite good, but I don't think it's worth the wait.

I had "The Plow" with a biscuit with honey butter to start. The biscuit was delicious, it was warm and soft on the inside, and had a crisp crunchiness on the outside. The honey butter tasted amazing went with the biscuit so well.

I had the Plow with over-easy eggs, and pork sausage. The pork sausage was well made and quite delicious, and a little overflow syrup from the pancakes adds a nice touch. The potatoes were probably my favorite, being nice and crispy and flavorful, and the hot sauce is quite good here as well!

The ricotta pancakes were decent, I think they are better at Kitchen Story which has a smoother and richer taste to them; it's a bit lighter here though I did enjoy the lemon flavor. The eggs were solidly made.

Overall a great brunch place if there was no line, but that line makes it too difficult to be worth it.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Plow - cute spot, if you go early the wait is only 20-30 minutes usually (before 10 am). The food is 4.5 stars, service is 3.5ish which makes it 4 stars for me.

They will only seat you if your party is completely there and will then give your table to someone else and then it seems like they bump you to the bottom of the list even if your party is complete after that? Anyway, it was weird and the hostess would say we had to wait cause our party wasn't complete which I understand but she would say it over and over again which kind of seemed like she was annoyed with it or was rubbing it in.

We were seated in the back and no one really came to check on us which was fine, but a little strange to me cause that isn't really how most restaurants function.

I like the space and open kitchen concept. Light and full of windows. It can get a little loud though. 

I ordered the prosciutto and gruyere toast which was delicious - it came with some greens and an egg on top and potatoes on the side. The chorizo scramble flavors were great, but the corn tortillas were just generic and plain  and the black beans had no flavor whatsoever. The French toast was amazing - custard-y and the cream on top was amazing. Their biscuits with honey butter are to die for. Get it. 

Overall - food is good, service is ok. Would come again if I'm the area.
author: Cindy L.

description:
I came here with high expectations. I really, really wanted to like it after hearing and reading such glowing reviews. But that may have been my mistake.

Scene: Saturday morning. We put our name down for a table for 4 at 9:30am. We then wandered around, let the dog play at a park ~5 blocks away, grabbed a latte, chit chatted. It felt like we'd had an entire day by the time we got seated just before 11. We are seated outside, so I put my pup under the table - was grateful that was an option, though she would have been just as happy to nap in the car while we ate. I also liked that they had blankets for the chairs outside, incase it got too chilly.

I ordered the prosciutto avocado toast, and swapped out my side of potatoes for more avocados. Yes, I am that extra. The avocado toast was no better than something I could have thrown together myself for less than what I paid here, though I will say they were generous with the avocado. I was disappointed because there was nothing particularly special about the flavor or combination of items on the plate. We also got an order of pancakes for the table. These were dismal - small and dry. Do yourself a favor and drive over to Griddle Fresh for some actual ricotta pancakes before praising these.

Yes, I knew there would be a long wait. No, I did not expect to be an exception to the rule. However, I did expect the food to be worth the wait, and here is where it fell short of expectations. Sorry to say I won't be back, but that probably works out better for all the other people who are willing to line up here to get in on the hype.
author: Melinda W.

description: I tried the lemon and house made ricotta pancakes at Plow. If anyone visits the San Fran area, stop by and get their signature dish--"the plow"--and don't forget the chicken apple sausage and a mimosa!  I gave them a four star rating because my party of six waited over an hour to be seated. This is probably due to the small space the restaurant is in.
author: Josh A.

description:
Wanted to update my review since I now came here with a child. So we got there at 7:55AM on a Sunday morning; Line was already 1/4 way up the hill. Got in line, thinking we had a good shot of not having to wait too long. I was wrong unfortunately. Started seating folks at 8AM - heads up - they are SLOW to seat people. It was another 10 minutes before it got to us and the inside tables were full but she said outside, there's no wait. So I say ok we'll sit outside. But then a big HAHA moment came, when she said they weren't seating outside for another 15 minutes to let the servers catch up with the inside rush. UGH so I say ok fine. 20 minutes go by, granted I have a 1.5 year old with me who was pretty patient, shocking I know. I go back in and ask how much longer, she says few more minutes, that's when I say, I need a definitive answer so that I can decide whether or not to leave. I got seated 3 minutes later.

The hostess part wasn't a great experience BUT our server was incredible. I didn't have to say anything, she just knew me being with a toddler that this was going to have to be a quick meal before he starts getting stir crazy and I was alone with him and she was on the ball with getting our order, serving food, and checking back with us to get the check squared away. It took 30 minutes from the moment we sat down to when we left.

The biscuit is toddler approved. My kid is still young and hasn't been exposed to a lot of sugar so the honey butter wasn't a win for him. That's ok, he'll learn how good it is later in life. 

The eggs Benedict - my poached eggs were barely runny. There was a tiny bit of a run but most of the yolk had gotten cooked. I am insanely picky when it comes to how poached eggs should be cooked, and the yolk should be completely runny for me so I wasn't thrilled about this but the rest of it was delicious so it's ok. I would've done 2 or 3 star review for this fact alone but I did love our server so much that I give them 4 stars. Plus I've been here before and it was so good that I give them the benefit of the doubt. I probably won't get eggs Benedict next time. I'll stick with the pancakes.
author: Lisa D.

description:
I'm really not sure what the hoopla was about because this place is O.K. Like, there was nothing special about it.

I went for a farewell brunch for our fantastic summer intern. Plow does not take reservations so two people went early to get our name and larger party in for a table. It took about twenty minutes which is wonderful for a table of six of you ask me.

We had heard that we should get their biscuits with honey butter so we ordered three biscuits to split amongst our group. They came and were warm. But yo....they were dense AF. Like, I was curious if it was a brick or a biscuit. It needed all the butter.

I opted for the breakfast sandwich. It was not great. It was quite bland. My potatoes were clearly ones from the bottom as they were mostly scraps and wayyyyy overcooked.

The one thing that was delicious were the lemon ricotta pancakes. Now those were awesome. They were fluffy, light, and not too sweet. I was quite impressed.

Overall, I'm not sold on the hype for Plow and wouldn't say don't go there but it wouldn't be an enthusiastic "eat there" from me.
author: Sierra R.

description:
Absolutely delicious. This was my first time here and because it is a Thursday and I went at 8am, it wasn't busy at all. I was told by a friend that there is usually a line out the door, and I'm not surprised. 

The general atmosphere fits perfectly with the farm to table vibe, it feels relaxed and familiar. The servers were super friendly and nice. It reminded me of going to a hip friends house for breakfast. I sat at the breakfast bar and was able to see the kitchen staff preparing food, which also gave the sense of cleanliness because I could see any missteps made. 

The food was delicious, it all tasted homemade and fresh. The eggs were creamy and moist. The potatoes had a crisp to them that made me keep going back for me. The pork sausage was slightly spicy, which I am not a fan of, but I was able to try my friend's chicken sausage which had a maple syrup aftertaste to them which was just delicious. I ordered the plow, which is two eggs, potatoes, meat and two of their lemon ricotta pancakes. Boy oh boy, those pancakes stole the entire show. They melted in your mouth with twangs of lemon and notes of sweet, melt-in-your-mouth savory flavors which I can only assume is the ricotta. Combined with the syrup served on the side and a small pat of butter on top, it was heavenly. 

I would absolutely check this place out again and suggest you do the same.
author: Emily R.

description:
(3.5 stars) I wasn't exactly blown away by Plow. Sure it's enjoyable and really beautiful to dine in with high ceilings and lots of natural light, but especially given the wait, the hype, and the price, it left me wanting a bit more. 

I went with the plow because it has their name on it and I couldn't decide what to go so as mine as we'll try a bit of everything. Yes the potatoes are dope, the crispness and the seasoning are lovely, but it loses its flair after a few of them. It could use a nice a nice homemade sauce: I asked and they have a garlic aioli which is a solid option. The house made sausage is super juicy and tender, but not the most exciting flavors. The pancakes are super fluffy and if lemon ricotta is your thing, then you'll love them. They were a bit overpowering for me, but thankfully the maple syrup helped balance it out a bit. The plow is all the standard breakfast fare just somewhat better than most other spots.
author: Jason S.

description:
Plow's notoriously long wait coupled with their slow af service makes me not want to come here again.

I ordered the Plow which consists of two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, two eggs, and your choice or bacon/sausage. It's essentially a sampler.
It was admittedly pretty good. I especially enjoyed the flavorful, buttery pancakes and the runny eggs. The potatoes were very well seasoned and the sausage was also delicious. They do their basics pretty well, but I kept biting into something hard with the potatoes.

My friend ordered the Vietnamese pork chop and it was absolutely terrible. I don't know if the chef just messed up but it was so overly salty we could not eat it. I'm pretty sure it was a mishap though because there's no way they'd still be in business delivering this kind of food.

The service isn't good either as there is very limited seating, so you have to wait a looooong time. Additionally, it takes forever to get your food. Set aside a really long dining time slot if you wanna eat here.

Price is 2/5
Food is 3/5
Wait is 2/5
Service is 2/5
author: Alicia L.

description:
I enjoyed the custard French toast and a side of sausage. It was incredible! The french toast with the vanilla mascarpone cream was so good I made another order to-go (and enjoyed the next day).

I cannot complain about a line, as I got there at 7:04 in the morning. When I left around 7:35, the place was pretty full so I will say: Get there early and prepare to eat amazing food!
author: Ricky W.

description:
My all-time favorite brunch place! I take friends from out of town here all the time (if they're here in SF during the week). 

Downside - there's usually a long wait. On the weekends, expect to wait up to 2 hours! On the weekdays, the wait is about 30 minutes. Do I think it's worth it? YES 

If you've never been here, be sure to get the Plow. I usually don't like breakfast foods all that much, but the Plow sure does it for me! With lemon pancakes, sausage (or bacon), eggs done your way, and potatoes, the Plow has everything you could possibly want!

If you want to eat something a bit lower calorie, the chia seed pudding is also good, but not very filling. Get that if you're not hungry and something on the side in addition to that if you are.

There's indoor seating and outdoor seating. If you choose outdoor seating, they also offer warm blankets for you to use. The staff here (in my experience) are very kind and friendly. I will definitely be back!
author: Kaitlynn L.

description:
I heard so much about this place and was excited to go. I was told the wait would be a little over an hour but it ended up being about an 100 minutes - yes that's right - the length of an average film.

After all that wait, we were seated at the bar - I didn't mind since I was starving by this time. We ordered the food and there was a HAIR in our BISCUIT. Yes a hair. The server took it back and seemed frustrated. She brought us another and offered a brisk and ingenuine apology. The biscuit was NOT COMPED, considering it had a hair in it, we should have at least not have had to pay for it.

Overall the people working there don't have a good sense of hygiene. One of the cooks was eating, another used his cell phone on the board where he was plating dishes.

P.S. The only reason this place gets two stars instead of one, is because the food actually tastes good.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Finally got to try Plow! I came in around 8:40 on a weekday and was seated immediately, which was lucky. The interior is so small, I can definitely see why the wait is insane on weekends. 

I was really excited for the famous lemon ricotta pancakes, but surprisingly it was my least favorite thing that I tried; the lemon flavor was good and they were pretty fluffy/soft but still not good enough to justify 3 pancakes for $16 in my opinion. 

By far the standout of the meal was the BUTTERMILK BISCUIT! I love baked goods of all types and I've had more than my fair share of biscuits but this is definitely leagues above any other biscuit I've ever eaten in my life. It's SO flakey and buttery and delicious and pairs AMAZINGLY with the honey butter for an ultra decadent experience. The outer crust is so perfect and the inside is so soft and warm; next time I come to Plow I'm literally just ordering like 5 of these biscuits and calling it a day.

I also tried the prosciutto & gruyere toast which was a solid savory option! The Plow potatoes are delicious, but I wish there was a bit more prosciutto. 

Overall, really solid brunch. Definitely get one (or ten) of the buttermilk biscuits.
author: Melissa H.

description:
Solid 4.5 stars for brunch. 

This place is great for brunch, though the waits can be horrendous. The few times we actually got through the wait we ended up wandering around dogwatch for a couple hours, getting coffee at a nearby coffee shop, browsing the nearby market, walking to the nearby park, and debating whether we should maybe eat somewhere else with a shorter wait (like Aina). We have never regretted holding out though!

My go-to dish is The Plow, which seems to come with all their top hits. The potatoes are some of the best breakfast potatoes I've had - well seasoned - and the sausage, the lemon ricotta pancakes, and the eggs were all amazing!

I forgot what the other dishes are like since I just get the plow for now, but someday I will venture past this dish! Also, please start using yelp waitlist!!! Waiting around dogwatch is so painfully especially at 8am when nothing is open!
author: Michele L.

description:
Plow is a pretty good place to get standard brunch fare. If you come early, the wait is really worth it! 

I've always come at opening time around 8 AM and probably wouldn't wait more than 30 min for it, so I highly recommend coming early. 

The menu consists of options like Soft Scrambled Eggs, Sausage & Eggs, Eggs Benedict, etc. It seems like the more popular dishes are the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and The Plow.

The Plow ($17.5) - Two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes with choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I ended up getting the Annie's Almond Flour Pancakes since it was GF which tasted great! The chicken apple sausage was also pretty good too. I had a side of fruit which cost a little more, but also tried the potatoes and they were really delicious

Plow stands out because of it's simple, yet delicious and quality ingredients. It does run on the expensive side though.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Came here on a Sunday morning with 4 friends- had roughly an hour wait but there are cute shops nearby to peruse while waiting. The food was incredible- everyone at my table ordered "The Plow" - lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes (highlight of the meal!!), eggs, and choice of meat. I subbed my pancakes for the seasonal pumpkin spice pancakes.

Beautiful atmosphere, incredible food, and lovely service. Will definitely be back here anytime I'm back in SF!
author: Hannah O.

description:
I came to Plow on a Saturday around 10am to an already healthy sized line outside. I put my name down for a party of 2 and was told it would be an hour or an hour and a half. I will say that if my friend didn't live around the corner I would've moved onto the next place. We came back an hour later and like clockwork it was our turn to be seated. 

We started with the homemade biscuit with honey butter and HOLY SWEET BABY JESUS IT WAS BOMBBBB! Flakely yet dense and buttery. The honey butter took it to the next level! You have GOT to order the biscuit! I wish i took a picture but I couldn't wait. 


I ordered the corned beef hash and my incredibly good looking friend ordered the prosciutto & gruyere toast. Overall I would say that the hash was good but it wasn't great, it needed more seasoning and the house hot sauce just didn't do the trick for me. I also found the poached eggs to be over cooked but i'm an animal and that doesn't concern me much but I will call that out for all the egg groupies out there. 

As for the prosciutto & gruyere toast my friend enjoyed it but he thought that the prosciutto got a bit too warm towards the end of his meal but overall he liked it. I will say the potatoes that came with his meal were bomb af too! Crispy on the outside but soft in the middle and they were really well seasoned! 

But forreal....GET THE BISCUIT!
author: Danielle D.

description: I went for à la carte options of poached eggs (almost perfect), pork sausage (perfect) and their burnt toast with condensed milk. 5*s especially for service and the burnt toast. Sitting at the counter is perfect for those dining solo (often, me...); the vibe is happy and the kitchen feel is honest/open.
author: Camille L.

description:
The first thing I will say is be prepared for a long wait. We went in Sunday (aka brunch day) so the 90 minute wait wasn't a surprise. Based on the glowing meal reviews seemed like it would be worth it. The place itself is small, but very nice. The staff is very pleasant and attentive. I gave three stars because the food is average. The house made sausage was a bit bland, the lemon ricotta pancakes were okay, and the eggs were simply eggs. I will say the potatoes are pretty good. Also, the fresh squeezed orange juice was perfection!

All in all, an okay brunch location. If I were with someone who suggested Plow as the brunch spot I wouldn't object; however, it would not be on my list of suggestions if I were to pick the location.
author: Shannon G.

description: Yes, the wait on weekends is long, but the outstanding flavors of the food made it worth it. Perfection can be achieved in scrambled eggs, and it was here. Unique smokehouse flavor in the bacon, home fries with a nice subtle addition of rosemary, and unbelievably good lemon ricotta pancakes. Coffee on point too. Two thumbs way up. But - be vigilant on that wait list: we almost got passed up and we were literally standing right there.
author: Adrian C.

description: I ordered the fried egg sandwich and the plow with chicken apple sausage. Potatoes were nicely crispy on the outside, egg was perfectly fried, bacon was cooked just right, orange juice was small but refreshing, and pancakes were fluffy! I was satisfied with my meal, and it made the two hour wait worth it! I also feel that over the years, their recipes have improved and portions are not as big as they used to be, which is what I prefer.
author: Andrea T.

description: I dream of these breakfast potatoes!! This cute little corner brunch spot is always poppin and servin dishes that just make your mouth water at first sight. I love this cafe's aesthetic, workers, and efficiency. The wait is long.... so either get there super early, super late, or bring a thick jacket to suck it up and eat on their outside seating. 10/10 recommend the pumpkin banana bread to get those taste buds going. When in doubt, plow it out
author: Lily H.

description:
Pro tip: if you come here for brunch on a weekend be prepared to wait 1-2 hrs. Bring a coat because it's SF weather and you'll freeze waiting outside (the sun shines on the opposite side of the street) and so you can opt to eat outside and expedite your wait time. 

If you love breakfast potatoes this quite possibly may be the best in town. The potatoes here are roasted and I'm guessing flash fried to create an extra crispy texture. 

I would highly recommend the Plow ($17) where you are able to experience this savory delight w/ bacon (also fried super well), your choice of eggs and sweeten your taste buds with the lemon ricotta pancakes. These pancakes live up to its hype and is worth getting. They have a strong lemon taste and are extra fluffy. 

We also got the French roast and I WOULD NOT recommend this dish. The French toast wasn't sweet, it was soggy in all the bad ways and the stuffing inside of it was bland. Even when we tried to drench the French toast in maple syrup it did not taste good. If you're looking for something sweet stick to the lemon ricotta pancakes.
author: Christina G.

description:
When I'm looking for breakfast during the week, I immediately think of Plow.  I give up going on the weekends as I just can't wait or find parking.  Luckily, I almost always get a seat quickly when I go during the middle of the week.  

My favorites are the lemon ricotta pancakes and their homemade sausage.  They definitely do well when it comes to getting your carbs in.  Oh and their potatoes!  Absolutely fried to perfection.  

On my last visit, I was especially impressed with their service.  The host saw that I had a cane and was nice enough to ask if I would want to sit at the counter on a stool or wait a little longer to sit at a table so I would be more comfortable.  That really was so thoughtful!  

If you're like me, sit at the counter and watch the magic of the cooks in front of you.  I love seeing them work and also love to see the other menu items made.  Makes me want to order the entire menu.

This is the comfort breakfast place you always wanted.  Go now!
author: Maria S.

description:
So... are YOU ready to plow into some total and utter goodness?! Get them forks and and knives ready people! On your mark... geeeeeet set... aaaand PLOOOW!

Ugh. You know, I don't often put on the stank face. But THIS meal that I had at Plow... yeah, that made me do it. Food was so damn good that I had to put on my stanky face. Like ooooh mah GAAAAWD! Why oh WHYYY was this food just so flippin' GOOD?! Mm, mm, mm! I couldn't tell ya... Naw, naw, naaaaw... now wait. I CAN tell you, and I will. 

First things first; YOU my dear... you need to wait. Yep. Just do it. Keep yourself occupied with the Yelp to make the time go by faster. I'll tell you a little secret though... if you come solo, you won't have to wait as long. I know people don't really like to dine by themselves, but if time is a major issue, then this is a major option. If you don't wanna do that, you'll be looking at wait times of up to 2 hours long! But don't fret... that's what your waiting buddy is for, right? It's worth it. It IS... WORTH... the WAIT! 

So, now you've finally been sat and you're wondering what to get? Welp, their entire menu looks exceptionally good. BUT... if it's your first time dining here... PLOW! Get the PLOW BREAKFAST PLATE! Like... don't even think twice about it. Just say "plow" and hand your server the menu so that those chefs can get to makin' some real magic in that kitchen! But why, you ask? Because it's their signature dish and it's damn delicious... DUH! So, shall I elaborate for you? Mmkay... 

On the Plow breakfast plate:

-Lemon ricotta pancakes: GEE-ZUS! Need I say more?! I personally don't even really like pancakes, but I looooved these! Warm, fluffy, buttery, with a delicious lemon ricotta flavor that bursts into your mouth with each bite. 

-Plow potatoes: The most crispiest and delicious stinkin' 'tatoes that you might ever taste in yo' life-ah! YAS! These carbs are just so damn GOOD! Oh yeah, and no salt needed for these babies. Perfectly seasoned. Thank you!

-House made pork sausage: So, you actually have a choice of meat to choose from. But if you're asking ME... I say, get the pork sausage because it's house made and it's just... GOOD! I know, I know. Repetitive, but hopefully you catch my drift. 

-Yummy eggs: I'mma give you a free for all on this one. I like my eggs scrambled and I must admit that they do them well. However, can have your eggs anyway that you'd like.

And, there you have it; the perfect breakfast! On a side note, I'll also mention that their house made lemonade is bombsy! As far as the service goes, it's definitely adequate. It's not bad by any means, but it's nothing over the top. If you frequent busy breakfast spots in the city, you should probably already know not to expect outstanding service... but good service. And good service at an all day busy establishment is good enough for me! Shoutout to that beautiful hostess who was able to squeeze me in at the counter! Appreciate 'cha!

If you remember nothing else from this review, please please pleeease just remember "Plow" as in the breakfast plate. I promise you won't ever forget it after you've had it. Now, go ahead and get ready to plow into that plate of heaven!
author: Shayla B.

description: Havent been here in awhile so decided to have another visit with a friend. We waited over an hour to be seated but we came late and it was weekend brunch, so that was to be expected. I guess my disappointment was with my order. I got my pork chops with poached eggs. The flavor on the pork was good but it was overcooked and a bit tough. My poached eggs might as well have been hard boiled as the yolk was cooked through and there was no delicious runnyness.
author: Rachelle T.

description:
Plow. How I've been wanting to try you!

We went on a weekday so there were no lines. You can sit outside but remember, it's SF so it's gonna be a little chilly!

We ordered the breakfast sandwich and The Plow meal. The breakfast sandwich had an aioli (YUM), cheddar, fried eggs and avocado (extra). This was YUMMY. The bun and the aioli mixed so well with the eggs and frisee. 

The Plow meal comes with pancakes, potatoes, eggs, and sausages. The sausage that is homemade is DELICIOUS. We got so full sharing these two items that I took it home and reheated the foods. The pancakes are delectable and great! I want to try this AGAIN. I definitely want to try this place again! Get their coffee too--this is gooood!
author: Natalie M.

description:
We arrived a little past 10 am on a Saturday and were told the wait was 1.5-2 hours.. ouch! Normally that'd be grounds for us to bounce, but we had two guests with us and were hesitant to take them galavanting around town to another joint, only to have to wait over an hour anyways. That's the reality of Saturday brunch in SF :(

Luckily, the wait was actually just around 1 hour because many others on the waitlist must have bailed. We had been counting on that so were glad it paid off. During the wait, I ordered a mimosa which they charged to our impending table - that helped to tide me over. The food was very good, but not mind-blowing, but then I've never had my mind blown with any brunch place in this country, for reference. The service was also very good, with the waitress knowing without being asked to separate the pancakes from the rest of my meal due to my lactose intolerance. We sat outside and were all provided wool blankets by the host since it was a bit chilly. Overall a great experience, glad we did it. I'm not big on brunch but if there were another occasion (more visitors?) I would definitely consider Plow again, though I might arrive even earlier than 10 next time!
author: J L.

description: The food is fresh and tasty. Everything we ordered was delicious!!! The host (Randall) was so friendly and the servers were quick and attentive. No wonder this place is soooo popular. The owners are doing something right.
author: Arlene M.

description:
BE PREPARED TO WAIT 1-2 HRS!

I just had to come here because everyone in SF talks about this place. This place did not let down. I got the plow dish and it was amazing. Instead getting one of the meats, I got avocado. They were able to do a free vegetarian substitution. The avocado itself was the softest, richest avocado I'd ever had. The plow potatoes amazing, they are seasoned so well. It also comes with lemon ricotta pancakes; they were very interesting and I know there's a lot of hype around it but I wouldn't go crazy. However, the pancakes w/ everything else on the plate was delicious. 
Also, try the strawberry lemonade. They give it to you in a small cup smh but it does taste good.
author: Angela L.

description:
I am pretty sure they lace their breakfast potatoes with crack. Seriously, the best potatoes ever. 

All the food we ordered was amazing. The ricotta pancakes were heavenly, the homemade sausage was so flavorful and delicious, the open faced sandwich with proscuitto and gruyere is to die for, adn the fried chicken sandwich is divine. The service is wonderful. The staff is so friendly, and it is clear that they're happy to be there.

The restaurant is pretty small, so expect a wait. I assure you, it is worth it!
author: Emily C.

description:
So this place has always popped up in conversations with friends, and I happened to try it out for brunch. Luckily the wait was only about 20 min, but since it's a really intimate/homey space I've heard it can be a while. Personally I believe it's worth it! The decor inside is adorable, and everything is accented with this lovely yellow color that complements the Potrero Hill location amongst all the beautiful homes. 

As for the food -- I ordered the Plow -- it comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, potatoes, and I substituted avocado for the meat. I opted for scrambled eggs, which were so fluffy and light. The potatoes were crispy on the outside and smooth, and not overly herb-y. I'm usually put off when there's excessive rosemary on breakfast potatoes. The real star of the show would have to be the pancakes. Which, perfectly lemony and fluffy and creamy all at once, are the reason I will be back.
author: Pooja K.

description:
Heard a lot about this place and was warned about the wait. Unfortunately, I did not wake up early enough and arrived at 11am on Saturday for a brunch. The food was good, but definitely not worth the two hour wait for a party of two. When we arrived, there were about 4-5 parties waiting outside; however, when I put my name down, I was told there was about 1.5 pages of parties ahead of us. We were told to expect a 45min to 1hr wait and decided to just wait outside. The host and hostess had called several parties without any response, so we thought it will probably be quick. After about 45 minutes of waiting and noticing that people arrived after us got seated first. Later, my husband went in and found out that, many of the parties showed up after they were called and placed back on the waitlist in their original orders; therefore, they were being seated before us. I have no problem waiting for good food, but I feel their system flawed. Usually you would have to go to the back of the line if you missed your name, but not at Plow. So, if you want to eat here, drop by and put your name down and return at the time convenient to you. 

After about 1.5hr wait, we were finally seated at the bar right in front of the kitchen area. Not only is their seating system flawed, their waitresses were not efficient either. We were seated for about 10-15 minutes until someone finally came to offer water and coffee, then we were told that she would come back to take our order even though we said we were ready to place our orders. While we were waiting again, we noticed that the kitchen had a lull, since no orders were being placed, and the person putting all the food orders together was looking at his phone. Once the orders started going in, we saw that he did not wash his hands before starting to handle all the food. In addition, while waiting for our waitress, we saw that the hostess went into the kitchen area, reached in the pile of bacon and grabbed one with her bare hands. She went into the door that goes to the back of the kitchen to eat, which is good, and then came out and washed her hands. Maybe it would've been better to wash her hands before touching food that they will serve to customers. 

Finally, despite the long wait for service and slightly disturbed by the kitchen staff's lack of appropriate hand washing we were glad that we got our food because we were very hungry at that point (about 2 hrs since arrival). I ordered the Plow (the most popular dish), my husband ordered the pork chop and eggs. First, the potatoes are very good. It has a hard crispy outside and very soft center. It is also perfectly seasoned with salt, rosemary, grilled onions, and other herbs. The lemon ricotta pancakes were also delicious. They were light and fluffy with a hint of sweetness, it's one of the best pancakes I've had. I wish there were more than just two small ones. I ordered pork sausages and scrambled eggs. The sausages were nothing special, actually tasted a little dry. The scrambled eggs were nicely cooked to a soft scramble. For my husband's order, the pork chop is a decent size, but the marinade was overwhelmed with fish sauce. I understand that the pork chop is Vietnamese style, but all I can taste is fish sauce and nothing else. For his order, he also got scrambled eggs, and it also came with potatoes. 

Overall, I would give the food a four star, I would deduct a star because I don't think the food is good enough to worth that much wait, also for the slow service and poor hygiene.
author: Linda L.

description:
Hostess: ABSOLUTELY ATROCIOUS (negative 5 out of 5)
Service/Waitress: 4/5
Food: 4/5

I used to love Plow, and would wake up at 7am to make it here by 7.40 am so I could be in the first group to be seated--such was my dedication!I haven't been in a while, more because of my reluctance to wake up at 7am on a weekend than anything else, but I visited yesterday (Sunday brunch) and was horribly shocked and disappointed by the hostess/front of house service. My friend stopped by around 9.45am to put our names down, and was given ETA of 90-120 minutes. So far, so good. (Honestly, the food in my opinion isn't worth a 2 hour wait, but np, we were going to commit).

We come back in just over 90 minutes (11.20am) to check on our seat. 25 more minutes the hostess says, back to Farleys (coffee shop) we go. We come back in about 20 minutes (11.40) to check again, and are told by a different (VERY sassy hostess) that we were called and weren't here, and so we'll get the next available table. She said it in a really dismissive way, sounding like she was really blaming us for not being here. That being said, I had to clarify and say, 

Me: "well, we were told 25 minu--"--oops before I can finish, I'm interrupted 
Hostess: "Well, we called YOUR NAME, and you WEREN'T HERE, so. We gave it away. You'll get the next table". 
Me: "How long will that be?", 
Hostess: "About 25 minutes". 
Me: "Another 25 minutes? We were just--" interrupted AGAIN 
Hostess: "WELL, we quoted you 2-2.5 hours, so we are STILL WITHIN OUR TIME RANGE we gave you. OKAY?!", 
me: "But--",  
Hostess: "M'AAM, We are still WITHIN The time we gave you SO." (glares at me, aggressive body language throughout--leaning in, glaring)

I can't capture tone here but she was straight up talking DOWN to me, super rude, interrupting me before I could even complete HALF a sentence--all I wanted to say was "is it actually going to be 25 minutes because if so I'm going to go wait in the coffee shop not stand out here in the frigid SF winds since you have no freaking space for your guests to wait indoors".  Also, you MISQUOTED ME. I didn't even get to open my mouth to tell her they quoted us 120 mins on the upper end, i.e. 2 hours, not 2.5 hours. I understand it can be hard to get an accurate quote, but you should NEVER talk down to anyone like that and insult me by not giving me the opportunity to even finish a sentence. I didn't even raise my voice or tone or anything like that, I simply wanted to know if I should wait here or go back to the coffee shop, because lady, you told me 25 minutes, I'm back in 20 and you tell me it's my fault and you gave away my table and refuse to hear me out? This is after I waited close to 2 hours at this point, LADY. 

Never in my LIFE have I been treated so atrociously and been intimidated like this at an eating establishment in America. I am not kidding she talked down AT me (not TO me) and raised her voice and cut me off repeatedly so I couldn't ask any clarifying questions. Incredibly aggressive body language. What a NASTY experience. There was another lady who was kinder, but she was addressing other people. Also, the food was definitely not fantastic enough to warrant such treatment. It was delicious, but definitely not worth waiting 2 hours, and getting treated like you're a beggar, but paying $17 for a plate of two eggs, potatoes, a bit of sausage, and mini pancakes. Only to be seated out in the cold and told that their blankets are all dirty right now.

---

Dear Plow--obviously quality of food comes first, but seriously, front of house staff are very important as well. Especially if you're having lines of people wait for brunch. Maybe consider employing one of those electronic systems that let's you notify customers via texts? Honestly never have I felt so insulted and intimidated.
author: Su Lin Y.

description:
On the second attempt, the boyfriend and I finally got to try this brunch restaurant called Plow. Why? Not only because it was a suggestion from a local San Franciscan, but my boyfriend finds fun and giddiness in the name itself. Weird. It's all about cows!!

Even on a Friday morning, this place has a wait for the inside, which is warm and cozy and the Christmas spirit is definitely in the air. With an airplane to catch back home, we opted to sit outside with no wait. This wasn't so bad because I do enjoy sitting on a cup of hot tea while enjoying the crisp cold air through my nose and on my face. What better Christmas spirit?

What we didn't know would be waiting for us was a very kind hostess who not only seated us at our table, but also had her hands filled with two warm and cozy blankets for each of us. I looked around. Every single seated customer had one around their shoulders or on their lap. What nice and thoughtful customer service to provide such amenities for the outside! Now I was really glad to sit outside. Just that small thing added to my cold and crisp winter morning.

I enjoyed the warm blanket. It was perfect!!!

So let's get to food??? We didn't order much because it was just us two and we both don't want to feel overstuffed. But what to order when you can only order one? This was easy to decide! It was clear what their signature dish is that all tourists and locals like to order alike ...

the plow - two eggs sunny side up, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes with house made pork sausage.

Now everything on this plate was scrumptious. The eggs were perfectly yolky and freshly made. The patties were hand made from scratch and you can taste all the fresh flavors and hard work into molding these. The potatoes were crispy, crunchy and hot. And now the lemon ricotta pancakes: WERE THE ABSOLUTE BEST! Perfectly fluffy and soft with that great blend of lemon flavors woven within. Not too strong nor tangy, but perfectly sweeet! Now this is what they were known for!

I would definitely come back here. Here for some more lemon ricotta pancakes and maybe try their almond pancakes next!
author: Cuc N.

description:
There's always a long wait especially on weekends (we came on Saturday mornings).  First time we came here, we were told that the wait time is 2 hours.  Since we were hungry, we went to a good french bistro two blocks away.  The second time, we were told that the wait time is 1 hour.  Since we are more determined and have come prepared with a granola for hunger emergencies, we waited it out.  And was surprised that my name was called 30 minutes later (since a lot of people walked away).    

My hubby ordered The Plow with Pork Patties (as we were told that it is their house specialty) that comes with 2 pancakes, their signature fried smashed potatoes, and two eggs.  Hubby said his was okay.  I got the Soft Scramble Eggs that's with shiitake mushrooms, spinanch and goat cheese mixed in the scramble.  It was good! It also comes with the fried smashed potatoes and two toasted bread wedges.  The potatoes are good too!  It was a perfect brunch meal for me!
author: Abby Q.

description:
I had brunch at Plow the other day and it was fantastic. We had to wait a while to be seated (even though it was noon on a Thursday), but once we had a table service was prompt.

I ordered the Two Egg Breakfast, and though there was nothing particularly unique about the food on my plate, everything was delicious (especially the potatoes!!). All of my friends enjoyed their dishes as well, and we shared one of the lemon ricotta pancakes, which was phenomenal. 

I probably wouldn't come here during the weekend, but if you can get in without a super long wait, go for it! (Also, I didn't partake, but I did see people ordering mimosas while they stood outside waiting...just a tip.)
author: Kristin W.

description:
Came here for lunch with a group of 5. The wait around 10am was a solid 2 hours, so be prepared to wait or put your name down and come back. 

The food was really good, although the prices were pretty high. My boyfriend got "the plow" ($17.50), which was two eggs, potatoes, two mini lemon ricotta pancakes, and choice of pork sausage, chicken sausage, and bacon. This was a pretty unique dish, and the pancakes were amazing - fluffy and sweet and lemony. The pork sausage was house made and also very good.

I got the breakfast sandwich, which came with eggs, bacon, and frise on a bun with potatoes ($15.75). It was pretty good but not unique enough to justify the price. It was a good portion though and filled me up. 

Overall food was about 3.75, but not sure if it's worth the wait if the wait is longer than 30-40 min.
author: Amy C.

description:
Food is good (but nothing earth shattering), wait is long (not a big problem as most folks know there will be a wait here), but what I don't have any patience for is the rude hostess that many other reviews mentioned. 

My wife and I went to Plow for a weekday breakfast and the wait was expected to be 30 minutes. No problem, as that's actually not bad, but it was quite cold and I was just parked across the street, so I suggested that my wife sit in the car and I'll wait at the door for our table. When my name was called, I waved my wife over and the hostess made a big stink that "everyone in the party needs to be present" and I explained that that's my wife getting out of the car across the street as she was trying to stay warm. The hostess immediately called another party of 2 and seated them as my wife got to the front door.  I didn't think much of the hostess calling the other party as I assumed there must be more than one open table, but when I showed the hostess that my wife was here, who just walked across the street in the 30 seconds that just elapsed, the hostess said "oh, I just gave away your table. Do you want to sit outside?".  Wow, really?  I just waited 30 minutes for a table and my wife took all of 30 seconds to cross the street and you gave our table away after you saw her walking over?  I don't want to say the words I was thinking at that moment or describe the hand gestures that came to mind as I don't want this review to get banished into the backwaters of yelp, but that hostess is seriously uncool. When I said we didn't want to sit outside at a table that was available the entire 30 mins we were waiting out there, the hostess offered the counter, where we had our breakfast with a bit of bad taste provided by the hostess. 

The good news?  One less restaurant line I'll ever be waiting in (I just hope that hostess never leaves).
author: Bernard H.

description:
My mom and I came here hungry, a bad idea on a Saturday morning with an hour long wait. However, we scored a sweet parking spot and didn't have anywhere to be. So wait we did, and though I probably wouldn't do the wait again, the food was worth it the first time around. 

Service & atmosphere: the place is cozy cute, but honestly I don't remember much of it since I was so starving by the time we sat down. Service was very attentive and quick.

Food: we had the plow with lemon ricotta pancakes and pork sausage plus the breakfast sandwich with bacon and avocado. First off, oh my GOD the lemon ricotta pancakes are not overhyped. Soft, cakey, dense, and not too sweet- they were absolutely the best part of the meal. The sandwich came in next, though I would have appreciated a little more of the aioli and less frisee. Surprise star were the breakfast potatoes that came with both. Crispy, well-seasoned, and just super comforting!

Def come here, preferably not at peak brunch time!
author: Marissa F.

description: Wasn't worth the 45 min wait. The food was lacking in flavor for me. I got the Benedict (ham) and it was pretty bland and disappointing. Not worth the $18. I would rather try some place else.
author: Lulu K.

description: I was really excited to try this place out after reading all the reviews and it did not disappoint. At first, I was afraid to get the Plow because I thought it would be gigantic, but it's definitely a good portion for one person. Everything was great- the house-made sausages, the Plow potatoes, and especially the lemon ricotta pancakes. I would definitely return just for these pancakes! You can definitely taste the lemon flavor and the ricotta and it was even okay to eat without too much syrup. I did find the scrambled egg a little too soft and soggy, though, which I did not like. It felt very undercooked. But other than that, it was a great experience!
author: Navie N.

description:
What is there to say about Plow that has not already been said? Amazing brunch. Expect a wait (go on a weekday if you can squeeze it in). Feast. Drink. Enjoy. 

My fiancé and ordered two delicious dishes (the Plow and the best ever prosciutto toast I've ever had) and nothing was short of amazing.

Agree that service can be a touch slow and it's pricey, but you're in SF so what else would you expect in that arena?
author: Siobhan F.

description: The worst customer service ever!!!! Except for one mexican guy that was so nice!!!! The place is so not worth it. Waiting for more than an hour and when my partner went to check on the parking, they simply didn't give me a table. So many good places in SF to end up at this. Absolutely nothing special about and we got in the trap of a 'new place' . Lesson learned. Never coming back to give my money to people that treat you like that.
author: Lor M.

description:
Definitely worth the hour wait!!! On our last day in San Francisco we discovered plow. After reading the reviews, looking at photos on Instagram, and speaking to locals in the area, we knew this was the place to try. 

Although we had to wait an hour it wasn't that bad because it gave us time to explore the area and go for nice walk. 

We ordered the fried chicken sandwich that comes with potatoes and the classic plate (I believe called the Plow)
with eggs, pancakes, sausages, and potatoes. The pancakes were delicious - we subbed them for almond pancakes and the sausages were great! BUT THE POTATOES!!!!!! Those were hands-down the best potatoes I think I've ever had! They were cooked to perfection and we're perfectly crispy and savory with some onions. 

Let me tell you I've tried a fried chicken sandwich at almost every restaurant and the one at Plow definitely came in under my top 3! It was so delicious had such great flavor

I would definitely come here again the next time I visit San Francisco and highly recommend this to anybody who truly likes a great meal
author: Dani F.

description:
The wait was about 1.5 hr on Saturday late morning.  I don't think the food was worth the wait but the food was still good.  They don't take reservations so you have to stand around and wait for your name to get called.

I got the soft scrambled eggs (no butter or cheese), my boyfriend and his friend both got the chicken rancheros (I forget the exact name of the dish but it was something similar to this), and the last friend had the breakfast sandwich.

My eggs were ok...I know I lost a lot of the flavors from the butter and cheese so my eggs weren't very flavorful.  The plow potatoes were really good though.  The chicken rancheros were good but not amazing.  And the breakfast sandwich was also good.  Our friend said the sandwich would have been better if there was ham or bacon that automatically came with the sandwich...with just the egg as protein, it wasn't super filling.

Service was quick and friendly.  There are bathrooms towards the back of the restaurant.  There was outdoor seating.
author: Kat A.

description:
It's a highly-recommended place to chow for SF Brunch. So many people have told me to check this place out. Just pulling up to it and I could smell something delicious and savory. We were put on the waitlist and walked around a little bit to kill time. 

We were nervous about sitting outside but how nice is it that they provide blankets! That's so unique and thoughtful and definitely appropriate. We overheard the other people around us order the biscuit (which sells out) so we got that + The Plow (with the sausage patties) + Breakfast sandwich. 

Favorite thing I ate during our SF food trip would probably be these biscuits and the Tony's Pizza. They were DELICIOUS. It wasn't dry at all, tasted fresh, and served warm. No wonder the couple next to us each got their own. 

The Plow ($17):
Yummy!! The potatoes are delicious. We asked for them to make it extra crispy which added +10 to taste. Not sure if I loved the sausage, you could really taste the fennel and maybe eating outside made everything too cold for my liking. The Ricotta Pancakes were good because of the actual ricotta you could see scattered in the batter. I also liked how you got to try a little bit of everything they had to offer. 

Breakfast Sandwich:
Arguably better than the Plow. The brioche bread really is a game changer for sandwiches. It had two eggs which was nice when we were trying to split it between the two of us. It was filling even without the additional extras. 

All in all, not sure if the wait would be worth it. The potatoes and biscuits were the highlights for me but I don't know how much I have to be craving it to wait any longer than 30 minutes.
author: Rae A.

description:
Follow the hype and it will lead you to Plow. This place is crowded every day of the week, and for good reason!

FOOD - 5/5
The potatoes are to die for! Fried to a crisp and seasoned with rosemary and plenty of garlic. I could eat these all day! Lemon ricotta pancakes are also delicious. The only thing I haven't been impressed with is the housemade sausage... For some reason it just doesn't taste that great to me.

PRICE - 3/5
$20 per person? Wait, this isn't New York... Oh well. When your brunch game is this strong, you can charge whatever you want!

WAIT - 3/5 on weekdays, 1/5 on weekends
If you're not lined up by 8am on Saturday, don't even bother...

AMBIANCE - 4/5
Nice, clean aesthetic. Love the big windows, which let in plenty of light.

SERVICE - 4/5
Waiters are nice, just busy.

PARKING - 4/5
It's surprisingly easy to find free parking in Dogpatch, add long as you're willing to walk a few blocks.
author: Joe M.

description:
Delicious!

Went for breakfast and we waited about 10 minutes for a single table. The restaurant is small and cozy. The waitress came over right away and took out orders. It seemed like a nice place for people to have chats over food and you could tell most people were regulars. 

We each decided to order the Plow Breakfast because it gave a little of everything from eggs, to crispy potatoes, lemon pancakes and a side of meat. I went with the homemade pork sausage. It didn't have a ton of fat or flavor. Tasted mostly like rosemary and herbs. 

The biscuit we ordered was so good!  With the honey butter it was magical. The coffee was flavorful and hot. 

Overall it was a great experience. I would recommend visiting if in the San Fran area!
author: Cortney W.

description:
Envision crispy potatoes, perfect lemon ricotta pancakes, and freshly made biscuits, while you are standing in an hour long line. Its worth the wait. 

Why I was here // I came with two of my buds as we decided to go for a Sunday brunch, we even got there 5 minutes before it opened and there was already a long line down the block. By the time we got our name on the list we were given a 45 minute wait time for the outdoor seats. Sigh....We took a stroll and chit chatted the time away but...tip: sometimes they will call your name early to fit the tables if the party above you is called and not there, I would honestly stick around the restaurant , where you can hear the host because we got called early and missed it. Our wait could have been 20 minutes shorter..

Service // Service is friendly for this bustling restaurant. Since we were sitting in the freezing cold in their outdoor patio area with no heating, they offered us blankets which was nice. 

Food // 
-Buttermilk Biscuit with honey butter // 5.00 // I was so happy I got this magical piece of fluffy goodness. The honey butter was creamy and sweet and meshed well with the light, crispy and warm biscuit
-The Plow // 17.50 // The whole package this one is. I got scrambled eggs with potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, and chicken apple sausage. The potatoes were cooked to crispy perfection and I loved the lemon ricotta pancakes! 

Overall // I would definitely come here to this magical palace of brunch. The only issue is that wait time can be pretty bad, so maybe I would try coming on a weekday next time around. 
Also this place is small and doesn't accommodate parties larger than 6, so choose your brunch friends wisely.
author: Emily T.
