The plow comes with 2 eggs, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes, and the choice of pork sausage patties, bacon, or chicken apple sausage. We ended up sticking with the Nueske's bacon. The eggs and bacon were good, but what really made the meal was the lemon ricotta pancakes and the plow potatoes. The lemon ricotta pancakes were so light and fluffy, and had the right amount of lemon ricotta taste. It also wasn't too sweet, which I really liked. The plow potatoes were made to perfection..the perfect amount of crispiness and seasoned well. Honestly the best potatoes I've had in SF. The amount was perfect for my friend and me, and we were both happily stuffed.

Plow is on the pricier side for breakfast/brunch, but also pretty typical pricing for SF. The service was great. They were quick to fill us up on our coffee and ask if we needed anything. I would definitely come back here as long as there isn't too long of a wait :)
author: Jackie C.

description: My roommates and I finally ventured to Potrero Hill this morning to try this famous brunch. My friend pt our name down early, and it was about an hour and half wait for four people. However, once we got our table the food came so quickly. We ordered a buttermilk biscuit for the table (definitely recommend), and one of my friends and I split the soft scrambled eggs and the lemon ricotta pancakes. This was more than enough food- we were stuffed!! The pancakes were perfectly cooked and fluffy. The goat cheese in the soft scrambled eggs was also on point. I was also a big fan of the potatoes, and I'm not even really into potatoes! Would definitely recommend this place to all my friends!
author: Sonia S.

description:
Plow is a pretty good breakfast/brunch breakfast place. It wasn't mind blowing but I would come here again.

We came here on a Friday during lunch time and waited about 45 minutes for a 2 person table. The place is pretty small, so it's pretty understandable. They do have little benches for you to sit on outside as you wait.

For food, we ordered the breakfast sandwich with bacon and the open face gruyere and prosciutto toast. Both of these dishes came with golden roasted potatoes that were crisp on the outside and soft on the inside, though it was a tad bit dry. The breakfast sandwich and open face toast tasted pretty similar so you can't go wrong either.

Some of the things listed on their website are not available in the actual menu. I didn't see Dungeness crab scramble or Chinese Breakfast, which I was hoping to try.
author: Karen F.

description:
Terrible customer service once we got sat. Bigger red headed girl with a bunch of tattoos was NOT attentive and when asked about taking our order...she replies with a sassy "I feel you" and walks away...

OKAY, worked front and back of the house and very rarely see a waitress with this level of incompetence for good customer service. I don't care if you're slammed on a Monday, this is my first and last impression of this place. 

Do yourself a favor and avoid the red headed girl...she's struggling on a Monday. I saw her chit chatting for like 4 mins while I'm waiting to give my order and as soon as I ask for an order she ignores me and rushes around. Meanwhile the busboy is hustling harder than anyone on the floor...he knows what's up...she needs to follow in suit.

Long story short, I'm still waiting here and don't care how good your food is. Tell your hipster waitress to go get another tattoo...maybe with instructions on how to properly serve.
author: Chris Y.

description: Not worth waiting for. Food is OK, but ruined by long wait and bad service. They were kind of impolite. I would no go here unless you come a weekday outside of rush hour.
author: OA J.

description:
WHAT? Why does this place have so many good reviews?! I waited almost two hours to eat here and I was expecting something WORTH my time spent waiting but it was all a lie, a façade. I had their ricotta pancakes which looked super plain on the outside and the inside. I thought, "Humble, modest outer appearance but probably all the flavors of it inside will tell a different story." LIES! It was plain inside and out. 

My husband got the caramelized French toast which was good but not anything WOW either. The biscuit was good and my sister in law said their chia seed pudding was good but I haven't tried it so I cannot verify this. 

Why does this place get so many good reviews? Is it the location? What gives? The wait is not worth it, guys. There are way better places. Keep looking.
author: Kimberly B.

description: Their potatoes are the real star of the show!! The homemade pork sausage is also a must. We got the almond flour pancakes which were great but not amazing, and the French toast which was also good. Will definitely be back to try the fried chicken sandwich, chia bowl, & chicory salad. The place was totally packed on a Friday morning at 7 am when it opened. Was completely full with a 5 person deep line by the time we left at 8 am!
author: Kylie F.

description:
Plow is another one of those trendy SF brunch spots with impossible lines. I've tried to come here several times before but always gave up because the lines are just too long. The last time I was finally determined enough to eat there that I was willing to wait. Put our name down, walked around the neighborhood, got some beverages at a little shop nearby, and came back to be seated. The space is really bright and airy and pretty, but it was so hot on the day we went (which is rare for SF) and we sat inside where it was really stuffy and we were sweating the whole time. We could have waited longer for an outside table but I didn't really feel like it so we just suffered through the heat.  

We got 2 mimosas to cool down, one orange and one grapefruit (I love grapefruit so I was really glad they had it!). For food we got the Plow and the chicken tinga. Everything tasted delicious, including the lemon ricotta pancakes that was so highly rated. However I wasn't blown away by anything, and I'm not sure if it was worth the long wait. 

The service was just ok. The hostess was super nice, but our server was kind of disgruntled and not very friendly. Overall I'm glad I had the chance to eat here but I don't know if I would be come again given the wait time.
author: Wendan L.

description:
Woke up at 7am on Memorial Day weekend to try this place out. Ordered "The Plow" and really enjoyed it. Everything is on point and the servers are very friendly.

And as you know, the down side of this place is it gets crowded. So def try to come at weird hours to avoid the line.
author: Joseph L.

description: This place is so charming and quaint, and the food is always on point. If you get there before 8am on weekday you can get seated within 20 minutes otherwise be prepared to wait at least an hours during their busy time. But it's still worth it. I've pretty much tried everything on their menu but my favorites are soft scrambled eggs, the plow or French toast (toppings vary by season) and of course lemon ricotta pancake are delicious!
author: Iryna P.

description:
Joel and his wife opened this restaurant about 8 years ago. 
Seriously wonderful people! 
The place is very vibrant! 
They even have little blankets on the outside if you decide to sit outside.
I got the prosciutto sandwich and it was wonderful!! 

I highly recommended this place!!
author: Lydia B.

description: Overpriced and staff is very rude. Definitely not worth the wait. When I said my friend is coming in 2 minutes - they wouldn't even let me wait inside in the corner and rudely forced me stay outside in the cold
author: Selcuk A.

description:
First Yelp review and Plow seems fit to deserve it! Stopped in on a late Thursday morning and had no wait but hear it can be busy.

Try their namesake. You won't regret it. Lemon ricotta pancakes are an absolute MUST MUST MUST! Will for sure be back!
author: John C.

description:
This place is rock solid....you figure a restaurant with 2+ hour waits for brunch is solid, and this doesn't disappoint.  
Highlights: 
Buttermilk biscuit with honey butter - delicious, though mine was a touch overcooked
The Plow - good mix of stuff, including perfectly prepared eggs, delicious chicken apple sausage, and great little lemon ricotta pancakes. 

Coffee was good but not great.
author: Dave R.

description: If you like simple dishes this is the place to go. If you go at normal brunch hours prepared for a long wait. The food was delicious. Everything had the right level of saltiness and the food was juicy without being overly oily. I would have liked the dishes to be more complex but I understand that many people don't like spices.
author: Diane Z.

description:
My Plow review is long overdue, tried this spot over a year ago and it's still at the top of my SF brunch spots list (I am willing to come back here for brunch every damn time). 

Plow is like the boy next door: no flashy gimmicks, only wholesome happiness. Everything on the menu is pretty classic brunch fare. My biggest struggle when brunching is having to choose between sweet and savory, so if that's something you go through too, fear not! The Plow (their namesake dish) makes sure you get hooked up with their famous lemon ricotta pancakes AND some potatoes and sausage/bacon! The Plow is hefty on its own, so I like to split it with something smaller (like the breakfast sandwich). Are you the kind of person who is skeptical about ordering non-meat foods? Fear not, the aioli in the breakfast sandwich transforms the egg in such a way that you will forget you even need meat! 

The biggest downside is the wait- this is a pretty popular spot so if you come at any normal brunch time it'll be something close to an hour. I've come about thirty minutes from closing and there was still a fifteen minute wait. But if you haven't been here before and are a fan of simple fare, you won't be disappointed.
author: Amy J.

description: I'm shocked to see all of the 5 star reviews here and even more shocked people will wait hours to eat here! This place is an average brunch spot at best. It's fine, but it's nothing special and certainly not something worth waiting 1.5 hours for (which I did today). I'm not sure that I would come back, even if there wasn't a wait. There are so many good brunch spots in the city, it's insanity to wait in line for the standard fare served here.
author: Mindy G.

description: First place I went when I got to SF. Get "the plow" with the Apple sausage and you will not be disappointed. The lemon ricotta pancakes on the side are very light fluffy and full of flavor. Delicious place !
author: Elena H.

description:
LOVED this place!

I ordered the plow: two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, and chicken apple sausage. The food came out quick and it was the perfect portion. The potatoes were well seasoned, eggs were slurped and gone in seconds, and the pancakes were so fluffy. Def try the pancakes because the hint of lemon got me hooked. I typically don't like maple syrup because of how sweet and thick it is but the syrup it came with was really good. The sausage tasted just okay tho. It wasn't anything special. 

The wait was no joke. They gave us a 1.5 wait time at noon and we were seated close to 2pm. But the staff was nice so I can't imagine them turning people away. 

TIP: come early to avoid the long wait
author: Ying Z.

description:
I came here once on a Friday morning for brunch and was not disappointed. I was pretty surprised how crowded it was for 9am on a Friday, but luckily, just being one person, I was able to grab a seat at the counter. The restaurant is pretty small and felt very crowded especially with all the waiters walking around in addition to the customers. 

Having heard how great their pancakes are, I got the classic plow breakfast which came with eggs, bacon, potatoes, and two lemon ricotta pancakes. The pancakes were delicious. They had a subtle lemon flavor and the texture was very interesting because of the ricotta. I also loved the potatoes. They had a really nice crisp on them.
author: Rachel R.

description:
The Plow Plate satisfied all my brunch cravings! Fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes + crispy garlicky potatoes + eggs your way + choice of meat is THE ultimate brunch plate in my book. You can bet I did not leave a single crumb on my plate lol. 

I got my eggs poached and chose the homemade pork sausage as my protein option. My eggs were a bit overdone but the sausage was bomb with the addition of fennel in it. A little dry so I'd probably try something else next time. But oh my those mini lemon ricotta pancakes were lifee. There will definitely be a wait for a table but it is worth!!!
author: Lucia L.

description: Favorite brunch spot. It's a small restaurant with limited seating, so come prepared to wait. The plow is my favorite; 2 eggs, choice of meat, lemon ricotta pancakes, and potatoes.
author: Tuuyen N.

description:
Always worth the wait! 
Always worth having to park sideways on a steep hill (Texas Street). 
Always worth drinking a starter mimosa outside in the cold SF air while waiting for a table for 4 (2 guests is a much easier wait time). 

We had just beat the local lunch rush by arriving at 11:30 and getting our name in for a table for 4. 
I barely had one mimosa before being called up to a tight squeezy space in the back of the restaurant. 
I'm a big girl so having to squeeze in between  tables to seat myself is nearly heart-throbbing. But I survived. 

The pork sausage is a fave of mine - just full of all the good fresh herbs that catch your senses like sage, possibly fennel seed, basil. Who knows, but it's herballydelicious. 
Their OJ is fresh squeezed, their potatoes are crispy and wonderful, their hot sauce is a vinegar-based delight. 
Their service is fast and efficient and no fuss. 

I really do like this place, not for a quiet place to conduct a business gathering but to eat good simple food and then to get the heck out.
author: J.R. S.

description:
I was so excited for my Tuesday morning breakfast at Plow that I could barely sleep the night before. See, I've had this place bookmarked on Yelp for longer than I can remember and every so often, in some obscure conversation, someone would mention how wonderful the brunch is at Plow. I'd listen with hunger and envy. I'd get motivated to try to find someone who would be willing to get up at the crack of dawn with me. And I'd be disappointed when my friends laughed at my suggestion of eating that early.

Fast forward to today, March 7, 2017. He was willing to meet me at Plow at opening time. He might be a keeper for that reason alone. When I got there, we sluggishly greeted each other; both of us were still in a sleepy daze.

We were one of the first to get seated and we browsed the many tasty options on the menu. He was a good sport about sharing The Plow with me. With two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes, and bacon, it was a good amount for a weekday breakfast. We also ordered the jiggly coconut mochi cake.

It was all excellent. Our eggs over easy were cooked perfectly with beautiful runny yolks. The pancakes had a fluffy texture with a bit of refreshing lemon flavor. The bacon and potatoes were crispy and flavorful. The mochi cake was sticky and filling in a great way.

I'll have to come back another day to try some other items on the menu. Next Tuesday at 7am, anyone?
author: Yi Z.

description: The wait is usually long, and there is seating both inside and outside. There is a bus stop immediately in front of the restaurant, which may affect whether eating outside is desired. The Plow was not bad. The pancakes were unique, fluffy, sweet and delicious. The scrambled eggs were cooked just right and not overcooked. The salad seemed not to be too fresh, but the potatoes are said to be quite good. The bacon is average.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I came here last weekend for the pancakes and was not disappointed. Yes, the lemon ricotta pancakes are exactly as good as everyone says they are, and yes, the plow is the perfect meal to try everything people on Yelp rave about. I also got a side of the biscuit w/ honey butter. #worthit

Will I be coming back here in the near future though? Probably not, unless I find some magical time when the wait isn't two hours longs. Minus 1/2 a star for the ridiculous amount of time I had to invest for this experience and another 1/2 for the tiny pancakes. Yes, they are delicious, and that is exactly why I want more! The two pancakes they serve with the plow barely amount to the size of one normal pancake. I just waited in line for 2 hours. I'm H U N G R Y. 

All that said, there are arguably better places in the city for pancakes that have shorter wait times. I'll be there most weekends instead.
author: Patricia K.

description:
The wait is ridiculous here. If you want to eat in less than an hour then I suggest coming here right when they open because otherwise you are going to be waiting for quite a while. My boyfriend and I got here around 1016am and the estimated wait time was 1.5-2 hours. After the initial hour pass, the worker said it was going to be another half an hour possibly for a table... it ended up being another full hour and thank god my boyfriend knows me so well because the hangry side of me was about to come out and reek havoc among SF. 

I don't want to say parking here is super easy because if you come on a weekday then it is time limited and some spots are metered, however, I guess my boyfriend was blessed this past Sunday because we were able to find parking across the street right away. 

The menu gives you a good selection of food and drinks depending on what you're craving and from Yelp reviews we saw that things most noted were probably their lemon ricotta pancakes and their house potatoes so my boyfriend opted for the Plow which gave him both the pancakes, potatoes, and eggs and I got their breakfast sandwich with potatoes. The food did come pretty quick which was nice because I was starving by the time we sat down. 

So... breakfast sandwich was pretty bomb. I'm not usually a fan of runny eggs, still not, but it was under the bun and I ate it and it exploded and it was very yummy with the rest of the sandwich so I cannot complain. The potatoes were cooked very crispy, but they don't really have a sauce for it outside of ketchup and hot sauce so I didn't find much flavor with it. And I never really had lemon ricotta pancakes before and theirs definitely taste strongly of lemon flavor, but I wasn't blown away by them. Overall, both dishes were finished and we were pretty satisfy with everything, but I don't know if I would come here again for brunch. There are a bunch of brunch places around San Francisco and I want to explore them.
author: Venus L.

description:
Tl;dr: Not worth the 2-hour wait. 

After years of wanting to sample the highly lauded Plow, I finally took the leap this past weekend and waited the 2 hours for brunch. 

We put our name down at 11:30 and aimlessly wandered the hills of Potrero Hill until, at long last, our name was called around 1:30. It was a chilly day and we were seated outside, but they provided lap blankets which was a nice touch. 

After having waited for so long, and unsure when I would have the patience to do so once again, I decided to order their "all-inclusive" offering - 'The Plow.' I had mainly heard their potatoes and pancakes were to die for, and 'The Plow' offered both. It was a good brunch (turned late lunch after the wait), but definitely not worth $17 and the 2 hours my stomach was calling out for food. While the potatoes were cooked to a perfect crisp and the lemon ricotta pancakes were delectably light and fluffy, the eggs were just standard and the house-made sausage patties were too bland and dry for my liking. 

In conclusion, the brunch was good, but not mind blowingly amazing as I had expected. 

Tip: Don't arrive hungry.
author: Vivian N.

description:
There was a long wait for brunch, but worth it! We chose to sit outside to cut down on our waiting time. They provided blankets for us.

I ordered the breakfast sandwich and it is still the most delicious egg sandwich I've ever had in my life. The egg, cheese, and aioli made a mouth-watering combination one can not soon forget. And the potatoes! Hands down, the CRISPIEST potatoes I've ever had the pleasure of enjoying. I can not stress the crispiness of these potatoes. I'm drooling thinking about the food here. Plow has made it on my list of "Must Eat" in sf. 

My only complaint is that the "large" orange juice is the size of my water glass. Wish it was just a littler larger.
author: Mallory L.

description:
Yay for crispy potatoes! They were tasty and addicting. Had the soft scramble with goat cheese, shiitake mushrooms, stinging nettles, yum. I enjoyed my dish since it was a good balance between the heavy potatoes and lightness of the eggs.

Tried the mochi butter cake with coconut flakes. It was almost a layered cake of mochi on the bottom, egg tart and toasted coconut flakes. A good dish to share and it was good to try, but will probably not order this again.

Tried a bit of the lemon ricotta pancakes, the texture and flavor was pretty good, but I'm not too sure if I care to go out of my way or this particular specialty.

The wait was about 30-40mins on a rainy President's day at 8:30am. That's determination on my day off.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Get ready to wait, and wait, and wait... for some of the best brunch plates you've ever had in SF. By the time you're seated, you're ready to PLOW! 

Order the Plow- a sampler of all of their best dishes: The Lemon Ricotta Pancakes have been described as "sunshine in a pancake", accompanied by breakfast potatoes that are crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Opt for the salty-sweet juicy house made pork sausage patties. Just YUM! 

Mimosas of course!
author: Mitzi G.

description: Such an amazing breakfast!  I had the biscuit and The Plow.  The potatoes are the star of the show, don't miss them!  The biscuit with the honey butter is so fresh and not dry.
author: Ahmed H.

description: I waited two hours for brunch here because it has such amazing reviews online, so I figured it would be worth the wait. The place is small and we sat outside. It was freezing that day so they had blankets at each chair outside, which is nice. The seating is VERY cozy. The people next to my table were practically sitting in my lap, and the waitress could barely fit through. So there is definitely no quiet here or privacy, just be aware of that. My table ordered the "Plow", a salad, and the soft shell crab sandwich. The salad had flower petals on it and was really delicious. I enjoyed the potatoes the best, and wasn't all that into the ricotta lemon pancakes. The soft shell crab was pretty good. I wouldn't wait two hours for this place again, though.
author: Althea A.

description:
Plow Is the spot! 

Buiscuits and gravy.... (finger licking good) My best recommendation for this place is sitting at the bar/counter. Just watching the kitchen staff get down is so impressive. Good food, good service, good atmosphere! What more can you ask from one of the best brunch places in the city of SAN FRANCISCO!! :) Two thumbs up!
author: Cesar S.

description: The line here for Saturday brunch is incredibly long, but the service was fantastic and the food was great. I ordered The Plow and the only disappointment was the chicken apple sausage. The potatoes, eggs, and lemon ricotta pancakes were fantastic. Would definitely come again and try something else, and also come at an earlier time to leave my name on the list.
author: Manuela R.

description:
We arrived to plow at around 9am on a Saturday and were greeted with a line and notification that we would be seated at around 10:15am. After some discussion we decided to wait it out and we were not disappointed by our choice one bit. The plow is a fantastic brunch spot (in a city full of them) so it's definitely worth eating at, as long as you're prepared to wait or to wake up really early. 

I ordered the plow, which I was afraid would be too much food, but which ended up being the perfect amount. The lemon ricotta pancakes were fluffy, not too lemony, and perfectly delicious. I ordered poached eggs which were well cooked - runny with firm yet tender white. The sausage I ordered was probably the least impressive part of the meal yet was still pretty solid. 

My friend tried the eggs Benedict which had excellent hollandaise sauce (which in my opinion makes or breaks the dish). 

I saved the potatoes for last as they were the defining part of the brunch in my opinion. We all agreed potatoes were cooked extremely well as they boasted a crispy exterior and a soft interior that complemented the other parts of the breakfast.
author: Alok N.

description:
Plow is a place that you first mock, then decide to visit, hate the wait, and finally realize why the wait is worth your time.

I'm a sucker for a good brunch, and having been spoiled by living close to great digs like Universal Cafe and Mission Beach, but Plow is on another level. My girlfriend and I visit every so often on a sunny weekend, diligently wait the hour or two that it takes to be seated. Thanks to a great staff who are kind to take time to answer your questions, this experience isn't too bad.

Although almost all items we've ordered have been great, my favorite is consistently The Plow (underwhelming, I know), and the lemon pancakes. You've most likely never tried potatoes or eggs cooked so perfectly, plainly in front of you.

Honestly, just pay a visit and wait the hour. It's worth it!
author: Jeremy C.

description: The wait is long. Yes. But the food is phenomenal. Only place in SF that's worth this long of a wait list food wise in my option. And oh is it worth it! Great gluten free options, and I love how fresh and local their ingredients are. Plus...there's no better meal than breakfast!
author: Emily H.

description: Love this place, it pays to get there early in the morning though. The Eggs Benedict was amazing, the hollandaise sauce was one of the best I've ever had. I highly recommend their pork sausage and their fresh orange juice. The service was great, I got in and I got out. Bada bang bada boom!
author: Kristina C.

description:
A decent spot for weekend brunch that gets incredibly crowded because it's one of the few good options in the neighborhood. The fried egg sandwich with cheddar, aioli, frisee, and extra avocado was a satisfying choice, in the comforting way that having eggs in the morning is for many people. The Equator coffee was decent too, and overall the prices and service weren't bad. 

Is it worth an insane wait on the weekends when there are so many brunch places that are at least as good in the West Bay? If you're from the neighborhood and don't want to saunter elsewhere on weekend mornings, perhaps yes. If you're making a special trek out here, perhaps no. In my opinion, it might be a better option if you're free on a weekday morning and it's less crowded. YMMV.
author: Vincent L.

description: The food was great. Good temperature and tasted fresh. The chicken apple sausage was flavorful. The lemon ricotta pancakes were fluffy and the combo of sweet and savory was great.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Well worth the wait! The food was superb, the restaurant was classy, and the service was great! My friend and I put our names down and explored different shops nearby for about an hour. The hostess recommended we grab a drink at a little dive bar across the street to kill time. Great suggestion because time flew by! 

When we went back we were seated right away. The restaurant is small so expect to sit relatively close to your neighbor. I was surprised that the prices were good and not horribly overpriced considering the popularity of this place and the amount of food you received was a lot.

There were plenty of options to choose from some being your basic breakfast/ brunch deal and others quite different. My friend ordered The Plow which was your typical breakfast/ brunch (2 eggs, choice of meat,pancakes and potatoes). I ordered the Prosciutto on toast( egg fried up on toasted brioche ). We were both satisfied with our orders, I especially liked the prosciutto on toast because it was similar to eggs Benedict with a twist! I would definitely consider coming back again if I am in the neighborhood.
author: Rochelle E.

description:
I've heard sooo much about this place so I decided to finally come check out the hype. My thoughts are that the food and service are both equally exceptional, BUT I wouldn't wait more than 30 min for it. Thankfully I arrived on a Sunday at ~7:45am and I was able to be seated right at 8am. The line grew substantially after I arrived so I would recommend coming around the same time I did. Parking on a weekend morning was easy and free as well.

Now for the food:
French toast: So yummy! Not overly sweet and just the right thickness. Mine came with strawberries and thick whipped cream on top. There was also plenty of maple syrup on the side. Definitely recommend getting this and also asking for extra whipped cream!

The Plow: This is what most people get and is definitely the best for your buck. The lemon ricotta pancakes were SO scrumptious. The lemon was just the right amount. Combine that with the ricotta and you have an amazing balance of sweet and savory. I got the housemade pork sausage, which was good, but I think I would opt for the bacon next time. The Plow potatoes definitely lived up to the hype--crispy on the outside yet soft on the inside. They also give you smaller pieces that are all crunch and that was my favorite part.

I shared these two dishes with my sister and it was the perfect amount--not too full and we left satisfied. I will say that I saw folks around us order the biscuit and holy cow it looked amazing.

This place is worth coming to if you're not bothered waiting OR if you come early like I did!
author: Angelina H.

description:
What can I say? This is the most incredible place that I've ever experienced!

Yesterday on 1/11/2017, while I arrived in San Francisco, I decided to dine in at this well known local breakfast and brunch restaurant at the Potrero Hill neighborhood. "Plow" is the name by serving the customers from young to old to tasted their contemporary brunch dishes on every season and year! The atmosphere is very natural and elegant as I welcomed there. The concept is much more modern and contemporary like Bacon & Butter in Sacramento and Great Maple in San Diego (both in California) has and it feels like vising to the old country's kitchen in the plain lands.

The employees from servers and cookers are doing an excellent job for making the customers like me an outstanding service! Very friendly and approachable. No cons necessary.

Now onto the food! I ordered the Plow Breakfast plate. It contains with your choice of house made breakfast pork sausage, Nuesake's bacon, or chicken apple sausage (I picked) along with 2 eggs (I picked scrambled), 2 mini Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and baked potatoes. As I ate it, that plate taste irresistibly delicious! The chicken apple sausage taste remarkable and flavorful and it cooked perfectly for perfection. The scrambled eggs cook very well and fluffy to eat which I did feel the softness of the eggs naturally. The potatoes cooked not bad and perfectly seasoned for both salt and black pepper. The biggest winner for the Plow Breakfast plate is the Lemon Ricotta pancakes! The pancakes tasted flawless and magnificent which I did feel the flavors of lemon and ricotta combined into a one great taste! Adding with a maple syrup is a breeze of fresh air. What a great breakfast meal indeed!

Parking at Plow can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearest surface street parking if it's available, but you'll better be act quickly to find the best spot to park. You can also ride a bike, walk or public transportation easier without the hassles.

In the end, Plow is the most majestic and sensational local breakfast/brunch duo restaurant that I've ever enjoyed the most! Perfect for friends and family gatherings of all ages! A must visit for your SF trip needs! A well received visit! My rating: 4 1/2 stars.
author: William L.

description:
I couldn't decide between 4 and 5 stars and was going back and forth, but opted to give credit where credit is due. Plow creates a unique brunch experience, and while not everything on the menu is exceptional, certain menu options will change the way you think about "typical" breakfast meals. 

First off, the wait can be horrendous if you get here at not the right time. The best move is to arrive at 7:45am and you're most likely guaranteed to get seated with the first group. 15 min wait is worth the early rise. And the food (as well as the endless coffee) will remove any other doubts you had about not sleeping in.

Let's revisit the coffee though. They have a special plow blend that they serve from Equator Coffee and if the smell of eggs and toast doesn't wake you up, the coffee sure will. It only costs $3.50 and they keep it coming the entire time you're there.

Next, I ordered the gruyere and prosciutto toast and, to satisfy my sweet tooth, I order one ricotta lemon pancake. The toast was great, but not anything special. Sure the soft and warm yolk of fried egg on top of the toast slowly dripping onto the prosciutto and soaking in to the toast makes it irresistible, but this toast did not change my life. In fact, I am confident that I can recreate this at home. Additionally, the potatoes were solid, but I've had much better potatoes in the past. At this point I was leaning towards 4 stars.

...then I tasted the pancake...

And, for the first time in my life, I understood what a perfect pancake feels and tastes like. The pancake itself was an oxymoron: fluffy, but compact; light, but rich in flavor; strong lemon flavor, but hidden sweetness. It was so good, I forced my friend (who was full at that point) to try some. Hands down, the best pancake I've ever had. There is no comparison. None.

The most striking thing about Plow is the fact that the space is so simple and unsuspecting. And that's what gives it character. You come in with high expectations given the favorable reviews, but somehow Plow still manages to make you feel comfortable and catches you off guard. 

I didn't fully believe the hype before I ate here, but after experiencing it for myself I can truly say I'm sold. Plow, you earned 5 stars and then some. Thanks for everything.
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
As a native, I've tried a variety of brunch spots ranging from the most Instagram Famous all the way down to the cheapest hole in the wall spots in San Francisco.  What I've learned is to not let all places with 1-2 hour waits prove themselves worthy based on how esthetically  pleasing their decor looks or how well their food photographs. With that being said, Plow is easily one of the few places in SF that is NOT worth the 1-2 hour wait, money or camera space. If you're going to wait anywhere for a table during brunch, do yourself a favor and play the waiting game at better restaurants like Kitchen Story, Sweet Maple or Mission Beach Cafe. Luckily service was nice and attentive which is always the more important everlasting impression anyways. 

The Breakfast Sandwich with Bacon- the best part about this sandwich was the cheddar cheese, aioli and frisée. The eggs are supposed to be served soft, but mine in particular came out hard. Bacon was soggy. 

The Plow- basically Plow's version of a Denny's Grand Slam. I hate lemon but love ricotta. I gave the lemon ricotta pancakes a try but if you're anything like me then definitely skip out on these. I overheard another customer sub out these pancakes for the almond flour pancakes instead. House made pork sausage patties tastes like Italian sausage by the brand New York Style Sausage Company that you can buy at Safeway. 

Buttermilk Biscuit with honey butter- best thing we ordered! It was a hybrid of a cornbread and biscuit.
author: Ingrid E.

description:
Damn, came here at 9:30am thinking we were early, but still ended up waiting 2 hours for brunch. And was it worth the wait?

My verdict, probably not. Food was good but to wait 2 hours was a little excessive. We ordered the plow with homemade sausages, the goat cheese and shiitake mushroom scramble and the prosciutto and gruyere cheese toast. The homemade sausage had a lot of fennel seeds so the taste was very distinct and strong. I thought it was ok, but worth trying at least since it's made in house. The ricotta pancakes were good and so were the potatoes! Was not too big of a fan of the goat cheese and shiitake mushroom combo. The prosciutto toast was really good though! I probably wouldn't wait again for two hours but if it weren't that long of a wait and if I lived closer I'd come again.
author: Vicki L.

description:
As a write this review I wish I were back in San Fran just so I could have brunch at Plow again, it was that good! A group of 6 of us visited Plow last Friday for brunch in the early afternoon. We arrived around 45 minutes before closing. We did have to wait a while but understandable with a larger group. We first sat outside but it started raining and the server was very accommodating to move of us indoors. 

As far as the brunch items, everything looked so delicious and everyone in our group loved their food. I ordered the breakfast sandwich which came with two eggs fried soft, aioli, cheddar, frisee on a acme bun. Plow potatoes were served as a side and were fresh and mouth watering. Bacon or avocado could also be added for an additional charge. We also each got a refreshing mimosa where we toasted to my friend's 30th birthday.

The food came out in a timely manner and the service was great. I highly recommend checking out this farm to table restaurant. It is a bit pricey for brunch (around $200 before tip for 6 people) but we all agreed it was well worth it!!

If ever in the San Fran area again, I will be sure to stop here again!!
author: Kassie C.

description: There is always a line.  30-40 mins wait time even if u arrive at opening.  Food is pretty good.  Sausage is awesome! Potatoes could use more seasoning. Pancakes are meh! Overall I'd come here again.
author: Bobby B.

description:
Not too many places meet expectations, only a few exceed expectations... Then there's Plow...Plow is a banger. SHEESH! 

Queuing up a song to match my feelings towards this brunch haven.

[Hook: Waka Flocka Flame]
Plow, plow, plow, plow
B**** I'm bustin' at 'em
Plow, plow, plow, plow... heh.

The hype is real. The wait is worth it. The food is quality. We were seated after a good hour but boy did I forget about the hangry wait afterwards. I ordered the classic plow breakfast. I had my thoughts on their HK styled brick toast dressed in condensed milk but I had no idea they did not serve it on weekends. Whatever, there's always next time. Anyways, everything on my plate was spectacular. The roasted potatoes.... They were just perfect... not at all oily, with the best crisp to them.. they just tasted so clean and so fresh?! (queue outkast)...And the buttermilk biscuit are such a delicacy soaked up in egg yolk... The popular lemon ricotta pancakes are also on smash. Personally, I don't even like lemon flavored foods but it really works well in this instance. I see what all the fuss is about.. and I hate myself for not finding out about it sooner. I'll be back.
author: David N.

description:
Came here on a Sunday morning around 9 AM. When we got here they told us it would be an hour and a half wait. Crazy. 

Food: I got the plow and my boyfriend got the breakfast sandwich. The lemon ricotta pancakes were probably the best pancakes I've ever had. Perfect amount of lemon flavor and a really good fluffy texture. The potatoes were also amazing, very good flavor and texture. 

Service: We ended up getting seated after about 45 minutes, quicker than expected. We sat at the bar seat which was cool because we got to see the food being made. Our waitress was great except we asked her to split the meal between two cards and she ended up charging one of them twice. Not sure how that would happen. 

Ambiance: The inside was a lot smaller that I thought it would be, guess that explains the long wait times. Very clean inside and we saw that they got a 100 score on their food/cleanliness which is always good to see. Big windows that bring in a lot of light. There was also outside seating. 

Overall it was a great meal. Probably not the best breakfast I've ever had but also nothing to complain about (besides the wait). Definitely worth checking this place out.
author: Hayley D.

description:
Went here on a Thursday for brunch and it was amazing! The wait was 30 min at about 10:30 am but was well worth it

I ordered the simmered eggs (which was basically shakshuka) and it was incredibly creamy and hearty. The Acme levain bread is from a local bakery in Berkeley and was also incredible.

The French toast was also super soft and the perfect amount of sweetness. It came with caramelized apples that were a great touch. 

My friend got the smoked salmon toast and really liked it as well. 

Would recommend!
author: Kimberly T.

description: Was a solid, satisfying brunch. We got the Plow meal and a biscuit.  The highlight was the lemon ricotta pancake which was delicious. The biscuit was also above average and the honey butter made it stand out. The rest was pretty standard and nothing out of the ordinary.  I'm not sure the 2 hour wait was worth it though. Because of the wait and the hype, it didn't quite meet my expectations. But if I take that out of the equation, then I was very satisfied.
author: Simon S.

description:
Plow is my go-to for a low stress, early morning breakfast spot. They offer simple brunch classics that are done perfectly. My personal favorite is the Plow, which is breakfast sampler of all things good in the breakfast world: lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, home made pork sausage (other meat options, but the sausage is my #1). My fiancé ordered a new one, the dungeness crab scrambled eggs, which was DOPE.

The inside interior is rustic romantic (you know that weathered wood, farmhouse feel). Service is great. I always feel like I am eating at home with my mom cooking me a great meal. It also has that neighborhood feel. One time I ate, a cop parked and just said hello and gave badge stickers to all the kids. There is ample street parking everywhere, so not an issue if you want to drive over.

I hear the line can get really long, but I am the crazy person that gets there around 7:30 am and is the first person in line. Around 7:45 people start lining up in masses. One thing to note if you want to be cray like me and be the first people seated, one time the biscuits weren't ready for us that early. Not really sure when they are typically done. But the biscuits there, also DOPE.
author: Frances P.

description:
Went here for brunch on a Sunday afternoon. It was packed. Of course. The wait turned out to be a two hour wait, but I mean what do you expect? The brunch scene in SF is legit crazy! 

The overall restaurant was really small. Groups bigger than 5-6 I think would be hard to accommodate. There's outside seating also. There is only 1 bathroom, so there's usually another wait to go to the bathroom. However, the bathroom is big and clean.

I ordered the almond flour pancakes, side of fruits, and strawberry lemonade. The pancakes were so fluffy and aaaaamazing! I highly recommend it. Although, the fruits and strawberry lemonade was not really anything special. I also do think it was a bit overpriced. ($7 or so for a small plate of fruits). 

The wait is ridiculous, so I definitely would take that into account when you come here! The food was good, although some items on the menu I would recommend not getting since it is a bit overpriced. 

I do recommend checking this place out.
author: Patricia A.

description: Ate the honey butter biscuit which was good, but I don't think I'd get it again for $5. The chia pudding tasted refreshing with some honey sweetness. I shared sausage patties (had a unique slightly sour taste) and bacon (had a smokey taste). Both were atypical flavor to typical brunch food. The plow did everything it needed as a main dish. The reason this isn't a 5 star is b/c of the long wait which is due to the small size of the place.
author: Michael C.

description: I've been looking forward to trying this place and I'm utterly disappointed. The service sucked, the ppl that worked there came off as rude and clueless. I tried the plow and the food was decent minus the pancakes being small and over cooked. Overall the staff and ambiance ruined it for me and I won't be back.
author: Rae W.

description:
I was skeptical but it was closeby. I'm a tad of a food snob. I'll eat just about anything but bitch about it. 
This was, hands down, the best breakfast I've ever had. Everything was magic. The bacon was indescribable. 
I don't care if you have to wait, it's worth it.
If I had called ahead last night and still had to wait an hour this morning I would have knowing what I do now.
author: Jay N.

description: Plow was there first stop I went to when I got to SF. It was the best breakfast I had my whole trip. The Plow is the fantastic. The egg was cooked nicely, the almond pancakes were delicious and my favorite were the potatoes. My mouth is getting watery as I think about them. Also I did try the toast that has condensed milk, anyway that was just fantastic. I forgot to get a photo of the buttermilk biscuit but that biscuit was phenomenal. Thank you plow for great food and great service! Definitely will be coming back!
author: Nickiee S.

description:
My favorite brunch place of all time! Worth the wait!

I've been here about 5 (or more) times and it's so good every single time!

I've tried the egg sandwich, the plow, and butcher's steak and eggs!

My favorite is "the plow," and I always recommend every friend to get it! The sausage (homemade sausage) is so flavorful, the eggs are a perfect consistency, and the potatoes are always cooked to perfection. Last, but not least, it also comes with lemon ricotta pancakes which are just as delicious and flavorful as everything else! It is a little pricey (20$) but it's so worth it! 

I don't really recommend the egg sandwich. Don't get me wrong, it is delicious, but not as delicious as the other 2 dishes. Plus, this dish doesn't come with potatoes and brunch is never complete without some delicious potatoes. 

During the weekend, there will be a long wait but I really think this is one of the few restaurants that are worth the wait! I usually recommend that you either go really early, or show up around 1:30pm (they close at 2) for a shorter wait time. If you walk up the hill, there is a beautiful view of San Francisco, but don't wander too far or you will lose your seat. They only call out your name about three times before they give up your seat to the next party!
author: Shirley S.

description: Delicious breakfast. The cooks are great. I could watch them from my seat at the bar. Everything was so organized and clean. Ingredients appeared fresh. I ordered the prosciutto toast with egg. I definitely recommend coming here an ordering it.
author: Gino C.

description:
What a cute little place for breakfast/brunch. There are hooks along the wall for your coats/bags.

I was forewarned about how long the wait can be, so I planned to come here on a Monday morning during my visit. We showed up not long after they opened and were seated right away. 

I was debating between the Plow, the Dungeness crab scramble, and the open-faced prosciutto + Gruyere toast. But since I was intrigued by the lemon ricotta pancakes, I opted for the Plow.

The dish comes with two eggs with choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes. I asked for scrambled eggs (which is a rarity for me) and bacon. Every element of the dish was really good, the potatoes were very crispy on the outside, and the pancakes had a nice balance of flavors.

Service seemed a bit slow, but I'll just give them the benefit of the doubt that it was busy. It certainly seemed busy, but I noticed the servers standing around and inattentive numerous times throughout our meal.

Overall, I would recommend this place for the food. Service wasn't terrible, but it wasn't fantastic either. Granted, it was early on a Monday morning. If I find my way back to this spot during a future visit, I'll definitely try one of the other dishes that intrigued me.
author: Lisa N.

description: A good brunch place! If I didnt't have to wait too long to be seated, I'd go here very often
author: Stephanie S.

description:
I endured a 2+ mile walk from the Tenderloin w/ my friend to try Plow out! We were super cold by the time we got to Plow and then were told that the wait would be almost 2 hours if we wanted to sit inside ... So we waited about 40 minutes for outdoor seating instead at around 9AM. The cold was barely bearable!

Soon after we were seated, we were provided with thin blankets and hot water that had the aftertaste of coffee. We shared The Plow (with sausages and poached egg), a mochi cake, and a crab scramble. All food was finished between two ladies!!

The Plow was definitely the item to get! The raved-about lemon ricotta pancakes were indeed delightfully fluffy, though I was unpleasantly surprised to find that they were about the size of the palm of my hand. The potatoes were deliciously crispy and had the texture of curly fries despite looking like regular breakfast potatoes. Sausages were normal and egg was perfectly cooked with a runny middle!! 

Mochi cake was also a good choice - moist and bouncy and not too sweet! But the crab scramble was kind of watery even though I was satisfied w/ the amount of crab provided. 

Prices were definitely more like brunch prices than breakfast prices ($$$$). I would come back on a nice day in autumn, maybe .. I already saw one bee in late December, so I probably would not want to sit outside in spring/summer lol.
author: Diana W.

description: Plow, why you make me wait so long?!?! Sheesh!!! Getting a table can take forever, but the food is worth it. I ordered the crab scramble and boy was I impressed! I'm going to have to figure out how to show up during their off peak hours. Waiting this long for food should be illegal. The worst part is that there's nothing really to do in the area, so I basically dwindled my thumbs for about an hour while waiting.
author: Ali R.

description: In my opinion, this place has the best breakfast potatoes in town. I LOVE the lemon ricotta pancake.
author: Jeanine G.

description:
The food was not as amazing as I expected especially after a 2.5 hours of wait on a Sunday afternoon. Among the brunch places in SF I have tried, Plow is definitely not my favorite ones.

The restaurant itself was not big and there were not enough waiters working on they day I went. After being seated, my friend and I waited another 20-30 min before someone finally came and brought water and took our order. Kinda frustrating.

Food we ordered:
--Chia Seed pudding (3/5): probably the saddest chia seed pudding I have ever seen and tried. The fruit topping they used was cantaloupe, hmmm...I mean, it's Plow and I was expecting something like berries and peaches. The chia pudding itself was pretty bland. Definitely will not order again.
--Plow with sausages (3.5/5): it's just a standard American breakfast. I don't see anything special about this dish. 
--Soft scrambled eggs (4/5): it was good but again, I could have just made it at home. My friend and I was trying to look through the menu to order something special, but we can't find any. 
--Side order: Lemon Ricotta Pancake (4/5): probably our favorite item but have to say, Zazie does a better job in making their ricotta pancakes. 

My friend and I had such a big expectation about Plow and our time there in the end termed out to be pretty disappointing.
author: Clare L.

description:
Plow is a kitchen-to-table restaurant and brunchery in Potrero Hill. The food is so fresh because of the tight chain of command: the waiter relays the order to the kitchen, which is exactly where the chef, who makes the food, spends his day. Once the chef has finished preparation, it goes directly back to the waiter, who serves the table without delay. 

The unique breakfast menu--pancakes, "French" toast, something called biscuits, eggs, bacon--is so San Francisco, and so good. Where else could you find all these options (and more)? Who knows. But they certainly have them here, and they certainly do them well. There is also a more lunch-like part of the menu, but who cares. Plow is brunch, and your best bet is to come early on a weekday, as people flock to this spot. Get the biscuit.
author: Oliver S.

description:
Plow makes a solid brunch but by no means is it worth the hype it receives. I have visited twice in the past year and tried a sampling of their items. Everything is good but nothing (and I truly mean nothing) is worth waiting more than 30 minutes. Plow is pretty small but the staff does cram quite a few tables in the narrow space which also has bar seating and outdoor tables. I would definitely not recommend coming if you have a large group, or really any group larger than 3. The space is very simple and perfect for a brunch joint. There is a ton of natural light which is perfect for snapping some pictures of your food which is what EVERYONE in this restaurant is doing all of the time.

I have sampled the Plow, the Prosciutto and Gruyere toast and the Breakfast Sandwich. My least favorite was DEFINITELY the Plow. Super overrated and nothing on the plate was really noteworthy. The pancakes are pretty basic and I think compared to a lot of the other notable places in the city offering lemon ricotta pancakes, the weakest. The Prosciutto and Gruyere toast is a pretty solid option and the Breakfast Sandwich is good, if not basic. The prices are pretty high for what you get but considering how popular this place is, I suppose it is reasonable. The service is fine but be prepared to wait a bit for your food since the kitchen is pretty small.

All in all, I do like Plow and maybe this review is negative. I just think there are other places in the city preparing more innovative food that are less mobbed and have better pricing. Plus, Portrero Hill is kinda depressing at 8AM which you will surely find out if you try to arrive at any point later than 30 minutes before opening.
author: Carrie W.

description:
On an early Sunday morning, we came here around 8:30am.  We were told that for a party of 2, it would be a little over an hour wait. And they were right! We got seated outside at 9:45am.  They have blankets if your cold!  What did we do to wait? Walk around! Plow is located in a quaint area with other small shops and cafes to walk by.  Get that walk in so you can fill that belly!

Here's what we had:

Five Mountains organic tea - $4.75
Rolled Jasmine Green
It's tea. Warm. It was cold out so it was fitting. :)

BUTTERMILK BISCUIT - $4.50
This hunk of biscuit was served with a side of honey butter, that was sweet and yummy.  The biscuit itself is shareable and fluffy. I really enjoyed it!

BROWN BUTTER COCONUT MOCHI CAKE - $4.25
This dessert was delicious! Order quick before they run out!  would never expect a mochi cake here!  There's a layer in There that tasted quite custardy.  I recommend getting this even if your full; have it to go!  

FRENCH TOAST - $13  
Brown sugar caramelized apples, blood, mascarpone, pure Vermont maple syrup.
Depending on the season, the fruit may change.  This French toast was amazing.  It was so creamy and you definitely taste quality in every bite. Get it!

THE PLOW - $17 
Two eggs, house made pork sausage patties, lemon ricotta pancakes and plow potatoes.
Not sure what to get? Get this one! It has everything!  The pork sausage patties was although not quite what I expected, was good.  It tasted healthier than your normal diner pork sausage patty--looks like there are veggies in the mix and it's not as salty.  I liked it!  The potatoes was probable the main reason why I got this.  It's all so crispy and yummy!  I can have a bowl of this in its own.  As for the lemon ricotta pancakes to fulfill that sweet side, it was great.  I liked the small portion and the flavors were subtle and wonderful.    

I enjoyed everything here. I can see why it's so popular and I was not annoyed with the wait.  Our server was friendly.  It started to right as we were leaving so freat timing! Don't worry they have a thing they roll out to cover you from getting wet. :)
author: Tu-Anh N.

description:
Gonna make this short and sweet since there's already so many 5 stars reviews: It's worth the wait!!! 

GET THE PLOW. They make the best lemon ricotta pancakes, juiciest pork sausage, and the crispiest potatoes. The portions are on point, not too much but just enough to fill you up. I think I found my new favorite brunch place! Can't wait to come back to try the other items on the menu and a grapefruit mimosa.
author: Cecille W.

description:
Plow has been on my "to try" list for awhile now and I finally got around to checking it out. My friend and I came in on a Sunday morning around 9:30. We ended up waiting about 40 minutes, which went by pretty fast. 

We both ordered the plow! I got mine with bacon and it was delicious! I loved the lemon ricotta pancakes. I was expecting them to be super sweet, but they were JUST right! Overall, I would recommend this place. It is a little more than I would like to spend on brunch, but it was definitely worth it.
author: Ariana T.

description: Food was great. Servers were good. It was a week day when we went. I heard that the wait for a table on the weekend could take some time. Thank God that it was a nice sunny day when we went. We got seated outside on a sloped sidewalk. Next to the bus stop. A homeless person got out of the bus and started rummaging for some leftover in the services station. The experience could have been better.
author: raimundo t.

description: This was an amazing spot for brunch! I loved not having to choose between a sweet and savory breakfast with "The Plow" dish. The potatoes were so delicious, nicely fried and the skins were a nice touch. The lemon ricotta pancakes were fluffy and very aromatic. The only issue I have with this place is the wait time. I recommend showing up at 8am or even a little earlier than when it opens because it's a non stop crowd of people outside. I waited 1 hr and 45 mins for a two person spot and arrived at 9:40 am.
author: Cassandra F.

description: YUM YUM YUM! I found Plow on Yelp and really any places that boasts about having the best breakfast potatoes in the city, I knew I had to check out. Because its a super tiny place (maybe there are like 15 small tables in the entire place), we decided to go on Tuesday morning rather than during the weekend. We were seated right away at the bar (no open tables even on a Tuesday!) and the service was overall good. The food itself was also really good! I got the Plow and my fiancé got the custard French toast. Both were REALLY good. I am not sure if they are my favorite potatoes in the world, but for sure they were the best I had during the trip to SF. They were crispy, well seasoned, and super hot! The pancakes were nicely balanced (not too sweet, not too lemony) and the eggs were cooked nicely. I would say what you get at Plow is simple food that is made perfectly, which is exactly what I look for when I go to brunch!
author: Karen G.

description:
My family recently moved to the area and I was super excited to try this place before I went back to school! I headed over with my mom at 9am on a Tuesday and was met with an already long line, but we weren't super put off by that. We walked in to ask someone how long the wait would be, and if we would be able to sit outside. We were told that they weren't doing outside seating but if they did start doing outside seating, the wait wouldn't be too long. My mom was looking around the restaurant and made an observation that there were two seats on either side of a couple (because I stated that I only saw one), but did not implicate that she was asking them to move people around just for us. Then, a server that we were not even speaking to at the time said "No we're not going to just move people around." I was immediately taken aback by the rude response-- as someone who has worked in multiple customer service jobs I honestly could not believe that an employee said something like that when unprovoked to a potential customer. My mom trying to make light of the situation said sarcastically, "oh we'll move them," while laughing and smiling, to which the employee rolled her eyes and basically scoffed, and my mom verbally had to say that it was a joke... I was just rubbed the wrong way by this place. Usually, I'm one to stick up for employees that work in customer service, as I work in the food/drink industry as well, but the attitude here by this one employee was extremely unacceptable. I immediately suggested to my mom that we go elsewhere. I really wanted to find a cute, breakfast spot in my neighborhood, but if this is the way this restaurant treats potential patrons, I would rather go somewhere else, no matter how good the food may be. 
Sad to say that I will not be returning, and wish I could say I had a great experience.
author: Sydney V.

description: I've lived down the street for years, and must say that this is one of the best lunch/brunch places in town. The food is always high quality, and focuses on sustainably grown and local farmers. I try to go mostly during the week. It can be very very busy on weekends, so you must have the patience for a wait, but the food and atmosphere are worth it! My favorites are the lemon ricotta pancakes and soft scrambled eggs! Dog and kid friendly!
author: Liz C.

description:
Dear Management,

You are my favorite place for breakfast in the city. I've been visiting your restaurant at least 3 times a week. Your gluten free Annie's almond pancakes are the best gluten free pancakes I've ever had. Those pork sausages are delightfully delicious. However, you have been disappointingly inconsistent on my last two visits. PLEASE bring back Zoe's chicken apple sausage (not the small skinny ones, but the bigger, plumper and juicer ones, they are so much more flavorful! My server (manager?) also agreed with me, said that they are much tastier). Also, the last time I was there, I was very disappointed in the potatoes, they did not have the correct amount of seasoning this time, or were missing the rosemary, but they were very plain Jane. 

Hope my next visit will be as amazing as my first visit. Thanks and keep up the great work!!
author: Nancy K.

description:
Pro tip: If you can, go early during a week day. You'll likely get seated without waiting + there will be plenty of time to eat before you need to be at work.

I trekked over from the Mission (dang, those hills will get ya!) early Thursday morning with the boy and got there right at 7 when they open. We were seated right away and then had the difficult time of figuring out what to order.

I'm pretty sure EVERYTHING would be amazing on the menu, and I'm really bummed that I couldn't justify ordering one of everything. The best option in my opinion is getting "the Plow" which satisfies a lot of different tastes. It comes with two eggs, their famous potatoes, choice of brekky meat and two lemon ricotta pancakes.

Guys, their potatoes. I don't know how to do them justice. They are the most crispy delicious things on the planet, and perfectly salted/seasoned as well. I wish I had a mountain of these.

The lemon ricotta pancakes were also amazing- light and fluffy and melt in your mouth delicious.

I really don't think there's a bad option on the menu; it's more of timing your visit right so that you don't get hangry while you wait!
author: Elliott W.

description:
Fantastic brunch in a cute spot overlooking the city. 

The sausage here falls apart in your mouth and is richly peppery with herbs. The bacon is perfectly cooked and tender. The lemon ricotta pancakes were fluffy and unique. I had the chia pudding which is made with coconut milk and came with plum, apricot, coconut slices, almond slices, honey, and bee pollen. It was beautifully presented, delicious, and filling. 

The waitstaff are very attentive and they have blankets outside for your convenience. We came here early and had about a 40 minute wait but there are plenty of cafes in the area to explore while you do.
author: Jessie Elizabeth J.

description:
Eh.

For the price I paid for this, I was underwhelmed. I tried coming here before with a friend when we stayed over the weekend in San Francisco, but the wait time was over three hours and we weren't down for that. 

I came this past Monday around 8:00 am so I was able to get a seat right away as it was only me. For my drink I ordered coffee, which was a mistake. The coffee here is so darn bitter! It could not even be saved with cream and sugar :( Please do yourself a favor and either get coffee beforehand from somewhere else, or skip coffee from Plow altogether. 

I ended up ordering the Plow, which comes with two lemon ricotta pancakes, chicken apple sausage (you can also opt to choose bacon or regular sausage), their potatoes, and eggs. Their lemon ricotta pancakes were pretty tasty, but that's about it. There was nothing particularly remarkable about this dish, I could have easily made something like this at home.

Bottom line- only come here if there is no wait, and do NOT order the coffee! For the price you're paying for your food (I payed $25 for coffee and The Plow), I would say to check out another one of San Francisco's great brunch places.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
My boyfriend searched, "best breakfast spot in San Francisco" and this was one of the few that popped up. It was our first time and it definitely blew our minds away. We were greeted with the "old vintage" look of the restaurant, it was super cute and chic! They offer a breakfast bar and shared tables and inside/outside seating. We caught them on a good day, so the wait time didn't exceed 20 minutes. We were pretty starving by the time we got our table though. 
First things first, get the orange juice!! Omg it's so fresh and not pasteurized! They offer two size, I got the small but if I knew it tasted this bomb I'd get the large. 
The breakfast platters are huge and it'll fill you up! I got the "soft scramble eggs" which comes with potatoes and toast and my boyfriend got the "the plow". Everything was great and the service was amazing. Totally got me off my toes, would revisit if I take another trip to San Francisco!
author: Tethivorada G.

description:
My fiancé and I live only 3 blocks away from here, and this is our FAVORITE spot to get breakfast in the city of San Francisco! 
We will wait 2 hours for this breakfast... its just that good. 
The biscuits are amazing, the Plow Breakfast is so large we can split that... we each get a mimosa and also if we feel "Dangerous" we will order a French toast :P 
Such amazing breakfast food with quality taste!
author: Justin S.

description:
Baby you're my everything, you're all I ever wanted.. 

Plow, you da best I ever had.

When a place is extra special you know I gotta throw in some Drake. 

I remember brunching at Plow a year or two ago and thinking it was the best brunch I've ever had. I came back for a second time recently (after many, many brunches at other places) and still agree that Plow is THE. BEST. (I've ever had, tehe) 

We came at around 12 on a Saturday and waited for almost two hours?! That's okay.. I'll willingly starve and be hangry for you, Plow. 

You must order something that comes with the potatoes. If you don't, you must order some potatoes on the side because those potatoes are CRACK. Perfectly crispy, yet so fluffy. They put other breakfast potatoes to shame. 

We also shared a spinach + mushroom benedict and the oh so famous lemon ricotta pancakes which were obviously delicious. Benedict was of course #eggporn worthy, not sure how other places mess this up but Plow's got this down solid. No additional details needed there. 

Hands down my favorite brunch spot in SF. With that being said..

"I say, you da fuckin' best you da fuckin' best
You da fuckin' best you da fuckin' best
You the da best I ever had,
Best I ever had, best I ever had, best I ever had"
author: Laverne N.

description: AMAZING! Worth the wait and love the environment. The homemade sausage and lemon ricotta pancakes were to die for. If you love lemon  the pancakes are a must. Portions are perfect and great service. Will be back whenever I visit SF. Take the 9-10 dollar Uber fare to get to Plow. You won't regret it.
author: Jeannie P.

description: After 6 years in SF I finally made it to Plow! It was a cold, rainy day so I ordered the Shirred Eggs in a creamy tomato sauce with crispy garlic toast. It was perfect. My boyfriend got The Plow. The lemon ricotta pancakes melt in your mouth. Service is impeccable too.
author: Kim O.

description:
They can't take more than 6 people in a party which was just perfect for us. We had to wait for about 1.5 hour for our table. Partially our fault as we missed the first time our name was called. There were people waiting at 9am! The staff was very friendly and the place is pretty cozy. 
We had almost everything on the menu... (we like to share)
- The plow
- Soft scrambled eggs 
- French toast 
- Salmon eggs benedict 
- Dungeness crab scramble 
- Breakfast sandwich 
- Hong Kong toast 

Loved their house potatoes because they were crunchy instead of smooshy. Their hot sauce was good too. My favorite was the lemon ricotta pancakes with the plow dish. The crab scramble was also delicious. Nothing really disappointed me in the spread we got. The Hong Kong toast was also good but it just wasn't my cup of tea. 

I wouldn't mind coming again but it may be a shorter wait with a smaller party. Parking wasn't too bad either. They also don't have room for stroller parking if you're coming here with a baby/toddler and it's pretty difficult to have a high chair given the tight space.
author: Jenna T.

description:
First things first, a word to those with TREE NUT ALLERGIES: There are pecans (or some other tree nut) in the apple cinnamon coffee cake. I had a small reaction to it and we also picked out a nut in the crust. Unfortunately the waitress said the chef said there weren't nuts in the cake, which is false. This is a serious blunder, especially if there are unsuspecting customers with more serious nut allergies than me. 

Favorite thing here: Lemon Ricotta Pancakes!! I am such a fan :) Apparently it's one of their specialties. I love the thin layer of ricotta within the lemon-ricotta batter. It's finished with a dusting of powdered sugar, and a dash of maple syrup really brings it home!

I ordered the Plow with chicken apple sausage. The eggs are fluffy and potatoes are super crispy with strong rosemary flavors. I couldn't taste the lavender salt in the potatoes but it's interesting to know that it's there. Chicken apple sausages were on the saltier side and slightly burnt, but really well-made. It's a ton of food, so a solid order for even the hangriest of people. 

Apple Cinnamon cake: small nut reaction aside, it was delicious. You can really taste the moist, buttery cinnamon and the crust is full and thick. 

Was it worth the 2.5 hour wait for a party of 4? Probably not. I could see myself waiting at most an hour for those heavenly lemon ricotta pancakes.
author: Julia Y.

description:
I am a fanatic about their pumpkin pancakes. The pumpkin wasn't too overpowering which is great and there was a berry compote and real maple syrup. I also ordered a mimosa and chicken apple sausage, both amazing!

The location was pretty solid. Not all that far from downtown. Quick Uber, bike, walk away. The restaurant is a bit small but they seem to get people in and out pretty quick. 


I would definitely return to try some of the other things on the menu.
author: Jason S.

description: I was in SF for the first time in November and I still can't stop thinking of the breakfast I had here. It was such a simple breakfast of potatoes, sausage, pancakes and eggs.. but it was so tasty! From the crispness of the potatoes and sweetness of the sausage. I hope I'll be back soon!
author: Paulina K.

description:
This was an amazing experience and so good! Downside is that there is always a line and a wait, my friend and I waited almost 2 hours to get a seat but it was worth it. 

I decided to get The Plow with sunny side up eggs and pork sausage with a butter biscuit. The drip coffee is also amazing and strong!! Highly recommend it and will be back soon!
author: Mel R.

description:
A cute spot in a cute neighborhood that sticks to a few solid standard dishes that they do very well.  Makes me think of diner meets hipster SF in that they keep it simple, but it's well-executed and don't make your arteries cry.  The food isn't particularly complex like I seem to find in other popular/up-and-coming brunch spots; the ingredients are good quality.

My friend and I did the lemon ricotta pancakes, poached eggs, and french toast.  Generally I get disappointed by lemon ricotta pancakes at restaurants (yet I continue to order it again and again :p), but theirs were excellent.  Don't let the small pancake size fool you.  I only got 1 pancake and felt satisfied...loved the small chunks of ricotta embedded in an airy pancake.

And the wait?  Obviously weekdays are better for avoiding long lines (20-30 min on a Tues morning), but even with the wait, you can stroll to Farley's across the way or Philz (10 min walk away) for some morning caffeine or just stroll the neighborhood.
author: Mon T.

description:
Simple menu and full with flavors and chef magic.
I got the chicken sandwich and it worth the wait. Guess what even the kids their nagging changes to plate licking and wow dad thx. Wife got the Plow two eggs and lemon pancakes and She finished her plate and not normal for her as for the kids one got the breakfast sandwich and the other got the almond pancakes.
author: M K.

description:
Plow oh Plow 

Even on a rainy Saturday afternoon at close to 1, there was still a 1-2 hour wait for a party of two. 

There's an abundance of reviews for this place. To keep it short, plow is known for their brunch. Yea, they do brunch well. 

From their lemon ricotta pancakes to their signature "the plow" brunch dish, plow has gotten brunch and break food down to a tee. 

A small establishment, anticipate an at least 1 hour wait on the weekends. Put you name down and keep within close proximity to the host as they normally do roll call ever so often. I would suggest that you come in a small party, otherwise I can't imagine how long you would have to wait. 

I can't deny that the food was good. But, frankly, I wasn't blow away.  Yes, their Crispy rosemary potatoes are super delicious, but the rest of my plow dish ( eggs pork sausage and I subbed almond pancakes as I'm GF) was mediocre. It was cooked well, but I actually felt like it was missing some flavors.  For 2+ hour wait...I don't know if I would do it again. 

The BF has the lemon pancakes and felt it was a bit undercooked. Maybe it's just our taste buds? He did like his salmon Benny though. 

Portion wise, it's decent and within the same limits as with most SF brunch establishments.  Pricing wise, most dishes are approx 15-18. Which is a little most hefty for brunch. 

Would I come back? Yes--absolutely. But not with that wait time. I would have to disclose that since I'm Gf I'm limited to certain items.  I saw a lot of other patrons ordering their baked goods and they looked delicious. So perhaps for you my friend, plow will be a 5 star worthy place even with the heinous wait.
author: Diane T.

description:
Came here for brunch with a few of my friends. We arrived right when the restaurant opened at 10, which allowed us to avoid the long wait. The staff was quick to take our order & the food for the 5 of us came out about 10 minutes later. 
I ordered the custard French toast with macerated strawberries & vanilla marscapone, and WOW it did not disappoint! The outside was crispy, but the custard inside was the perfect amount of softness, warmth, and sweetness. the pure maple syrup they gave us was also of great consistency. My only complaint is that the portion may have been a bit on the smaller side for the price I paid ($13/2pc, $16/3pc). Other than that, I would definitely come here again for a quick brunch
author: Alicia P.

description: This little breakfast place was PHENOMENAL and totally worth all the forms of transportation we had to take to get there! The food was above and beyond delicious (especially the plow potatoes!) and the staff was very nice. We sat outside on the little patio where it was a bit chilly so one of the waiters offered me a cozy blanket to use during my meal! It made my experience even more enjoyable. I would recommend this place to everyone, it is worth the drive!
author: Katie M.

description: Was visiting sf for the weekend and came across this great brunch spot! Ordered the Plow breakfast plate and it was delicious! Their fresh baked biscuit is also a must try too! Although the wait to get a table was long, the food and the friendly staff made it worth the wait:)
author: Meredith P.

description:
Got to check this spot out on a random Thursday morning and the wait was only 15 minutes! I ordered the plow because I wanted to try their lemon ricotta pancakes and have potatoes and eggs. It was pretty much an obvious choice. The boyfriend ordered french toast with a side of potatoes. Let's just begin with how awesome their potatoes are! They do such a great job with them- I personally love it when the potatoes are super crispy. The pancakes and french toast were good too, but my favorite part of the meal were the potatoes for sure!

And I love how they offer blankets if you sit outside! How thoughtful!
author: Dara S.

description:
Finally got to try this place out... ive had this place bookmarked for a couple years!! Went here for brunch with my bff yesterday we both really enjoyed it here! We both ordered "the plow" which came with 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, potatos, two eggs, and your choice of sausage patties, bacon, or chicken apple sausage! We also got a glass of mimosas which were super refreshing! 

Overall I had a great experience here, it has such a cute ambiance, service was great and the servers were fast. One of the workers even refilled our glasses with more champagne towards the end and offered to take our picture! Definitely coming back!
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Most overrated place in town. We got there at 12pm and were seated at 3pm. The host gave us the expected wait time of 1 hour and it ended up being 3. We stayed because she kept saying it was going to be soon. 3 hour wait is understandable for such a busy place but not setting the right expectations is not okay. 

The food was meh to be honest, not close to the 3 hour wait. I'd suggest to avoid this place
author: David V.

description:
Everyday longgggg line!
I order the plow and french toast
All is ok but the french toast 
I think they soak bread too long
