Every plate is big portion think before you order
author: Gibkm O.

description:
Good, but not worth $66 (for 2) and an hour and a half wait. My wife loved the fresh fruit (but it was $7.50). She had the plow for her main and loved the pancakes. I had the soft scramble which was good but was light on the goat cheese.

Food came out quickly (in a good way) and the server was friendly and attentive.
author: Drew H.

description:
I'll start with this. Great food. If based solely on the food it would be five stars but two ladies that were working were dreadful. 

I was on my way to a business meeting and a co-worker was meeting me at this establishment. I walk in and ask for a table for 2. They explained they do not seat incomplete parties. That's ok no problem. A bit later I had asked since my coworker was going to be late to just sit in the bar area and order food my self since my co worker was running a few minutes late. After some evil eyes I was able to sit. 

I then went on to order two plates one for myself one for my co-worker. Shouldn't be a problem since this is an establishment that sells food and literally doubled the revenue let alone the tip. I had asked if I could get one to go and that seemed to ruffle some feathers. More on that later. 

My friend arrived shortly after and we enjoyed a wonderful meal. As said food was great but a lady interrupted us and said "for next time, this is why we don't sit people prior to having a complete party" 

My thoughts:

1.) I doubled your revenue and tip
2.) you only had to serve one person. 
3.) I am a paying customer if I want to order the whole menu who cares. Better for you right?

She then explained as I asked her to put something in the box " that they weren't doing to go orders because they were short staffed" I guess the guy or gal that puts things in boxes called in sick because we were both paying patrons. 

The last part of this was after I paid and was still gracious enough to leave these brats of humans a 20% tip. A lady came storming out with accusations of me leaving without paying. Rudely saying "tony, you left your card without paying I'm
Just going to run this for you" my name is Ryan.
author: Ryan P.

description:
A stellar brunch destination and easily within my Top 3 of all-time, but that wait is as ridiculous as many others have said.

My dungeness crab scramble was superb - loads of fresh crab meat and very balanced on the palate.  The accompanying potatoes were damn tasty as well in their exceptional crispiness.  My brotato opted for the plow and one bite of the lemon ricotta pancake was enough have me sold.  I loved the delicate, fluffy texture complemented by the mild, balanced flavors of citrus and ricotta.  Everything was in harmony and I could easily see myself devouring a full plate of these the next time I'm around.

Definitely try to come around opening time if possible and just be prepared to build your appetite up a fair bit if that doesn't pan out.
author: Eric F.

description:
In one word? Wow.  This place is great. 

The food (soft scrambled eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, regular scrambled eggs) was fresh and delicious.  I'm not a pancake junkie, but I don't remember ever having better pancakes than these. They're lighter than they sound and they're reasonably sized. 

Fast and friendly service.  Plenty of natural light inside. 

Yes, there will be a wait. Yes, it will be worth it.
author: Joe G.

description: Came on a Sun very close to closing and still had to wait maybe 45 min. Pretty standard brunch cuisine, but a cozy nice place to spend your weekend brunch. I got The Plow which was decent. Really enjoyed the homemade pork sausage- delicious. The ricotta lemon pancakes are actually quite small and dense. I  also tried a bit of the crab scramble which was tasty with the creme fraiche on top. Equator coffee was good. Overall- a good standard brunch, very very very long lines so if you are in no hurry at all enjoy a leisurely wait here.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Always an excellent brunch here.

THE WAIT
They open at 8am on Sundays, and we got there at 8:11am.  There was already a line around the corner, but it was moving. We got on the list around 8:20am and had just barely missed the first wave of seating. They estimated a 30-minute wait, and we got a table inside around 8:50am!

SERVICE
Friendly and efficient.

THE COST
$66.61 before tips for 2 coffees, 1 starter, 2 sides, and 2 entrees. A very reasonable brunch for three.

MUST -HAVES
As always: Lemon Ricotta Pancake, anything with their potatoes.

* Chia seed pudding (almond milk, coconut, honey, almonds, bee pollen, apples, raw hemp seeds. $9.25) - 4.5 stars
My boyfriend's mom really enjoyed this. It was a nicely done, light breakfast. She wants to learn the recipe and make it herself!

* Breakfast sandwich + bacon & avocado ($17.50) - 4.5 stars
Always a great sandwich with quality ingredients. The potatoes, as always, easily the best in the city.

* Soft scrambled eggs (stinging nettles, shiitake mushrooms, goat cheese. $15.75) - 4 stars
Great texture to the egg, love the combo of cheese and mushrooms. Excellent potatoes.

SIDES
* One lemon ricotta pancake ($5.50) - 5 stars
Always amazing!

* One pumpkin pancake ($5.50) - 4 stars
Great seasonal item, though somehow not as moist as the lemon ricotta, and missing that interesting pop in flavor.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Got here at 7:40am and there were like 7 people ahead of us.  Was really excited to get here since I've seen all the reviews and pictures and everything looked really amazing.  We were seated quickly after they opened up the doors.  The place is really cute inside but kind of small.  It was nice to see that they brought out tables and chairs to further accommodate the patrons.  Although a bit chilly, in my opinion...My son and I ordered "The Plow" and it was good...but nothing majorly spectacular.  The bacon we ordered on the side seemed okay.  Kind of pricey at $4 for the few small strips.  The pork sausage was just okay as well.  I mean everything tasted good - just not THAT good.  If that makes sense.  What I enjoyed the most was the coffee (LOL) and the lemon ricotta pancakes.  I liked those.  Maybe may come back but will not wait in that line again.  Service was also excellent - friendly waitstaff.
author: Jill P.

description: The wait for brunch is very long, especially on the weekends, but oh so worth it! I had their plow brunch plate and it was just the perfect amount of food and over the top deliciousness! My favorite was the lemon pancakes, sooooo good! Definitely would love to go back. The food and the service was great.
author: Nita C.

description:
Best eggs I've ever had! Very filling brunch place..
+ Ordered the perfect thing (for my taste) - soft scrambled eggs (shiitake mushrooms, stinging nettles, goat cheese, plow potatoes + toast) LOVED IT!
+ tried to famous lemon ricotta pancakes as well - really fluffy and different from regular pancakes and I liked it but was definitely too full (even tho I ordered it as a side)
+ my friend also enjoyed her condensed milk toast very much :)
+ the aesthetics of the place are gorgeous!!
+ really friendly waiters and waitresses (they check up on you and are helpful)
+ played nice background music too!!

- long wait time so expect that (even on a thurs morning)! You can put your name down and come back though,which is what I did (there's a coffee shop not too far from here just down the street that was really cozy called Farley's where you can order coffee and wait)
author: Mahima D.

description: Long line but worth it! The potatoes are sooo good! I ordered the breakfast sandwich and added a grapefruit mimosa
author: Ebony T.

description:
Warning: Only go eat at PLOW if you're okay with most breakfasts thereafter dulling in comparison. As PLOW provides the things that Brunch dreams are made of.

As a LA native, I've been coming to SF for years and have long tried to make it to PLOW but there was always a heinous long line or I wasn't able to make it before 2PM. 

Well, as fate would have it, my first official day as a San Francisco resident, was the day we would me meet PLOW for brunch. Arrived at around 1pm on a Tuesday (still a full house but no line). There was one table left outside and the weather was great so we went for it and were seated immediately. 

My hubby and I shared the Breakfast Sandwich + Potatoes plate & the Ricotta Pancakes (comes with 3). 

* Crispy Potatoes- the best we've had- a must! 
* Ricotta Pancakes delicious & not too sweet
* Breakfast sandwich Delish with avocado 

Service was prompt, efficient and very pleasant. We'll be back. I almost don't want YOU to go... because then the lines will get even longer... but not telling you how crazy good this place is would be just selfish of me.
author: Amanda A.

description: Best darn brunch spot in all of SF.  Go early on a weekend or a weekday or you'll be stuck waiting for hours.  The dishes are overwhelmingly delicious!
author: Alyssa L.

description:
This place has a menu that makes your mouth water. I took the waitresses advice and went with the prosciutto and gruyere toast and it was really good and the potatoes are no joke and come out crispy and taste of rosemary. 

My dining partner however, received the wrong dish. The waitress gracefully brought the correct dish but it was awkward eating while my friend was still waiting. Despite that and the wait time I would try it again especially because I want to try the monte cristo sandwich with House preserves that change seasonally.
author: Jeannine A.

description: Omg, when I used to live in Poterero Hill. .T H I S was the spot I'd take my friends and family from outta town or if  it was my choice for brunch. I loved their lemon ricotta pancakes so much when I make pancakes its lemon ricotta. :) I've actually tried other items on the menu. Yum. But my favorite will always be the lemon ricotta pancakes.
author: Erin S.

description:
Love this place for Brunch, even if I kind of hoped that they were less well known because the line is crazzzzzy long! But we can't blame them for being so popular! They are delicious!!!

Love everything here but my favorite is probably the prosciutto croque monsieur and their almond flour pancakes!
author: Looblue L.

description: Overall food was great pork chop was cooked perfectly. Potatoes were well seasoned. Only bad thing was the service staff took a while to check up on us and provide us milk for our coffee by the time we knew it out coffee was already cold. Overall great place with good food
author: Ivan C.

description:
I've been to Plow twice now and it's one of those places you would definitely trade sleeping in for. They open at 8am on the weekends you better believe there's a line forming starting at 7:30am, if not earlier. Outdoor seating doesn't get going until 8:30am, so once the inside fills up with the early birds, it's just a waiting game. Luckily, there's a coffee shop a few buildings down so you can grab a cup to pass the time and saunter back. No buzzers, your name is just called, so make sure someone in your party stays behind in the event there's a rare opening!

I'm a big proponent of doing a sweet dish as an amuse bouche for brunch, and while you might be tempted to get the lemon ricotta pancake, do the HK style toast instead. It's a thick slice of brioche toast lathered with butter and then glazed with condensed milk. Better than a cinnamon roll. Trust.

The bfast sandwich is no joke. The minute my cousin bit into it (which was comical to watch her try to figure out how), the yolk sprayed everywhere. All up her sleeve. While maybe not ideal, definitely the sign of a beast of a sandwich with an egg cooked just right! The waitress came by to check on us, saw the mess, and chuckled..."happens all the time."

If you want a more sophisticated version of a bfast sandwich go with the prosciutto and Gruyere toast. It was like a gorgeous charcuterie/cheese board in bfast form.

Both dishes come with their signature twice fried/baked Rosemary-Ed, etc potatoes.

Sitting outside is ideal, as the tables inside are a little too close for comfort. Service is friendly and efficient, as they want to turn over those tables fast!
author: Katie B.

description: The place is really nice and the service friendly. However , and after having tried many places in SF ( sweet maple, Mymi etc) the brunch fell a bit short. The plow breakfast is ok, especially the lemon pancakes tasty, however the fried potatoes are not to die for, and I was actually hungry despite the hefty price tag. It is ok, but after one or two days I won't remember it
author: Emmanuel B.

description: We've been wanting to go here for a long time but the wait is always too long and we're too hungry. Today we were determined to get there right at opening on a Sunday thinking we would have better luck. They open at 8 and we got there at 8:08. By then it was already a 35 min wait for two. We walked down the street to a coffee shop to wait. It was freezing outside. The food was good and priced fairly. Idk if the wait is worth it though.
author: Amela M.

description:
In the cutthroat brunch scene that is San Francisco, Plow shines as one of the best. If its not obvious from the wait/long lines on the weekends or the confusing fact they typically have a small wait during the week this place is popular for good reason. The restaurant itself is small, inside there is a small counter and the seating with tables can get tight so don't be surprised if you touch your neighbors shoulder. They also have outside seating which can be a good option depending on the day. Don't let the size of the place fool you because the food they make will make you forget about the seating arrangement. 
My go-to items are the breakfast sandwich (I recommend you treat yoself and get bacon and or avocado on it cause it dials up the awesomeness), buttermilk biscuits (make sure to get plenty of the rich sweet honey butter), and lemon ricotta pancakes. FYI the biscuits do run out so don't be sad if you get there late and they are out. However my favorite thing to order is The Plow, their namesake dish. You get 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, 2 eggs, potatoes, and choice of protein. The lemon ricotta pancakes are served with maple syrup and are fluffy delicious. They have just the right balance of lemon and ricotta so the pancake isn't soggy. While I'm partial to bacon as my protein side, their other options the pork sausage patties and chicken apple sausage are also quite good. If you're extra hungry or just appreciate a variety of breakfast proteins, order an extra side with your order and you'll be a happy camper.
author: Peter P.

description: I can't say enough good good things about this place. The food was just so amazing. Aside from that the service was above and beyond. We came right before closing. We waited only 10 minutes for a table and the staff made sure that we always had something in our hand and their full attention. Ill be back here and you should come too!
author: Joanna K.

description: A great brunch place with amazing food! My two friends and I decided to come here early (right when it opens) since we read from the Yelp reviews that the wait would be an hour to an hour and a half. We came on a Sunday and we drove by at 7:55ish (it opens at 8am on weekends) and there was already a long line, so I can't imagine how early the people came and waited in line! We dropped off one of my friends so he could stand in line while we were looking for parking. Parking wasn't too bad, considering it was around 8am, and there's street parking nearby (90 degree street parking on hills). We proceeded to wait in line, and the line was quick, only for us to discover that the hostess was just taking down how many people were in your party and whether if you preferred sitting outside, inside, or no preference. She told us it would take 45 min before we were seated (we had 3 people and said we were fine sitting outside). I can imagine the long wait time for being seated since the venue is small, and the outside seating only had a few tables as well. When we checked in to see what our position in line was, it turned out that they already called us (though we missed it), but they told us we were next in line to be seated outside. So in total, our wait time was about an hour. Since it was a bit chilly, they offered blankets while we ate, which was a nice touch. The service was efficient and attentive. My friends really love biscuits so she ordered a biscuit as an appetizer and it was warm and delicious. I ordered The Plow, since it had a little bit of everything. It comes with 2 eggs, a choice of meat (I got the housemade pork sausage, potatoes, and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes. Although the items seemed small on the plate, it filled me up. The eggs were fluffy (I got them scrambled), the meat was a little dry but well seasoned, the potatoes were nice and crispy, and the pancakes were amazing and lemon-y. Overall, the food was amazing, though the wait time is a bit of a downer but there's plenty of places to walk around to while you wait, and if you're in the company of great friends, the wait time is no problem at all!
author: Lisa C.

description:
HOLY SHIT!!! I came here visiting from Los Angeles & let me tell you, Plow was the highlight of our trip! All around BOMB brunch. Everything was amazing. I came at 9 AM on a Friday. (Black Friday to be exact) For a table for 4 we were quoted 1-1.5 hours and we were definitely turned off at first.. but then after failing to find a bar open that early to kill time while we waited, we came back at 9:30 to find out that all the other parties got discouraged by the quote time and left meaning we got sat after only a 30 minute wait! yay~! (So try to stick around despite being quoted a long time AND try to come early!) We got seated outside & it was a bit chilly but they offer blankets for every seat! Kudos.

I forget who our server was, but she was very down to earth and nice despite it being quite busy. NOW on to the important part: THE FOOD.

THE PLOW:
effffinggg AMAZING.

Lemon Ricotta Pancake? Small, but amazing. Fluffy and perfect flavor. Sad that I didn't try the other ones cuz they sounded just as appetizing.

House-made Sausage? Really good (recommended by server.) However, my friend got the apple something chicken sausage and THAT was astronomical. I'd say go for that one cuz that blew our minds.

Fried Potatoes? Best I've ever had, hands down. Perfect thin crisp on the outside. Seasoning just perfect, not overly salted with the perfect amount of rosemary coming through. Inside nice and soft, perfectly boiled. 

Soft Scrambled Eggs? This is how they do their eggs and boy do they do it gooooooood.

We also got the honey butter biscuit which was big and yummy. (though I have had better biscuits) BUT to be fair this was more scone-like and we did thoroughly enjoy them.

My only regret is not getting the other pancakes or the prosciutto and gruyere (because I had another reservation elsewhere for lunch right after.)

Plow, I will be dreaming of you until I get a chance to return.

Cheers to the team at Plow! You deserve more praise!!!
author: Mae Louise L.

description:
Dear Plow,
Inside your quaint dining room, a pleasure it is to chow.
Your potatoes are superbly crispy and pancakes impeccably fluffy.
I'm glad the eggs benny has no shrimp in it.
Otherwise my cheeks would turn puffy.

Surprisingly, but somehow,
This Filipino boy, hailing from the islands of Luzon, Visayas and Mindanao,
Ordered your sinful egg sandwich, which the waitress said would explode.
When swiftly sliced down the middle,
Ooze from the yolk cascades like the ice cream over warm pie a la mode.

All I can say is wow, so go on and take a bow.
The title of "Best Brunch in SF", truly deserving of art thou.
Enduring your 2 hour wait is worth it - at least for now.
I like dogs and hate cats.
But woof doesn't rhyme; what does is meow.
author: Miko B.

description:
The exact type of trendy/delicious brunch you're probably looking for in San Francisco. My friend, a local to SF, wanted to try the restaurant and chose to take me along. It's situated right on a corner overlooking SF and offers both indoor and outdoor seating. 

We sat after around 5 minutes, and asked our knowledgeable waitress many questions about the menu which she fielded perfectly. I ordered the soft scramble with a side of chicken apple sausage, and my friend had the breakfast sandwich with avocado. 

My meal navigated the perfect balance between filling, aesthetic, (somewhat healthy?), and absolutely delicious. You could tell the ingredients came from fresh sources and the dishes were freshly made. As strange as it is to say, the potatoes were addicting and one of the best parts of the meal, but the rustic bread and fluffy eggs also both held their own. 

Even the service was impeccable. Our waitress came to check on us multiple times in the hour we dined, and our water jug never ran empty.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Visited her with the girlfriend the other morning for a quick bite before work (around 0800), no wait, plenty of tables, and great service. I was surprised that there was no wait, so if you're looking to beat the crowds I'd say show up early or prepare to sit outside in the cold.

Ordered up the Plow (number one seller) with Lemon Ricotta Pancakes plus I went ahead and added bacon on the side even though the plate comes with sausages and potatoes. Also ordered one of their famous biscuits which I did finish. 

The potatoes from Plow were featured on 7x7's best things/places to eat in San Francisco a few years back and I can understand why. Roasted and cooked to perfection, seasoned just right and the perfect compliment to the pancakes. I enjoyed the meal very much with the potatoes and biscuit being my favorite. It's a large biscuit so if you're not planning on eating it all or sharing, I'd say order it to go.
author: John M.

description:
Popped in by myself on a Monday morning ~8:45AM and was able to immediately grab one of the empty counter seats. Service was prompt and friendly with the staff offering a lint brush to me after seeing me absentmindedly brushing off lint from the white napkin in my black pants. 

Food was excellent per usual! I always end up ordering the Plow in order to grab a bite of their pancakes but also have their house made sausage patties and amazing potatoes. I've waited a very long time in the past which of course impacts the overall experience here, so I do recommend visiting at a more unusual time if possibly instead of peak weekend brunch hours.
author: Kellyn W.

description:
A light, delicate, won't leave you feeling stuffed, breakfast place!

Came on a Saturday around 10 and the wait was an hour and a half, but the actual wait was only 45 minutes. 

My friend and I shared the breakfast sandwich, which is two eggs fried soft, aioli, cheddar, Acme bread, frisee and of course we added avocado. The aioli really made the sandwich tasty and they give a lot of avocado! This entree also came with plow potatoes which are fried, so the texture is crispier than most breakfast potatoes. I actually forgot to take a picture of my own food but took pictures of everyone else's food... I must have been too excited to eat. 

I also got to try the chia seed pudding, which was light and delicious! The peaches they used were SUPER sweet and the pudding had a eccentric texture with all those chia seeds incorporated. 

Another preference is that most of my friends preferred the chicken apple sausages over the bacon, if you're ordering the plow, which is what they're named after.
author: Samantha C.

description: The place looks so promising but it's way overpriced for what you get. Ordered summer succotash and really what you get is 3 beans with some bit of other veg swimming in water and two eggs on top. Just not wowed considering it's $17! Other dishes looked more impressive but I feel I've been ripped off.
author: Anya M.

description:
Delicious food! Quaint place, but they are EFFICIENT! Staff is very friendly and fast moving! 
The Lemon Ricotta pancakes are AMAZING, full of flavor yet light, I could eat them all day! The Prosciutto and Gruyere Toast is absolutely delicious if you're looking for savory! The house potatoes are crispy fried with just the right amount of rosemary, they compliment every dish. Will absolutely come back when we visit the city again!!
author: Marissa E.

description: Wonderful! As a St Louis native moving to SF I'm still exploring the city and looking for new places to try. I found this place and cant say enough great things. Had a little bit of a wait on a Friday morning as an individual but no more than 20 minuets. Once inside and seated, it was great! The staff was so friendly, and the everything that came out of the kitchen looked/smelled amazing. It was way too hard to choose. I settled on the crab scramble. I was not disappointed   wow. Everything was spectacular! Those plow potatoes- man. I could have just eaten a plate of those by themselves. Will definitely be back.
author: Kejla A.

description:
There's a reason there is a 45 minute wait for this place on a weekday for brunch: it's really good. There's coffee while you wait on this corner with nice little benches all over the place.

I got the plow. This was your standard full breakfast with some incredibly nice twists. I chose the bacon, which was very much not standard. It was incredibly smokey and full of flavor. Never had this type of bacon before, and it was awesome. Eggs - standard. Potatoes were quite good. Slightly crispy, soft and warm on the inside. Seasoned with several herbs. I personally enjoy eating this with the egg yolks, but that is up to you. Lemon ricotta pancakes are as good as everyone says they are. Light, fluffy, and flavors everywhere. Lemony to match the fluffiness, and the ricotta there to give it that extra bite. Man these were good. I was also able to taste the almond pancakes which were good, but the lemon ricotta is king. They are a bit on the smaller side with ordered with the plow, but that's because you wouldn't be able to finish it all if they were larger. 

Service is great. We sat outside on this nice day, but it was quite nice. Highly recommend this place. Would come back if I'm in the city early enough to not get too hungry waiting in line.
author: Bryant C.

description: Nice area and nice day to wait outside. I drink black coffee and taste the coffee not the sugar and cream and this was terrible coffee!!! I had eggs benedict with salmon. The sauce was way too lemony or vinegary, I could not tell, and it left a heavy feeling in my stomach for most of the rest of the day. The potatoes were very good.
author: Gabriel M.

description:
My party arrived about 10 minutes prior to opening on a Saturday morning and whooo-wheee, there was already a line with 8-10 parties ahead of us. I lost count because it seems one person would stand in line and people who arrived later would come in and out. We put our name down and they told us it would be about 45 minutes to an hour wait. 

My group of 3 didn't mind, it was the first time for my SO and munchkin to be in SF so we decided to wander the streets and enjoy the architecture and the quiet of this area before it became a bustling area. Once we arrived back about 30 minutes later, we waited around and chatted with some other families who recommended some places for us to check out as well as dishes to try here at Plow. We ended up ordering THE PLOW and the Apple Cinnamon loaf as well as a kids meal. There was more than enough food for everyone. It was a SOLID breakfast. 

The only reason I'm not giving it a higher review is for the customer service and the wait time for the food on top of the wait time to take a seat. I'm not sure if it's because it's super busy or if they didn't have enough servers, it was difficult to flag someone down for more coffee or even the check. As for the food, we placed our order as soon as we sat down and still waited an additional 20-30 minutes for our food to appear.
author: Farah M.

description: Good food, just wish there was a bit more seating area & can get really busy. Plow potatoes were
author: Nadia P.

description: Although the lemon ricotta pancakes were wonderfully fragrant and tender off the fork, my favorite part of the day was sitting at the counter and watching the cooks hustle in the kitchen and flip all the pancakes on the crowded griddle.  Nobody works harder.
author: Sara N.

description: The place is pretty, but almost always will have people waiting to get in so, expect to spend some time waiting. For vegetarians their menu is a bit restricted, they don't encourage changes or alterations. Their potatoes are delectable! The eggs and bread are fine, I had better variations in LA!
author: Premila M.

description:
Totally worth the wait - as long as you order the right things. It's tempting to opt for The Plow and get your classic American breakfast fix, but the rest of the menu is just so good. 

My friend and I arrived at 8:10am on Sunday and waited about an hour for a table inside. They offer blankets if you are ok with sitting outside, but we didn't mind waiting the extra 15 min or so on top of the overall wait time to be warm. Everything on the menu sounded delicious - we decided on the buttermilk biscuit, crab scramble, breakfast sandwich with avocado, lemon ricotta pancakes, a side of bacon and mimosas. 

We couldn't decide which item we liked most because it was all just so good. The biscuit was just perfection and a great item to share as an appetizer. The scramble and sandwich were perfect as entrees and the order of pancakes were a great idea to share so you get both savory and sweet. 

At the end of the meal we both agreed that the wait was worth it. I think you just have to be mentally ready for it and you'll be fine.
author: Roshni B.

description:
I felt #basic one day so I walked in wanting to try it with few of my coworkers. I would value this brunch place at a max wait of 45 minutes - usually on weekends it could be a 1.5-2 hour wait.

Things I would recommend: The Plow - comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, choice of sausage meats, eggs, and potatoes (I would highly recommend subbing the potatoes for fruit - you get fresh mango, berries, grapefruit super unique for a brunch place), the Chinese breakfast (pork shoulder with some spicy sauce), and others.

In terms of drinks the grapefruit mimosa has a fresh fruit and is pretty strong (if you're trying to have a turnt up day then go for it). 

Service is good. Comparable to Mission beach cafe, Sweet Maple, and all those other brunch giants.
author: Kunal T.

description:
Good? Yeah sure. Worth the weekend wait? Unfortunately not.

I was super excited to finally come to plow, I plowed myself out of bed at 7am just to make it to plow by 7:55am right before opening. At that point, there was already a long line! Omg, crazy! (It must be amazing for everyone to be lining up like they line up for new iphone releases). We didn't make it to the first seating, so ended up going to a near by coffee shop to wait for 30min, came back and there was an available table for us. Woohoo.

The staff, though super busy was attentive and very friendly. We ordered a coconut mochi cake, The Plow, breakfast sandwich and French toast. 

My favorite was probably the mochi cake and everything else was pretty good but nothing mind blowing. The French toast and breakfast sandwich were both decent but the way it's made feels like you can do it yourself at home. The plow had lemon ricotta pancakes which were probably the highlight of that dish. 

Coffee was subpar :(, id just get coffee next door. 

Overall, good experience and if there weren't a line, I'd definitely go more often since it is that comfort brunch food that you'd want on a Sunday morning. 

I've heard from others that their weekday lunch menu is better and dishes are more special, maybe that's what I'm missing from this review. I'll have to try it again on a weekday.
author: Rohenne L.

description:
I finally made it to Plow!

My girl friend had been telling me that I have to try the lemon ricotta pancake at Plow - as a person who's not a fan of pancake, it has to be really good pancake to "wow" me - and Plow did it!

It was a rainy Friday and I got there a little past noon. Because of the rain there was a uniform line waiting outside the door. At first I thought we just line up to get in, but then I figured out you have to tell them your name so you will be on the wait list. Luckily it didn't take me long enough to find out, or else I won't be eating there!

I waited for almost an hour for 3 people. I have to say it's a bit crazy especially it's on a week day. Menu was simple - a variety of brunch items. The three of us decided to get the Plow with homemade sausage (recommended by our waitress), dungeness crab scramble and prosciutto gruyere egg toast. We have also ordered a side of the hk style toast (as a person from hk I felt obligated to order that lol~).

Food came out pretty fast. I got to try everything (except the meat) and everything was so good! Pancake was so good that we ended up ordering an extra side of it. I like how the hk style toast was burnt, which brought out the flavor of the toast and matched perfectly with the condensed milk. And the potatoes! I usually left out the potatoes on brunch dishes but I got to say Plow made some really good potatoes. 

It's hard to say if I ever gonna go back since there are still a lot of brunch places to try out in the city. But if you haven't been to Plow yet, make sure to put them on your to go list!
author: Louisa L.

description:
Plow sure does plow a hole in my wallet! 

The Plow is famous for their brunch and notorious for the wait, which is usually at least an hour on weekends. TL;DR is it worth the wait? No, it's not worth the horrendous weekend wait; however, it is worth the hassles of going early on a weekday. 

The menu is always changing, with some staples such as the plow, the breakfast sandwich, some type of French toast, and the buttermilk biscuit. It seemed like some of the specialties could be hit-or-miss (I saw someone next to me get something that looked fancy but small.) I'm also usually a fan of French toast, but in a lot of pictures it was surprisingly burnt here. Thus, I went with their signature plow. 

The Plow plate is the epitome of perfection on classic brunch items. In fact, I was almost going to pass on Plow because it seemed so commonplace, yet so professionally crafted. It seemed as if so much thought had been put into every detail, you could perform mindful eating with your otherwise mundane sausage/bacon, eggs, potatoes, and pancakes. My thoughts:

1. Lemon ricotta pancakes - the most memorable! Soft and fluffy (albeit a bit burnt), with a refreshing lemon zest balanced by an attenuated sweetness and a touch of creamy ricotta.
2. House made sausage - a close second. The patties were wonderfully juicy without being too greasy, and I especially liked the extra dimension from the boldly heavy use of pepper and caraway. 
3. Potatoes - quite a bit of hype, but I found it to be just okay. It did have a nice crisp and aromatic tones from the rosemary, though I found the outer crunchy coating too thick, causing the potatoes to be too dry.
4. Eggs - Scrambled eggs pretty on point. The texture, consistency, and taste were all well executed. It used less butter than some of the more indulgent scrambles I've had, making it a lighter version.

I had expected portions to be bigger for the $17 pricetag on the bouge equivalent of a McDonald's big breakfast. If you eat it slowly, you'll enjoy it more and it the portion size turns turns out to lie within the narrow window of satisfaction without a debilitating food coma. Plow was memorable, delicious, and Instagram-worthy, but for a total of over $20 for a breakfasty plate, I don't think it's worthwhile to return after the one-time dining experience to cross it off my bucket list.

I arrived just after 7am on a weekday, and by the time I left around 8am the place was nearly full o_O Sometimes I feel like SF brunch is a encephalopathic pandemic.
author: Edna C.

description: Came here with Mom at a friend's suggestion for brunch. Seating is available both indoors & outdoors, although it will likely be a longer wait for seats indoors. Ended up sharing the cold-smoked salmon toast & the signature dish here called the Plow. First impressions here are nothing but positive. In regards to the cold-smoked salmon toast, the salmon this joint uses is really as tender, yummy, and pleasant to taste as I've ever had. Never realized how good farm-raised salmon could be ... something for me to remember for next time. The combination with farmer's cheese, pickled red onion, caper, dill, Acme levain, and simple green salad served only to complement the dish even better. As for the Plow, I loved the potatoes because of the seasoning that the chefs use on it, which is most stellar & left my mouth most happy. The lemon ricotta pancakes were just as soft, moist, and their tartiness was just perfect & not too overpowering. Eggs & sausage were also done well. Overall, a most pleasant place to come for brunch & I would definitely recommend it to others. Don't be surprised if there is a wait (there usually is).
author: Jack M.

description:
Plow is a cute little breakfast spot nestled in the residential neighborhood. Its a homey breakfast restaurant perfect for families and friends to check out when they're looking for a good hearty breakfast. Not the greasy diner food breakfast- but slightly elevated. 

Tip: There is always a line at the door so get there early or prepare to wait. Also seating is pretty limited so they cannot sit more than 6 people at a time. 

The breakfast sandwich was made with acme bread (yummo) and generous amounts of avocado. The aioli served on it was also very tasty. The potatoes had a crispy exterior and a soft center. Loaded with flavor from the onions and well seasoned. Staff was friendly and were great about checking in on us and making sure I had enough coffee refills.

The ricotta pancakes were fluffy and light and definitely had that great lemon flavor. All of the food was satisfying without being heavy and oily.
author: Kayla U.

description: My sister took me here when I was in the area and I was not disappointed the food is fantastic, I also added a biscuit which was sooooo yummy I would definitely recommend this place to anyone that loves brunch
author: Stacey L.

description:
Expect long wait times and delicious food.

The ricotta pancakes are extremely tasty and worth every penny!
author: Alison H.

description:
Came early on a Saturday morning and there was a wait but it wasn't too bad. I had the plow, which I think it's perfect because it has the ricotta pancakes, homemade sausage, eggs, and the best effing potatoes I've ever eaten! It's the best plate if you're indecisive  like me. 

The pancakes were fluffy and small, with a zesty lemon flavor. I thought the homemade sausage was kind of dry, but you do have your options of bacon as well. Now to the star of the plate, the crispy potatoes. Not sure what they cook it in, but it was so addicting!! It's hands down the best potatoes I've ever had, and is a must get!
author: Vy T.

description:
Don't think I've ever waited this long for brunch before which was shy of just 2 hours! Was it worth the wait? Find out in my review below. 

This restaurant is located in corner of an intersection. There is a steep hill right next to it, we parked on top of that hill which turned out to be quite the walk.  
Here is what we ordered: 

the plow  - two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes

The lemon ricotta pancakes here were the highlight here, small and fluffy and just the perfect ratio of lemon flavor mixed it. The plow potatoes were quite good too, crunchy and complements the rest of the breakfast plate. Be sure to mix it with the egg yolk for maximum yumminess! 

Beef Hash Skillet - two eggs, beef hash 
Pretty standard here, had better ones 

Overall the food was as expected it to be, I think the reason why the wait times were so long is because the restaurant is so small and cannot accommodate more than let's say 20-30 people at a time. 

The good thing about this place is that parking is easy to find since it is in a neighborhood. All in all, it is a good spot for brunch to cross of the list and onto the next one when I come back to visit!
author: Charlton C.

description:
All the food was tasty. If you put your name down, go get a coffee, bring a snack and catch up with friends during the wait, then, the wait doesn't seem horrendous. If I was coming truly just for food because I was hungry, though, it is pretty absurd. I think the best strategy to minimize wait time on a weekend is to go right before 2pm. There will still be a wait, but most people are going to think they are closing. They do a final wait list call at 2pm (so you have to be present), but if you are there, you will be seated. 

Food came out fast once you are seated and order. I had the plow. Love the lemon ricotta pancakes, and potatoes were deliciously prepared. House made sausage was eh...I would get the bacon instead.
author: M T.

description: This place was absolutely phenomenal.  Amazing friendly service with extremely fresh food.  Beautiful seating area aside with lap blankets provided when it's chilly.  The coffee was top notch too, highly recommend.
author: Laurie T.

description:
Every couple of weeks or so I sneak in here at 7 a.m. for a solo pre-work breakfast feast at the counter, and have never been disappointed with the food. I often choose the Plow, which is eggs, those devilishly good crispy potatoes, choice of meat (try the new-ish bacon confit, which is basically   a roasted piece of pork belly -- so yummy!), and a couple of those luscious mini lemon ricotta pancakes. It really is way too much food for one meal, so you might try my trick of eating no more than half of each item and taking the rest with me. I also love the french toast, which I had on today's visit, along with a side of that irresistible bacon confit (I just have to remember to rescue the remainder from the office fridge later today...). The dungeness scramble is also very good, with eggs that are cooked just a tolerable bit past runny. I'm freaked out by gross undercooked eggs, so this works for me.

The only down side for me is the coffee, which is a very bitter roast. I know that a lot of people seem to favor that over-roasted, super-bitter thing, but I'm not one of them. Give me a bitter cocktail any day (please!), but you can keep the bitter coffee. Really, I don't expect such a small kitchen to keep more than one type of roast on hand, so I do understand they have to pick something that a lot of people like. 

I've found the service to be attentive and oblivious at the same time. I'm pretty sure I was the very first person to put in my order this morning, but I saw a lot of food come out of the kitchen headed to tables that hadn't even settled on the menu before my order went in. When my food finally arrived about 16 minutes later, it didn't include the bacon confit side -- that was another 8 to 10 minutes in coming. None of this is a big deal if the server addresses the delay with a cheerful explanation, showing the customer that they haven't been forgotten. My server didn't say anything about any of it. Pretty disappointing. 

But make no mistake: this is a very good place. I don't think I'd try it on a weekend since I hear the wait is way over the top.
author: Teresa D.

description: I started coming to Plow when they first opened in 2010. Back then, they still had the lamb sandwich and it was one of the most memorable meals I've had (please bring it back!!). I moved away for 5 years and was skeptical whether they would maintain the standard. Boy, they did not disappoint! They are still just as delicious and still my favourite restaurant in SF. It is truly the ONLY restaurant I would call my favourite since so many places in SF are so overrated. I also notice that they added more selections to their menu recently, which is great because it encourages me to try something new. I can't wait until I can go again! Thank you, Plow, for bringing solid food to SF!
author: Wanda K.

description:
3 words: Lemon Ricotta Pancakes!!

I came here one morning with a friend alll the way from Castro Valley just to try Plow. It's been on my Yelp bookmarks for soo long! The wait was about 30 minutes once I put my name down. The indoor seating is a little limited and crowded; my friend and I were seated outside. Good thing it was a nice day out in SF. Not too cold and or too windy. 

I knew I wanted to order their Lemon Ricotta Pancakes for sure and although everyone recommended The Plow which comes with eggs, sausage, potatoes, and pancakes, I knew that would be too much food for me so I just planned on getting them as a side order. However, my friend said I could just take one of her pancakes so I did that instead and ordered the Coconut Chia Seed Pudding which came with seasonal fruit, bee pollen, and honey. The chia pudding was delicious and light and the pancake was probably the best lemon ricotta pancake I've ever tasted. It was super fluffy and you could actually taste the lemon! 

I would definitely recommend Plow to a friend or anyone looking for a nice brunch place in SF. And I would definitely recommend those pancakes! I'd probably come back just for the pancakes next time!
author: Jessica N.

description:
There are two parts to this review, the food and the experience. 

First, THE EXPERIENCE. My kids have Celiac disease and therefore need to eat gluten free and be wary of cross-contamination.  This is insanely hard to manage when you eat out, so my experience is always tainted by that. I spent hours and hours making a list of choices to eat in the Bay Area that could be safe-ish based on yelp reviews and website info. 
Plow had lots of Yelp reviews talking about the GF pancakes and people saying they were sensitive had NO problems there, so I decided it would be a great choice. I took my husband and 2 seven-year-olds and there was a wait, which was expected. We had snacked earlier. We were told 45 minutes, which was a lot, but figured we'd be ok. It was cold and windy on that corner and there is no indoor place to wait. So cold, that the sidewalk tables came with blankets for those brave enough to sit there. We waited across the street in the sun with other waiting guests.
We waited and waited. My kids had their tablets and were very good, but my husband's blood sugar was dipping and he was getting mad. We checked the list that was 10 pages long, not kidding, and kept being told it wasn't our turn. The 45 minutes quoted passed. I finally begged the hostess as my kids looked like they would cry, and she snapped at me that she told us 2-hours. Wait, what!? Um no, she didn't! I tried not to get mad and was holding back my tears at this point as I went back outside to wait. 

  ***See, a person with Celiac can't just walk into any restaurant and order food expecting it to be fine, because the way food is prepared makes it very unsafe for the most part. And these are kids. Usually you call the restaurant in advance or read lots of reviews, it's pretty exhausting when planning a trip. And there is always anxiety.***

So we just--kept--waiting. It was two hours until seated.
THE FOOD / Experience - Finally seated, I asked to order immediately for the kids. The server then tells me that their gluten free pancakes are NOT safe for my kids because they are made in the exact same spot as the other gluten food. *I had promised my kids yummy pancakes and thick bacon as seen in so many yelp reviews... I teared up at that point and my husband looked sick and furious. I asked could they please cook the food in a pan, that was washed, instead of on the griddle. She must have noticed the panic and excused herself. She came back and gave me a speech about how the chef would make an exception this ONCE as it was very busy (Yeah, I hadn't noticed) and we cannot expect to get our gluten free pancakes without gluten. me- Fine, fine, thank you, thank you! Can I get 2 orders of bacon? Her- Oh, that won't be gluten free either... Me- WHAAAAAt? It's meat... Her- Yes, but its par cooked on the griddle earlier, with the other gluten stuff.    O M G.   Ok, so thats how it went. The "children's meal" was $11 and came with 2 pancakes smaller than my hand, about 5" diameter, and a small dish of potatoes. Those were good, not amazing, but good -and the starving children liked them. Husband and I had the hash. The meat was good quality but dry, the dish was just ok, and really expensive also. So $70 dollars and 3 hours later... we learned a hard lesson to not buy the hype.

NOTE- The server tried hard to make it okay. And I really appreciate that she actually knew what gluten was and the dangers of cross-contamination to those with Celiac, because most people don't.
author: Jacquie G.

description: This place is seriously delicious breakfast.    Lots of baked goods, specialty flavored pancakes to house made muffins and scones, and of course yum egg dishes.     The energy is really fun.     Counter seating as well as window tables.     Get here early as they don'take reservations so it's a sign in sheet.
author: chris b.

description:
Simply the best!
Whatever you order, they won't disappoint you. 
The only thing is too long line...
author: JS P.

description:
Came here on a Saturday around noon, the wait was 1.5 hours for a party of 2. We put our names down and walked around the neighborhood to kill time (many, many hills beware). Walked back a little early, there were still a lot of people waiting outside. There are a few benches to sit on while you wait, so you wouldn't have to stand the entire time (they also serve you drinks and mimosas)! I think they still seat you after 2pm (when they close) as long as you put your name down ahead of time. 

We got: 
The Plow $17
- breakfast platter w/ eggs, sausage, potatoes, french toast (substitute for the lemon pancakes w/ an extra charge), the potatoes were SO GOOD. Perfect amount of crunch, everything else was also tasty 

Chia seed pudding $10
- pretty interesting, it was my first time trying chia pudding. Wasn't too sweet which I really enjoyed the fruit toppings were a little sour (apricots + peach) 

Side of bacon $5 
- basic bacon craving satisfied 

The price is a little high for brunch + the wait is terrible but overall a pretty good experience. Service was good, the guy who sat us was very welcoming. Would come back again!
author: Nancy C.

description:
Finally got my seat at plow this passed Saturday. Been waiting to come here for awhile. The week before I got to plow at 11:30am and it was a 2.5 hour wait for a party of 3. We couldn't wait because we were hungry. Came back this Saturday at 10:30am and it was 1.5 - 2 hour wait for a party of 2. WOW!!! I know, the wait is crazy long. Instead of just waiting outside, my friend and I decided to get coffee 2 blocks away to kill time. Also you can order coffee, drinks and baked goods from Plow as you wait for your table. 

It was slightly over 1.5 hour wait and got a seat at the counter. We ordered **Equator coffee $3.75. Unlimited refills. We started with their **Hong Kong style toast  buttered brioche + sweetened condensed milk. I was super excited because its been forever since I had condensed milk. The brioche we had was super dry. Was a bit disappointed with that. We had one piece and let the milk soak in to soften up the brioche. My friend had their famous **"The Plow". Comes with everything, two eggs, choice of protein, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes. She got the house made pork sausage patties. I thought it was super yummy. I got to try everything she had. I really like their triple fried plow potatoes. Must have!! I got their special **Cornbeef hash on poached eggs. I really like it. Wasn't too heavy. This dish is smaller in portion size but I thought it was perfect for me. 

Not my favorite in the city but it has became my TOP 5 BRUNCH in SF. Service was good, staff was friendly, especially the chefs.
author: Sandy B.

description: Lemon ricotta pancakes are the best I've had. Got the breakfast sandwich that was also very good. I rarely care for breakfast potatoes but they were tasty.
author: John L.

description:
One word: Overrated. The hype is disproportionate all around. This is a trendy, healthy spin on continental breakfast. Yes the food is good, but that's a standard met across the city. The food is not unique in concept nor content and the long lines you'll encounter after 8 am, moody staff, and pricy extras you need to buy to have a full meal make it overrated. 

Following up on that, my most recent experience here was terrible. My boyfriend was leaving for an extended trip and we decided to come at 7 am. We were friendly and yet from the start the waitress was quite rude. She actively glared at us, while smiling and laughing with their customers, went out of her way to not serve us unless we gesticulated wildly, and rushed us out before we even finished our food.
author: Quinn Li O.

description: Cute little spot on the hill. We were greeted quickly, sat immediately, and our table was greeted quickly. Our server was friendly and helpful, and our food came out within 10 mins. The god tasted fresh and we used their homemade hot sauce! It was tasteful. The entire menu actually was unique and there seemed to be an item for everyone. Their breakfast sandwich was good, although the egg was drippy which made it messy. May be easier to eat with scrambled eggs opposed to fried. The potatoes that came with it were cooked perfectly; crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. It was way overpriced but that was probably because rent is so expensive for them. I may come back in some time.
author: Elizabeth G.

description: Came here sunday morning around 9:30 and waited less than an hour for two people. My friend and I both ordered the Plow & it was amazing! I am a huge fan of lemon flavor so the lemon ricotta pancakes were delicious. Also, if you like sausage patties, the house made pork sausage is a must try. The Plow is the perfect amount of food to satisfy your brunch craving & I would definitely come back again.
author: Jennie J.

description: We went on a Saturday about 930 am. We ended up eating about an hour. But it was soo worth it. Their hash browns are the best!!!
author: Mizzie C.

description:
It's a chilly late-December morning in the week after Christmas. I have the day off work and so, visions of soft-scrambled eggs and crispy potatoes dancing in my head, I head over to Plow for breakfast. There's a line outside, as there always is, but when I inquire with the hostess about the wait time she says there's a seat opening up at the counter and it should be free in just 10 minutes. Only 10 minutes! Lucky me! I settle in for a short wait.

Understanding that things at a busy restaurant can take longer than expected, I wait some 30 minutes outside with nothing but a newspaper for company (no coffee, no seating)  before poking my head inside again to check on the wait. "Not too much longer," says the hostess. Back outside I go to chill, and I mean that in the sense of being cold. Somewhere in there I watch the hostess walk down the street and step directly in front of a (slowly, thank God) moving bus. Another 15 minutes pass so again, I ask to check on my progress. "Sorry, there's nothing available yet" says the hostess, looking agitated. Perhaps she's grumpy from getting honked at by the bus.

Fifty minutes after I first arrived--yes, that's 50, five with a zero after it, as in 5x the original estimated wait time--the hostess finally gestures for me to come inside. Alas, the seat isn't actually ready so she abandons me to stand in the small front lobby. For 5 minutes I wait awkwardly looking at the sign asking people not to stand in the small front lobby. At some point a busboy tries to shoo me outside.

Finally--oh, miracle of miracles! a place setting is prepared and I sit down at the counter. Frozen and too hungry to think straight, I eagerly accept the server's offer of coffee while I contemplate the menu. A man arrives and is seated next to me. He asks to order a moment later and the server obliges him, taking his food order ahead of mine. When he tries to chat me up later it takes a great deal of my self-restraint not to stab him with my fork.

"Ah, but how was the breakfast?" you ask. The breakfast was fine. Okay, taken on its own merits it was more than fine. The soft-scrambled eggs were creamy and tender with perfectly cooked mushrooms and greens. The Plow potatoes were hot and crispy. Their coffee is nice and strong and served in big hand-warming mugs. No one can dispute that Plow's cooks have their technique down. And just to be clear, I take no issue with Plow's long wait times as such--it was the completely bogus time estimate, along with the sneaking suspicion that I as a solo diner got bumped down the list--that had my hangrily grinding my teeth.

I share the tale of this ordeal with you, dear readers, because it prompted me to make a serious lifestyle change. No more waiting in line for brunch. Don't do it. Cook breakfast at home. You too can learn to make hollandaise sauce. Go out for pho or a bowl of porridge with Chinese doughnuts. Most pho restaurants even have coffee! Anything but the interminable wait accompanied by the gurgling Gastrointestinal Orchestra of hunger. Fellow San Franciscans, look around you and see: The Brunch Emperor wears no clothes.
author: Zare K.

description:
Had a recent impromptu SF trip that was all too brief. A dear friend recommended this place highly and it did not disappoint! 

Loved the local ingredients, the simple menu, the flavors of the food being able to dance for themselves--definitely worth the Lyft trip from SoMa. I'll be back in town in November and look forward to bringing my family by for some delicious breakfast  

Portions are filling, pricing is fair, quality is great, seating is cozy.
author: Melissa K.

description: Lemon ricotta pancake is as good as everyone else mentioned. Worth the try. I ordered 'The Plow'. The eggs, potato and sausage were well done but a bit salty for my taste. Would definitely order the pancake next time.
author: Vabs S.

description: Arrogant staff! This place got snobby. I asked a friend to join me for breakfast, but he's only going to have coffee and would join me half an hour later. There were empty tables and seatings, but the staff (tall black female), refused to seat me until my friend arrives. I told her he's only going to have coffee and she was adamant I would have to wait. I then suggested that I could have a seat at the counter and order my breakfast and when my friend arrive, she could move us to a two-seater, but that was not sufficient enough for her to seat me. She said no, I would have to wait period. I think I was dealing with a robot. Again, there were seats and tables available, plus plenty of seats at the counter. Wow, the level of arrogance is hard to comprehend in the city of San Francisco. I don't care how good this place is or how hungry I am, I will never put my foot in this place ever. I'm already full from the empty soul fed to me.
author: BN T.

description:
As busy as this place is, staff is super SUPER friendly. Not just on occasion but consistently friendly! Food? Oh dear....totally a foretelling of how the food will make you feel - warm and stuffed inside! Biscuit, must have!!!! 

Love that you can even get a cup of coffee while you wait. Staff is so nice about it!
author: M. H.

description:
Get ready to get plowed . This place is one of my favorite brunches but be warned about the line 

I usually get the plow plate and extra sides like bacon. The fruit juice are fresh and the pancakes are bomb. You can't go wrong with the food here for brunch!
author: Kevin L.

description: Always a long line but delicious. We walked around and checked out the cute bookstore a few blocks away while we waited about 40mins to an hour. I always get the prosciutto croissant and plow dish and share! Their buttermilk biscuit is also really good with coffee!
author: Jun Hee D.

description: Always a line. Limited seating while you wait. Open to coffee drinking while you wait. The wait. Let me tell you, the wait is typically 1 and a half hours. But so worth it. Great service and really good, hot off the stove. Get "The Plow". This is the famous dish with tiny lemon ricotta pancakes. You'll have a happy Sunday after this.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Finally got to eat here! 
We avoided the ridic long wait by coming on a weekday around 12:30. We were told the wait was 20 minutes and were seated at a communal table in about 15 min.

Food was AMAZING! I don't know if I would wait any longer than 45 min for a meal in SF but this place blows many hyped brunch places out of the water in terms of quality and deliciousness (*cough cough* Zazie). 

I ordered the Plow since I don't know when I'll be here again and it's got a little bit of everything. I was disappointed that they didn't have any of their biscuits (though at $4 each, that was probably a good thing). The best thing on the plate BY FAR were the potatoes. Breakfast potatoes can go so wrong and these were perfectly crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Pale, limp potatoes are such a travesty and Plow has mastered the art of frying/baking this humble vegetable. 

Second best thing were those lemon ricotta pancakes---sooooo good! Flavorful and lite. You don't really need the maple syrup at all on them!

Scrambled eggs and bacon were above average and quality was there. Entire plate was $17 which I thought was fair given the quality of ingredients and the portion size.

Would love to say "I'll be back" but the wait times are just silly so I probably won't be back again unless it's another random time on a weekday.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Really solid brunch. Waited an hour and a half on a Sunday morning at 10:15 AM. Ordered "The Plow". The potatoes and pancakes were perfect--the home fries in particular were maybe the best I've had. Pancakes were slightly crispy on the outside and super moist and creamy on the inside. The eggs were fine, cooked to order correctly which is about all you can ask for. The pork sausage was fine. My girlfriend ordered a two egg breakfast. The toast was good but I think the bread she got (a thick crust with an airy crumb) would have benefited from slightly thicker slices. The plating has great "Instagram appeal" if you're into that.

If price isn't a concern and you come with a small group at an off-time, it's a five-star place. I think the price (I paid ~$21 before tax and tip for my meal + orange juice, and didn't leave feeling particularly full) and expected wait (a little over 90 minutes for us) make it a four-star affair.
author: Andrew T.

description:
I came for brunch and stayed for Kanye.

If you want to feel pumped up and ready to party while you enjoy your delicious brunch, Plow is definitely the place to be in the city. 

The restaurant is small, but the vibe is 'popping' as the staff is all super friendly and fun and the music blasting through the restaurant will get you grooving in your seat (or up and about the restaurant if you're brave enough). 

I was in the mood for a bit of everything that day, so I decided to order the restaurant's namesake, The Plow, which is an all in one dish that consists of two eggs served in any style, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and a choice of pork, bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I asked for my eggs poached and I substituted a salad for the meat options.

The eggs were perfectly poached, but had no seasoning to them otherwise, and the salad was fresh and crispy, but again, bland. The standouts of the dish were the crispy potatoes and the lemon ricotta pancakes. The potatoes were so expertly seasoned and full of flavor -- they could quite easily be some of the best potatoes I've ever had. And those lemon ricotta pancakes were out of this world! The lemon is very present in the pancakes and is balanced nicely by the ricotta, and the syrup with the pancakes added a nice sweetness that wasn't overbearing. The pancakes were light and fluffy and don't sit heavy in your stomach. I'll definitely be coming back for those pancakes!

Something to keep in mind: Plow is one of the most popular brunch restaurants in SF, so expect a long wait time (at least 1.5 hours) on the weekend. However, if you're a brunch queen like me who's trying to catch 'em all, you are an expert on surviving the brunch hunger pains and boredom of long wait times, and having to wait no longer affects you. 

If you are not on a brunch quest like I am and you are willing to endure the long wait, bring a friend to keep you company, eat something light beforehand, and try to come as close to opening hours as you can, and you'll be brunching down in no time.

There is a lovely cafe across the street called Farley's that has plenty of indoor and outdoor seating and serves tea and light pastries where you can keep yourself from starving as you wait to be called. In general, the neighborhood where The Plow is located is really lovely and has a stunning view of the city skyline, so even if the wait is long, the environment is inviting. 

I'm putting The Plow on my list of brunch places to return to, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an exciting brunch spot!
author: Pooja M.

description:
My favorite underrated brunch place in SF! I feel like there isn't enough hype around Plow, but there is still always a wait. The wait on weekends can be about an hour; I came on my own on a weekday this time and had to wait ~20 minutes.

I had the dungeness crab scramble a while ago and remember loving it. I was really looking forward to getting more of it this recent time but it wasn't on the menu anymore, so I tried a couple new things instead.

1) Buttermilk biscuit with honey butter (5/5) - AMAZING. The biscuit is large, golden brown on the edges, and fluffy inside. The honey butter is essentially butter mixed lightly with honey, but the balance of the creamy saltiness of butter with the sweet was so good.

2) The plow - Combination plate that allowed me to try a lot of different components. Crispy potatoes (5/5) - YES, so crispy on the outside, really well seasoned, but still buttery on the inside. Two overeasy eggs (4/5) - no complaints on the eggs themselves, wish they could have salted it a bit more though. House-made pork sausage (5/5) - really flavorful, it tasted like they mixed in little pieces of onions and herbs into it. Lemon ricotta pancakes (4/5) - actually not quite what I expected, for all that I hear about these pancakes, I was a little disappointed. The pancakes tasted really good, with just a hint of lemon that wasn't overpowering. However, because of the ricotta, the texture of the pancakes is a lot more dense, and I prefer my pancakes fluffier and airy.

A bit out of the way over in Potrero, but the trek is worth it!
author: Tiffany P.

description: I happened to be in the area and found a parking spot right across the street walked in and to my delight was sat down right away at the counter. I ordered the plow with their homemade sausage which I found to be a bit on the dry side.The potatoes were okay I watched them being cooked in a deep fryer which kind of turned me off. The lemon ricotta pancakes were very good but the coffee was not as strong or as flavorful as I would have liked. I thought the service was great everybody was very friendly and a very good atmosphere but for the pricepoint I thought it fell a bit short with a 20% tip it ended up being $28.00 Not sure I would come back especially if I had to wait in line.
author: Leonard B.

description:
Went there on a Thursday at 8:30-ish and there was no line! :)  I had the French toast and thought it was good. Unlike one reviewer below, I didn't find it soggy at all. I feel it actually needed to soak in the egg mixture a bit longer. Maybe it depends on the day. I would still order it again. My husband tried the blood sausage and said it was ok. It has a very subtle flavor. I think there may be a hint of oregano in it. Don't confuse it with spicy Mexican chorizo. The coffee was good. 

Plow gets 5 stars for cleanliness and hustle of the kitchen workers. I haven't seen workers like that in YEARS! I even saw the manager/owner cleaning smudges off the window after some patrons left! Amazing! Wait staff was pleasant too. 

I just had one issue while I was there. A woman at the table across from me was speaking so loudly I couldn't hear myself or husband speak. Please think of your restaurant neighbors when dining. Thank you! 

Suggest to the restaurant: 

Put two trash cans in the bathroom.
author: Angela V.

description:
My friend and I got to Plow at 6:45 in the morning because we thought there were gonna be a lot of people after reading the other Yelp reviews. However, we realized that was WAY too early since there was no one around. We suggest people to come at exactly 7 during the weekdays. The restaurant quickly got busy after it opened and there was a line around 7:25.

For the food, we ordered the Plow ($17) and the Two Egg Breakfast ($15.75). The Plow included two eggs, a choice of meat (bacon/sausage), two lemon ricotta pancakes, and potato. While most of that dish tasted like any other breakfast place, the pancakes were a surprise to us. We both really like the pancakes because they were so fluffy and soft and I love the slight lemon taste in them. We had really wanted to try the Hong Kong style toast but our server told us they didn't have that or the custard French toast or the prosciutto toast. I guess we must have picked a bad morning. And now time to get some nap..... zZZzZzzz
author: Ida L.

description:
1st time here and we ordered the following:

-Equator Coffee (OK)
-Buttermilk Biscuit (Good)
-Steak + Eggs (Good) - The steaks were good
-The Plow (just OK) - Disappointed but the Potatoes were very good

*Friendly server :)
author: Wendy L.

description:
I can see why this place always has a line and have so many good reviews. We had a group of around 5 people. I personally like brunching with a decent sized group but it was a bit difficult for a table around that size. The restaurant isn't the biggest and can only fit so many people. There were more tables outside but it's so windy. Plow does provide blankets but I'm a bit meh about using blankets that everyone else have used (just me, I think). Also, it was so windy when we went here. Expect to wait at least half an hour for a table.
I ordered the plow with the apple chicken sausage, two sunny side up eggs, and the lemon ricotta pancakes. The platter was huge! Admittedly, it was a bit expensive but it's pretty worth it. Also, SF prices, sigh. I ate three quarters of the plate and was stuffed. The pancakes were so good and the sausages, full of flavor. But the star of the meal was the cinnamon roll that our table shared. Crispy on the outside and not covered in icing, which I totally prefer. I would come for the cinnamon roll all the time if I can. 
I took the rest to go. Sadly, lemon ricotta pancakes are not as good when it's cold. I recommend to eat the pancakes as fast as possible when you get it fresh. Although it's way out of the way of the suburbs and such, I think it's somewhere you have to come at least once.
author: Michelle R.

description:
Let's get this out of the way: There will be a wait....now if you don't want to wait, get your ass out of bed earlier, dude! It's not that hard, especially for a place as fantastic as this.

The food really is something special here. When I went for the first time, I was alone so I sat the counter, which gave me an opportunity to watch their skillful cooks work their magic. It is a really intimate space, and everyone on staff is really adept at working together to make the operation run smoothly, especially considering the volume of patrons they serve each day.

I got signature "plow" breakfast plate with their house-made sausage patties, two eggs, the ridiculous rosemary and seat salt potatoes, and of course their famous lemon ricotta pancakes. Everything was superb, and as I sat there enjoying my meal, I saw several other dishes being prepared that also looked to die for, so I will be back.  

and if you're feeling the need to walk off the food coma that will most certainly fall into once you are done, they are located at the base of a nice long hill that provides a great view from the top.
author: Caddy M.

description: The Plow is my all-time choice everytime I go there for brunch! The biscuits is worth trying although it is very to be sold out.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Took my mom here for a birthday breakfast on Thursday March 23rd. 
The place is a little small so there was a bit of a wait for a table inside for 5 of us; there was no wait for the tables outside. One of the employees (Juan) went the extra mile and offered us coffee while we waited.
Our server was friendly as well as the rest of the staff. 
The Plow breakfast was the perfect size, potatoes are perfect and the lemon ricotta pancakes are so delicious. 
Will definitely return next time I visit San Francisco!
author: Crystal M.

description:
Incredibly tasty brunch options. I love the Plow with house made sausage, almond pancakes (they substituted almond flour pancakes for me bc I'm gluten free) and fresh eggs. 

Well worth the wait!
author: Kevin H.

description:
I enjoyed yet another brunch adventure with Nina Y. even though she had been here before. We waited for about 45 minutes in the freezing cold weather. For some reason I never seem to check the weather before I head to brunch in my maxi dress... #BRUNCH.

We were seated at the countertop facing the chefs. It's always fun to see them prepare each meal. I like that the menu is short and simple. For such a small place, patrons needs to make quick decisions! We ended up sharing the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and the Scrambled Eggs. Both tasted very light and healthy. Would recommend. The service was also wonderful.

Overall I felt like we spent longer waiting in line than actually eating and sipping our coffee, but it's definitely worth coming here to get a taste of those pancakes!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
About as warm and friendly of a neighborhood restaurant as you could ask for. We were lucky enough to be the last 3 seated (at the kitchen counter, highly recommended) for a Saturday breakfast once it opened up at 8. We shared two Plows (with delectable twice fried potatoes & lemon ricotta pancakes that are quite different, in a good way, than the ones at MyMy in Nob Hill) and a Gruyere Prosciutto plate (with an Instagram/porn-worthy garlic chili egg running overtop of the open-faced toast - WOW) and were treated warmly and with care from the moment we walked in the front door.

We ordered a cinnamon bun, which came out hot and fresh towards the end of the meal, and was simply orgasmic. The orange zest that's baked in is an incredibly palatable yet subtle addition to the already-near-perfect bun. 

Maxine, the owner, is one of the nicest people I've met in the industry of late, and I really appreciated her talking to us for quite some time during our meal and sharing stories with us. The chefs were hard working and communicated well to knock out ticket after ticket during the morning rush - they were fun to watch! Our service was outstanding throughout the meal. Can't wait to dine again in the friendly confines of Plow. It's worth the trip to Potrero in and of itself!
author: Andy L.

description: Can I give a breakfast place a 5 starts? Looks like there very few places I would do this, and one is Plow. Perfectly poached eggs, wonderful pancakes, and nice ambience.
author: Paco R.

description:
Maybe I had my hopes up too high? 

With the glowing reviews on Yelp of Plow, it has been my mission to come here and try this place out. One day, we decided to head here and make that happen. The wait was long - and was to be expected - like similar brunch places in SF, and especially for a place such as Plow. The place itself is very small. When we (finally) got seated, we were lucky enough to get the window seat of the restaurant, but even our waitress had a difficult time coming to our table to give us our menus/take our orders since there was another table REALLY close to us. I decided to get the Plow so I could get a little taste of everything, including the lemon ricotta pancakes I've been dying to try. The food came out at a reasonable time despite how busy the entire place was, and overall it was just...okay. The food tasted average, and the lemon ricotta pancakes I had were just, okay. I've had lemon ricotta pancakes at other restaurants that have wow'd me and made me want to keep eating even when I was extremely full, but this was just...meh. It wasn't terrible, but it also didn't make me want to wait on a busy day to come here either because I honestly don't think it'll be worth it. For the price we payed, the amount of time we waited, and the overall experience, it didn't make me feel this place is as spectacular as the reviews had made it out to be. I'd give this place 3.5 stars. 

Overall, this probably wouldn't be my first choice to get brunch in San Francisco.
author: Victoria K.

description: Best breakfast ever!! If you can't decide between Sweet and savory, order a single side of lemon ricotta pancakes... I left feeling like I should receive some kind of 'amazing orderer' award!
author: Brandi C.

description:
TL; DR - The food is good, but it isn't an hour plus wait good. 

I got the Plow with chicken apple sausage and eggs sunny side up. I would say the stars were the potatoes (perfect crispiness) and the baby ricotta pancakes which were tasty. The chicken apple sausage wasn't anything to write home about. 

The reason I gave this a 3 instead of 4 stars is because I wouldn't wait an hour for food I could just as easily make at home. There is a coffee shop across the street called Farley's to help tide you over while you wait. You will have to stick around the area though because they don't take down numbers.
author: David H.

description: Arrived right after they opened on a Sunday and asked to be seated outside as I brought my dog for a walk. It was just 2 of us, but they quoted our wait an hour. They were exactly right with the estimated time but to be honest it was not worth the wait. I know this place has tons of rave reviews but for the wait and price of the meal, I left dissatisfied and hungry. Service was good, and the food came out quickly, but the taste was mediocre and the variety was poor. Maybe this is a place for foodies which I am definitely not. I just wanted to have a nice breakfast with a friend. It's not for me.
author: illy m.

description:
The plow at the plow.

No matter how early you go, the wait is at least an hour. I came with a couple friends at 9:30am on a Saturday, and we weren't seated until 10:30am. Half the times I've waited before for brunch doesn't take that much time, but the brunch game in SF is always on point. Service here was efficient and welcoming, and street parking is everywhere.
