TIP: Drop your friends off to get a spot on the waitlist while you find parking.

All 3 of us ordered the Plow, and I also ordered a grapefruit mimosa along with my meal.

The Plow (two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and side of either bacon or sausages) was delicious. How did the potatoes stay so crispy the whole time, I will never know. They were well seasoned too. I expected the pancakes to be the highlight piece on my plate, as I've had them before. Sadly, these pancakes weren't as good as I remembered when I came here last. Yes, the sweet lemon and honey taste was there, but the flavors just wasn't as packed this time around. The grapefruit mimosa was alright. Nothing too special and isn't worth $10.5 a glass. I'd rather go to Radish for their unlimited grapefruit mimosas ($15/person).

I'd come back just for the pancakes.
author: Kevin S.

description:
This is one of the few brunch places out of many I have tried that I would actually come back to. It was definitely worth the wait and the public transportation to get here. 

The potatoes were AMAZING and the toast was really good as well. The patty was too salty, but it was really great that the waitress was observant enough to notice that I barely ate it and asked how it could've been improved. This showed to me that they cared about their customers and their food quality. It was a little overpriced, but I would still come back for more potatoes.
author: Catherine S.

description:
TBH I don't know what all the fuss is about.  This place is located in a great location... Great for us since we leave in Dogpatch... And there's excellent outdoor seating and the place is bright and has a lot of light inside....  It the food.... Not all that it's cracked up to be.  I had the egg sandwich with bacon and I felt that I could have gotten it anywhere.  Wasn't anything special, didn't taste particularly great, but not horrible either. 

Probably wouldn't come back since it's always super busy and there's always a wait.  Did I order the wrong thing??
author: Nyla K.

description: I eat here every time I visit San Francisco, and it is always good.  My favorite is the egg sandwich.
author: Bisley B.

description:
The stirred scramble (think: shitake mushrooms meets goat cheese) was incredible. I will most definitely be returning for this dish! My friend got the smoked salmon salad and the salmon was just right. 

Great service and delicious food. We didn't have to wait to get seated but that is not normal, typically it is a 1-2 hour wait on weekends.
author: Melissa C.

description: 1st time at Plow, there was a line, and I must say it was well worth the wait. The food is fantastic and flavorful. My partner ordered The Plow and I ordered Prosciutto & Gruyére Toast. The potatoes were crispy and came in a generous portion. The eggs were cooked right runny and yummy. Best of all the lemon ricotta pancake is to die for, it leaves an unforgettable taste in your mouth...it was moist and sweet with an instantaneous burst of lemon.
author: Tina L.

description: The plow meal was delicious! Potatoes were on point and the lemon pancakes were awesome -not too sweet, but just right. The wait was long on a Sunday but that was expected since the restaurant is small. so I would recommend planning on going for a little walk while you wait.
author: Shaina P.

description: The lemon pancakes were one of the best things I've ever eaten. The rest of the food was good as well.. but nothing compared to those little pancakes. We sat at the counter and were mesmerized by the amazing system that the cooks had going. We got there 5 minutes after they opened and were able to grab the LAST spot at the counter / entire restaurant. It was definitely popular!
author: Megan R.

description:
Holy breakfast of the Gods. This place lives up to the hype. You can't find too many traditional breakfasts/brunches anymore. Pop in here and order the aptly named "Plow" breakfast and watch your world change. 

I was a little doubtful of the rave reviews. After all, this is San Francisco and many a popular spot seems to have unusually good reviews based just on how trendy it is at the time. Fortunately, I came on a Wednesday when the wait was minimal and we sat almost immediately at the bar where we could watch the chefs work. Based on my buddy's recommendation, I ordered their self-titled brunch speciality: two eggs any style (I went poached), house made pork sausage patties, bacon or chicken apple sausage (I went with the sausage), potatoes and two lemon ricotta pancakes. I'm usually one to avoid lemon flavored foods, but I have to say these two flapjacks were some of the lightest, fluffiest, tastiest I've had in as long as I can remember. The eggs were perfectly cooked, the sausage savory and hot. The other real highlight was the potatoes, which are twice fried. Throw on a little hot sauce and you're in brunch heaven. 

Some waits are worth it, others are not. I'm here to say this is a brunch worth the wait, and worth coming back for.
author: Alex L.

description:
Went there today for brunch on a last minute decision. Luckily enough, it was a little chill outside and we didn't mind getting a table outside so we had to wait 15 minutes only to get a spot. They offered us some blankets and we got Equatorial yummy coffee right away so we barely had time to bother about the typical windy Sf weather.
They change the menu often, which I love! We can enter the website to check from which farm the ingredients come from, it's a little bit pricey for a breakfast/brunch but hey, you get what you pay for, right? If we want good quality, fresh ingredients and creativity and love on the preparation, nothing more fare than to pay for it. 
Ok, enough with the blablabla and let's talk about the food. I got the Pastrami, gruyere cheese toast, my husband got the tuna sandwich and we also shared a side of lemon ricotta pancake. Oh man, everything was incredible!! I highly recommend the toast, it's a bit on the heavy/rich flavor side, but what would you expect from a pastrami toast? I would not get an entire dish of pancakes myself but if you have a sweet tooth, go for it! They are fluffy and the lemon gives a little hint, I think they were the best pancakes I've ever tried on a restaurant before!! 
Both dishes come with a choice of house made potatoes (crunchy and delicious) or salad.
The service was very good too! Everyone greeted us with a big smile and they were always nice and appreciative for the patience of the costumers outside waiting for a table! I will be back for sure!!
Obs: many street parking available around the area! Huge plus!!
author: Laura C.

description: Probably the best french toast I've had all year. Super friendly and exceptionally diverse staff. Definitely worth waiting in line.
author: Mayra Lizzette Y.

description:
This was actually the first time that I've waited 2.5 hours for a meal... And it was raining too. Gosh that was really an experience I would rather not repeat. (Tip: go grab coffee at Philz while you're waiting!!!) 

The food was amazing! I got the plow, and the lemon ricotta pancakes + crispy potatoes just blew me away. I'm generally not a pancake lover, but those were so fluffy and smooth, it was almost like eating a cake. The potatoes were season so perfectly and had just the right crispiness, so that was honestly beautiful. I didn't care for the eggs or bacon tho, so I ended up just kinda pushing them away. 

Overall it was a great dining experience as the service was also pretty great. However I don't think I'll ever come back just because the wait is way too long and the food is kind of overpriced.
author: Diane Z.

description:
I can't believe it's taken me so long just to finally try Plow! I've definitely been missing out and will be back soon! 

We put our name down around 12PM on a Saturday and got seated at the counter within an hour. Not too bad of a wait as I had heard others had to wait almost two hours especially for a weekend! I think we got lucky. :) 

We were seated at the counter, overlooking the kitchen. Best seats in the house since we were able to watch the cooking process. :) I had the breakfast sandwich, which came with two eggs fried soft, cheddar, aioli, and frisee with added bacon. It also came with the plow potatoes on the side. The breakfast sandwich was amazingly delicious! Very filling and not too heavy! Eggs were cooked perfectly and the bacon added a nice crisp to the sandwich. The potatoes were cooked to perfection. It had a rosemary kind of flavor. Crispy on the outside. Very delicious. I also got to try the lemon ricotta pancake. Oh man, that was soo good! Fluffy and light with a hint of lemon flavor. Loved how the lemon flavor wasn't too overwhelming. Definitely a must order! Everything that I tried was five stars and definitely want me coming back for more. :)
author: Philana C.

description:
Plow is an excellent place for brunch! We came here at around 1:30pm on Sunday and had to wait around an hour to be seated. The place "closes" at 2pm, but as long as you are there before 2pm, they will take your name down and you will be seated. Right at 2pm, they do a final call from the waitlist, meaning they call out everyone on their waitlist and see who's there. More than half the people on the list aren't there so whoever they call out at 2pm AND is present is guaranteed a table past 2pm. The place is very tiny so a wait is inevitable. There is also seating outside and they provide blankets for outside tables as the area gets a bit chilly.

Parking: There is ample street parking near the area so parking wasn't a problem for us.

Food: We got the Plow ($17.50) and steak + eggs ($20). Both dishes were very delicious. The eggs were so fluffy and the potatoes were absolutely great. The food definitely made the hour wait worth it. There is not a single thing I didn't like about the food; it was delicious. I would definitely consider coming back here for brunch again. Make sure to get a dish with potatoes, they're amazing! Also, highly recommend scrambled eggs, they're super fluffy and taste amazing.

5/5 for a VERY delicious brunch spot, highly recommend!
author: Jen S.

description:
We came here on a Friday morning and there was also a queue (although more manageable than weekends). 

We had the plow, butcher's steak and pancakes. All were good but I thought the Butcher's steak was surprisingly excellent. 

Aromatic Equator coffee rounded off the great brunch. 

I would visit more often if not for the long queue!
author: Lindt C.

description:
Got "The Plow" w/ bacon, poached eggs, and the other stuff that comes with it, along with a side of Hong Kong toast

This is the best brunch spot I've been to so far, definitely recommend. Thank you
author: Nick O.

description:
Eh. I got the soft scrambled eggs and an almond pancake. 
Eh.
author: Christineeeeeee K.

description:
Food:
I went for brunch. I ordered the breakfast sandwich and everything about it was supreme. The brioche bun was perfectly toasted and buttery and the eggs were warm, creamy and perfectly sunny-side up. The country potatoes were rich in flavor and seasoning, and my favorite part: crispy. A lot of restaurants tend to make their french fries, hash browns, country potatoes etc a little soggy. Not Plow, these potatoes were golden.  
The coffee was strong, dark, rich, and aromatic. 

Ambiance: 
Rustic and homey decor. Warm light, beautiful wood furniture.

Staff: 
Friendly, competent, and personable. 

Only complaint is that you cant have more than 6 guests but it is understandable because its a pretty small location.
author: Aubriana M.

description: The Arugula Salad with Burrata was delicious, but the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes were coarse.  Kitchen Story's are much better. I've heard the potatoes are the shining star here at Plow, but I don't like potatoes.  Probably wouldn't come back.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Plow is as amazing as the reviews say.

***WARNING: car breakins are rampant in this area.  they target out of town people so do not leave anything of value in your car.  I live in the hood and it happens at least one time per day.***

Again - Plow is amazing and worth the visit.  Please plan accordingly.
author: Rob P.

description: The Plow Breakfast is a must! It can be shared amongst 2 people or 1 FA.  :) I've done both. The homemade sausage is pretty bomb, the apple chicken sausage is also great.. and can't go wrong with bacon.. (so those are what you get to choose besides how you like yo eggs). And I have repeated dreams about their lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes. I've been here 3 times and it has not disappoint. I love taking new people here to mold them into fans. (: The wait is a bit long, but hey, you can always explore the area. We walked to the Dogpatch area which is about a 10 minute walk. We also went next door to Provender Coffee (:
author: Jenna L.

description:
It doesn't always make sense to drive from the East Bay to SF just for breakfast, but it NEVER makes sense to drive someone to SFO and not make a stop in the city for some chow. I had dumped my parents off at the airport and was relishing in an unusually light traffic day and combed my hit list for breakfast before venturing back across the bridge.

I had hopes that the usual crowds were tame, this being a holiday week Friday morning just after 8am. And, I was sorta right. Upon arriving, I was told that I'd be seated "very soon" since they were about to turn several tables. And, they were right about the tables, though it was very clear that they were giving seating priority to full tables and leaving me and another solo diner to wait. "Very soon" ended up meaning 40 minutes, but I get it. The place is small and its better for business to fill tables up. You know going in that you're going to wait, so buckle in and dress warm.

So what is it that draws the crowds to Potrero Hill? Eggs are eggs. But, OMG, those potatoes! To the demise of my carb-cutting plans, I ended up with the two egg breakfast (sacrificing the delight of the famous pancakes) which of course comes with a heaping scoop of the wonderfully crisp and flavorful potatoes. I managed to save half back to share with the fam, but still left quite satisfied.

The chicken apple sausages were a perfect accompaniment, with a browned skin and warm and juicy center. And the Highwire coffee makes for some high quality joe.

As expected, it all comes at a price north of $20 for breakfast and coffee. That and the wait had me leaning towards 4 stars, though service was very nice. But for an occasional morning splurge, it is hard to beat so I rounded up! Bravo Plow!
author: Shawn W.

description: This place had a line out the door. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable, and made me feel very welcome, and the food was great. It had a very high-end feel to it. However, the price is a bit steep, and it took a while for the food to come out, due to the server forgetting to put in the order for us. However, honest mistakes make the world go round.
author: Chris R.

description: I almost don't want to post this. Plow is the best brunch in the world. Order the farmers plow- lemon ricotta pancakes with. House made sausage . If you come on a weekend expect a line up
author: Vivian C.

description:
Very disappointing ! So I have been the The Plow twice before , food is average but the lemon ricotta pancake never fails to disappoint me . So I have decide to bring my parents along this time . 

The line system needs works on , very unorganized , as they will wait for the previous people to show up before they can move people up the list . For example , Party A have two people , the receptionist call out party A but no one came up , they will still wait for them to show up until a while later .... 

I have checked in with the receptionist fell very unwelcoming and she is super rude . Since I have came before other party does , I checked in with her again making sure we are still on the list however she is very rude and gave a very bad attitude to me and my mom so we were both very disappointing already hoping the food can make up our disappointment .  
Finally got seated , the food is alll over cooked that my parents and I couldn't finish the dishes . 
Bacon is too over cooked that it became crunchy like chips ..... 
the lemon pancake is still good however considered this time of a super bad experience with the restaurant staff I will not return here anymore .
author: Priscilla F.

description:
If there is any restaurant that can serve as the example for all other restaurants to follow, it's Plow. Yes this place is a fabulous place to get breakfast/brunch, but what amazed me is the service. My wife and I didnt have many needs this afternoon, but our server Andrea got to us quickly and super efficiently, never skipping a beat with greeting us, taking our orders, running our food, and dropping the check. Thanks so much!

But the true unsung hero is the guy without a name on a receipt. You can tell this guy has been here for a long time because of how efficient he is, with clearing plates, setting up tables, seating guests from the waitlist, polishing silverware, and even with the breakdown of the outside patio seating. This dude completely blew me away with how every move he made was calculated and done very swiftly. I wish he worked for me!



ON TO THE FOOD. Mimosas, both grapefruit and OG, were served in wine glasses, which was greatly appreciated lol. I got the breakfast sandwich with bacon and my wife got the Plow with chicken apple sausage. 

The breakfast sandwich is your traditional egg sandwich with frisee, cheddar, and aioli. Done perfect and just what I was looking for. The yolks were runny, which is just bliss, the potatoes were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, and the acme bun was soft and tasteful. 

The Plow the restaurant's go-to: two eggs, choice of meat, in this case chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and plow potatoes. Nice snappy sausage with full flavor, the potatoes again were crispy and soft at the same time, but the pancakes def stole the show. You NEED THESE in your life!

BOOKMARKED. WILL RETURN FOR MOAR.
author: Jurem F.

description:
Hmmm what to say about Plow....

Heard amazing things about this place and have been dying to try it! My friend and I finally ventured out to Petrero Hill (10 min car ride from my apt...) to try Plow and boy did it live up to the hype. We had been looking over the menu in the uber ride there and already knew what we wanted...The Plow. Of course. It had everything you could ever want...eggs, meat, pancakes, AND potatoes. YUM. I was ready to take on The Plow. 

We knew the line was going to be long and we'd probably be waiting for over an hour but it would be worth it. The second we walked in, we told the hostess we had two people and she said we can either put you on the list for inside or seat you outside right away. My friend and I both looked at each other and said outside at the same time. We could not believe it! Note: It was a little chilly outside but who cares...we were getting seated RIGHT AWAY! Anyone who lives in SF and eats brunch on a weekend knows how rare this is. So outside it was! They even provided each customer with their own blanket!! Incredible. Is there anything they don't think of?!

As soon as we sat down, I started looking over the menu. The Plow still looked amazing but on the other hand, the soft scrambled eggs looked heavenly as well. I mean...shitake mushrooms and goat cheese in my soft scrambled eggs? I think yes. Plus I've been told they are known for both these dishes. It was going to be a game time decision. As soon as the server came over, I completely scrambled (pun intended) and went with the soft scrambled eggs BUT added an order of the lemon ricotta pancakes on the side. Could I BE any more excited? The answer is no. Plus I also ordered an iced chai. It was so tasty. 

I could not have been happier with my decision to get the soft scrambled eggs. it was everything I could have hoped for and more. Much more. 

Plow, you have my heart.
author: Ilana B.

description:
I've only been here once but it made quite an impression. I went way back when the Giants won the World Series in 2014, thinking that it wouldn't be crowded and I could avoid the long waits. Wrong lol seems like a lot of people had the same idea. 

It was roughly a 30 min wait for two people. It's a pretty small space so it'll be cozy but don't worry, the food will make it all okay. My boyfriend and I both ordered the plow plates. Those lemon ricotta pancakes. Dang. I could eat 50 of those. Everything on the plate was just so well made with great ingredients, and it was easy to see why the waits are constantly long. I will not wait till the Giants win (even year tho heyyy) to come back!

Free street parking, but it's pretty hilly because duh San Francisco. Bring a jacket for the wait outside haha
author: Stefanie S.

description: This is the perfect place for brunch outside on a sunny day. The line is pretty crazy though, we had to wait about an hour outside. We ordered the salmon eggs Benedict, breakfast combo, and chia seed pudding. I'm very happy that they have a gluten free option for the pancakes!
author: Michelle C.

description: Met a friend here for lunch on a friday noon time. Got there around 11am. We had to wait an hour before being seated. There is no where to wait. A few benches or stools would make the experience better. We then got seated around noon. The decor has a lot of natural light and high ceilings which makes it feel bigger than it is. The decor is like your grandmothers kitchen and dining room with a bar that faces into the kitchen. The vibe is nice so you can see the staff preparing your food...which looks fantastic and makes you want everything.  I got an omelette. It was good, the potatoes that accompanied it were delicious and fed made me fall off the no carb band wagon. My friend got the lemon ricotta pancakes, which were soft and not too sweet. They refilled my coffee generously. The waitress was nice and there was definitely a rushed vibe. We wanted to order takeout to bring to a friend that was not with us and they don't do that apparently. Generally the food is very good and the atmosphere is great for catching up and talking. At the same time the waiting and the feeling rushed is the reason it doesn't get 5 stars.
author: Anne S.

description:
Best breakfast in the city for sure! The line is always long but the food is always perfect. Generally if you come on a weekday before 930, the wait is pretty reasonable. Anytime after and you'll be waiting for quite a while. 

I've ordered "the plow" which is basically a little bit of everything for breakfast. Definitely a lot of food!

This time I ordered the pork chop! I wasn't sure if it was the right call but I would definitely recommend it! It was very moist and juicy and cooked perfectly! Give it a shot!

The sides are also very delicious, and I'm mainly talking about the plow potatoes. It is not something you can get anywhere! Come here and try the food!
author: Jason W.

description: This place was recommended by a friend.  I must say that this was the best breakfast I've had in a long time.   I ordered the plow with a substitution of French toast instead of pancakes.   Every bite on my plate was better than the last.
author: Heaven R.

description: Typical breakfast and brunch basics that are high quality, yet expect to cough up a pretty penny. Pancakes are delicious and location is pretty.
author: Andreas D.

description:
Plow is another epic San Francisco brunch location. Yes, you will have to about 1-1 1/2 hours to be seated, but this gives you the opportunity to explore the neighborhood! Also, your food is served in a timely manner once you've been seated so that is always a plus. 

It was really hard to decide which entree to enjoy. I opted for a good old eggs benny. It was delicious! The perfect amount of tang in the hollandaise sauce and the eggs were perfectly poached. The potatoes that complimented the dish were very tasty. I couldn't help but overhear other guests sharing the same delight. I had a taste of the lemon ricotta pancake my sister was eating. It was so good! I will definitely have to eat that on my next visit. 

Staff is also very friendly. They even provide blankets for guests enjoying brunch outside.
author: Sarin P.

description: We loved the BLT because it had a beautiful beefsteak tomato and pimiento cheese - both memories from Missouri childhood.  The Hong Kong toast reminded her the pan de sol sandwiches she used to have.  The plow breakfast had wonderful potatoes.
author: Vernon A.

description: This was a nice breakfast. The potatoes were fried crunchy. The pancakes were delicious with a unique flavor. The scrambled eggs were fluffy and tasty. The bacon was crispy and easy to chew. The staff were polite. The waiting time was close to an hour. But it was worth the wait.
author: Ricardo W.

description: Expect to have a long wait. We put our name on the waiting list and walked down the street to get some coffee. The food was fantastic! It was exactly as what we saw on other yelpers posts. It was a little chilly outside so they handed us a little throw to keep us warm. The service was great! They were attentive and so sweet. Like I said earlier the food was fantastic! We ordered the honey butter biscuit, pudding, the plow, and the sandwich. Everything was amazing. Other then the wait we had a very good brunch. Definitely be back when I'm in town to visit!
author: Hoa V.

description: Plow was one of the best breakfasts I've had in San Francisco. The only reason for a 4 star was that the wait gets extremely long from the moment it opens. Service was impeccable, but we got there at 9:15 and had a 45 minute wait. By 10:00 they were telling people it went up to 2 hours. I highly recommend the eggs Benedict with salmon. Definitely one of the best I've had (and I try that at every breakfast spot I go to). My friend and I also split the lemon ricotta pancakes. These were incredible! The lightness/ fluffiness from the ricotta.. paired with the blueberry compote. Absolutely delicious. If you have a few house to wait, I would say this spot is worth it.
author: Mariel P.

description:
The wait time is Not worth the food. If I didn't wait an hour to get in, then I wouldn't have had a problem with the mediocre food. My friends and I had their potatoes because that's what they're supposedly known for. But they weren't that great. The server was nice but you could tell she was stretched thin because she kept forgetting items from our order. At the same time, the employees in the front were more focused to talking to each other rather than helping customers.

The food was still good. We ordered a bottle of champagne with orange juice on the side. It's just a REALLY small space and a long wait. There are a few bars around that restaurant that are pretty cool so maybe check those out while you're waiting !
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Came here to have breakfast with my brother and nephew and I must say wow this place blew my mind!!! The lemon ricotta pancakes and the French toast were outta this world!!! I got the one with coffee to go with my French toast, a little too strong for me but still delicious. Service was great the waitress was super nice always kept an eye on us to see if we needed help with anything. Definitely coming and recommending people.
author: Enjoy S.

description:
Checked in on May 31st, 2016.

First time to San Francisco, searched on Yelp for breakfast place and found Plow.  Very impressed!
Rating:
1) Food - 5/5
2) Service - 5/5
3) Ambiance - 4/5

We ordered:
1) The Plow: was very good.  It was a big order, can easily be shared between 2 people with big appetite, or 3 people with small appetite.  Comes with 2 eggs, choice of sausage (we took Apple chicken), potatoes and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes.  The pancakes were my favorite.  Everything else was good and perfectly cooked.
2) Mochi: was excellent.  
3) Cold brewed Iced coffee: did not care much for it.

Service was efficient and timely.  I have taken off one star due to the cramped setup.  I would like to see them move to a larger location with more space between 2 tables.
author: Anjali A.

description:
Good food, but not feeling the approximately 1 hour and 45 minutes wait on the weekends. 

I'm not going to lie---the food just wasn't worth the unbearably long wait. Didn't blow my mind. 

I ordered the French toast with strawberries, mascarpone, and pure maple syrup while the mister ordered the Plow breakfast with two eggs, house made pork sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes.  No complaints! All the components on the Plow were nicely cooked and the two fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes truly had a pleasant lemon essence. I thought my French toast appeared relatively burnt, though it didn't taste like it. 

+ Can only accommodate parties of 6 or fewer due to the small size of the venue 
+ No reservations
+ Indoor and outdoor seating
author: Merica S.

description: What a great spot for breakfast! We went on a weekday and it was full, so I can only imagine how packed it gets on the weekend. Hubby and I split a biscuit (comes with honey butter) - that was sooo good, great texture - and "the plow" which is your choice of eggs, your choice of meat, breakfast potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes. The plow was soooo delicious but also sooo much food so I'd def recommend splitting it. The eggs were phenomenal, the chicken apple sausage and bacon (Hubby requested an extra meat side) were good but greasy, the breakfast potatoes were amazing (especially those small crunchy bits, but the star of the show was the pancakes! Such great flavor, not too heavy, great texture because of the ricotta. I just wish I had gotten to eat more of the pancakes
author: Xenia P.

description:
I must be on a quest to try every brunch place in the city because that's all I been reviewing lately, and this place happens to win a spot in my list of best brunches in the city. 

I came here on a weekend and for a party of 2, the wait was about 1.5 hours... which is about average in this city. The place seems like a fairly small place and the ambience is pretty fresh and bright because the place was filled with natural sunlight. I took the bus here but parking doesn't seem to be like a big issue in this neighborhood. 

Me and my friend both got 'The Plow' which came with 2 eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, homefries and your choice of pork sausage patties (like the kind you get with your sausage mcmuffin), chicken apple sausages (links) or bacon. Me and my friend decided to get the sausage patties and the chicken apple sausages to share. Between those two, I would recommend the chicken apple sausages more, but they were both moist and juicy. The pancakes were fluffy and with the right amount of lemon in it (yums.) The homefries potatoes were extra crispy (they actually fry them @___@) and seasoned just the right amount. I was lucky enough to be seated at the bar, meaning I had the pleasure to see the cook season the potatoes and she actually tries every batch to make sure they're seasoned enough. 

Overall, I would definitely recommend this place for all brunch lovers.
author: Jenny N.

description: Worth the wait! (On a Sunday) We ordered the plow and everything on the dish was unique and tasted great. The peach upside down cake was heavy, but delicious and was a nice sweet after our breakfast.
author: Ashley Y.

description:
I don't use Yelp to complain about places but this one needs a mention so that people are aware. 

Food is not bad (we had the plow which was not mind blowing, but pretty all right), and that's why people wait for a long time. For us, it was 2 solid hours on a Sunday morning. 

However, the server was EXTREMELY rude. I believe she was agitated with a different customer and vented her stress on us. 

After a 2 hour wait, we got seated and because it was cold outside we wanted to order a hot coffee and asked the server if we could order. She replied "I'm helping a customer here ok? I'll be with you after that". I replied "got it". I understood they were busy and did not hold it against her. When she got back to us I asked for her recommendation and she just replied "Everything is good". Well that doesn't help much and doesn't fix the situation either. The way she took our orders was also very angry, didn't repeat what we ordered, and generally hurt our experience no matter how good the food was (which I mentioned was not exceptional). Oh and she only gave us one side plate for both of us. Really?

With good service I would have given it 3 stars but please, jeep your servers in line and fix your seating situation. There are so many customers complaining about the chaotic seating and ordering situation and it doesn't seem this business gives a damn about it because people still line up. Just a sad situation and a poor experience overall.
author: D J.

description:
Waited over two hours for brunch at Plow.  Best way to kill the time is to wonder around the neighborhood and grab a coffee at one of the nearby cafes.

Plow is known for its lemon ricotta pancakes. I'd say they're good, but not mindblowing.

My favorite dish was the dungeness crab scramble - not skimpy on the crab meat and you end up getting some in every bite. 

Another signature dish is the "plow" which is like a "best-of" dish that includes two lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, homemade sausage, and amazing smashed potatoes.
author: Hieu H.

description: I brought my mother here while in the area and I just yelped breakfast which Plow was the top around the area and the photos that everyone posted looked appetizing so we came by and ordered the special that comes with the fluffy pancakes, eggs, bacon and toast while my mother ordered the crab omelet. Even the tea pot was super cute and delicious! This place is a solid 5+ stars! If you're in SF, this is a must stop breakfast joint. Super tiny and everyone is almost touching elbows but one of the best tasting! Worth every penny!
author: Jenna C.

description: This place is one of my favorites in the city. If you can swing it, I'd recommend going early during the weekdays, then you really won't get much of a wait. On the other hand, I've come at 10:30 on a Sunday and been told that we won't be seated until 1pm, soooo take that as you will. While the wait is long, I think it can be so worth it though!  The lemon ricotta pancakes are by far my favorite and I think the Plow breakfast is just overall delicious and awesome. This is one of my favorites as a SF local!
author: Laura T.

description:
We dropped by last minute on a Friday afternoon and were pleasantly surprised by the relatively quick 20 minute wait. My friend and I split The Plow, which consists of lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, a meat, and eggs. We went with the house made sausage and over medium eggs. I loved the potatoes, which were soft on the inside and super crispy on the outside. The portions were just big enough that we felt satisfied, not bloated like we usually do after brunch. The meal was quite expensive - $17 + tax and tip for a very simple meal, excluding the potatoes (which as I mentioned before, were extraordinary).

Service was attentive and the atmosphere is great. I'm not sure if I would make a trip back just for the potatoes because Plow is definitely on the pricey end but it's worth trying if you're in the area!
author: Anna H.

description:
Hipster spot. I don't usually go out for brunch, but this place is certainly an experience. 

Got in, the waitress told our party of two the wait was about 30 minutes. They did seem very busy. We went walking around and looked around. We come back after 10 minutes, the waitress seemed to be looking for us. She said the table was almost ready. Sure enough, we were seated after a short wait. 

I ordered the plow breakfast and coffee. It came with potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, bacon, sausage. The waiter was very friendly and very attentive to coffee and water refills and kept checking on us.

It's very easy to find parking here. Definitely recommend this spot if you are on Potrero Hill!
author: Jaime F.

description: Great food! Homemade sausage, yum, lemon ricotta pancakes bear repeating. Salmon toast light and flavorful
author: Dawn G.

description: Worth the wait. Don't even ask how long. Just wait!!! Best breakfast environment + food + staff + best IG pics!
author: Ashlie H.

description:
Probably the best lemon ricotta pancakes I've ever had. Not enough for me to come back and wait almost 2 hours for though...which was how long my friends and I waited.

Just by ordering the "Plow" you get to experience what they're known for which are the lemon ricotta pancakes and amazing crispy potatoes (super hot so watch your tongue but oh so good); in addition you get a side of eggs and choice of sausage or bacon.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Came here in a Monday afternoon, for a group of 5 our wait was about 30-35 minuets. Not too bad because a couple of parties before us didn't show up.
Our servicer was nice she got our orders in as soon as we were ready. 
We ordered 2 buttermilk biscuits to start off our lunch. The butter was sweet and seems like it was house made. 
I got the plow with pork sausage, and soft scrambled eggs. My plate turned out exactly what i thought it would. The lemon ricotta pancakes are supposed to be a huge hit here but I personally didn't favor them. The dense ricotta made it too heavy for me to finish both. But it seems to be exactly what a ricotta pancake should be. 
I would definitely come back next time for brunch again!
author: Paulina N.

description:
1.5 hour wait for a delicious soft scramble? I'll go for it since there's a good coffee shop nearby.

Coffee was good. Also got the biscuit, which was the perfect balance of fluffy and crumbly. The breakfast sandwich looked really good and I also tried some of the pork sausage. I thought it was a bit to dry and crumbly, but Rus was a fan. My egg scramble was perfectly cooked. The eggs were creamy but not runny and swirled with some cooked spinach, sat atop some goat cheese. Delicious. The potatoes are also really good! Crispy on the outside and soft and steamy on the inside.

Server was extremely friendly despite the restaurant being packed and droves of people waiting outside. Have to dock one star for the wait, though.
author: Carol B.

description: Amazing food and great hospitality. The best part of the experience is sitting at the bar and watching the cooks do their thing. We love the people over everything, but we REALLY love the food, so imagine how great the atmosphere is!
author: Erika M. D.

description:
Saturday, 11:30 AM.

Quickie:
+ Drink/Food quality
- Service
+ Hygiene
+ Atmosphere
- Turnaround
+ Menu variety
* Layout

And then...?
The line system needs work, as we observed some folks cutting in front of people already waiting. Plow makes legit brunch and in case it was an off day, we hope to stop by again.
author: Chuck N.

description: An amazing place for breakfast. Came for the first time with friends. A great area where you can sit, if you enjoy watching the chefs. Amazing staff, service and food. Strongly recommended.
author: Julien B.

description:
I have tried to eat here three times. THREE TIMES. The wait is usually around an hour, and all the people standing outside can be intimidating, but it's absolutely worth it. 

I went at 9am to put our name in for a group of 4, and our table was ready about 45 mins later. Opted for inside seating cause it was cold, but would have been happy to sit outside just to finally be able to eat at this place. Limited seating, so I don't think a party bigger than 5 or 6 would be a good idea.

Ordered the plow so I could try a little bit of everything. The lemon ricotta pancakes. AMAZING. SO GOOD. HOW. WHY. Country style potatoes and eggs. Definitely the perfect hearty size after a late Friday night.

I would suggest ordering the grilled cheese. A friend ordered it and as soon as they brought the food, the entire table was jealous. 

I would eat here every weekend this wasn't San Francisco and I didn't have to wait an hour to sit at a fabulous restaurant.
author: Steph D.

description:
Pretty good! 

Came here for brunch on a Tuesday morning around 11, and was surprised to see that it was busy! Had to wait less than 10 minutes for a table, and the hostess seated us at a two-top right next to a four-top that was within breathing room of us. It felt awkward being a bit close, so we scooted the table over a bit. 

With that said, Plow is a small restaurant. Be prepared to get comfortable with your table neighbors! 

My friend ordered the plow dish, and I ordered the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes with a side of bacon. 

Our food came out in about 15 minutes, and it was good! My bacon was greasy, fatty, and most importantly, crispy. It added the salt needed to the sweetness of the pancakes. The pancakes were delicious. I could taste the lemon without it being overpowering, and the ricotta was present as well. The blueberry compote that comes along is a great addition, as it adds a bit of tartness to the pancakes. Plus, the purple-blue of the blueberries on top of the lemon pancakes look so colorful and fun! 

My friend seemed enjoyed her dish, she ate the whole thing! 

The service was great. Our server made sure our coffee mugs were filled, and took good care of us. 

I'd recommend this place to a friend for sure. I'll come back in the future and order those pancakes again!
author: Taylor M.

description: Omg! What a great breakfast. If I were to cook breakfast, this is exactly how I would make it. All the ingredients were super fresh. My husband actually said, "this is going to sound weird, but it was too fresh!" Ummmm not possible. The food and ambiance were amazing. The eggs with goat cheese were fantastic! A very charming little spot that I look forward to visiting again
author: Kk B.

description: This hidden little gem is suddenly our fave!! The pancakes.... omg..... the in house sausage....omg...... the toast....omg..... the potatoes...... omg..... the vibe...... on point....... worth the wait..... let me repeat.....WORTH TGE WAIT!!
author: Darren G.

description:
Brunch review. Third visit.

Pumpkin pancakes - 3/5
The plow - 5/5
Ginger molasses cake - 3/5
Biscuits and honey butter - 5/5 - Unbelievably good. Best Biscuits in the city. 

Overall, the plow and the biscuits are "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description: Tiny space packed with so much goodness! I recently had a friend move here and she insisted we visit this neighborhood spot! We arrived by 9 on a weekday a fortunately were able to be seated right away however directly following we watched quite a line grow. Be prepared to wait! Great biscuit and honey butter! MOST IMPORTANTLY the lemon ricotta pancakes with blueberry compote were out of this world! What a deliciously moist, dense, sweet pancake! One of the best pancakes I've EVER had!
author: Karleigh M.

description:
Wait was a bit long for a large party, but the food is pretty good. The lemon ricotta pancakes are definitely worth it! The breakfast sandwich was amazing!

Outside seating was pretty good, even though it was one of the hottest days in the city.
author: Amy N.

description: Great breakfast. It lived up to the hype. Get lemon riccotta pancakes and definitely try the buttered biscuit, it's scrumptious.
author: Jay S.

description: This place was just okay. I don't mind waiting 1 1/2 hours for brunch if it's worth it but sadly I was disappointed. The only thing that stood out was the lemon ricotta pancakes, those were really good.
author: Shanna S.

description:
Want an absolutely beautiful brunch? Come to Plow. 

Everything is stunningly simple. The setting is rustic, modern, and clean.

A side of fruit isn't your run-of-the-mill medley of not-quite-ripe melons, insipid strawberries, and slightly-softened grapes. No, no. You'll get a small, perfectly beautiful serving of seasonal specialties...perhaps slice Asian pear, apricot, plum, and fig.

The biscuits are delicious on their own, but are best used as a vehicle for transporting the house made strawberry jam to your mouth. It's the jammiest, strawberriest strawberry jam I've every had.

You really can't go wrong with anything on their menu, but whatever you do, make sure you order the potatoes. They're fried crispy, perfectly seasoned, and loaded with rosemary for the most deliciously savory breakfast potato experience of your life. They're the stuff brunch dreams are made of.
author: Dara M.

description: I'm not exactly sure how you found yourself looking for breakfast this far south of downtown San Francisco, but consider yourself lucky to be in the neighborhood. The farm-to-table food is light but filling, delicious and sourced from the freshest NorCal purveyors. Dig in and enjoy, and don't forget the coffee and fresh squeezed orange juice.
author: Tim B.

description: Get the Plow... just do it! But, don't wait 2 hours for it like I did. You've got to be strategic when it comes to brunching in SF. Come early and be among the first group to be seated. On the plus side, patrons are fairly self-aware and don't linger around after they scarf down their food because yes, you will work up an appetite from all of the waiting. This single meal lasted me all day. The carb-protein-fat ratio is just perfect. A must try when in town!
author: Julia K.

description: Excellent place. The portions they serving are really huge, the biscuits are buttery and melt in your mouth, and the coffee are a dream for a caffeine lover.
author: Ireland C.

description: I love this place! We waiting 1.5hrs due to small space, but it's worth the wait. I love their toast with condensed milk, it just melts in your mouth and full of flavor. I would definitely come back for more.
author: Tan D.

description: Came here for breakfast on a weekday. Recommended by a blogger on her travel guide so decided to check it out! The wait was about a half hour- not terrible at all but I never mind wait time. The service was marvelous, the food was delicious! Those Lemon Ricotta Pancakes were all the things! Cutest breakfast/brunch location and worth any wait time! Check it out!
author: Lizzette N.

description:
When I visit this place with a coworker during regular day, we're able to get table with short wait. They do have good brunch by offering best ingredients with higher than average prices and small portions. Let's say you can consider this place as the French fine dining for brunch.

Came back on Sunday 10.30 and they told us for 1.5h wait. We understood that since this is a super hipster place. Came back 1.5 later at noon and we're told to wait for another 1h. They close at 2pm.

We decided to go to Spark SF nearby where we don't need to wait and get cheaper food with same taste as we don't need the gluten free organic no antibiotic no gmo food.
author: Richard W.

description:
Plow is one of those classic SF brunches that people are willing to wait forever for (which you must, as there are no reservations). I went at about 9am on a Saturday and the wait only ended up being about 30 minutes, which wasn't bad.

The restaurant itself is a little crowded, but not too bad. The staff was very friendly. The food was excellent - we got their biscuit, which is flaky, butter perfection (made even better by the honey butter it comes with). I wasn't a huge fan of their lemon ricotta pancakes (a specialty of theirs), as they were a bit lemony for my taste. That said, if you're good with that flavor, you'll like them - the texture was perfect; nice and fluffy. I also tried the prosciutto and gruyere toast - definitely recommend that.
author: Alex W.

description:
Food was amazing! Service was good. Went on a weekday so no wait. Had the biscuit, grapefruit mimosa, lemon ricotta pancakes and fried egg sandwich with avacado. Lil pricey but worth it.

The place is small but they have outdoor seating so it would be difficult to seat large groups. They do have a few tables for outdoor seating. Only 2 bathroom stalls so you may have to wait.
author: Lena M.

description:
I decided to be productive this morning and go to the gym. But of course, considering the time it takes to get ready, drive to the gym, and sit in traffic, I decided instead to plow my face at Plow. They open at 7am but already at 6:50am people are congregated outside their door. Inside has a nice, quaint, homey feel. The server seated me on the counter facing the kitchen, so I had a perfect view of the kitchen. 

I ordered the Plow, which consists of 2 eggs, 2 lemon riccota pancakes, their house potatoes, and choice of protein-chicken apple sausages, Nueske's bacon, or house pork sausages. I opted for the pork sausages based on the server's recommendations and ordered a cup of their Equator coffee to pair off with my meal. I don't know if it's the coffee fiend in me, but their cup of joe was addicting. I may have had a total of 4 cups.

The meal was real hearty leaving me stuffed. The house potatoes were nice and crispy seasoned with what tasted like rosemary. The lemon riccota pancakes were nice and fluffy with just the perfect amount of lemon flavoring. Initially I ordered for over-medium eggs so the yolk doesn't run throughout my plate but instead was served over-easy and a bit salty. I typically refrain from using condiments so I can savor the flavor of the dish, but their pork sausage was a tad dry, overcooked, and overly seasoned with herbs that ketchup helped neutralize the taste.

As I was wrapping up my meal, the chef also pulled out a fresh mochi cake from the oven and of course I couldn't resist, so I decided to order a slice to go. The cake reminded me of a Filipino bibingka cake. It has a spongy and gelatinous texture with a coconut after-taste. Very delicious especially when warm. 

Plow is perfect for splurging on breakfast. Personal advice is to come early because they do get packed and of course for the owners to add bottomless mimosas to their menu- one can only dream.
author: Denzell S.

description: My favorite breakfast spot in San Francisco!!! Three words... Lemon. Ricotta. Pancakes. Enough said. The location is a bit out of the way for a tourist, but well worth the uber ride. They also have this apple sausage that is amazing. Everyone has always been super friendly. You need to eat here if you're in town!
author: Rachel H.

description: Everything was just fine. The food was served hot. The wait staff was friendly. Everyone at my table loved the potatoes, but found other dishes a little bland. For me, it wasn't worth a two hour wait or the price tag... but perhaps you'll love it.
author: Phoebe O.

description: Nice place, not sure it's worth waiting for brunch. My husband said he had the best pancakes he ever had in here. I disagree.
author: Gali S.

description: This place is super cute and the service is fairly quick. Don't let the wait turn you away because turnover is good. The food was solid. The Plow was awesome and now I'm craving lemon ricotta pancakes. Yummmm! The food quality looked consistent from the dishes I saw pass by. I definitely want to try this place next time I'm in town.
author: Josie V.

description:
As soon as we picked up our rental car at the airport, we knew we had an hour to get to Plow before they closed for the afternoon. We made it with time to spare and boy are we glad we did!

Our waitress was amazing and gave us great suggestions.  Their lemon ricotta pancakes are the stuff that dreams are made of.  They are light and airy but filled with a lovely lemon flavor. Perfectly made over easy eggs oozed out over the open faced prosciutto and arugula sandwich.  Words don't begin to do this place justice.  Just trust us, it's worth the trip!
author: Linda S.

description:
I'm generally not a fan of breakfast food, but the exception is Plow. 
Hands down the best breakfast I've ever had, so much so that whenever I do have a craving for breakfast it's for Plow's lemon ricotta pancakes or crab scramble. 
This is now a stop that's always planned into my SF itinerary.
Tip: Be prepared to wait!
author: Richard C.

description: I can see why Plow is so popular! Excellent breakfast on our last day of vacation. Came on a Thursday morning around 9 and there was no wait for a table inside. Service was very attentive and friendly. I ordered the soft scrambled eggs but also got a side of lemon ricotta pancakes. Both were out of this world! We will definitely be coming back to Plow next time we are in town.
author: Kate O.

description:
Not sure I get the hype. The lemon ricotta pancakes were subpar really. Everything else was very generic.

Thank gd we went on a weekday morning and scored a table right away. We would have been super pissed hungry hippos!
author: Michelle I.

description: This place has great food but gets extremely busy on weekends at Brunch. A party of two, We has to wait 45 mins on a Sunday. Don't order the Apple chicken sausage.
author: Ryan J.

description:
+ good service
+ biscuit was delicious, especially the butter

- plow was okay. the pork sausage or pancake did not taste special.
- long line (1.5 hour wait on a rainy day)
author: Margaret R.

description: This cafe was recommended by a friend as a destination place.  It certainly proved to be.  I ordered the lemon ricotta pancake and ate it all.  I'm not a fan of pancakes, but these were fluffy served with a nice syrup and blueberry compote. Service was excellent from the hostess to the server. Moreover, I was seated at the counter and watched the kitchen staff at work...what fun.  The amazing thing is that the nice lady next to me (who after a bit of conversation about the food we ordered) asked me if I wanted to taste one of the items on her plate.  That's about as good as it gets.
author: D. Q.

description:
Heard this was one of the best breakfast places in san francisco. There was about a 20 minute wait but that was expected. Very friendly staff and nice dining experience.

The food was great. We ordered the fried chicken sandwich,side of bacon and lemon ricotta pancakes. The chicken sandiwch was good and had a nice crunch to it, well seasoned too. The la cakes were said to be one of the best in San Francisco and did not dissapoint. 

Just hoped they had freshly squeezed orange juice. But overall the place was great will definitely come back
author: Richard A.

description: Fabulous breakfast stop. We arrived at 7am and had mimosas and coffee and great service.  We just landed from Honolulu
author: Caroline P.

description:
I don't really understand what the hype is all about. 

My friend and I came on a Saturday morning around 10:30am and the wait was 1-1.5 hours for a party of 2. We went for a stroll across the street to grab some coffee and toast while we waited, but I saw others order coffee and mimosas from Plow while waiting. The staff seemed super nice and accommodating, considering how busy it was.

We finally got seated after about an hour and 15 mins. We both ordered The Plow, which comes with eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, and your choice of pork sausage/bacon/chicken apple sausage. I went with the classic bacon option while my friend opted for the pork sausage.

Being seated outside, I noticed that we were not given a jug of water that we could use to fill our own glasses, while people sitting inside were. It didn't matter too much because our waitress was pretty good about refilling our waters. Just wish they kept it consistent with the tables, though.

Onto the food... Honestly I was very disappointed. My over medium eggs came with a perfect runny yolk (yay!) but overall were extremely bland. They tasted like they were barely seasoned with any salt or pepper. The bacon was terrible. It was waaay too salty and was not crispy at all. It was actually pretty soggy. The lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes, on the other hand, were the redeeming factors of the dish. The pancakes were fluffy and had a good balance of lemon flavor. The potatoes were pretty good as well, but not remarkable enough for me to say they were amazing. I tried some of my friend's pork sausage and thought it was pretty average. The worst part was when I found a piece of hair at the bottom of my plate. Definitely know it's not my own since it was short and black instead of long and ombré. It's too bad I had already eaten a majority of the plate when I found it...

I also noticed that they printed the menu specific for that day. I'm not sure if they print the menu everyday, but I sure hope not because that would be such a waste of paper.

Overall, Plow was definitely overhyped. It wasn't worth it to me to wait 1+ hour and pay $17 for a mediocre plate of food that had a hair in it... But maybe I just had a bad experience? I'd give it a try again maybe if the wait weren't so long.
author: Cheryl N.

description:
I'm actually a little sad to be the minority that is not really in favor of this place as I just thought the food was 'okay' and nothing special.  As a previous yelper said, I honestly think the reason why it gets such high reviews is the location. =/

I ordered the ever so popular 'The Plow', which comes with two eggs, choice of protein (chicken apple sausage, house made pork sausage patties, or bacon), two mini lemon ricotta pancakes, and their plow potatoes. Everything was good, but nothing great. 

The chicken apple sausage was a standard sausage in my opinion. I was able to try my bf's house made pork sausage patties, and while they do have a robust smokey flavor, I found it dry and tough.. something I wouldn't like to have more than a few bites of. The potatoes were a little disappointing; if you can see with my picture, our potatoes were more on the dark brown, amber/orange side with a lot of burnt potato skins. At first I said to myself, "I'm paying ~$17 for this..?" (I will admit, the actual potatoes (that weren't burnt) were tasty though!) It's not when we finally left and saw that other people's potatoes were golden yellow and plumped with starchy goodness. So that's what the potatoes were suppose to be like! The lemon ricotta pancakes were probably the best of the dish, although nothing that I would be dying to come back for. 

My bf and I had the lovely outdoor seating on a beautiful SF day. It's a little comical thinking back that we were all seated on such a steep street/hill with an incline hahaha. That's SF for ya! (Must...fight...gravity..!!) I loved the decor though! Portions were huge, so at least that was something to make up for the more heftier price. Service was just okay for us, nothing above and beyond. Again, everything in general was good... but not great. For now, I wouldn't be back!
author: Kris C.

description: I paid $26 for the plow - which included 3 pieces of bacon, 2 small lemon ricotta pancakes with a teeny tiny bit of syrup, half a plate full of potatoes (which tasted quite bland), and egg whites (charged an extra $3 for the egg whites), and a pot of mint tea. About a 25 minute wait to sit at the bar. You definitely feel like you hae to eat and run because there are so many people waiting for your seat and the waiters/waitresses can't wait to whisk your plate away.
author: Camille H.

description: I went to this place with three of my friends to celebrate one of their birthday. We got to the restaurant around 9am on Saturday and waited for one hr and 30 mins. The foods were all great :) However, the waitress forgot to bring my friend a birthday biscuit as requested and had to be reminded. When she finally brought it, she rudely left it in the center of table and said, "I don't know whose birthday it is, but here". I am plowing my way out of here.
author: Vivienne M.

description:
May have been the best brunch experience I've had in San Francisco. Arrived at 8:45 on a rainy Saturday and was informed that there was an hour wait for a table for 3, not a problem, found a nearby coffee shop and the hour was over before we knew it. Had the homemade biscuit with honey butter, the plow, the French toast with caramel apples, and the gruyere and prosciutto open face sandwich.

The highlights of the meal was the biscuit, which was crunchy on the outside, moist, and delicious on the inside. And the Plow potatoes, which were crunchy on the outside and tender on the inside, perfectly salted. The lemon ricotta pancakes that came with the plow platter was cake like and not overly sweet.

I could have lived without the french toast which was nothing special.
author: Ray K.

description:
***This neighborhood breakfast spot utilizes high quality ingredients and a well-run kitchen to churn out delicious and satisfying breakfast and brunch dishes***

Plow is located in Dogpatch, an up-and-coming neighborhood that will probably introduce several more destination restaurants in the next few years.  Plow is a weekday and weekend breakfast and brunch eatery.  The restaurant is small and casual though the décor is nicely done featuring homey but still contemporary notes.  The counter is nice and provides an excellent view of the short order counter where the team of chefs here efficiently crank out breakfast dishes like a well-run greasy spoon.

The food at Plow is not greasy spoon staples though.  You will see more upscale ingredients here like prosciutto and frisee as well as some great looking bread from a prestigious San Francisco bakery.  I had The Plow, which is their signature breakfast plate.  It is a hearty plate featuring two eggs, crispy fried potatoes with onions, choice of meat (chicken apple sausage, pork sausage patties or bacon), and two lemon ricotta pancakes.

With the exception of the lemon ricotta pancakes, this breakfast veered more towards fairly classic interpretations.  I had the eggs sunny side up, and they were quite good.  I would have liked the egg yolk a little less done, but the flavor was great.  The crispy potatoes were quite delicious.  The caramelized onions provided a mild sweet flavor while the potatoes combined a satisfying crispy exterior with a hot and soft center.  I also had their bacon, which was Nueske's bacon, a popular Midwestern bacon from Wisconsin.  The bacon had a smoky flavor as well as an appetizing pork flavor from the crispy fat.

The bacon was not as thick as Niman Ranch bacon, but the flavor was definitely memorable.  I also ordered their pork sausage patties, and these were good though I probably did prefer the bacon.  The center of the sausage was moist while the outside was well seared and crispy.  They get a little more adventurous with the seasoning so you get more herb and fennel notes with their sausage than you would experience at most breakfast spots.

The kitchen gussied up the pancakes a little more than they did with the other breakfast items in The Plow.  The pancakes featured both lemon and ricotta.  The lemon was nice.  It provided a noticeable lemon flavor as well as a lot of freshness.  I felt though that the ricotta probably hurt the pancake more than it helped it.  The pancakes had a great color and the smell of the pancake was very inviting.  Unfortunately, the pancake could have been sweeter.  The center was also a tad on the dry side and did not have that light and fluffy cake-like texture you would expect in an excellent pancake.

Service was fairly quick given how busy this restaurant gets (even on weekdays).  Prices are higher than your standard breakfast spot, but the ingredients at Plow are definitely high quality and the portions are surprisingly generous.

I enjoyed The Plow at Plow though I felt the savory items were far superior to the disappointing lemon ricotta pancakes.  Part of me really loved the breakfast here, and, in some ways, Plow would rival my favorite breakfast restaurants--Matt's Big Breakfast in Phoenix or Huckleberry in Santa Monica, which features an excellent fried egg sandwich with bacon.  I would definitely go back and give Plow's other dishes a shot.  If you are a big breakfast fan, Plow is a must visit if you live in San Francisco or are just visiting.

I believe free street parking is available in the nearby residential area though parking spaces are probably hard to find around here.
author: Anthony N.

description: I haven't found an exciting brunch place in SF in awhile, but Plow checked all the boxes for me! Several items on the menu looked appetizing and it was hard to pick, but we settled on the Plow (with the blueberry sauce on the side for +$1) and the pork chop. I thought the Plow was delicious until I had the pork chop, which was also insanely delicious. The only thing I would change on the Plow would be the housemate sausage patties, which were dare I say bland? On the other hand, everything else on the plate was delicious and well-seasoned. The pork chop was tender and juicy!! Delicious! We came on a Monday and still had to wait around 15-20 minutes, but I can see why. Come ready to wait and eat!
author: Allison S.

description:
Great brunch food, but not worth a 2 hour wait. I recommend going on long weekends when people leave town, or during weekdays. 

Service is a hit or miss - I've experienced really long food wait times after being seated, other times they brought things out at a more reasonable pace.
author: Elisa L.

description: Smelly glasses. I am concerned about hygiene. The table wasn't cleaned well too, it smelled. Killed appetite. Rude hostess but servers were nice. Burnt pancakes? (See pics) No fresh OJ, but mimosa was decent.
author: Deepika N.

description:
I'm giving this place 4 stars because the food was pretty good and they had a nice decor. Although the place is a little small. We ordered the 4 main sides: biscuits, mochi cake, coffee cake, and something else. They were all really good. The food itself was good, I ordered the Eggs Benedict and others order the plow. The one thing that did disturb me was the 2 hour wait time. I don't get why there's such a long wait. I get that the brunch place is good, but it's definitely not 2 hours wait time good. I'd suggest going on an off hour if possible. I guess if they make you wait long enough and you get hungry enough, all food tastes good. I'll have to go back when im not so hungry to see if that theory is true. 

We also got mimosas but they were extremely pricey. For the price of the glass,I could have had bottomless at another place. Not something i'd recommend. 

Otherwise, this place is decent. I will recommend to others.
author: Kevin W.

description:
With over a thousand reviews, you've probably gleaned that there is a ridiculous wait for a delicious breakfast. 

I finally got to come here on a Saturday with a party of three and was quoted a 1.5 hour wait. While pretending to be a flowerpots sitting on the sills outside, we decided to imbibe some self serve coffee (very strong - solid flavors). 

Upon being seated a little over an hour later, I noticed how once again new San Francisco the place is with a minimalist look, lots of natural lighting and light woodsy interior. It was also very cramped inside, but we did not want to wait extra for al fresco dining. 

Of course I ordered the Plow which came with the lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes and opted for the pork sausage and my eggs over medium. I also had a camellia iced tea on the side. I thoroughly enjoyed the fluffly sweetness of the pancakes but the CRISPY POTATOES were the star of the show; I now have a much higher standard for my brunch potatoes. The eggs were cooked perfectly (over medium is not really a thing so basically over easy). However the pork sausage was a huge letdown as it was very dry and had whole cumin seeds in it. It was remediable with dashes of Youk's hot sauce, but it was really just tough and dry. I had a bite of my friend's fried egg sandwich with avocado and it was stellar (though this is something rather difficult to not succeed in). The camellia iced tea was blase but refreshing.

Service was wonderful and our waters and teas were refilled regularly. I was a little miffed because the self serve coffee was ~$4 and there was no real sign or warning from the hostess who merely said "help yourself." I guess it is San Francisco and people no longer bat an eye at a $4 cup of coffee. The area is definitely different now than it was when I drove through to lifeguard at UCSF in my high school days. 

On the whole, a solid brunch place, but a little pricey ($30 after tax and tip for myself). I would come back if the wait abates.
author: Angela L.

description:
The food is good but the wait turns me off. 

90 minutes later on a Sunday morning I was seated at the bar for a party of 2. 

Ordered the Plow with chicken apple sausages. This is a good choice if it's a first time visit and you want a little bit of everything. The potatoes made the meal! It was crunchy and well seasoned yet soft on the inside of every bite. I'm a fan of roasted potatoes that come out crispy but not dry-- Plow's didn't disappoint! As for the rest of the dish, it was alright. Ordered eggs over easy and it was just exactly that. The lemon ricotta pancakes is something I was really excited for. They were good: fluffy, soft, light, lemony and sweet. But they were a little too rich to eat an entire order of pancakes. I didn't even finish my two dollar sized that I got with the meal!

Overall the food is solid. But you have to mentally prepare yourself to wait over an hour in the SF cold (or sit at the coffee shop down the street). If you're up for it, go for it!
author: Carissa G.

description: I love the breakfast sandwich and the smoked salmon. The scrambled eggs was ok to me.
author: Linglong Z.

description:
Cute spot for breakfast with a gorgeous view of the city.  On the weekend, the line wraps around the block before it even opens.  On weekdays, it's not nearly as crazy but it does fill up quickly.  The service is very friendly and the food is soo good.  Seriously, everything I've ever ordered has been delicious.  

BREAKFAST
The Plow- eggs, potatoes, bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes
Chia pudding bowl
Breakfast sandwich
Eggs benedict + spinach and mushrooms


My only negative experience is getting food poisoning once.  We shared The Plow and I think the lemon ricotta pancakes were the culprit. Both of us were throwing up the rest of that morning.  Even though I now have PTSD (Pancake Traumatic Syndrome Disorder), I would still get the pancakes again because they were that good.
author: Lyn C.

description: Incredible breakfast with nice scenery, great friendly service. The green tea and toasted rice is genius!
author: Mark T.

description: If you're a fan of perfectly done potatoes and pancakes, give Plow a shot. The potatoes are deep fried and are served with yummy eggs and bacon. The lemon ricotta pancakes are among the best pancakes I've ever had. The homemade granola is decent if you're into that. Only slight drawback is the price (SF premium) but that shouldn't hold you back if you're in the area!
author: Matt H.

description: Came to the plow after reading several good reviews. Came at 930am on a Saturday and waited for an hour. The staff was very friendly. My husband and i both ordered the plow. The potatoes and house made sausage were delicious. The pancakes on the other hand were very small with a chalky consistency, and very little lemon flavor. They actually made me a little nauseous. I would not come back.
author: Naima G.

description:
This is the best brunch place I have ever been.
We waited for almost an hour.
Everything was very fresh. 
 Best Eggs benedict.
Banana bread is so  perfect.
author: Krishna M.

description:
I wish I could give it a 3.5. My experience was good here but it's was not shell shocking die worthy.  Aka--a tad too much hype! I'm pretty sure the only reason there's so much buzz is it's in Potrero hill...

If you come here, make sure to get the lemon ricotta pancakes (yum they were good). 

There was much buzz about the fried egg sandwich... I got it with the nueske bacon. Yeah it was good but again I wouldn't shell out that much for a fried egg sandwich and it wasn't that memorable

I think what I still dream of are those freaking fried potato fries things - make sure to get an order of those. I am actually serious about that.
author: Tiffanie T.

description: Ate breakfast here while visiting San Fran.  Wonderful food and great service.  We waited 20 minutes for a table for four on a Friday morning.  Don't miss the Hong Kong style toast (listed as a side item) - it's amazing!
author: Jessica P.

description:
Another wonderful experience at Plow this weekend! I mentioned Juan in my last review. When we arrived, he remembered us and I was there about a month ago! It was so refreshing to know that staff truly cares about their patrons. There was a bit of a wait again but it's worth it! We ordered the soft scramble and almond flour pancakes to share. Some of the best pancakes I have ever had. And the scramble was cooked perfectly, with just enough goat cheese! Yum. Also, the breakfast potatoes are insanely delicious. They have a bit of a sweetness and a little crunch, which I appreciate.

Not only is the food incredible, I will continue to come here because of the lovely staff. Can't wait until I am back in town to go again.
author: Lauren W.

description:
I'm not sure I would wait 1-2 hours on a weekend to eat here. I waited about half an hour with a friend on a Tuesday at 10:15am. We were seated outside (I would have preferred inside for the ambiance) and the table was kind of lopsided because the outside tables are on a small hill and one of the legs wasn't level, so my friend's coffee spilled when the table jerked to one side and someone had to come with a wedge. 

My friend ordered the breakfast sandwich and liked it. I had the soft scrambled eggs with shiitake mushrooms, cherry tomatoes, and goat cheese. It comes with a couple small pieces of toast and I substituted the potatoes with a side salad. I enjoyed the side salad but the eggs were probably not the most exciting thing to order (I've seen the lemon ricotta pancakes are recommended by others). We each got coffee and the waiter kept it flowing! The price (about $15 each) seemed reasonable for the food and experience.
author: Sara M.

description:
We saw people waiting in line outside of this tiny place and were curious what's that's all about. We waited for our spot for 25 minutes but our order was right out. 

I was disappointed with the chia seed pudding; if you're craving one; the best one I've had so far at Jane's on Fillmore. It felt really heavy and the bee pollen doesn't make it taste good.

Potatoes were tasty BUT I was sick after eating them for hours, couldn't get the taste of them out of my system; so I'd never order these things again. 

Friend I was with got a smoked salmon "do it yourself" plate. After such a long wait it was annoying to have to deal with all the ingredients on the plate and dry pieces of toast to have a decent dish. 

Personally, I just had a way better experiment at Chez Maman around the corner, next time if in the area I'd only go there instead.
author: V L.

description:
Tucked away in the residential area is this awesome little breakfast place. The food is delicious, service impeccable and views down the street are breathtaking. 

This, like many other small, cozy establishments is a place that will make you remember your visit to San Francisco. It enables new friendships with people sitting at the table next to yours, it sticks in memory.
author: Matija A.

description: Wow this place was really excellent.  A friend and I came here for brunch on a Saturday morning- we waited for around 30 minutes but the wait was well worth it!  The vegetarian scrambled eggs were perfect.  The potatoes were delicious, grapefruit juice was fresh, and they even had blankets for us since we were sitting outside and it was a bit chilly that morning.  The lemon ricotta pancake was amazing.  Don't miss this place!
author: Laleh J.

description:
I LOVEEEE Plow. It is easily on my top 5 breakfast places in SF. Be warned, the wait is long and you need to be ready for it. Every time I have been here its been over an hour wait. They have amazing pancakes and AWESOME potatoes. I could eat just dishes of those. Even brought my little cousin here and she was able to easily find food she liked too! 
The staff here is super friendly. I've sat outside a few time and they have blankets for you to use if its too cold. Be prepared to want to order everything on the menu. I recommend the Plow breakfast. That way you get to try it all! Not great for large groups as it is not a super big place and they have a lot of little tables.
author: Makenzi B.

description:
Amazing, amazing brunch spot. I came here on a Friday morning around 9:30 am and had to wait 20 minutes for a table for 3 and it was definitely worth it. Plow looks like a plain brunch place- the menu isn't that extensive and pretty simple, but they make everything so well. The place is also pretty small, but they manage to cram a lot of people in there! (There is also outdoor seating). 

I had the breakfast sandwich with bacon. I'm actually not much of a bacon person and I don't usually order it; I'm so glad I did. The bacon was cooked perfectly and almost a little sweet! The sandwich was also just delicious in general. The aioli sauce is so good and they really slather it on there. I also got to try my friend's order of the famous lemon ricotta pancakes and I now understand why they're so popular. The lemon flavor is quite prevalent, and the texture of the pancakes is crunchy on the outside and soft and cakey in the inside. So good!! 

The place is also really nicely lit with cute decor. Such a nice place to have brunch with friends. Street parking is free and easy. I would love to come here again!
author: Ellen M.

description:
LOVE this place. The food is perfectly right. Super crispy fried rosemary potatoes, homemade sausage, lemony pancakes perfectly fluffy and soft scrambled eggs done exactly how they should be which I find pretty rare. Our server Yonya was great and always around for coffee refills. 

One gripe though made it lose a star- it was $4.75 to order a piece of toast. It came with 3 slices and homemade jam that we didn't need or want and that price is outrageous, especially considering the Hong Kong toast with condensed milk was just $4. It's a small thing but that really irritates me when a place price gouges on the side items. 

Waitress was awesome.
author: Christine H.

description:
Tip: Anyone taking a ride share here after 8:01 be prepared to place your name on the long lost scroll aka the host notepad of never ending two-tops. I've been here on Wednesday mornings waiting 30-45 minutes. Weekends are like a Jordan release. If you are from out of town and only have a few days to experience the awesome PLOW with its crispy and crunchy perfectly salted spuds alongside the heavenly lemon ricotta pancakes then do as I say!!! Start with a warm base layer thermal onesie if you must. Then your favorite hoodie, jeans and goose down coat. Walk up to the host and proceed as instructed and thank me later "Hi! Table for two AND outside tables are fine." Not only will your feet thank me but seeing other patrons who wished they were having a mimosa and a biscuit is priceless.
