I only decided to share this because I felt sorry for the throngs of people that hopped out of that musty Prius running to the front door like they were on Amazing Race only to have that look of disdain walking back out to tell their foodie cohorts that the wait is only 2-2.5 hours. Hold this L.
The food is AWESOME. You see the pics and other reviews. None of em tell you what I just did. Cheers!
author: Rob M.

description:
Preeeeetty upset about immediately getting seated on #sunchdaybrunchday with a million people waiting outside. And wouldn't you be? Look, I had my sunscreen on, brought my Zora Neale Hizzurst book club novel, had my online date inbox pulled up to actually stop ignoring beezys... dude I was so ready to urchin it out till like sundown before chomping brunch. #sigh #firstwaitinglistproblems #orlackthereof #yesimjoking

(^_^) Biscuit #iwant10more #twss
(^_^) Blood Sausage #wishmoresavory #twss
(^_^) Iced Tea #anecessity
(^_^) Music #ripmj #jackson5 #ogreggae
(;_;) Pig Ears #stillathingofthepast

Need gravy though. #thatswhatshesaid Funny how Beat It played after I'd posted about a random grandma I saw en route resembling the Beat It MJ x Elvira; this brunch was meant to be.
author: Dan B.

description:
I mean... best brunch I've had in years. Get THE PLOW with lemon ricotta pancakes. Absolutely best  pancakes I've had in my life. Their eggs and  bacon are also delish. The home fries-omg. I can't even describe their crunchiness. I left STUFFED. Completely stuffed and happy. Coffee was good too! And I'm picky about my coffee. 

You will probably have to wait on a table, but it's worth  it. Service was good, atmosphere was great. I will return next time im in San Francisco. All 5 of us loved everything on our plates.
author: Lauren B.

description: This was my first time here and I have to say this is a great breakfast spot. I got the Plow and my Bf got the breakfast sandwich and both were delicious! Definitely making another stop here next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Christina R.

description: The line was incredibly long and they weren't taking reservations. It ended up taking about an hour to be called and we waited that long because we heard the food was good and we were already committed. We got seated outside in the freezing cold and our little kids were freezing as well. Good thing they have blankets for the guests that have to sit outside. The second cup of coffee served to me was cold. I feel like they tried their best but overlooked some stuff. The food was good but the experience wasn't. I probably wouldn't go back.
author: Julie P.

description:
It's a standard brunch place at the end of the day. Food is pottery solid but probably not worry the inevitable wait you'll have to go through.

We were told 1.5hrs and then after a bit of walking around it extended to two hours. Basically everyone gets the plow, which is standard breakfast - eggs, potatoes, meat and a couple small lemon ricotta pancakes. The bacon was very good and so we're the pancakes. The other stuff was fine too but nothing special. The best thing was the biscuit as a side - super buttery with a nice crust on the outside! 

Overall not worth the wait, just go down the street or elsewhere.
author: Phil D.

description: Amazing food and bonus points because they played Fleetwood Mac the entire time I was here.
author: Justin M.

description: Had breakfast here. It was ok but a little over priced for breakfast. Kind of a hipster place of which I am not. so.........
author: Jim B.

description:
With my Yelp bookmarks on the rise due to Ben F.'s food pictures, I knew I wanted to knock a few off during the Memorial Day weekend.  After a quick stop at Neighbor Bakehouse beforehand, we headed over to Plow.  We arrived about 10 minutes before opening to already a long line so still had to wait an additional 40 min after opening to secure a table.  We were flexible with either inside or outside tables to cut the wait time so I was a bit confused when two parties of 2 after us in line got seated inside before us.  

We got one of the outside tables that they start opening up at 8:30 and although it was a bit chilly, they provide blankets to keep you warm or to use as a backrest if you happen to be leaning back on an incline.  Per Ben's recommendation, we knew we had to get the Plow and if I did not just buy 7 pastries from Neighbor, we would have both gotten the Plow.  Lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, pork sausage and two eggs anyway you like (we like poached), it is brunch heaven on a plate.  For our second order, we decided to go for a full order of lemon ricotta pancakes with blueberry compote and Vermont maple syrup.  If you order just pancakes, they are larger and thicker than the ones that comes with the Plow and comes with an order of 3.  At first bite, it tastes fluffy and light but as time goes by, you realize it is also decadent because of the ricotta with the hint of lemon lending a brightness to it.  

If I lived in the city and could get here even earlier without having to get up at 6AM, you would see me here more often so if this is Ben's way of getting us to move to SF, it may just be working!  Seriously though, although it is not foreign to me to wait in line for good food my limit would still be an hour.  However, if you don't mind waiting longer, I suggest swinging by Neighbor Bakehouse beforehand and get a pastry to stave off your hunger while you watch all the good food paraded past you while you wait.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
One word: Potatoes! Plow potatoes are to die for! And generally everything on their menu is very tasty! I particularly like the breakfast sandwich and prosciutto toast. Their ricotta pancakes are also quite unique, but not really to my taste. 
The only downside is that there always seems to be a wait for brunch. Expect half an hour on weekdays, and at least an hour on weekends. And because the establishment is extremely small, prepare to get cozy with neighboring tables!
author: Audrey G.

description: The lines are long but the service is friendly, the lemon-ricotta pancakes melt-in-your-mouth good and bacon nicely crispy. I've only been once but, despite the noise and lines I was impressed: one of the better breakfasts I've had in recent years. The free coffee-while-you-wait is a really nice bonus. Worth a trip.
author: Eli L.

description:
Made the trek to Potrero Hill for some a Friday morning breakfast and the wait was about an hour for two people. We ended up getting seated at the bar, which was fun because we got to watch all the cooks do their thing. Decided on ordering The Plow, since it had a good balance of everything. It includes the lemon ricotta pancakes, sausage patty, scrambled eggs and potatoes. Boy do a lot of people order The Plow, because that's all it seemed the cooks were cranking out. 

My favorite part about the dish was the crispy potatoes. The pancakes were super fluffy and had a nice lemon flavor. The sausage patty seemed a bit dry, but I liked the flavor. Price was pretty steep for $17 a plate, but it was a solid meal.
author: Tessie N.

description: There is always such a long wait here but I do love their breakfast. I recommend getting "the plow" because it comes with everything. They are known for their lemon ricotta pancakes and plow potatoes which are included in that breakfast.
author: Yvonne L.

description:
Plow is the definition of brunch: sophisticated yet rustic, inventive yet comforting, locally sourced yet transcending space and time! Okay, maybe I'm being a little dramatic, but let's be real, you can't find a more perfect brunch spot anywhere. First, I gotta give a shoutout to the street it's located on (Texas St, woot woot). 

You will most definitely have a wait but you can grab a coffee and hang outside and soak in the views at the intersections around the block...not a bad way to wait for food! The interior is small but surprisingly fits a lot of people! There's bar/diner seating too if you're on your own. Service was seriously spectacular from the moment you walk in to the moment you (sadly) walk out. 

Food: potatoes. potatoes. potatoes. Get the potatoes. They are crispy, soft, bold, herbacious, and with some of the hot sauce on the side...perfectly tangy. The lemon ricotta pancakes are heavenly--warm, fluffy, with just the right amount of lemon and sweetness. All this with a side of the seasonal fruit, and you are in for one hell of a day. It is incredibly filling as well! We didn't eat again until the evening and walked around golden gate park all day! 

Next time I'm in SF, I know without a doubt where I'll be eating!
author: Nazia H.

description:
The Brunch place in the city, all the hype is true and well deserved. Now the wait times are ridiculous especially if you are coming in with a bigger group. I have come here with a party of two and came here just by myself and both times i was seated within 10 mins. But I believe i am just one of the fortunate few. 

The Plow is the go to dish for any rookie over here. you get eat everything that you can want for your breakfast. eggs, plow potatoes (da bomb), sausage . The potatoes are mind blowing. 

they had a pork chop dish on special. I hadn't seen that on the menu on previous visits so I was curious and ordered it. I was in for a treat. one of the best pork chops I have eaten. Tasted great, great cook on it and prefect sear on both side. loved every bite of it. 

Lemon ricotta pancakes - got a side order of it. they were fluffy buttery and delicious, but i am more of a savory kinda guy so if you got a sweet tooth this is a must. 

There is a reason for the long lines, but if you wait you will be rewarded and the reward tastes oh so delicious.
author: Anuj C.

description:
I'm so glad I came here for breakfast on my trip to San Francisco! I ordered the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes with blueberry compote, and they were hands down the best pancakes I've ever tasted. Light and fluffy, not dense and heavy like most pancakes. My boyfriend got the breakfast sandwich, which was also delicious! The breakfast potatoes are cooked to perfection as well. If you're a coffee person, definitely try the cold brew!
Food came out pretty quickly too! It's a small place, so get there early!
author: Michelle O.

description: Terrific establishment. I love sitting at the bar and watching the cooks work their magic. Roasted potatoes are well cooked. All was just perfect.
author: Bryan H.

description: My favorite breakfast in SF! Try their plow potatoes and fried egg sandwich. You will not be disappointed! Totally worth the wait.
author: Elvia D.

description:
The place to see, be seen, be seen eating.

I've been having a bit of fun trying to find new places to go in my new found freedom, to no fault of my own.  I've taken the cue from a few other people and tried to get here early.  I arrived before 8:30 am during the week to a nearly empty restaurant, and by the time I was finished less than an hour later all the seats were taken. So get here early.  Time went quickly, as I sat at the counter, dining solo, and enjoyed watching the chefs do their thing.

First time I had The Plow breakfast.  This comes with 2 eggs your way, choice of protein, Plow potatoes,  and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes.  I like my eggs over hard, so that way I know I will get fresh cracked eggs.  I did not notice if the eggs for scrambled eggs or omelets come from a ladle.  I chose chicken apple sausage.  Everything was very good.  The lemon ricotta pancakes do not need any of the accompanying maple syrup and are light, and the lemon brings it together.  The potatoes are first boiled, lightly smashed, then deep fried and tossed with a few herbs and fewer onions that do not overpower.  Quite possibly the best breakfast potatoes I've had.  They pale in comparison to the undercooked potatoes from Crepevine, but that's another review.

The second time I had a simple two egg breakfast with house made pork sausage and a buttermilk biscuit.  This was an equally good choice, but I would choose the pork over both the chicken sausage and bacon, for the simple reason that the pork is house made, the bacon and chicken sausage are not.   Some of the coffee cakes and biscuits are only available until they are all gone, so it's a good idea to grab it while you can.  Same for the Chinese Breakfast,  which I want to try next ... pork shoulder with chili garlic ginger sauce, 2 fried eggs and rice.  It sounds so perfect. 

Service is friendly and efficient.  Sitting at the counter I saw the servers correct the plates several times when the order was incorrect.  

Coffee is provided by Equator, if I recall.  This place is worth getting up early for ... of course I'm up early every day whether I want to or not.  The only negative was the provided hot sauce ... it was not as spicy as I normally like on my eggs.
author: Michael M.

description: It's a cute place that was so busy even on a Thursday morning. I came around 9:30 am and waited for about 20 min. This isn't bad compared to a weekend, but we're talking about a Thursday. I got the infamous Plow with pork patties and scrambled eggs. The eggs were so nicely done! Still a bit runny, which I personally love. The patties were good, though drier than I expected. My friend got the bacon, and he said it was heaven so maybe order that if you go. My absolute favorite part was the LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES. Man, I cannot describe the fluffiness. Not too sweet either! I sat at the counter and saw them making fresh pots of ricotta. Literal magic. You can see that they always were grilling up at least 10 pancakes because they were in such high demand. For $17, it was on the pricier side, but the pancakes make it worth it.
author: Sophie D.

description: The 2 hour wait is worth it.  The food is amazing, I went with two other people and tried their meals too which were all amazing as well.  The staff is super friendly and nice, the restaurant is clean and cute.  Don't wonder too far or at least keep someone waiting while you do other stuff they do call out before hand and they mark you down when you are not there.  I would eat here everyday if i had the time!
author: Sebastien L.

description: I really love this place. So delicious. We had house made granola, lemon ricotta pancakes and the plow..
author: Suzane S.

description: Wonderful employees and food is delicious. Really enjoyed the El Paso scramble. Love that you can choose any side no matter the price. Incredible place at all, left recently with a good mood.
author: Madelyn F.

description:
I'm giving this place 3.5, just because of their lemon ricotta pancakes. YUM!
Gotta say this place is popular!  Got here on a Saturday morning 20 minutes before opening and we were the 7th in line.  0.o

Ordered:
              Blood sausage/eggs/toast/potatoes 3.0
              The plow 4.0

We aren't strangers to pork blood and so ordering something that different was a no brainer for us, we're open minded.  But we shouldn't have been.  It wasn't very good...Lover is a champ and downed it but I could tell he wasn't happy.  Although the crispy potatoes were good!
  
My dish was YUMMERS!  I love the lemon ricotta pancakes, my first time btw.  They were soft, fluffy, slightly tangy, a hint of sweetness so that I don't even need that sweet maple syrup they gave me.  I opted for their housemade sausages instead of the other bacon option...WRONG CHOICE.  Their sausage was made from a lean cut or something??  Boy was it dry.  This dishes' saving grace was the crispy po' and lemon ricotta pancakces.  

Will I visit this place again? Heck no, nothing spectacular.

I have to add there was a girl in front of us waiting by herself.  When they finally opened she asked one of the guys if they do take-out.  Response "No"  O well can I sit down, order, and take it to-go. Response "No"  Wow that SUCKS.  She was there BEFORE us and she left empty handed.  Douche.
author: Katrina N.

description:
Absolute favorite brunch spot of all time - SF or anywhere.  Yes, there's a lot of hype...yes, there will be a wait...yes, there will probably be several tourists trying out the spot.  Typically, this will sway me away from any place, but after seeing all the pictures, reading all the reviews, and also hearing from several of my SF friends how delicious it was, I ponied up and decided to make my way there.  

My husband and I opted to try it out over the 4th of July weekend on a Friday mid-day, hoping to avoid the Saturday/Sunday brunch crowd.  We just prepared ourselves for a long wait - we ended up getting there around 12:30PM or so, and I think we waited for about an hour, which isn't bad.  My husband grabbed a beer as we waited, and I popped in to one of the boutique stores just up the block to browse/bum time.

When I was browsing at the store, I asked the store owner what she recommended at Plow.  She started off by highly recommending the "Plow" plate to get a sampling of all their stuff, said to ("whatever you do") get the baked good of the day if they aren't sold out, and then proceeded to pretty much list off every item they offered.  Pretty much, I knew right then and there that Plow would be a repeat brunch spot ;)

Everything we tried was excellent - every item blew my mind.  You can tell that every ingredient they use is high quality, in season, and fresh.  The eggs, for example - the yolks are bright orange, and whites so fluffy.  I learned that they buy their eggs from a local organic egg farmer in Napa - always delivered fresh.  

While we wanted to try everything on the menu, we tried:

The Plow (two lemon ricotta pancakes, two eggs any style, choice of pork sausage/chicken sausage/bacon, crispy potatoes) *****5 stars*****- We decided to share the Plow so we could try a bunch of the stuff they offered.  We selected the pork sausage per recommendation of the waitress and poached eggs.  I can't even pick which item was my favorite - everything was so perfectly done and went so well together. The perfect amount of savory and sweet.  The crispy potatoes were the best I've ever had - crisp on the outside and soft in the inside, and piping hot from the fryer.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were the BEST pancakes ever, ever, ever, ever.  I will be getting these (at least as a "side") every single time.  Holy crap, so good.

Banana Bread - *****4.5 stars***** One of the "baked goods of the day" - We thought it would be a bit much with everything else we were ordering, but since we received the recommendation to order "whatever baked good they are offering" we decided to go ahead.  We figured, "well we can bring any left overs home."  Uhhhh, let's just say, there were no leftovers.  SO delicious; came out warm, had a crispy crust of sugar coating the top, had chunks of gooey bananas throughout, and buttery flavor.  Mmmm...

Little Gem Salad - *****5 stars ****** To balance out some of the savory of our meal, I decided to order a little gem salad.  I was expecting nothing special, but even the salad surprised me!  The dressing was amazing; fresh and tasty.  All ingredients were fresh, seasonal, and balanced everything nicely.  I wish I could get this salad for lunch every day!

Bubbles/Beer - We also opted to make it a true brunch and ordered some adult beverages.  Decent selection of beers and wine.  If a cup of joe is more your cup of tea ;) - I heard that their coffee (even their decaf) is excellent.

Overall - this place is brunch/lunch perfection.  I am SO happy we're a quick walk to this place.  We will DEFINITELY be back many, many, more times.  Definitely, definitely, definitely a must-go....
author: Rachael S.

description: $4.05 for a serve your self, as I am too busy, cup of coffee? Come on guys! Get a different coffe supplier if they are charging you that much. Unless , you are the one ripping people off by making over 200% per cup.
author: Davis E.

description:
Thinking that there would be no line on a random Tuesday- I was wrong. Definitely be prepared to wait anytime and any day of the week! We waited about 30ish minutes, so not terribly bad. 

I ordered the veggie and egg bowl, it was really good!! I had to also add a side of Nueske's bacon which was tasty as well. My friend ordered the Plow- can't go wrong with that. 

Overall, would definitely come back!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Just enjoyed the signature Plow breakfast at this amazing spot! Adding another five stars to the chorus!

One of the best places I have dined at in San Francisco. Great, scenic walking area with hills that take the guilt away from the multiple pancakes you're likely to take down. I'll definitely be back next time I visit SF
author: Jay S.

description: After trying to come here multiple times (wait was over 2 hours) I finally got in! We were seated outside, the service was prompt and the food was delicious. Definitely a bit overrated. Not sure it is worth that long of a wait, but it is a good brunch.
author: Claire M.

description: Best breakfast I've ever had! Everything is fresh, homemade and it tastes yummy! Their freshly made sausage patties are the best I've ever had. The potatoes are baked and then fried making them crispy on the outside and full of flavor with the fresh spices added! You can't go wrong with this place!!!
author: Rod D.

description:
It's true. The lemon ricotta pancakes are heavenly. Came here on a Monday morning around 8am and it was already packed! The servers were pretty quick about clearing tables and moving the line so we were seated pretty quickly. It didn't take long for me to decide what I wanted since I went there with the lemon ricotta pancakes already in mind. I ordered "The Plow" which consisted of two eggs any style, plow potatoes, your choice of house made pork sausage, bacon, or chicken sausage, and two lemon ricotta pancakes. 

So I never usually finish my potatoes at any brunch place but omg these were amazing. It was roasted perfectly with rosemary and super crispy. The sausage was seasoned perfectly and my over easy eggs were pleasingly runny. But the real star was the pancakes. How they make it so fluffy and light I will never know. They had a super strong lemon flavor. So, if you don't like lemon, don't order. But how could you not? 

I would definitely go back to try the other items on the menu. The plum ricotta pancake seemed interesting. If you're a first timer, you really can't go wrong with "the plow" because the dish includes everything that you would want to try as a first timer.
author: Jennalyn L.

description: Oh The Plow, let me count the many ways I love you.  There is yet to be a restaurant that has pure almond flour pancakes without a bunch of other junk in the batter.  I do believe these flapjacks flopped down from heaven just for me. The wait is long, so snuggle up next to a tree and watch SF hustle and bustle in the meantime because it's worth it.  Their house made pork sausage is scrumptious as well.  Thank you Plow for being the only restaurant where I can eat pancakes  I will gladly visit you every vacation I have to SF.
author: Melissa R.

description:
Outstanding. One of the culinary highlights of a recent trip to the Bay Area. Sat at the counter, which I normally don't like, but watching the experts at work making our breakfast right in front of us was a delight.  Was thrilled to see blood sausage on the menu and loved it, but was also quite envious of my companion's lemon ricotta pancakes.  

Crowded and we had to wait even on a Wednesday at 10:30 (I thought I understood how seriously San Franciscans take brunch; I was mistaken) but totally worth the minor inconvenience and then some. Will definitely be on the itinerary for the next trip.
author: David T.

description: Came here for brunch with two friends and ate outside. Luckily it was decently warm enough out and they provide blankets for you while you eat. Didn't give 5 stars only because they don't take reservations and you need to put your name on and wait for a couple of hours it seemed. Also, by the time we sat down, a few menu items were no longer available.
author: Samantha E.

description:
Came here around 1pm on a Friday (they close at 2) and it was only a short wait. I did my Yelp research and ordered the popular egg sandwich, bf ordered the plow, and we shared a Hong Kong style toast. Everything was good and lived up to its reviews. However, it was overpriced for the portions. The Hong Kong style toast was one of my favorite childhood snacks but honestly not worth $4. You can buy a loaf of bread and can of condensed milk for $5 and have 10x the portion. 

I would say that it's worth a try, but not a place I would be going back to anytime soon.
author: Renee B.

description: Had the pleasure of trying Plow for Sunday brunch with some friends. We had to wait about 1hr and 45 minutes which was ridiculous but I figured the food must be that good. I had the soft scramble which was delicious but i don't know if it's so good it worth waiting almost two hours for. I also had a side of the lemon pancake which was deliciously soft. Our food came out very fast but that was probably but that could have been because we were the last few people to get seated to eat. The staff was friendly. I may try it again but I would have to go when they first open because I refuse to wait that long to eat again.
author: Kami M.

description: The 1 hr wait was worth it.  Bring a book or grab coffee and get there early.  I checked in by 9:20 and was seated by 10:15.  If you're in the Bay Area you must come here for brunch
author: Bernadette P.

description:
If you're not willing to wait 2 hours on a weekend, you can stop reading. :)

Best lemon ricotta pancakes ever. If I am in the mood, I would wait in a coffee shop nearby (there is one half a block away) and patiently wait to eat my pancakes.

To be honest, everything here is done so well. The menu is not big. But every item is solid. Their home fries are delicious and I normally can't be bothered with fried potatoes. They're crispy on the outside and very flavorful.
author: June W.

description: Came to plow today Sunday January 14th Sunday at 9:30 when we came they told us our weight will be about 45 minutes we we were okay with that we sat for about over an hour and they told us that we had about 4 people ahead of us 30 minutes before I was really excited to go to plow heard a lot of people Rave about it just wish the wait wasn't so long my advice is maybe stay open later I can't even write their food to say if it was good or not but I know I won't come back because it wasted my time
author: Erin W.

description:
Ok, I never leave reviews.  Mainly because most experiences, especially dining do not wow me.  I have to review Plow because it was an experience that was good enough to me that I want others to know.  

I was here this past Saturday- 9/30 and got there about 12:30 for brunch.  I expected the hour or so wait and the weather was beautiful, so no complaints there.  

The host staff was awesome.  Hustling obviously, but happy, smiling and engaging as well.  Just great vibes all around (See the dread dude Randall at the door). 

The food...I had really high expectations for the food as I had previously read some reviews touting Plow as the best breakfast in SF.  Usually I would brush these off as hyperbole, but in this case, those claims must be taken seriously.  

I ordered the Plow, which was Lemon ricotta pancakes, breakfast potatoes, homemade pork sausage, eggs.  I did not want this meal to send.  Everything was perfectly cooked and the flavors were very memorable.  Everything, even down to the onions in the potatoes had so much flavor. This was clearly not your run of the mill brunch.  It doesn't matter how long the wait is here, the food is worth it.  So glad I got to try this place out while in town.  This will be a must hit spot anytime I am in SF.  

So essentially everything about this place is right, the hosts, service, food, atmosphere were all top notch.  Hats off to Plow for making this Minnesotan actually write a review.  I am already looking plane tickets to get back for my next experience.
author: Brian C.

description:
My friends and I went on a Saturday at 7:55am (they open at 8) and still had to wait 30-40 minutes to be seated. On the upside, there's a cafe half a block away called Farley('s?) that was good to get coffee at and wait!

The food - we shared the Plow with the homemade sausage, Custard French Toast, and a side of chicken apple sausage.

It was all good, but honestly nothing you couldn't get at any other brunch spot. The Plow came with two small lemon ricotta pancakes (which were very lemony in a positive way), sausage, eggs, and potatoes. It was also $17... Other than the tiny pancakes, you could literally get that anywhere else for MUCH cheaper. The pancakes don't explain the steep pricing. The french toast was also nothing amazing, the apples on top were good though. 

Long story short, the food here is good, but nothing to wait in line for. There are pleeenttttyyyy of other places you could go, pay less, and get the same food.
author: Jillian Y.

description:
Great service and food!!!!

Chia seeds pudding was great!! Nuts and fruits added to the bowl bringing more texture

Biscuits were amazing as well with Jan and butter :)
author: Roy K.

description: This is second time trying out the place, feel service isn't  great and also slow. We were covered by dust at the end of the meal from napkins. My hubby's pants and our phone covers were filled with the dust. Foods were ok, nothing special. I am not sure I want to go back here in the future.
author: Hana W.

description:
I came here this morning with my boyfriend at 9:30 and expected a long wait. There was a huge crowd outside and the restaurant staff were working nonstop as fast as they could. We checked in and was told there will be a 45 minute to 1 hour wait. Many people were holding coffee, not sure if there is another cafe nearby or they ordered it from the restaurant as they wait. By 10:30, we were seated at the bar and placed our order of two egg benedicts with smoke salmon. 

The restaurant had an extremely friendly and casual environment. Some customers came in athletic attire while others were in a casual dress. Outdoor seating is available. but it will not affect your wait time. We didn't understand why they needed 5-6 waitresses when we estimated seating capacity to be ~50, but everyone was always busy. There were 5 kitchen staff constantly preparing muffins and fried potatoes. 

The fried potatoes were crunchy and not too oily. Even the bigger pieces of potatoes were crunchy which is extremely rare. My first benedict and salmon was delicious. But my other salmon was slightly sour and muffin a little too thick for me to enjoy. 

Great for kids. But due to space limitations, not a place where you should dine with more than 6 people. 

Four stars because the smoked salmon was not as fresh as we expected.

We will definitely return to Plow.
author: Danae L.

description: I've had breakfast here twice and both times were excellent. It's a small restaurant but the food is fantastic and the service is good. I love the almond flower pancakes and breakfast potatoes but everything is solid.
author: J M.

description:
My favorite brunch place in the city. Mostly visit after 1 pm when the line is relatively short. They accept names till 2 pm so that's good.
My go-to dishes:
Lemon ricotta pancakes - d'uh! My friend almost cried, it was so good. 
Get the entire plate (which comes with the blueberry compote), the side doesn't but you can always ask for it I guess. I'm not even a fan of blueberry yet I love the compote.
Almond flour pancakes/French toast - pretty good and a nice change from lemon ricotta
Breakfast potatoes - crispy and heavenly
Scrambled eggs - the fluffiest, softest, amazing eggs I've ever had 
One of the non-egg dishes my friend ordered (can't recollect which) wasn't particularly enjoyable
If it's a little chilly and you are seated outside, they give nice warm blankets!
author: G J.

description: I don't like how I felt rushed ordering my friend was running a few minutes late and I had to order for her. The waitress was stressed I understand the policy is to order together, but the hassle and having the waitress correct my friend's order because what I had ordered for her she didn't want could have been resolved if they could wait a few minutes. If I could wait on the waiting list as a first timer patiently, Surely they could have waited for my friend. My first and last time coming.#sfnative
author: Marygrace F.

description:
Normally I'd say get the Plow - it's the perfect breakfast combo of eggs, bacon (or sausage), potatoes and pancakes. But sometimes, you gotta venture outside of your foodie comfort zone.

Enter Plow's Chicken Tinga. With a sunnyside egg on top. The photo speaks for itself.

Normally I try and show restraint when dining out, eating half of what's served on the plate. Not so much with the Chicken Tinga. I ate the whole thing! And munched on my friend's pancakes ;)
author: Abby S.

description: Came here with a bunch of friends, we ordered lemon pancakes, a fruit platter, and a "Chinese Breakfast". The lemon pancakes are extremely lemony yet not overly sweet, quite good, the fruit platter has somewhat unconventional combinations of persimmon, pear and stone fruits. The Chinese breakfast definitely has Chinese-ish items in it, also very filling, except that probably no one in China did this for breakfast (a good fit for a fast-food lunch though). Good atmosphere and a little bit overpriced, but decent. Come early, there was a line at 8am.
author: Tian W.

description: Come early! It takes an hour to sit down... buuutt its really good! The breakfast is deeelicious, the lemon ricotta pancakes are small but taste like a bomb lemon cake. The potatoes are very seasoned and delicious. They have that good bacon that's not that cheap crispy bacon. Overall very good experience out here in San Fran!
author: Mauro M.

description:
3.5 stars. This would've been a solid 4 stars had the wait been shorter.

I was really excited to try Plow. The pictures of the food looked delicious, and the decor looked super cute and up my alley. As mentioned in previous Yelp reviews, the wait is LONG, about 2 hours for a table and food. Because of the long wait, I had fairly high expectations that were unfortunately not met.

Food - went with The Plow with house-made sausage patties and eggs over medium & the Hong Kong toast. 

The Plow is easily sharable between two people, but who wants to share? The potatoes were definitely the highlight of this dish - they were crispy on the outside, but warm and fluffy on the inside. The pancakes were also warm and fluffy, but I found that the lemon flavor tasted a bit artificial. Sausage patties were underwhelming and under seasoned. In hindsight, I would've went with the chicken apple sausage. Eggs were also leaning towards over hard, rather over medium. 
The Hong Kong toast was burnt to black and I don't think this is how it was supposed to be intentionally served. Not impressed by the lack of attention to detail in the food.

Atmosphere - Very simple, but in the best way possible.

Service - I understand that it gets busy here, but there really aren't many tables around. Water glasses were left empty until we called the waitress over.

Overall: Would return if the line wasn't ridiculously long. Otherwise, there are plenty of other brunch places in SF to try.
author: Shirley H.

description:
Two stars, one for the mediocre food and 1 for the decent server. Done. The food was just OK. Not worth 45 minutes wait at 9am on a Saturday. 

Imagine that the waiter tells us as soon as we sit that they are sold out of 2 offerings, including the French toast at 9am after only 1 hour of breakfast service...(?!) how can that happen? It's bread. 

I should say, after trying 4 times to get here in time to get a seat, and finally only having to wait 45 minutes... I suggest they start taking reservations because honestly, this place isn't worth the wait!  
The food could be found anywhere, I think they were better some time ago... but they've past their prime. See ya!
author: Bridget K.

description: Great breakfast. Quintessential San Francisco. Everything about this place will make you happy.
author: Patrick T.

description:
POTATOES. I waited a good hour for breakfast on a good-weathered day, and yes, it was worth it. It's a tiny spot with delectable options, so the wait makes sense. My favorite thing was the potatoes, hands down. They fry em with onions and goodness gracious, douse those heavenly carbs with some hot sauce and I could die happy. 

I got the Plow breakfast plate and opted for chicken apple sausages. They were great and so was everything else on my plate. I was stoked for the lemon ricotta pancakes, but slightly disappointed because the lemon didn't pack a punch. My two friends insisted that they contained plenty of lemon flavor, but I fucking love lemon-flavored anything so I wanted MORE. But they were still good and I ate as much as my small self could handle. 

I wish I could have that Plow plate right now. But until next time, when I am once again willing to drive an hour then wait another.
author: Daisy T.

description:
Plow was WOW!!
We arrived early and we're lucky enough to get right inn. Place is small so heard there is almost always a wait. I would go back again and be more than happy to wait for their food. My wife and I split a order of the Hong Kong style toast  buttered brioche + sweetened condensed milk and it was amazing.....I wanted to lick the plate. I had the open-faced proscuitto + gruyere toast  chili + garlic egg fried up, frisee + parsley, toasted Acme brioche   14.75 and she ate the the plow  two eggs with choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes. Both delicious. This is a must when in the city.
author: Keith C.

description:
So this is my first time in San Fransisco & I must say the food is amazing; just off this one brunch spot alone!

So yes, there was a long wait (about an hour); but well worth it! 

*Suggestion: go with a group & divide & conquer regarding waiting to be seated. We split up in 2 groups & wandered to the nearby bookstore & swapped off in 30 min increments to wait in line. 

Anyways, the ascetics of the place is so San Fran! Cool vibes, natural lighting, nice people, good drink options, a little hipster energy! 

I ordered the Plow & substituted the pancakes for French toast, for a small fee. The potatoes were hardy & crisp & the overall meal itself was bomb! We also got the small fruit plate which was sooo tasty & fresh; it came with peaches, mango, plum, & some other exotic fruits. 

I'd definitely recommend this place, just brace yourself for the wait!
author: Maya M.

description:
Not bad, not great, and definitely not worth a 2 hour wait on the weekend.  Came here on a Tuesday at 12:30 and had to wait 35 minutes, not really worth It either, but it beats 2 hrs. Won't come back.

$32 for The Plow and a sandwich.  The food was good, but it doesn't warrant a crazy wait time.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Super great breakfast! 

Line outside before they opened. I was alone so I got a seat at the bar, which was great bc you could watch all the guys prepping. They had it down. 

Fast, friendly service. I had the coconut mochi cake (JUST finished being made, was still warm and was awesome) and the breakfast tacos. Holy crap. Spicy chorizo, sour cream, avocado, cilantro, so good. The plow potatoes were seasoned well, super crispy and soft on the inside. Good coffee that they made sure to refill.

Very pleasant experience, no cons! Get here early!
author: Tessa M.

description:
Finally got to try this place for brunch!! The place is tiny, which is really why the wait is so long.

I knew the wait would be long, so we planned ahead for it. Got there around 10:20AM on a Saturday, and the wait was around 1.5hrs for a inside table. If you don't care about inside / outside, then the wait is slightly shorter. We used that time to run some errands. By the time we came back, it was just past our name, but they still seated us promptly.

For two somewhat hungry, but not too hungry people, we ordered the plow as per everyone else's suggestion and the chia seed pudding to share. Plow was tasty - chose scrambled eggs and the chicken Apple sausage. The home potatoes were good, but not as delicious as other people had made it out to be. Similar with the lemon ricotta pancakes. Tasty, but it's was the flavor was a bit light in my opinion. 

The chia seed pudding was a nice surprise. Surprisingly refreshing with almond milk, seasonal fruits, nuts and honey. Great way to finish the meal.
author: Cynthia X.

description:
Lemon ricotta pancakes are cakey, fluffy, and moist.  They're amazing and so perfect with the maple syrup.  The plow seems to be the go to, as you get to try a little of everything.  Sausage patties are tasty and the potatoes are crispy.  

Service is friendly and pretty fast.  Parking is plentiful. And the wait's not so bad when you come close to closing.
author: Samantha C.

description:
The potatoes are to die for. 

I went to Plow on a Monday at 10 AM to get brunch with a couple of friends and the place was already packed full with a decent line. We had to wait 30-40 minutes just to get an outside table.

I ordered the open-faced prosciutto + gruyère sandwich, which was pretty good. The heaviness of the prosciutto, gruyère, and egg was well contrasted with the frisee. The toasted Acme brioche was satisfyingly thick and served as a good base for everything without being overbearing. The sandwich was a little bit on the greasy side, but it was definitely tasty.

The Plow potatoes though. Best. Potatoes. Ever. They were crispy, light, and airy on the outside, yet still soft and creamy on the inside. The potatoes alone were worth coming for. 

TL;DR - Long wait, pretty good sandwich, amazing potatoes.
author: Jon S.

description: Absolutely amazing food here. The only reason this place didn't hit a 5-star review in my book is the overpriced menu, the short staff, and the understocked kitchen. The waitress was running around with her head cut of off due to the capacity of this restaurant. She also had no sauces left in stock. I asked for vinegar, mustard, hot sauce.. they had nothing. How can a breakfast place operate without any condiments? Oh well. Food was still delicious. I recommend the Eggs Benedict. Home Fries are a 10/10.
author: Josh S.

description:
Kudos to the cooks behind the counter, these guys produce some of the best breakfast the bay has to offer. Those lemon pancakes people rave about, they're as good as everyone says. Eggs are always seasoned right, Oh so crispylicious potatoes, that French toast, the great coffee... 

But is it worth the time? 

That's on you. My gf hated me for asking her to wait almost 2 hrs to have breakfast here. In the end, she admitted it was almost worth it. Almost  (She's not as big on breakfast as I am, and she's very snobby about food, so that's somewhere between an 8.5 and 9 on the food from her) 

Get here EARLY, put your first AND last name down. 

Minus one  because the food is not always cooked just as well as I know it can be, for the wait time involved, it should be. Still, it's leagues above what most of the bay serves for breakfast. 

Also first visit I didn't put my last name down, my table was given to a person that arrived later than me. Adding salt to the wound a lady at the door made me feel like a liar and a criminal when I brought it to her attention. 

But it's all good that was just one time, once I put my fork in the food and it dissolved on the tongue I was like  

Every other time the staff has been really pleasant and great with service
author: Alex M.

description:
So after 4 some years in San Francisco,  I finally made it to Plow. Wowowowow. 

I went in on a Wednesday around 10am with a friend- we waited maybe 15 minutes before being seated at the bar. We then split a chia seed pudding, housemade granola with yogurt, lemon ricotta pancake, and a biscuit. Everything was phenomenal- the lemon ricotta pancakes actually taste like you are eating a cloud. The service was great and I will definitely be coming back!
author: Eliza D.

description:
Damn you, lemon ricotta pancakes. 

I was quoted a 2.5 hour wait. Unfortunately there didn't seem to be too much else in the area to explore, so my friends and I went to 2 other brunch places, put our names in, and after calling back to Plow to check in 2 hours later, were told we were the next large party to be seated, so come back. Slightly misleading, because when we got there we waited another 30 minutes - this place is TINY, with 6-7 tables and some bar seating. At least their wait time guess was accurate?

I got "the plow" which was 2 eggs, potatoes, choice of sausage or bacon, and the lemon ricotta pancakes (2 small ones compared to the 3 larger ones that come as an entree). Were the pancakes good? Yes. Was the wait worth it? No food is worth 3 hours. 

Do yourself a favor and do breakfast instead of brunch.
author: Ling X.

description: Solid, but why is there ALWAYS a wait?? I'm a huge fan of the lemon ricotta pancakes and their crispy potatoes, but I'm not a big enough fan that I'd wait an hour+ on a given day. I guess if you're down to wait, there are several coffee shops you can meander to and then catch up with friends while waiting outside. Whenever I drive by on early weekend mornings, there's always people with books reading outside - they were prepared to wait!! Parking is not a problem - you're bound to find something around the block or so, but be careful not to leave anything out in open view, since I've heard of lots of people getting their cars broken into.
author: Lily C.

description: Delicious food. Great service. Obviously I'm not in the minority here. If it was closer to my house and didn't always have a wait, I'd eat here every day.
author: Naomi W.

description:
Oh Plow....how sad I was this past visit...

The potatoes, the ones I used as my benchmark for all other potatoes, were sadly not the same. The texture was there but the seasoning missed the mark! 

Biscuits and gravy was satisfying, hearty and done well 

Surprise dish that morning, the pulled pork sandwich! It was simply scrumptious! 

Overall Thoughts

Third time might be the charm?
author: Eddie W.

description:
Plow was underwhelming for brunch and not worth the long wait. Luckily I called and was told to come around 1:00pm, an hour before closing for the shortest wait possible, so I only wait half an hour instead of two. Nevertheless, I still wanted to be amazed by their food, especially the pancakes and The Plow. 

We ordered the plow, which has a nice mixture of savory and sweet brunch items - eggs, sausage patties/bacon/chicken apple sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes, and plow potatoes. The eggs, sausage patties, and potatoes were overly oily and the potatoes were burnt. The lemon ricotta pancakes were softer and mushier than I expected. At least free street parking is ample; just be sure to read all street signs.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Way overhyped. Like all other popular brunch places in this foodie city of mine, the wait is ridiculously long. The food? Nothing to write home about. It was good but not stand-outside-in-the-cold-for-2-hours kind of good. 

I ordered the most popular dish here, the plow, which comes with 2 eggs your way, 2 mini lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy Rosemary potatoes, and a choice of either apple chicken sausages, bacon, or pork sausages. 

Sadly the best item on my plate was the crispy potatoes. The apple sausages didn't taste too different from any store-bought kind that you can heat up on your own at home. The lemon ricotta pancakes were dry and didn't taste completely cooked through.

Service was efficient after we sat down, but the hostess definitely messed up with seating people in the order that they came in. People were not happy about that.
author: Catherine C.

description:
This place was recommended to me and I think it was spot on. The potatoes are delicious and you'd kick yourself if you didn't try the lemon ricotta pancakes. There was a wait of course but they did work efficiently to get people in and out so the wait was shorter.

Make the trip for brunch, you'll be glad you did.
author: Alan B.

description:
Plow's crispy rosemary potatoes are pure potato perfection! I know it sounds silly that potatoes, of all things, are what keep me coming back, but after you try them, you'll understand that these are not ordinary spuds. These little bites of heaven must be double-fried because they have the most delightful crispy edges that go into all the nooks and crevices. They're perfectly salted and seasoned with fragrant rosemary. Hands down, the BEST brunch potatoes in the city!

Of course the potatoes aren't the only selling point for me. The popular lemon ricotta pancakes have a refreshingly light kick from the zest and are balanced out by the creamier texture of the ricotta cheese. They're definitely on the denser side, so if you're a fluffy pancake fan, these may not be for you.

They have a relatively small, but well-rounded menu that contains favorites such as the fried egg sandwich, smoked salmon eggs benedict, and corned beef hash. If it's your first time here, or for me the first 3 times, "The Plow" is the way to go! For $16 you get a nice sampling of two lemon ricotta pancakes, two eggs, a mound of heavenly potatoes, and your choice of bacon, or pork or chicken apple sausage.

They unexpectedly play throwback 90's R&B music all the time and I like the feel of their open kitchen and large glass windows that let in lots of natural light to help brighten your brunchy morning. The service is pretty average here. You're lucky if you get checked on once since they're busy running around all the time. They give you a pitcher of water though so refills are no problem. 

Expect an average wait of 1.5 hours, but if you're willing to wait until the early afternoon, you can arrive at 1:30 and only wait about a half hour since they stop taking names at 2pm. They can't accommodate parties of 6 or more due to their small size and they don't take reservations. Benches and a beautiful view of Mission Bay are available while you wait and parking isn't too bad. Plow continues to be one of my top brunch spots in the city. They are definitely worth a try!
author: Deanna Y.

description: I loved the quinoa bowl with the mushrooms and avocado.   The Plow was really good as well.  Coffee was perfect.    The quality of the ingredients was apparent and was worth paying extra as it was not cheap.
author: Deborah P.

description:
3.5/5~ Pretty solid brunch, I wouldn't wait more than 20 minutes but for simple items the food was well done. A really small corner that is pretty hyped up and decently lives up to its hype. Parking is easy around the area on the hill nearby.

I tried the chia bowl with almond milk and bee pollen as well as a pumpkin pancake. The chia bowl was light and refreshing, I liked the texture, temperature, and the golden bits of bee pollen that added slight bursts of flavor. The pumpkin pancake was standard, not too great of a seasonal item.

I also sampled a bit of "the plow" (platter) which was an enormous amount of food. The sausages were good and the golden potatoes were some of the best I've ever had. They had a nice color, seasoned well, and very aesthetically pleasing. It was just slightly too oily for me.
author: Steven V.

description: Had brunch here with a friend while i was in town for a quick trip. He suggested going to Plow for their much written about pancakes. I was in the mood for the soft eggs with shiitake mushrooms. My dish hit the spot! The mushrooms and eggs were very flavorful; the potatoes that came with them were a bit overcooked though but i scrapped a bit of the crust they had off and they were great. My friend seemed to enjoy his pancakes and will make the trip from Outer Richmond again for them. Service as very friendly and the restaurant was very clean.
author: Gaby E.

description:
If it's a Sunday, GO EARLY!!

My parents and I arrived 30 minutes before doors opened and there was already a line of 8 people! By 759AM, there were more than 2 dozen people in line!! That's crazy for a Sunday morning. As soon as the doors opened at 8AM, we were greeted and went straight to the counter. (We always enjoy sitting at the counter to watch the chefs. The chefs get into a rhythm which is a joy to watch. Each station is so different and they're masters of it!!)

As for the food, it was above average. To be honest, in the past the food was a bit better. Whenever we go, at least one of us with get The Plow which is amaaaaazing. (It comes with two eggs, two pancakes, your choice of house-made pork sausage, bacon, or chicken sausage, and Plow potatoes.) This time we got The Plow and it was just okay. The potatoes weren't really seasoned, the pancakes were gummy and the eggs were over-easy when I requested for sunny-side up. The best part of the meal was the house-made pork sausage. It had some spiciness to it, which was great. My mom ordered the Smoked Trout Salad and my dad ordered the Corned Beef Hash and Eggs. My mom's salad was lightly dressed with a vinaigrette, large chunks of smoked trout, avocado, and a poached egg on the side. It was tasty. My dad's corned beef hash was decent. We've had better at Sally's Dinner on the corner of 16th and De Haro. Both are homemade, but the one from Sally's has a better texture. The one from Plow was crunchy where it was hard and not as flavorful as the one from Sally's.
 
The service was great as always. They're personable and attentive to the customers. Every so often we catch a glance of them checking their phones and chatting, but it feels like a norm in the restaurant industry. Whenever we needed their attention, they gave us their undivided attention which is what matters anyway.
author: Aimee I.

description: One of our favorite spots by UCSF. Their biscuits are to die for. However the line is always very long to get in. Expect at least an hours wait.
author: Claudia V.

description:
Great brunch spot. I got the plow special and loved the pancakes (I normally don't). The biscuit (sold separately) was also really great! The pototoes were also really good. They also had endless coffee and other options including asian toast with the condensed milk over it. 
The line gets long so get there early even on weekdays. I got there Thursday morning and found the line about 30 mins. It fills up at 8am and then slows down a bit after 9am. Groups up to 6 people can fit, but if you are by yourself you can easily just sit at the counter.
author: Lily P.

description: Food is good. The potatoes in particular are amazeballs. However, I've been here 3xs and all times waitstaff suck. Reaally slow (30min 4 food whilst watching others who come in afterwards get served first w no acknowledgement) and dont chk in on you, within reason (i was once a busy diner waitress), or just rude in delivery. I asked about water once because the person next to me who came in after me got water first & i just asked if i should share the bottle with her. She deadpan said yeah as she was turning, ie w her back to me. I doubt i will go back unless a friend wants to go
author: Jt K.

description:
One of the best breakfasts I've had in a long time. The service was excellent and the food was delicious. What more could one ask for? 

I ordered the plow which I feel is a great way to sample a bit of everything, from eggs and chicken sausage to lemon ricotta pancakes. The potatoes were cooked to perfection-just as crispy as they should always be. The juice taste fresh, endless coffee and the tart is divine!
author: Catherine R.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for years and the food definitely lives up to the hype. I ended up getting their specialty, "The Plow" - two eggs, choice of bacon or handmade sausage (pork or apple chicken), potatoes and lemon ricotta pancakes. I opted for sunny side up eggs and the pork sausage. I am not a pancake person at all, but the lemon ricotta pancakes were definitely the highlight for me! Crisp on the outside, but perfectly fluffy on the interior - the lemon flavor was absolutely delightful. I don't remember the last time I enjoyed a pancake. The potatoes were also excellent - super crispy and filled with rosemary flavor. The pork sausages were juicy, but not super greasy - I thought the flavor was great. 

Plow takes the classic breakfast and adds their own twist to make it their own. I've never had a breakfast / brunch quite like this one, which is why Plow is always so busy. They know how to do breakfast right! 

I knocked off a star because of the wait time. I wish the hostess would have been more upfront with how long the wait was. I showed up at around 9:40am and was told my wait time would be 45 minutes to 1 hour, but ended up waiting 2 long hours. Since I was told 45 to an hour I didn't think the wait time was bad at all, since most brunch places in SF have similar wait times. Had I known up front that the wait was going to be 2 hours I probably would have gone someplace else. 

With that being said, I am glad I stuck it out and finally got to eat here - Plow is DEFINITELY worth the hype. This place is pure breakfast perfection and people come swarming here for a reason! Just know that it will take 2 hours. I definitely got a bit hangery towards the end of the wait, so I would definitely recommend a snack.
author: Samantha G.

description: There was a lot of hype for this place so we ventured during the severe storm advisory and were able to get seated within 30 minutes. The lemon ricotta pancakes were amazing but they were so small for the price. I would direct you to Finn town if you are into lemon pancakes it was a sizeable and portion and delectable taste. Pork was very flavorful, home potatoes intensely crunchy which is what we all crave, thank you for that. But it doesn't justify the wait for me.
author: Morgan S.

description:
4.5 stars. 

As you probably know by now, all decent brunch places (yes even in The Dog Patch)  are oversaturated with humans lining up early waiting for a table; in short, plan to dedicate at least 2 hours for any brunch experience in SF even though the meal itself shouldn't take more than an hour.

I put my name down around 9:10 and I think our party of 4 got seated around 10:15. Everyone got The Plow (2 pancakes, 2 eggs, potatoes, and meat of your choice) and we also shared the seasonal kale squash salad. The lemon ricotta pancakes were perfectly fluffy and lemon-y and the potatoes were the best breakfast potatoes I've had thus far.

Service was great as all of the staff was friendly and courteous. My -.5 stars is because the bacon wasn't very crispy and my friend's sausage patty was a little dry, but those reasons didn't get in the way of this being one of my new favorite brunch places.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Finally made it to Plow. I highly recommend making a trip here when you have a weekday off.
The breakfast sandwich was indeed as good as people on here have said, and the breakfast potatoes were also delicious. Oh yes, and try a lemon ricotta pancake. It's the perfect sweet ending to your meal here.
author: Teryll H.

description: Amazing! Hour plus wait, totally worth it! Had the prosciutto and gruyere toast with chili flakes... sooo good! Perfect balance of salt and heat. Also had the ricotta pancakes, they changed my feelings on pancakes...now I'm obsessed! Next visit to San Francisco will definitely include Plow!
author: Chelly L.

description:
Probably one of the greatest places I have eaten while in SF!

Great place for breakfast or brunch! Visited on a Monday morning early, like 7am because I heard it can be a long wait. Seated right away, party of three. It was fairly overcast and slightly chilly so there wasn't outdoor seating just yet. 

Me and two other friends ordered The Plow. Best option if you want a little of everything! The pancakes were on point!
author: Belen H.

description:
Best breakfast/brunch/lunch in town, no doubt about it!  Everything I've tried here has been amazing:  super light lemon ricotta pancakes, breakfast sandwich, open face prosciutto, the always reliable Plow breakfast, French toast.  Even the gluten free almond pancakes are tasty.  I have to mention the Plow potatoes separately because they are unbelievably crunchy on the outside, tender on the inside with just the right seasonings.  The restaurant uses high quality, locally sourced ingredients, and you can definitely taste it.  

I also love that the wait staff and the cooks seem to joke around with each other and give off a happy vibe.  Just a guess, but it tells me that they're treated well and are happy working there.
author: Amy P.

description: All I have to say - the lemon ricotta pancakes are to die for! The food here is out of this world. Come early because the line gets long as it's first come first serve.
author: Alexandra S.

description:
"I'll plow this field any day :P" Tell me that someone has said this already.

Some of the best breakfast food just happens to be a few minutes from my gf's house. Plow has THE best potatoes (seemed lightly deep fried rather than pan fried), house sausages, and lemon zest pancakes. Come mid week to avoid the wait. We got seated immediately (at a shared table) on Wednesday morning.
author: Joshua F.

description: First time going to SF and I walked up and down those hills to make it here.  Totally worth it and they had an excellent pancake!  I'm going back again in summer, and I'll definitely be visiting again for some brunch.
author: Paula N.

description:
This is my best friends favorite breakfast/brunch place so I come quite often. Make sure you come early or plan to wait in line because I can only remember not having to wait in line on two visits. 

The decor is really nice. I love the wooden tables and the counter seats have a marble table. Super Instagram friendly! 

I always get the plow because it has a little or everything. Meat, their lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, and eggs! Their potatoes are always perfectly crispy. I am not a pancake, ricotta, or lemon person, but Plow somehow makes me like their pancakes! 

Definitely a top brunch place on my list!
author: Lydia H.

description: This is so expensive!!! but it is good. The french toast is fine, but the potatoes are where it's at! I dream about them. Come to this place for the hype. The ricotta pancakes are not as special as I thought it would be. I enjoyed my experience here.
author: Evon K.

description:
I came around lunch time on a Tuesday to catch up with a friend and the wait was only 10 minutes! The place was cozy, the service was great, and the food was tasty. I ordered The Plow which came with 2 eggs, potatoes, bacon slices, and lemon ricotta pancakes. I'm not a big fan of pancakes, but these were delicious. The potatoes were crispy and made into perfection. 

Will be coming back in the near future!
author: Tina T.

description: This place is amazing. The staff is just hustling plates of goodness! Sitting at the bar gives you front view of all the amazing food they serve up. Everything we ate was delicious and they have a couple gluten free options along with vegetarian option. Will be back to this place next time I am in SF!! Thanks guys!
author: Kara D.

description:
Oh my. Probably one of my favorite brunch places in town. We walked in on a random weekday morning a little before 9AM and were met with a wait time of about 30-45 minutes. Considering the last time we tried to eat here, the wait time was over an hour, we decided to grab some coffees at the front and sit it out on the little ledge protruding from the side of the building.

Ambiance: Your typical SF brunch spot. Bustling place with small tables and a lively crowd.

Service: Our waitress was excellent and everyone else was really nice, too! Even though it's a busy place, we didn't feel rushed at all.

Drinks: We grabbed coffees up front and they just added it to our bill after we actually ate. They refilled us at the table, of course, though.

Food: I ordered The Plow  (two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes + crispy potatoes). Delicious. The pancakes were amazing and I love that the breakfast potatoes are crispy! The house made pork sausage was just okay and I think I would opt for bacon if I were to order the same dish again. My bf's fried egg sandwich was pretty legit. So filling and so worth it.

Cost: Not too bad for an SF brunch spot!

Would I return? Yup!
author: Leana L.

description:
The Plow got solid 4 stars from me. We got there fairly early around 8-9 am on a weekday and we found a parking spot on the downhill street next of The Plow. It was a little chilly in the early morning but they have open table on the outside. We were so glad we didn't have to wait too long for the seats. We decided to take the seats since we had to drive back down to LA right after. Then, one of the staffs handed me a blanket and said it will be chilly outside. I'm so happy about that. Then, she came with more blankets for the rest of our party. That was what I called a top notch service. 

I got the infamous egg breakfast sandwich with addition of avocado. It came with their well known potatoes. The dish is huge in portion. I could not finish the potatoes even though I have great love for them. My friends got the plow with home made sausage and they said it was really good. Their dishes were even bigger in portion. I also ordered an order of Earl Gray tea and it came with the most awesome tea pot. The tea itself is a bit pricy but it was worth it given the fact that they really invested in providing with the pot, etc rather than handing you a cup of tea. The staff came to check on us periodically and refilled my friend's coffee several times too.
author: Jen L.

description:
Good food but not sure it's worth the wait. We were a bit disappointed as the restaurant is listed as brunch with a view and there is not a view when seated either inside or outside. However, if you walk  a few feet from the restaurant and look down the hill there is a nice view.

Food was very tasty but expensive. We had the plow (2 eggs, potatoes, 2 sausage patties, and two small yummy lemon ricotta pancakes $17). Not sure it was all worth the hour long wait to get a table.
author: Teresa G.

description:
I find it hard to believe that I've only had one check-in at this place because I have certainly been here more times than I can count! 

It is my belief that this brunch spot has become the hipster version of Mama's (in Washington Square). What I mean by that is often times now when tourist come to visit and ask locals for a good brunch spot, there is a good chance they will be directed to check out the tasty and seasonal menus here at Plow. 

If it is your first time here or you're thinking of checking it out, BEWARE that if you come here on the weekends, expect to wait in a line (~1hr wait time). This place does very well and for good reason too. The ambience is "rustic"--the tables and furniture are all wood. I don't know why but it does something strange to my body that puts me in the brunch mood all the time. Also, if you're struggling to pick out something off their menu, I highly suggest trying The Plow (eggs, potatoes, homemade sausage patty & lemon ricotta pancakes) or The Egg Sandwich (Frisée, fried egg, bacon, aioli with a side of potatoes). Both are very tasty and stay on the menu throughout the year. This time around I had their Pork Chop and Eggs. The pork chop was cooked in a soy and garlic glaze and prepared with the perfect tenderness. If you have room for it, try one of their pastries too. I've never had room for one but they seem to be the first to go when this place begins to run out of certain items throughout the day. 

I cannot be absolutely sure but it feels as though they raised the prices on their menu. I remember The Plow being ~$13 but that is no longer the case. Everything on their menu jumped up noticeably by $1-2. If it comes from the price of a "farm to table" system then I guess I'm ok with it because the food is still very good and my experience has always been pleasant here. 

The 4/5 rating comes from the wait time primarily. Sometimes it can get a little out of hand. 

P.S. The brioche french toast with cinnamon apples is dabomb.com
author: Greg Y.

description:
Delicious breakfast in a picturesque, hilly neighborhood. We arrived mid-morning on a weekday and were able to get right in to seats at the bar. As a fan of watching the action in the kitchen, this was the perfect seat for me. I fancy myself an accomplished breakfast-chef. Those that know me are probably rolling their eyes because scrambled eggs and boxed brownie mixes are about the extent of my cooking ability, but please let me live in my own fantasy.

The front row view was perfect: when this place gets busy, the chefs ramp up their speed and work together in the cramped kitchen to get everything timed correctly, served while hot and sped out to the customer. Watching them griddle batches of pancakes, beautifully scramble eggs, and salt a batch of the crispy fried potatoes and shake them around the steel mixing bowl before plating was theater of the highest sort for me (OK hyperbole, but it was FUN!).

I enjoyed my Plow breakfast. I'm not totally a fan of lemon flavored pancakes, but these were perfectly prepared. If there was an option for just a buttermilk version I may go that way next time, but everything tasted good. SO had almond pancakes of some sort which she enjoyed. Overall a great experience if you can get in without having to wait forever.
author: Stephen K.

description:
The Plow was too much for me... but I couldn't enjoy it because of the dusty atmosphere.  I was sneezing, coughing, runny nose all throughout my meal.  Mind you, prior to walking in I was perfectly fine and when I walked out all my symptoms subsided.  

The place is cute, I must admit and their services was attentive, and I did enjoy their food but was it mind blowingly amazing like how some others have described?  Not so much.  

Great place for OnTheTable, morningslikethese, and foodporn hashtags... but it's all hype.
author: Lea M.

description:
Such great food!  Breakfast is my favorite meal, and Plow does it very well.  The eggs are cooked and seasoned beautifully, the potatoes are crispy, and the lemon ricotta pancakes are truly amazing even though they seem so simple.  The only thing I wasn't a *huge* fan of was the house made breakfast sausage, but it wasn't bad.  

We came here on a Wednesday morning around 10:30 am and had a short 25-minute wait.  I love the huge windows and natural lighting, and the area is quiet and inconspicuous with a few other cafes and coffee shops down the street.  Very cozy and happy environment! 

For the price, I definitely wouldn't (or rather, couldn't) come here often, but for a special breakfast once in a while, it might be my go-to.
author: Julia E.

description: Mm-mm-mm-mm-MM! Best brunch I've had in a long time! The breakfast sandwich was amazing - perfectly fried egg, plus tasty fixin's to boot! But OH MY GOD the Plow breakfast plate. It had absolutely everything anyone could ever hope for in a breakfast. Incredibly flavorful sausage, eggs scrambled to PERFECTION (and I'm a scrambled egg snob), lightly crispy country potatoes, and the delightful little surprise that is the lemon ricotta pancakes! Top it all off with a sparkling rosé on a sunny Saturday late morning and you've got yourself heaven on earth right here in San Francisco.
author: Hannah K.

description:
One thing for sure, expect to wait when you come here. When putting your name on the list, I would suggest leaving open the option to sit outside, and if your name gets called, tell the waiter or waitress you would like to wait for a table inside, so you can at least gauge if sitting outside will be comfortable for you as you wait, as it gets pretty cold and windy in that area (although they do provide blankets). Surprisingly, parking in the area is not that difficult, we've found spots open pretty quickly the few times we have been here. 

The FOOD is exceptional and this place is very clean! I'm really big on freshness and the quality of ingredients used and you aren't going to find many other brunch places that serve food of such high quality and flavor! All three times I've been here I've gotten the PLOW, can't go wrong as you get a little taste of everything. From the pancakes, to eggs, to the potatoes, to the bacon, every bite is so flavorful and savory. Might be my favorite spot for brunch in SF!
author: Austin B.

description: Delicious breakfast spot. If you don't get there 30 minutes before they open, expect to wait anywhere between around almost two hour. I always get the "Plow" which composes of eggs, crispy potatoes, choice of meat, and lemon ricotta pancakes. If you're in San Francisco and want to try something new, check out Plow.
author: Nima B.

description: The wait was super long but I think it was because the restaurant is very small. We waited about 45 mins to get in on a Friday early afternoon. The food was great and our waitress was quick, friendly and helpful. Ingredients in the food and even the condiments I think are local or as local as possible. They had the door open the whole time and it was super windy even inside the restaurant. Even though the food was good I'm not sure I would wait that long again. Worth trying at least once though!
author: Natasha B.

description: This has to be one of best breakfasts spots in San Francisco (in my opinion) every dish is amazing, they never fail. all the servers are so nice and caring. I love how you can watch the chefs cook the food. I feel right at home when I come here. definitely my Saturday morning treat after a long week, makes me feel so much better.
author: Jadah W.

description:
So I officially LOVE Plow. 

I had this place bookmarked for a while and my bf suggested we can grab brunch here. I have heard about the long wait so we tried to get there early, but alas, we waited about 45 minutes for a seat inside. 

However, the wait was worth it. We decided to try everything since we committed to the long wait time. We ordered a buttermilk biscuit, french toast and each got our own "the Plow". 

The biscuit was awesome and I would order it again.The french toast was perfectly grilled and the bread they use is perfect for french toast. The Plow comes with eggs, a meat, potatoes and 2 smaller lemon ricotta pancakes. The housemade sausage patty was OK, it was a little dry, but it went with the fluffy eggs and the DELISH potatoes. The potatoes are crispy and taste perfect. 

The lemon ricotta pancakes were the highlight of the entire meal. They had the right amount of lemon, where it didn't taste too tart and melted in your mouth. I didn't even use that much syrup because it tasted so good alone! I would definitely order these again, maybe on it's own too. 

Plow is officially my fave brunch spot in the city, it's a must try.
author: Leah F.

description:
Quality food all around!

(+) Potatoes were seasoned to perfection.

(+) French toast were thick and tasty. The cooks take their time with these. I observed their cooking process and they made sure they cook through and brown perfectly. 

(+) Biscuit was amazing. Yum! 

(+) Cooks and servers were the best! 

(+) No wait 7am on a Tuesday! Score!
author: Monica R.

description: 5 stars are under judgement!!! This place is the best breakfast I've had in my life. I mean, I own a restaurant and these guys just made it all come together so good i had goosebumps! This just Hit me! The most most amazing chicken burger  I've ever had in my life, and that came with the best pancake I've had. What an amazing place!
author: Gints Z.

description:
The Plow is a tiny little brunch place where a wait on a weekend is practically unbearable. I've been there as early as 8am and as late as 12pm. Either way, be prepared for a wait. The only reason why I keep coming back is because parking is plentiful and I spend most of the wait time at Farleys, the coffee shop down the street with tons of magazines to keep you busy. Oh, and the food too. 

You can't go wrong with the plow that everyone has mentioned. It gives you a little taste of everything, the crispy potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, your choice of eggs and some meat. I actually opt for one of the egg benedicts--the salmon or the mushroom and spinach are both amazing. I also really like the breakfast sandwich, which is pretty much just a burger. You can add either bacon or avocado on it, which is a great touch to that fried egg. Everything here is definitely a size large, so no need to fight over those crispy potatoes. Also, if you get a chance to sit at the "bar", it's pretty awesome spectacle watching them cook.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Came here on a rainy day, but still had to wait about 1.5-2 hours. I ordered the prosciutto and gruyere toast which was delicious. My favorite part of the dish were the potatoes - they had nice and crispy potato skins in them. 

What was a little frustrating was that I felt like we were being rushed out. Definitely a place where you catch up with friends during the wait and spend about 20-30 minutes actually sitting in the cafe and enjoying the food.
author: Janice J.

description:
Like most SF brunch places worth a damn, expect a wait. We waited for over an hour, walked around the block, got some coffee in the mean time. But the the Lemon ricotta pancakes themselves are worth the plow. 

Definitely would recommend coming to plow
author: Vince E.

description: I'm giving 5STAR to this place. Food tastes good and never been disappointing.
author: Mega Team R.

description:
Me and my wife visited before Christmas for a little getaway. This was the best food we had!! Better than our $70 breakfast/brunch at The Garden Court. 

Order the Plow, it was perfect! Can't stop thinking of those yum pancakes. We also got the eggs Benedict and the biscuits are awesome! Love it!
author: Adrian V.

description:
Came here with my friend on a weekday(wed) at around 12:45pm? The wait was only about 10-15 minutes, which wasn't too bad. We sat outside and it was looking somewhat gloomy and actually drizzled a bit. Thankfully we didn't have to use umbrellas, but the employee did offer haha. Which I thought was funny. But the menu was simple and to the point. My friend and I both ordered the plow, but she has bacon with hers and I had chicken apple sausages. 

Our food took quite some time to arrive, maybe 10 minutes? Which may not sound too bad, but we were both starving haha. I didn't get that many potatoes.. Probably 2 large pieces and a bunch of little scraps. But, I was able to finish my food because there weren't that many potatoes haha. The sunny side up eggs were perfectly done! The chicken apple sausages were pretty good. And the lemon ricotta pancakes were to die for! Probably my favorite overall on the plate. I love how you have a full plate with a little bit of everything incorporated for once price. It makes it easy to not have to think or debate on different dishes, when this one is simple and both savory and a bit of sweet.
author: Audrey K.

description:
