It's two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes and it comes out all photo shoot ready for your Instagram shot :) I loved everything on my plate and it was one of the best brunches I've ever had but definitely the lemon ricotta pancakes get a shout out. I'll be back for sure!!
author: Jingxi Z.

description: Arivved here from San Jose after reading all the great reviews. However after a two hour wait and trying the food, it is highly overrated. It was good but not amazing or worth the wait. The ricotta pancakes def make them stand out from the others. However we did not appreciate the waitress working outdoors saving tables for her friends and taking them before everyone else, considering the limited amount of seating.
author: Jenya R.

description:
Tip: Come early! The line gets very long!

Service: We did wait about an hour or so and were one of the last to be seated (it stops taking patrons at 2 pm).  The waitress did seem a bit pushy but she took our orders and everything came out as asked.

Food: Incredible!!! I never thought a simple order of pancakes could be so delicious! I ordered the almond flour pancakes.  Huge pancakes that filled me up and satisfied my hunger.  My boyfriend ordered "The Plow" and also enjoyed every bite!
author: Marissa R.

description: Definitely a place to go for breakfast/brunch. If you don't mind the wait it is well worth it for the food. The ambiance is pretty cool and laid back. The service was amazing to top it off. I'd recommend getting the The Plow if you ever don't know what to get, especially since it's their signature dish. Plus the grapefruit mimosa as I constantly saw people ordering them. Overall awesome service, awesome food, awesome place!
author: Quaid M.

description:
Three words: lemon ricotta pancakes!

They're delicious. They're lemony without tasting like dishwash detergent and the ricotta isn't too heavy. They're dense and fluffy at the same time, with a mousse-like consistency. And they're good enough on their own that the side of pure maple syrup, served in the most adorable little dispenser, isn't necessary. I'm not a big fan of pancakes, yet I'd be willing to order a full serving of these amazing lemon ricotta pancakes next time!

I also love Plow's crispy potatoes. Every time I'm given a choice between side salad or side potatoes, I always opt for salad to be "healthier". Plow only offers potatoes. But I'm glad that's my only option or else I'd feel more guilty for not eating my veggies. The potatoes are so crispy! They're packed with flavor and I love the generous amount of dried rosemary used to season these carb-loaded tubers.

I recommend "The Plow" -- two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, two eggs (any style), and a choice of bacon, house pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage. This dish is huge, very satisfying, and has variety. You'll unbuckle your belt and roll down the hill after you've devoured everything and licked the plate clean.

The Eggs Benedict with smoked salmon is also tasty. The muffins are too thick and too large, proportionally, compared to the salmon and eggs. The salmon is salty and flavorful, and it pairs nicely with the beautifully poached, ooey-gooey runny eggs. 

Our host was extremely friendly and our waitress was nice, but service was poorly timed. It took a few minutes before we got our water and for her to take our orders. We arrived at 1PM on a Saturday and were seated outside within 30 minutes (inside would've taken at least another 10 minutes). Plow is on a hill with a slight incline, so it felt a little awkward eating on slanted tables outside. Therefore, I recommend dining inside. And I can't believe I'm saying this, but parking is VERY easy in this neighborhood. I will definitely be back!
author: Priscilla W.

description:
Yea this place lives up to hype. 
Yea the lemon ricotta pancakes are good. 
Yea the wait really is about two hours.
Yea the potatoes are crispy and delicious. 
Yea this place is tiny. 

No, I don't think the lemon ricotta pancakes are worth waiting that long for. 
No, I don't like waiting. 
No, the Nueske bacon isn't all that special (if your meal comes with it, cool. If not? Don't bother ordering it as a side) 
No, they don't give you enough ketchup. 

Eat your food, pay, AND THEN GET UP AND LEAVE YOU DAMN HIPSTERS!!! Other people have to fecking eat too!!!
author: Susy C.

description:
This place is good. I wouldn't say I would ever wait an hour long to dine here again though. 

First off, the hostess... she was slightly snooty. She was not rude, just not very welcoming. Can't put my finger on it. It's like she didn't know how to smile.

Our server on the other hand was very sweet. I ordered the plow. Yes, the house made sausage is pretty tasty. Other than that I can't rave about the lemon pancakes. They weren't as amazing as many reviewers said they are. I think I prefer plain ol buttermilk to be honest. 

It's easy to find. Parking was not too bad on a Friday morning. It's clean but with a tight seating arrangement. 

My other peeve is they only serve drip coffee... no espresso drinks.
author: M E.

description:
The lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing!! I came here randomly after seeing it posted on thrillest as best brunch in the city so I thought I'd try it. I told the waitress that I'd never been before and to bring me something popular that would fill me up for a while. 

I had the pancakes eggs potatoes and fresh sausage. Everything was so fresh and delicious. It was SOOOOOO filling but not heavy which I really enjoyed. 

They had this amazing south American coffee as well. I always like to drink it black so I get the full flavor and let me tell you....this was flavorful!!!
author: Michael P.

description: Came in. Had the plow special heard about this place and been wanting to try it for a long time the wait was about 30 minutes on a Friday afternoon everything was good service was good food was OK not somewhere and rush back to you but maybe if I was in the area I'd stop in again just a normal breakfast spot
author: Johnny C.

description:
I've passed by this place many times and noticed the constant line no matter how early (7am) or late (2pm). We decided to try this out Friday morning and ended up waiting for an hour to be seated. We were seated around 9:30am and they were already out of crab scramble :(

We ordered the fried egg sandwich with avocado and bacon and French toast with a side of almond pancake. All in all the food was fine but nothing to warrant an hour wait. I'd rather wait for Mission Cafe.
author: Tiffany L.

description: This spot satisfies my love for creative and delicious food with inspired spaces.  These two dishes are the Plow and the Omelette.  The Plow, really really good, but the Omelette was just ok.  We were both not hungry anymore because we had to wait an hour and we ended up walking over to Farley's for a coffee and a Carrot Zucchinni Bread.  Even still...we both thought the food was excellent and highly recommend!
author: Soo K.

description:
5 stars for the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes! 

To celebrate my girlfriend's birthday we came here on a Friday for brunch. I was surprised at the amount of people here being that it was a weekday - we waited for about twenty five minutes for a table inside. Well worth the wait!

Lemon Ricotta Pancakes: Oh so soft and perfect... mouthwatering delicious! My new favorite.
Housemade Pork Sausage Patties: had that homemade fresh, feel.
Soft Scramble: Delightful combination of eggs and goat cheese. The crispy potatoes are a must eat!

The hostess and our waitress were both friendly and attentive. The ambiance has a casual, refreshing feel with light wood accents, but the space is very small and cozy. Be prepared to share your table if there are open seats next to you. There are tables outside and some small benches to sit on while you're waiting. If you don't want a long wait, I suggest coming on a weekday. Parking in this area is a breeze.
author: Josh L.

description:
It's been less then 12 hours and I'm already wanting to go back! The breakfast here is on point! Love the fresh ingredients! 
Got here on a Saturday morning at 8:45. Yes, the wait was long..like an hour, but it was so worth it! I got the French toast with strawberries. It was hands down the best French toast I've ever had. The syrup is the bomb! My husband got "the plow" with the special lemon ricotta pancakes. You can really tell the ingredients are fresh!
author: Amanda H.

description:
Plow is quite simply one of the best restaurants I've ever been to.   I'm a breakfast fiend and am constantly searching for those magical spots with high-quality food and good atmosphere.  

Recommended dishes:
Anything with spicy tomato is great
French Toast phenomenal
Dungeness Crab Scramble world class
Potatoes perfect
Service friendly.

Be prepared for a long wait, the restaurant itself is quite small but the wait is worth it.
author: Colin M.

description:
I was a little underwhelmed with brunch at Plow today. I was expecting that with the long lines at 10am that this place must be really good - especially since a lot of people travelled here from outside the neighborhood.

We left our names at the register and went to Farley's to chat away our 1-1.5hr wait. Why they don't take phone numbers to call beats me - too civilized that way? They do let you call to see where things are. So after 45 minutes we call and are told our table will be ready in half an hour. 15 minutes later we're back at the door and wait... wait.... wait... some more. We finally ask and they're like oh yeah, we called your name but we can put you at the top of the list now. I replied that we'd been waiting there for the past 20min at least and didn't hear anything. And we were watching them like a hawk because they weren't shouting people's names, just mumbling them as they walked around the sidewalk (it took most people several takes to understand that it was them being called).  Pro Tip: Try saying people's name louder than a whisper if you want us to actually hear you.

Service inside was good enough. I ordered the fried egg sandwich w/ bacon and my friend got the soft scrambled eggs. We didn't have to wait long for the food to arrive. Mine looks great. Hers looked like they gave her the potato dredges from the bottom of the bowl - lots of onions and burnt potato bits. I was a little surprised they even served it - it was noticeably poorer quality than everyone else's plates around us. Needless to say she wasn't going to take it lying down and asked them to exchange the potatoes

After that was sorted we were ready to dig in - almost. I picked up my eggs sandwich and the yolk just dribbled away onto my plate. Okay, I can just sop it up later. I take a bite of my sandwich and yolk squirts out all over my hand and shirt sleeve. Yikes! I guess I should have expected it in a softly cooked egg but I had mistaken the sandwich for something I could eat by hand - you know, like a sandwich. So I put it down, cleaned myself up, then proceeded to eat it with knife and fork deconstructed style. Didn't really work because it was hard to get bread, frisee, spread, egg, cheese, bacon all in one bite. I ended up eating it one at a time and the bacon whole because I couldn't cut it into pieces with the knife.

Okay, so these are all mishaps that shouldn't be held against the restaurant. However, in the end the food was just okay. Yes, it's better than your typical brunch place but I have high standards. The potatoes were crispy (deep fried instead of roasted) but bland. Definitely needed both salt and hot sauce to make interesting. Definitely looked better than they tasted. The sandwich wasn't that interesting - the extra for the bacon went to 2 skinny strips that I couldn't cut. Could barely taste the cheese. Was mostly a runny egg and nice bread meal.

Overall, not worth the wait. If you live in the neighborhood and can stop by when there's no wait at all I'd bump it up to 3.5-4 stars possibly. My friend enjoyed her scrambled eggs and newly exchanged potatoes with added salt and hot sauce.
author: Jean K.

description:
The Plow is a cute little place with indoor and outdoor seating. The first time I tried to go to the plow, I was told it would be a 1 hour wait on a Sunday morning. However, after waiting 1 hour.. I went to check up on the wait list and was told it would be 1 more hour. At that point we were just too hungry so we decided to leave and try somewhere else. A few weeks later, we decided to go back and give it a try, and waited 1 hour to get in. 

we got "the plow".. and let me just say.. those crispy potatoes doe. i know everyone's raving about those..  they're almost like those typical potato hash pieces brunch places serve.. but fried to a crisp perfection. as a huge fan of fries, im in love with these! the rest of the plate was good with two poached eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes (very unique!), and house- made pork sausage, 

we also got a plate of french toast! the french toast here was unlike any other french toast that i've had before. the outside was what you'd expect- toasted bread. but the inside of the toast was what surprised me. it was super moist and soft.. and it basically melted in your mouth. it was a really interesting juxtaposition of textures. 

overall, food was really good.. but the wait time is a bit too much for me
author: Sandy Y.

description:
Hadn't been to Plow in a few years because the hours long wait is always a little daunting, but today I decided it was time to give it another try.

We waited ~1.5 hours and then were ultimately seated at the bar. A little disappointing to wait so long only to be crammed in at the bar, but it's fun to watch the chefs at work in the kitchen. There was catchy music playing and the folks in the kitchen were scrambling eggs and tossing pancakes to the tunes. They were clearly enjoying their work, which was kind of awesome to see.

I ordered the lemon ricotta pancakes and a biscuit. I had tried the pancakes the last time I was here a few years ago and remember not liking them. However, they're so hyped that I thought for sure it must just have been an off day or something. Unfortunately, I have to say - not sure exactly what it is, but they're just not my thing.

I also got a biscuit - that was pretty good. The soft scrambled eggs were slightly better though I wasn't much a fan of the potatoes they came with - super large potato chunks and not particularly crispy. 

Overall, I left feeling marginally unsatisfied. It might be another 3 years before I give plow another try.
author: Gowri R.

description: I wouldn've given Plow 5 stars if not for the fact that we waited almost an hour for a table for 2... on a weekday! But we had a nice time walking around Potrero Hill while waiting (it was a warm day) and the food was phenomenal. The lemon ricotta pancakes are Plow's star dish, and they were indeed delicious (almost like a very light cheesecake in pancake form). But the breakfast sandwich with avocado was so surprisingly perfect and flavorful and it was the thing I want to eat every day for the rest of my life. Also good: The two slow scrambled eggs and the iced chai latte. Service was friendly and fast once we were seated, and the atmosphere both inside and out (on a nice day, anyway) is lovely. I'd love to come back, but the wait is just too long!
author: Gaelen X.

description:
Visited during Saturday brunch hour. Waited over an hour, and probably would not have gotten a table if hadn't spoken up, as they seated people who came after us before us. 

However, the food was perfectly cooked, the atmosphere and service are friendly, and the coffee while you wait was a caffeinated perk. 

We ordered the Plow breakfast (with lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, potatoes and chicken apple sausage), and the seasonal pumpkin pancakes. The lemon ricotta pancakes were beautifully golden brown. They had a definite hint of lemon, but I thought they were a little bland. Not enough sugar in the batter perhaps. The potatoes were extra crispy on the outside, tender on the inside, and perfectly seasoned (no ketchup required). I highly recommend the potatoes. 

I also recommend the delicious pumpkin pancakes. They were like pumpkin pie in pancake form, topped with delicately flavored pears. 
 
If you can visit during an off time, do. They make a great breakfast, however I don't think it's worth the wait.
author: Keys W.

description: Was looking for a decent breakfast place and Plow had great reviews. We had to wait over 45 minutes so went for coffee up the street for coffee while we waited. The staff were nice, food was pretty good although wasn't amazing for the price. The place is a little out of the way so not highly recommended unless you're close by.
author: Judson M.

description:
I've wanted to try Plow for a while, but was apprehensive about the infamously long 1.5 hour+ wait on weekends. But when a friend visiting from out of town requested Plow, I eagerly hopped on board. 

I went at 11:30 am on a Saturday to place our party of 4 on the list. The hostess said it would be a 1.5 hour wait. We came back in 1.5 hours, and they had already called our party, but gave us the next available table. 

We all ordered the Plow, which came with plenty of food but not overly so that I felt uncomfortably stuffed. The lemon ricotta pancakes that came with the dish- out of this world. I never knew pancakes could taste so lemony and fluffy! 

The potatoes were also delicious. I usually do not eat all my potatoes, because let's be real, they usually suck. But not Plow's! They have perfected their potatoes to crispy bites of enchantments. 

The service was also impeccable. Our waitress was friendly, as was the general manager (I think his name might have been Randall?) of the establishment. SO friendly. I really enjoyed interacting with the manager. 

Overall, a lovely brunch with excellent food. However, I don't think that it is worth the 1.5-2 hour wait. I recommend writing your name down and coming back later on the weekend, or going in on a weekday if somehow possible (I know, most of us have this inconvenient thing called work...). A friend of mine went in on a Thursday morning/early afternoon and he was seated with no wait!
author: Mina K.

description:
The plow breakfast may have very well been the best breakfast I've ever eaten. And I really, really like breakfast. Lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs cooked perfectly, homemade sausage (it shows), and excellent deep fried potatoes with rosemary.

They serve Youk's hot sauce here, which I was unaware of until now, but is apparently my favorite hot sauce. Especially for eggs.

Prepare to wait to be seated. A while. It's small. They'll allow you to put your name in, take a walk and/or grab a coffee nearby and come back though.

And once you sit down, service and the kitchen are super fast.

Seriously, you MUST go here if you're in the Potrero Hill area and don't get put off by the wait. It's WELL worth it!!
author: Shayna B.

description: I had the butcher's steak + eggs and it was good but nothing special, actually the meat and eggs were a little cold. The hostess was super nice, but honestly for me the place is not worth a long wait. I went there during the week for lunch and had to wait 45 minutes.
author: J J.

description:
AMAZING!! This place did not disappoint.  We had The plow breakfast.  The potatoes were perfectly crunchy and super flavorful.  The house sausages not greasy and delicious.  The pancakes were not huge like other places, which for us was a big plus, instead they are small enough that you can actually finish the rest of the food and not feel stuffed.  Prices are on the high end, but for a breakfast like this, don't mind AT ALL! 

This place lives up to the hype!
author: Rosa G.

description:
Everything positive you hear about this place couldn't be more true. We came and was told there was a two hour wait, which we expected based on other reviews, so we dug in and started watching some Beyoncé videos from the concert the night before. We were called 58 minutes later. A lot of people leave so it's easy to get in much sooner than they say. 

Now about the food. I ordered the breakfast sandwich and my friend ordered the pork chop. Both were a breath of life. The pork chops flavor was out of this world and when people rave about the potatoes, they're right. #life The lemon ricotta pancakes were bursting with flavor. (Note: if you don't like lemon, don't get it, obviously). The breakfast sandwich, add bacon, no more words necessary. 

On to the service, its what made this rating 5 stars. My biscuit was delivered to the wrong table and without a second thought our side pancake was free and we got some free banana bread. 

Mexican coke is great, don't forget about that. 

Come here and live. It's worth it.
author: Blake M.

description: Long wait but definitely worth it! The roasted potatoes were the best thing I ate, but the lemon ricotta pancakes were a close second. Generous portion of eggs make The Plow a delicious and filling choice.
author: Ashley R.

description:
Slow service. It was actually pretty busy on a Wednesday morning, so we had a 15 min wait before we were seated, but then there was another 30 min wait for our food. And we ordered right when we sat down. For brunch food, I don't think it should have taken this long.

We got the Plow and corned hash. These were both just okay; when you order a combination dish with pancakes plus other stuff, you expect and usually receive regular sized pancakes. Here, they give you baby ones. If we had known that, we would have just gotten the lemon ricotta pancake dish. I also wasn't really impressed with the sausage, so I'd advise the bacon instead as a side. The corned hash with toast and eggs your way was nothing spectacular. Both dishes required a lot of hot sauce and pepper for my taste.

As not all brunch places in SF are open on a weekday morning, we were happy to stop by Plow. The ambiance is nice, with lots of natural lighting and an open kitchen (there's bar seating too). But still, that wait time and the just okay food.
author: Stella A.

description:
Oh, plow. How I've struggled to get to you before the rush times so I don't have to wait an hour+ 

I've eaten here three times now. I've tried a lot of the things on the menu because I have gone with a group two times out of the three. 

I have gotten the lemon ricotta pancakes some way or another every single time. The first time- it was SO good, super lemony and it had the perfect amount of sweetness. The second time- had a weird taste at the end that I can't put my finger on. The third time- barely any lemon flavor. I have to say it was nice and moist all three times though. Maybe the batch differs by whoever that makes it? But the taste has not been consistent. 
They cook the eggs well- some places are too oily or buttery. The sausage patty tastes homemade but came out burnt last time. 
Okay the plow potatoes- am I missing something??? They're okay- I personally don't think they have much flavor. 
Open faced sandwich- my BF is a fan of. Get it if you are a fan of prosciutto! 
Chia seed pudding is a great healthy option but I wish it was a little bigger.
The fried egg sandwich- meh. You're in SF! Why you get this. Just no. 
The French toast with balsamic strawberries- the bread itself is super thick so it wasn't cooked all the way through last time. 

Grapefruit mimosa is good and it's a good amount but it's a lil pricey. The strawberry lemonade is waaaay too sour. 

The waitresses are nice and attentive- I have no complaints. 

Do yourself a favor and get here before 9 AT LEAST. Parking is actually pretty easy- plenty of spots.

To be honest, it is overhyped but it's definitely worth a try. I think I've had my share of plow for now.
author: Michelle M.

description: Best breakfast I have had in a long time! Really simple breakfast staples like eggs and pancakes, but the done in a very elegant and delicious way. You really can't go wrong with the Plow. It gives you a little bit of everything that this amazing places has to offer
author: Kate S.

description:
Bottom line: tasty food, but not worth the hype. 

Twice, the boyfriend and I have headed to Plow for brunch, and twice we balked at the multi-hour waits and went somewhere else. This time we put our names on the list, held back a wince when we were told a 2 hour wait, and went to a coffee shop to pass the time. We came back two hours later and were seated promptly. 

The staff was nice and the food was good. I had the Plow with chicken Apple sausage, sunny side up eggs, breakfast potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes. The food was pleasant and well flavored and fresh... But nothing to write home about. 

Basically, it was a solid breakfast option but certainly not worth the insane wait time.
author: Lori S.

description:
OK, here's the deal. I love Plow, having eaten there probably 10 times in the last couple of years. There's always a wait, but the food is worth it. 
BUT
Today was the second time that the bus-person ruined my experience. Three of us today & after the main plates were cleared by the wait staff - we were enjoying the last of our coffee and tea post meal - the bus person first removed my friend's coffee cup before he was finished, tried to take mine, but I had to tell him firmly that I was not done, removed our napkins, moved the condiments around while we were trying to converse and basically tried his best to get us to clear out.
My previous experience with this same guy was to have him tell me and my breakfast mate to please finish our coffee so he could clear the table because "people are waiting". Even after we told him we were waiting until the restroom line cleared, he told us to go stand by the restroom. 
Great food, great serving staff, but terrible bus service - to the point where it ruins the meal.
author: Dennis S.

description:
Brunch at Plow is kind of the best.

First, the neighborhood is adorable. Beautiful homes, elderly women gardening outside accompanied by cats as fat as dogs. Love love.

The wait can be long, but you can bribe a friend to go earlier than you to get your names down. If you get seated outside, they have an array of blankets for you to chose from in case the 62 degree weather is chilly for you. I mean, the blanket might have some food caked on it, but it's really the thought that counts.

Get a mimosa and order several plates. Yes, the pancakes are good, and so is the benedict; but what really stole the show was the prosciutto and gruyere toast. You can't go wrong with thick, melty slices of gruyere with poached eggs and prosciutto. Also, the potatoes are  goddamn perfection. 

I love Plow.
author: K M.

description:
I love Plow so much. 

This tiny restaurant is PACKED at any given time of the day. I always like to show up when the doors first open to avoid the 1+ hour wait time. But boy are you in for a treat once you're finally seated. 

I've tried pretty much everything on their menu at this point and NOTHING disappoints. The best thing though hands down are their lemon ricotta pancakes. Each bite is like a little taste of heaven. I order the Plow ( eggs + pancakes + potatoes) each time just to make sure I get a little bit of everything. Their crispy potatoes are also delicious. Customer service is always on point. Feel free to ask for a mimosa or a cup of coffee while you wait. They'll gladly oblige. 

Can't wait to go back once I'm in town!
author: Kayla M.

description:
One of my FAVE places to have brunch in the city. WHY? Their potatoes!!!! And pancakes!!! The potatoes are twice fried so totally crispy crunchy and delicious! Their pancakes are so fluffy and airy. 
The place is worth the wait to try it at least once. I find parking easy here and no time limit since it's the weekend.
Oh, and word of caution. There is self-serve coffee at the host area and they charge you. It's not free!
author: Angela D.

description: The people were super, super nice. The food is rather bland for my husband and I. We like our food with more flavor and the portions are on the smaller side for the amount you pay. Other than that, the place was clean and well kept, if a bit small- quaint is the word that comes to mind when I think back on it. Not the kind of breakfast place for my husband and I but others obviously enjoy it. I like trying different places and know I'm not going to enjoy every place I come across- I was hoping to like this place though.
author: Kristine S.

description: I wanted to visit the Plow very much, because of its popularity and long lines near cafe. I was expecting from this place something really delicious. So we came Wednesday morning and the line was just 20 minutes for us. Staff was very polite and nice - they smiled all the time and did a great job. Place is very clean and neat - that is so important. We ordered The Plow and Soft scrambled eggs, two cups of coffee and one orange juice. Portions are big, you will not be hungry at the end. But the food is just ok... We payed $50 plus $10 tips for our breakfast. For me it doesn't worth that money and lines.
author: Mariia N.

description:
I came here with a friend for my birthday brunch. It was a random Wednesday around noon time. I was expecting there to be a long wait but nope! It was probably a 15-20 minute wait which isn't bad at all! 

After putting our name down, we were able to get a copy of the menu and decide what we were going to eat. Even though, we both already had something in mind from all the pictures on Yelp! 

Once we got called, we asked to sit inside rather than out because it was still a little chilly in SF. We sat at the bar & were amazed since we were able to watch the chefs cook! Everything they were making looked delicious!! I ordered the plow which consisted of lemon ricotta pancakes, house potatoes, chicken sausage (or bacon) and eggs with their iced chai tea! I wasn't a fan of the lemon ricotta pancakes, I thought they were a little too dense. I'm not really a pancake person, so when I do have them I expect a lot. I'm also not a chai tea person, but the chai tea was really good! I ordered it with almond milk instead of regular milk. It had a very strong spicy taste to it. My friend ordered the chia pudding, a side of the Hong Kong style toast, with their strawberry lemonade.* All I remember is seeing her food then seeing nothing but an empty plate & bowl! So I'm pretty sure it was really good!! 

The service was very good! The setting of the restaurant was very warm and cozy. There's an option to sit outside, inside, or along the bar area. The price for each dish is reasonable. When looking at the menu some of the dishes had an * next to them. Looks like some dishes they only serve until they run out, so heads up! 

Definitely coming again to try the fried egg sandwich!!
author: Vangielynne P.

description:
Okay, I understand all that hype about the lemon ricotta pancake but seriously, waiting hours just for that? I certainly have more important things to do in life.

I went in on a Friday morning before I go to work assuming that things will move fast and boy, was I wrong. I sat at the bar, ordered the plow with beacon and found out that they don't have beacon. Uhm..., so you don't have the most consumed product in your menu at 9am? Well, then I went ahead with the chicken sausage per their recommendations and it took exactly 45 minutes for me to get my food. If on a normal Friday morning things are moving that slowly, I can't imagine how it'd be like on a weekend. 

So to sum up, lemon ricotta pancakes were awesome. Scrambled eggs were fluffy and pretty good. Sausage and plow potatoes failed. Wait is frustrating. Prices are right.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
This is the worst restaurant... they discriminate with their seating. We waited 2 hours and were never seated. People who arrived after us were seated. The African American hostess was rude. 
We were told 1 hour wait and after 2 hours left. Our feelings were hurt and we were disappointed, my 3 children had to see discrimination first hand, try and explain that to kids under 10. They had no regard. I was told people came by and placed there names on the list... however a large group of 6 came in 45 min after us "Rose A" and placed their name on the list in front of us and were seated and we were left standing with 3 kids.
author: Harinder S.

description:
Lemon. ricotta. pancakes. Just about every other review will talk about these so needless to say they are awesome! Came here for the first time (of many to follow) this last weekend. I don't think they take reservations so we rolled up and were quoted about 1.5 hours to be seated on a Sunday. We ended up waiting for about 2hr:15 minutes to actually be seated, so expect that or go as early as you can. 

I got The Plow which consisted of the legendary lemon ricotta pancakes, home fries, sunny side eggs and chicken apples sausages. It was a great introduction to this restaurant because you aren't just getting the lemon ricotta panakces, which everyone comes here for. A friend got the same except with bacon. The moment we got our food all the waiting was well worth it. Everything was perfect. Next time I will definitely try to get different things because everything looked amazing. Particularly the french toast and the banana bread. The chicken Tinga also looked great. We ended up being seated at the counter and got to watch all the workers do their thing and jam to the music that was playing (literally everyone was dancing). 

The one thing is that there isn't much to do in the surrounding area while you are waiting. So you have to rough it out and stand in front of the restaurant until that fateful moment when your name is called. Then again, maybe there is and I just don't know the area. Find a way to keep yourself entertained while you wait.
author: Thielson D.

description:
So I finally came here Memorial Day! I thought it wouldn't be busy but when I got here around 8:30am there was already a line outside.

My experience here was wonderful! The food was so good and tasty.  We ordered the Plow Plate and the French Toast both were fantastic.  I would definitely come back here again.  I was telling my daughter she has to try this place she would love it.  Next time I will try the pancakes.

The staff was very nice and friendly always attentive.  The service was just great!  Can't wait to go back.
author: C C.

description: Came on a weekday for lunch with some friends, and when we arrived there was no wait, but we couldn't get seated until our other party arrived. Such a cute little place on the corner! The hostess checked on us to see if our other party had arrived as we waited, which was nice and appreciated. We sat outside on the sidewalk, and our waitress was charming, witty and attentive. We all ordered the plow as suggested by our friend, and it did not disappoint. The lemon ricotta pancakes were my fave! I can see how this place would have a line out the door on the weekends for brunch.
author: Cynthia T.

description: AMAZING! Get the Plow, a little bit of everything. And you MUST MUST MUST get a buttermilk biscuit with honey butter. Everything is great!
author: Tatum C.

description:
Bottom Line:  The food is delicious, the interior is cute and the service is friendly, but I don't think I'd typically wait more than 30 minutes to eat here.

My friend lives two block from Plow so as foodies and elite Yelpers, we had to give it a try.  If you are thinking about venturing to Potrero Hill yourself, here is some information that I hope will help you decide if Plow is worth the trip and the wait:

- The Wait.  My take away from reading many Yelp reviews is that the wait runs one to two hours.  I really can't imagine waiting that long and luckily I didn't have to.  I arrived a few minutes before 8am on a Saturday and only waited about ten minutes for a party of two.  Since the restaurant doesn't open until 8am on Saturday, and we were able to get in on the first seating, we only had to wait long enough for the hostess to get to us.  It helped immensely that there were only two of us.  

- Size Does Matter.  Plow is small and if your party is big, Plow won't be a good fit for you.  My recollection is that there are a handful of four-top tables but not many bigger options.  In fact, there website says they can only accommodate parties of six or less.  If you have a small party and want to sit at the counter, you can probably get seated faster.  And if you are a party of one, don't let the wait deter you, because you can probably snag a seat at the counter rather quickly.  

- Food.  The food here is really good but not so good that I'd wait hours for it.  I do like how fresh their ingredients are and the uniqueness of some of their items.  You can definitely taste the quality of the ingredients they use and I fully appreciate their efforts to source their ingredients locally.  Also, they make many items, like their ricotta and pork sausage in house.   Because I was starving, we (and by "we," I mean "I") ordered lots of food.  

   - Breakfast Dessert!: We were seated at the counter overlooking the freshly baked breakfast desserts so of course I had to order the chocolate chip walnut coffee cake to start.  That probably isn't the right name for it, but just know those breakfast desserts are good!

   - Eggs Benny:  Plow's rendition of the classic Eggs Benedict was wonderful.  I did it with the Fra' Mani ham (Fra' Mani is a fancy pork company out of Berkley that sells its products wholesale and to Costco).

   - The Plow:  Probably the most popular dish on the menu, my friend went with the Plow.  She started it and I finished it!  (Hey, I said I was starving.)  Even though I am not much of a breakfast potato person, I thought Plow's crispy potatoes were delicious and I ate way more of those potatoes than I would anyone else's breakfast potatoes!  I also really enjoyed the sausage.  I am sure it helped that I had been in town for a vegetarian wedding all weekend and was craving meat like a cave man.  The homemade pork sausage had great texture and flavor.  For me, the lemon ricotta pancakes weren't worth the hype.  They were good, and I like the unique combination, but they didn't wow me.  Nevertheless, I think Plow makes their own ricotta which is very cool and admirable.      

- Service.  Service was friendly an attentive.  Despite a line out the door, the staff remains calm and keeps on plowing through the service.  I also like that they kept my coffee full and didn't rush us out of there.  

- The ambiance is very cute and the décor is well done - hardwood floors, marble counter top, big windows and an open kitchen.  

- Extras.  Plow is a very cute, cohesive, well-thought-out place.  They also have a great, classy web site.  I can tell the owners put a lot of love and pride into this business and for that I applaud them!
author: Courtney K.

description:
This restaurant is located in Potrero Hill of San Francisco. 

I and my husband have tried several times to have for brunch on weekends.
There are always a long lines, so that we gave up every time.
We retried at 8:15 in the morning on Thursday.
Fortunately, we can sit down without any line!
  
The atmosphere in the restaurant makes me comfortable and cheer up.
The service is great who everyone is friendly and kind.

We ordered two dishes with two cup of coffee.

(Rating: +++ is perfect)
Lemon Ricotta Pancakes + + +: 
Pancakes were a little crispy outside, fluffy and airy on the inside. I felt a flavor of lemon.
This pancake I ate is the best in I have ever had in my life.

Two eggs +++:
We ate scrambled eggs that it was perfectly my favorite texture. The muffin is crispy outside, chewy on the inside. The crispy potatoes felt a flavor of rosemary.
 Chicken apple sausage of house made is unique taste and made me cheer up.  

How well organized everything!
author: Hiromi S.

description:
Waited for food on a beautiful Saturday morning. Marvelous.

As we put our name down, the incredibly welcoming host mentioned that the wait would take about 1.5 hours. We were fine with that. We decided to take a walk around the neighborhood and enjoyed the bookstore down the block and some cafe's around the corner. We took a stroll back to check our status and we were cheery to be seated.

We had time to look at our menus and I decided on the Plow with pork sausage and poached eggs. My friend ordered the Plow as well with bacon with sunny side up eggs and the last member ordered a ham egg benedict. 
My plate came and I was surprised with the large portion. I first began with the patty pork sausage and I felt that it tasted decent. It was quite solid and wasn't too juicy.  The poached eggs were flavorless and overcooked. There were way too many potatoes for one person to have for breakfast and I noticed that most of my pieces were pretty dry and burnt to the brownest of the brown. The lemon pancakes were a tad sour in my book. I ended up cutting up half of everything and passing it onto the other members of my table. I then drenched my food with the hot sauce that was provided and drowned it with pepper. I also ordered their black coffee that I thought tasted watered down and burnt at the same time. I was bummed.
I had a sample of the ham benedict and I thought it was amazing. The egg had a slight hint of lemon that I enjoyed with this combination. But the english muffin itself wasn't crunchy at all which I thought was a bummer. The friends said the bacon was a Class A bacon which I regret to not have been able to try. 

Don't get me wrong, I really enjoyed my experience at Plow. I enjoyed the busy and bright atmosphere. The waitress was very kind and attentive. The hosts were really friendly and sarcastic. Maybe it was an off day for my pallet? Maybe it was an off day for the cooks? But for my first experience at Plow, I would say it was a memorable one.
author: Linda K.

description: Not worth the 1-1/2 wait....honestly would not come back and spend $57 including tip on a mediocre breakfast....
author: Trinity A.

description:
YUM! I love everything here. The potatoes, the pancakes, the homemade sausage. Wish I still lived in Potrero Hill so I could go more oftern

Keep it up Plow!!
author: Susan G.

description:
Despite the crowd, this place is amazing!!!! We came here on a Sunday morning roughly 25 minutes after their doors opened (8am), and restaurant's first seating was full! (Man, everything good in SF requires a line!) The conservative wait time for us was 45 minutes for a table, which at the time had me concerned since my boyfriend and I had to meet up with a tour at 10am in Union Square. Immediately after the hostess told us about the wait I had asked about outdoor seating. She said that they would be seating people outside shortly, which concluded to me that our 45 minutes would be the extent of our wait if they had about 8 tables out on the sidewalk open.

My boyfriend and I had to strategize. If were were going to be seated before 9am, our order had to be ready buy the time they directed us to a table. So we went through the whole menu.  It was short and sweet which indicated to me that all of these dishes had to be good.  But the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes screamed at me, so I went with that and a side of bacon. My boyfriend, the Egg Sandwich with potatoes.

We were finally seated at 8:55, with our orders submitted by 8:57 (Hell yea I was watching the time!) Refills on our coffee and two waters followed at 9:02 and 9:05 respectively.  Our server also mentioned that seating outside generally starts after indoor tables' food tickets' have passed through the kitchen, which in my opinion was reassuring to hear.

Our orders -  finally delivered by 9:15 with the bill ready in hand without even having to ask!!! 

Their CRISPY POTATOES? Uh-mazing! Their LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES? Best pancakes of my life. BACON? Extra crispy/crunchy just like I like them. The hot sauce? Local, made by Youk's 

What I did notice about Plow that put them at 5 star was that they gave out blankets to the customers who sat outside!! Wasn't too sure if that was upon request or just done out of hospitality, but knowing that they were available just topped my cup off.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Went today, a Tuesday, and there luckily was no line. Service was very pleasant and the food delicious. I had the Plow breakfast: 2 eggs, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, 2 plow homemade sausage patties and the best breakfast potatoes I've had the pleasure of tasting. The lemon ricotta pancakes! I can't wait to have them again. 
Plow has something I'm not sure I can describe. It's a feeling, a good feeling emanating throughout the small dining room and counter space. The staff appears to genuinely enjoy their job and their kindness comes through in how they move, how they talk amongst themselves and how they interact with the patrons. And to the one staff member, owner, chef, manager (I'm not sure) who was smiling the entire time I was dining, thank you, you made my day.
Thanks, Plow!
author: Don A.

description:
this was my second time here and it was just as good as I remembered. The lemon pancakes are to die for. There is always a wait so expect for that. Service is really good but the the  tables are very tiny. 

everyone got an entrée and ice, orange juice and the bill came out to be about 30 bucks per person.

I would highly recommend anybody who has patience to wait to come try this place. You will not be disappointed. Thank you so much.
author: joann U.

description:
One of my favorite breakfast places in SF, Plow serves delicious and reasonably priced traditional American breakfast in Portrero Hill. Bacon, eggs, pancakes, sausage, potatoes, and toast thrive here on a raw yet refined menu featuring all of the classics and then some. 

What makes the Plow different and "better" than other traditional breakfast joints is the high quality of their ingredients. The eggs, produce, dairy, breads, and meats served at Plow are sourced carefully and their superiority to the cheaper ingredients used by other restaurants is apparent both visually and in taste. 

The restaurant is small inside although they do offer additional outdoor seating. The interior decorum is clean and modern with stainless steel bar and stool seating at the kitchen counter as well as table and chair seating in the dining room.

My favorites include "The Plow": two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, their DELICIOUS potatoes, and choice of bacon, chicken apple sausage, or pork sausage. I order "The Plow" when I am very hungry as this is a VERY filling breakfast. When I am a little less hungry I order the "open-faced proscuitto + gruyere sandwich" which is basically a piece of brioche toasted and topped with a garlic fried egg, gruyere cheese, prosciutto, frisee, parsley, and chili flakes. This also comes with a small side of their DELICIOUS (I'll say it again) potatoes. 

By the way, did I mention the breakfast potatoes here are DELICIOUS? You've got to try them.
author: Tomas K.

description:
I'm down... even with a parking ticket due to street cleaning ( it's the city, I know).

Got here around 830am and waited about 30min to get seated. I ordered the Plow with bacon and a side or pork sausage as well as split a biscuit with honey butter.
Yea it was pretty good, the pancakes had body but then slowly fell apart- delicious. The potatoes were seasoned, hot and crisp. The pork sausage patty was had a nice flavor too. In addition, the biscuit with honey butter was addicting, but hey it's butter. And last, their drip coffee was a great compliment to the entire dish.

We were seated on the counter which we liked; we got to see the cooking process which is quite fun to observe. I'll be back and won't hesitate to try a few new things
author: Raymond L.

description:
Favorite breakfast spot that I've found so far in San Francisco. Perfect hipster vibe with the wood tables and white linen napkins. 
My breakfast was delicious (ordered The Plow meal - eggs, bacon and lemon ricotta pancakes - YUM) and the coffee strong!  Service was very friendly and timely. 

I will go back and you should, too. :)
author: Sarah F.

description: Horrible customer service. We went to brunch for our friends birthday. And our serve comes and bring the biscuit with a candle and said idk who's birthday it is but here you go. After we clearly told her who it was. And then came back and asked who's tab the biscuit would be under.
author: Mireya G.

description:
I'd heard many great reviews of Plow before coming and it did live up to the hype, although I wouldn't wait an hour for it. Came here at 11 for brunch on Saturday - my friend had put our name down at 9.45 and was told that it would be an hour's wait. We were finally seated at 11. 

We ordered a buttermilk biscuit, soft scrambled eggs with potatoes and toast, and the lemon ricotta pancakes to share. Everyone seems to rave about The Plow but we decided that it would be too huge a portion to finish (which was a good call since we couldn't finish the potatoes from our order)

The food did take a while to arrive. The buttermilk biscuit came with honey butter. It was decent, though not worth the price ($4.25). The pancakes ($13.75 for 3) came looking nondescript, but they were custardy, not overly sweet, and absolutely delicious warm. Definitely lived up to its name of being Plow's must-order dish! The soft-scrambled eggs ($13) were pretty good, with generous fillings (goat's cheese, asparagus, spinach, mushrooms). That said, it wasn't a particularly memorable dish. I'm not a huge fan of potatoes to begin with, and so wasn't blown away by their famous potatoes.

Service is great, and the servers were attentive and really friendly, which is fantastic, especially having waited for an hour for your table. Our total bill added up to $40 (for the above 3 orders and a coffee) including tax, which is pretty affordable for such a popular place. Love the farm to table vibe of this place, and I'd be back if not for the long wait. Perhaps on a weekday :)
author: Casatrina L.

description:
I like eggs for breakfast and 1.5hour wait is a long time for "just" eggs (I had the scramble with asparagus and mushrooms, no goat cheese for me). It was tasty, the toast came with butter on top which I forgot to order without. The potatoes were crispy but probably not the healthiest option since there was probably a lot of fat involved in frying them. I wish I would have chosen something more special. The eggs Benedict's (salmon) looked delicious and were tasty. They have blood sausage, so maybe I try them next time if I come back.
So if you want to order just eggs, skip the line. If you want to try something special from their menu, it is worth the wait.
author: Michèle S.

description: Get there early! There is line before they open at 8am. Go put your name on the list and grab a coffee up the street at Farley's. I had the biscuits & gravy, eggs over easy with a side of bacon. All on point! My fiance had the steak and eggs, he wasn't a huge fan of the steak, it needed to be cooked longer but it wasn't terrible. Coffee is strong! We sat outside and they brought us blankets which was an excellent touch. Highly recommend this place!
author: Lauren S.

description: We waited almost 2 hours to get a table at Plow, but those lemon ricotta pancakes made it soooo worth it. They had a great lemon flavor and it kind of melts in your mouth. Honestly, I'm sad that I'm not still eating it. Absolutely make that part of your meal. (I ordered the Plow and while the other components of the meal were also delightful the pancakes are the component that are going to make me come back for more!)
author: Emma M.

description: Food was good but still not convinced it was worth the 1.5hr wait. We put our name in and walked across the street to get a cup of coffee and keep warm while we waited. We ordered the plow to share and a side of fresh seasonal fruit. The plow is a nice dish to try if you want to sample a little of everything- I enjoyed the lemon ricotta pancakes, but beyond those the rest of the plate (eggs, potatoes, chicken sausage) was not particularly noteworthy. Fresh fruit was great- mix of peaches, plums, pluots, and fig. Would be worth trying on a weekday when it's (presumably) less crowded.
author: Melissa P.

description:
Great breakfast incredible eggs and bacon the brunch was excellent and overall delicious and it actually cool to sit at the bar and see the cooks/chefs at work making it they do it with such care and expertise it's awesome. Pancakes were excellent. 
Only problem: service was lacking. They seemed the weakest link took forever to get order in and they were more entertained talking in the corner than doing their job, talking about watches. Our waited took forever to get us refills on coffee, bought me toast after I was done with the meal, and the Check took forever to get. 
Would come here again but they need to get their hipster wait staff to get into their job as much as their into looking cool.
author: Juan N.

description:
This is my favorite San Francisco breakfast! I've been here twice, once for a long line for a table of four on the weekend, and once in the morning on the way to drop a friend to the airport before driving back to Los Angeles. While I will gladly admit that it's great to be seated at Plow immediately (and a 7AM breakfast will allow for that), this is a place I'll wait in line for any day!

And for me, the thing to order is The Plow: an assortment of their offerings, including house made pork sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes and plow potatoes. And all of it is fantastic. Rarely do I not try new menu offerings on a return trip to a restaurant, but I can't imagine doing better than this plentiful platter.

I'll be back to San Francisco soon. Rest assured, I'll be returning to Plow.
author: David Z.

description:
I don't know how I more or less randomly picked the most Midwestern brunch spot possible on my vacation from Chicago, but I did. Plow is that spot, and I mean that in the best way possible. It was a little pricy for my tastes (Although I understand that is standard in SF) but the sausage was delightfully un pretentious, I always appreciate a good plate of breakfast potatoes,  and I'm still thinking about the Lemon ricotta pancakes.

The downside? You're gonna have to wait for it. I was alone so my wait was ONLY 20 minutes, but people were being told to expect 1.5 hours! I'm not sure I'd wait that long, but the wait is totally rewarded with a solid plate of breakfast.
author: Nick H.

description:
The plow is a great dish for first timers. It has the famous lemon ricotta pancakes (excellent soft and super tasty), pork sausage (freshly made, not frozen or prepackaged), home fries(freshly cut and tossed, tasty). Blood sausage is good if you like that stuff. 
Big downside is the long wait, be prepared for an hour wait most weekend brunch time.
author: Sridevi K.

description:
I am usually not one for places that are hyped up. They are often ... well ... hyped up? Too many people show up, too much line waiting occurs, and everyone leaves annoyed and low on patience. 

Except Plow. Oh Plow.

I have to say, I don't know what kind of expectations I had. And despite having waited 1.5 hour for a brunch date of 4, in the freezing cold and THEN had to sit outside for the duration of our brunch, I am impressed that I am giving Plow 4 stars.

So then it must be a real testament to their food! I have to say, their food is delicious, simple, and yet so very worth while. I got the salmon benedict with a side of their seasonal pumpkin pancake. Friends got the Plow dish with their lemon ricotta pancakes + apple sausages, and my gf got the french toast. All around everything was deliciously carb-tastic and amazingly fatty goodness. Seriously, every bite was brunch heaven. 

I know this sounds ridiculous, but have someone come here early, put in your name, go sit in Farley's and grab a latte while you wait. It's worth your time!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Sorry, Plow... I like you, but I'm just not blown away.

My friend and I agreed that we wouldn't wait more than 30 minutes to eat here. Luckily, she got there right as they opened so we were seated pretty quickly. I've walked past Plow around prime brunch times (10-2pm), and there's always tons of groups waiting outside.

The service was awesome and very attentive. The food was good and fresh. The restaurant is super cute and makes a perfect brunch spot. So why only 4 stars? I just didn't feel like any of the dishes were really unique or amazing. Don't get me wrong- everything was executed perfectly, and I definitely appreciate that what they do, they do really well. I was just expecting.... more?

As recommended by all the reviewers, I got the Plow. The Plow is a giant dish of potatoes, two eggs, meat, and lemon ricotta pancakes. 
Potatoes- really dang good potatoes, well-seasoned and very tasty
House-made pork sausage- meh, kind of dry and bland
Eggs- it's eggs
Lemon ricotta pancakes- meh, I'm not sure why everyone loves lemon ricotta pancakes. I've had them at some other places, and every time, they don't really do much for me. You can taste the lemon, but the ricotta always seems to dull the pancakes.

My friend had the benedict, which was very tasty, but I've never said no to a benedict. We also shared the chocolate chip walnut cake, which tasted as good as it looked. Overall, I'm glad I tried Plow. I'm just not sure I would want to go at 8am or wait two hours to eat there again.
author: Alice T.

description:
I am always on my quest for the perfect breakfast and Plow did not disappoint.  I ventured there by myself as my husband was working and even opted to use Uber Pool since I wasn't rushing.  Plow is a little out of the way but well worth the trip.  It feels like a neighborhood cafe that I was lucky to find.  

I am trying to eat sugar free and carb free so as much as I wanted to taste the pastries and bread I managed to order a trout salad with a pouched egg.  The breakfast was very tasty even though it was served without the egg and I had to make sure from the menu that the egg was supposed to be on top!  They delivered the egg and I was completely satisfied!!
author: Linda H.

description:
The only reason why I went to Plow is because our friend lives right up the hill. Being the pal he is, he walked down, put our names in, and told us to come back in about two hours. That is friendship right there.

We were seated outside. It was nice of them to have blankets out there, though I personally would never touch them, because I have a problem with germs and stuff. The wait staff is super nice and friendly!

I wanted to come here to try the hash that my coworker told me about. Sadly, they did not have this hash. Fortunately, everything else on the menu sounded amazing. I basically wanted to order everything and eat it all.

The boyfriend and I were strategic about what we ordered. There was a matcha mochi cake, which I obviously had to try because MATCHA MOCHI sounds so fantastic. I got the Plow, because hey, this place is called Plow. Boyfriend got the 2 piece French toast vs. the 3 piece because we saw that there was HK toast. So...yes. All the toasts! They also serve Five Mountains tea, which isn't bad. On the bright side, they serve it in heavy iron tea pots.

The food itself was so very tasty. The French toast with strawberry and lemon curd on it basically made me cry. That's how good it was. I think I like it more than Curbsides, which is blasphemous in itself, but oh my goodness, I haven't had French toast that good in a long while. The Plow was delicious. I asked for my eggs to be hard-scrambled, but it was still on the soft-side - I guess that's what they're known for. I had to explain my messed up allergy but they were really understanding and fixed that for me in a jiff. The bacon was delicious and super crisp. The lemon ricotta pancakes probably would have been delicious if I didn't eat the fabulous French toast first - they were just a shadow of the French toast after the fact. Oh, and eat the potatoes as soon as they come out. That is when they are tastiest.

I'd definitely come back, but I don't know if I'd wait for 2 hours for it.

Also, don't park at the bottom of the hill. That's where all the car thieves are, according to my friend.
author: Robbin A.

description: Really great breakfast place! You can see that most people order "the plow" -- it includes pancakes and eggs. We opted for the breakfast sandwich (amazing) and the soft scramble (so good). The wait wasn't too bad -- about 30 min at 9am on a weekday.
author: Jen G.

description:
Over-rated, self absorbed hipster crap service.
It used to be good when it was fresh, the menu has not really changed, the prices are high, and the service comes with attitude. Oh, and it is cold, inside and out. Personal keeps the doors open, customers, don't give a shit and so you have draft inside and the food outside is always cold. And oh yes, the food you can find in other places with less attitude. Waiting times are a joke.

Funny, when you rank reviews to see the latest, it turns out that they really pile on the negative experiences lately.
author: Michael S.

description:
Put your name on the list and order a few mimosas to sip on while you wait. Typically the list is extremely long making the estimate wait time stretch to over an hour, but if you're lucky + observant, you'll realize about half of that list won't be coming back. 

A table for 2's expected 1 hour and 45 minute wait became just about 50 mins, which wasn't too bad after a stroll and a drink! 

I typically appreciate restaurants where the menu is more refined to a few great items. Plow is just that, but then it also becomes tough because everything just sounds amazing. I ended up getting 'The Plow' and really enjoyed it, a good mix of classic breakfast foods. TIP: If you don't order The Plow, make sure you get a side of their potatoes - it is seriously the best.
author: Kim N.

description:
Being raised the city has really raised my standards for good brunch places. But I really think if you're in the mood for some hearty brunch, Plow is the place to go.

My boyfriend and I arrived on a Friday afternoon at around 12PM. We waited around an hour and 10 minutes to get seated outside. The overall feel of plow is rustic and really clean. I love the wooden tables that had some amazing hot sauce!!!

I opted for "The Plow" which came with two eggs, your choice of meat (I went for the chicken apple sausage, yum!), some AMAZING POTATOES, and two really really yummy lemon ricotta pancakes!!!

I have zero regrets getting the plow because it was just that good!!!

On the other hand, my boyfriend didn't really enjoy the fried egg sandwich as much as he hoped he would. He said it lacked a bit of flavor even adding avocados in it, but the house potatoes were perfection!
author: Kary Y.

description: The food is good, but it's very pretentious. They don't care about customer service at all. They make you wait for hours without telling you how long it will be. They make smaller groups go in front of you if they feel like it. And when you express your disappointment they basically tell you that you can leave if being treated this way doesn't work for you, because there are dozens of people to replace you. That's the problem with being too popular: success gets to your head. Expect to wait at least 1 hour for a table on a week day, and 2 to 3 hours during the weekend. OR you can go to Chez Maman which is a block away and treats you like an actual customer.
author: Doriane M.

description: This was a recommended breakfast place from a SF friend. Delicious!  We had the Plow, 2 Eggs Breakfast, and the Apricot Ricotta cake.  And coffee, or course. Arrived a little after 8:15am. Waited only a few minutes. Service is fast. Worth the wait even if it would have been the predicted 25 minutes. Tables also available on the sidewalk. The host provided lap blankets!  Polite courteous service. Street parking.
author: Lorene P.

description:
Went for breakfast with 2 friends. The wait wasn't too bad.. approx 45 minutes. 

All three of us got the signature dish, The Plow. It came with 2 eggs, super delish potatoes, some meat (bacon, or 2 types of sausage if I recall correctly), and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes. The pancakes and potatoes were superb!! The service was good. Only complaint is that there's only one restroom and it's unisex so there's usually a wait.

Would definitely go again and would recommend to anyone within a 50 mile radius of SF!
author: Toni J.

description:
I don't know that I'd want to fight the crowds that this place must draw on weekends, but at 9am on a Monday I cannot think of a better place for breakfast. I absolutely plowed through my biscuit and gravy, and my over-easy eggs were beyond perfect.

Sitting at the counter allowed me to watch the cooks work their magic. Super smooth. They clearly take pride in their work. Even though the house was packed, every burner used, and the whole griddle utilized, they never missed a beat and even made continual passes at wiping down every work surface. My vantage point also allowed me to see numerous dishes as they made their way to the guests. Every single one looked amazing.

I only happened to be in the neighborhood by circumstance, but now that I know about this gem I'm certain to make Plow a breakfast destination. I cannot wait to come back!
author: Erich N.

description:
2 STARS because I found a really long piece of hair in my food. Delicious am I right? At least if I found a bug, I'd have extra protein. 

On the bright side, the first 2 or 3 bites before I found the hair snugged in my potatoes were pleasant. (I got The Plow btw) And when I told one of the worker (the girl who took the names and sat the customers down), she first asked "Where", then followed by a "Would you like half of it remade?" Why half? Are you going to put the other half of the original plate onto my new plate or something? And WTF, I took 3 BITES, that's definitely not half the plate. That question itself got me speechless. I just stared and said "uhhhhhhh" until she offered to have my server come over. At least she had the sense to offer to have the whole dish remade and comp it entirely. 

I don't think I'll be coming back here, but still props the useful server and a big thumbs down and WTF at that other worker. 

Overall, you might enjoy the food if you don't find a side of hair in your dish.
author: Harriet W.

description: Super good food and very attentive staff. The breakfast sandwich on toast is...A M A Z I N G.
author: Steve P.

description:
This is definitely one of those horrible restaurant like Causwells with beyond terrible customer service. 

The hostess told us to wait outside because it was a bit crowded. So we ended up waiting outside for a good 20 mins. We went back in to check with the hostess and she said she already called our name... 

What the ... What you mean you called our name..  If you called our name I am damn sure we heard it. At this point it is just beyond ridiculous... On top of all this, she tried her hardest to argue with us saying we asked for a table for 2... Unbelievable. 

Had no mood to eat at this restaurant anymore. 

DO NOT COME HERE
author: James N.

description:
Tried Plow today for the first time with fellow Yelper, Kimberly S. We got there around 12:50 pm and luckily didn't have to wait too long for a table. Something weird is that when they call names for people who aren't there they don't just cross it off the list - they keep calling it every time. So, we were advised we'd have to wait 30 minutes or 1.5 hours. Err...okay?

Atmosphere: Standard SF brunch ambience. You know what I'm talking 'bout.

Food: I ordered the soft scrambled eggs (with shiitake mushrooms, goat cheese, spinach, and a side of potatoes/toast) - approximately $15.75. I was quite pleased with my selection! The portions were good size but not overwhelming. Kimberly got the breakfast sandwich and she really liked hers. Huge fan of the potatoes. 

Service: Our waitress was quick and I attribute that to how much they need tables to get a move on :). Still friendly though.

Probably my second favorite brunch place in the city so far and that's saying something.
author: Salma R.

description: Pretty good breakfast food.  Simple and straight.  I got the plow,  which is the pancakes,  chicken Sausage,  and potatoes.  I would say the pricing doesn't necessarily match what you're getting.
author: Arman J.

description: One of the best breakfasts I've ever had. Order the mochi cake- it'll blow your mind. The egg sandwich was great as well as the biscuit with honey butter. Definitely a must try
author: Analeise T.

description:
This has been a place that my girlfriend and I have wanted to try since moving to the city around two years ago.  We finally made it out there just before New Years and decided we should go early to avoid the normal long lines that we've heard about in the past.  When we pulled up, there was no line and we thought, is it even open?? It was and we were seated immediately at the counter which we like so that we can watch the chefs in action.

It's a very nice place with a simple, casual and inviting ambiance while also being quite hip.  The staff was friendly and I particularly enjoyed watching the chefs cook, especially the eggs.  Anybody can cook eggs but cooking them properly is another story and Plow makes exceptional eggs every way.  All of our food was delicious and reasonably priced.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Landon Y.

description: Came here today on a Wednesday and there was no wait. It was still pretty busy and got even more packed 20 mins after ver arrived, closer to 11 am. We sat outside, it was a cool breezy day but they have blankets that you can use to keep warm which I think is a really nice touch. My husband ordered The Plow and I ordered the avocado toast with a side of sausage. My husband devoured his breakfast, and said everything was delicious. The lemon ricotta pancakes are yummy, sweet and fluffy. The avocado toast was lemony, tangy and the bread crispy and flavorful. They have homemade salsa which wasn't spicy but added a burst of flavor. The coffee was good it's Equator coffee. Definitely recommend this place, only downside is that I wish that the avocado toast included 2, other than that great service, great food and nice area. Found parking easily which is a big plus anywhere near the SF area.
author: Esmeralda Q.

description:
I'm conflicted because I love brunching here, but I can't say the extremely long wait is always worth it. 

Last time, me and a friend put our name down at 10:30 and was told it would take an hour to be seated. Over 2 hours later, I inquired about the wait and mentioned the hour difference and the guy without apologizing said "well, it's not exact science." lol, cool.

Other than that, the food is fantastic. I like the Egg's Benedict with Smoked Salmon.
author: Monica H.

description: Possibly the best brunch destination in SF. They really should expand given the exploding demand.
author: Ronn G.

description:
Plow is a great weekday brunch spot, with a clean and cozy atmosphere, and awesome food! As a brunch-loving out-of-towner with only one day in San Francisco, I chose to make Plow my first stop for the day after getting off the Caltrain at 22nd Street. My brother and I arrived at the restaurant around 10:45am on a Thursday morning, and had to wait about 10 minutes for a table. We ended up with a table outside - perfect for enjoying the beautiful weather.

My brother and I both ordered the plow. I ordered mine with scrambled eggs and chicken apple sausage, and he ordered his with sunny side up eggs and pork sausage patties. In addition to eggs and your choice of meat, the plow also comes with two mini lemon ricotta pancakes and a generous helping of potatoes. The eggs and the sausage were good but nothing out of the ordinary. The lemon ricotta pancakes, on the other hand, were ah-MAY-zing. They tasted like lemon meringue, and weren't too doughy or flaky, which is something I often don't like about pancakes. The potatoes were also delicious - salted, with lots of crispy potato skin.

The service was great, and our server came outside to our table often to check on us and the other people sitting outside. If I lived in SF, I'm sure Plow would be one of my regular brunch places!
author: Michelle L.

description: Food and service was excellent!  Well worth the 2-hour wait. We had the French toast, crab scramble, steak and eggs, and side of sausage...oh, and grapefruit mimosa.
author: L B.

description: Good location and good food. But they probably are taking a bit too much for granted for the good business they enjoy. We arrived around 8:30am but not seated until 10:30! The host is uncompromising, refusing to pull tables together to make room for a party of 4 of us. All the two people party coming after us were seated while we had to wait for an hour and half before they finally pulled two tables together, something they would have done more than an hour ago. As the host of the party I did not know what was really going on until after we finish the breakfast when one of my parties talked about it. I alerted to the manager of the situation right away. The manager is quite unruly I have to say.  Her apologies clearly lacked the sincerity but with an attitude of like "well, why didn't you tell me sooner?" She moved on from us quickly without addressing our concerns. We definitely will not come back and will not recommend.
author: Matthew C.

description: Plow is incredibly good for breakfast - by breakfast, I mean late brunch since I'm slow moving in the mornings. If you can, get the avocado poached egg toast and try the lemon ricotta pancakes, but go on a WEEKDAY! On the weekends, you're one brave soul to bare those lines. The wait is genuinely two hours! But it's that good - I'm just not one to wait for eggs, but if you can check out Plow during the week when the crowds aren't around. The space is gorgeous and it's generally sunny in Potrero Hill, so I could totally see myself sitting outside and getting some work done while nommin' on these goodies!
author: Frankie I.

description: Very good breakfast spot.  There was a ~20 minute wait for 1 on a Thursday at 10am, so I can't imagine what weekends are like.  Delicious and big portions, but total cost including tax/tip for an egg dish and tea was a bit pricy at $25.  If the stars aligned and I was in Potrero earlier in the morning and also really hungry, then I'll definitely be back.
author: Janelle F.

description:
Went here on a Friday morning during a day off work hoping it wouldn't be as busy as it usually is. Alas, it was more than an hour wait.

The interior is really nicely designed and clean looking and the food is pretty tasty. I'm personally not a fan of huge quantities of potatoes, because of they way it bricks your stomach, so I ended up ordering a pancake and 2 pork sausage patties. They served real maple syrup, which was nice and the sausage patties were delicious! The pancake wasn't anything special. Ended up paying $12 for those 2 tiny items. 

Overall, I give 3 stars because I don't see where all the hype is coming from? It's a decent place with an extremely long wait. In that time I could have made my own breakfast for half the price.
author: John S.

description: Worth the wait. No bottomless mimosas but I ordered the Plow with bacon, cleaned my plate and 3 mimosas later, est. $50. I'd come back anytime.
author: Hazel H.

description:
I was INCREDIBLY lucky. Came here with my coworker/lova and we only had to endure a measly 15 minute wait. At 12:45 pm to boot! So if you want to test your luck, come here on a weekday afternoon (happened to be a Friday for us) and maybe the pancake gods will take mercy on your pitiful mortal souls!

Everyone is right about the lemon ricotta pancakes. They are amaze balls and quite special. For all you anti-lemon people out there, trust me when I say these fluffy babies will change your mind! If anyone here has ever had three twin's lemon cookie ice cream, it reminds me of that. The lemon flavor isn't citrusy or sour...it's more floral and subtle if anything.

I got them in combination with "the plow" which also comes with SUPER DUPER crispy potatoes, eggs (I'd go sunny side or over easy) and your choice between bacon, pork sausage, and apple chicken sausage. I opted for the chicken sausage and it was delightful! The smoky apple aftertaste was tasty. 

Plow is charming, homey and a little bit rustic. The rave reviews are well deserves, and if fate is kind enough to bring me back one day, I would love to try out the pumpkin pancakes as well! :)
author: Kero D.

description: I thought having Plow for the first time was one of the best breakfasts I've ever had in my life! The wait was about 30-45 mins., but I didn't really mind it. I ordered the custard French toast and I thought it was killer! My dad gave me some lemon ricotta pancakes from his dish, the Plow, and I thought that it was SO good, just like the custard French toast, and my mom gave me her I think it was called Skirred Eggs, and that was bomb! I thought that it was the best brunch place I have ever had!
author: Pil C.

description: First in line on a Saturday - we got it down to a science! We decided to both try something different than last. I got the prosciutto Gruyere toast w/ potatoes, and he got poached eggs and Hong Kong toast. We split the coconut mochi cake (must have, runs out fast). Coffee with free refills. The service is always great -- they are friendly and don't make you feel like you're getting pushed out to get the next people in (they over tables fast though so if you get in line around 8 you'll probably make it to the second round of service, approx 30-40 min wait). It's a small space-- drawback is tables are sooo close together that I can't help but look at what my neighbor got, and vice versa. There's some seating outside and they provide blankets, which I thought was a unique and nice touch.
author: Anita H.

description:
The gluten-free pancakes are seriously mind blowing. The service is friendly and efficient. I love Plow so much I make sure to take a trip here every time I'm in SF. I even randomly nag my friends visiting SF to go to Plow. If I can't make it to Plow when I'm in SF, I feel extremely disheartened. 

Unfortunately, if you want to come on the weekends, expect at least a 1-2 hour wait. It's much better to skip work / school and come in the middle of a weekday instead :O)

Also, the generous natural light is absolutely perfect for Instagram purposes. So there's that.
author: Kathy O.

description: Great experience! Awesome food and great cooks sat kitchen front at the bar and it was awesome ! Cooks are incredibly fast and everything was impressively clean ! Our waitress was pleasant and even though we waited an our to be seated it was worth the wait.  we love ordering the plow so delicious !
author: Gabi M.

description:
Really feeds to your need of gourmet breakfast food. The flavor is all there, the ambience is sweet and the grapefruit mimosa does not hurt one bit.

Just a tip... come an hour and a half before just to leave your name. (Walk to Phil's down the street in the meantime and have a nice conversation while you wait).
author: Ann Marie L.
