description: the lady told me just one hour and we waited for more than 2hours.   it's getting sad to wait that long but I don't wanna miss it since I already waited for one and half hours.   The chia seed pudding is really good but the others just fine and I feel I can have something better than here.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
After my gf suggested this place, we decided to pay a visit this morning. You would think that there would be less people during a weekday, but I was surely wrong. I've been to many brunch spots in SF (my reviews don't show it, I KNOW) and after my meal today, I can honestly say that Plow is my favorite. I don't remember the last time I arrived at a restaurant with a menu so appetizing that I didn't know what I wanted to eat even after waiting nearly an hour and a half. Eventually, I decided to order the most enticing entree I saw photos of on here. Since pictures don't do justice, two orders of The Plow were on their way to our table. The portion and size of the order were perfect, consisting of mouth-watering homemade pork sausage, mini house-made ricotta cheese lemon pancakes, and the most damn delicate deliciously made potatoes that were crispier with every bite. Oh, and let's not forget my perfect over easy eggs that spilled yolk everywhere after I sliced and diced them over the pork sausages. There's so much more to try, but we'll be back next time. Nonetheless, I highly recommend anyone pay a visit! 

P.S. No need to worry If you get seated outside on a chilly morning, they provide blankets to comfort you during your meal!
author: Tim P.

description:
Best biscuit I've had in SF so far, maybe on the west coast all together (and I have high biscuit standards being from Georgia). It was buttery, and soft and moist, and with a proper crunchy top. The honey butter that came with it was good, but I might ask for plain butter later as I was wanting something more savory than sweet. 

The potatoes are super good too. Very crispy. 

The famed lemon ricotta pancakes were good, but can't say I was blown away. And the eggs were good, but pretty standard. Overall a very satisfying brunch experience. 

The staff was very friendly. Also, if you sit outside on a dreary day like today was, they'll give you a blanket which is very cute and sweet and thoughtful. 

A practical tidbit of learned wisdom: we tried getting there pretty early and got there at 8:30. And the line when we were leaving around 9:45 was about the same as when we got there. So unless you get there at 7:30 (before they open), it's not worth rushing.
author: Rita K.

description:
Today a Christmas miracle happened; my friend and I got in the door and had a table within 5 minutes! 5 MINUTES! That never happens in San Francisco, especially at a place as good as Plow. The party of two that was before us on the list did not show up, so they sat us first (which was fantastic). I know that it was a weekday morning and Christmas eve, but still, that's pretty amazing.

The first thing I noticed about this place was that the tables were pretty close together. We could hear the conversation of the table next to us and if we stretched our arms out, we would have definitely hit them. I did not mind this all too much, since the people sitting next to us were super friendly. 

Now, the food/drink. I got the coffee while my friend got the 12-hour cold brewed iced coffee. He says that if you really need to wake up, the iced coffee is the way to go. We both ordered the plow. He got the chicken and apple sausage while I got the house made pork sausage. We also ordered a side of bacon. Everything was great! The potatoes were nice and crispy and the scrambled eggs I had were not dry. The lemon ricotta pancakes were AMAZING. It was like biting into a fluffy lemon cookie. The serving size was great for what we ordered because we got to try a little bit of everything.

I will definitely be coming back. The service was great. I will definitely appreciate the Christmas miracle of having brunch within 5 minutes of putting my name on the list since this will probably never happen again.
author: Breniel L.

description:
This is my all time favorite brunch place. Hands down. I try to make a trip up for brunch every couple months or so. The lines here get super long especially on weekends, but trust me, it's worth the long agonizing wait. If it is your first time here, I would order the plow (5/5). It is just their breakfast platter with a little bit of everything. On my numerous trips back to this place, I also tried the fried egg sandwich (4/5) and their crab scramble (3/5). 

The plow is basically the most amazing breakfast platter you will ever eat. It comes with a heaping pile of potatoes (5/5). The potatoes aren't your average hash brown or the soggy potatoes that come with a diner breakfast. These potatoes are super crispy and brown on the outside, soft on the inside, and seasoned to perfection. You can hear the crunch as you bite down. You also have the option of bacon (4/5) or sausage (5/5). You really can't go wrong with either option. Their chicken apple sausage is the perfect amount of sweetness and savory. The bacon is fatty and rich. My only qualm is that the bacon is a little limp If you're really feeling hungry, get both! Why not! Also, with the plate comes the standard 2 eggs any way you like, I personally prefer them poached soft so you can dip the crispy potatoes and meat in the runny yolk. Finally, to top it all off, are 2 lemon ricotta pancakes (6/5). These pancakes are not your average fluffy pancake. They are slightly denser, but packed full of flavor. I'll be honest, I'm not a pancake person normally. Waffles win it all for me, but when it comes to these lemon ricotta pancakes, I would eat a hundred if I could. 

As for the egg sandwich, they fry the egg to perfection. Yolk is perfectly runny, acting as a great sauce for the sandwich. The only reason this got a 4/5 in my book was due to the fact it really needed the addition of some meat. If you do get this sandwich, spend the extra couple bucks to add in some of that delicious bacon they have. Trust me, it'll take the sandwich to the next level. 

The crab scramble had way too many green onions for my liking (I personally hate them and will pick them out given the chance, but this had way too many to do so). It covered up the taste of the crab a bit. There were large hunks of crab throughout the omelet which is great, but there were quite a few pieces of shells too, which made it a bit annoying to eat.

Amazing food, great service - nothing more you could ask for.

Cons: 
- long wait on weekends and in the mornings 
- restaurant is small, so if you sit on the patio, it does get very cold

Pros: 
- brunch food here is A+ - everything is cooked to perfection
- service is fast and friendly
author: Diana C.

description:
I went in on a Saturday morning for breakfast. Very crowded with about an hour wait. Worth it. I had the soft scrambled and they were very good. I switched out my potatoes for salad and it wasn't a problem. 

The place was over crowded but it didn't seem to matter to much to our small group.
author: Brian G.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday and the wait wasn't bad. We waited about 20mins before they seat us down. The only thing that bother me was that they wouldn't sit me until the two of us were there. The food was good. I was excepting more since there is always a crazy long line. 

I got the strawberry French toast which was good. The strawberries were fresh and the fresh toast was soft, a little sweet and fluffy so I didn't need much syrup. 

The fried egg sandwich was okay. Nothing extravagant, and way over price. However I did like the potatoes, they were crispy and flavorful. 

I don't think this place is worth a two hour wait, or $18 for a fried egg sandwich.
I don't think I'll be coming back.
author: Chiara M.

description:
Everything here is so good. Egg sandwich is simple but it makes you wonder why so few restaurants get it right. Potatoes are addictive. 

I went back and had the Chinese breakfast which was super tasty. Nothing like starting your day with braised pork on rice, bok choy and a sunny side up egg. I could eat this all day.

It does get crowded but if your among the first 30 before they open, you'll get seated. The food is great and the staff is super friendly. Don't forget to grab the almond cake to go.
author: J L.

description:
We came here for breakfast and although it was hard to order anything but "the plow" (basic breakfast with their signature ricotta & lemon pancakes), we also opted for the little gem salad to counter balance the bacon. First, their potatoes are fantastic. I don't understand why so many breakfast places can't seem to get the potatoes right when it's such an important staple?! But The Plow does them A+. They were my favorite part. The ricotta & lemon pancakes were fluffy and melted in my mouth, topped with a little Vermont maple syrup. The eggs which I took scrambled, were perfectly cooked. The pork sausage was ok, I'll opt for the bacon next time. The salad lost me a bit. I know, I know... Who orders salad at a breakfast spot... Still. It's a salad. And salads are in. It was bland, with boiled beets and raw carrots atop lettuce.

Otherwise, service was fantastic, coffee was tasty and plentiful, OJ was freshly squeezed, decor was cute, atmosphere was comfortable and they offer a front patio for those wanting to brunch in the sunshine.
author: Isabelle R.

description: Located in a nice neighborhood. Pretty small interior but a great ambiance. Courteous staff. We ordered the biscuit with honey butter and chia pudding. Both were delicious!!.Be prepared for the at least an hour wait time though!. Over all great experience! will be back again.
author: Raja K.

description: Oh.Em.Gee! I got the prosciutto and gruyere toast and I honestly believe this might have been one of the best meals I've had in SF. The wait was a little long, but definitely worth it!
author: Melissa B.

description: A great breakfast / brunch spot when you are in the area. The place is small so be prepared for a wait or come when they open. They have some tables outside as well.  Their crispy, crunchy, oh so yummy potatoes is a MUST order. If your getting something that doesn't come with it, order it as a side. Trust me! You can thank me later. They get most or all their ingredients from local farmers. Coffee is always good when it comes from Equator. I've had their fried egg sandwich, avocado toast, lemon ricotta pancakes, french toast, and the plow. Everything so far has been great! Parking in the area is a bit of a challenge especially if you come on a busy time. Prepare to walk.
author: Ardielyn F.

description:
5 stars for seating my party within 5 minutes of our arrival (with no reservation) for brunch on Memorial Day. 

Also one of the best brunches I've had - everything is organic! + excellent service
author: Jessica C.

description:
What I ate: Monkey bread, fried egg sandwich
Visit date: January 27, 2013
First time? Yes.

A one hour wait with good company isn't so bad, especially on a sunny day. And then we were rewarded with monkey bread! The monkey bread is a definite must eat (note: limited supply!). It's like a cinnamon bun, but on crack. Warm, just enough gooey, and a touch of sweet. For our main dish, my friend and I split the fried egg sandwich (two fried eggs, cheddar, aioli), crispy potatoes, and a side of Nueske bacon (salty, salty bacon). Ok, so I could have made this at home without the one hour wait, but it wouldn't have come with an awesome egg show. Try to get seated at the bar and you'll see what I mean. The egg guy was on fire -- no timer, just instinct. Soft poached, scrambled, sunny side -- you name it, and he was on it! He was too cool. Also fun, the host/ess will take your coat and hang it up for you; made me feel like I was visiting someone's home.
author: Erin G.

description:
3.5 stars. 
Pretty good breakfast place! 

Tips: 

-Menu changes daily, so what you want might not be there. Benedict and strawberry French toast wasn't available on the day I went. 

-Be prepared to wait. We had a 45 minute wait for just two people. 

-you might possibly have to share a table with another party. This place is pretty small, and they've tried to seat more people than they should. 

Food: I tried The Plow, which comes with two eggs, mini lemon ricotta pancakes, house made potatoes, and your choose of sausage, sausage patties, or bacon. 
The eggs and the house made potatoes, which were in bite sized pieces, we're perfectly cooked! The potatoes were nice and crispy.  Don't bother with their bacon here. Unless you like the thin, cheap cuts of bacon that's burnt. The lemon ricotta pancakes were the clear stars! Tasted out of this world!  


The reason I knocked this place down a star is because their waitresses were very pushy and seemed to be rushing us. Also didn't like the fact that the place was really crowded! Like elbow to elbow with the party next to us.
author: Kay A.

description:
3 stars for my main dish. The lemon ricotta pancakes had a nice, light lemon flavor, but the texture was rather eggy. Halfway into my first pancake, I felt that it was a little too heavy for my taste. I guess I prefer it the old fashion way where it's fluffy, airy and light.

The crispy potatoes must be the best potatoes I've had for brunch.

The green tea is brewed with tea leaves and comes in a teapot- good!

It was about a 20 minute wait on a Wednesday morning.

It was a bright, clean, boisterous place; I had a good time catching up with an old friend.

I was surprised that parking was so easy to come by!
author: Tes Y.

description:
The food here is delicious. And the person who seated us and the waitress were great too. But our entire experience was ruined by the front of the house woman, who I believe was the owner, who came to our table after we were seated to loudly berate my daughter, claiming she had cut in front of other customers. When I went inside to speak with her about it, her response was initially that she had done nothing, and it was her word against my daughter's. What?  While I was having this conversation, another employee went to our table and apologized to my daughter for how she had been treated.  Apparently we had been mistakenly seated before others.
This is not the only place in San Francisco where you can get perfectly cooked eggs. But it's the only place where I've been subject to public excoriation for the restaurant's mistake.  I suggest you try another brunch spot.
author: Dorothy G.

description:
I'd like to be different, but like everyone else, I agree, the lemon ricotta pancakes were simply delicious.  It was so good, I looked up the recipe online and made them myself!  This place is solid, but the wait is kinda ridiculous especially on a weekend.  I'm not a fan of that, but I guess I can't hate on them for having business.  

The pumpkin spiced muffin was perfectly warm when our server brought it out.  The plate is a generous portion, so I got 2 meals out of my brunch plate.  Oh yah, the potatoes were perfectly seasoned too.  Watched them toss is while we sat at the counter.  

No sure why other people are bitching and complaining and I don't care, I like this place and I'll be back!
author: Meshell C.

description: So good!! Try to get there early and expect to wait. But just know that the wait will be worth it! Excellent customer service and even better food.
author: Jackie S.

description:
My husband loves this place. He always gets the lemon ricotta pancakes.

I love the chia pudding and the Hong Kong toast.

The service is a little slow on the weekends but they get pretty busy so it is understandable.
author: Mina F.

description: Oh, Plow, how delicious you are. Sure, the wait is brutal, and you're probably going to be sitting in the cold outside (heaters, please, in the future?) after standing around getting cold for an hour or so, but the food is great. Plow potatoes - crispy, airy, and hot. Lemon ricotta pancakes - fluffy and zesty. Smoked salmon toast - great bread, but the fish could definitely use some seasoning/spices. Stack some crispy bacon and over easy eggs on that, and you've got a winner. Overall great service and really good food. Plates are about $12-15, so it's not cheap, but you're getting quality stuff here. Getting their housemade patty next time for sure.
author: Danny C.

description:
Trust me, you will wait and you may wait for a while (we waited 30-45 minutes) and the waiting is outside, but IT IS SO WORTH IT! This brunch place is on a quiet little corner in dogpatch. The seating is very limited and just a tad cramped, but the natural light, and amazing food more than makes up for it. 

There is plenty of variation, but as a brunch lover I went for a classic Eggs Benedict. The hollandaise sauce was superb, the eggs were perfect, and there was so much food that I felt satisfied and justified for the weight and higher price range. 

My husband ordered the "Plow" plate that consisted of some meats, and other breakfast foods that honestly I can't remember now. Their potato pancake was chewy and flavorful. The hashed potatoes are great as well. They have great choices of beverages which are unique and flavorful. 

The ingredients are organic and hand picked from the farmer's market every morning. The restaurant doesn't take reservations and is only open until 2 so be careful!

Happy Munching!
author: Alisa K.

description: Omg! I ordered the eggs in a tomato sauce and they were awesome, i also ordered the smoked trout salad. The place is constantly changing their menu so go often. Their breakfast potatoes are out of this world.
author: Kaylee B.

description: One thing about this place is that, the seating is super crowded. Be prepared to be sitting literally and inch close away from the table next to you. When i arrived, just to put my name down it was approximately an hour wait. My boyfriend and I decided to just go ahead and wait since we were already there. As time went on, it went down from an hour wait to 45 minutes. Once seated, my boyfriend and I knew already what to get, due to past Yelp reviews from other people. We went ahead and ordered the plow. It was super amazing! The food is delicious, completely worth the 45 min to an hour wait. With the plow, I ordered with the patty as my boyfriend ordered it with bacon. I like how the pancakes has a lemon twist to it. Overall, place and food is amazing.
author: Raena R.

description:
Showed up just before 9 am on a Saturday morning and was shocked to hear that the wait would be an hour. I figured Sunday, yeah. Or 10 or 11 am, yeah. But 9? But we were in for the food and waited patiently. 

It was probably about 45-50 minutes before we got seated, and there was some sort of snafu where they seated some other person with the same name ahead of us. It's good I went to check our place on the list because my name (with last initial!) was crossed off. 

On to the food:
Buttermilk biscuit - we shared this, and it was great by itself and even better with the accompanying honey butter.
The "plow" breakfast - This allowed me to try everything everyone had told me about: the crispy potatoes (good, but not mind-blowing) and the lemon ricotta pancakes (great!). Meanwhile, the housemade pork sausage patty was flavorful and the eggs were, well, eggs.

While I'm not sure I'd go back and wait an hour to do this again, the food was definitely very good overall and I loved the atmosphere of the place. Friendly service, nice ambiance...a good place.
author: David B.

description:
Tried this place out again on a weekday lunch because my girlfriends wanted to go against my wise advice ;)

I don't know happened this time or last time but the lemon ricotta pancakes were ON POINT!

I'd go again but NEVER on a weekend, unless I was being held hostage against my will.

FYI line at around 11:30 on a Tuesday was about 25 minutes
author: Eileen W.

description:
I must say, Plow did not disappoint.

I came here on a Saturday morning 5 minutes after they opened at 8am and I still had to wait 30 minutes for a table. That alone was impressive. To have people line up at opening to have breakfast at a restaurant, it must be good.

I ended up ordering the Plow because it came with everything I wanted: lemon-ricotta pancakes, Plow potatoes, and the house-made pork sausage patties. Holy smokes. They sure did take some normal brunch items and did them up well. The lemon-ricotta pancakes, just perfectly executed. Delicious balance between the lemon and ricotta with just the right fluff, moisture, and size. The crispy potatoes, again just perfectly executed. The house-made pork sausage patties, now that is how every breakfast sausage should taste. I usually don't care for breakfast sausage but this was my absolute favorite part of the dish. Honestly, I took the last patty home because I was not ready to part with it and I just munched on it the rest of the day Okay, reading that out loud makes me seem a little crazy. Oh well, NO SHAME.

If it's your first time, be sure to get the Plow. You will be "plown" away.
author: Brent C.

description:
I love Plow, but I hate the crazy waits. Food is seriously good though. 

Breakfast sandwich- Amazing. I love it so much. It is seriously perfect. 

Shirred Eggs- These are good. I had to try them because I'm a sucker for eggs poached in a tomato sauce, but haven't gotten them since. Prefer the breakfast sandwich.

The Plow- This is a good plate to try a bit of it all. Their house made sausage, is killer. I liked the lemon ricotta pancakes, but not as much as everyone else does. 

This place is great. Try going during the week, but menu is a bit different on weekend.
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
Got here around 9:40 on a Thursday. Wait was about 30 min but according to these other reviews that's relatively fast for this place. The space is small and cozy.

Service: on the slower side but understandable considering how busy this place is 

Food: I got "the plow" with lemon ricotta (good), plow potatoes (amazing) eggs and bacon (normal) $17

My gf had the $14 breakfast sandwich (great amount of cheese on fresh bread) and we had a side order of Hong Kong toast $4 (meh, alright) 

Reason why a 4 and not a 5 was portion size, can't really knock the prices cause that's normal these days. But my gf noticed how quickly I plowed through the plow (see what I did there?) and luckily she's a small eater so I got about 1/4 of her sandwich which left me satisfied. And the Hong Kong toast, $4 for one slice of bread with condensed milk on top? For that much you could go get a full loaf and do it yourself at home. But overall, great brunch place, fresh ingredients and above average for a "light" breakfast (by my portion standards)
author: Virgil C.

description: Best brunch spot in San Francisco. Its usually an hour and a half to two hour wait for 2 people or more. You can get seated much faster at the counter if your by yourself. Single counter seating is more in the 15-25 minute waiting range.
author: Vivek G.

description:
I am not easily impressed by overpriced brunch spots, but today I was an exception. It's funny that everyone emphasizes organic and locally-sourced ingredients these days. Eating organic isn't enough anymore, but you now must do society and your community a service by supporting local farms, etc. I hate it for the most part only because it usually means pricier bills for mediocre food. Plow keeps their menu simple, but they do it well.

I got the fried egg sandwich, constructed with two eggs, aioli, frisee, cheddar on an Acme bun. Pay the extra couple bucks for the Nueske bacon; you will not regret it. The sandwich was the perfect answer for breakfast. The bun was soft and airy, and the combination of melted cheese, fried eggs, and crispy bacon was heavenly. The crispy potatoes on the side were amazing. The best thing on the menu is the lemon ricotta pancakes. The texture was softer and crumblier than a normal pancake and the flavor was outstanding. It was probably one of the best pancakes I've ever had. 

Overall, I loved the breakfast here. The prices weren't cheap ($13 for the breakfast sandwich and $15 for the plow). I wouldn't normally pay this much for breakfast, but if it's done right, it's hard to pass up.
author: Bailey Z.

description: This place is always full with a waiting line but, that is not bad at all unless you are in a rush. Food is delicious. Every single plate I had try have been really good. Specially their gluten free pancakes with lemon syrup. They serve brunch until 2:00pm. If you go put your name in the list and most likely you will wait from 45 minutes to an hour. Just go and walk around the block, take some pictures while you wait. Come back later and enjoy breakfast at Plows. It is worth the wait.
author: Jorge N.

description:
TL;DR Wait over an hour in the cold for average diner food that is $30+ per person.  Save your time and money.

Maybe it's the ever-present 1+ hour wait that raised my expectations, but I have no idea why there is always a line at this place.  People must just like the scene.  Given that there is always a wait (even on a weekday), they should come up with a better scheduling system.

The good:
4/5 stars for service.  The staff were mostly friendly and attentive.  The atmosphere inside is cozy.

The bad:
1/5 stars for the long wait.  You have to put your name on the list and you wait on some tiny benches outside in the cold.  (They recently added a single heat lamp outside for people to gather around).  I wouldn't mind waiting if the food was really good, but...

1/5 stars for the food (at the price)
I know this is SF and everything is expensive, but I'd rather pay an additional 20-30% if it meant having better ingredients.  We ordered "the plow", OJ, coffee, tea and a fruit plate.
- $4 for a tiny glass of OJ that's not fresh squeezed - don't bother ordering
- $5 tea in tea bag that's so old there's very little flavor
- $4 for coffee that was burned - at least they give you free refills
- $7.5 for fruit plate served with pieces of brown fruit
- bacon was not high quality.  It was burned yet somehow still fatty.
- chicken sausage was average and burned
- lemon ricotta pancakes were ok, but not above average
- the potatoes are better than at an average diner but nothing special
- the eggs were ok

Overall, 2 stars.  

To be fair, I guess the bar is pretty low when it comes to breakfast and brunch in SF.  I can't think of many spots that I would consider good for the price.  (Olea used to be good, but their ingredients took a step down).  Overall, Plow will leave you feeling like you ate at a greasy diner, but somehow overpaid by 2x.

Example good brunch spots: La Note in Berkeley, Square One in L.A.
author: Greg T.

description: Plow is worth the hype and the wait! I don't say that often... order the plow and you won't be disappointed. All their pancakes are delicious.
author: Marie-Therese J.

description: I got the plow for my breakfast which came with bacon, potatoes, pancakes and eggs. I also ordered chicken apple sausage on the side because I was starving. When my food came out, I was a little disappointed because they burnt the sausages and pancakes which isn't something that I enjoy. Maybe I should've warned them to watch out. Anyway, other than that food was pretty good. Service is pretty good. My friend and I were sitting outside the restaurant and it was extremely cold. They handed me blankets to cover myself which was super considerate of them.
author: Kilim C.

description:
After a couple of days in San Francisco and the regular union square spots, we somehow encountered this location. I read online that the wait time was a long time...as we pulled up, I realized this wasn't a joke. Truth was, I NEEDED to try the lemon ricotta pancakes everyone was talking about! 

Let me just say that the wait was COMPLETELY worth it. We were advised the wait would be around 45-1hr for a table for 2. Thing was that people are impatient and about 3 couples ahead of us choose to leave rather than wait, so our actual wait time was only 25 minutes!!! I think we got lucky, a local way saying it is always crazy, so if you plan on coming out, expect the delay. 

Now on to the food...we ordered the plow with the lemon ricotta pancakes and another with caramelized apple french toast. TOTALLY worth however long we waited or were going to wait!! The food tasted fresh! From the sausage patties to the bacon, you can definitely taste the natural.

Every single person that makes the staff up is super nice! Which also made the experience a wonderful one! This place is awesome! Next time I'm in town I'm coming back! That is for sure!
author: Mariana C.

description:
I was given strict instructions when I went to Plow. They were short and simple, but were sure to provide me an experience that could not be flawed.

1. Don't look at the menu
2. Order "The Plow"

Easy enough right? Right! I did as I was told and had an exceptional breakfast, which admittedly was a little out of my wheelhouse, (not a huge breakfast fan), and resulted in the plate basically being licked clean. 

The Plow is brunchy bliss comprised of two eggs, your choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes. I went for the house made pork sausage but was able to steal a chicken sausage link off my buddy's plate - both were awesome! Nine times out of ten I'll order anything but pancakes but seeing as these were part of the "package deal" I approached with not only an open mind, but also an open mouth. I was told that the lemon ricotta pancakes "are a make or break item" leaving you loving or conflicted on the breakfast. Truth be told, they were a big win in my book but the true star of the show were the crispy potatoes. Kissed with a hint of rosemary and crisped to the point that they're crunchy, but not overcooked or burnt. Be sure to ask for a bottle of hot sauce if you want to take them to another level and wash it all down with a cold glass of orange juice. 

Thanks Plow!
author: Brad B.

description:
In short, this is the best breakfast spot. I have been here twice and have been blown away each time. Everything I have ate has been super tasty and flavorful. 

First time I had the breakfast sandwich which came with their potatoes. I usually hate potatoes with breakfast but these were amazing. They were fried perfectly and the seasoning they use gives them a good flavor. 

Second time I had to bring a friend. We shared the "Plow" dish and the salmon plate. More than enough food for the both of us and I got to try their famous pancakes. SO GOOD! To top off the meal we had pomegranate mimosas to was it all down. Can't wait to go back!
author: Alfredo R.

description: The food is great here, love the potatoes, but very overpriced.  $7.50 for a side of fruit, $4.75 for tea.  Also the policy of having folks wait outside is taken to the extreme.  There are extra spots at the bar and I need to wait outside when it's quite cold outside.
author: E. W.

description:
Came here for breakfast and ordered the plow. My plate looks good by looking at it but when I started to dig in....it was just average to me. Lemon ricotta pancakes were ok, the crispy potatoes are not so crispy, Sunnyside up was a tiny bit raw and with the apple sausages was good.

For a weekday around 930ish am was busy and i waited about 20 mins to be seated. Yes, this place is too hipster for me and the prices on the menu are pricey. Got fooled by the yelp reviewers and I do not plan on coming back here.
author: Cee M.

description:
Dear Plow,
Get over yourself. You're wait is not worth it. An hour and 1/2 to 2 hours---your eggs are not worth that much of my time. Figure out how to take reservations or at least text customers when their table is ready so people can go for a walk to enjoy the view.  I really do want to love you but, come on. Make some adjustments.
Sincerely,
Mel N.
author: Mel N.

description:
This place was really good. I came in on a weekday morning and there was still a line, albeit not very long, but it was surprised to see this place packed.

The Plow - two lemon ricotta pancakes, two housemade sausages, two eggs and the crispy potatoes. The pancakes were really amazing. The lemon wasn't too strong and the flavor combined with the Vermont syrup was perfect together. The sausages have a little kick to them. I'm not a spicy eater so these were just the right amount combined with the savory flavor or the pork. The crispy potatoes were also just good, very good. I'm not sure how they get them so fried and crispy like that. I was nibbling down to the very last little bit on those.

Shirred Eggs - also a must get, two eggs in a tomato based concoction where the tomato doesn't overpower the dish and combines with the egg to produce a very smooth flavor. It's limited due to the fact they serve it in a hot dish so get this if you can.

Overall it was really good place for brunch and I hope to definitely come back!
author: Ander C.

description: Brunch is tasty, restaurant is tiny, so be prepared for a long wait for Sunday brunch. We had 5 and waited over two hours even though we arrived at 10am. 4/5 stars
author: Patricia S.

description: It's a very cute place, but very small for amount of people who come here. I waited almost two hours but it was totally worth it. The waiters are really nice. I ordered The Plow and my boyfriend ordered the Benedict and both were really good. ALSO MUST TRY LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES!!
author: Chloe S.

description:
Second time here and I really enjoyed my meal:

Short Ribs Hash - tender, juicy beef with potatoes topped with eggs.

Buttermilk Biscuit - a dense, great version of a biscuit, it arrived with a portion of honey butter, which really made it fantastic.

Either come here when they open or be prepared to wait a while...I arrived on a Saturday at 9am and the wait was already an hour.
author: Ken G.

description: I'm not sure what magician whipped up the buttermilk biscuits but I thank you good sir (ma'am). Start your meal off with that but make sure you just get 1 and share it with at least 1 other friend. The proscuitto and gruyere toast is out of this world. Swap out the potatoes for mixed greens so you don't feel like a chubster when you leave. The staff is insanely nice and super accommodating. Coming to this place you should know it's ALWAYS busy. Expect a 2 hour wait Friday - Sunday if you're going anytime from 8 until noon. No joke. Lucky for me I live in the neighborhood so a pop in at 7:30AM on a Wednesday isn't unusual.
author: Rachelle T.

description:
The food is outstanding!  I ordered the lemon ricotta pancakes and they were "to die for". Because I stick to a vegetarian diet, I asked if there was something they could substitute in lieu of the bacon or sausage offerings.  I was pleasantly rewarded with a 1/2 of an avocado.  Not only is the food good, but the presentation is that of a  restaurant.  

We were a party of four and it took us 1 hour 45 minutes to get a table.  This was on a Sunday morning and the only downside to our experience.

However, if you are on a visit to The City, and this is your only chance to try this lovely eatery, it's well worth the wait.

The potatoes alone are worth the wait!  The wait staff are on top of business and exceptionally pleasant considering they never stop!!!

We hope you will enjoy your experience.
author: Patrice F.

description: Expect to wait a while to be seated for brunch on Saturday or Sunday but I promise it was worth the wait. I had the Plow with bacon, eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes and plow potatoes and it was amazing. There are so many great options on the menu I wish I could have tried it all.
author: Kelsey L.

description:
-Arrived at 12:00PM on a Wed, seating in 5 minutes. It was a beautiful day so we sat outside
-Great service and friendly staff.
-Of course I got the PLOW: Two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes
-Their crispy potatoes are honestly the best I've ever had. Better than french fries i've had too!
-the lemon ricotta pancakes were delicious with a light tangy taste
-I would pass on the house made pork sausage. It was very bland
-$16 for my plate which I thought was reasonable with HUGE portion I was served

In conclusion, would def come back and recommend to friends
author: Lisa N.

description:
5 stars for their potatoes
How do they make these wonderful potatoes?! 
So crispy and crunchy yet soft and tender on the inside. They are brunchtastic magic!

I had the plow which comes with eggs, a side of meat (sausage,bacon), potatoes and lemon ricotta pancakes.
Good amount of food offered since it was like $16.00. But of what was offered the potatoes were the most memorable. 2nd to that was the pancakes which I had as my dessert, light and sweet. 
Good solid brunch spot, but can get a bit tight during busy hours, as seating can get pretty "friendly" to your neighbor.
author: Julie B.

description:
I've wanted to come here for a long time. I love lemon ricotta pancakes and heard this place is one of the best spots for that.

We came around 1030am and waited for nearly an hour. It's quite small inside so you wait outside. We quickly figured out you can go inside and get a cup of coffee while waiting. AWESOME.

After our wait we finally got seated at the counter. It was so fun to watch all the chefs in the kitchen. They're amazingly fast and talented at preparing delicious looking and smelling food.

Food was amazing. I ordered the plow w/scrambled eggs, add cheese. So good and enough for two people easily. Maybe it's not your most creative breakfast food, but it sure was satisfying.
author: Veronica T.

description: Well wow! Just heard about this place from a friend and hopped right on it -- we are breakfast-obsessed after all. Got here on a Saturday morning at around 10, no trouble at all finding parking, and were told it would be an hour wait. Now I'll admit that in 95% of restaurants I've found the host/hostess will overstate how long the wait will be, so I assumed we were looking at less than 45 minutes. Credit to them - they know their customers -- it was one hour exactly. Nice little neighborhood to stroll around in while you wait and friendly, relaxed crowd to hang with on the sidewalk (there are a few places to perch yourself if you'd rather not stand). Really cute place, and about 10 tables out on the sidewalk as well. We were taken inside at the one hour mark and they had coffee in front of us with lightening speed - high marks for that. The staff was incredibly nice and on top of everything. The husband ordered "The Plow"- eggs, sausage, potatoes and lemon ricotta pancakes (our friend had told us these were unbelievable and she was was right!)  I had a dish which was so amazing I have completely forgotten the name (amnesia induced by bliss). It was a slice of toasted brioche bread, gruyere, prosciutto, frisee, and a garlic pepper fried egg, served with their oh-so-delicious plow potatoes. The coffee kept coming and we had reached breakfast nirvana. We will be back and we will not bitch about the wait :-)!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Underwhelming, especially for the 1.25 hour wait. It's so ridiculous.

$40 for 2 orders of "the plow" and 1 coffee (not strong).

Service was professional but unattentive and mediocre like the food.

The pancakes come out pretty black on both sides and then almost undercooked in the middle. If you absolutely must come here (as in all other brunches are closed and eating toast isn't an option), then I suggest you go with the lemon pancake instead of the almond pancake. It's the only thing that had any luster.

There are hooks under the counter if you end up being seated there.

Better off somewhere else.

Just because there's a line does not mean the food is good. Hipsters are lemmings.
author: Chia-Fen Y.

description:
Came here for brunch with two girlfriends while visiting San Francisco for the weekend. We found this place via Yelp, and it was a big hit!

We went in on a Monday morning at about 9AM and we were able to snag three bar seats without a wait. The place is really small, ~10 tables, so definitely be prepared to wait. Our bar seats were great-- we had front row seats to look at the open kitchen and watch the chefs cook. Very cool to see them making the homemade pancakes, potatoes and eggs. 

I tried the plow 2 egg breakfast, complete with two eggs sunnyside up, the handmade pork sausage, the famous plow potatoes, and toast. The winner of this meal, and perhaps the restaurant in general, were definitely the plow potatoes. Fried to perfection. The pork sausage was nicely seasoned, but a tad bit dry. My girlfriends got the egg breakfast sandwich and the lemon ricotta pancakes. They loved both. I was able to try the lemon ricotta pancakes and these are a little slice of heaven. Sweet and savory all in one!

One thing I'll say is that breakfast seemed pricey. Dishes were about $14-$16, which seems steep. That being said, San Francisco is more expensive than Chicago!
author: Coleen K.

description: The food was fire, really worth the wait!! Get "The Plow" it lets you taste a  little it of everything. Made our trip to SF insanely better
author: Lorena H.

description:
Having read reviews on Yelp, I knew that the wait would be long, especially on a Sunday that was Father's Day! For our group of 5, we waited for around 1 hour and 30 minutes - luckily the SF marathon passed us just one block down the hill, so we were easily able to entertain ourselves that morning.

Plow has this great, welcoming, and airy ambience. It's small, so small you squeeze up against the waitstaff and other customers every time you get up out of your seat, but also so clean and cozy it feels like you're dining in a cloud of pleasantness and good intentions. It is a little loud, but comfortably so.
 
Per Yelp's recommendations, we ordered four Plows and one fried chicken sandwich: two with bacon, one with pork sausage, and one with chicken apple. Each was amply sized:
    * two delightfully sweet and light lemon ricotta pancakes
    * two eggs cooked as you liked them (I had mine scrambled: so fluffy!)
    * your meat option (the chicken apple sausages are nicely sweet)
    * crispy potatoes. Might I mention that if you come here for nothing else, you order    
    these potatoes. You wait an hour for these potatoes because they are WORTH IT. Just the right amount of batter, salt, and seasoning to make me forget about how much starch I'm consuming and wallow in happiness for the rest of the morning.

The fried egg sandwich, which my mother ordered, seemed kind of messy as the yolk managed to drip out all over her hand when she first picked it up.

Otherwise, I have no negative comments about Plow. The service is great, the food is outstanding, and it is worth the wait and the hour long drive we made to get there. C:
author: Connie L.

description: The wait is just out of control buuut...the food is bomb. This is a legit breakfast place. Simple decor, warm and friendly service. You wait outside and the cold or even rain but well worth it. I have tried pretty much the whole menu now and there's really nothing I don't like, love the simple, well executed soft scramble. The quality of the ingredients and freshness that you feel when it hits your palate. This is by far the best breakfast place in San Francisco...so far. My quest continues  5 stars! All the other places should learn a thing or two about this place...
author: Patricia H.

description:
Best breakfast/brunch food ever. 
I told my friend about this place and I said "lemon ricotta pancakes" and he just looked at me funny. We went there and after he tasted them, he was pleasantly surprised. It tastes like a dessert but not an overwhelming sugary dessert. These pancakes hands down the best I've ever had - so light and fluffy.

Same goes for the sausages - they have fennel in them and are the absolute best sausages I've ever had. 

I would recommend "The Plow" with the sausage!
author: Sasha P.

description:
One of my favorite brunch spots. Wish they had this in San Diego! 

I ordered the plow... Can I just say the crispy potatoes did not disappoint and the lemon ricotta pancakes were Aaaaaamazzzing!! I've definitely never tasted something like that before. Also, the biscuit with honey butter melts in your mouth; I'm drooling as I type this.

I definitely recommend this spot if you're into the savory kind of breakfast and if you have time (long wait, but worth it!) When I visit SF again, I will def be coming here!
author: Jennifer F.

description:
Came here 10 minutes before they opened on a Saturday and the line wasn't too bad at all.  Ordered The Plow and it was enough food to share with my friend...with leftovers.  Portions are huge and delicious.  

The Lemon Ricotta pancakes melt in your mouth and taste like dessert.  

Got the chicken apple sausage and it didn't disappoint.  Will need to be back to check out the rest of the menu!
author: Jenny L.

description:
The food tasted horrible and so oily (unhealthy) ,
Service was so bad as servers never smile get so annoyed if u ask about item or you need to change something.
author: Mai Y.

description:
I came here for brunch on a weekday and I have to say, one of the best I've ever had. Plow is located in Potrero Hill and the decor inside was neutral colors and quaint. Since it's a small restaurant, it can get a little cramped.

I'm not normally a pancake fan but people raved about the lemon-ricotta pancakes so I had to try them. 

I was not disappointed. Nice, lemon flavor with bits of ricotta cheese. 

Brunch companion had the regular eggs and potatoes dish with homemade sausage patties. Usually potatoes in dishes like these are semi-crispy, even when requesting extra crispy. But not the potatoes at Plow - these were fried up perfectly crispy and had that crunch that I love. Homemade sausage patties were flavorful and a slight kick to them.

They had an open kitchen and the guys in the kitchen were like machines - cranking out quality food even as the restaurant was bustling. Everything was delicious but the crispy potatoes kicked it up to 5 stars.
author: Nette T.

description:
Brunch before our flight back to NY was delightful.  We had a table outside and the meal was 5 star.  Plow home fries and Lemon pancakes were savory!  Will be back soon.

Side note - Sadly a patron that just finished their meal discovered their car broken into in broad daylight on the steep hill next to this place.  I recommend not keeping valuables in your car.  SF is known for snatch and grabs.
author: M N.

description:
I finally got to try this place and the food was good.

The line of course is always out the door, even on a Tuesday at noon when we thought there wouldn't be. The woman taking names down was the only reason why I didn't give this place 5 stars. I have her my name and party number and later realized we needed a high chair for my niece so we went and told her to add it to our party. When we were called I walked over to our seats as my sister in law got something out the car. When she met me at the table we pulled up the high chair thinking the woman had forgot, but she quickly came and rudely said "I'm sorry ladies I can't do that!" We explained to her that we had told her to add a high chair to the party and she told us to wait outside until she could get a bigger table. She then showed us she had two Samantha's and that she called the other Samantha. I'm convinced she just didn't hear us when we said to add the high chair to our party, and added our names to the list as a new party which made the wait time even longer.

What saved that encounter was a really sweet busboy who came and asked what name our party was under to see what the wait time was because he had noticed every one being called except us. He came out and told us the big table was close to being available and then asked us if we wanted a drink while we waited outside. He kindly brought us coffee which was just awesome. He was the best, amazing customer service from him.

The wait time for our food was also a little over an hour but we were very satisfied with the food. The potatoes were flavorful, the bacon was smoked and the lemon ricotta pancakes melts in your mouth. Delicious!
author: Samantha N.

description:
This has been on my list for a while. I can see why it's always so busy and there's often a wait. 

Delicious food well done. Friendly welcoming staff. And beautiful. Cozy space. 

We were disappointed they didn't have the Pazole but the mushroom and stinging nettles soft scrambled eggs were very good. The crispy potatoes are top notch and the pork sausage so tasty-pork!

Friends had Annie's ricotta pancakes and loved them. Thanks Annie.
author: Mark M.

description: The hype and wait are worth it. Really outstanding brunch food. The potatoes and ricotta pancakes are my favorite things. I am not at all a lemon or flavored pancake person normally but these are amazing. Also coffee while you wait makes such a difference. Staff is generally friendly. Pretty cramped inside and the first time I came in we sat beside some annoying sports bros but the food made up for it.
author: Nora C. E.

description:
The GF and I came here around 12:00.  The hostess informed us it would be an hour and a half to an hour and forty five minute wait.  We decided to walk around the neighborhood, and ended up at Whole Foods.  After half an hour there, we walked back, and waited for the remainder of the time.  We were seated in practically the worst spot in the entire restaurant- right next to the bathroom.  If this was not bad enough, the bathroom only has a single stall, creating a never ending line.  These people waiting in line were practically hovering over our table.  

The GF ordered "the plow" and I got the eggs benedict.  The benedict was average tasting.  Either the hollandaise sauce or the muffin tasted somewhat sour.  Maybe the bread is sourdough.  Regardless, it had a very strange aspect associated with it.  The best part of the meal was the potatoes, hands down.  It is true what they say about this place having the crispiest potatoes. I tried the pancakes too, and my taste buds did not go for it.  It is very different tasting than a traditional pancake.  I will pass on that next time.  

Overall, I loved the potatoes.  The eggs benedict was just alright, and the pancakes were a no go in my book.  

I cannot justify waiting almost two hours to eat breakfast.  :(
author: Victor L.

description: Be prepared to wait for your food for a really long time but the food's really really good. I guess its the curse of Yelp that once someone recommends an item everyone orders it - but the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes are worth every review written out here (must try!!). Ordered the Plow, French Toast and the Fried Egg Sandwich as well and pretty much everything tasted great ( plus the wait makes you super hungry as well :P )
author: Preethish S.

description:
Plow sits in the up and coming Dogpatch and I'm really loving this area. That being said, I was really excited to try this place. The only catch - it's basically a 2 hour wait.

The food is good, definitely. As all the Yelpers recommend, get the Plow. I agree - it gives you all the breakfast basics: eggs, sausage or bacon, pancakes and crispy potatoes. Everyone comes here for the lemon ricotta pancakes. Being that I'm the stranger person that does not like lemony baked goods, I went with the almond flour pancakes. I was a big fan of the almond flour pancakes and the crispy potatoes. Everything else was made well and overall, it was a fulfilling breakfast.

But it is NOT worth a 2 hour wait. If you're an early riser, then definitely come when they open. Otherwise, plan to put your name down, walk around grab a snack, take your time and come back 2 hours later.
author: Angela K.

description:
I echo the sentiments on the service being outstanding -- everyone was organized and very nice. We didn't feel rushed through, which is key after the inevitable wait, even on a weekday morning, which is when we went.

I think the wait is the thing most people mention in their reviews, whether good or lukewarm. Like others, I was more than willing to wait a half hour for an outstanding breakfast -- but this was far from outstanding.

First of all, the meals are a heart attack on a plate -- everything seems to be deep fried or cooked in vegetable oil (we sat at the bar, so we could see everything as it was cooked). My two friends got the Plow, which was two pancakes, eggs, breakfast meat, and toast. I ordered two eggs and the chicken apple sausage and toast.

The pancakes were, as others have written, delicious. The lemon flavoring makes them feel lighter than they are. The eggs were completely flavorless; my guess is that cooking with oil was behind this, rather than butter. I even had them add some cheese; what they added appeared on one side of the scramble but I didn't see cheese throughout.

The potatoes were delicious -- dude. Deep. Fried. How can they not be? Crispy and good. The toast was either a sour dough or almost Italian type bread which, when toasted, was hard to chew. The apple sausage was good, but not particularly memorable. For drinks, we ordered coffee and tea; they were happy with their coffee, my tea didn't stay very warm in the individual pot that was brought to the table.

In the end, if you do choose to go here, keep in mind that the portions are HUGE -- so perhaps share with someone at your table. I ate maybe a third of the eggs, 2 out of 4 of the sausage links, both small slices of toast, and maybe 1/2 the potatoes and left feeling very fool. And of course, bring a book or newspaper, something to keep you occupied -- because you'll be waiting a long, long time.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Everything was really good, food, service, ambiance. The crispy potatoes are amazing, biscuit with honey butter was really good too. Would definitely go back, worth the wait.
author: Jen M.

description: Always great! Perfect service, delish food and if you time it right, you shouldn't have to wait too long.(especially if there's only 2 or 3 of ya) and pro tip: wait across the street in the sun on weekends
author: Pilar T.

description: This place is really good, but kinda expensive. I probably wouldn't come back unless with my parents or grandparents! Everything was really good, the iced tea isn't worth the price, skip that. This place is far from SFSU and my friend and I waited over an hour to be seated
author: Katelyn K.

description: Visited from Seattle last week and as a brunch enthusiast, I must say I am a definite fan of this establishment. The dungeness crab with fresh herb omelet was like the best thing ever. And the gluten-free pancakes omg delicious. Yes we did wait an hour, but we were told it was going to be a 2 hour wait so we were pleasantly surprised. I would wait it out again for that brunch any day!!
author: Emy J.

description:
Maybe I over-hyped it. Maybe 7x7 over-hyped it. Maybe my friends over-hyped it. Or maybe Yelp just over-hyped this place. All of the above? I don't know, but I left somewhat unimpressed.

Our table ordered the following:

Lemon Ricotta Pancakes - these were good, but not fantastic. I'd say maybe too lemon-y and a little dry.

Fried Egg Sandwich w/Bacon - while this was good, it wasn't mind-blowing. It's just an egg sandwich in bread nicer than toast. The potato wedges were great though.

Dungeness Crab Scamble - This was my favorite dish, however $17 was a tad expensive IMO. I liked that they put a decent amount of crab meat, but it could still use more. Nothing really special about this scramble either except for having crab meat.

We came here on a Wednesday afternoon around 10:45am and for a party of 4 we waited about 20-30 mins. Not a bad wait, so hearing about 2 hour waits on the weekends makes me wonder why people would wait that long for the food here. Don't get me wrong - their food is good, just not great or better than many other brunch places in the city. I'm glad I finally tried this place, but I probably will not return anytime soon. Bummer.
author: Joanne Y.

description:
This place is spot on for the food/service/atmosphere.

To start off, I had a minor celebrity spotting while I waited for a table.  I found it even more entertaining when they seated me AHEAD of the minor celebrity because I came in first...well done for service and treating everyone equal.  

I tried the Plow, anything named after the restaurant has to be their signature dish and SOOO GOOD.  It's a little bit of everything and guaranteed to hit the spot.

The homemade sausage patties were out of this world, rosemary potatoes some of the best I ever had..but the marvel of the dish was the lemon ricotta pancakes.  I dont know how to describe how well this hit every piece of my pallate.  Little zest, not overly sweetened, creamy yet firm.  Wow wow wow!

Service was also impeccable.  Friendly and made you feel like a guest in someones home. My coffee cup was NEVER empty and you could tell that they all kind of loved being part of the team.

Food Recommendation: The Plow or Lemon Ricotta Pancakes
author: Reena B.

description:
Came here with my fellow foodie Fanny W., we found parking across the street (that never happens...), walked in and were seated right away at the last table available, sweet! There's nothing like a bright and sunny morning in SF, I mean how often does that happen honestly? Good thing Plow takes full advantage of whenever the weather is beautiful with its huge storefront facing windows. 

We opted for the Fried Egg Sandwich and THE PLOW. I thought the Fried Egg Sandwich sounded a bit ordinary, but it was far from it! Equipped with  two eggs fried, aioli, frisee, Vermont cheddar, Acme bun. The aioli puts a nice twist on the egg sandwich, and to top it off with Acme bun made fresh in the city, I could not resist. 

The Plow is a must order at Plow -- two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes. We went with the two eggs, house made pork sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes. Man-oh-man was this dish delish. The pork sausage was nicely seasoned, not too salty (which is a huge plus to me), the lemon ricotta pancakes were AMAZING it made my mouth drop (and this is coming from a girl who doesn't like lemon zested anything...), and the seasoned house potatoes sounded average, but they definitely weren't. 

Overall we had a fantastic experience here at Plow. Parking was easy (no meter), we were seated right away (rare moment), and the service/ambiance screamed brunch, what more could you ask for. One thing bothered me though, there was a huge mix up with the check, we were charged an extra $20... Something was obviously wrong here. I've been reading about restaurants scamming their customers a lot lately down in Santa Ana, so I was extra careful to check the tab. I'm sure it was just a mistake, but for it to happen to both our table and the table adjacent to ours? Kind of strange, I think Plow needs to figure that one out... Nonetheless Fanny W. and I really enjoyed our experience here and hope to be back real soon!
author: Elaine N.

description:
YUM.

It's one of the best places for breakfast in San Francisco. If you are planning on going to San Francisco anytime soon, bookmark this place and come early! We came super early on a weekend morning on our way to a retreat. We were one of the first groups in line so luckily we didn't have to wait very long at all. Even if there was a wait it would be absolutely worth it. 

The place is quite small, they have a bar which seats singles or for those who don't want to wait for a table and are just there for a quick bite to eat. I think the biggest table they have seats four people. The decor is quite simple, a hint of an industrial and a touch of farmhouse chic, super cute. 

So you may think that it's such a simple egg sandwich, which it pretty much is. But it's soooo much more than that. The bread is very slightly sweet and buttered and crunchy. And the sauce that they pair with the frisée doesn't overpower the true taste of the egg. The egg is cooked to over-easy perfection and the yolk turns into this messy deliciousness. Probably the most delicious egg I've ever eaten. Simple and clean flavors, everything works so well together. The lemon ricotta pancakes were also to die for, seriously.
author: Lina T.

description:
This place is so amazing. I ate here a couple months back, but I just recently started reviewing on Yelp & came back across this place on the "Yelposphere." 

If I could give this place 6 out of 5 stars I totally would!  It's pretty popular, especially in the morning time, but it's earned its name. My family, boyfriend, and I went around 9:30 ish in the morning (party of 6) and had about a 20-25 minute wait from what I could remember. We were starving but the wait was totally worth it. 

First off, the service is great! ABSOLUTELY WELCOMING! Everyone there is super friendly and smiling, and always willing to offer you a helping hand, regardless of your needs. 

The food was so delicious. We all nearly melted in our seats. I forgot what it was called, but I ordered the waffle with the strawberries & potatoes on the side. And I also tried my boyfriend's Lemon Ricotta pancakes. SOOOO GOOD. And makes me so hungry just thinking about it. The waffle was so fresh, the fruit and everything else complemented each other so well. The potatoes had the perfect amount of salt and spice and CRUNCH. I could cry just reminiscing. The pancakes too, oh my god. So much flavor. Lemon ricotta was such a good idea. 

The decor was just a plus. Super clean, sleek, and modern. The clear windows allowed lots of sun to shine through which was nice. 

I will definitely be coming back in the near future. 10/10 would recommend!!!!
author: Lauryn S.

description:
First off, the potatoes here are amazing. Each piece is crunchy and I'm not even a big potato person. It took me about 4 hours to decide what I wanted, and the server ended up choosing the breakfast sandwich for me - great choice! I ordered it with chicken sausage. The sandwich was perfect, it had two fried eggs, frisée, homemade chicken sausage and melty cheese. The bread was a brioche bun and the sandwich was so delicious! 

My friends both ordered "the plow" which came with A LOT of food! I had a bite of the famous lemon pancakes which had a great texture. Very tasty, but a little sweet for me. The coffee here is strong and made well, which everyone can appreciate. I can't wait to go back to try more of the menu!
author: Lauren G.

description: I ordered the plow and was able to alter my order without complaint. Service was great, surmising quick wait. Food was fresh, but not the best brunch I've had.
author: Fernilla S.

description:
Crispy potatoes... *drool*.... mmmm, mmmm good!

Yes, there's a ridiculous wait for this place on the weekends (up to two hours), but it's totally worth it! Though I do suggest that you try to hit up this place during the week. The wait time goes down to 30 minutes. 

This cute little place is located right at the corner surrounded by FREE parking. Just hope that you can find a spot! The place is small. Maybe no more than 20 people can sit down at a time. But there are a handful of seats at the counter where you can watch the magic happen.

The menu is small but features locally sourced, high quality ingredients, making even the simplest dishes stand out in comparison to the basic breakfast joint. Choose from a warm mushroom salad to a dungeness crab scramble to chia seed pudding.

The lemon ricotta pancakes are a popular choice. Very fluffy and light with tons of lemon flavor. I love the texture, but the lemon was a bit to strong for my taste. I suggest getting The Plow combo if you want to enjoy these. That way you can get it with two eggs any style and your choice of housemade sausage, Neuske bacon or chicken sausage. Some salt to balance out the sweetness.

My fave is the fried egg sandwich! Two eggs over easy sandwiched by soft, toasted Acme bread with frisee, aioli and cheese with the additional Neuske bacon (everything is better with bacon!). The creamy egg yolk mixes with all the components and makes it finger lickin' good! It also comes with a side of their infamous crispy potatoes!

They're serious about their potatoes. Smashed red potatoes flavored with fresh rosemary and onions and fried to perfection! They managed to find a way for you to have your hashbrowns and country potatoes together as one! You can't find potatoes like this anywhere else!

By the way, if you like scrambled eggs, they know how to do it right. Super light and fluffy yet still creamy. I don't even like scrambled eggs, but I love them here!

Good thing I don't live next to here or else I'd have a muffin top full of crispy potatoes and bacon!
author: Daisy T.

description:
Best brunch I've had in a long time. While the menu appears to have simple, classic brunch items, Plow really perfected all of the items on my plate. I got 'The Plow' which features the best of sweet and salty breakfast options. The lemon ricotta pancakes were perfectly fluffy and were complimented well with the little pitcher of maple syrup. The home fries, oh the home fries. These were very well seasoned, crispy and golden on the outside, soft on the inside. A separate waitress made sure we had little dishes of ketchup to go with our potatoes. Lastly, the scrambled eggs. These were also very yummy and I definitely got way more than the two the menu said I'd get. WIN. I got the chicken apple sausage and recommend it.

You won't regret going here!
author: Danielle C.

description:
Finally made it down here after living in Potrero for over a year. Went on a weekday to avoid the long lines but still had to wait 30 mins. 

Highlights were the lemon ricotta pancakes (best pancake I've ever had) and the pork sausage (great blend of spices and crispness). Everything else was solid but not wait-worthy. 

Friendly service and they comp'ed our buttermilk biscuit because our food took a long time to come out.

Will be back again but not waiting more than 30 mins!
author: Clinton L.

description:
Lots of rave reviews for Plow, tho depending on what you value in your dining experience it could be a good or poor experience. 

Service. I'm rating not only the service in the restaurant but on the phone as well. Service I'd give as 2-stars. Not that it hasn't been good it has, but it's also been inconsistent and poor - at times staff overwhelmed with the crowd or inconsistent messaging when calling in an order - sad to observe but sometimes the service is more along the lines of what's convenient for the staff, not the customer. 

Food. I'll never review a place I haven't been to at least 3 times and in the case of Plow it's 6+. The star of this place is the lemon ricotta pancakes. They are as good as other reviews have said. If lemon ricotta pancakes are your thing or even if they are not - give these a try at least once. Those pancakes are the only thing that brings me back to this place. The rest of the food appears fresh and is good, but can also be inconsistent. Bacon has been overcooked on more than one visit(leaving it on the dry side) and potatoes have gone from crisp on the outside, steamy good on the inside one visit to a greasy soggy mess on another. Sandwiches have been good.  The guys in the kitchen are hustling and doing a good job of getting dishes out, just need to focus on the consistency part. 

Ambiance. Plow is a cute clean place on the outer edge of shops and other restaurants on its street. It has a smallish indoor dining area and a handful of tables along the outside of the restaurant. They also have a counter space where you can see most of what's going on in the kitchen. The seating outside is plagued with people waiting, watching you eat while they suffer thru that long wait. Not uncommon to have 15 - 20 people milling around outside this place.  Lastly, it can get cold outside(most time you are in a shade), they offer blankets for folks sitting down to eat at the outside tables.  

Recommendation. The place gets busy busy busy. If you don't mind waiting for an hour plus then line up, if you don't, then try to visit during the week(tho still busy) for those pancakes and see if they measure up. Or try coming by yourself and see if you can score a single seat at the counter quicker(this has worked but not always). Lastly, if you do hate waits, this place is not for you - I've seen people get worked up and not enjoy their breakfast/lunch.
author: Jorge M.

description: Everything was delicious--from the eggs, crispy potatoes, ricotta lemon pancakes, bacon, everything! The only down side is the wait is atrocious. I walked in and was told the wait was 2 hours. Although, five min later, I was told my wait was one hour. It was a little difficult to get an actual exact wait time.
author: Clemonce K.

description:
We got lucky and were seated quickly considering they have limited seating. I got the fried egg sandwich with bacon. It came with their fried potatoes, which were fried to perfection. Very crispy outside, and soft on the inside and well seasoned. The sandwich was a delight. It had cheese and a expertly fried egg. The bacon acted as the sprinkles on a good cupcake! Really good! We shared some of the Almond flour pancakes, which were surprisingly light and fluffy. 

I got to try some of "the plow", which had their house made sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes.  I really liked the lemon ricotta pancakes, too! They had a little citrus flavor that went well with a little bit of syrup. They don't have an extensive menu, but it is like that for a reason. They do what they do well and that is all you need to know!
author: Aaron Y.

description:
Outstanding... the only place that I would happily walk to, in the rain, without an umbrella or rain boots, and then wait 2.5 hours to get a seat. 

As everyone else has said, The Plow is delicious. Also try the biscuit as an appetizer! It's insanely good. I like the ambiance of this neighborhood as well. Grab a coffee at Farley's and/or browse the aisles at Christopher's Books while you wait. 

Just a note: they don't close at 2PM - they just stop taking names then.
author: Melody Y.

description:
This brunch spot holds a special place in my heart :)  It's in my childhood neighborhood... it's cute, quiet, and a pretty little "suburb of the city."  Plow is never overcrowded, or too loud for comfort like other brunch locations; it's small, intimate, and cozy.  You'll always have at least an hour wait, but that is a to be expected price to pay for a enjoyable brunch experience.  Worth it.

The menu changes, and I've enjoyed many items over the years, but this last weekend I tried the Benedict with Smoked Salmon and my boyfriend had The Plow. The Plow contains house made sausage that is so delicious!  It has a ton of flavor and melts in your mouth.  The house potatoes are a crispy baked potato wedge that with their hot sauce and ketchup are yummy with every bite.  The Benedict doesn't over do it with the hollandaise sauce and their smoked salmon is incredible, really bringing up the level of the classic Eggs Benedict.  

I typically bring friends and family that travel from other parts of the state and/or other parts of the country to this little neighborhood spot.  With constant menu changes I'm always in for a treat with my traveling guests making this a wonderful regular location even for a lifelong local.  

Mimosas are always a nice touch to brunch, however, not bottomless, so don't indulge too much! 

xox
author: Mik B.

description:
So the wait sucks. Like many places in SF if you go brunch, brace yourself for waiting. Also a tad on the pricy side. Occasionally you stumble upon a place that is worth the wait and money and  this is one of them. 
First, the service was amazing! The wait staff made me feel like we were long time BFFs. 
Second, the drinks were amazing - fresh squeezed grapefruit mimosas. Can you start me on a catheter of this please? Also, the tea is wonderful and served in a clay pot. 
Third, the food is amazing - the most amazing biscuit you will ever have. EVER.
author: Cris B.

description:
Overall unimpressed with Plow.

We came on Friday at noon & the wait was about 45 minutes. Didn't mind the wait too much, but was disappointed to find that the food was just mediocre & nowhere NEAR other amazing breakfast joints in the city (i.e., Griddle Fresh). 

- The pancakes weren't soft & fluffy. 
- The apple sausages were slightly burnt.
- The grapefruit mimosa was 99.9% juice. 
- And they don't allow you to get bacon, apple sausage, & pork sausage all on one plate! (I asked & was told I can only choose one. Seriously?) 
- The potatoes were the only thing that stood out on the plate. 

Lastly, service was below par. They were incredibly rude to both me & my friend. After the server checked our IDs for the mimosas, she proceeded to tell him "Wow, you're a lot older than her," then left. I was speechless! 

Anyways, I won't be back here. Too many other breakfast joints more deserving of my money.
author: Sylvia N.

description:
This is a really cute place and the food was pretty tasty. I ordered the two-egg breakfast and my table shared pumpkin pancakes. We did have a pretty long wait for 4 people (almost 40 minutes on a Thursday morning), but that was to be expected from other reviews as well as the size of the restaurant. 
The reason it is 3 stars instead of 4 is because my hot tea was served tepid.That sounds really picky, but I was sitting outside and it was chilly, so it would have been really nice to have "hot" tea. 
I do want to go back and try the lemon ricotta pancakes, and give Plow another shot.
author: Nichole F.

description:
First off, the wait here is always at least 2 hours long for some reason. If you have other things to keep you busy anyways, I'd say it's worth it, but the long wait time is definitely something to take into consideration before you go. 

Plow is one of the most charming and pleasant brunch spots I've ever been to. Everyone who works there are very nice in a down-to-earth kind of way, and if you sit at the counter you can watch the cooks whipping up their magic out in the open. My boyfriend and I were the last ones allowed to be seated even though it was literally past closing time (bless our waitress' heart). By the time we started eating, there weren't many people in the restaurant anymore and we found ourselves having a nice, peaceful meal to the background sound of the employees brunching together at the tables next to us. Really relaxing. 

The food itself is really good. Their soft scrambled eggs in any dish were one of our favorites, and in general it's hard to go wrong with this place!
author: Hope X.

description: Wish I could give 6 stars !!!! This is by far the most incredible brunch I have ever had. Their execution was absolutely exquisite. Came two days in a row. Can't wait to go again !!
author: Kiersten Y.

description: "The plow" is the best item without a doubt. The sausage patty in this plate is very good and lemon ricotta pancake is out of the world. You try chia seed pudding which is a healthy and interesting take on dessert. Make sure you are prepared to wait for at least 1 hr in the line and have the complete eating party at the time time they call your name or else they won't serve you. The best way to kill time is to go to coffee shop in the next block.
author: Ash M.

description: The Plow is so good, and everyone has to try the lemon ricotta pancakes. And you can't forget to grab a biscuit (as long as they're not sold out)!
author: Preciosa M.

description:
The reviews don't lie, this really was the best breakfast I have ever had. Usually I never wait more than 1/2 hour, but with friends visiting from out of state and knowing that by the time you get to another worthwhile spot it's going to be the same wait we decided to stay and wait the 1 1/2 hours. There are some good coffee spots around or you can order coffee or mimosas here and have them while you wait so it's not too big of a deal. 3 of us ordered the plow I had mine with poached eggs and chicken apple sausage. I thought they gave me pork sausage it was that good, and those lemon ricotta pancakes amazing. Another good thing was parking plenty on the same street and other close streets, each is only 2 hours so you might have to move your car while u wait but hey close and free parking in San Francisco is worth it.
I would definitely recommend and go back
author: Bianca R.

description: One of the best breakfast spots just outside of the city. There is always a line so be sure to get there before the doors open!!! It's pretty common to see the line up the hill by 7:45 on the weekends....That being said if you're not in a rush, put your name in, grab some coffee & stroll around. Their fresh made biscuits with honey butter are completely worth the wait! The "plow" is what most people are there for....plenty of food, that gives you a little bit of everything your looking for at brunch. Coffee is strong, rich & bottomless :)  the atmosphere is fun & vibrant as the sun peaks over the hills. Servers are always welcoming & fun. If you're looking for a great breakfast place while visiting the city, it's a must! If you live the the area, it's still a must....just more often!
author: Xander M.

description: Got here around 12:45 on a Friday and it was a full house but we only waited about five minutes for a table of two. For drinks we ordered a root beer and a homemade strawberry lemonade. The lemonade was adorable and came with one of those old school paper straws with red stripes on it. It was a little on the sour side but was still refreshing. My boyfriend and I ordered the plow breakfast combo which came with two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, REALLY REALLY BOMB ASS crunchy potatoes, and two pork sausage patties. The lemon ricotta pancakes were sooo flavorful and really moist. We also ordered a French toast which came with marscapone cream and strawberries on top (also bomb). Everything was absolutely delicious!!  Would definitely be back again to try their weekend brunch menu.
author: Linz C.

description:
Holy Overrated, Batman! Everyone told me this place was gangbusters, and the long line I saw outside seemed to confirm it was worth waiting for. 

Let me tell you: it wasn't. I live in Potrero Hill and I will still never be back. The best thing I can say about this place is that the hosts and hostesses are very, very nice about managing the very, very long wait. 

The food is forgettable, except for bad things: the much-ballyhooed lemon ricotta pancakes taste like soured lemon square dessert with a strangely unwelcome doughiness to it. If you want lemon square dessert for breakfast, save yourself the hassle of the wait and go buy lemon squares. They will taste better.

The egg sandwich was the greasiest thing I have ever had. I LOVE a good breakfast sandwich and have never been so completely, utterly disappointed. I was unable to finish it as I began to feel queasy halfway through from all the butter that was making my hands shiny. I saw someone refer to it as "Southern" in another review.
