I used to live in Louisiana, and let me tell you, there was nothing Southern about this oily, sickening monstrosity.

The potatoes were fine. They tasted like I expect breakfast potatoes to taste. All of you who think they are God's gift to breakfast potatoes, where do you normally dine? Because anyone operating a restaurant ought to be able to produce a decent breakfast potato exactly like these very normal breakfast potatoes. It's a pretty basic side item.

There is a stunning dearth of restaurants with nice atmosphere in San Francisco, particularly given the upscale clientele and general quirkiness of the place. Plow is a nice place to sit - and easy to talk, especially when your table is next to a couple where the girl is taking selfies on her phone the whole time and not saying a world to her boyfriend who works on his laptop the whole time. And if you don't mind the sensation of knowing that there is a crowd of people waiting for you to hurry up and get out.

I'm glad that Plow is doing well as maybe more brunch places with thoughtful decor will appear. But unless the idea of eggs drizzled in at least half a cup of movie theater popcorn butter is appetizing to you, skip it.
author: Esther M.

description: Came here around 11 AM on a Tuesday and the line was already long as expected. The wait was about 1.5 hour long as we got seated outside. What I didn't like about this restaurant was how any one was allowed to sign the seating list without their whole party there. It made it extremely unfair for those who actually waited more than an hour (like my friends and I). After finally being seated, I ordered the egg sandwich with bacon and avocado that came with their house potatoes. It was super delicious and was around $15. I'd recommend that if you're not up for some pancakes.
author: Sarah F.

description: Probably the best egg sandwich I've ever had. Pork sausage is also awesome. Lemon ricotta pancakes are good too, if you're into that.
author: Tish M.

description: Came here twice in case first time was an off day.. This place is not worth the time or money. The food was a yuppie version of Dennys.. Ordered the plow..the small eggs scramble was wet, the bacon tastes of rubbered gasiline.. pancakes were cold. The mochi cake was rubbery in a microwave form. The whole afternoon i spent feeling as if the food was sitting at my neck,, which happened the first time so i checked in with my friend and she felt same all day! We will not be coming back again. At this rate this place will be a flash in the pan for SF.
author: Nushka V.

description: Keep in mind that this is just a brunch spot! Just brunch! Not a Vegas nightclub on New Years! We waited for 2:35 minutes and watched two other groups go in ahead of us (that arrived after us) the hostesses were rude (all three of them) and no one came out to reassure us with a "sorry, we are super busy, bluh bluh bluh"! Again, this is just BRUNCH! I felt belittled and undeserving of eating at their basic San Francisco pretentious brunch spot #47! I'm sure the food is delicious but I had better luck buying a pair of Yeezys on release date!
author: Brandan P.

description:
We walked here from the 16th St BART Station. Not a good idea. I didn't think to check the distance (1.6 miles); it seemed so close on the map. It's not that a 32-minute walk wasn't good for me (I totally earned my breakfast, not), it's the unsavory characters that you encounter. So, don't do what I did. However, the meal was worth the trouble!

We arrived around 9:30 on a Tuesday and it was much busier than I expected. Fortunately not busy enough that we had to wait because thankfully, there were two seats available at the bar. Some helpful notes: they will not seat you unless your entire party is present. Even if it is just one other person. No exceptions. Also, there's only 6-7 seats at the bar and roughly seven tables (very small space). There are a couple tables for outside dining as well.

Owner/Chef Maxine Siu was directly in front of us busily preparing dishes in their small partially-open kitchen. She was careful not to make eye contact with any patrons. Totally understandable, but it would have been so much fun to talk food. 

Ruben started with a cup of Equator Coffee ($3.50) and we shared a Cinnamon Brioche ($4). It was a delicious rendition of a cinnamon roll and the center was perfectly gooey and flavorful. I selected The Plow ($16) with sunny side-up eggs, housemade pork sausage, two Lemon Ricotta Pancakes, and crispy potatoes. The sausage was nice, but dry. Not my favorite sausage. Though the crispy potatoes were lovely and the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes were perfect! Ruben had the Fried Egg Sandwich with Nueske Bacon ($13.50), two soft fried eggs, aioli, cheddar, and frisée on an Acme bun. This was also tasty with the addition of the "Food's Best Friend Lucky Dog" hot fire-roasted pepper sauce.

Our server was really friendly and everyone was very pleasant. We didn't loiter much since there were several people waiting, but it's a nice setting to hang out and catch up with friends. The decor is fun with many pigs around! Oh, the important question - would I wait for 1+ hour(s) for a table? No, but that is why you plan ahead!
author: Amelinda L.

description:
Plow was pretty good, but was it an hour wait long good? Ehhh, let's just say I'm not in a hurry to come back. And an hour is on the SHORTER end of the wait time frame!

Decided to make a trip here for brunch on "Spring Forward" DST day, hoping people were thrown off by the hour that disappeared from the day. Was intending to get there by 9:45am but lagged myself until 10:30a (oops, darn DST lol). I was almost dropped off to get our names on the list but I rushed out my house blind (without contacts on) so we had to go find parking first (again, oops lol). Good thing parking was easy to find! We got a spot right around the corner and then the hour wait commenced...

We were seated at the bar, which I love because of the open kitchen, and this is how I learned that:
[+] pork sausages are uncooked, hand-formed and cooked only when ordered
[+/-] chicken-apple sausages are cooked a bit and "reheated"/"recooked"
[-] bacon is cooked beforehand, sits in an open metal pan, and simply "reheated" on the flat top griddle (albeit it is most efficient this way, considering how busy it is here)
[+] everything else is cooked only when ordered
[+] the cooks have a very organized system so, props to those guys!

THE PLOW ($16)
[+/-] Lemon ricotta pancakes (2 small) were very good in some bites (depending on where the ricotta is), but it was a bit dry overall and had a very faint lemon flavor. I usually don't use syrup with my pancakes but for this, I had to dip a bit to add some sweetness to it.
[+] Potatoes were on point. I love the crispy, herby tastes and it was not overly salty either.
[+] Chicken-apple sausages (4 links) were very enjoyable and did not taste overcooked from the "recooking"
[+/-] Eggs are made to your liking

CORNED BEEF HASH ($15)
[-] Yes, it comes with potatoes but it is NOT their signature crispy, herby goodness! You've been warned.
[+] Corned beef was corned beef. Good and thinly-sliced.
[+/-] Comes with 2 slices of lightly-toasted rustic loaf
[+/-] Eggs are made to your liking

SERVICE
[-] Took a while to get our waters after we were seated
[-] Waitress/server totally forgot I asked for a box, even after giving us our check
[+/-] Was never asked how we were doing, but maybe because we were at the bar?

We finished our meal around 12:30pm and there was STILL a long wait. I don't know how people wait so long for this place! It's good but I'm not blown away. If I'm going to wake up early and wait at least an hour for food, I expect nothing less than awesome. Until next time, Plow. And maybe on a weekday morning for a shorter wait time.
author: Sandy T.

description: We got plow with sausage and veggie eggs benedict. Everything was delicious. Potatoes were seasoned well, ricotta pancake texture was nice, and the sausage patties filling. My partner really loved the lemony hollandaise sauce. Satisfying breakfast.
author: Naty D.

description: The potato was crispy and well-seasoned. The French toast was thick and soft inside - which was good. The pancake has lemon flavor and quite delicious. However, I didn't like their jasmine tea. It was so light and just like water.
author: Anya C.

description: This is one of the cutest brunch places I've been to. The inside is just so French, like effortlessly cool. And the food is simple but elegant in a rustic way. I always get the plow at plow (haa) since my love for lemon ricotta pancakes is just as strong as my love for nueske bacon. The fluffiness of the pancakes are just not recreate-able. If they were, I'd be making them every morning.
author: Nina S.

description:
This place is not all that. Don't believe the hype.  The breakfast is mediocre at best.  I tried to order Steak and Eggs but was told after ordering they didn't have steak and eggs.  How do you not have steak and eggs??  Finding a curly hair in my potatoes and undercooked pancakes in the "PLOW" was just lovely.  What a waste of $130 on breakfast for 5 people.  I wish I would have just gave the money to a homeless person who would could have had a better breakfast at McDonalds for 2 weeks.  Not worth the wait at all.  Just plow yourself to Denny's or IHOP.  

Oh I will say the biscuits were good.  =). Otherwise it would have a been a 1 star!
author: Donald L.

description: Came here with a few friends on Sunday, and I loved it! We made a reservation for 5 ahead of time, so I'm not too sure on the wait, but if you did make a reservation, make sure your entire party is there or they won't seat you! (They usually have a long line, I've heard.) The inside is a bit smaller, but not crowded at all, but we just preferred outdoor seating. We got the "Plow" plate (look for "Plow" on the menu), which was apparently one of the most popular, and so glad we got it! It came with a little bit of everything, including apple sausages, eggs, potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes. I am a huge fan of their potatoes, sausages, and above all, their lemon ricotta pancakes! Usually the lemon/ricotta flavor is subtle and I can barely taste it, but Plow did a great job in making a flavorful pancake with amazing hot fried potatoes that filled me up! The waiters were also super friendly and attentive, which made me love the place more. If you love brunch, you have to try this place out!
author: Hana C.

description: Came here while visiting some friends in San Fran and I was blown away at the line out the door. We got there at around 8:30 am and I've never had brunch in Frisco before so I was in for a surprise on how long lines everywhere are. After waiting for about an hour and got a table outside. I had gone with the omelette and I must say everything was amazing! The potatoes were too die for. I ended up trying my buddies biscuit and I must say that might have been the best biscuit in my life. Overall I would recommend this place to anyone who is willing to wait. If not then you might get annoyed before even getting your food because of the wait and think differently of the place. Overall everything was excellent.
author: David Z.

description:
This place has become an absolute favorite after just one day. I was initially feeling miserable as I saw my fiends sitting outside, the wind had been picking up and the sun was nowhere close to touching my skin. One of the waitress offered us blankets and it was very much needed. I see this a  sign of paying attention to the needs of customers and their satisfaction. I don't think I would have been able to enjoy my meal if that blanket wasn't a part of the equation. 

The waitress was very patient as my friend and I caught up after almost three years apart. I ordered "The Plow" and it had all the makings of a good breakfast. The potatoes were amazing and just right. There was a great balance between the starch and crisp layer. We topped the order off with a biscuit and to be honest that would have been it for me with some coffee or tea. The honey butter is a great addition and melted makes it even better. The biscuit doesn't look like a biscuit but once you bite into it all those thoughts escape you. 

I look forward to going back, I hear that you have to go early. Wish me luck!
author: Jodie G.

description:
I've had Plow bookmarked for quite sometime, but since I am an impatient person, he & I have stayed away due to the long waits.  Yesterday morning though, we both woke up early and decided to try our luck.  Parking was pretty easy as we got a space across the street. We arrived about 5 minutes or so after opening and got seated at the last table, which we shared with a couple that got in right before us.  Of course I was afraid that it wasn't going to live up to the hype, but it did!  7x7 released a few months ago the recipe for Plow's lemon ricotta pancakes and I took a stab at making them.  So, naturally I had to get The Plow ($16) & he instantly gravitated towards the Dungeness crab scramble ($17).  The waitress was coming around asking if we wanted coffee with her big pitcher.  Bf said yes and I declined since I'm so picky with coffee.  However, he (usually drinks black) and I (usually gets vanilla lattes and macchiatos) thought the coffee was quite good even with just a little bit of sugar, it was pretty mild.  The coffee was Equator.  

The Plow is two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, house potatoes and your choice of bacon, housemade pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage.  I chose to get the pork sausage.  I was so excited when our plates were finally in front of us.  His crab scramble was plentiful too and had a lot of fresh crab in it.  The creme fraiche was the perfect addition for the scramble.  He loved the house potatoes which was served with his meal too.  The toast it was served with was standard though.  As for my Plow: The eggs, which I chose over easy were perfectly cooked and the yolk just oozed all over once punctured.  The house potatoes were so crispy.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were fluffy, moist, and lemony; they were to die for.  The only thing that killed the breakfast was the sausage.  We were surprised that they were made into patties, and it did have some nice seasoning but they were so dry.  We had to dip the pieces into the egg yolk or pour syrup on them.  Perhaps they didn't put any fat in it and that's why it was so dry?  The dry sausage was really the only thing that killed the breakfast and prevented us from deeming Plow a 5 star breakfast.  

Okay, I think even by SF standards the dishes are a little pricey for breakfast, but they're so worth it.  I'm gonna say a little gripe though, what I don't get is that, they offer free cups of coffee (refills too) for those stuck waiting for a table outside, but will ask around patrons dining if they'd like a cup...thought it may have been free, but was surprised to see the $3.50 charge on the receipt.  Bf was more optimistic than me though (even though he paid) and said, "Well at least they kept filling me up.  Not all places give free refills."  Plow is a solid 4.5 stars.  I can't wait to come back for more lemon ricotta pancakes and house potatoes!
author: Cat C.

description: Aaaammmmaaaaziinnngg. Lemon ricotta pancakes are my jam. The biscuit was so good!! My boyfriend got the almond pancakes and he finished it in like two minutes. Everything is delicious and the waitresses are so sweet too! Would love to come here again! The only thing is that parking can't be kind of annoying and the wait is quite long. So that's why I come here around 12ish on a rainy Wednesday!
author: Ells Z.

description:
The best brunch I have EVER had.  The only downside is that there was an extremely long wait (which is to be expected on Saturdays) and all the hills, but it was totally worth it. 
My friend and I ordered and shared:
-Lemon Ricotta Pancakes- So so so so good! The texture was perfect. Fluffy on the inside, slightly crisp (for a lack of better words) on the outside, and not too sweet!
-Soft scrambled eggs- amazing flavor! It has heirloom tomatos, goat cheese, and the eggs were so fluffy and soft.  The toast on the side was a nice touch and the crispy potatoes are perfect and a must have at Plow. 
-Lemonade-nothing special.  It was on the more tart side.

Overall I would definitely recommend this place to anyone visit SF.  Just avoid going in large groups on the weekend because the waiting time will take forever!  Other than that, I can't wait to go back!
author: Grace L.

description: My husband and I visited this place in the middle of the week to try something "newer" than our regular go brunch spot in SF. There's a weird cult following of this uber tiny place and in the middle of the week we waited for an hour only to be underwhelmed by a hipster breakfast place. Hipster ( definition--let's jump on the band wagon cause everyone else does it too???) Nope! Our food wasn't bad but we paid a hefty hipster price for just meh food. Do your homework, there's plenty of other breakfast establishments without the long wait, and tastier food. ( MyMy's, sweet maple, zazie's or the butler and the chef are far bettter!)
author: Amy F.

description:
Raving about the fried egg sandwich and the potatoes!

I didn't think the lemon ricotta pancakes were to-die for; might be because I'm not that head over heels for ricotta or lemon. It was fluffy and not overly sweet, which is a good thing in my book. I much prefer the banana wheat germ pancakes over at Stack's.

But the fried egg sandwich is delicious! I have never golfed down a sandwich (or even breakfast) that quickly before. The soft sweet bun added the perfect taste and texture to the savory fried egg and the aioli. I don't remember the last time I was so ecstatic eating a fried egg sandwich.

The potatoes were fantastic! Crispy and flavorful - definitely added crunch to the soft potatoes. Great service and casual ambiance. 

I came on a weekday before 9am and there was already a 15min wait! I know Plow is known for the ridiculously long wait, but hey, if you can cheat your way out of it and come here on a weekday, I highly recommend it!
author: Jamie Y.

description: The 2 stars I am giving is because the food was actually not bad potatoes were awesome, my best friend and I both ordered the breakfast sandwich which was good too. But considering I was only able to finish HALF of my food before the waitress rudely took my plate and dumped it into the bussing tub without asking, they will only recieve half a rating. And had I received a sincere apology I would have been more understanding but what did I receive instead? ATTITUDE!! So disgusted that somewhere in this neighborhood could actually hire and keep someone so rude around. Especially since they are suppose to be a classy brunch spot. Its a shame their employees are giving them a bad rep! Not sure what her name is but she was serving the outside area around noon. HORRIBLE SERVICE cost them a good rating.
author: Haley M.

description: The potatoes are so crunchy and the little pieces are the best !and the inside is almost creamy the eggs are light and fluffy and the bacon leaves you asking for one more piece
author: Gabriel R.

description: My husband and I went here for breakfast because it was rated really high! We did have to wait about an hour but it was a beautiful day so we didn't mind waiting. My husband got The Plow which included the lemon ricotta pancakes and he loved them! He also got the pork sausage patties and said the flavor was delicious. I got the breakfast sandwich which was also delicious. And of course the coffee was great!
author: Jess C.

description:
Definitely yummy but way overhyped. I went on a weekday once and thought I might be able to have a leisurely brunch given there wasn't a line outside. It was tough to enjoy the food though, since they gave me a check shortly after my food arrived and I was sandwiched in-between other solo diners on the limited counter space.

I understand that they're extremely in-demand and their food definitely is fresh, but I don't think it's worth hurrying through your meal to eat artisan eggs. If you're looking to catch up with friends you don't seem often, you may want to opt for the outside tables (where you're a bit more out of reach) or go somewhere with more space.
author: Emily H.

description: Super long wait but worth it for an awesome breakfast beer and all. Ordered the plow and plowed through it.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Biscuits: MUST TRY. It is $4.50, but the size of my hand! It comes with a side of honey butter that compliments the biscuits wonderfully! I'm going to be dreaming about these biscuits haha.

The plow: came with choice of meat, 2 eggs, potatoes, and pancakes. The lemon ricotta pancakes were yummy, very subtle lemon flavor which I liked, anything more would have been too overpowering.

The restaurant: small with outdoor seating. Very cute place. Portion sizes are just the right amount.
author: Melissa O.

description:
This is my second favorite breakfast spot in the city or is it first!? I can't make my mind. (the other one being the mission beach cafe )
I only go here during the week so I don't wait in their insanely long lines.

Their biscuit is the best biscuit!! Too bad I haven't had it in a while since they only serve it on the weekends. The bacon also is very impressive. 
Everything on the menu is good. You won't be disappointed with the food. 5 stars for sure!
author: Tumay A.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for the longest time. Decided to wake up early on a Saturday for breakfast at the Plow. My bf and I hoped that there wouldn't be as long of a wait in the morning as there would be during brunch, but we thought wrong.. Arrived there at around 9am and there was still a 45min- 1 hr wait.

I ordered the Plow (two eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, bacon or sausage, and crispy potatoes) and he ordered the Ham Benedict with potatoes. We both thought the food was good but it wasn't as AMAZING as we thought it would be. The pancakes didn't have much flavor and I've had better potatoes.
author: Jamie T.

description:
Amazingly popular place. Even on a Tuesday morning,t his place was packed. Had the plow with sausage and lemon ricotta pancakes. Literally everything was delicious. 

The sausage which I heard is made in house was hearty and salted perfectly.

The potatoes were made just how I like them: with a lot of crunch yet soft on the inside. Like a french fry but round. They really do a great job with the potatoes here.

The Lemon Ricotta Pancakes were a surprise. Not as good as they were hyped up by my friends but they were still rich, creamy and lemony.

Service was slow but they recognized it and gave us a lemon scone.
author: Adam Y.

description:
Come here in the morning if you want a short wait! Came here at 8:15 on a Saturday morning and only had to wait 20 minutes for a table. By the time we got seated and were eating, there was a huge crowd outside waiting. 

I ordered the "Plow" while my girlfriend the fried egg sandwich. Each order came crispy potato wedges and these are to die for. Most places deliver soggy wedges by the time the plate arrives at your table but the potato at plow are crispy on every single side. Not only this, but they are seasoned well too! Most places honestly need to just add a little salt and pepper to take their food to the next level. The scrambled eggs here tie for the best eggs I've had in my life, tied with a place called Australia Milk Company in Hong Kong -- the fluffiest, lightest eggs. The pancakes that came with my order were very rich. While my girlfriend wasn't the biggest fan of the pancakes, I enjoyed them very much, so they're definitely hit or miss. The fried egg sandwich had a perfectly fried egg inside if there were such a thing. Such a simple sandwich yet so delicious.

I love this place!
author: Austin W.

description: Stopped in as a single and sat right away at the bar even though there was a huge line.  Fresh ingredients and delicious breakfast sandwich.  Everything I saw coming off the grill looked amazing.
author: Dave L.

description:
Oh so yummy. I don't usually eat pancakes, but when I want some, I go here. They make bomb lemon ricotta pancakes. I MEAN BOMB. and those crispy potatoes?! FANTASTIC. Great, welcoming vibes, great smells, awesome brunch spot.

Downside? The wait. To get a taste, I waited in line for 1 hour and 25 minutes for my first try. The second time around, I waited 45 minutes. So if you're starving and need to be seated immediately, don't come here. You'll be raging hungry and throw a fit before a table frees up. But if you can stand to wait, I think it's worth waiting for.
author: Pamela B.

description: whenever i go to sf to visit my sister, this is one of the places i must eat for brunch. the plow with their potatoes is one of the best things i ever ate. i love potatoes in any form but this is one of my favorite iterations. also their handmade sausage patties are yummy as well. it's worth the wait if you come at peak brunch time but if you get there when it opens, the wait isn't as bad.
author: S L.

description:
Not too long ago, I wrote about how Mission Beach Cafe is one of my favorite brunch spots in the city.  While that hasn't really changed since then, they're going to have to make some room at the top of my brunch list for Plow.  MBC is still great and all, but it's kinda like when a kid gets a little brother or sister - still loved, just that there's someone else now to share the spotlight with.

After my friend's brother raved about the food at Plow, my friend and I decided to come by on a Saturday morning to check them out.  He had warned us that there there was usually a long wait on weekends, so we were fully prepared with the possibility of not getting seated for a while.  However, when we put our names down, we were pleasantly surprised that was only going to take about 20 minutes to get a table.  Sweet!

Although there were several dishes on their menu that I wanted to try (particularly "The Plow"), I ordered the Duck Hash with Poached Eggs so that I could compare it to the one I had at MBC.  Now unfortunately, I forgot to take a picture of my dish, but trust me when I say it looked so good when it was brought out.  And like the one I had at MBC, this one tasted just as good as it looked.  The hash had a lot of duck flavor, but not to the point where it was overpowering everything else on the plate.  It was especially impressive given that there wasn't a ton of duck meat (there was still enough to keep me happy though).  And what can I say about poached eggs?  Aren't they always good, especially when they're runny?  Yum.

While I'm reluctant to say that the food at Plow is better than MBC (or vice versa, for that matter), they definitely win out in one important category - parking.  It was such a breeze getting a space.  Even though the drive here was a little longer, being able to drive up and park within a block without circling made it well worth it.  For that reason, I'd be slightly more inclined to come back to Plow than MBC, but I'm still going to show equal love to two of my favorites.
author: Mike L.

description:
Two words. Plow. Potatoes. I would come back here and just get an order of them! Being a "potato connoisseur" that was by far my favorite part of the meal. However, I did order the breakfast sandwich with no additions (bacon or avocado) and that was pretty amazing too.  The aioli is a nice touch that I wasn't expecting, but really enjoyed!

I came here on a Tuesday morning at 9:00am and the wait was 30 mins if you wanted to sit inside and they sat you immediately if you wanted outside. We chose outside so we wouldn't have to wait. They give you warm blankets which is a nice touch! I heard the wait is crazy on the weekends so try to come during the week if possible!
author: Alexandra E.

description: Got here around noon and the wait wasn't too bad, maybe a 20-25 min wait for brunch. Ordered the plow which was really good! However I found a hair in my food which I wasn't too concerned about but the staff kindly insisted the food was on the house! Really great staff, these things happen!
author: Rj L.

description:
I really wish this would have been a different, better experience for me because there are so many good reviews on here, but it was a very unpleasant experience.

First off, tip for everyone considering Plow, the wait is unreal.  We went there on New Year's Eve for breakfast and the wait was over an hour and a half.  I was starving and freezing by the time we got seated - outside.  Seriously, it was no higher than maybe 50-55 degrees and we were sitting outside.  Not pleasant.  I would advise them to stop seating people outside and just do indoor seating, but there is a very small dining room so that would not work.  It was not pleasant.  The seats were cold and not comfortable.  Plus, the seat we ended up sitting in was vacant for 20-30 minutes before we finally got seated.  What were they waiting for?  

For breakfast, I ordered the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes.  They were bland and overly sweet all at the same time.  I know that Plow focuses on natural ingredients, but the lemon tasted very artificial.  I know it wasn't, but it tasted that way.  I found the pancake consistency to be very heavy and dense.  I couldn't finish the 2nd of 3 pancakes, although this was mostly due to taste.

The straw that broke the camel's back is that our bill was $40 - for breakfast.  When you're not ordering meat, you shouldn't expect to pay that much for breakfast.  I was not impressed at all.  Perhaps I caught them on a bad day, when it was really busy, and the kitchen was rushing to get food out, but this was not the experience I heard all my fellow yelpers raving about.  I feel like I got cheated.  

My advice is that if the line looks long - go somewhere else.  If you're lucky enough to get there with a minimal wait, then maybe it's worth another try.
author: Jeff L.

description: I don't know what was worse - the wait or the unapologetic apathy of the staff. After waiting more than 3 hours (yes really) we were told they didn't know how much longer it would be and we needed to wait and see who else was called. The problem is you can put your name in at anytime and show back up, bumped to the first in line, resulting in upwards of 20 parties doing just that in addition to those waiting. The hipster attitude of those working only exacerbated the inefficient process and unprofessional experience. Needless to say, we won't be back.
author: Meagan W.

description:
I've been working this area for over 11 years.  I make regular stops at Farley's, Ganims, and New Potrero Market during my working hours.  Without going into great detail, Ive done things in this area that helped the community, before this restaurant even existed.  I came here with my family, including two kids, and was given a wait time of 20 minutes.  I peeked at the sheet, because I don't want to get bamboozled, and noticed there were 4 parties ahead of me with 2 people for each party.  As I was waiting outside, I overhear the employee taking names talking on her phone telling the other person on the line to come to the restaurant now.  Now 20 minutes has gone by and all the parties above listed get their tables.  Out of nowhere, a group of 5 show up and magically get seated before us.  Keep in mind they did not have two hungry kids with them.  I kindly ask the employee how much longer is the wait and she responds by telling me it'll be another 5-10 minutes.  I questioned her about the party of 5, who weren't on the sign in sheet when I initially signed in, and her "defensive response" was how do you know they weren't ahead of you?  I told her I saw the list as she penciled my name on it and it did not reflect that party of 5.  She asked how long was I waiting and I told her over 25 minutes.  She responded to me and said, "This is a restaurant, what do you expect?"  
In my opinion, this is clearly an inexperienced person who needs to learn how to talk to customers.  Not once did I yell or make a scene in front of other customers.  I kindly told her we are leaving.  She responded by telling me if we wait she is saving the front table near the door for us.  I told her that this is the second time this happened to us where she seated people ahead of us and I didn't appreciate that.  I asked for her name and the manager.  She identified herself as Jess and she was the manager.  I again told her I'm not angry, but just disappointed on how we were handled and treated by her.  I may look like I'm 20, but I'm really in my late 30s, definitely older and more experienced with customers than her, based on our incident.  Don't get me wrong, the food here delivers, but they really need customer service training.  After reading a few reviews, it seems like this happened more than once.  Is it a profiling or racial issue?  Based on my situation, I really felt like it was because of the vibe and defensive reaction I got from the manager.  I didn't want to write this, but I felt like I had to because it was really eating me up all day.  Since I support the area, I immediately made my way to Just for you and was served immediately by their staff.
author: Marvin C.

description: Great food, maybe the best hollandaise I've ever had. We waited, but not as long as our hostess said we would, thanks to some outdoor seating. The food is locally sourced, farm to table and this is definitely reflected in the price, so be prepared.
author: Taryn D.

description:
I probably love the lemon ricotta pancakes here more than I love Nicole Kidman. Or at least, it's a close call.

Came here on a date, not with Nicole Kidman, but a blond nonetheless. 

This is one of my favorite breakfast joints. I love this place so much that my co-workers buy me gift certificates to PLOW because they know I'll make good use out of it. One year I received $100 bucks in gift cards. Enough for 4 meals, I joked.

I love their ricotta pancakes, their crab scramble, their potatoes, their sausage...basically I love everything on the menu.

So my date kept saying over and over like a broken record, "I work for Twitter." As if I'm supposed to be impressed by this? 

"How do you like the food though?" I asked.

"You know the best thing about Twitter..." and that's when I tuned out. 

I started thinking about Plow's specials, that day they had a special muffin and sausage something. I thought about the times when I had their almond pancakes, and thought, wow, these are really good too.

Thank goodness for those ricotta pancakes, which gave me a feeling of serenity and happiness, which is more than I can say about the date.

"Did you hear what I was saying?"

"Yes," I said. "Twitter."

"Yes, how'd you know?"

"Just a lucky guess," I said, wishing that I was like that Twitter bird, and could fly right out the window. Or jump. Jumping is an option too I thought....
author: Jack R.

description:
"The Plow", need I say more? 

I have tried to dine here for brunch 3 times in the past and have always given up because the wait is 2 hours+. One Tuesday morning, I finally scored a table outside with no wait. As many Yelpers advised, it is better to dine here on a week day versus a weekend. Right away I already knew what I wanted. 

I had the plow with scrambled eggs, chicken apple sausages, lemon ricotta pancakes and their house potatoes. It was delicious for such a "standard traditional breakfast". I did pass on the house made pork sausages because a lot of reviewers said that they were dried. The potatoes were seasoned with rosemary and had a nice crisp. I really liked the lemon pancakes because they weren't too sour or doughy. 

I would come back but hopefully there won't be such a long wait.
author: Laura T.

description:
Portero Hill is a bit out of the way, but I was willing to make those transfers to grab brunch at Plow. The lemon ricotta pancakes are worth the visit. In LA, there's BLD for lemon ricotta pancakes, but I wanted to try Plow's first because they looked so delectable.  The small portions for the pancakes allow you to enjoy them with greater appreciation. Great consistency with the batter and not too thick, and the combination of zesty lemon and creamy ricotta works well! I prefer these compact, slightly fluffier pancakes over thin, wide ones. Really, the syrup is not necessary. People who complain that the pancakes are not sweet enough are crazy. Honestly, you're asking for diabetes if you're wanting something outrageously sweet. 

My brother enjoyed Plow's take on the traditional herb roasted potatoes by lightly frying them but didn't seem impressed by the sunny-side up eggs. He, too, found the lemon ricotta pancakes to be delightful. However, the french toast--as much as it was fluffy and not heavy--it wasn't my favorite. Nothing compares to the brioche french toast I had at M.Henry in Chicago. Regardless, Plow offers a solid plate of french toast! Now, the coffee here is a whole other matter. I downed 3 cups because I hadn't had my coffee in the morning, but I suggest you skip it if possible...
author: Christine K.

description:
I just had THE BEST BRUNCH OF MY LIFE at Plow.

Despite the yelp reviews, I wasn't expecting anything extraordinary. Afterall, my dish, the Plow, didn't sound like anything special: potatoes, sausage, eggs, and a pancake. Boy was I wrong!

While all the elements were simple and recognizable, each one was perfectly executed. The potatoes were the best I've ever had. The eggs were unbelievably fluffy. Even the sausage, which I don't usually care for, was delicious. And the lemon ricotta pancake brought it all home with a nice sweetness to round out the rest of the savory meal.

The wait wasn't too bad for two people, either: 30 minutes. Bring a book and park yourself under the many shady trees to while away the time before your name is called.

The only disadvantage of this place is that it's a bit out of the way...a 38 minute walk from my place, and 30 with public transport (who else hates SF public transport?!), but it's completely worth it.
author: Neha S.

description: My first time I went here with my dad and sister. I ordered the plow with Almond flour pancakes, bacon, poached eggs with mixed greens. Delicious soft pancakes, bacon and creamy eggs! Healthy and Hearty brunch!
author: Vanessa R.

description:
"Have you gone to many places in SF for brunch?"

"Nah, I've only been to once place. Can't remember the name. It was pretty amazing, though."

"Oh cool. Well, I have an idea, let's go to Plow for brunch. Good reviews."

"That's the place I've been!"

GOD. DAMMIT.

Whatever.

Minus one star because that chia pudding was weird but also the wait sucks. 

Four solid stars, however, for having pretty great food. The scramble was fantastic. Toast. Eggs. Mushrooms. Spinach. Fruit. Amazing.

You should go if you have the patience to wait a fucking long time.
author: Jaime L.

description: SO DELICIOUS. We arrived at 10:30 on a Thursday and this tiny place was packed. The hostess said 30 minutes so we walked around the block and within 15 minutes we were seated. I ordered the cold smoked salmon and everything on the plate was fresh and delectable. Definitely on the pricy side but worth every dollar. Will visit again if in the area.
author: Samantha K.

description:
Their crispy potatoes and lemon ricotta pancakes are a real treat. A friend and I ate outside with our dogs and the service was great. 
You can taste the freshness and simplicity in their food. 
Highly recommend. My only complaint.... I wish they had a better coffee-- I prefer coffee on the smoother side; plow's is on the bitter side.
author: Maria G.

description: Worth the wait. Lemon ricotta pancakes were amazing. Only reason only 4 stars is because the kid menu needs to amp it up.
author: Alana S.

description: Oooh Plow, I wanted to love you, but meh. I arrived at 930 & was told that my wait would be about an hr and 15mins, which was fine; I've read the yelp reviews. So, I grabbed starbucks and went to office depot, just to return right on time. I ordered The Plow with almond flour pancakes instead of the lemon, because I don't like anything with lemon. I ate everything but the pancakes because they tasted just like almond flour, it was horrible!! Not sweet, or buttery, just flour...almond flour. My boyfriend, who eats EVERYTHING couldn't even contain his facial expression when he tried it. It was just bad, and to think that I stalked this place from a Postmates AD and flew down there just for the disappointment.
author: Kae W.

description: Omg so good every time!!! Recently tried the biscuit, it was amazing! Highly suggest ordering it. They also make their own sausage patties that are really good!
author: Autumn M.

description:
Pros:
- crispy potatoes (everything you could ever want in fried potato chunks)
- lemon ricotta pancakes ( crispy on the outside, soft and creamy on the inside, great balance of lemon and cheese)
- waitress was super nice and gave us blankets because it was chilly on the patio

Cons:
- 1 hour wait at 1:20pm on a Sunday afternoon

Bottom line: must go at least once! If it weren't for the long wait, I would definitely go more often.
author: Jiann M.

description: We had to wait close to two hours for brunch only because we were party of 4. Space is limited and if you are party of two or single party then seats more available. We didn't mind the wait since there are plenty of cafes and shops to fill your time while waiting.  It was well worth the wait. The PLOW was great if you want to taste a bit of everything - got to try their lemon ricotta pancakes and crunchy potatoes from my husbands plate! Got a bite of  the fried egg sandwich from my niece. A taste of the salmon Benedict from her friends plate and then enjoyed my scrumptious Farro Salad. Atmosphere is great along with the staff. 4 stars only because of the limited space.
author: June R.

description:
Arriving on a sunny, windy weekday afternoon, we entered Plow at around 1pm. The restaurant had quite a number of people, so we were kicked to curb, to wait in the wind. By kicking us to the curb, I mean they told us to step outside to wait till we're seated because they don't want it cramping up by the entrance. I like this idea because it makes the dining experience more enjoyable. They told us to wait about 5 mins, but we were seated within 3 mins. 

Located on the corner of Mississippi St and Texas St, this place can easily be missed..only because it's located in a residential area. They do have a sign sticking out that says "The Plow" though. Parking wasn't bad for my friend and I because we found one quick, right across the street. 

Seated in the back, service was still prompt and good because they would come check on us quite often. The food came out fairly quick in about 10 minutes. For my drink, I ordered the housemade strawberry lemonade ($3.75) [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/plow-san-francisco?select=idHQVocGRxfnUjULoUkgDA#N3EwXeV_dXhdgR037ddEUw]. The drink looks adorable and instagram-worthy with its cute striped straw and lemon on the side, but don't let that fool you! I like the looks of it, but the straw is made of paper which can make it soggy. That's the only thing that irks me because the longer it sits in the lemonade, the faster it becomes soggy and the harder it becomes to drink. 

For my dish, I ordered The Plow ($16) [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/plow-san-francisco?select=idHQVocGRxfnUjULoUkgDA#NYJXSTwF-Ugv0vFpKULyvQ] and a side of Nueske Bacon ($5.50) [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/plow-san-francisco?select=idHQVocGRxfnUjULoUkgDA#fzy-q83TFoTe12n157Wu4Q]. The Plow was delicious! It consisted of  (2) small Lemon Ricotta Pancakes, Crispy Potatoes, Eggs, and House made pork sausage patties. I ordered this becuase it basically consisted of everything from the highlights on the Yelp page! I highly recommend ordering this for your first time because you get a taste of everything. Going from the lemon ricotta pancakes to crispy potatoes, to eggs and the house made pork sausage patties, everything just tasted so different from each other and unique! It changes your taste buds! 

The side of nueske bacon was a recommended dish in the highlights and as a fan of bacon, I just haaad to order it! I don't think it was all that special, but it was decently good. It was also pretty oily. 

If you can't finish your meal and plan to take the leftovers home, skip the crispy potatoes...it won't taste crispy anymore, haha. 

Overall, I enjoyed my experience and would definitely come back again..on a weekday! ;)
author: Mandy G.

description:
Awesome brunch spot out in Potrero but beware seating is limited and the lines are long.
Get there early (before 7:40) if you want to avoid the wait.

Great variety of pancakes and unique home fries. The more routine items are going to give you sticker shock.

But what you are primarily paying for is that Potrero Hill experience - from the interior to the style of the staff, you'll feel like you've just had that mason jar enhanced meal at an environmentally friendly, kid friendly Pottery Barn.

So probably a place to go when you feel like splurging or taking your out of town friends or mother-in-law to a nice brunch.
author: Yohdaddy M.

description: The mimosas are $11 or more (!!) and are small. The potatoes are very good (though plain) and everything else tastes just like any other breakfast place but at a 50% price hike. The wait to be seated, even for just two people at 1:50 P.M., is 75 minutes. Both times I have gone, the host took a mimosa order ($23), never put the order in, then went off duty and left. Also, be prepared to see large groups that arrive after you walking home long before you get seated. Not much else to write about.
author: Andrew F.

description:
Belly up to the bar!
It's so much fun to watch the throwing of potatoes in the air.. Especially when I know they're for me.  But what really gets you is that it's so busy that you don't know it's for you, UNLESS you watch the cooktop! Yes, this is the little game I play while I pretend to read my newspaper at the super tiny counter waiting for my food. The chefs are cuties and interactive oh and the coffee is BOSS!
author: Milan F.

description: The food is delicious and definitely worth the long wait! Definitely get the ricotta pancakes, they are fluffy and heavenly.
author: Olivia R.

description:
Great breakfast spot! I recommend getting there early, the wait can be up an hour or two!

The lemon ricotta pancakes were delicious! What I noticed is everyone got the plow. It had potatoes, eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes and a meat selection. My fiancé got that and he liked it.

Enjoy!
author: Emily K.

description:
Plow is the epitome of what it means to be a brunch spot. I wish I could stop coming here but their food really gets me every time. 

I usually opt for THE PLOW when I come here. The LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES are the perfect blend of zest and depth for a pancake, this is definitely a must try! The NUESKE'S BACON and HOUSE MADE PORK SAUSAGE are both delicious, but I wouldn't recommend the Chicken-Apple. The potatoes are always fresh and crispy and eggs how you like 'em. The FRENCH TOAST w/ bananas is a great way to end brunch on a sweet note. Coffee, grapefruit juice, and the ginger beer are all great pairs with their dishes.

Things to keep in mind: The wait is going to be long. I was lucky to come by here when the wait was 15-20 minutes, but I know the wait can be up to 1.5-2 hours depending on the day and time you come by. You won't miss this place because of the large crowd standing at the corner of the block waiting to eat at this place.

Service is always great and friendly. Food doesn't take long despite the popularity and seating is both indoor and outdoor.
author: Veronica L.

description: it was ok. I don't think id wait that long again..but, hey, it's the flavor of the month. pancakes are a bit small for the price. Kiddy plate anyone? Coulda been bigger imho...pricey. 45 bux for two? hm...seems like a lot for breakfast...
author: David W.

description:
Generous 2.3 for brunch very recently. Bookmarked for 3 years----crestfallen experience on a warm afternoon.

I was stuck on the Bridge; plenty of empty tables available outside. My friend was forced to stand and wait until I arrived in order to sit down somewhere. Joking me?? I understand upholding that when there are not a minimum of 6 2-tops open! Off-putting

The plow breakfast ordered was such a letdown, upon immediate glance of small plate. Crispy potatoes tasted stale to both of us, and instead of properly cut small chunks, we got little bits and bobbles of leftover pan. Couldn't even spear them with the tines of a fork. Resigned, we just wasted an already small plate of food for $16.

Lemon ricotta pancakes (2 silver dollar-sized) did not have that refined, think crispy buttery edge with super fluffy, melt-in-mouth feel. Lemon was very nice on the tongue, but it certainly was the only positive attribute to them.

Nueske bacon fine.

After within the month, going to many brunch places, I find the food way overrated. Way.
author: Jana C.

description:
Exploding Egg Sandwich = fantastic!

Enough has been written about the sandwich that I won't waste my breath here. But.... 

...This place has cracked the code on the country potatoes that accompanies most breakfast entrees. 99% of the time, these potatoes are just fillers to make sure you hit that 'brunch food coma' no matter the size of your main entree. The potatoes here are totally worth eating. I ate every molecule while only taking a couple of bites at other joints before giving up. Lots of crunchy edges here and minimal soft starchy centers. It both satisfies the country potatoes part of the brain as well as the FRENCH FRY loving part of the brain. These puppies must be deep fried here (and I love it). Just like the egg sandwich, so simple, yet no one else pulls it off like Plow. The abundance of rosemary is the icing on the cake. This herb is so cheap, wonder why more people don't use it liberally. It grows like weeds 365 days in most CA backyards.

Waitress #1 warned me the egg sandwich might explode. I bit in to it, and indeed it popped, covering my hand and watch with egg yoke porn. It's a miracle the kid at the next table didn't lose an eye. Waitress #2 saw this, went inside, wet a towel (with warm water) and brought it to my table. Excellent service! Even better, I went for lunch on a weekday and had zero wait. For the above reasons, I have to give this place 5 stars. 

TIP, use your knife and cut the egg sandwich in half to 'pre-pop' the yoke.
author: John H.

description:
It's bizarre to see people line up for this place at 8am.   On the home page for Plow on Yelp, you'll see people eating with umbrellas.  Contrary to the caption, it's good, but not THAT good.    They do in fact offer a very good brunch and perhaps because of the very limited options in Potrero, locals go bonkers for this place but in reality, it's just on par with Universal Cafe, Mission Beach Cafe, and so many others in the Mission.

OK, all that said, try it.  It's very good, solid 4 stars.
author: Saminda W.

description: The potatoes here are just so perfectly crispy, it's really amazing. Sooooo rosemary! The lemon ricotta pancakes are also very unique, and the husband enjoyed his fried egg sandwich. Delicious brunch everyday! We'll definitely be back!
author: Archana P.

description:
I went here with a party of 3. The wait wasn't too bad since we arrived around 1pm. My friends raved about this place so I was pretty excited to finally try it. We ordered the proscuitto toast and the plow (one with bacon and one with chicken sausage). My order was the plow with bacon and it very tasty! The pancakes were light and fluffy, the potatoes were crispy on the outside and seasoned well. If I were to rate this restaurant on food alone, I would have definitely given this place a 5/5! It was actually the service that was less that subpar. ):

I don't know if I went on a bad day but the service my party and I received was one of the worst and I wish I had spoken to the manager or someone about it. 
1) The server accidentally gave us the wrong food (two plows both with chicken sausage, no mention of a third plate coming either); it was supposed to be for the party of two in the adjacent table. No big deal, mix-ups happen. We gave them their food and they flagged down the server to let them know they had made a mistake. The server looked at us angrily like we had made the mistake and then rushed to the back. 
2) The server came back to let us know that we had ordered the same thing. I asked to confirm if mine had bacon, because that's what I had ordered. She rudely replied "your food is coming soon" and left without confirming what I had ordered. She could have just said yes and left it at that??? I didn't ask how long my food was taking, nor did I care about how long it would take... 
3) During the meal, our server did not check on us (or anyone for that matter) to see if we needed water or anything, not even once throughout the meal. 
4) When our server came by the tables I asked her "excuse me, may I please have the check?" She ignored me and continued to scan the tables in the area without approaching any of them. I thought that she didn't hear me so I repeated myself several more times until I got her attention. She gave me a dirty look and went to get our bill.
5) When my friend got her card back with the receipt, the server threw the pen next to her instead of handing it to her along with her card. 

You could've just said you didn't want to be tipped instead of treating us poorly? But you do you... We tipped her out of courtesy but it felt wrong because the service was nonexistent /: 

The guy giving us condiments was totally coo tho. 

Anyways, I would go back cause the food was bomb but definitely not anytime soon because of this experience lol maybe next time will be better??? Who knows......
author: Rochelle M.

description:
I came here expecting really great foods...and was a bit disappointed.  I mean, not enough to tell people NOT to come, but enough to not put it higher on my recommendations for good brunch in SF.

I came here with my sister on a Friday morning. Knowing there was going to be a line, we budgeted a 30 minute wait. We seemed to have come in right before they opened the outside dining, which was cool because that shortened the wait significantly. Then again, they still staggered us (which, I assume is to not over burden the kitchen). And plus...the outside seating is on an incline. Made for some awkward sitting. 

We had the french toast and the Plow...which was good, but again not amazing. Plow included the lemon ricotta pancakes people rave about. The pancakes people rave about is just ok. Seriously. If I didn't know it was ricotta in there, I'd think it was under cooked.  I still have my doubts on the full-cooked-ness of these pancakes. Outside was crispy, inside was goopy. 

The rest of the food was pretty solid. I like that they don't shy away from making the scrambled eggs JUST done. Like seriously, a second less and it'd be runny. But I kind of like my eggs like that. 

The pancakes dinged it a bit for me...and also the service. Oh, the people were relatively nice and all. But my coffee (which I legitimately LIVE for) I had to flag down folks many times for refills (I nearly told them to leave the carafe. And had pre-warned them of my caffeine needs). We were ready to order right when we sat down, and they acknowledged this and still waited quite some time to come back.  

I'm usually one that's willing to wait for good food, but I don't think I'd crave Plow enough to wait in a line longer than 30 minutes. =/
author: Lily W.

description:
Well I eventually plowed my way into Plow.  

It took 1.5 hrs of waiting but we did get in.  I give this place 3.5 Stars in reality.  This is a good place to come if you live in the area but I can honestly say I would NEVER wait this long to eat here again.  The staff is friendly, efficient and the food is of the highest quality.  It is flavorful but in some instances too much so. (The pork sausage was so spicy that it was barely edible and the bacon's smokey flavor was not my favorite.)  I don't down grade them for this as they are preferences but I caution folks to really ask questions of the server before ordering.  I promise you the taste is not the same as regular bacon and regular sausages you find on other restaurant menus. (To be fair, one of my friends LOVES that spicy sausage so it really is a matter of personal taste.)

In my opinion Plow is a good restaurant with an eclectic menu.  They do their best to keep up with the demand but just like many other restaurants, it is tough to do so.  Waiting an hour and a half for Saturday breakfast is not for me.  The food was good but not good enough for me to deal with that wait time again.  They are a victim of their own success...lol  Its worth a try for those that haven't been but my next purchase from them will be take out :)
author: Brian S.

description:
Thought there would be a long line, but we were seated almost immediately, though we did come on a Friday (near closing time). 

This is hands down one of the best brunch places I've encountered in San Francisco. Located in a beautiful neighborhood with quaint little cafes and shops across the street, Plow fulfills the definition of what a true brunch experience in the city should be, fresh and local. 

I highly recommend "The Plow" with homemade pork sausage. You get a bit of everything, including two of their famous, melt in tongue, lemon ricotta pancakes. 

Don't forget to drizzle your sausage with some of their Lucky Dog hot sauce. 

So amazing!
author: Claudia N.

description: Plow had a great aesthetic. It was the kind of place that secretly made you happy to just sit inside because everything was adorable and hip. The cliental all had a very hipster vibe. My friend and I split the prosciutto gruyère toast and the mascarpone French toast and wow we left the place stuffed. Both dishes were made on a gigantic piece of acme toast, which to be honest I wasn't a big fan of, but my friend was overjoyed so it's probably a matter of preference. We substituted potatoes for a side salad and it was quite a refreshing and crisp salad, a very good call on our part. The prosciutto on the toast was incredibly fresh and the chili garlic garnish on the egg really brought the whole taste together. The French toast on the other hand, I wasn't blown away by. Again it might be a matter of preference but I was a bit bothered by the thickness of the toast because the inside remained soggy from the batter. But what kept me the most satisfied through the brunch was the drip coffee, they serve equator drip coffee so it's not your classic crappy drip. Nothing says, upper level brunch place like quality drip coffee. Overall, I would definitely come back, but I'd most likely order something else.
author: Simona K.

description:
SOLID! We arrived on a Friday morning around 9:30 am and had a 15 minute wait. We sat outside, and they had blankets since it was a little chilly.
Most of us had the fried egg sandwich, one had the plow and one had a crab omelette.
The fried egg sandwich was amazing. The bacon in it was really tasty and high quality. Most dishes come with the best potatoes one could wish for. 
We also shared a lemon ricotta pancake for the table. 
Service was friendly and attentive.
author: Luciana B.

description:
The wait is wayyyy too long here but if you come before 9am, it's not so bad. 

The egg sandwich is delicious but I wish it had a different bun! The bread is a let down. If you're super hungry or just like diversity, get "the plow". It's a bit of everything -- 2 eggs, 2 pieces of bacon or sausage, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, and the smashed potatoes. While the pancakes are so soft and fluffy with just the right amount of lemon flavor, the real winner is the potatoes. Imagine potatoes that are smashed and deep fried so that it's extra crispy!
author: Xinxin W.

description:
Yum! Order the PLOW. Comes with your choice of meat, eggs, potatoes, and their famous lemon ricotta pancakes! 

The only downside for this place is the wait! There's always a wait, no matter what time of day. I've waited an hour at most, but today we got seated within 10 minutes. 

Regardless of the wait time, were always down for some plow.
author: L F.

description:
Since I read such amazing reviews about the lemon ricotta pancakes and house made pork sausage and wanted to try both, I ordered the plow (2 eggs, house made pork sausage, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes).   Plow also offers side orders of both items.  I really enjoyed everything, especially the pancakes and potatoes.  Unless you dislike lemon (the pancakes really are pretty lemony), I highly recommend you at least order the side dish for your table to share.  

Meanwhile, one of my friends ordered the french toast, which was good, but in my opinion not as good as the pancakes.  Another of my friends ordered the chia seed pudding which though I did not personally try, had a gelatinous texture (due to the chia seeds) that she did not enjoy.
author: Cici A.

description:
This is as good as it gets for me. From the Equator coffee, to the ridiculously crispy/soft potatoes, to their homemade sausage and fantastic buttermilk biscuits, Plow consistently outperforms its competitors when it comes to SF brunch fare. They do the basics well, which is surprisingly hard to come by these days, and have creative/interesting twists on them (the prosciutto/melon salad is one of the best things I've ever eaten). I would put this up against any of the Eater SF contenders. To top it off, Plow's friendly wait-staff make you feel like you're eating at your best friend's house (the one who effortlessly is cool/casual and who may have an appreciation for Toms and all things succulents). 

If waiting in line for a table bothers you, walk around the quaintness that is Potrero Hill (shout out to Farley's and Gaelan's Boutique). Or try it out by yourself and sit at their chef's counter and have a front row seat to all the action. Some things are worth waiting for and this is certainly one of them. 

Thank you Plow for being my happy place!
author: Sheila E.

description:
I think this place's food caters to a certain type of patron, and I was not of that sort (i.e. someone who likes heavy/greasy food). 

I ordered the plow and the stars of that dish were the ricotta pancakes and the pork sausage. Both were especially yummy and the kind of stuff I'd drool over. The meh parts of the dish were the potatoes and the eggs (scrambled). The potatoes were essentially deep fried and were just too heavy for my taste. The eggs were basically thrown onto a skillet with nothing else (very bland). 

Ultimately, given that half the dish was great & half forgettable and that it was a 1.5 hour wait knocks this place down to a three.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
Perfect suburban-lookin' breakfast joint in the city!

My friends and I were told that our wait would be about 30-45 minutes. We were a little hesitant to stay, but we decided to stick to our itinerary. We could tell the workers were trying to be really accommodating to us throughout our entire wait . We appreciated their hard work in wanting to find us a table as quickly as possible!

Besides the great service, the food here is enough to make you want to check this place out. 

Everything tasted great, but one thing I want to come back here for is the lemon ricotta pancakes! The ricotta cheese doesn't have a strong smell or taste to it and neither does the lemon. The taste of both flavors is subtle and each bite is full and hearty, but not too heavy.

The place is small, so try to avoid coming in big groups (anything more than 4).
author: Jane S.

description: Both times I've been to plow I have really enjoyed my brunch. Reason for the 4 stars is because if you don't get in line by 7:50 am you will most likely have to wait two hours for brunch. I had the soft scrambled eggs which were very yummy. We ordered the chia seed pudding for the table which I will definitely skip on my next visit.
author: Tracy S.

description: Loved this place! I came here New Years Eve for brunch with 2 month old, 2 year old, and wife! Super accommodating and the friendliest hostess Jess, who is really kid friendly even when it was really busy and crammed! The food was delicious! Loved the lemon ricotta pancakes were a first for me and were bomb.com and eggs and potatoes were on point! Homemade sausage patties were delicious when drizzled with yolk from my sunny side eggs. My two year old enjoyed almost all of our Nueske's bacon...I was a little mad at this but what can you do. I am coming back for more and to try it all.
author: David N.

description: Another over-rated, trendy restaurant. Potatoes were the best part of my meal. Hubby and I found the lemon ricotta pancakes to be whatever and scrambled eggs were standard. I wouldn't wait for a table here, but the service is great and outside seating with the heavy blankets is perfectly ok....but we probably wouldn't be back.
author: Hanster P.

description: The lemon ricotta pancakes here are RIDICULOUS. That said, don't expect to a) find a parking spot close by, or b) wait any less than an hour, even with reservations. Cute bookstore down the road if you need to kill some time. Don't come hungry because the smells from the kitchen will drive you insane. Service is fine; they're very busy and don't have time to really chat with you. Sit outside if you can!
author: Katie G.

description: Popped my Plow cherry and it was everything I wanted it to be and more! I went with the pork chop and 2 eggs (others have told me that I shoulda tried "The Plow", but hey, we can't bat 1.000). I was not disappointed. The pork chop was seasoned and flavored quite nicely with some sort of soy sauce glaze? Their potatoes are golden and crispy (just how daddy likes em). I also got to try their pumpkin pancakes and it was fire flame emoji. I'd be lying if I said it wasn't one of my favorite brunch spots in SF. I'll be back, Plow.
author: Bradley C.

description: Meh... it was good breakfast food for the price. Coffee tasted odd. Not too memorable.
author: Zainab J.

description:
Came here on a weekend around 11AM and left because the wait was too long.  Finally got to try this place on a monday morning with a part of four.  We waited about 30 min, which isn't bad compared to the waits on the weekends.  

It wasn't too hard to find parking other than how some streets had street cleaning.  The service was good with polite staff.  The music was nice and suits the environment.  We ordered The Plow, Fried egg sandwich, Cold-smoked salmon toast, and two egged breakfast.  It was A LOT for four people.  

Overall, I'm impressed with the Cold-smoked salmon toast and Fried egg sandwich.  The potatoes were AMAZING.  Totally worth the meal and would come back on a weekday.
author: Crystal Y.

description: For under $20, this brunch place is solid, if you're willing to wait for an hour or so.  The ricotta pancakes may get the headlines, but the crispy potatoes are the real winner.
author: Herb K.

description: Unfortunately I had a horrible experience at that delicious food place. I understand they don't take reservations and of course we were happy to wait. We were 4 latinos guys excited and hungry to eat there. We put our name in the waiting lists for 4. There were only 4 ladies waiting outside before us since was a day during the week plus we planed to be there before the crowd. The 4 ladies got sat down of course before us. Then there was more people coming and getting sitting down before us. I came in and asked and they said because they were less than 4, I understood that. Then there were groups of 3 and 4 coming and getting sitting down before us again. After more than one hour waiting and starving, I ask the hostess ( an Asian lady) what was going on, then she said that we still have to wait cuz we were 4. We told her we saw groups of 3 and 4 getting a table before us even then came way after us and all she said is that they were in the list before us! Which it was a huge lie since I put my name on the list and I saw their names scratched off and we never got called. I felt discriminated and we promised not to come back again to that place no matter how good food is there. There's tons of more good choices all over the beautiful SF. We all work for the restaurant industry and that's NOT how it works. They lost 4 immediate customers plus some more after we shared our discriminatory experience. Hope they'll change their attitude soon.
author: Uriel G.

description:
Worth the wait...egg drizzle burger thingamabob totally mind blowing! 

I have been wanting to try this place for the longest time but every time I go there is an insanely long wait! Finally I said heck with it I'm going to wait for my shot at brunch. And in the end it was all worth it. 

Heck I would even wait just to get the side of potatoes. Everything down to the little details were all delicious. They even have outdoor seat on attached to the side of the building for all the people that are waiting. The staff is extremely friendly and the food came out in great time. For those who are gluten intolerant there are a couple options for you too! This place is awesome. Yes a tiny bit pricey but totally worth it!
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
The environment, the breakfast, the potatoes!

Sunny space, friendly staff, delicious egg scramble and breakfast sandwiches. Total neighborhood gem!
author: Tj T.

description:
Plow plow plow!  Eat The Plow at Plow!

Showed up at 11:30 with Ingrid C on a Sunday for brunch... we were told the wait would be AN HOUR.  WOW.  So popular!  But since all my Yelpy friends said it was worth the wait, I was very excited that the wait was really only about 35 minutes.

Sitting at the marble? counter is an excellent experience.  The 3 guys pumping out the brunch menu for 40+ occupants really know what they're doing.  It's fascinating watch them make the eggs, fry the potatoes, cook the lemon ricotta pancakes, and dole out all the other goodies in very organized and efficient fashion.

Tasty mimosa, tasty coffee.  I have to say, the lemon ricotta pancakes really were not my favorite.  I did appreciate that they were crispy-edged pancakes and the lemony flavor was spot on.. but I didn't quite like the ricotta texture in my otherwise fluffy pancakes.  I didn't feel like the cheese added anything... but then again, I'm lactose intolerant and don't really enjoy cheese anymore...

LOVE the potatoes.  Super fried and delicious!  Seasoned perfectly.  The bacon was tasty but not memorable.  I tried Ingrid C's pork sausage and that was flavory herby goodness.

Definitely worth the wait.  There are plenty of cute shops to browse around including a bookstore about a block away.

My favorite brunch is still St. Mike's in Palo Alto, but this is pretty damn tasty if you're up in the city.

Extra bonus love to all the piggy figurines and piggy symbol as the restaurant mascot.
author: Ruth C.

description:
Oh plow how I love thee. 

Delicious coffee, delicious food, lovely staff full of life and happy, open kitchen with a staff working diligently to make fantastic food. Totally worth the wait whenever you go, little coffee shop up the street to grab some tea or coffee while you wait. 

I've been here 6-7 times and have loved everything about it every time. Perfectly cooked food, the most amazing hash browns and fantastic spicy flavorful sausage.
author: T B.

description:
I'm going to say it - and I may get some flack for it, but this is by far and away, in my opinion, the best brunch in San Francisco. Yep, I said it!

The wait: It's always long, even on a weekday which leaves me wondering - what do all these people do for a living if they can wait in line for brunch at 10am on a Tuesday?! But then I realize I'm right there with them :)

The food: Get the Plow ($16) if you've never been before. Their lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing and no matter which protein you pick it will be delicious. Recently they've started having an eggs Benedict ($17), which makes me the happiest person around! But the soft eggs scramble ($15) is always amazing!

The service: always efficient and friendly, but not too friendly where you feel like you've gained another table mate. 

The restaurant: it's decorated in such a way that I feel calm and relaxed despite the crowded small space full of hungry diners.
author: Emily S.

description: I loved this little corner cafe. The food was amazing and i will defiantly go back the next time im in San Francisco. Our server was a little...off.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Went there for b-fast on Wednesday morning like 7:30. I know this place is been very popular with locals and packed on weekends, so thought today was a perfect timing to swing by.  There's 3-4 tables were taken already at this point!
Ordered The Plow and liked Lemon ricotta pancakes:). I didn't like crispy potatoes that much because they were too crunch and crispy and had barely portion to eat.

Will come back for the full portion of pancakes again!
author: Asato T.

description:
I would actually give this place a 4 1/2 stars but unfortunately that isn't an option.  The half star ding is just for the wait time which actually isn't that big of an issue.  You can put your name down and leave and if they already called your name by the time you come back, they'll just bump you to the top of the list.  

More importantly, the grub.  For all its reviews and all the stars given, I went in with high expectations.  This can be dangerous and lead to disappointment (like when I waited in line for 2 1/2 hours to eat at mamas and the food was jut meh), but Plow came through.  It met, if not exceeded my expectations.  The plow platter and French toast were everything we hoped for and more!  It sounds corny but it's just true.  You want to eat here.
author: Courtney L.

description:
This may seem trivial to some but to me it is not.

I do not enjoy giving a negative review. In fact I have never given a negative review to anyone. I am a business owner in a highly competitive environment with a big emphasis on customer service. I know the challenges involved in dealing with the general public. It can be very demanding. 

The plow does a really good breakfast sandwich. It is pricey but I enjoy it.

Because of my busy schedule I always order to go. This morning I ordered my sandwich en route.  When I arrived at the restaurant I noticed it was not as busy as usual so I politely asked the waitress if I could eat my to-go order at the restaurant and requested a seat outside. The waitress was gracious and asked me to wait while she asked the chef if that was ok?

The Plow has an open kitchen so I was standing approximately 10 feet from the conversation the waitress was having with the chef. Based on the facial expressions and body language of the chef she seemed troubled and reluctant to permit my request. I was put off by what I was witnessing but I gave them the benefit of the doubt because I could not hear what was being said and I could easily have been reading the situation wrong. 

All seemed fine but as the waitress escorted me to a seat at the counter she said something to me that I did not hear. She placed my plate on the counter top and I asked her to repeat what she had said. 
She said "just want to let you know that we cannot do this again. This is the only time". I was very surprised and felt like I had just been reprimanded. I asked for an explanation and I was told that the to-go box cost extra!!!  "Are you kidding me!?"

I was not happy. If I had not witnessed the chefs reaction to my request I may not have been so annoyed. The waitress pleaded with me to sit down and explained that the box had been thrown away. I told her to get another box and to charge me for both. 

Why didn't the waitress inform me that it was not a problem to seat me but there would be an extra charge for the paper box? Don't take me to a seat ignoring my request for outside seating and warn me as if I had done something wrong.  

My thoughts are the manager or chef needs to pay attention to the fact that she is being observed and she should show a little appreciation for her customers. Maybe she is over worked or maybe she just doesn't care? Maybe she might act differently if she was trying to start a business rather than running what outwardly looks like a successful one.

When I go to a place to eat I want to be treated with a modicum of respect. I want to feel welcomed. I do not want to be treated as an annoyance. I am a regular customer here but I don't think anyone noticed.
author: Peter B.

description:
We were the first ones seated at opening at 7 a.m. on a Friday morning.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were pretty good.  But they were a little bland and undercooked.   The corn hash was ok but had these fat bubbles on them, a little smaller than dimes, tasted kinda gross.  

I don't know why people would wait over an hour to eat here.  The interior was nice - it  is quaint and cozy, think Chevron grey and white with canary yellow highlights (kinda French but still a little urban).

The service was ok.  The coffee was ok.  I had two cups because I was so tired.  I am clearly not a morning person (unless I'm on vacation!).
author: Chris L.

description:
Came during a weekday so there was no wait (I'm assuming this isn't always normal during the week and it was more luck than anything). 

Had "the plow" which was eggs, meat (I had bacon, my friend had sausage so we tried them both), crispy potatoes and ricotta pancakes. 

Food was amazing, particularly the pork sausage, the pancakes and the potatoes. Sausage was house made, super moist and had amazing flavor. The Ricotta pancakes were the perfect crispness on the outside and perfectly light inside. Some of the best pancakes I've ever had, although there was a little bit too much lemon flavor. The potatoes are damn good. My guess is they're deep fried breakfast potatoes so a little different than what you would normally get. 

Totally recommend it, but not sure I'd want to wait 2 hours for it.
author: Sean M.

description: Plow is the perfect breakfast spot. Be prepared for a 30 min wait. People start lining up before they even open. It can be a little pricey and if you check Yelp menu prices they may not be accurate. Check their direct  website.  Food a great and tasty. They have something for everyone.
author: Shana W.

description:
Yes the wait is long, and yes it's definitely worth the wait. They offer coffee to patrons waiting to be seated. 
The ricotta pancakes aren't too heavy or too sweet. The breakfast sandwich is all you ever wanted in a wholesome breakfast: toasted bun with egg and bacon/avocado. The breakfast potatoes are love at first bite. They elevate the meal and aren't just some afterthought of an add on. My ONLY complaint is they never cook my eggs over medium. They always without fail come out over easy -_-
Great customer service. Even met the owner who poured our coffees and made conversation with us.
author: Dre M.
