description: Honestly the best breakfast menu I've ever seen. I come here every time I am in SF. The staff is great, the food is incredibly fresh and they offer something indulgent and something healthy. If you don't like those breakfast potatoes, you don't like puppies or rainbows.
author: Sean S.

description:
I agree: Best breakfast I've had in months. 20 minute wait to sit outside - hostess was very gracious. Great waiter...tables are very close...Note:too close to bring a lap dog to dine at your table, Binkie.)
Had the perfect Soft Scramble...avec Nettles! Fabulous toast with real  butter.
Parking can be a pain
author: Red J.

description:
Dont get me wrong, the food here was good. But what knocks 2 stars off is the wait/space.

Now i can understand waiting over an hour for some AMAZING food. And yes the food here isnt amazing, but it IS good. Food wise, 4 STAR. But when i review places, i REVIEW. So i take into account EVERYTHING. Which is how it should be right?

So if you willing to TRY it out. I highly suggest it. Would i return here? Nah :\
author: Jordan J.

description: Plow is the best brunch place in town! However, you need to have the patience as a mourning elephant pod. It can take up to 2.5-3hrs wait during their traffic hours. Even getting there at 8am in the morning entails a 1hr wait. Food is amaze ballz though. Simple, yet very thoughtful brunch menu. Fresh produce, cheese, eggs and bread ingredients. Chefs can throw down on the omelette, soft scrambled eggs and pumpkin pancakes. Everything has an artisan feel to it, with light touches of simple, yet divine flavors. I would compare it to great Japanese cuisine, but in the breakfast realm. Coffee is pretty good too, although not to be compared to the institution Sightglass....never...
author: Ella H.

description:
Every time my husband and I try a new restaurant, we always ask each other if we would be willing to come back .  In regards to Plow, that would be a yes.

We really enjoyed the Salmon Eggs Benedict and The Plow (lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs made to order, choice of pork sausage, chicken sausage or bacon, and potatoes).  Seating is cozy but the staff was pretty friendly.
author: Rose A.

description:
Had breakfast here today. Was there right when they opened, so didn't have to wait (didn't get to experience that long wait that everyone keeps talking about). 

Boyfriend had "The Plow" w/their home-made pork sausage. The crispy potato was good, but nothing super special in my opinion. The lemon ricotta pancakes were really good and tasty, however, my favorite of the dish was the pork sausage. Very well made and tasted almost "burger-like" - but in a good way! (maybe the patty shape had something to do with it)

I had the Gruyere with prosciutto and chili fried egg sandwich. It was big, but not too overwhelming. The bread was pretty thick, so I had to eat it with a fork and knife. It also came with leafy greens. It was very delicious and tasty, however, you can't really go wrong with fancy cheese + proscuitto + fried egg can you?

Overall, I thought that the food was good, place/vibe was excellent, however, it didn't really live up to the hype. I'd go back here again if I'm lucky enough to not have to wait in line again for sure, but it hasn't convinced me that it's worth the 45 minute wait.
author: Sam B.

description: Fabulous brunch. Worth the wait since it's a small local spot. Plow breakfast is best of both worlds. Eggs and their signature lemon ricotta pancakes. Charming spot in Potrero area.
author: Stacey K.

description:
I got the Plow meal to try get a little bit of everything they had to offer. Biscuit is great, and eggs were delightful. Home fries had a just the right amount of seasoning.

Coming on a weekday morning and sitting at the bar meant no wait for me, though everyone doesn't necessarily have that flexibility. A wait will be rewarded by a solid meal.
author: Nathan C.

description: Service & food OUTSTANDING. Get there early but worth the wait. The Plow breakfast is a great choice but you certainly can't go wrong with 1 of their biscuits and a side of bacon.
author: Marla M.

description:
This place "plowed" me away! Haha, get it? 

We waited 45 minutes to get seated. It wasn't bad since me and my friend went a little crazy taking pictures on the hill right around the corner. I have weird knacks for hippy like brunch places. I loved the interior design and everything that was there. Definitely a small restaurant, but it was spacious and not cramped (at least where I was sitting). I kinda wish they had more than one restroom though because homegirl over hurr had to go and I couldn't wait! 

Food wise. U H M A Z I N G!! 

"The Plow" review: 
Omgosh, crispy side potatoes, sausages, eggs, and lemon ricotta pancakes were on point. I think I fell in love with their french toasts. It's hard to find good french toasts, and I think this is the place! We tried ordering their cornbread but they were out :( So sad, oh wells, next time!
author: Anna L.

description:
This place has a friggin huuuge wait time. Made reservation and came back 2 hrs later for our seat!! 

The food is great, but i would do this only when i dont have better things to do. Not entirely sure the food is worth the wait.
author: V M.

description: If you're in the neighborhood and looking for breakfast, go here! Plow does everything about breakfast right. It's got all of the staples but the farm to table quality really changes all of the dishes. I had a simple egg scramble with sausage and potatoes, but it was one of the best breakfasts I have had in a long time. The potatoes were my favorite in particular-- they smash them and lightly fry them to a crisp with lots of fresh rosemary. The still taste healthy and very fresh unlike most potato hashes you get at breakfast. It's a little small, so you might want to call ahead, especially on the weekends. Either way, it is very worth the wait!
author: Ekta P.

description:
when they say the wait is an hour they really mean it's 2 hours.  

if you don't have anything better to do on the weekends, come waste your time at plow waiting for brunch.  

dropped by on a sunday for brunch at 12.  we were told it would take less than an hour to get our table, and we didn't get seated until 2.  we decided to sit on the outdoor patio and it was the worst decision we ever made in our life.  it happened to be a cold breezy day and was it the worst meal ever.

the whole waiting game is just frustrating considering 1)  no reservations 2) no call ahead.  never again.
author: Alice C.

description: Really good clean food, quality ingredients. Organic, non gmo etc, etc.
author: Henry K.

description:
Great spot for brunch but only if you don't have to wait too long. otherwise, head to foreign cinema at 11am and you could get a seat without too much hassle.

Tall ceilings surrounding a sunny ambience. laid back. not too loud. great food. hard working bus boys leaping to the next table to get it cleaned. all of the things that one wants at a fantastic brunch place.

The Plow Plate was great. the Ricotta pancakes are out-of-this-world (the best thing that I had on sweet toothed brunch items anywhere). I like that they make their apple chicken sausage in-house.

The eggs benedict was a bit too creamy for my taste but probably just right for the benedict lover.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Crispy Potatoes- #92 on the 2013 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

I tried going to Plow once before, and the line was so crazy on a Saturday that they couldn't even accommodate to-go orders. I tried again on a Friday afternoon, and my friend and I got there around 11am and there was already a 20 minute wait! Luckily we were just a party of two and got seated after 10-15 minutes. We decided to split the Fried Egg Sandwich (Two Eggs Fried, Cheddar, Aioli, Served w/Crispy Potatoes, $11 + Nueske Bacon, $2.50, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/plow-san-francisco?select=GFi1WD9m-LXQzmYujzQpmA#YwR3TfuxiYN9OUvbMeiiBA) since I wasn't that hungry, and it was delicious. However, it didn't compare to the crispy potatoes, which were AMAZING. These were probably the best crispy potatoes that I've ever had. They were super flavorful, and cooked really well- this was a perfect addition to the 7x7 list. The egg sandwich is highly recommend but the potatoes are a must order!
-12 Hour Cold-Brewed Iced Coffee ($4, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/plow-san-francisco?select=GFi1WD9m-LXQzmYujzQpmA#GFi1WD9m-LXQzmYujzQpmA): Also really good, and highly recommended. The coffee was really smooth, and had good flavor.

Overall, the lines at Plow are justified, and is one of the best brunch spots I've been to ever. Although the restaurant and tables are small, and it can be difficult to find parking at times (it was easy on the weekday), I will definitely be back to try other items on their menu. I really like our waitress, who was really friendly and accommodating.
author: Amy D.

description:
I just got plowed (no homo)

After months of being on my bookmarks i finally made my way over there. This is probably my first time eating in that area of small restaurants and shops. really cozy. I find myself going here on thursday and it was fairly full about a 20 min wait and parking was relatively easy to find, but i would imagine it would be hard to find during the weekend.

I ordered the pork loin sandwich with a side of lemon ricotta pancakes. 

The pork loin sandwich reminded me of a similar sandwich from roli roti except roll roti does not use fresh jam to offset the savory. It was a different take from the very familiar pork loin sandwiches that are served out there. I still like roli roti better but this one is not far behind. 

The lemon ricotta pancakes are also a popular choice at plow. I personally the non lemon versions of ricotta pancakes like the ones served at kitchen story, but plow is just as fluffy and soft and tasty. 

Overall, i enjoyed myself here and i recommend it anyone who enjoys a good breakfast!
author: Ryan R.

description:
Came with a party of 6 at around 1pm on a Sunday. An hour wait they said... we were seated at around 2:30pm. 

Maybe that was their plan all along because we were starving by the time we were seated. Everything tasted amazing. My highlights were the fried egg sandwich, the almond pancakes (they were out of lemon ricotta by then), and a really refreshing glass of iced tea. 

My group was especially fond of the throwback R&B music! Would definitely come back.
author: Linda X.

description: Their lemon ricotta pancakes will change your life. Ridiculously good coffee as well. I'd recommend to go early to avoid the crazy line as the facility is very small. The only reason I'm not giving it 5 stars is because the customer service the last time I went could have been a bit more attentive.
author: Eliza A.

description: Went here with a party of 2 to a half full dining room got sat in a tiny dark corner away from the windows all the way in the back... got pretty fast service and when we ask to be moved to the table in back of us the waitress told us "no thats where the kitchen guys are about to sit" ARE YOU F***ING KIDDING ME? I got the plow, potatoes were burned, super stingy with condiments, only got .5 oz of syrup for the gross lemon riccota pancakes.... im olny giving 2 stars for the fresh high quality food #hipsterfood
author: Marc A.

description:
On a Wednesday around....11am....BEAUTIFUL! Only a 5 min wait. WHOOHOO. Parking isn't too bad at all.

We sat outside, a little windy but not too bad.

Ordered
The fried egg sandwich- my bf had this with bacon and avocado, sounds like a simple boring dish but it was really good. 
the plow- I ordered this with sunny side up eggs and the pork sausage. The sausage I did not like...it was dry and lacking flavor. Everything else was good. the lemon pancakes were good but not great...not too sweet, had to drench in syrup...oh the potatoes were yummy! i don't like potatoes but I loved these! 

skip the strawberry lemonade.

Overall very happy! good solid breakfast choices! May be our favorite brunch place yet!
author: Christine M.

description: This place was fantastic!! I ordered the sausages and eggs, which were really good! The pancakes looked amazing, so I will try them next time I'm in SF. Breakfast comes with unlimited coffee - hard to beat that! Restaurant has a light, relaxed atmosphere, in a nice neighborhood. It's very popular, so be prepared to wait. But definitely work the trek from Downtown!
author: David P.

description:
This place turned me into the person that waits 2 hours in line for brunch and I'm okay with that. I was always a huge fan of brunch, but I didn't know that it could be that damn good! 

I ordered the Plow and it was wonderful. Everything on my plate was fantastic. However, the crispy potatoes were the standout item. 

Do yourself a favor and bear the line at least once so you can try their amazing brunch.
author: Abena O.

description: Plow makes a delicious breakfast.  However, it is a small restaurant with very long wait times.  Because I live across the city most likely I will never go back and will just stick with Zazie. However, I came here for my birthday a few years ago.  We had to wait over an hour on a Friday morning for breakfast.  However, after that long wait the food was fabulous.
author: Christy L.

description:
After reading the reviews I was really excited to try this place, especially the pancakes, I live for pancakes...

After waiting to be seated for about 45 minutes I built up a strong appetite. I ordered the egg sandwich which came with a side of potatoes and I ordered a side of pancakes. 

The egg sandwich probably would have been good if I was wasn't disgusted by the raw egg yolk bursting in my mouth and running all over the entire sandwich. I did ask for my eggs to be cooked hard btw. The potatoes had an interested flavor that I think I liked but I couldn't tell because all i was served was a plate of potatoes skins. The pancakes... Hell nah, the texture was gross and there was an excessive amount of ricotta cheese, it was disgusting and I hated it.

After all of this, I was absolutely underwhelmed and I wanted to gag myself.
author: Sam Q.

description:
To avoid the extremely long wait time, my friend and I got here 10 minutes before opening, on a Saturday. About 6 people were waiting before us and by the time the front doors opened, there were just enough people lined up to fill the first seating.

We both ordered coffee and The Plow. My friend got it with the pork sausage and I got it with the chicken sausage, which are like meat patties and not the hot dog shaped ones. The chicken sausages were extremely dry and a little hard to swallow. The lemon ricotta pancakes were not fluffy whatsoever, which is how you imagine ricotta pancakes, but were somewhat hard. The flavor was good tho. My scrambled eggs were good and my friend enjoyed the poached eggs. The highlight were the potatoes. So crispy, perfectly seasoned, and full of rosemary flavor. My friend doesn't like rosemary too much so she wasn't fond of them, but I lovedddd em.

Our coffees were never refilled and had to ask twice before it was. Since we woke up early, I NEEDED that second cup! 

I wouldn't wait the crazy 2 hours.
author: Cheryl Q.

description: Loved this place for a more traditional breakfast option. It's in a great location and I'll definitely be back. I got the plow breakfast and loved the potatoes, super crispy. The sausage and lemon ricotta pancakes were delicious too.
author: Megan C.

description:
If you have never been to Plow then you must know that Plow has more of a cult fan following now than anything else. Their gluten free pancakes or crispy potatoes or waffles or scrambled eggs - whatever it is, there is nothing like it elsewhere. They have distinguished themselves in a very big way when it comes to food, so everything else is secondary. For me, there has never been a chance to ever notice the service (although luckily it has been good for me whenever I have been here). There has never been a chance to ever notice the long line which can be pretty long (Read: might have to wait for an hour or more sometimes).

I have been among that fan following where I would wake up at 6.30 am on a weekend, quickly drive to this place and wait in the queue; then feel highly accomplished for being one of the first few ones who quickly got a table for my hard work (waiting in the queue lol!). People who live in SF and who love good food know how amazing it is to be able to eat at this restaurant - it is THAT good! 

I have not found many restaurants who take the trouble to make gluten free stuff, much less gluten-free pancakes. Whatever I found at other restaurants scream this at the top of their lungs: "Here it is! We took some corn/rice/quinoa/or whatever you call it 'gluten free' flour, dumped some milk, sugar, butter, oil and eggs in it. To give it some flavor as a favor to you, we will add a tiny bitsy drop of some fake vanilla essence like we are lazying around in the park on a bright sunny day; then throw this mess of a vanilla smelling concoction on a pan and v.o.i.l.a. there you go! See, we told you we have it in the menu!" 

Plow is one of the very few restaurants who takes gluten free seriously and so well! Their gluten free pancakes with almond flour tastes like one jolly best stuff in the world! Keep it up Plow! Never stop making those pancakes ever ever!
author: Sun B.

description:
Here's a tip: On weekends, arrive 15 minutes before they open to get in line.  Otherwise, you will wait an hour in this line:  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/plow-san-francisco?select=um-AE1XJC_0QFdltGIEllA#um-AE1XJC_0QFdltGIEllA

The lemon ricotta pancakes live up to the hype ($13): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/plow-san-francisco?select=um-AE1XJC_0QFdltGIEllA#Vk1YdvVHw8-TIIdGSTOcfw
They are extra thick, and may have some crumpet batter in them.  A cross sectional analysis reveals little chunks of ricotta: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/plow-san-francisco?select=um-AE1XJC_0QFdltGIEllA#hTHUyrc9A_tN4pTjVu_ytA
And it's even better than it looks.
author: Scott F.

description: This is one of the best brunch spots in the Bay! Their potatoes and pancakes are great, and I definitely recommend trying the mochi cake and any other fresh baked goods. Literally everything we've eaten there has been sumptuous. The staff are friendly and the place cozy.  Be aware that getting there quite EARLY is the best bet for a table, and they only take small parties.
author: J B.

description:
This review will likely end up on "Letters to Penthouse".  

The French Toast with fresh strawberries, mascarpone, and pure maple syrup was divine. How so you ask? The instant it penetrated my mouth was pure heavenly bliss; reminiscent of the first time I've been made love to, so erotic, so sensual. The essence and savor of the moist bread titillated every one of my taste buds, leaving my lips parted, yearning for more!! The second mouthful had my tongue and body trembling with delight and desire. The mascarpone was milky and creamy, yet light in flavor and was enticing with the strawberries. The intensity of this level of foreplay nearly sent me over the edge. With haste, I drizzled the maple syrup over the toast and selfishly devoured more than what I can handle for my orifice was burning with greed. The final bite of toast consummated with my mouth so passionately it sent my body into a state of euphoria. The release of accumulated sexual hunger in my body left me feeling relaxed, like smoking a cigarette after getting laid. I closed my eyes and sighed in contentment.

I think I can die now.
author: Janny S.

description: We waited in line to check it out! Coffee was strong and very good. My favorite were lemon ricotta pancakes! Must try...
author: Jenny I.

description: This place is good. The most original and unique item on the menu is for sure the lemon ricotta pancakes. These pancakes are really something else. They are so fluffy and taste fabulous. Don't come here without trying them that's for sure. These pancakes are for sure their signature item. Now, this doesn't mean the rest of the food isn't good. All the food is good, but really the dish that makes this place so special is the pancakes. Yes, their potatoes are good and nice and crispy on the outside and soft in the inside. My second favorite dish has to be the fried egg sandwich. It's simple and great. Every ingredient compliments each other perfectly. After that my favorite dish has to be the salmon Benedict. So, if you come here, then make sure to get one of these items to really understand what's so great about this place. Yes, the wait is long, but all brunch spots in the city have a long wait, so I guess we are just accustomed to that now. I'll be back for those pancakes for sure!
author: Ahmed H.

description:
Plow definitely hits the spot for all your breakfast lovers! This was my first time here, and I am def going back! They do not take reservations so be prepared for that. I went on a Tuesday,in the early afternoon, so the wait wasn't bad at all. 
We ordered the:
-Fried Egg Sandwich - delicious - but I wouldn't get it again just because I would rather try their specials. 
-Famous Lemon Ricotta pancakes - VERY good, but I felt like it was more a dessert dish for me. So I prefer the
-Almond Pancakes - Amazing! LOVE this! Goes perfectly along side your main breakfast dish =)
-Corned Beef Hash - last but not least, one of the best corned beef I've had. Crispy crunch on the outside and juicy, flavorful and tender on the inside! Paired with poached eggs - what an absolute delight!
Great food, great service, location is nice and atmosphere is warm. What's not to love?!
(July 2013)
author: Charlene R.

description:
Had breakfast-for-lunch this Tuesday about 11 AM, just me. Can you call this meal brunch if it's not the weekend? Hmm... 

About 8 people waiting outside with me. I sat about 10 minutes sitting on an outside planter to get counter seat after putting my name on waiting list. Once in, I appreciated the pretty table setting with pressed striped thick cotton napkin folded between silverware, well-used coffee mug adding honest patina to marble counter. Heavy glass embossed salt & pepper shakers plus "raw" sugar in single-pour dispenser. It's the little things.

Ordered: 

Banana Cardamom Bread - DELICIOUS. Having it grill-fried only makes it more so. For sure get this if available. Really. Monkeys would be in eeeping nirvana eating this.

The Plow - I got this with over-easy eggs & pork sausage. Great news: Eggs perfect. Rosemary potatoes very tasty. Bad news: the pork sausage was well-spiced but dry; I recommend avoiding. If I am going to eat pig, a lovely animal, it should be worth it ;-) The lemon ricotta pancakes were not for me, though most Yelpers love them; they tasted like soggy Pledge polish to me.

Grapefruit Mimosa - Served in a pretty champagne flute but a bit $ at $10.50. I'd skip this next time.

Coffee - Tasty, smooth, subtle coconut flavor. Yum! 

Service - Excellent! Friendly & quick from Angela. Thanks!

The kitchen was working hard to get the dishes out, and I appreciated their labor, but pork sausage needs more fat or something -- and I will leave the famed lemon ricotta pancakes to the other people who adore them. Cute place, great service, but next time, I would stick with the classics: eggs, potatoes, bacon, coffee.
author: Sarah J.

description: I tried this place after seeing a independent show with two brothers eating their way through the city. It was on my place to try. I was not let down. The food was out of this world. The coffee was really good too. I ordered the plow breakfast with pork sausage patty and a side of Hong Kong toast. I cleaned my plate. The wait was around an hour and a half, but there were a lot of friendly people waiting as well and we had good conversation and the time flew by. The wait did not deter me and my husband from driving all the way from Modesto just to eat there again with our kids. The wait was again about and hour but it flew by once again. I can't encourage you enough to go and try this place for the best breakfast of your life. Be sure to order the Hong Kong toast as well.
author: Anesa H.

description:
I don't usually go on rants in my content, but rather try to pin point the best parts of my 5-star reviews... But this place has sentiment...so here I go.

LOVE LOVE LOVE this spot. A fairly minimal menu, but all unique options. My fiance and I ate here for our first meal as a couple, purely by coincidence. We happened to be staying in Potrero Hill, and found this hidden gem down on the corner. Favorite thing about SF? The constant "serendipities" that I experience! 

So about the food.. well, just trust me, it's some of the best breakfast this city has ever seen. And fear-not you gluten free folks... they have the best almond flour pancakes I've ever tried... and I highly recommend them to wheat eaters as well. Moist... moist...moist. 

I ordered the soft egg scramble with goat cheese.. and my mouth is watering just thinking about it. I'm an egg lover, and consider myself an egg connoisseur if you will.. so believe me when I say- this one's a winner.

If you're into rich breakfast, you will be taken care of here. I tend to stick with my egg dishes, but from what I've seen on other tables, it's not a dissapointment! 

Forget the farm...go "plow" it up over here!
author: Courtney M.

description:
My husband and I ate Sunday brunch here just on a whim, it was delicious! We showed up around 1:30PM and had about a 30 minute wait, ended up sitting at the bar, this place does not take reservations so be prepared to wait!  The crowed is hipster, even though this place is right in the middle of Potrero.  There is outside seating, but it's all in the shade, so even on those sunny days, you won't get any here. 

SUNDAY WAIT AT 11:30AM WAS 90+ MINUTES, ABSURD!!! 
We stopped by this weekend with another couple and they told us the wait was going to be 90+ minutes, really???  That is absurd, for any place, so we left and went to MIssion Rock, got a table right away and sat outside on a gorgeous Sunday overlooking the bay. 

THE FOOD: 
Brunch here is delicious, the crab scramble is amazing, the ricotta pancakes are yummy, bacon was great too. The dishes are on the larger side, so come hungry and have a glass of wine or mimosa while waiting. 

I would definitely come back here for brunch, but if I can't made a reservation, I'm only prepared to wait for so long for any place and it's about 45 minutes, it would be nice if half this place could be for those of us that plan ahead and want to make a reservation.
author: Inga W.

description:
* ~ * ~ * April 22, 2012 * ~ * ~ * 

Our first beer goggle-free date:

Mr. NSS: "Did you want to go to brunch?"
Me: "Sure, let's try Plow; I've been wanting to go there for a while now."

*Arrives at Plow*

Wait staff: "It's going to be a two hour wait."
Mr. NSS: "Two $@$^&*# hours?!?!...uhh, no thanks."

Mr. NSS: "I would never wait THAT long for food; it's just 'food', let's go somewhere else."
Me *thinking*: "Thanks for speaking for the both of us, you jerk!"

Fast forward nearly a year of dating a food snob. 

* ~ * ~ * April 5, 2013 * ~ * ~ *

Me: "Since we both took a day off, let's try going to Plow again?"
Mr. NSS: "Uhhh, the place with a two hour wait?"

Me: "Or, we can go to Red Door Cafe instead where the owner may molest your bootay while we wait in line?"
Mr. NSS: "Actually, Plow sounds PERFECT!"

*Arrives at Plow at 10:30 am*

Me: "I'll get the Fried Egg Sandwich w/ Bacon and one Lemon Ricotta Pancake please."
Mr. NSS: "I'll have the Dungeness Crab Scramble please."

*Our order arrives after 10 minutes*

Mr. NSS *talking with mouth full*: "Dayaum, I never knew crab and eggs could taste THIS good."

*2 minutes passes and Mr. NSS annihilates his crab scramble*

Mr. NSS *eyeing my sandwich*: "Aren't you going to ask if I want a bite?"
Me *reluctantly hands over sandwich*

Mr. NSS *Kills the rest of the sandwich*
Me: "WTF! That was MY sandwich!!!!"

Mr. NSS: "Sorry, you always give me half of your food."
Me: "UGH! You're sleeping with Ms. Lubriderm tonight!"

*Walking back to the car*

Mr. NSS: "So the next time we come to Plow, let's put our name down then come back two hours later ok?"
Me: "Uhhh, WTF has Plow done to my bf?!?!"

YEUP, it's THAT good folks!

OTHER NOTES:
*Expect a 30+ minute wait on weekdays and up to a 2+ hour wait on weekends. NO reservations. 
*Rockstar staff. The waitresses are very friendly and the very efficient kitchen staff churns out 6-7 plates at a time. Very impressive. 
*Get the Fried Egg Sandwich w/ Bacon ($13.50): http://bit.ly/16ICt9c! Simple but top-notch ingredients that's perfectly prepared = AMAZING: http://bit.ly/Y8xCIJ! The potatoes are f*cking delicious so make sure your order comes with this as a side!
*The Ricotta Lemon Pancake ($5) is also a must order! It's like a Lemon Meringue Pie but in a pancake: http://bit.ly/Y8xFEu. SO good!
*Why is the Chinese Breakfast always sold out or never available? It wasn't available on Friday. =(
*Outdoor seating, indoor seating, and counter seating. Sit at the counter and watch where all the magic happens!
*Loved the low-key casual ambiance with TLC, Destiny's Child and Toni Braxton bumping in the background.
*Fairly easy residential street parking.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Good food.  Ordered a salmon toast with green tea. Awesome tea and salmon was just delicious
author: Harsh B.

description:
Set high in this quaint little neighborhood in Potrero Hill that has a great view of the downtown SF is this wonderful breakfast/brunch joint. 

I've been here twice and both times were equally amazing in food quality and service. I would rate this place higher if I had the option to. 

The last time I was in attendance to have brunch here, I ordered The Plow which consists of 2 eggs prepared anyway you'd like, choice of pork sausage/bacon/chicken sausage, crispy potatoes, and of course their popular lemon ricotta pancakes which are fluffy, moist, and scaled to perfection on taste. 

Needless to say, this is one of my all time favorites in the city. 

WORD OF ADVICE: COME EARLY!! The wait is usually pretty hardcore, but don't worry... you can order a mimosa to ease the pain while you wait outside. I'd recommend the grapefruit option over orange. Also, as much as I love sitting outdoors, I'd choose to sit inside on this one. The bus stop is right next to where you're seated... "I'll have The Plow please. Hold the dust."
author: Mike D.

description:
Got here at 8:30 am and didn't get seated until 9:30. SF brunch game is too strong. 

Boyfriend got the Plow. Omgggggggg lemon ricotta pancakes are fluffy, moist, light, and perfectly lemony. I could inhale this forever. Perfect potatoes are perfect. Delicately crispy on the outside, soft and creamy on the inside. 

I got the eggs benedict with mushroom and spinach. Egg was poached perfectly, the sauce was creamy and rich with a little bit of tang to keep things interesting, and the English muffin  was to die for. I'm craving this for reals. 

I'm coming back for you. Soon.
author: Hayne P.

description:
Today I decided to take my daughter Clarissa to breakfast. Petit dejeuner, as they say in France. 

(That's where my daughter Clarissa lives most of the year for work. She is a model, lawyer and UN ambassador.)

So we arrived at Plow only to be greeted by a gigantic line of people waiting for food. Reminded especially me of the lines I would see at supermarkets in East European communist countries at times when they would sell special items like bananas or apples. Even Clarissa giggled. 

Still we were seated promptly and were able to enjoy an absolute delicious breakfast. Even by the standards of my well travelled model daughter. 

Here's the only downside. We were seated right at the entrance and there is a lot of traffic coming through these doors. My daughter has to be a size zero for work reasons and therefore gets chills easily. People just have no etiquette and leave the door open, even when kindly asked to consider the effects on the people seated. 

The restaurant staff tried to compensate - with sometimes too little effect. 

So, that is the only minus in this experience. The food is stellar. I wanna find out what they do with their amazing crispy potatoes. And their turkey sausage. Clarissa can't wait to talk to her French friends about this. After having a cigarette of course. 

Delicious, Clarissa is off to New York now, to give a speech in front of the UN. I hope she won't have gotten a cold from those ignorant people waiting in line. 

Not chic,
U. L. and C. H. M. L.
author: Ulrich L.

description:
Came here on a weekday with my brunch buddy, the best kind of buddy there is. Found parking pretty quickly. Parking on these steep hills always freak me out, though.

Only had to wait about 20 mins. Not bad!
The space and decor that they had was nice..reminded me of NOPA's interior. The nice light wood tables..big windows that let in natural light. Made for a pleasant dining experience. We had to sit directly next to another table though, because of space, but I didn't mind too much.

Had the fried egg sandwich with bacon. Pretty good, but honestly the highlight of the meal was the potatoes. Holy crispiness. Haha, so herby and delicious! If you're a texture freak like me, then I think you'd appreciate these as much as I did. I liked how crisp they were, like super fried but it didn't feel greasy which was nice. :]

My buddy had "the plow"--2 eggs, bacon, and lemon ricotta pancakes. Pretty good. the ricotta pancakes...were good. don't get me wrong, but I did have better--at Zazie's in Cole Valley. Sorry! I'd still come back if I were in the area! :D 

Service was good. Left happy. Prices weren't too bad for what you got. Until we meet again, crispy potatoes...
author: Mariel A.

description: Their lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing! I just can't get enough. Every time I'm in the city, I need to make a pit stop here!
author: Judy S.

description:
Came here alone and, though there were several open tables and counter spaces I was seated in an awkward spot at the end of the counter, squeezed in between a rack of coffee cups and two business dudes. I was not thrilled at this, but figured it was probably restaurant policy to keep as much seating as possible open for groups.

Business dudes left, and even though the restaurant was even emptier, the next guy who came in was seated right next to me too, even though there were five empty barstools to his right and - like I said - the restaurant was almost empty. This guy is literally up in my armpit.

Seemed a little weird, but then several more guys came in. They were all seated along the bar with plenty of space between them. 

Hard to escape the conclusion that the waitstaff - who were all women by the way - somehow feel that dudes deserve way better seating. I said something to the hostess, was looked at like I was crazy. Tipped 10%, feel like a chump for doing even that. C'mon, Plow. Feminism is forty years old. Get with the program.
author: Hawley S.

description:
Perfect breakfast. 
Y'all know I'm a big fan of cheap, and somehow paying $14 for a breakfast that other places charge $10 for kind of goes against my nature.  But damn if this isn't THE BEST BREAKFAST out there.  PERIOD.  I'll go broke, but I'll be happy.  

POTATOES POTATOES POTATOES.  What else can I say?  These potatoes were perfectly cooked.  This is how breakfast potatoes / home fries should be.  Anyone else who is serving "chunky" style breakfast potatoes - as opposed to shredded hash browns - you need to come here and see HOW IT IS MEANT TO BE DONE.  (I'm looking in your direction, Crepevine.)  

Eggs?  Perfectly cooked.

I took a gamble and went with the sausage patties because they had the words "House Made" next to them.  Usually I'm wary of sausage patties - it's too easy to put bad stuff in there.  OMFG, these patties were the best tasting sausage patties EVER in the whole entire f-ing universe.  (Sorry, but it's true.)

Yes, you're going to pay 30% - 50% more and yes, it's totally worth it because this is the EXEMPLAR of breakfast food.  Finest kind, bar none.
author: FoodDudeS F.

description:
I plowed into the Plow at Plow.

This brunch item had a bit of everything:  two eggs (poached), some pork sausage, two small lemon ricotta pancakes, and the infamous PLOW POTATOES ($13).  The potatoes have ruined me for all future breakfast potatoes because the bar is now sky high.  They were really soft inside yet very crispy on the outside and sprinkled with great rosemary and salt seasoning.  And don't forget to try the locally made Youk's Hot Sauce!

The Fried Egg Sandwich came with two eggs over easy on a soft n' squishy Acme bun ($9).  The eggs were nice and runny and went great with the cheddar cheese, aioli, frisee, and Plow potatoes on the side.  

The bright space has a clean look with large windows and a cute sign that said, "No cell phone.  Please."  It's a small place though and busy for a weekday lunch.  I probably wouldn't brave the long wait on the weekend.

Unless "Plow Potatoes by the Bucket" becomes a menu item.  Then it's on like Donkey Kong!

More info here:  http://goo.gl/rnt4y
author: Amy C.

description:
This is easily one of the top brunch places to go to in SF. If you get The Plow, which is basically their breakfast sampler, skip the sausage patty (very dry), and go for their bacon (nice and crispy). The lemon ricotta pancakes are delicious, but the star of The Plow has got to be the crispy potatoes with rosemary. Yum. 

They have some staples on the menu like the fried egg sandwich, which is very good, but they also have great seasonal dishes. I tried the salmon tartine last time and it tasted delicious.

Pro Tip: Come on the weekdays to avoid the ridiculous lines.
author: Helen Z.

description:
I looooooove brunch. If I had it my way I would eat breakfast foods all day. Heard about this place from friends so I'm glad I got to stop by as I was visiting from out of town. We got there around noon on a Sunday and of course, the corner was bustling with people waiting for a table. I can't believe we waited almost two hours to get seated, but I'm proud of us for making it through alive. The moment when your name does get called makes you feel like you've just won the lottery, it's great. We got a table outside which was fine because as other reviewers have said, they provide blankets. The outdoor seating can get a bit awkward with hungry folks staring at you and your food, the likelihood increasing exponentially the closer you are to the main door (which we were right beside). The indoor area is a bit small, but love the decor and atmosphere.  

Maybe it was the hunger (or hanger), but I thought the coffee was really good. My friend had the plow while I had the dungeness crab scramble. The food here did not disappoint. The scramble was really good but it seemed to be a bit watery/mushy? Tried friend's pancakes and they were also good, not too flour-y. Definitely pretty heavy on the lemon, whether you are or aren't into that. Seemed like a lot of folks dining around us were substituting in almond flour pancakes. I also couldn't stop eyeing all the egg sandwiches that were being carried out of the kitchen! Overall had an enjoyable brunch experience at Plow. Would've been slightly better had we not spent a good portion of our day waiting and eating.
author: Cathy C.

description:
Best brunch I had in SF! Being from DC, I was kind of disappointed with the SF brunch scene but Plow definitely changed that. Yes, the wait is long and kind of annoying depending on when you go, but it's worth it, and definitely better than some other touristy brunch places (looking at you Mama's). Plow is in Portrero Hill, a mostly residential neighborhood and there are some cute stores, restaurants, bookshops around the block that you can check out while you wait. 
I decided to get the Plow as it has a little bit of everything - eggs your way, choice of pork/chicken sausage or bacon, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes. Come hungry! The crispy potatoes are seriously the best - absolutely MUST HAVE. The lemon ricotta pancakes were really good too. I had my eggs poached and the chicken sausage, both of which were good. Although, the potatoes really stole the show! The fresh orange juice was delicious. We were seated outside and it was cute to watch people walk up and down the hill as we enjoyed our huge brunch. It's dog friendly which is nice. A bit more expensive than other places, good food, and friendly service except for the long wait. Will go back for the crispy potatoes!
author: Jaya P.

description:
I came here with a gal pal on a Thursday lunch break (~12:15pm). Parking was easy (say what the what? It's never easy in SF). Since I was in great company, the wait wasn't long at all--probably 10-15 minutes max for first available seating. We got seated outside, which was fine. The weather was amazing, so we didn't mind. 

She ordered a side of scrambled eggs with the Almond Flour Pancakes. I got the Plow breakfast (hey-- when in Rome, right?) which came with two eggs (over-easy for me), 4 things of chicken apple sausage, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes (yes! and yes!), and a big hoppin' load of crispy potato chunks (it's a bit ginger-y, so be advised). Oh-- and a cup of Equator coffee to wash it all down. I loved The Plow (get yer mind outta the gutter...lol). I believe the gal pal loved her pancakes too. I only wish my lemon ricotta pancakes had some blueberry compote (sp?) like the ones in the regular lemon ricotta pancake entree. And, I think the crispy potatoes were a little over-powering with ginger taste. All in all, I loved the dish and the experience. 

This place is worth a visit in my book.
author: Melody W.

description:
This place serves crack.

I swear.  Pure craaaaaaaack!

This is a plate of crack:
http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/plow-san-francisco?select=AQQHQEMRFHofOnyRFOBWCA#ToiZprRvyLu9we-MuuTI8g
It's the signature dish, the Plow.  A plate of crispy potatoes(crack), Nueske bacon (crack), lemon ricotta pancakes (crack) and eggs (cracked =P)  My GAWD this was delicious.  The Nueske bacon was simply the best bacon I've had.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were heavenly.

Cold smoked salmon, fromage blanc, pickled red onions, capers, grilled Acme rye:
http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/plow-san-francisco#OZ955kbTXWpM8skTrkEXEw

This was good.  Ingredients were fresh.  My only complaint would be that the smoked salmon was not smoked enough.  I come from the land of smoked salmon, and this needed more smoking.

Also ordered a side of house made sausage patties.  Again good, but, yours truly makes a better version.  There were chili flakes and fennel in the spicing mixture.   So attn,  Management of Plow, you wanna pack 'em in even more?  PM me and maybe I'll share my sausage spicing recipe with you.  Pfffffffffft......

One real stand out.  Coffee.

I should have asked where they got their coffee, b/c this is a first!  And I really do mean first.  I do not like sour coffee.  I drink it black.  The coffee they served here was amazing.  It was fruity and citrusy with nice acidity WITHOUT being sour.  I have not encountered coffee like this before.
-----
Update:  Just found out the coffee is from Equator out of San Rafael!
-----
Plow, I'll visit you again.  2 hour flight, rental car, 30 minute wait, and all.  I'll come again.
author: Herman E.

description:
My favorite breakfast in the peninsula, well actually, in the whole Bay Area. Very simple and delicious menu. I've tried the eggs Benedict with smoked salmon. Wow! What I'm having today and on most visits here is The Plow. You can never go wrong with their basic breakfast sampler of crispy seasoned potatoes, eggs any style (I get them as whites scrambled with cheddar) with your choice of apple chicken sausage, nueske bacon or (...can't remember the other choice) along with 2 very perfect lemon ricotta pancakes with real maple syrup. Yum! 

It's always busy here but well worth the wait (usually 45min-1hr in the weekends)
author: Cameron T.

description:
My girls and I needed a place to brunch at and we decided to check out Plow after reading all the other Yelp reviews. We went on a Saturday morning. Parking was fine, given it was located in a fairly residential area. 

Go EARLY and get your name on the list. We had to wait for an hour before getting seated. It was a gorgeous day and we sat outside. 

FYI - there's coffee available while you wait, BUT they will charge you. It's NOT FREE. We were mistaken and thought they were complimentary until we saw the charge on the bill. 

Food: get the PLOW SPECIAL. The ricotta pancakes were great. And it's a great mix of everything Plow has to offer. I would definitely go back again. :)
author: Sharon G.

description:
They have a pretty good system in place for seating parties. You put your name down and they tell you when to come back to check on your status. It's good that they do this so you don't have to wait outside the restaurant for them to call your name. Who knows how long that will take. 

When we got seated outside, the waiter asked if we would like blankets in case it was too chilly. Beverages and food was ordered promptly after we got seated. I'm glad we didn't have to wait long for our orders to be taken. The food was great. Everything tastes good on The Plow dish.
author: Sandy W.

description:
LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES

Came here on a wet weekend for brunch with my cousin. It was already packed when we got there and it was only 10am. Make sure to put your name down. They tell you how long it might take. Told us it would take 45 mins so we decided to make a short trip to Trader Joe's for flowers. 

By the time we came back, we didn't have to wait long to be seated. The seating area inside is super tiny, most likely you'll have to share tables with someone. We sat next to these two old gay men who were probably a couple. Didn't bother me at all. 

I ordered the lemon ricotta pancakes while my cousin had the sandwich. Both were good. I think the best part about it were the crispy potatoes. They were really good and probably super unhealthy! They are super fried. 

Parking isnt too bad. You'd have to park residential. I parked on a hill. I know some of you tourist aren't used to parking 90 degrees on a hill in SF but luckily I grew up here and I'm used to it :)
author: Tommy L.

description:
Plow is worth the 1 1/2 hr brunch wait!

We ordered the French toast for the table. Everyone loved it. 

The eggs were phenomenal farm fresh eggs. I had the scrambled eggs and 3 other people had the egg sandwich. Rave reviews got all. 

BUT...the potatoes are out of this world. They are worth going to Plow just for the potatoes. Plow is an unpretentious neighborhood favorite with a friendly service staff and welcoming attitude. Best Brunch of 2013.
author: Keith B.

description:
Local fare, healthy and delicious
Fantastic Brunch

My brunch here was perfectly prepared. The potatoes were unreal, the kale salad was great, eggs cooked to order. The little homemade doggie treats were later devoured by a couple of happy yorkies :) 

A bad review of this place would be surprising. Met the owner, loved the staff. Will ALWAYS come here when I am in town.

The Scene: Local, Earthy, Farm2Table
Destination Rating: 9 
Date Rating: 8
Hob Nob Potential: 3

Strong suggestion: Cookies to go :) Nom nom nom.
author: Megan C.

description:
Plow is located in a convenient spot off of 280 in Potrero Hill.  There was easily found street parking nearby when I went so I think parking shouldn't be much of a problem.  

Keep in mind I did not dine in for my meal during this visit to Plow, just a simple takeout request since I was alone.  

I opted for "The Plow" which came with two lemon ricotta pancakes/maple syrup (so good), two eggs (got mine just pure egg whites which were perfectly prepared), bacon (it wasn't the best, I should've just got the chicken apple sausage), and potatoes (which were the highlight of my meal -- I wish I ordered more because they were made to absolute perfection, crispy and all with just the right touch of rosemary).  

If you're in the area this place is so worth trying out despite the wait I've heard it has.  They've got some top-quality eats and excellent/friendly service even though my experience was brief inside the restaurant since I was just claiming my takeout order.  Definitely plan on returning soon!
author: Jorel C.

description: The ambiance is nice, and the smell of their food is mouth watering if you're a big seafood fan. I recommend the clam chowder and lobster roll if you're willing to spend a little extra for quality over quantity.
author: James A.

description:
The review is for my weekday visits. I don't ever go here on the weekends because the wait time is so long I don't have the time. 

This restaurant is fantastic! The hostess was really warm and friendly from the moment we entered the restaurant. She was really sweet and kind to my 20 month old girl. They gave us a great spot for a high chair, which connects to the table and was very clean. The waitress knew that it would take a while for our order to show up so she brought my daughter fruit ASAP. Very considerate of her. 

The food is just as good as the service. Try the ricotta pancakes. Delicious! The egg sandwich is flavorful and cooked to perfection. They are served with potatoes. I don't usually feast on potatoes but these potatoes are really delicious. They are crunchy and seasoned with rosemary. 

Enjoy!
author: M W.

description: I'm used to the impression that San Franciscans don't normally head out for brunch until later in the morning, but my recent trip to Plow proved me wrong. We got there around 9:30AM and there as definitely a good amount of people already there waiting as well. We were seating after half an hour or so which I guess isn't *too* bad though. I ordered the Fried Egg Sandwich. While the sandwich itself was pretty tasty, what really stood out to me here was their potatoes! They're super crispy and addicting. Definitely would like to come back here again. Yummm.
author: Stephany L.

description:
Insanely good breakfast! Get there early because there is always a wait. We arrived around 9am on a Saturday morning and waited an hour. However, they made the wait a very pleasant experience. They served us fresh coffee that we took with us for a nice morning walk around the neighborhood. 
My husband had soft scrambled eggs, which blew his mind. I had an amazing farro salad with fresh, roasted veggies and a vinaigrette that was so yummy. I also induldged in the almond flour pancake, which was seriously the best pancake I remember ever having. We will definitely go back!
author: Heather H.

description:
You know a place is popular when my mom starts to talk about it. Being in close proximity to her work, I decided to take her on Saturday before she began her shift. Everyone knows you'd better be prepared to wait over an hour for a seat at any brunch spot in San Francisco; and Plow was no exception. To our surprise, our expected hour and a half turned into only 50 minutes! We were seated at the counter facing the open-aired kitchen. Plow is extremely homey. From the wooden decor to the spices stored in mason jars, I already knew I was going to like what I ordered. 

My mom and I both got coffee to start the meal. If I didn't drive, I definitely would have tried the Bloody Beer. But their coffee was great! My mom even said, "This is the best coffee I've had from any of the brunch spots you've taken me." It's hard to please my mom, especially when it comes to her coffee! 

But onto the food... between the both of us, we ordered two dishes.

My mom chose the soft scrambled eggs with oyster mushrooms, spinach and cheddar accommodated with potatoes and toast. I never knew eggs can be that light, fluffy and divine! I absolutely love eggs, but this made me fall in LOVE with them even more. Oyster mushrooms have a really "meaty" quality to them, so I didn't miss that there was no carnivorous protein on the plate (besides the egg). 
.
I decided to go with the Plow (2 ricotta lemon pancakes, eggs, house made sausages and potatoes). I had a small issue with my pancakes because they were a bit underdone in the center. The taste though... a punch of lemon-y goodness balanced with ricotta cheese! As for the house made sausage, the flavors again punched me in the face and left me in awe. It was unfortunately a bit on the drier side for my liking. 

But the key to this delicious meal lies in the potatoes... It doesn't make sense! Crispy goodness from the start to finish of meal. To be honest, I'm not a fan of the potato. Plow has to be seasoning their potatoes with something, because I ate every bite possible off my plate and then my mom's plate!

You definitely need to give Plow a try if you have any interest in brunch foods. I promise you won't be disappointed!
author: Derrick H.

description: Not worth the wait and money! The food are just normal, there's nothing special or that stand out. I don't get why people overrated this place. There are plenty of better brunch places.
author: Ellie D.

description:
I had a tuna sandwich. 
I was expecting the eggs to be pouched (not sure why, maybe it was just my imagination...) and I had two boiled eggs instead, and they were not as soft as I may had wanted them to be, but that's fine... they are still eggs.
Salad was good. tea was just ok.
author: Maggie J.

description:
I like the clean & simple neighborhood feeling of this restaurant. Waited an hour on Saturday but it wasn't that bad since the weather was nice and I had a Mimosa in my hand. 
I ordered the Plow with my eggs over medium and chicken apple sausage. My potatoes were a little too extra crispy. However, others that had the potatoes didn't suffer the same fate I did. I loved the lemon ricotta pancakes. The favor was light and not overpowering so I could easily see myself eating many of these.
Soft scrambled eggs - Who knew that stinging nettles and goat cheese went together so well. The eggs had that almost cooked looked like it was a little runny but when I ate it I tasted perfectly that way. 
Service- Hostess and servers were very nice.

They didn't have the monkey bread on the menu that day so I missed that opportunity.  If I was around Potrero Hill area I stop in again.
author: Nguyen L.

description:
After we got married, we ended up in the heart of San Francisco being the tourists we are. Thankfully we stumbled upon this charming little quarter. It is worth every single second of the wait...odds are there will be a wait! I'll save you some time ordering though -- Get the plow breakfast! You get the best of all worlds. Lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, bacon, eggs, you name it. The almond flour pancakes are also incredible, my hubs ended up stealing mine because he doesn't like lemon pancakes. They make everything fresh and you can see them cutting potatoes or squeezing orange juice when you walk in the door!

See the link below for my top 10 favorite Breakfast Spots//Coast to Coast --

http://www.kaitgmiller.com/healthy-eating/10bestbreakfastspots
kaitgmiller.com
author: Kaitlyn M.

description: So we took a Cousin here during a 12 hr layover. We had seen the vids on YouTube about it and we were pleasantly surprised. Sunday morning about 9am the wait was about 45min. But worth it. I had "The Plow" plate which incl. two eggs, some really delicious Rosemary country potatoes, awesome sausage pattys, and to finish off, what I came for, Lemon Ricotta Pancakes!  If you visit for the pancakes alone it's worth it. They were fluffy , light and just lemony enough to not be overpowering and the ricotta, well let's just say I'm adding ricotta to my pancake mix from now on. Also delish was the corn millet muffin.
author: Javier A.

description: Worth the wait and small dining area, come in and sit down even if you get seated outside. The almond pancakes and french toast with lemon curd were delicious! They can't seat groups larger than 6 tho, you may be split up. Still come for the breakfast done well!
author: Lorna F.

description:
The plow is such a good place to have brunch. The food is great. I ordered the plow. It has 2 fried eggs, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, 2 house made pork sausage and crispy country potatoes. First, the lemon ricotta pancakes were sooo good! They were light and fluffy. It has a unique taste that you just just have to taste for your yourself to truly appreciate it. Second, The crispy potato is amazing! Country potato is normally roasted and are soft with a texture to more of bake potato. But the crispy potato at plow is so different. Has tons of flavor! Third, The house made sausages were really good too. Full of herbs and spices. Making your own sausage in house, gives you a clue at the quality of the food you will be eating. 
If fresh food with great flavors is what your looking for, then plow is the place to go! Will definitely be returning to try other things on the menu!
author: Roger P.

description:
Ambiance:  Plow is exceptionally simple.  I compare it to Piccino, which may or may not make sense to some of you out there.  It's sleek, sophisticated, very well lit with natural lighting, clean, and with feelings of minimalist white and wood.  The servers and staff are all unique and there are no uniforms.  I get the sense that everyone genuinely enjoys working there, which always makes returning there easier and enjoyable.

Service: Pretty good.  I've been here twice and both times we've sat outside.  This can be tricky because the seating outside is unfortunately draped in shadow.  If this is a real concern though, be advised that they offer (or they at least offered us) blankets!  That's pretty awesome, ya?  And they make a point to keep your coffee cups filled to the brim, so that's another way to stay warm.  Beyond that, they're really good about taking your order quickly and bringing you your food even quicker. But don't worry, they neither encourage you to eat faster nor give off the impression that they want for you to finish so that they can seat others.  All in all, the service is legit.

Food:  Three words:  Fried. Egg. Sandwich.  See my photo.  This sammy is the real deal, kids.  And the potatoes that come with it?  GOLDEN.  And they're fried... in BACON FAT.  I mean COME ON.  No joke though, the food here is really delicious and (in my opinion) seem to be made with superior care.  I have also enjoyed the pancakes, which are delectable.  If I had the time, I'd make a point to try everything on the menu because it all sounds, smells, and looks delicious.
author: Bryan H.

description: The bacon, eggs having everything natural and organic I loved the experience and will definitely be back
author: Jakis P.

description: Really loved this place. It is always busy and it's small. The tables outside are nice except for when it's cold. They provide you with a blanket that u can wrap around your legs to keep you warm. I liked that...our food was delicious but got cold so fast due to the day being extremely cold.. Service is great, and food comes out pretty fast.
author: Claudia E.

description:
I don't think I've ever had breakfast as good as this.  When I pulled up the line was intimidating but I walked in to put my name on the list and the host was running around like crazy but still acknowledged the fact that I was there and that he'd be right with me.  He was totally friendly and courteous and said my table would be ready within 15 mins "So grab a coffee at Farley's and when you come back you'll be ready to go." So I did just that.

the wait for our food was a little lengthy but not complaining.  Everyone else had a plate of food that looked so good you wanted to reach out and grab it for yourself.  But I waited and it was WELL worth it.  I had the "Plow" meal which consisted of 2 small pancakes (delicious) 2 strips of bacon (amazing - even with the fat which I usually hate and ask for extra crispy) 2 eggs prepared any way you want them and country style potatoes which I swear were made in heaven.  I don't know if they were deep fried or what but those things could easily be my breakfast lunch and dinner.

I will without a doubt be coming back to Plow.
author: Kevin J.

description: Lovey little spot that stays busy all morning but is worth the wait. Had "the plow" and the pancakes and pork sausage were the highlights of the dish hands down. The staff is extremely friendly and takes good care of you. Would visit regularly if we lived in the area.
author: Trevor C.

description: great find in the neighborhood.  be prepared for a wait!  good comfort food and great brunch in SF.  Small restaurant with limited amount of seating and almost no waiting area--they will tell you to wait at other restaurants with no worries b/c they are so busy.
author: Sri C.

description:
I had "the plow", which included two eggs any style, two pancakes, crispy potato along with some fancy bacon - could also choose the house made pork or chicken apple sausage. I added the house made pork to the order (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/A0AziPST4T6k-V3neWFRNA?select=Nvx5t7GSC0M9qR9nAUcjvQ). Add a refillable coffee and the total was $21.

The place is still new, only a few months old so it feels nice, looking like an old Victorian converted (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/A0AziPST4T6k-V3neWFRNA?select=rMjzBGdWw3oWzRP5ph3JFg). I feel like this is one of those nicer brunch place for foodies, so if you're into that scene then it is perfectly fine. And, while not extravagant, the menu  prices (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/A0AziPST4T6k-V3neWFRNA?select=RWYDmjlqUDtKN1aMzOeaMA) are higher than the average greasy spoon spot. But, the food was plentiful and worth it.

Go by 9AM on a weekday and you should find parking within the block - only a street over from Mariposa (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/A0AziPST4T6k-V3neWFRNA?select=KrJE6HcQ9q9AEOmc-wvpgw) - and no waitlist. The server Ashley (liked her NZealand accent!) was also helpful with the menu suggestions. I plan to include this place in my brunch rotation - returning other days and times and update the review.

Note: Bumped into one of the owners of Candybar. A sign for another UYE?
author: Peter L.

description:
Delicious! Both what I ordered (egg sandwich) and every dish that came out of the window was amazing.

Definitely a high end brunch spot that serves up those same options every day. I've always found myself frustrated that some places have specific (and amazing) brunch menus only on Sundays, maybe Saturdays. But to have a location that specializes in fresh & inventive brunch fare that I can enjoy during the work week is priceless.

I am also a fan of combining the modern, clean, and well lit atmosphere with the open kitchen. Sitting at the bar area allows you a close up view of how they prepare everything... which they do quite well.

Definitely plan on returning!
author: Ethan B.

description: Came here on a Friday morning at 10:30 and surprisingly there was a wait! We waited an hour for party of three. Me and my other friends all got the Plow and I loved their crispy potatoes!! I was very satisfied after this meal (:
author: Tina C.

description:
Wow this place really impressed me. I came her for Sat brunch (10:30ish) before a Giants game.  After waiting 45 minutes for a table, I was really hoping it would live up to the hype from the Yelp reviews I read.  I must say it impressed me in all levels. 

Ordered a couple pastries to start, a Raspberry Galette and a chocolate scone. I am not sure which I liked better because they were both delicious. I could have eaten that alone and have been fine. 

I ordered the "Plow" with a side of bacon and it definitely did not disappoint. I was able to try their Lemon Ricotta Pancakes. I normally hate anything lemon, but this made me a convert (at least for that day).  

The service was pretty fast and very friendly. We had about 3 different people help us and one of the guys even chatted with us about the Giants. 

The only drawback I had was towards the end of our meal, there was a group of 5 seated on a table really meant for 4 to my left.  The seats were so close together that the 5th girl was literally straddling between the tables. It was definitely a little AWKWARD.  If I was still eating, I'd be quite irritated that they even let someone do that (as well as the fact that I'm left handed and would have probably bumped arms with her).  

I'd definitely recommend coming when it first open to avoid the wait. Otherwise expect to wait 45 minutes - 1 hour with the rest of the peeps!

I'm coming back here again (but earlier!)
author: Phillip D.

description:
The lemon ricotta pancakes really are every bit as good as all these reviews make it out to be. Try it or regret it FOR LIFE. I'm just kidding, do what you want, I'm not your mother.

Another pleasant surprise were the breakfast potatoes. So crispy on the outside, just perfectly chewy on the inside. Repress your healthy conscience and don't wonder how they got the potatoes to be so crunchy and enjoy that heavenly mess. Pork patties were tough and bland. Definitely choose chicken apple sausage over the homemade pork patties.

The biscuits and gravy were disappointing. Having grown up in the South, I never turn down a chance to try biscuits and gravy. The biscuits were a bit stiff. The gravy on the sweeter side, with a really heavy aftertaste of the sausages.

Wait was 35 minutes, but this was 9:30 am. Pancakes and potatoes are well worth waiting in line for.
author: Chia L.

description:
Yum! Definitely worth the 40min wait. I was disappointed that they ran out some things I want try like the Monte Cristo and Eggs Benedict. 

Pumpkin pancake - So Good! Perfectly cinnamon-y, fluffy and flavorful

The Plow - 2 eggs, crispy potatoes, 2 Lemon ricotta pancake - sweeter than the pumpkin, lighter and fluffier, and pork sausage. Amazing. And a great way to try a few different things

Pork lion sandwich. Hard to put down. That red sauce in it brought all the flavor. The bread was nice and not dry. 

Got their ice tea - whatever. Tasted like tea, that wasn't worth the $4! Haha
author: Tiffany N.

description: Dood this place is amazing! Stayed in San Fran this weekend on vacation and tried a lot of good places to eat but this place here just blows every other place out of the water! The music they place is great, the food is amazing, and the employees are friendly and helpful. Definitely will be making this a must have every time I'm out here in San Fran! I 110% recommend this place! I had the plow with sausage, extra bacon, egg whites and a French toast and I loved every bit of is! Their toast is a must have as well! This place made my last day here one to remember!
author: Ismael L.

description:
Came in on Easter Sunday and had a 45 minute wait for 2, which we expected. We really enjoyed our brunch and can't wait to come back and try more! 

We had the chicken tinga and the crab scramble. Both were delish! 

Parking was plentiful in the area and there are lots of coffee shops around to more comfortably wait for your table at plow.
author: Annie C.

description:
Wow is this place popular!  I came here around 8:50 on a Sunday morning, thinking there was no way there would be a huge wait. Was I wrong! I guess San Franciscans really like their brunch!

I have to say brunch was worth the wait. I got the Plow, which includes 2 eggs, your choice of meat (I got bacon, obviously), crispy potatoes, and 2 small lemon-ricotta pancakes. It was the perfect amount of food for someone who has been waiting for a table for 1 hour! It was also delicious. The crispy potatoes were mixed with onions and both were extra crispy. These are probably the best breakfast potatoes I've ever had! The lemon ricotta pancakes were of course delicious as well. The only negative was they were a little on the luke warm side. 

Next time I come here (and there will be a next time) I'm going to get here right when they open at 8, or come on a weekday.
author: Sungeeta A.

description: Loved the brunch. We ordered the plow, a delicious biscuit and soft scrambled eggs. Highly recommend all three. Everything around us looked so delicious but we were so full off the two plates we ordered that we didn't get to try more.
author: Sandra S.

description: My favorite breakfast/brunch place I just wish it wasn't the favorite other people as well - the lines are long so be prepared to wait for 35-45 minutes.
author: Raymond A.

description: Amazing breakfast choices with to die for flavoring. First time here for breakfast. Small, quaint, attentive but worth it.
author: m s.

description: Just terrible and so overpriced.   One of the worst breakfasts I've ever had.  Too expensive to try again
author: Cathy S.

description: Long over due for this review.. Plow on the weekends is a 1-2 hour wait. Surprisingly, the parking is not bad. The interior of this place is " cozy ". And for the food, it's just a little different but not bad. I got the plow and I loved the potatoes! The lemon ricotta pancakes were good as well, but I got easily tired of it. I will probably try to come back again on a weekday.
author: Erika-Kelly C.

description:
Came on a Saturday morning at 11:15am and was told it'd be a hour wait. So took a walk to nearby neighborhood for maybe 25 mins or so .. Come back to check in, it'll be another hour. Umm say what?!?! I know it's crazy here but .. That's a crazy long wait! Luckily, we decide to stick it out and wait. By 11:50, they were starting to call out parties of 2! Turns out that everyone either left or went for a walk and we got so lucky to be seated before 12! 

It was my second time here but the first wasn't memorable. This time .. It kind of really blew my mind! I got the plow with house-made sausage. The potatoes were amazingly crispy but not in the oily tasting way. House-made sausage blows the chicken apple sausage out of the park! And lemon ricotta pancakes actually had more of a lemony taste to it vs the first time I had it. 

Overall, it was a pretty awesome brunch. But if I had a choice, I'd avoid this place during the weekend! I think we just got lucky with the seating. It's probably easier during the weekdays!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
5 stars for the lemon ricotta pancakes and the eggs benedict! And those potatoes were fried to crispy perfection!

5 stars for the friendly staff (despite my annoying questions about the wait...everyone has a smile and the energy of people was cheerful)

Overall, a delicious brunch experience...just a little bit too long of a wait. Would definitely go back, but probably at 9am to avoid the rush.
author: Arel O.

description:
Holy cow this place is worth the flight to San Fran. 

We know there are plenty of great breakfast spots in this city, but we can't help but come here every time we visit. It's just that good. 

The eggs benny are like nothing else and the lemon pancakes are off the hook. Everything is piping hot and fresh. Our muffin was right out of the oven. Pure delight! 

I love the open kitchen style and the service is friendly and attentive. (Everyone on staff just happens to be a mega babe ... but I guess that's San Fran for you!)

If you get there and there's a wait, a really nice feature they have is self serve coffee. Even though I'm not a coffee drinker, my husband was super glad he was able to fill up a cup (and pay for it later with the meal) and sit on a bench outside. We lucked out that it was a lovely day! 

I did leave feeling uncomfortably full (my own fault!) but it was worth it and luckily we walked a ton that afternoon.
author: Kate S.

description:
After having Plow on my list of brunch places to try in SF, I was luckily able to convince my boyfriend to get up at an ungodly hour on a Saturday to venture over here with me. Why ungodly? Coming from Berkeley, we knew we had to get up, at the latest, by 06AM in order to make the commute via BART to Plow. You bet I would have been disappointed if this brunch wasn't any good. 

Sadly .. we still didn't make it by 08, hahaha (although to be fair, I was taking a little longer than I needed to get ready). We arrived around 8:45AM probably, and were told it would be a 45-60 min wait for two. There's not much to do around this neighborhood while you wait, sadly. You could walk a few blocks more to meet a freeway overpass (a little scary). There were a few shops around the area, but they were closed since it it was pretty early still. I think you get free coffee inside as you wait (I didn't get it myself .. because I didn't see it until we were already seated..).

We got our seats after about an hour, right at the counter. Pretty cool to watch the chefs pump out Plows like clockwork. It made waiting for our food not as bad! 

BF and I ordered:

+ The Plow (of course): the bacon was good, the potatoes were good, and the eggs (we got them poached) were also good, but the real winner (to me) was the lemon ricotta pancakes!!! 
+ Dungeness Crab Scramble: so happy this was on the menu on this visit :) I never imagined mixing crab with eggs, but it worked so well! I loved it. Also came with the potatoes, which I was really happy about because they were well-seasoned, and muy yummy :) 


Service was fast and efficient as it could be. 
Parking on the street, didn't look like it would be too hard to find, at least on a Sat morning. 
Restaurant is tiny, so yes, if you don't want to wait.. getting here early is important.
author: Ashley N.

description: I hate yelping... I am not a yelper... I'm even embarrassed to be on here, but, my experience at Plow kept popping up in my head and restaurants like these have to know that they are not infallible- my gf and I had friends in town and wanted to show them a good time, so, we decided to take them to the "best brunch spot" in SF... we all sort of thought we knew what we were in for, but not to this degree... when I arrived I was informed that our friends had put our name in about 20 minutes prior, and I(being the assertive fellow I am), decided to double check the time remaining which was originally quoted at 90 minutes... when I asked, the hostess stated "you've been here 10 minutes" in a not so nice tone but not exactly blatantly rude either... ok ok, I get it, I work in the business, I know what you're dealing with... I went back at least 4-5 times to talk to them, each time being quoted a longer time than the one before... once 2 hours rolled around and a 4 top was being dissected into 2(for some reason) we had had enough... my gf believes that people that they may have known(regulars, who knows) were being seated before us... I don't know about that but the overall attitude seemed to be "oh well bro"... the same hostess who seemed to have an attitude originally, said "if I had known(you would have been like this) I would have just told you 2 and half hours"... welp, like I said I'm in the business and I'm sorry but that IS what you do... under-promise and over-deliver... but, of course, if people will wait that long to eat there and still give them 5 stars then they probably don't give af what I think! But maybe someone will! I gave them 2 stars because we obviously left before we tried the food and I'm still a softy for any restaurant... to a point
author: Brian C.

description:
My two friends and I arrived for Sunday brunch at 9:35 and didn't get seated until close to 11.  Yes, the wait was long.  (The place is tiny; definitely not a place for large groups).  However, Plow's location in a charming neighborhood of coffee shops and boutiques gave us out-of-towners a nice way to pass the time as we waited for a table. We grabbed coffee at a nearby coffee shop and said "hi" to the occasional dog that sat outside the various cafes, patiently waiting for their owners.

And the wait was so worth it. 

Our food came quickly once we ordered. I had the eggs Benedict with smoked salmon. It was a very generous portion with a side of perfectly crispy potatoes. My friends and I also shared an order of the lemon ricotta pancakes. I'm generally not a fan of flavored pancakes, but these were the best pancakes I've had in recent memory -- perfect thickness, wonderfully soft in the inside, slightly crisp on the outside, with a subtle lemon zing. For meat lovers, I'd recommend the pork chops. The meat is tender and perfectly greasy; it was a favorite at the table.
author: Grace S.

description:
Saturday waiting is horrible!!! Get there early or be prepared to stand outside.
But once you're in, it's totally worth it. Yummy pork sausage patties... and the scrambled eggs are really nice, not dry & not too creamy
author: Kylie F.

description:
Solid spot for Sunday brunch, but not worth the 2 hour wait. Luckily you can put your name down and grab some coffee down the street... but still there are comparable brunch spots in SF.

I had the Soft Scrambled Eggs. The crispy potatoes (raved about on Yelp) were just ok. They are less greasy than your typical diner potatoes, but they lacked seasoning and salt. I had to put a lot of hot sauce and ketchup on them. They also come with a lot of fried skin, which may or may not be your thing. The eggs themselves were good but nothing to wait 2 hours for. They were soft as advertised. The feta flavor was subtle and didn't overpower the overall eggy flavor.

It's a small place with some outdoor seating. Ambiance is just average.
author: Mel C.

description:
Plow is top of my brunch list these days. 

Reasons why I will wait an HOUR for Plow: 
- Potatoes. Potatoes. Potatoes! There is a reason why it's on the 7x7 Big Eat list. Plow has my favorite breakfast potatoes yet. They are crispy, seasoned and sprinkled with onions! 
- Their eggs are cooked to perfection. The soft scrambled eggs are soft, the poached eggs are runny, and the fried egg sandwich has a slightly runny egg. 
- The bacon is thick and smoky, although I find the homemade sausage to be too lean (*gasp) and chewy. 

Unfortunately, it's closed on Mondays and sometimes the line outside will appear short but will actually be long. People tend to put their names down and wander around to pass the hour. It is a smaller place, so I recommend 4 or less in your party. Service can be a little spotty but the potatoes and hard working kitchen staff makes up for it. My favorite spot is at the counter!
author: Rachelle T.

description:
I discovered this through my friend a week before I moved away. 

Sad, because this is probably one of my favorite breakfast places on the planet. 

I've had the plow (drooooolll) and the fried egg sandwich (also drool). I don't know which one I like better and I don't know if I'll ever be able to figure it out, and I am perfectly OK with that. 

Come early, or wait a long time.
author: Emily D.

description:
"Hour and a half wait," says Randall.

"No worries, we'll wait it out," I told him. He smiled and handed me some coffee to pass the time. He also pointed down the street and shared a tip: "Rico makes some killer Bloody Marys. In case you're interested."

Of COURSE I'm interested, Randall. We wasted a good 45 minutes at Blooms Saloon, (http://www.yelp.com/biz/blooms-saloon-san-francisco#hrid:g60JAte3LvIB4-uJ8CCUXw) then headed back to wait out the remainder of the time. 

EATS
