+The Plow: two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes with pure maple syrup, and some crispy potatoes. The boy got his with the sugar pie pumpkin pancakes (instead of the lemon ricotta) and they were just as heavenly--if not better. We both opted for the bacon--and it was just OK; kinda smokey.

DRANKS
+Mimosas: watered down and not that great; especially not after that spicy Bloody Mary.
+Coffee: San Raf's finest, Equator coffee. Excellent.

Service was good, Randall made it great. Will I be back? Probably not, but happy to have tested it out to see what the hype was all about.
author: Adena B.

description:
Love this place! The food is delicious (and they do have lighter options for smaller appetites - try the smoked salmon & grapefruit salad) and they have blankets when it gets cold outside!

Tip: the lines get long (as in 1-2 hour wait) so show up at 9am (we waited 5 minutes!)
author: Sophie B.

description:
came on a Tuesday around 11am, there were about 5 parties ahead of us. ask them to put your name on the list. some people tried to just sit themselves onto open tables. it is not open seatings. they have little benches for you to sit on as you wait. they will ask if you prefer outdoor or inside seatings or whichever is first available. around after 12, the crowd dies down and not much of a wait. they are open till 2pm though and closed on Mondays. took around 20 mins to be seated. 

ordered the plow: 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, 2 eggs any style, crispy potatoes, and choice of home made pork sausage patties, bacon, or chicken sausage. I got sunny side up and bacon. the plate was a lot of for me and I couldn't finish. LB got the fried egg sandwich with added avocado, side order of pancakes and the pork sausage. he can eat and was not able to finish too. 

food was pretty good. not mind blowing. some of the potatoes are extra crispy like potato chips, egg yolks was small, bacon had a smokey taste, pancakes was alright. I made the mistake of eating that last and it has gotten cold. I do taste the hint of lemon. 

service was good. LB's coffee got refilled 3 times. they asked if you want water also, but we declined. When food arrives, waiter will ask if you need anything else like ketchup or hot sauce. they did not check up on us afterward. the food took a bit to come out, around 25 mins. so don't go hungry. 

a little pricey breakfast, but you're paying for the quality of the ingredients. their juices are not freshly squeezed though, came from bottled jugs. I got the grapefruit juice. Comes in small or large. 

plenty of parking around the neighbor. not metered. nice view as you wait. right off the 280 freeway.
author: Jules L.

description:
I finally got to try Plow last weekend with my bf. We got there around 10:30am and the wait lists were quite long already. We waited for an hour before we got seated. I'm an inpatient person, since I was willing to waited for an hour for my brunch. IT GOT TO BE GOOD FOOD. Also,It was cold in the morning, so it was very nice of Plow offered complimentary coffee   for people who were waiting to be seated.  

We ordered the Fried Egg Sandwiches with avocado and The Plow. We really enjoyed our food, specially, the crispy potatoes They were the best crispy potatoes that I had tried so far. The egg sandwiches was good but it can get  really messy as well. Tip: cut the sandwiches in half before chowing it down. 

It's delicious. Definitely, will go back and try the other dishes on the menu. Maybe try to go there earlier too just to avoid the long wait.
author: Stacy L.

description:
WOW. If you're up for a 1.5-2 hour wait for breakfast on the weekend, by all means - come to Plow. You really can't go wrong with the Plow breakfast: the potatoes are insane - cooked to perfection and delicious, the chicken sausage is flavorful and the ricotta pancakes are a little eggy, but fluffy and light nonetheless. The lemon zest flavor really sets them apart. The size of the meal was unexpectedly large - not one of us cleared our plates.

The only thing they're missing to make this breakfast perfection is a bloody mary!
author: Lauren C.

description: Long wait line, hostess doesn't know how to count her own wait list of people.  Told us the bar was included in the wait,  but started seating people walking in while I was waiting for over an hour and a half.   Ridiculous wait!
author: May T.

description:
There are so many wonderful things about this place.
First and foremost, the weekend brunch is quite delectable. Everything tastes amazing and you can see it being cooked right in front of you if you sit in the booth. I came here with a friend on a Saturday and we shared french toast, eggs benedict, and the dungeness crab scramble. Everything is tasty, delicious, and every other adjective you can think of for good food. Those crispy potatoes are quite something. So amazing. 
The french toast is served with ricotta cheese and (somehow) totally perfect strawberries. The eggs benedict has some amazing hollandaise sauce too--really lemony. The dungeness crab scramble. Wow. No additional words needed. Simply delicious.

There is a bit of a wait though, but I think it was totally worth it. It's in a cute neighborhood so you can take a bit of a stroll before you eat. Also a stroll after you overeat like I did. Plenty of parking nearby too! That's always a plus. 

The works are also super friendly and nice. Will definitely be coming back here to try other items on the menu. That fried egg sandwich looked amazing.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Serious brunching action at Plow. Very little fancy foodwork, just a singular focus on using high quality ingredients to make simple, high quality dishes. We had the egg sandwich (+bacon is a MUST), french toast w/ vanilla braised pears and mascarpone cheese, coffee cake, and lemon ricotta pancakes.  

The homestyle potatoes alone are worth coming here for - perfect amount of salt and savory seasonings, then fried with onions until they're all encased in a crispy shell without being greasiness. The little bits at the end are sheer happiness.

The lemon ricotta pancakes are semisweet and have a fresh, light lemon essence without any bitterness. Definitely try these.

The french toast is very traditional, and while it was delicious, the thickness of the slices made the inside slightly soggy, and the mascarpone cheese didn't shine through. Admittedly I approached these a little critically as I was comparing it to the french toast l'orange at Snooze. 

Coffee cake was well made, but nothing too special. 

Overall, excellent brunch spot. Prices come to about $10-20 per person, which is reasonable for the quality of the food.
author: James W.

description:
Lemon ricotta pancakes, pork sausage patties, scrambled eggs and the most amazing potatoes I think I've ever had. 

I don't give 5 star ratings flippantly. But, breakfast at 1:30 in the afternoon with outdoor seating on a crisp autumn day was just what the doctor ordered. 

Service was on point, and the food came out amazingly fast. 

I wish I knew how they made those potatoes. What's their secret?
author: K W.

description: Amazing! We absolutely loved this place! The decor was super cute, totally my style. I got the crab scramble with toast and home fries. It was better than expected, the crab didn't overwhelm the eggs and didn't taste super fishy. The flavors blended perfectly. My boyfriend got the shirred eggs and my mind was blown. Seriously, holy shit. The flavors were incredible, the tomato sauce went surprisingly well in the dish. We almost went there again for breakfast the next day
author: Shannon D.

description: This is THE BEST brunch spot in town! The only downside is you are going to have to wait between 30 min to two hours for a table and they don't take reservations. I have had most things on the menu and you really can't go wrong, but I think the best thing to get is "the plow" because it comes with a little bit of their best foods! I also always get a biscuit on the side because they are to die for! The service is great and the staff is friendly. Overall, great spot!
author: Lauren P.

description:
This is one place that seriously lives up to all the hype. Hello...Lemon Ricotta Pancakes! I not even a huge pancake fan but these things killed Mama's and Dotties pancakes. Yes, that's right...they're better than both Mama's and Dotties. (Dear Dottie, I love you too, so don't worry I'll be back)

The eats - I had The Plow. It's a great plate that gives you two silver dollar sized lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, crispy potatos (wow) and your choice of meat. 

Service - Great, everyone is really friendly and seemed to be happy. The wait wasn't even too bad for a Saturday morning. I think we only had to wait 30 minutes which is pretty fast considering how busy this place gets.

Atmosphere - I love the open kitchen concept and enjoy watching the chefs prepare food. The decor itself is warm, modern and bright.
author: Leanne S.

description: I am almost afraid to write a review for this place out of fear that it's going to get even more popular. It's absolutely delicious food - so well thought out and well executed. The service was also impeccable (which is sometimes very hit and miss in San Francisco). The lemon ricotta pancakes were some of the best I've ever had (and I'm one of those people who must have them if they're on a menu, so I have a good basis for comparison). Will go again...
author: Suzy W.

description: I'm not impressed after 1.30 hr+ wait. The eggs Benedict were good; but not out of the world. The French toast was subpar. And very inefficient waiting system.
author: Lyn X.

description: If you are brave enough to wait through those long longs on weekends (and weekdays for that matter), you are in for a treat.  Their breakfast is amazing.  Those potatoes and lemon ricotta pancakes and French Toast are my favs.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Over rated , I had a rude server. Who said "I will talk to the machine!" When I said my tea wasn't hot. Initially when we were ready to order she said "you have to wait I have a system" and then when I asked for honey she practically threw it on the table 
Food quality has gone down as well, the pancakes were not tasty and the Benedict was sub par
author: babak h.

description:
SO SO SOO AMAZING! This is my new favorite brunch place. My friend and I came on a Thursday around 12 noon so there was only a five minute wait, but that's probably nothing compared to how long it is on the weekends. I can't even imagine how crazy it is then. As for the food, we both ordered "The Plow" which consists of their:

-silver dollar lemon ricotta pancakes - I'm not normally a fan of pancakes, but these blew my mind! Probably my favorite out of everything on my plate. Eat them slowly and just taste all the flavors in these light and fluffy pancakes! Still thinking about them...so good!
-crispy potatoes - all I can say is crispy and oh-so-delicious, just the way I like it. 
-nueske bacon - can't go wrong with bacon. 
 
I'll definitely be coming back to try the almond flour pancakes and french toast!
author: Shannon L.

description:
Came here for breakfast and got the egg sandwich and it was uhhh-mazing. The bacon was perfectly crisp and the egg came runny. The lemon ricotta pancakes are pretty good too, but the ricotta can get slightly overwhelming after a bit. 

A quite hefty breakfast, but totally worth it. A cute spot to start the morning.
author: Angela K.

description:
Bow to Plow! I would dare to say that this is the BEST place for brunch in San Francisco. The wait is usually long, however it is definitely worth it! While waiting I would recommend going to get some coffee at Farley's which is a block away and their coffee is bomb! 
Perfect place for Sunday brunch and mimosas !
author: Victoria L.

description:
I have to say that I am not sure what the grand luster is for Plow, but I gave in last week and hunkered down for an hour to find out.  I am always a fan when a restaurant knows they have long lines for tables and offer coffee or drinks while you wait to help pass the time more pleasantly.  I saw some folks starting up with mimosas before their tables were ready - that's the spirit! It is brunch after all...

Décor is simple, clean, and as open as it can be for the modest sized restaurant.  I felt it was borderline industrial, but with a country, rustic charm.

Their menu changes daily, if I remember the waitress correctly.  My party opted for eggs benedict with ham and I selected gluten free pancakes with a side of bacon.  I must say, the star of our plates were their breakfast potatoes! Are those rolled in crack?  I am just sayin' if any restaurant wants to know how to properly cook a breakfast potato they should take a lesson because Plow's are AMAZING!  The seasoning is delicious, not spicy but flavorful that goes deep into the hearty potato wedges.  Once rolled in their seasoning, I assume, the spuds are deep fried for a golden, crispy skin that keeps the potato soft and delicious inside.  My mouth is watering as I write this review thinking about the potatoes.  I am lucky my breakfast buddy shared because my pancakes came solo.  I would put those spuds on all plates, everyone deserves to have them!

My pancakes were so light and fluffy it was perfect.  I have tried a lot of GF pancakes, but these were delicious with a little sweetness to them without any syrup.  I did use my syrup sparingly, but they don't even need it.  Excellent texture and flavor for even a regular pancake.  Even my non-GF friend enjoyed the pancakes.

I cannot attest to the eggs benedict other than I am told the sauce was a little lemony on the initial hit to the palette but didn't finish with that flavor, so it was complex enough to be interesting and enjoyable without being smacked by lemon.

Overall, if you have time to kill, I suggest making it happen because it is a beautiful neighborhood, there is good coffee while you wait, and people watching is at your disposal.  After a morning run or sleeping in it is a good way to start the day.
author: Mandy L.

description:
I love this place!
The food is great and the space is awesome! 
When I come here I ALWAYS get the Plow and the lemon ricotta pancakes are such a treat. 
A great place to bring out of town guests.
I would give it 5  stars if the wait wasn't that LONG. It can be frustrating but once you are seated and you get your delish food all is forgotten.
author: Schisandra S.

description:
Waited 45 minutes and ordered "The Plow." 

The Plow ($16) : 2 eggs, choice of pork sausage, bacon, OR chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes.

Got seated outside on a cold morning. You can ask them for blankets since there's no patio heaters outside.

No tobasco sauce here. Only serve Youk's hot sauce -- wasn't that spicy for me.

Everything was good, but wasn't a big fan of the lemon ricotta pancakes as I thought I would've been. Customer service was attentive and friendly.
author: B. R.

description:
I had an impromptu visit to Plow since I work around the area. I was looking at places to eat for breakfast and stumbled upon this beauty! I called beforehand to pick up my meal. I had to park pretty far to get breakfast, but it was definitely worth it! 

This breakfast had to be the best ever. I had gotten their house plate and it was truly an experience.The pancakes were perfectly cooked and the eggs so fluffy! 

Can't wait to try it again! 

By the way, it's really much easier to take it to go. But I guess if you're visiting the City I would suggest having that experience! The restaurant is very small but definitely worth the wait!
author: Elaine M.

description:
I was only in town for a few days, and luckily my friend lives in Potrero and knew about this amazing breakfast and brunch spot.
The decor was relaxed and inviting, the staff were warm and welcoming, and the food was amazing.
I had the two eggs, chicken apple sausage, and potatoes, and I could not have asked for anything more delicious or filling. I am a big breakfast person, especially considering we were going to head over to Anchor for a tour, but I didn't come close to finishing my plate here! The potatoes were fried so crispy, yet still tender on the inside, and they were seasoned so well! The chicken Apple sausage seemed as fresh as when I make my own sausage from scratch back home! The toast was a very thick cut slab of Acme bread that just could not be compared to anything else.
My friends had the ricotta pancakes which were light and tart, not too sweet. And the salmon toast which was lighter fare, but still filling.
Overall, it was a wonderful start to a day of touring around SF, and I will make it a point to go here anytime I am in town!
author: R F.

description:
Perfect breakfast spot. Love the atmosphere and the menu is great - variety but not an overwhelming number of options. We were a group of four; arrived 8:30 on a Saturday and were seated by 9:15. Coffee with refills while we waited! 

After some rave reviews from the woman at the table next to us (a few too many mimosas by her own admission), we all ordered a version of Eggs Benedict. Perfectly poached eggs, crispy potatoes, and the right amount of sauce. Highly recommend!
author: Laura M.

description: This breakfast joint seems to be mainly a locals place, so since there are no reservations, be prepared to wait 45 - 90 minutes. Get your name on the list and take a morning walk in the area. I'm partial to breakfast places to do it right, and they do it right! We ordered about 8 times off the menu and they were all awesome!
author: Chris M.

description:
Have eaten at Plow about 15 or 20 times -  including with partner who's very perspicacious about food (i just had to see if i could write out that word).

Consistently intelligent, upbeat, friendly service. Consistently intelligent, upbeat, friendly food.

The salads are healthy and dee-lightful as well as the egg dishes and more. The menu varies enough to keep it interesting.

Farley's Coffee House has indoor and outdoor parklet seating and is just a crosswalk + a few doors up 18th Street (on same side of street). Farley's is a relaxed close-by spot you can hang out at during the long wait for seating at Plow.

Staff has been accurate in estimating wait times. And you can often cut your wait time by eating at the counter where you get to watch the amazing staff prepare the really good food.
author: David G.

description: They have a one of the first policy and first customer service. You cant seat without all people comes. i never see this kind of policy. and Service lady was rude person.. Sucks place and food is not good...
author: Baki T.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!!!!!! 

My husband took me here on a date when we were dating and we automatically fell in love.....not only with plow but also with each other. 

Everybody and I mean everybody that works and eats here are amazing. Yeah you have to wait a bit but who cares!!!!! The food is great and the coffee is bomb.com
author: Samantha L.

description:
Date & Time:  Friday September 24, 2010 @ 12:30pm
Dining Companions:  Mommy & Husband
Scene:  Small Groups of 30-40 Somethings:  Ladies in Little Summer or  Vintage Dresses & Guys in Ironic Slogan Tee's   
Vibe:  Energetic
Decor:  Urban w/ Country Charm.  Bright Airy Space w/ Bench Seating, Tables for Four & Counter-Seating w/ View of Open Kitchen
Service:  Very Nice & Sincere
Imbibe:  Stewart's Orange Cream Soda & Mexican Cola
Devour:  Roast Pork Sandwich on Acme Bun w/ House Made Pickles, Grilled Gruyere Cheese Sandwich w/ Oven-Dried Tomatoes, BLT.  All Sandwiches Served w/ Choice of Green Salad or Herb Roasted Potatoes.  Dessert of The Day:  Pear Galette
Total:  $41.72
author: Genevieve Y.

description: Amazing staff and food. Can't give a full 5 stars because our car was broken into right outside the restaurant! So many valuables taken  not even the amazing plow food could make up for it
author: Hanna E.

description: We are VERY lucky at finding some of the best breakfast places everywhere we go and Plow is definitely on that list.  After reading all (ok some of) the reviews we went prepared for the big wait.  Luckily for us we got in at just the right time with only a 10 minute wait before being seated and beginning our tantalizing breakfast journey.  Of course I had to get the Plow breakfast and boyfriend got the breakfast sandwich.  DELICIOUS ugh I'm craving it just remembering.  Although all the food was outstanding I think we both were surprised by the potatoes.  How do they do that?  They were like baked and fried at the same time - very good!  The pancakes of course stood out too they were very tasty.  Just try it!
author: Bianca A.

description:
Been here twice, both times were to take friends visiting the area. It's good, with all the other amazing breakfast/brunch places in SF, I may skip this place next time.

What I've tried:
LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES: First time I had this, I didn't enjoy it. Second time was much better.

FRIED EGG SANDWICH: My only grip with this dish is the bun used. I guess I'm picky about my carbs....

SOFT SCRAMBLED EGGS: asparagus, oyster mushrooms, goat cheese. One of my favorites from Plow --I would reorder next time I visit.

EGGS BENEDICT: I got the spinach/mushroom combo. The english muffin must be bought at a nearby bakery --thicker than your usual. Flavor was a little lacking, would pass on this for the SOFT SCRAMBLED EGGS.

Of course, the CRISPY POTATOES are as good as everyone says it is.

PARKING: If you come at the right time, you should be able to find street parking.

FIRST TIMER? Walk through the crowds near the entrance and put your name down with a staff. Expect to wait at least 45 min on weekends. There's bar and table seating inside, as well as a handful of tables outside.
author: Sunny W.

description:
Based on their infamous long wait-times, I was really hoping Plow would suck and I wouldn't have to continue to plot ways to survive the line. Unfortunately, Plow fully and completely won me over. Two hour wait for some of their crispy breakfast potatoes? Sign me up.

After rushing over and putting my name in at 9am on a Saturday morning, I proceeded to pick a friend up at the airport and by the time we made it back, our name had already been called. First thought was: NOOOOOOOOO. Fortunately, being the awesome servers they are, the Plow peeps sat us right away at an awesome table outside! At this point, I was already sold.

We both ordered "The Plow," based on excited reviewers who claimed this was the first-timer's MUST ORDER. The eggs were definitely just your average eggs, but boy the lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy breakfast potatoes were something SPECIAL. If you're dying to try the pancakes, but also want to (/NEED TO) try the potatoes, the Plow was definitely a good way of getting the best of both worlds.

Definitely go early and put your name in with an hour - two hour interim plan and definitely try the potatoes.
author: Rachel L.

description: The 4.5 stars doesn't do any justice to this place. 5 Stars by far!!! Everything is so clean and fresh tasting!  My wife and I are from SF and we have eaten just about everywhere here. This place is right at the top. Plow = Yummy!!!!
author: John W.

description:
Do I need to say more?

If you come here, just get the lemon ricotta pancakes!

We got the plow and the tuscan kale salad. Both were delicious. The lemon ricotta pancakes have a strong lemon flavor, which I like. It very distinct and the pancakes are fluffy and soft.

I came here on a weekday and the wait was not long. 

So it looks like a lot of food but I actually feel like it's not a lot of food compared to other brunch places (ie Zazies). The food is good though! This places reminds me of restaurants/chefs who perfect their dishes and only give you a little of it to try to satisfy your palette (like what you see on iron chef)! The portions are decent though, but you won't leave here super stuffed and full, just satisfied!!
author: Margaret L.

description:
I love when great things move into Potrero Hill. Although you will probably have a very long line for weekend brunch, it's absolutely worth it. The space is small so I would suggest going with a small group of people.

My boyfriend and I headed over to Plow a bit late on a Sunday. We got there at 1pm and were told that we were just about borderline on whether we would get in before it closed or not. But, after 35min, we had a place at the bar, overlooking a chef's kitchen. We marveled at the organization that Chef Maxine had in her kitchen. People owned their stations and passed plates around with amazing speed. Granted, they have a few kinks to work out, but hey, they have only been open a week. No doubt they will get there very soon. But the speed and efficiency with which they work through their constant steam of orders is pretty amazing. 

By the time we got there, they were out of a lot of things. Lucky for us, the things that we wanted were still available. The boy had a pulled pork sandwich and I had the egg sandwich to which I added bacon. Greatest decision ever. Together, the bill was just under $22. And both were fantastic. I can't speak for the pulled pork, because it was gone before I had a chance to ask for a bit. So I assume that it was delicious. The egg sandwich was one of the best I have ever had. I know it's just an egg sandwich but the ingredients blended together perfectly. The egg was done over easy and the yoke was the perfect gooey-ness. Together with the greens, cheese and aoli, it was amazing. 

And of course, the potatoes. Just about every non-french toast or pancake dish comes with potatoes. And they are fantastic. Amazing. The waiter brought us ketchup and hot sauce but it would have been a total waste to use them. The potatoes stood on their own. I love a place where condiments are a waste of table space. 

On top of all of this, the service was great. Friendly and professional, they keep customers happy while running the restaurant as well. With the fast paced floor that they manage, they still had time to laugh and make jokes with us. Even the chef, as exhausted as she was, came to chat with us for 2min in between orders. And at the very end, when they caught us talking about the lemon cake that was on the counter, they gave us a complimentary taste. It's that kind of service that wins the hearts of a neighborhood. 

All in all, I think Potrero Hill has a new gem. I can't wait to go back.
author: Mariko F.

description:
Great spot for breakfast in SF! We stopped here on a brief visit to the city, and it was well worth the wait 

The lemon ricotta pancakes were amazing and the crispy potatoes are a-maz-ing. 

It was 20 minutes on a Thursday, so I'm thinking the weekend is a nightmare. I'd recommend getting there early.
author: Sarah G.

description:
3.5 stars.

THE WAIT: About 40 minutes around 12:30p on a Saturday. 

THE FOOD: 
|| THE PLOW: 4 stars: Lemon Ricotta pancakes were sweet, full of lemony flavor & fluffy. The crispy potatoes were PERFECT, as they were crispy on the outside, yet retained the potato texture and flavor on the inside (I hate when a crispy potato becomes unrecognizable in flavor other than a fried mess)! The pork sausage was good. The scrambled eggs was unfortunately disappointing because it was soggy. 

|| DUNGENESS CRAB SCRAMBLE: 3 stars: The eggs were again soggy, but the scramble preserved the crab flavor. Good dish if you really like crab without much flavoring added to it. 

PARKING: Lots of parking, since it is Potrero Hill, your car will likely be parked at a 45 degree angle. 

ATMOSPHERE: Small restaurant with cute, clean decor (pottery barn-esque). Seating is limited inside and our table of 2 was awkwardly super close to the table next to us (so censor your conversations :P). 

SERVICE: Friendly and with a smile.
author: Emily C.

description: A rare breakfast experience with a staff that makes the atmosphere warm.  Plus GF pancakes!
author: John E.

description: I am a mega breakfast and brunch fan and this is my favorite breakfast place I have ever been! Breakfast meats and eggs prepared perfectly and all of the waffle and pancake type items tasted and looked great as well! Just be prepared to wait on the weekend if that is when you decide to go. Get the "Plow" which is a combo of all of the best things and you'll be set!
author: Nathan B.

description:
Lucky I live in the neighborhood-
Food is not worth 2 hours like the usual wait but maybe 40 minutes.  
Anyhow the Lemon Ricotta pancakes, chia seed pudding, egg sandwich, biscuit and potatoes are all super tasty. Overall a good brunch spot to go to-not frequently but maybe once of twice a year if you live in the city to be honest.
author: Lynn J.

description: 3.8/5 stars. Solid breakfast/brunch spot. The prosciutto and Gruyere toast is divine. The lemon ricotta pancakes are melt in your mouth good as everyone recommends. Get the Plow so you get a full hearty eggs, sausage and potatoes to go with it. Favorite part: the potatoes included the crispy bits at the bottom of the pan that I love to scrape off and eat myself, but much better done here. Wish coffee selection was a bit better. A cappuccino would've been a nice compliment but a-ok drip coffee suits, too. Long lines...good spot, but I probably wouldn't wait longer than 30-40 min for it.
author: Viv T.

description:
Perfect breakfast. Absolutely perfect. 

Their breakfast potatoes and homemade sausage should be on your list of things to eat here. The portions are extremely generous- I had to bring some home because I wasn't able to finish my entire meal.

Service could be a bit more attentive, but the quality of the food here more than makes up for it.
author: Natahlie B.

description: The wait here can sometimes be ridiculous, which may put people off. Do not come here during peak brunch times or your wait will be at least 1.5 hours. The highlight of the meal were the potatoes. So whatever you get here, just make sure it comes with a side of potatoes. Other than that the food is your standard SF brunch food
author: Derrick W.

description: Great breakfast despite the hour wait for a table. Great house made sausage, crisp potatoes and Lemon Ricotta pancakes. Also had great service
author: David S.

description: The lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes are just incredible. I had The Plow, and while I was not especially impressed by the pork sausage patties or eggs, I was absolutely blown away by the rest of the plate. We waited for quite awhile on a cold Saturday morning (seriously, that wait!), but once we got inside, the restaurant was beautifully bright and adorable. Perfect place for brunch if you're willing to wait!
author: Kelly R.

description:
My cousin and I came to the Plow a few months ago, and I believe it was  Friday morning. We had to wait about an hour, but it wasn't a big deal because we walked down the street to this super cute coffee spot and the wait went by super quick. 

The restaurant is small and quaint, one of those small, cozy (as another yelper said) restaurant. It has a lot of bright open space, so if you're feeling a little vampirey and antisocial not wanting to share your space, I suggest you do not go here! Lol, onto the food.

I ordered the lemon ricotta pancakes and she order the plow which comes with two eggs, chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes. We basically split everything, and I finished my own set of pancakes. The pancakes were so light and fluffy, but you could taste the lemon and ricotta in every bite - exactly how it should be, right? Everything in my cousin's dish was delicious - the crispy potatoes .... to die for. The chicken apple sausage was yummy as well. 

Bottom line - it was a fun experience. Good food, good service topped with a beautiful sunny day in SF. But since I was having a leisurely day and not pressed on time, I was okay with waiting the hour to be seated. I wouldn't wait an hour if I had other things to do - i thought this was important to add :)
author: Kathleene E.

description: I don't know what else to say other than incredible. Everything was absolutely delicious. Do yourself a favor and get the plow. I was skeptical about the chicken sausage but it was perfect. I would eat here daily if I lived anywhere remotely close. Just go.
author: Tim L.

description:
I absolutely LOVED this place. I highly recommend getting "the plow" your first time there. You get a good assortment of different items on the menu (sausage, pancakes, exquisite potatoes, eggs).  The LEMON RICOTTA pancakes were just divine. I'm still dreaming about them...

My bf had the egg sandwich with bacon added. He claims it was the best egg sandwich he's ever had. 

The wait was a bit long (about 45 min at around 9am on a sunday) however, you can get a cup of coffee to sip on while you wait. I liked that, especially since it was a bit chilly when i went. And the host was just a doll, very nice lady :)

Also extra stars for the awesome busboy that brought my pup a bowl of water! 

I can't wait to go back!!!
author: Gina G.

description:
3.5 solid stars

Such a cute, quaint venue! Love brunch! We came on a weekday, so the wait wasn't too bad. 

Service was slow, but coffee was good. Open kitchen if you sit by the bar. 
French toast: 3.5/5 Generous portion--delicious! I recommend sharing this plate!
Plow: 3/5 I usually don't like cooked citrus, but their lemon ricotta pancakes were delicious

Will definitely be back if the wait is not too long and if I am in the area!
author: Jen H.

description:
This breakfast is one of the best you will ever eat. Fresh local bought food. Great service. Highly recommend the monte cristo. If your in the area it would be a travesty to not stop by. 

Locals are such die hard fans that you will see them eating outside in the cold and rain.   You will just want more after youve gotten your fill.
author: Izaak W.

description:
Came here at 9am and was still hit with a 45min wait. Pretty modest at Plow. But once inside, the atmosphere was modern, yet cozy. We were seated at a table meant for two, so it was a little cramped, but we made it work. FYI though, Plow does not seat for parties more than 6 people.

I opted for The Plow ($16) which came with 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, 4 modest sized chicken/apple sausages, 2 eggs done your preference, and breakfast potatoes. The pancakes were so heavenly...like biting into a meyer lemon cupcakes. It was more dense than I imagined, but still very delicious. The potatoes are done to a crisp and has some sauteed onions mixed into it. It was really good, but some of the pieces were very large and too potato-y for my liking.

All in all, the meal was very delicious and filling. Seriously, it's been over 4 hours and I still feel stuffed...
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Plow is great.  The food is delicious + the space (though tight) is well done.  

Expect to wait.  Beverages are expensive (and small), but the food is consistent and generally worth the wait. 

My personal favorite is the BLT with their thick cut bacon when it's on the menu.  I recommend skipping the salad and going for the potatoes - they do not disappoint!

I am docking a star for the following reason:  
I have ordered their fried egg sandwich with the eggs medium to hard (typically served soft, but I'm pregnant and raw eggs are on the 'avoid' list) twice now with the same result. . . the sandwich I am served has both times had super soft fried eggs.  As in, dripping to the point I can't even pretend they're medium.  I never send food back (it pains me to do so), but I had to this time.  They remake the sandwich without hesitation, but there has never been even an inkling of an apology; I get a more of a 'I'm putting them out' vibe.  Both times, by the time I receive my new sandwich, my friends are finished or nearly finished with their meal and then they're waiting on me which is a bummer.  An apology or even a gesture of an apology would have made things better on both occasions.

Though disappointed 2x, I will return!
author: Jen D.

description: Long wait - but well worth the wait! The honey butter biscuits, the eggs, the country fried potatoes, I don't think you could go wrong with anything on the menu. Great service and they provide blankets when it's chilly outside. Definitely recommended!!
author: Zarlakhta W.

description:
I was craving a very good breakfast, flying in the night before and dodging all the Black Friday madness of everyone shopping my cousin and her husband brought us here for a good start to our day. Lacking sleep already and a night of turkey I needed something to bring a good morning 'ring' to my day as I was tired, and mediocre was not going to do, thankfully I have a cousin who knows about food, and still remembering from years before on how she took me to places, I could put my faith in her to deliver.

She said that this place usually has line-ups going up the block (as this place is located on a hill), so to get here early, we arrived at 8 AM, the place was not empty, but it wasn't packed, probably being a holiday. It was a charming little place with real high ceilings, very bright white walls, defined by natural wood tables. It's a very happy, bright look, with the open kitchen concept that seems standard nowadays with new restaurants.

Once we sat down, we were presented the menu, and looking at that pageful of items to order, the problem was to decide on what to order. From pancakes, eggs, bacon, granola, sandwiches and salads, everything looked so good. My cousin and her husband had 'the Plow' which consists of two eggs, two pancakes, and they decided on the Nueske bacon. My partner ordered the lemon ricotta pancakes and I decided on the corned beef hash with yukon gold potatoes, chillies, and two eggs. As it wasn't that busy when we were here, the orders came quite quickly.

Speaking on my dish of hash browns, this was pefectly done, little bits of pefectly cooked potatoes mixed with strands of corned beef, and this was the stuff on the bottom of the plate. You could taste the freshness of the ingredients mixed with some chili to provide a kick, this was under the two sunny side eggs that were laid on top of the hash, welcoming me to breakfast like a set of eyes. Two small pieces of bread were laid on the top side of the eggs and I was ready to devour like a monster looking at this thing. My partner's pancakes were fluffy and had a good dense chew. I remember a smile everytime I took a bite, and I also remember my partners fork constantly coming over to my plate picking at little pieces of potato and meat.

Another thing that was damn good was the bacon here, whatever farmer they are getting this stuff from, it's like crack. I love the look that my partner had when she took a bite. One of those breakfast joints that if I was to be back in San Francisco I would check it out. From what I heard from my cousin, come early, or wait, but when was waiting for good food wrong.
author: Simon K.

description: My wife have eaten at Plow 8 times in the last 3 years- all breakfasts/brunch on weekends. We are somewhat automatic in what order: lemon ricotta pancakes, almond flour pancakes, and several times the French toast. On two occasions, I  have personally order The Plow. We generally get there early- between 8am to 8:30am, so that we do not have to wait in line. After 9am, you expect to wait in line about 10 mins to 30 mins depending on the size of your party. What we've always enjoyed about Plow is its consistency with how simple and how good their food is. The service is pretty good and fairly quick. Surprisingly enough, we've never had any challenges with finding parking within 2 blocks.
author: Al G.

description:
Warning: waiting in line for plow on a weekend will make you completely hangry but it's worth it! 

Came here for the second time this past weekend. Learning from my past visit to plow, I knew the wait was going to be absolutely ridic so I held back my stank face when the host told me the wait was going to be an hour and 45 min. To keep your sanity, go run errands or grab some coffee while you wait. 

Here's what we had:
- soft scramble (A-): perfectly scrambled eggs with asparagus, mushrooms, and goat cheese. I love the goat cheese in the scramble, gives the scramble a nice creamy finish. 
- fried egg sandwich (A+) added a pork sausage patty: I've had the sandwich without the pork patty and life is better with meat!
- the side of potatoes (A++): this is pretty much the crowned jewel of plow. The potatoes are super crunchy and cooked to perfection. I can adamantly say that these are the best "homefries" that I've had.
- side of lemon ricotta pancake (A): light, fluffy, and a little citrusy. Perfect to share with your dining companions.
author: Grace Y.

description:
My husband and I waited quite some time to eat breakfast here on a Saturday morning. We arrived at 9 AM and were met with a one-hour wait, which we never tend to mind. We sat at the bar and it was fun to watch the cooks prepare the orders (also a good way to decide on different menu items because you can see them being prepared).

We got the Plow, which is their breakfast plate. It includes two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, and choice of meat. The pancakes were an absolute standout. My husband is the meat eater between the two of us and said the house-made pork sausage patty was delightful. We also shared a biscuit with honey butter and enjoyed it immensely!

Be aware that the menu items were pricey. We paid $4.50 for the biscuit, which felt high (especially compared to other restaurants where we typically get a biscuit on the side). Would highly recommend and would go back!
author: Roxanne S.

description: My favorite restaurant in the city. And that's saying a lot! The breakfast sandwich and crispy potatoes are unlike anything else. The wait time quoted on weekend mornings are typically at least 45 mins. I don't mind when I go in prepared to wait though. Both indoor and outdoor seating available. I've never had an issue with street parking here.
author: Alias A.

description:
Yummy potatoes ! Great food. Nice ambience. A favorite for breakfast.
I also like the rapport between the chefs. It appears that these people enjoy working here. Good. 
But however seriously long lines. I waited 2 hours several times :(
If not for the delicious food -- I would never wait this long. 
They need to take reservations
author: Pilates G.

description:
Came in at 9am on a Saturday and we were told it was going to be an hour and a half wait (be prepared to wait that long, specially on the weekends). We live conveniently close to Plow so we put our name on the waiting list, went home and got ready and came back, and they had just started calling my name. 

The lemon ricotta pancakes were exquisite alongside the dungeness crab eggs which were also bomb. Definitely will be coming back again!
author: Carla T.

description:
Let me say the ONE and only bad thing about this place--the lemon ricotta pancakes.  I'm sorry, but it tasted like old lemon cake.  The consistency was wrong and the flavor was too sweet, not tangy enough--and just off.  

I was going to ask to see if we could sub for the Almond pancakes, but I forgot....damn.

The coffee? Delicious. The french toast.  Oh god, the french toast was sooo good.  The potatoes were fried well.  The fried egg sandwich--delicious delicious delicious.  The poached eggs? Perfectly cooked.  

The wait is long--about 30 minutes for Sat around noonish.  There is a cute bookstore about a block or so away if you want to walk around.
author: Aly A.

description: This place was great! Even their orange juice was so delicious! Definitely coming back. My favorite was the french toast and crispy potatoes. Be prepared to wait in line.
author: Katherine R.

description:
Get here early, and still be prepared to wait. It's a small restaurant but they turn the tables quickly. 
The food is amazing! I had the eggs Benedict with salmon and it was great. The crispy potatoes are prepared perfectly and the lemon ricotta pancake is a MUST! Share it with your table mates - it's the perfect combination of lemon, ricotta, and pancake! It's how empty carbs and calories are meant to taste!
author: Joshua S.

description: If you can stand the waiting in line, then definitely try it. Lemon ricotta pancakes and the potatoes are something you wouldn't want to miss.
author: E U.

description:
I came here on a Saturday morning before the giants game.  Arrived around 9 and the wait was less than 20 minutes for two.   

Service was friendly and attentive. 
Restaurant itself was clean and cozy. 
Food:

1. pastries - good
2. French Toast - good 
3. Bacons - good
4. The plow - great value, my fav was their sausage patties and the lemon ricotta pancake ( too big for one person, share it)
5. Their pacific pepeminit tea goes great with the frech toast!
author: Wasabi L.

description: Classic brunch shop. Everything was so fresh. My only complaint is that the space there is extremely intimate, I definitely felt crammed in there!
author: Magdalene K.

description: Average food. High priced. Super long wait. Waited almost two hours for a noise crowded diner like environment. Stay of you're a foodie but if you're entertaining visitors, go somewhere else. One of those go once in a lifetime but never go back again places. Kinda like pinks in la
author: deejay w.

description: The best place we ate on our trip to San Francisco. We stayed for a week and were all over the city. We had several breakfasts and a few fancy dinners but plow was the absolute best. It was our last meal before heading to the airport, but had we stayed longer we would have revisited a second time. We enjoyed everything about our meal, the service, and the ambiance of this small community restaurant. I am looking forward to revisiting the city just for a chance to revisit Plow.
author: Adam H.

description: Wonderful meal, wonderful service and this lemon ricotta pancakes... Amazing!!! If you are in the neighborhood, or even if you need to drive a little, don't miss this gem.
author: Karen M.

description:
On a warm weekend morning when you have at least 5 hours to spare, there's nothing like driving to Potrero Hill to get plowed.

Plow prepares the best breakfast in San Francisco, and absolutely everyone knows it. We began waiting in line for breakfast around 11 AM...and by the time we got a seat, it was almost time for dinner. Ways to make yourself feel better about the delay: they provide free coffee and the classic SF 90 degree hill above the restaurant has parking vacancies. Bring your mountain climbing gear to reascend to your vehicle.

Plow achieves equal prowess with the sugary and the salty: they offer both the best French toast in town and the best standard breakfast in "the plow." The soft scrambled eggs with goat cheese and oyster mushrooms, while boldly priced at $15, is the bronze medal dish. Don't be ashamed to order yourself two dishes. You earned it by walking up and down the hill 20 times before being seated.

Last time I went here, the next door building caught on fire--presumably an act of arson by a starving patron trying to cook their own sausages in the street. The fire truck roared onto the scene and parked parallel to the outside tables. The firefighters jumped out in formation, posing for a moment like TV show firefighters awaiting exaltation, then sadly grabbed their hoses and walked away when they realized nobody had stopped eating. That's the kind of food you're signing up to enjoy.
author: Lou S.

description: First time coming here and I will for sure be back. I'm always a sucker for potatoes/hash browns and they honestly have the best potatoes by far! Went on a Tuesday at 12pm and there was no wait which was nice. Ordered the plow * came with mini pancakes and they were so yummy! This place is also insta worthy for those people looking for a cute Instagram restaurant!
author: Julie T.

description:
I loved my breakfast here!  

If you can, enjoy breakfast here during the week, as it is less crowded and a great way to start your day.  My favorite part of the breakfast was getting to see the chef prepare the meal and seeing the owner send her kids off to school with healthy, homemade lunches.

Definitely worth a visit if you haven't yet been!
author: Mary L.

description:
Those CRISPY POTATOES, though!!! They were the star of our meal. I would recommend them to anyone with functioning taste buds, because seriously, who wouldn't appreciate the perfect crisp that complements that nice, soft yet dense interior? Coming to Plow and not ordering those crispy potatoes is like going to Ike's and not ordering a sandwich. You just can't. Respect your body by giving it the best possible version of potatoes one could possibly eat for breakfast (permutations of dinner potatoes are a different story). I liked sitting at the bar and seeing all the work that goes into making the food.  

regarding the wait: don't be intimidated. Who are you kidding? It's the 21st century, and we all have things to do while waiting. Catch up with friends, do your grocery shopping, instagram, call your grandma, read a book, give out-of-towners a tour of the Mission, just do whatever you'd normally do and be rewarded with a beautiful breakfast by the end of it! I put my name down at 11:30am on a Saturday and was told the wait was going to be 2 hours for our party of 2. Not a problem, it was a beautiful day in SF so my brother and I killed time by taking pictures (instagrammers love those benches outside!) and making a coffee run. We got back at around 1 hour and 55 minutes after I was told "2 hours", but it seems we should have gotten back earlier, because our name was called multiple times already. They were so nice and called our name next as soon as we told them we were there. Other places are not this nice and will put your name at the bottom of the list and make you wait all over again. Thanks, Plow!
author: Tuwie N.

description:
This place is top of my breakfast list for several reasons...

Service...from leaving our name, to being seated, and beyond the staff was so friendly and accommodating, heads above all the rest.

The food...organic, sustainable and yummy!! We opted for the special, that way we got to try it all.  Bacon was some of the smokiest I have ever tasted....yum!  Eggs were perfect, potatoes were very crispy and savory with the onion.  Lemon Ricotta pancake was like a deconstructed blintz...heavy, but oh so yummy. 

I honestly would not change a thing. Very kid friendly with a cute menu, and piggies to color...what more could we want??
author: Katherine F.

description: Our service was great, and the food was good. I had "the plow". The lemon ricotta pancakes were amazing! I've never had anything like them. They barely need any maple syrup. The bacon was nice and crispy. The potatoes were well seasoned with rosemary and had a nice crispy texture as well. The wait can be long but it's worth it.
author: Cyn L.

description:
When I wait for an hour and a half for a table, my expectations are pretty high - I expect the food to be exceptional. It's extremely good but not exceptional. Their lemon ricotta pancakes are very special but the rest of the menu is decent.  The wait staff are friendly and the service is decent. I just don't want to wait an hour and a half for very good or decent.  

Universal cafe is a far better choice to plow - never waited there for more than 30 mins and the food is organic and pretty damn good.  Far better trade off.
author: Hema P.

description:
A recent visit has me downgrading this storied brunch spot from a 5 to a 2. 

Why? Service, service, service.  Yes it was Sunday, and yes it was brunch. I'm well aware of the standard busy-ness and crowds. I know how it works .

It's never an excuse to be abjectly rude to your customers or actively dissuade them from enjoying yoru cuisine. Many many instances occured during our wait and meal that shocked me vs. my last experience (the differential perhaps being the increase in popularity recently).

Now, all of this is sometimes still worth it if the food is epic (a la soup nazi). Unfortunately, it's no longer the case. Upon our seating, we waited 40 minutes for our [very simple] orders. not only that, the food arrived very cold. 

At one point in time, Plow was worth every second of the wait and / or mild disrespect. I'm sorry to say that's no longer the case. Hop on over to Radish, Foreign Cinema, or really, anywhere else instead. 

--
No questions on this rating. Absolutely one of the best brunch places I have ever been to and a must-visit for aspiring foodies 

Get ready to wait-- 1.5 hours @ peak time. The hipster coffee shop around the corner provides ample opportunity for people watching and general credibility-building in the area ;) (let's just say our designer handbags and celebrity-gossip infused conversations got us some looks at first, but my friends and I are quick learners and briskly changed the subject matter) 

I digress. 

Simple order recommendations: the plow and the lemon ricotta pancakes. Divine. 

Happy eating. I'm jealous from afar.
author: Meghana D.

description: I had one of the most decadent brunches ever here this morning. I had biscuits and gravy with potatoes and over easy eggs. I also tried their chicken apple sausage. Everything was perfect.  The lines are insane here but our group kept saying, "now we know why". I cannot wait for an excuse to come back!
author: Darin E.

description: Absolutely delicious and well worth the 2 hour wait, despite it being a weekday morning. I got "the plow" dish, which comes with eggs, chicken apple sausage (there are other meat options), PERFECT POTATOES, and lemon ricotta pancakes. My friends got the breakfast sandwich and also raved about it. The place is very cute. Even though the prices are kind of steep, the food is so tasty!!
author: Michelle K.

description:
Aside from the people walking by outside and giggling at the name (not easy to explain to my 7-year old), our experience with Plow was unparalleled. It is a small place in a discreet neighborhood but the ambiance and friendly service more than make up for the ride from the center of town.  

We had the famous lemon ricotta pancakes, and I also ordered a side of eggs and fruit which were both fresh and delicious.  My daughter ordered from the kids menu, and even though she was the only child in there, she was treated wonderfully.  I would say that while this place is friendly towards children, err more on the side of slightly-older, well-behaved children who can sit still and order politely.  

We arrived at around 11:30 on a weekday so we were seated after only a 10 minute wait, but with it being such a small establishment I can understand why the waits on the weekends get so long.  

Overall, one of the best breakfasts I've eaten, and with a wonderful atmosphere.  I'm not sure if I would go out of my way again to eat here if I was just visiting, but I'm sure I would be here regularly if I was local.
author: Erika B.

description: Amazing! Go here on a Tuesday at 1 pm won't have a terrible wait. A wonderful brunch place everything was great
author: Hannah B.

description:
Dear Plow,

You are, dare I say, the epitome of why I go out and pay money for brunch... You provide an experience of flavors, quality, and sheer size that knocks everyone else out of the water.

Your staff is friendly and quick to take care of me as I walk in...

Your lemon ricotta pancakes are sheer brillance... with or without the love of Vermont maple syrup...

Your soft scrambled eggs with oyster mushrooms, lambs quarter, and goat cheese is sheer heaven... being light and satisfyingly rich of flavor and texture.

Your eggs benedict with ham is sheer perfection...

And the potatoes!  Fried crisp on the outside with the potato-y soft goodness on the inside.  I could've eaten these on the side of everything!

My only complaint is can you make all the other people go away, so I don't have to wait in line?  No?  Okay, I'll just come early for easier parking and the ability to walk right in and enjoy my coffee.

Much love and full of deliciousness,
Christine
author: Christine K.

description: This place is well worth the wait.  The lemon ricotta pancakes are the best I've ever had!  Definitely coming back here!
author: Shira G.

description:
How could I have forgotten this review? 

Go here now!

The lemon ricotta pancakes are still stuck in my mind six months later as are the, "... the best crispy potatoes I've ever had." They are amazing.

Also coffee in line while you wait, is an excellent idea.
author: Justin S.

description: Crappy overpriced food, crappy service plus I got a big cockroach in my drink to boot.
author: Mikee E.

description: After two hours of waiting and being told we were next multiple times, I just hope the food makes up for the headache.
author: Michael V.

description:
My friend picked this place for a recent brunch.  It was a 45 minute wait, but it was DEFINITELY worth it!  They don't accept reservations so you either have to wait or eat elsewhere.  Seems they're only open for brunch/lunch, no dinner.  

The interior is nice and clean.  Service is pretty friendly although I was slightly bothered when our female server decided to take my guy friend and my husband's order before mine.  What happened to ladies first?!

Started off with coffee and their fried doughnut holes.  One order came with 3.  They were good, but nothing too special.  Let them cool before you munch on them.  

I ordered the Plow, which came with 2 eggs, choice of Nueske bacon, house made pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage, 2 of their famous lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes.  I chose the pork sausage.  The portions were just right.  My 2 eggs were nicely formed in a circle that they must have used a circle mold.  The pork sausage were basically patties, but they were really tasty.  You can taste the fennel with a little spice.  The best part was the lemon ricotta pancakes.  They were EXCELLENT!!  It just melted in my mouth; very moist.  With just a little bit of syrup, it's like dessert.  I had seen Yelp reviews about them and they were right!  You HAVE to try these!  Potatoes were nice and crispy.  Everything was so good, I finished my whole plate!

My husband had the Short Rib Hash and that was tasty as well.  Have to come back again!!!  Thanks, Richard for taking us here!
author: Erica S.

description: Everything I had read about Plow was absolutely true and more. I am so glad we trekked out to Potrero Hill at 9:30 for this. It was an hour wait but there was plenty to walk around and see in the cute neighborhood and we got coffees at a nearby cafe. I ordered the soft scrambled eggs with goat cheese and nettles and acme toast. There was...not going to lie...a lot of butter, but it was worth it. The crispy potatoes are also delicious. My friend got the salmon tartine, which was good, but not as unique as mine. We shared one lemon ricotta pancake, a must-try!! It basically tasted like cake. The atmosphere is good, the service is excellent. It's just a long wait after 9:30 so I suggest going early.
author: Madeline S.

description:
Plow is simply amazing. I'm never one to wait any amount of time for a restaurant, but I will wait for Plow...even if it was an hour + wait. -_- It's worth it. If it's your first time here, definitely get "The Plow". You can't go wrong with this. The lemon ricotta pancakes are to die for!  I've also had their dungeness crab scramble, which was also amazing.

Service is great. Even though this place is always packed, the employees here are super efficient. While you wait outside, you can always order your drinks/coffees first. Also, sit at the bar area so you can watch all the action.
author: Annie L.

description:
Most delicious biscuits I've ever had. Everything is fresh, homemade and delivered to your table with care. 

The busman employed at the time of my visit was also the fastest napkin folder I've ever seen! Plow abounds with talent!
author: Natalie M.

description:
The key is to either come 2 hours before you're hungry or between 8am-9am. Anytime after that and be prepared to make long conversation with your friend/voices in your head. 

I've somehow had brunch here 5 times even though I make it a point to try new places in the city and lines make me crotchety because it. is. just. that. good. That's about 10 hours of my life spent waiting in lines, and yet I have no regrets. The Plow is to die for. Every element comprising it from the lemon ricotta pancakes to the crispy potatoes to the bacon to the eggs are made to perfection. It's like sushi in a way - simple-looking but each component has been carefully prepared and a lot of care has been placed into each element, creating one amazing meal. 

Ditch your acquaintances because this place is rather small, and it will elongate your wait time.
author: Em F.

description: What a wonderful place! Fresh, delicious breakfast, very gracious host Maxine!! We will return, hopefully very soon!
author: Kevin M.

description:
I haven't been to a good brunch place in a while AND I haven't written a Yelp review in a while... but Plow was so good that they broke both streaks!

They close at 2, and we got there at 2:05... and there was still a line... luckily, the host & hostess felt bad that we had trekked so far to go there and there were "only" 4 tables ahead of us, so they put us down anyway. We ate "brunch" at 2:30 - better late than never :)

I had the fried egg sandwich and opted to add sausage instead of bacon (even though they only list that you can add on bacon) and my friend got The Plow (which is pretty much your basic breakfast combo plate). We were both very, VERY happy with our choices. The fried egg was perfectly cooked with a still runny yolk and the crispy potatoes were SO GOOD. Usually, I think of potatoes as an extra filler and try to not get too full off of them so I can finish the main part of my dish, but they were super crispy and tasty so I couldn't help myself! I tried some of the lemon ricotta pancakes that came on The Plow, and they were deeelish. I normally don't like ricotta, but it added a nice texture to the pancakes and the lemon flavor was just right.

Next time I'm in the city for brunch, this is where you'll find me!
author: Miss H.

description: Amazing potatoes!! Wear a jacket because you may have to wait awhile, but it's well worth it! The lemon ricotta pancakes are killer and the house made pork sausage is so interesting. I'll definitely be back for more.
author: Andrea J.

description: Recommend getting the scrambled eggs with potatoes. Now that's what real food must taste like.
author: sheetal t.

description: We waited only 30 minutes but we're quoted 45 at 11:30am.  We ordered the breakfast sandwich and the plow.  My god, amazing doesn't even describe it.  The fresh squeezed orange juice was superb and the lemon ricotta Pandora are to die for.  Definitely would go back.
author: JonMichael E.

description: I went to plow yesterday (Saturday morn). They told us there would be a 25 minute wait. After 35 min, I asked how much longer? They said about 20 min. I'm pregnant, I don't mind waiting 55 min to be seated but I need to mentally prepare for the wait. If it's going to be 20-tell me. If it will be an hour-be a better estimator and be honest. We left and I was frustrated bc I looked at some of the plates and they looked really good.
author: Kristy J.

description:
FRIED EGG SAMMY! Okay, realistically, it would've been a lot lot lot better if I added bacon into it, but I didn't. OH WELL. 

PS. Their mimosa is almost all champagne with a hint of orange juice. It was enough to get me buzzed!

Note to self: Next time ADD BACON!
author: Jeanette Y.

description: Plow is my favorite breakfast in SF. The potatoes are perfectly crispy, the lemon ricotta pancakes are just the right amount of lemony, the homemade pork sausages flavorful. .the only downside is ours no secret how good it is so there's always a line, when before it opens!
author: Kat R.

description:
Plow is such a cute little neighborhood spot. 

It's a great breakfast/brunch place that has a lot of familiar breakfast foods done a little bit better. For instance, they have lemon ricotta pancakes, super crispy (and well-seasoned) potatoes, and Equator coffee. Overall, the food was very well-executed here, and is delicious. 

I also enjoyed sitting at the bar during my meal. I was watching the cooking staff, and they were dancing and seemed really happy. Some were even saying thanks to the customers as they left. I definitely enjoyed this happy vibe. 

The only disclaimer is that this place is super busy, so be prepared to wait. Don't come starving (and expecting to eat as soon as you arrive). Otherwise, you'll be very unhappy to hear your wait time.
author: Sarah G.

description:
The rating isn't for the food. The food was great. I had the plow, which included lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, potatoes, and bacon. My boyfriend had the eggs benedict, which he also enjoyed. 

When we first showed we were expecting to wait awhile. We arrived about 11am on a Saturday, and of course, there was a mob outside the restaurant. When we asked how the long the wait was, the girl said an hour and a half. We were about to leave when someone else came up to her and said it was more like 45 minutes. Well, we believed him, and we should have left because an hour and a half later they called our names. We got a table outside in the shade which was at an angle because of the hill. This made it very awkward for me to set down my mimosa glass. 

Food was yummy, but I won't be waiting an hour + again. I will always remember being hangry. Maybe if I'm ever free on a weekday?
author: Katherine C.

description: Awesome food! Definitely worth the hour wait for the fried egg sandwich with super crispy potatoes. The ricotta pancake is also amazing. Complimentary coffee while you wait!
author: Jeff P.

description: My current favorite breakfast. First time I didn't like the coffee but it's grown on me. The eggs are very fresh and the bacon or sausage is the best I've had, consistently.  I love trying the daily pastry special.
author: Stanley J.

description:
Had the plow. Pretty dang good.

Chinese breakfast was out when we wetter seated at 11:30. Midweek...Waited about 15-20 min at 11:10 check in. 

Small. Great service. Excellent coffee.
author: Amy O.

description: We visited Plow after many recommendations from friends and from Yelp. It did not disappoint!  The food was great and the service was excellent!
author: Steve R.

description:
I went with 3 other people at around 11:30am and we're told to come back at noon. 

The host screwed us over by telling us to come back at a certain time. He gave away our table at the time we arrived. Instead of trying to accommodate us as quickly as possible, the host walked away and never helped us again. He did, unfortunately, pass off the responsibility to the other hostess. They didn't communicate the situation to her and we preceded to wait as if we were just the next table in line. He decided not to interact with us for the rest of the time. Coward! If you see him, Black guy, cool hair, no balls.

Table after table, small two top tables were being sat before us. At this point they should have put together two 2 tops and sat us as soon as possible. 

I even saw TWO people sitting at a 4 top. This to me says poor management during a busy brunch rush. It's never good. One of my guest is the concierge at a major hotel in SF and I was embarrassed for the restaurant's poor first impression. Needless to say, I would rather be plowed by a bulldozer than try Plow again. I write this as I enjoy my lunch at Piccino's just down the street. 

Good luck! I'm sure the food a Plow is fantastic. But a restaurant isn't all about the food.
author: Preston M.

description:
A must.

One of my go-to spots for breakfast in the city. There will be a wait (typically longer than an hour on weekends). The wait will be worth it. Casual ambiance perfect for brunch on weekends. My favorites are the lemon ricotta pancakes and the crispy potatoes (included if you order "The Plow" or you can just order the pancakes by themselves). Seriously, they are incredible. Service is always friendly and prompt.

I'll be back. Early!
author: Ashley K.

description:
Not bad Plow, not bad. 

A very long wait time of 90 minutes for a tasty set of lemon ricotta pancakes, perfectly seasoned country potatoes, light fluffy crab scrambled eggs, and my personal favorite: the fresh salmon and capers on toast...fantastic for the 2 of us. Would we go back knowing this 90min wait is average? Nope...but we enjoyed our meal absolutely. 

I will say that the 2 female hostesses could've been much more personable, one slightly rude. You are the first impression customers get when eating at such a highly rated spot, I'd expect the quality of food to match the staff.
author: Lauren N.

description:
I don't mind at all waiting for brunch. I actually think it can be fun and add to the experience - especially on a beautiful Sunday morning. But really, being told check back in an hour, and then waiting over two hours is a little crazy. 

But great food would totally make up for it. And I was ready for some awesome breakfast. Unfortunately, that is not what we had. I had the summer vegetable hash. Eh. It was too greasy, not fresh. My friend had the egg sandwich. He didn't enjoy much at all.

I did take a date walnut muffin with me when I left and had that the next day, it was very good. If you live in the neighborhood, it's probably worth it. But not worth going out of your way for.

Ooooohhhhh wait - if you're a potato fan - definitely get them. I don't really eat potatoes, but both friends I was with went wild over them!
author: Kelly S.

description:
Husband and I hit up this place after reading the Conde Nast article on Plow, entitled "San Francisco's Best Brunch. It's Worth the Two Hour Wait." I think the title is a bit generous, I mean its a very good brunch and maybe worth a 15 to 30 minute wait, but 2 hours? Folks, this is not manna falling from the sky. 

We arrived exactly at 8:00 am on a Saturday, because any later you will be stuck in a line for at least 45 minutes. Service was great, providing fresh coffee and water as soon as we sat down. My husband got the steak and eggs and I ordered the Plow. Both were equally delicious, with the crispy potatoes being a highlight of the meal. The lemon ricotta pancakes were fluffy and not too sweet and balanced well with my hickory smoked bacon and eggs. All in all, our meal here was good, not the BEST, but I would definitely come here again, at 8:00am. 

Plow is like the Ariana Grande of SF brunches. People says she sounds like Mariah Carey, but when you hear her, she's good, but she ain't no Mariah Carey.
author: Joann A.

description: Pretty good food, but not worth a two hour wait.  .  Come early, 9am the latest.. put your name down and go get a coffee down the street.
author: Kristina K.

description:
Plow you have broken me down. I'll admit it- I'm a fan. Partly thanks to my laziness and partly in large part to my love of brunch I kept returning to Plow hoping to find that magical brunch item that would make me love this place. And yes I've found it in the most unsuspecting item- Muesli. Yep I said muesli. I know that sounds boring and not fun (i.e. not fattening at all), but I love muesli and I especially love Plow's version. I order a almond flour pancake (yum) on the side so that I can pretend I'm enjoying a gluttonous breakfast, but the main attraction is the muesli.

I've tried 
The Plow (akin to a Denny's grand slam although perhaps a bit more refined). its kind of messy and I wish it was a little more refined for the price.
The Lemon Ricotta pancakes (I'm wrong- these are actually pretty disappointing- too much ricotta)
Two eggs (good when dressed up with ketchup and hot sauce- they're soft scrambled btw)
And the Plow version of bagel and lox (its toast with lox and pretty boring)..

So there you have it- I'm a fan but still avoid this place like a plague on the weekends. Definitely not worth an hour plus wait....
author: Ritu K.

description:
Once a place gets mentioned as being among the best brunch places in SF, it becomes critic proof. 

And if a line forms shortly after opening, so much the better. It must be fantastic!

Being a badge collector and seeing as this place was voted number one brunch venue in SF, I thought it had to be worth a visit.

The parking was decent on a Thursday morning at 8am with no line in site. But walking up to the venue, you could see it was pretty full already.

The space itself is quite small, with a counter on the right and a selection of smallish tables on the left. Best tables are at the window, mostly so you don't get bumped by the waiters.

The chairs are metal, making them cold and hard, evoking memories of Moscow style canteens.

The menu comes with a variety of choices, with the most popular being a combo plate ($16) which included the lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, fried potatoes and choice of sausage patties, bacon or chicken apple sausage.

While the potatoes were truly excellent, the eggs came off a little too runny, the sausage patty too lemony and the famed lemon ricotta pancakes had the excitement factor of mochi. 

The missus ordered sides of bacon and eggs for herself as she didn't want carbo action included. Which then came on two little side plates. Weird. The bacon was ok and had some name that nobody knows but looks interesting on the menu.


The coffee they serve here is truly excellent. 

Best brunch in SF? Will keep looking.
author: Pantera W.

description:
I've been here on 2 occasions and each time was a great experience. The atmosphere in this place is extremely comforting & charming. With an open kitchen and friendly staff this place gets a thumbs up. 

The food is amazing! Locally grown and organic. I got the crab scramble which was good but what keeps me coming back is the POTATOES (made to perfection!) and LEMON-RICOTTA PANCAKES! Something I've never tasted before. What a weird combo but works oh so perfectly....

On one occasion my eggs were super runny....I couldn't even believe they served it to me like that. I had to send it back and they made it better without complaint. Nonetheless I'd definitely come back....
author: Caye Q.

description: Great huge, pretty lean sausage patties.  I've come a couple times and found I could get in at the counter.   They have a lot of great things.  I keep it simple with scrambled eggs, sausage, granola /yogurt and coffee of course.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Every single thing here was absolutely delicious.. down to the potatoes. We each got the Plow breakfast and couldn't have been happier, or more full. I'm not sure that any of us finished our plates. I had the house mimosa and was ecstatic with my choice!

The only reason I'm giving this 4/5 is because of the wait. Even on a Sunday during a holiday weekend (when the city is empty), there was a 1.5 hour wait. This is truly a neighborhood brunch spot, but in my opinion, those are all over the city. You just need to find one that hasn't been written about time and time again. 

There's a coffee shop right UP the street with Ritual coffee, a good place to hang out while you're waiting.
author: Wendy K.

description:
I never knew there's a brunch place in the secluded neighborhood, but I'm glad there is. It wasn't as crowded and have as long of a wait as other brunch restaurants I'd been to. The place is small but it feel spacious probably because of the high ceiling and open kitchen. 

The food here is pretty good. I tried the ricotta pancake (highly recommended), the almond flour pancake (gluten-free taste so good), smoked salmon toast (kept wanting more) and french toast (it's okay).

The service here is okay. I had to keep waving for my water to get refilled. Also, I felt a little rushed at times. All in all, I would still go back for more.
author: Mandy C.

description:
This is my favorite brunch place in the city so far. The place is very cozy and small, resulting in a long wait, but it is worth it. The place has large windows and reminds me of a farmhouse, which definitely matches the food they serve there.

I always get The Plow, which comes with eggs, your choice of meat, lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes. Though I'm not particularly a lemon or ricotta person, the lemon ricotta pancakes were SO GOOD! I could eat them all day. The pancakes are fluffy on the inside and delicately scented with lemon, mixed with the taste of ricotta. I've also never had potatoes quite the same as I had at Plow, they were perfectly seasoned and just crispy enough. I've tried the house sausage and the chicken-apple sausage here. Both were good, but definitely overshadowed by the pancakes and the potatoes.

Service here has always been friendly, but the staff are definitely busy. The food is simple yet heavenly. My only complaint is the wait, but it is definitely worth it.
author: Joy C.

description:
Love at first bite.

I love brunch and came here for my birthday brunch with the boyfriend.

If it's your first time, try The Plow! It comes with two eggs, pork sausage, bacon or chicken apple sausage, two lemon pancakes and potatoes. IT IS HEAVEN.

Our waitress was really kind. I love the atmosphere. The neighborhood is cute.

Will definitely be coming back to bring a friend who is visiting San Francisco for the first time in a couple weeks.
author: Jessica R.

description:
The line is always ridiculous, but at least they'll serve you alcohol while you wait.  We were initially quoted an hour, then it became 90 min when we checked back in, and I think ultimately it took about 2 hours to get a table even though we arrived around 10am.  We were able to put our name down and come back, but they won't call your phone, so you have to come back and check in. We actually missed being called, but they kept us at the top of the list. 

The champagne pours they gave us in paper cups while we waited were VERY generous, so that definitely helped the wait significantly.

We started with a sausage biscuit, which was a buttery flaky biscuit with melted cheese and a sausage patty. The sausage had really good flavor, and this really hit the spot because we were all starving.

- Fried egg sandwich: fried eggs with runny yolk, cheddar, Nueske bacon (in honor of National Bacon Day!), with a little bit of frisee so you feel less guilty about the other contents of the sandwich.  The bun was light, and it was a well balanced sandwich.
- Chicken tinga: fried corn tortillas topped with shredded chicken and two fried eggs, topped with a chipotle tomato sauce and avocado. I was craving something with tomato sauce and runny yolks, so this was perfect
- Crispy potatoes: amazingly crisp (possibly deep fried?) and very well seasoned, plus there's a hint of thyme, which makes them really stand out among all the home fries I've ever had

Food was really good, and it's nice that they can serve you alcohol while you wait, but I don't think I would wait 2 hours again.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Best brunch I've had all year!
