Great little place. Even though this is hipster central, I didn't feel like my pants were too baggy, or my bike had too many speeds, or that my jacket wasn't vintage enough to be there. 

Basically everything I ate here, including off my friends plate was amazing!

How good was the lemon ricotta pancake? I literally started experimenting with pancake recipes the following weekend, and I never make pancakes! 

Sub 20 minute wait on a beautiful Sunday afternoon. 

I'll be back and I'll order the lemon ricotta pancakes again and hopefully whoever I go with will order something new : )
author: Benny N.

description:
Plow: You've done it again.  This time, your with the Dungeness crab scramble - asparagus, greens, scallions, cremini mushrooms, crispy potatoes and toast (which I subbed for fruit instead).  To say I was satisfied with my meal is an understatement.  Each bite was better than the next.  My only complaint is that there wasn't more to eat (but that's just being greedy, I know).
When you arrive, put your name on the list and then get ready to wait. The place is small and the food is delicious which adds up to a long line, but one that's worth it. Trust me.  Somehow I have become a regular here and I live thousands of miles away.  Go figure! lol!
author: Elsa M.

description:
(See pics) Review #1192. Great all local purveyors ingredients brunch that brightens up any gloomy day or energizes a sunny day.

The day we visited, they were out of monkey bread so we opted for corn millet muffin which was good.

The Plow with the two eggs, Nueske bacon, chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes was a total brunch that had everything you need and desire. The bacon and sausage were good salty, sweet and meaty, while the pancakes definitely were the highlight. Eggs were prepared perfectly to my likeness.

As mentioned many times in my other reviews, I love locally roasted beans. Equator coffee was earthy and was happily light roasted.

My friend had the fried egg on Acme bun that was hearty and freshly tasted.

Mimosa was nice but more orange juice than sparkling wine.

Many had wondered about the San Francisco style long wait and yes even on a rainy weekend we we visited. However, the server was extremely helpful and actually told us not to go get coffee up the street because there would be a table coming up shortly and if those who were not there while called, they would lose the spot. Amazing enough, we only waited for 10 minutes. While the place was completely packed, service was super friendly and perky, we were never rushed to finish, though we were considerate to not hold up the tables.

Do wish they were closer to public transit stops.
author: T L.

description:
This used to be my five star place until today. I'm infuriated because they quoted me one hour to 1.5 hour wait. We checked back in after an hour, and they told us another twenty minutes. We waited and waited and waited... They kept on saying we were next but didn't update us on that it was going to take longer. We would have left if it was longer than the 20 minutes. Do you realize how difficult it is to wait with a 3 month old and hungry two year old that exhausted all her snacks?!!!
(Grumbly tummy)
author: Elaine L.

description:
Yum yum yum...came here on Sunday and waited about an hour for a table.  Well worth it..good time to catch up with a friend while waiting is always good.   The place is tiny and they offer seating outside, but just remember to bring a jacket if u sit outside as this place is located on the shady side..wish it was across the street where the sun is at.

Once we got seated, my friend ordered the "plow" which was a taste of eggs, the pancakes, bacon, and the crispy house potatoes which was really awesome btw.  I ordered the crab scramble it was very tasty with the home potato, oh so yummy.

We also tried their ginger scone which was very good.  I usually don't care for scones because they are usually hard and bland, but this one was very good..came out warm and soft with a slight crunch.  The lemon spread helped as well.

A definite place to hit up for brunch if u have time to wait.
author: James L.

description: We ordered the chia seed pudding, fried egg sandwich, lemon ricotta pancakes, and the eggs Benedict with salmon, and it was all delicious! Definitely going there again when I visit SF. The wait could be anywhere from an hour to two but completely worth it
author: Karan G.

description:
ok i suppose it is worth the wait - but i dont know about 2 hours.
luckily we only waited 30 minutes 
very cute homey vibe and food was really good too
service was friendly - a total neighborhood feel...
the pancakes were fluffy and the plow breakfast i had was a huge portion 
grapefruit mimosas are the way to go!
author: Marie r.

description:
There aren't many places that the wait is over a hour long and you finish everything and feel it was worth the wait. I've driven by plow many times and have never seen it without people waiting. 
I finally went to get it a try and see what everyone is willing to wait for. 
We waiting a little over and hour, there aren't many places to sit so we sat across the street and watch the crowd maintain its size. 
When we finally got a table the server was really quick and helpful. 
Everything on the menu sounds good but we settled on 
The Plow with homemade sausage 
Dungeness crab scramble 
French toast with caramelized bananas
Fruit plate 
& mimosas. 
It was only my friend and I but I felt like being a fatty. 
All the plates were awesome!!! The scramble and French toast are definite must try's  
I look forward to going back to try the other menu items but not looking forward to the wait
author: Blake R.

description: My first brunch spot in SF and I am very happy i chose Plow! A little pricey but it's a given when you're dining in SF. I made sure my bf and i made the first wave of people for their 8am breakfast but unfortunately we arrived at 8:10am and they already had a 45 min wait. What the heck! lol That clearly meant this place is amazingly delicious and i couldn't wait to try it! :D We sipped on their complimentary coffee while sitting on some cute benches on the side of the building. I was ready to eat and placed my order as soon as i sat down =P I ordered "The Plow" which was a little bit of everything! I am in love with their lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes! I am a fan of sweet and salty so "The plow" was a great combination of everything. My bf ordered the fried egg sandwich. This place was packed with flavor and if you love runny eggs like my bf, this is a great dish! Love this place.
author: Shirley N.

description: Everytime I am in SF, I try to make it a mission to stop by here for breakfast. A friend of mine brought us here once and it exceeded my expectations of breakfast. I had this special broccolini breakfast sandwich which was amazing. I always crave it when I go back but their menu is usually changed with new and exciting dishes.
author: George M.

description:
My favorite breakfast in san francisco!
Fried egg sandwich YUM add avocado YUM

My boyfriend is in love with the lemon ricotta pancakes, they taste like cake. I think they smell better than they taste but i'm not a huge fan of dough.

The wait here can be SO ridiculous, I try to come on weekdays around 10 when less people are usually in line. Even though Plow on the weekend is like a total dream come true. 

The crispy potatoes are SO crispy and have crunchy carmalized onions mixed in with them...sooo good! I'm not even a huge fan of potatoes and I eat some.
author: Alexandra C.

description:
I was warned when I first arrived in Potrero Hill that a lot of the people in the neighborhood were "visitors," and that if they looked hip or trendy, they were probably heading to Plow. Because people actually dress up to come here. 

I therefore avoided this restaurant. 

UNTIL!!! I'm 13 days and 15 interviews into my trip, and have just completed my final interview after a grueling commute. It's mid-afternoon, and I haven't eaten breakfast or lunch. I'm tired, I'm hungry, I'm grouchy, and my host isn't answering his phone (or his buzzer). HALP! I'm stranded on a hill in Potrero Hill without a pair of sneakers!!! 

So I slouched over to Plow, which, amazingly, didn't have the standard line out the door, and peeked at the menu. And immediately started salivating.

They had me at "plow," the signature dish of this fine establishment: a decadent and solid combo of eggs (any style), bacon/sausage, fried potatoes, and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes. Hellooooo nurse!! I can only hope that the rest of the patrons were making fun of the way I was dressed, given that a) I was wearing a horrific suit, and b) I'd been all judge-y and deserved as much - but I didn't care. The bacon was crisp, the eggs perfectly cooked, the potatoes crunchy and well-seasoned, and the pancakes were among the best I've ever had. Perfectly sweet and substantive, not too heavy, lovely and lemon-y. I savored them until the last bite.

At the end of the day, it's back to the lesson most of us learned long ago: if there's a line out the door, the food is probably worth the wait.
author: Ray J.

description: Great food. Fries are out of the world.  (waitress tells me it's not cooked in duck fat though. ha!) it was fun sitting at the bar watching them prepare food.  The pancakes looked so good though I didn't try them. I had their prosciutto toast and it was soooo delish. A must try when visiting SF!
author: Alice W.

description: Awesome breakfast and ambiance. Beautiful and tasty food -- go ahead and get those lemon ricotta pancakes and the pork sausage patty shaped like an overstuffed slider.
author: Andrew S.

description: A small modern rustic restaurant that serves a solid American breakfast. The food is fantastic and the mimosas were spot on. Yeah, dropping $20+ for brunch shouldn't be a surprise, make it $30 if you want a few mimosas in you. Came with a party of five and waited like 40 minutes which wasn't too bad. I ordered the plow, of the meat choices I'd recommend the chicken apple sausage then the pork patties - the bacon is just bacon. And yes, if you haven't already heard, the lemon ricotta pancakes are the bomb.
author: Ryan L.

description:
A bit of clarification first - Plow is indeed not wheelchair accessible, as there are a few steps up into the restaurant. However! They have outdoor seating on nice days, and that IS accessible, albeit requiring that one deal with the slight incline of the hill on which Plow sits.

Showing up around 9am last Saturday, my friend and I were eventually seated after a ~45 minute wait. Part of this was due to having to wait for an outdoor seat though - had that not been necessary, our wait would have been about 15 minutes shorter. After perusing a fairly succinct menu, we ended up ordering the Plow, Dungeness crab scramble [ http://flic.kr/p/c2HfrY ], and an order of French toast to go.

The crab scramble wasn't bad, and most enjoyable when the scramble was eaten along with the accompanying toast. I was slightly turned off by how fishy the dish was though - while it WAS seafood, the taste was far stronger than one would expect of fresh seafood. The crispy potatoes that came as a side of that dish were pretty good though, albeit a bit too salty for my tastes. And while the French toast was just okay, the lemon ricotta pancakes that came with the Plow were easily the best part of the meal - light on both the lemon and ricotta, they reminded me somewhat of fluffy lemon cream cookies.

After all is said and done, with tax and tip, expect the meal to come out to about $20 a person for a single entree. Service is friendly, and while I suppose the local ingredient sourcing is a nice touch, it's never been a make or break factor for me. While I can see myself coming again solely for the pancakes, I doubt it'll be particularly often, or during their busier hours.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I was excited to try a new breakfast joint and when I came on a Friday around 1030am there was already a line. The wait was only about 20 minutes but I feel like the food is just typical. Nothing really stood out. I had the plow and ordered a extra side of chicken apple sausage, my scrambled eggs were runny and the lemon ricotta pancakes weren't as good as people said they are. I tried my friend's crab scramble but that was just okay too. Their bacon is nice and smoky though, I think that was the only thing I enjoyed. Besides their quick refills of coffee.

It's nice that they have seating outside, and also benches where you can wait outside but I suggest you go across the street in the sun to wait because they're situated in a shaded area.

Yay for glass cola bottles!
author: Jenny Y.

description:
It lives up to the hype.

I love coming here because I can get a great hearty breakfast or something healthy and both are going to be great. I had the Chia Seed Pudding last time with a side of the Avocado Toast and I was set for the morning.

The decor and ambience are great too. I like coming here on a week day solo and sitting at the bar which features a granite counter-top and glass partition so you can see all the action in the  kitchen.

Definitely the best breakfast gem on Potrero Hill!
author: Jim C.

description:
I dragged my husband here, fresh off a flight, with the promise that I read about their gluten free, lemon ricotta pancakes. Alas, those do not exist, so I jumped on the almond flour pancake option, while my husband ordered the breakfast sandwich.

The breakfast sandwich, according to my husband, was amazing. Such perfectly runny eggs, lovely bread, and oh the potatoes! He couldn't stop raving about the best potatoes he had ever tasted.

Sadly, he had to look across the table at me. While I was in love with my iced chai, my pancakes were a sad surprise. I took it to mean a lot about the service at Plow when the plate of pancakes was put in front of me, burnt. I was starving, and the wait was long for food, so I dug in. I ended up peeling back the overly burnt portions and trying to salvage some breakfast. Unfortunately, the waitress wasn't by early enough for me to send the meal back, but again, if they put it in front of me that way, then obviously they think burnt pancakes are acceptable. The only saving grace of the plate was the syrup, which I literally drank from my spoon, in order to remove the burnt flavor from my mouth.

Should I have made more of an effort to seek out assistance and get new pancakes? Probably. But there has to be something said about a restaurant that lets obviously burnt food go out to a patron. 

For all the hype, maybe my husband's meal was worth it, but mine certainly wasn't.
author: Andrea M.

description: I think this place is pretty overrated.  We waited more than 1.5 hours on a Saturday morning.  Their food is really standard that you can pretty much find any other breakfast places.  There's nothing really special about their food.  They are known for their lemon ricotta pancakes which I think they were just alright (BLD in LA is so much better).  There's a lot of brunch places around the city, so I will probably not go back here.
author: Andrew J.

description: I've never had an emotional response to good food, but my breakfast here made me tear up, it was so amazing.
author: Abby M.

description:
I'm really not sure what's going on with the downfall of customer service in the restaurant industry in San Francisco but it seems everyone is very full of themselves and does not require anymore business.

I literally just called Plow to order some food for pick-up and the woman informed me that they are not taking pick-up orders because they are too busy... then she hung up on me before I could get a word in to ask about wait times to come in.

Are you kidding? A pick-up order is the best thing for a restaurant that's busy... That means you can run your restaurant at full capacity AND continue to generate income by food going out the door. On top of that, I would have made a reservation and then come in.

Whoever the woman was that I spoke to, who hung up on me. Thank you for the warning about the type of service I would receive at your establishment. You will never get my business.

I would leave a 0/5 star if I could.
author: Aaron A.

description: I've never had such a delicious breakfast in my life! So amazingly good! There's minimal seating but it's worth the wait. The pancakes and potatoes were spot on. I would recommend their signature dish "the plow."
author: Steven G.

description:
Had the plow and absolutely loved it.

The restaurant is so clean and charming. Sat at the bar with my ladies to share a wonderful Saturday brunch and left completely stuffed and satisfied.

The pork sausage is amazing, as well as the egg sandwich. We saw the cooks preparing a variety of dishes and I must say that the salmon benedict, scrambled eggs and random ingredients layed out in the kitchen all looked really fresh. I'm definitely coming back here. Next time, I will put my name down on the list, and then sit at Farley's for a nice cup of coffee to kill time.

Don't hesitate, it's worth the wait.
author: Gloria C.

description: Charming, popular brunch spot in Potrero Hill. True to form, I loved the lemon ricotta pancakes and finished my entire bowl of chia seed pudding. (Don't knock it until you try it!) My boyfriend and I waited for about an hour on a Saturday afternoon - not bad, with sunny weather and other people to talk to. Just make sure you keep track of where you are on the list and stay within earshot of the host. I wish I was hungry enough to order one of the larger breakfast plates with eggs and potatoes. Just another reason to go back!
author: Auburn S.

description:
I came here on a Tuesday morning at 830am and there was a 30 minute wait. Yes a 30 minute wait on a Tuesday morning! My friend had warned me of the popularity of this place, but I was still surprised to see so many people waiting around. 

When we finally sat down, we quickly told our server our order and our meals came out soon after. We ordered The Plow, because why wouldn't you order the dish that's named after the restaurant? 

The lemon ricotta pancakes were a delicious treat for my tastebuds. It reminded me of a fluffy lemon bar, but only the custard part. The homemade sausage patties were a bit dry. The table next to us ordered the same thing but with bacon and I was drooling from second hand aromas. 

In conclusion, I'd go back if they accepted reservations or if friends were visiting but not on another weekday whim.
author: Michelle W.

description:
It's my last weekend in the city! And all my co-workers raved about Plow, so I figured that it was as good a time as any to give it a chance. There was still a 1-hour wait at 1pm (seriously), but the hostess told us that we would be guaranteed seating if we came back at 1:50-ish, if we weren't seated before that. So we went to Farley's on the next block for banana bread and coffee, and came back around 1:30. We got seated around 1:45.

The service was great, the food was great--the 3 of us split an order of lemon ricotta pancakes, and then we got the prosciutto sandwich, the fried egg sandwich, and the cold-smoked salmon toast. All three of us also really loved the ambiance and the lighting in the restaurant.

I love smoked salmon. And this was some really good stuff. I would've loved some avocado to go with the toast rather than the weird cream cheese, but it was still pretty good. My friend's egg sandwich definitely needed a little more oomph, but she also didn't get the bacon or avocado add-ons--adding some bacon to it would've done the trick. The pancakes were fabulous. We went to MyMy's last weekend and got the lemon ricotta souffle pancakes, and while Plow does not have souffle pancakes, there was a stronger lemon flavor to their recipe, which I preferred over MyMy's.

If you have good company willing to wait with you, coming here is great. Street parking is super easy too if you're willing to walk a block or two--an added bonus!
author: Sharon L.

description:
Our group of four arrived at Plow at 10am for Sunday brunch obviously expecting a waiting time based on other Yelp reviews. We were told it would be about 40-45 mins -- not so bad. After an hour wait, we were finally seated...outdoors on a slightly chilly day (not ideal, but hey, a table is a table).

We ordered the small order of french toast brioche to get started, since we were starving! Easily cut into four pieces, it was a fab start to the meal.

The huevos rancheros and monkey bread were sold out by the time we were seated. What!? On to plan B...

For main entrees, I shared the lemon ricotta pancakes (clear winner on the table!) and the fried egg sandwich. Do not go to this place without ordering the lemon ricotta pancakes! They are thick, heavy, moist, and filling, but oh so good!! The lemon flavor is very prominent and just a wonderful way to begin the day with some coffee.

The fried egg sandwich was a bit of a disappointment. While the Acme bread on which it was served was pretty delicious, the sandwich really only consisted of egg, cheese and frissee. Lacking in salt, it also ended up lacking in flavor. Definitely an item you can skip.

Overall, brunch at Plow was fairly good. However, for an hour long wait, there are many other great places with shorter wait times.

Note: Plow only takes max party size of 6. It's a pretty tiny spot!
author: Mansi A.

description:
I rarely post and when I do it is because something is exceptionally good or exceptionally bad. The food at Plow is in a different realm from most restaurants. Like other bay area Panis and Larders, Plow takes the simple classics (of breakfast food) and perfects them. And also, like other bay area Panis and Larders, the cooks at Plow are on top of their game. They can poach an egg almost as good as Chef at Bouletts Larder. 
Lemon ricotta pancakes and house made sausage from Plow will make you abuse your body. When it begs you to stop, your fork hand acts on its own and pleases the pallet with bite after bite of fluffy sweet or perfectly textured salty.
Smoked Bacon, 10.
The 90 minute wait is worth every second, but the food WILL ruin breakfast for you from any other chef for the rest of you life.
author: Aaron K.

description:
If you don't like the long wait that everyone speaks of, all I can suggest is to live close by.  My fiancée and I moved to SF from Atlanta, and picked Potrero Hill as our first neighborhood.

Little did we know that we were only 1 block away from Plow.  When we want brunch from Plow on the weekends we put our names down and head home for a bit to do whatever.

I typically have just ordered the "the plow".  It has a little bit of everything and the crispy potatoes are SOooOOoo good.
author: Felix C.

description: We waited 1.5 hours to be seated. We were able to get coffee while waiting outside. The place is very nice and quaint. We were glad our 4 year old was behaving while waiting. The food was amazing. The pancakes are to die for. I was able to get the recipe.  I recommend this place to anyone. The wait is worth it!!!!
author: Jessica H.

description:
Great tastes. Fine service. Questionable food handling techniques. 

In case you haven't already guessed, this is not another "So, I was like, ohmygod, the lemon ricotta pancakes!" kind of reviews. There are plenty of those already. 

On my last visit, instead of sitting at a table, I sat at the counter. I was able to observe the food preparation in great detail.

Unfortunately, I observed a lot of things which, once seen, can't be unseen.

Workers continuously alternated between touching surfaces of the kitchen and then raw food.  Some of the food was later cooked, which was a relief. However, some of the food was smoked fish, garnishes, or and salad greens, scooped by hand and placed on a plate.

I observed a kitchen worker blow his nose, and continue working without washing his hands. Another sneezed, and served food off the stove using his hand. Another lifted his shirt and scratched his bare skin. Then he touched food. 

I never saw gloves used the kitchen area. That in itself is not a problem. Gloves usually lend a false sense of security, because they are not changed each time they come into contact with food. Often, workers touch all of the same contaminated surfaces with gloves, and then go on to touch food, then go back to touching equipment. An employee would have to go through thousands of glove changes each shift, for gloves to be effective.

The only way to avoid cross-contamination is to wash hands first, do only one type of food preparation, followed by another good hand washing. However, in such a small place, the workers are constantly alternating between touching all of the kitchen surfaces, and touching food. 

I'm knocking off only two points, even though this is a potential life-threatening food safety issue. I'm being realistic, since I think almost all restaurants do the same thing. However, in most cases, the customer doesn't see it.

If you sit at the counter, take a look at the workers, and see if you don't notice the same thing. Even if you're sitting at a table, as you walk by, see how much of this you can observe. And if you ever get food poisoning after eating there, think about what I've said. 

I love this restaurant. I want them to do well, and I want to come back many times. I do hope that on some future visits, I notice some major changes.  If not, I'll be calling the health department.
author: tout le monde a.

description:
PLOOWWW ON DOWN, LIKE TAHHHH DOWW!!! Like, uhhh now.

ULTIMATE PLOW $15 (which is lovely, as you get a little bit of everything, esp those crunchy potatoes and deeeeelectable lemon ricotta pancakes, sweet and savory OR savory with dessert!!):

- 2 eggs (served however you'd like)-I got mine sunny side up and they were perfectly cooked, ooey gooey in the middle
-so crispy crispity potatoes- did I mention these are CRISPY? It's like they triple fry em.
-a meat of your choice (chicken apple sausage, Nueske bacon, homemade pork sausage)-I got 2 sized chicken apple sausages, yum.
-2 lemony cricket ricotta pancakes- fresh, lemony, pillowy, light, lovely pancakes, you can definitely taste the lemon and the ricotta.

-1 star as this place is a little pretentious. Hosts were somewhat snobby and had their noses all up in the air like it was the freaking Catalina wine mixer. Gee whiz, it seemed like such a privilege just to be put on the wait list. 

HOT TIP!!:
GO @ 1:40ishPM on a Sunday afternoon. (just not on a day when I'M trying to go..) This way you can take it easy, have a lazy sunday, sleep in, get it "in", do ya thang, whatevs, and still make it to brunch. Most likely, and you will not have to wait a ridiculous amount of time. Luckily for us, we were able to get our name on the list, grabbed coffee at Farleys, and returned right back to have our name called in 5 mins!! *When they say, don't stray too far away, they mean it. A couple of dudes doing bromantic brunch together didn't get back in time and had their table given away but STILL waited another 30 mins!

Can't wait to get plowed again!!
author: Angela W.

description:
Four times. 

The number of times I ATTEMPTED to go here before I finally scored a table for brunch. Brunching at Plow is straight out of an episode from Portlandia. It's crazy and worth it, I dare say! 

I finally scored a table here by arriving right when it opened on a Saturday morning and willingly sitting outside with my dogs. At this point, I was willing to do anything just to try this place. Luckily, the food lived up to the hype. 

What strikes me about this place is how SIMPLE the food is. Some people might say that the food is too simple, and unimpressive. But I'm a believer that most often, simple food is harder to make than complicated food because you have to really do justice to the ingredients to make the dishes shine.

And that's what they do best at Plow, simple food, but prepared with extraordinary care and attention to detail. We tried: 

-Cinnamon Brioche: deceivingly simple, but outrageously good. Reminded me of a Kouign Amann from B Patisserie
-The Plow: the house made pork sausage was really really good
-Fried Egg Sandwich w/ Bacon: hits all the notes - savory egg yolk, doughy bread, salty bacon, creamy aioli 
-Lemon Ricotta Pancake: good, but I've had better (Aquarius Cafe in Emeryville. R.I.P.)

And those were my favorites, in that order. 

And possibly what's even more perplexing to me is that my favorite thing at Plow was the side crispy potatoes that come with every order. Chunky, twice-fried nuggets of potatoes that are impossibly crispy on the outside and creamy inside. The crispy side potatoes are worth a detour by themselves!  

If you can stomach the wait or manage to get there early, Plow is worth the trip!
author: Monelle A.

description:
The wait is usually ridiculous, so I was nervous to try this place. But we once came around 1pm on a Saturday and lucked out - we only had to wait 15 minutes. 

Get the super crispy breakfast potatoes & fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes. My fiance got some sort of breakfast sandwich, which he seemed to enjoy as well. The french toast was just okay, so I'd skip that. 

I'd definitely come back here, but just not on a Sunday.
author: Shreya O.

description: Completely empty restaurant won't seat me at 7am because the party is not all present. Great way way to serve your ex-customers. I guess you don't want people to feel comfortable meeting here for breakfast.
author: Fred S.

description:
Why you make me wait so long to eat Plow? Don't you know I get hangry and when I get hangry I want to break stuff.... Maybe you make us wait so that when we finally do eat we're tricked into thinking its the best food ever put in our mouths... figured it out! Ha 

Either way after 1.5 hour wait for brunch with a group of 5 we finally sat down to eat. The table fell silent as food was served. 

I ordered: 

Lemon ricotta pancake - I can't even think about these pancakes without swooning. Amazing! 

Egg scrambler: goat cheese, spinach and fancy mushrooms and eggs perfectly cooked (not rubbery or too runny), house potatoes so crunchy almost French fry like and toast - I. Can't. Handle. How. Delicious. 

Spilt bacon and sausage side - Bacon perfectly crunchy and not oily. I thought the sausage would be links but instead patties, only mildly disappointed but my starvation mode didn't care.  

Which I feel is exactly what Plow wants to do - starve you until you will Instagram, yelp and moan over what ever they plop in front of you and we just keep standing in line for more punishment. People of SF we are masochistic when it comes to brunch. 

P.S already planning a trip back for those damn pancakes. Damn you Plow!
author: Jade W.

description:
Plow opens at 8am and I got there at 8:15am. It was one hour wait and it was worth the wait. 

We sat at the bar and got the plow-crispy potatoes, eggs, bacon, and lemon pancakes. Super yummy. The pancakes were fluffy, the potatoes are fried and seasoned well. They gave me 4 pieces of bacon and it has a smoky flavor to it. Most places give you only 2 pieces. The eggs were a decent amount too.

Staff is friendly and I will be back! This place makes my heart warm and fuzzy. :)
author: Karen H.

description:
I'd say if you walk by and they have seat you can give it a try, but if during a Saturday morning for a 2hr wait... Go wait for Rotunda at least you got union square and Neiman Marcus to kill time, and with a bit higher price you got way better quality of service and food.
The scrambled crab with egg was really bland... And the plow is nothing impressive, even the look. Maybe I am expecting too much but I guess it's a bit overrated after all.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Plow is probably my favorite breakfast spot in San Francisco. Yes, it's small and yes, you will have to wait to be seated unless you're literally there when they open however, the wait is definitely worth it. Plus, they offer a cup of coffee while you wait which is nice since it tends to be cold in SF. My favorite dish is "The Plow", it comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, potatoes and Chicken apple sausage. One word, heaven.
author: Laura F.

description:
My friend suggested an early-ish brunch Saturday morning at 8am.  It's quite frankly too early for me but I oblige.  I arrive at 8am and he is already in line and we barely get the second-to-last table.  

I loved the space here--high ceiling, big windows, and lots of light.  I felt torn looking at the menu, because everything I love for brunch is listed, including lemon ricotta pancake and pumpkin pancake, among others.  I ended up getting the Plow, the ultimate combo plate for noncommittal people like me, with eggs my way, house sausage patties, crispy potato home fry, and lemon ricotta pancake.  The crispy potato had nice golden brown crust and was hearty.  The lemon ricotta pancake was probably the best I have had, so fluffy and light, with just the right level of sweetness.  The coffee was good, too, and the service was friendly and relaxed.

By the time we left, there was a crowd of people waiting outside and apparently the wait can be long.  But they serve coffee to people in line, which is super nice!
author: Alice A.

description:
FINALLY went to Plow on a Sunday for brunch. Arrived around 10am and was told the wait will be 2-2.5hrs. Yikes. 

My friends and I walked over to Front Coffee to kill time and came back to Plow after about an hour. We waited another half an hour and were seated. 

The three of us ordered the "Plow" with house made pork sausages, an extra order of pork sausages, and a full order of lemon ricotta pancakes. My favorite part of the meal  were the crispy potatoes which were perfectly seasoned. I was underwhelmed by the pancakes :-\ I liked the lemon flavor, but it tasted a bit bland so I had to drown it in syrup. The texture was too gooey. The soft scrambled eggs were unmemorable and needed a lot of salt. The homemade pork sausages were good -- they had a bit of heat, which I appreciated. The cold brewed coffee was yummy. 

I probably won't be back any time soon given the underwhelming food and the unreasonable wait time.
author: Michelle K.

description: I was visiting from Vegas and researched gluten free restaurants prior to trip and came across Plow. I knew it had a wait because they're very popular! I came as a just one and got to be seated at the bar top area instead of wait 2 hours. I ordered the Annie's almond flour pancakes plus a side of eggs. SO GOOD!!
author: Cari G.

description: Amazing food!! But wait was super long.. and it is because of their limited space. I really wish this restaurant was bigger so we do not have to wait 2 hours to sit down.. a little upsetting. But when we waited they ask if you want coffee and when we sat we were given blankets and water. Food was soo good and lemon ricotta pancakes are the bomb.
author: Mckenna T.

description:
Plow is a great place for breakfast...as evidenced by the long line of people waiting outside even at ridiculous times like 8 AM on a Saturday morning.  What a bunch of crazies -- Saturdays are for sleeping in.

I got their French Toast - 3 thick and fluffy eggy bread slices with strawberry and lavender jam, mascarpone, and maple syrup. I have more of a savory tooth for brunch, but enjoyed this sweet dish a lot.

My husband got The Plow, which is a combo of lemon ricotta pancakes, bacon or sausage, eggs, and crispy potatoes. This is a good dish to order if you are new to Plow and want to sample different items.  However, his eggs were undercooked (to the point that the egg whites were slightly runny) and his chicken apple sausage was dry (it was seasoned well though).

I like the lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes a lot.  I may even want to make them at home, you know, at like 11 AM on a Saturday morning.

1 star off: I do not like dried sausage in my mouth. Get your mind out of the gutter. Read my review above.
author: Ally W.

description:
Plow - how do I love thee?  Let me count the ways...

1.  You are seriously the potato Maestro.  Hands down the best potatoes I've ever had. 
2.  Lemon ricotta pancakes.  
3.  Killer mimosas. 
4.  Phenomenal coffee.  
5.  OH MY biscuits.  
6.  Clean open kitchen with singing and dancing cooks.  
7.  Baked goodies are always amazing and they switch it up often to keep it exciting!
8.  Generous portions. 
9.  Recommend "The Plow" for a perfect Sunday Brunch. 
10.  Let's start again.  

Cons:

1.  Loooooong wait. 
2.  Some of the waitstaff/greeters can be a bit dry.  You can be cool AND friendly at the same time ya know!

I love the food so much that it makes me forgive the cons.  Highly recommend for a great breakfast.
author: Samantha M.

description: Food is great here but this is the second time this has happened to my husband and I. We really tried to give it another chance. I give it 1 star for making my family and I feel profiled and treated a certain way because of the way we look. It may not have been the case but it sure felt like it. Either it's that, or people who live in the neighborhood get preferential treatment. We got there and were quoted 20 minutes. Everything seemed okay until people who started arriving started to get seated before us. A good 4 parties. We are patient people but my husband decided to check on the wait and he noticed that the sign in sheet had been completely rewritten and he was told, "your table should be coming up". Outside there were 2 empty tables that could have easily been placed together, but then they seated another 2 parties who, of course, came after us. When finally my husband said we were leaving because we were obviously being skipped the hostess Jess, offered no apology and said, "This is a restaurant and how it works, this is how our tables are set up." Insinuating that she was not able to put two tables together outside when I have seen it done the last time we ate there. Her tone was very snotty and rude. She ended saying, "I don't know what I could've done differently really" all while rolling her eyes.  I have lived in SF all my life and I can't believe what this city has turned to, my husband and I both may look young but be have respectable jobs. We have both worked in costumer service and by the way she answered it was obvious she was young and did not know the definition of it. We didn't get upset we just walked away. Never coming back. I'd rather drive all the way to Sonoma Mission in for the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes than to come here again. So disappointed.
author: amber c.

description:
The lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing here! This place is so cozy and cute. 

I recommend getting here early because the wait can be awful! That's my only complaint. Definitely worth it though!
author: Archana Nadig K.

description: Baffled by the crowd outside Plow on a Friday morning, but the wait was probably around 15-20 minutes, not bad at all on a sunny day! The Plow is fantastic - 2 eggs any style, house potatoes, choice of 3 meats (homemade pork sausage, chicken apple sausage or bacon) and 2 pancakes. They say Lemon Ricotta and the bottom of the menu says no substitutions but we were able to get Pumpkin pancakes, which were quite delicious! Plow is a really cute space and a great brunch destination in SF, would totally come back.
author: Lydia W.

description: I finally got to try Plow!  All the hype about the lemon ricotta pancakes is true, they're absolutely delicious :) The staff told us the wait would be around 1 to 1.5 hours when we arrived at 11am :\ Luckily the actual wait was about 30 minutes after other people waiting went to Chez Maman instead. The Plow dish includes 2 eggs cooked whatever style you prefer, choice of bacon/pork sausage/chicken apple sausage, home potatoes and two small lemon ricotta pancakes. Yummies!!! I will definitely be back =)
author: Kaila Y.

description:
Came on a Wednesday morning, arrived somewhere around 930am. No wait, although it was packed. Think the people out front waiting were waiting for outdoor seating, but since it was a heat wave in sf I was more than happy to sit inside. 
Ordered the plow with eggs over medium. Comes with 2 eggs (however you like), a pile of the best crispy potatoes ever, 2 strips of bacon (or you can order some sort of sausage) and 2 small lemon ricotta pancakes, which were to die for. Honestly this breakfast is the type of breakfast that ruins future breakfasts to come. 
Also ordered one of their homemade biscuits on the side, cause they look so scrumptious. Uhhh, it was divine. Came with some sweet whipped butter. 
Added a mimosa to all this. 
Jealous?
author: Sarah U.

description:
Probably 4.5 stars, but have to give them the 5 for atmosphere and food. Okay, so we are huge fans of Dotties, and pretty much go there every day when in SF, but Dotties is closed on Wednedays (and as it turned out this trip Thursday too) so my brother in law (who lives in SF) recommended Plow.  It was a typical cool foggy day downtown, but was super sunny at Plow and wait was less than 10 minutes.
Coffee is fantastic (although they seem to only fill halfway each time). I ordered the corn beef hash was nice and light and very healthy tasting and the 3 other people in my group got the Plow which includes eggs, fried potatoes, choice of meats (everyone went for sausage) and lemon ricotta pancakes.  The pancakes are insanely good and could rival my favorite (Luluc in Brooklyn) and how can you go wrong with fried potatoes!
Highly recommend and can't wait to go back.
author: Jonathan H.

description: Long waits that are immensely with the incredible breakfast options.   Amazing eggs and breads.   Blood sausage and ricotta pancakes.   Amazing place
author: Jerod H.

description: My new fav breakfast place when I'm in town! Food is amazing, service is great. Breakfast sandwich is out of this world.
author: Melanie M.

description:
Okay I know my review is going to be a drop in the bucket. But forrealz, this place ain't all that. I ordered the plow (breakfast sampler) and although my potatoes were nicely crunchy on the outside and soft in the middle, everything else was just normally decent. Potatoes, eggs, small pancakes, sausage. Nothing to rave over. 

But THEN, for the rest of the day, I got to re-experience my meal in the form of stomach pains and queasiness. I called my brunch friend and asked her how she was feeling and she said her stomach was hurting too! The only thing our meals had in common were the eggs. 

I'm sorry, if you're a brunch place and you can't make eggs without making customers sick, you've got a problem.
author: Hilary F.

description:
GODDAMN THIS PLACE IS EXPENSIVE.

Its expected though, and they serve Equator coffee which is my favorite brand. So def a plus! They have outside seating which is also a plus. Oh and they have some sitting area outside for you to sit at while you wait too. Service was very good.

I got "The Plow". LEMON RICCOTTA PANCAKES= BOMB. Perfectly cooked over easy egg and crispy potatoes. I got the chicken apple sausages which were meh, were they packaged or something? Because there are "homemade pork sausages", that I wish I tried instead but will next time. Overall, sweet spot I would definitely come again.
author: Jefferson Y.

description:
A follow a photographer on Instagram and she frequently posted pictures from this place so I knew I had to try it the next time I was in town. Went with a few friends and we all ordered the Plow. Everything on this plate was delicious. The bacon and potatoes were cooked perfectly and the lemon ricotta pancakes were a nice delicate compliment to the rest of the meal. Definitely a healthy portion of food so come hungry. 

The atmosphere is nice but the place is on the smaller side, so don't come too hungry cause you'll probably need to wait a little bit before being seated. But it's worth it.
author: sara r.

description:
One is as Good as Two


I love the food here.  Fresh and locally sourced ingredients, well seasoned and well prepared, visually appealing-- the food is delicious.

What does put a sour taste in my mouth is the service.  I live in the neighborhood and appreciate the small businesses that still predominate the area.  Given the plethora of places, a diner has the choice of where to patronize and support.  Plow has tested this power of choice on several occasions.  The first experience was when my sister came alone on the weekend around 1:30. She was told by the host that single diners could not be seated.  She then inquired about the bar and about ordering to go, but was told that neither was possible.
She left disappointed and puzzled by their service but assumed it was perhaps their policy on a busy weekend.

After hearing about that experience, we were hesitant to try the restaurant but the online reviews persuaded us to at least give them a chance.  We were seated after about two hours, after receiving a call about our table being ready, and had a wonderful meal.  At the conclusion of the meal, we asked our server about their policy for solo diners and were told enthusiastically that solo diners were welcome, indicating their bar was a space that one could sit at.  And of course, takeout orders were possible.  We relayed what had been told on the previous occasion and the server insisted that it was not their policy to turn away solo diners, that they did indeed accept take out orders and that person who had given the erroneous information must not longer work there.  But in fact, as we departed from the restaurant, who did my sister see but the same person who had turned her away going into the back of the restaurant.

Was this a case of discrimination for being single?   A restaurant policy to turn over as many tables as possible? Or was this a case of inconsistent training for service?  I will give them the  benefit of a doubt.  Paranoid or not, these are questions that restaurants should heed when making decisions on turning away people.  Isn't one customer just as good as two, especially if you're sitting at a stool at the bar that would otherwise remain empty?  The closing of SF's critical darling, Local's Corner should be an opportunity for businesses to reexamine their business practices and the public's perception of their business policies.  Restaurants are in the hospitality business to make people satisfied.  Diners want not just excellent food but are at the restaurant for the social experience of eating out. Plow should remember that their success depends on the satisfaction of their diners.  And this is one diner who would rather take their business elsewhere than to have to support one that only cares about the bottom line.

Update July 2016
Plow no longer gives you a call to let you know that your table is ready.  When the wait invariably stretches from an hour to two or more during brunch hours, it's just plain mean to your customers to have them lingering outside on the stoop!  I realize it was a courtesy call, so I guess now they're just plain rude for taking it away.
author: Betty T.

description:
Yummy!!!!!!!!

This became one of my favorite brunch places in the city! I can't wait to go back! 

The wait was pretty accurate. We waited over 30 minutes which is what the manager or host told us when we put down our name. The service was fast and efficient as well. And the food was just sooo good! I got the plow sampler. The potatoes with Rosemary was sooo good. The egg was good and although I didn't like the ricotta lemon pancake (I wished I did) but that a "me" problem and not their fault. My boyfriend had their crab scramble and it was delicious as well. They put plenty of crab in there. Also ordered a side of fruit for our son and even the fruits were super fresh organic and our son are it all. Def a new tradition every Saturday for us.
author: Ava L.

description:
Great place for brunch. The line is insane on weekends but still a cool vibe hanging out on line even! If you can, go during the week. I personally don't like waiting on lines. Especially when I am hungry. 

Everything here is really good. I would recommend the crispy potatoes with whatever you get. Great little breakfast stop.
author: Christos C.

description: The food was delicious! The staff was incredibly patient and attentive. The space was cozy.
author: Veronika O.

description: This place is amazing. The freshness of the food that you receive is basically straight from a farm or a small local business. One will not be disappointed with anything! Beware of a wait, but it's worth it.
author: Jimmy Y.

description:
another yummy place that I would never have gone to because it's so out of the way from everything, but my friend insisted. We put our name down, and drove off to go get ice cream, and came back just as they called out name. :) great timing! 

I shared the plow plate, with a side of bacon and fruit. 
* lemon ricotta pancakes, you make me swoon with pleasure. 
* bacon, well, how can you go wrong there? 
* homemade sausage patties, you were a little short on the flavor. 
* fruit bowl: you are the pick me up that I was looking for. blood oranges, tangerines, some other non-melon fruit... glad to see you weren't honeydew, cantaloupe and watermelon. 

I want to be your neighbor.
author: Vicky L.

description:
For breakfast: 1 lemon ricotta pancake, 1 almond pancake, side of crispy potatoes.

The friggin best rosemary crispy potatoes i have ever had for breakfast. I gave some co-workers a sample, and they all quickly agreed. Great crunch, full flavor packed.

Pancakes, absolutely loved. There was some powder sugar dusted on top, no syrup (i had it to go, and didn't notice til i got to work) but they were scrumptious. I might have liked the ricotta one just slightly above the almond, but both were some of the best pancakes I've ever had. 

Only downfall, the price. I think i paid around $15 for everything..which wasn't a whole lot, but i will certainly be back
author: Abigail W.

description: WARNING: after eating the breakfast sandwich here, all other breakfast sandwiches become sad a depressing. And the potato hash browns! Goodnight! The breakfast 'bar' has been raised and there is no going back. THANK YOU PLOW!
author: Luke M.

description:
This was, hands down, the best brunch I've ever had in San Francisco. 
We did have a bit of a wait and after coming to check back in at the time we were told, it did get my blood a little heated up that we were passed over several minutes before and ended up having to wait another 15 minutes while they rotated through some other parties that were on the list after us, but . . . . the brunch we had did more than I could ever hope to lift our moods. 
The wife and I had 'The Plow' which they were happy to swap out the lemon ricotta pancakes. My brother raved about those but the almond flour pancakes were AMAZING too. Luckily I forgot to ask them to hold the potatoes because the potatoes were nearly worth the trip on their own. Beautifully tender on the inside and the loveliest, crunchy outside I have ever experienced. The bacon was was absolute perfection too. 

I can't think of a single thing I would change. You can count on us waiting patiently outside at least twice a month. 

Bravo Plow!!!
author: Deniz U.

description: Can't believe how good the lemon ricotta pancakes are. The rest of the food is fine, but pancakes are by far the best.
author: Oli J.

description: Overall a great experience. Almost full even on weekdays. Get 'the plow' to experience their best stuff: potatoes, eggs (poached was great), the meats, and of course the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes. I'm not a big fan of pancakes but these were fantastic. Great atmosphere and service as well.
author: Mert S.

description: 45+ minute wait for 2 on a saturday morning 9am. We both got 'the plow'. The lemon ricotta pancakes were amazing. Sausage was a-ok. Eggs were great. Service was fast & attentive. Couldn't quite convince myself if the whole package was worth that long of a wait for 2 people only.
author: Tina B.

description:
I read the Yelp Reviews. I'm a breakfast aficionado. I was intrigued.

About Timing: I read about long lines so I arrived at 8am on Sunday and about a dozen people waiting so I sat right down when they opened. By 8:30 it was almost full but still no wait.

I love going out for breakfast but I can prepare a better breakfast at home than I find in most restaurants. This is my breakfast dilemma. So when I read the reviews, I hoped that the food and great space would make it all worth while.

The space is impressive, clean, well-run and organized.

i ordered "the Plow". Each part of it was good but as a combination, i wasn't impressed. Runny, fried eggs without bread? I loved the crispy potatoes but they were not ideal for sopping up eggs. The ricotta pancakes were great. The pork sausage was good but putting these items together on a plate didn't do it for me. i never eat pancakes but the lemon ricotta pancakes were great but with pork sausage and fried eggs? The price was $20 before the tip.

Over-all: Plow experience is more like a rushed lunch at a hot new restaurant than the perfect breakfast in which one puts ones thoughts together for the day. Apparently from the reviews, Plow is popular and people were strategizing what to get before it opened at 8am on a Sunday. 

Personally, I prefer a leisurely breakfast where i take my time; enjoy browsing the paper in sunny comfort, breaking into caffeine induced philosophical discussions now and then. 

I recommend trying Plow but for my taste, as a breakfast experience, it may be a victim of it's own success.
author: Bill W.

description:
Three of us came here at 1pm on Sunday and it took an hour to get seated. It was another 30 minutes for food. We ate in 20 minutes,  got the bill and left in 25. The most relaxing part of this brunch was waiting at Farley's, a nearby coffee shop. 

After 40 minutes at the coffee shop, the table still wasn't ready. They gave us free apple fritters while we waited. I think this is their beignet but they called it "apple fritter" when they gave it to us. Freebies are a generous move and it was much appreciated.  

They told us a table would be another 20 minutes but the counter was available.  We waited 20 minutes anyway for our food.

I was grumpy from hunger and impatience by the time my eggs benedict came.  My poached eggs had several pieces eggshells in them.  I bit down and felt a disgusting crunch.  Aww hell naw hell naw.  Further insult - the hollandaise was no longer emulsified.  The sauce had curdled.  Gross.  Lastly, it was not good in flavor... they added too much lemon.  Thumbs down for this dish; the other components were just so so.  The side of crispy potatoes with onions was the best thing on the plate.

My lemon ricotta pancake never came so they just canceled it and I GTFO'd.

The wait is definitely not worth it.  Not even if it was good.  Which it wasn't.

- - - - -

Comments unrelated to food:

Sitting at the counter gave us a full view of the cooking.  One line cook who was in charge of eggs had a permanent close-to-tears look on his face.  My friend asked if I thought they liked cooking, since he was literally pumping out eggs (fried! poached! scrambled!) dish after dish.  This guy was a one-man sweatshop for eggs.  He and the other line cook (who was in charge of meats and pancakes) very much earned their salary.  

There was a woman in the kitchen who was in charge of potatoes and plating, and she would snack on every other dish she was preparing.  She was super chill and seemed to be just standing around every five minutes while the other two line cooks toiled away.  She also only wore an apron instead of a chef's jacket.  This led me to believe she was BOSS.

I think it was just my hunger talking but I started to resent every dish she plated that wasn't my food.  She kept snacking everything she plated/prepared.  Where was my damn snack?  (Ok, definitely hunger talking since they gave me my damn snack in the form of a free apple fritter.)
author: Erika C.

description: We waited 2.5 hours when the wait staff said it would be a two hour wait. After two hours they wouldn't even tell us how many people were ahead of us and just kept saying "it will be a bit longer" the apathetic staff was incredibly frustrating. I am still waiting as I write this. Why? Who knows?
author: Justin G.

description:
They don't take reservations so our wait time was almost an hour. By the time it was our turn to eat, they ran out of the Monkey bread. Bummer!!

I ordered the Plow,  which included two eggs any style, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potato & house made pork or chicken apple sausage. The Lemon Ricotta pancake was simply the best, just cant be missed. 

The servers are friendly and accommodating. If you are a dog lover then this is a perfect spot to hang out with your canine while brunching.
author: En J.

description: The service is good and the food is delicious! But I was pretty disappointed when I went today and they charged me $4 to replace the meat side of The Plow with fruit. Even for SF prices, that's a little absurd...
author: Megan H.

description: The frebch toast with marcaspon was great.. so was the strawberry lemonade. My favoeite thing was their biscuit.  I culd have eatten 5 of them. I also got the plow. Good portion.
author: Nam V.

description:
Their crispy potatoes are addicting! So flavourful... savory, and naturally sweet. They are super crispy... I love them!

My sister and I shared the The Plow and the French toast with red wine poached pears. The French toast was okay. It was nothing special, and was actually lacking a little oomph. The Plow consisted of two eggs (over easy), house made sausage patties, crispy potatoes and two lemon ricotta pancakes. The patty was good, and the pancake was delish!
author: Leslie P.

description: I didn't feel the food was that great. The potatoes were deep fried (not my thing) and the pancakes were average. I paid $17 for a meal that I could have gotten anywhere else. I was disappointed, especially because we waited 2 hours for a table.  I will not be coming back for seconds.
author: Jamie B.

description:
Neat little breakfast/brunch restaurant serving VERY delicious breakfasts. Tastier than the famous Mama's in my opinion. Every item on the plate has its own unique flavor and texture, yet it works all so well together.

I'm a foodie who not only loves eating, but also loves cooking. I can usually make the typical cafe style breakfast/brunch at home, so I usually don't find breakfast menu surprising or eye catching, to me they're all pretty much the same. But at Plow, even their potatoes stand out of the breakfast restaurant crowd! Its crunchiness is amazingly  addictive that makes your teeth wanting to take one bite after another ( yet it's stil; fluffy on the inside). 

I had 'The Plow" because i wanted to try the well-reviewed lemon ricotta pan cakes but I also wanted a salty breakfast ( The plow comes with 2 small pan cakes along with home made sausages and your choice of eggs). The lemon ricotta pan cakes didn't do it for me, BUT, the pork sausages I had was so flavored and made with high quality minced meat that left me amazed at how delicious it was at every bite. 

Again, I usually find breakfast at restaurants really average, but Plow's breakfast went beyond my expectation, it is truly worth the wait.

Very busy if you are visiting in weekend. No table reservations, first come first served, put your name on the wait list and walk around the neighborhood. They only seat you if all parties have arrived.
author: Lianne M.

description:
This place is two blocks from my house and I've been meaning to go for some time but the line is forever. Like, over an hour and I really don't believe any place is worth that, even if it's excellent, especially when there are so many other good choices in the city. Not their fault though: there isn't a lot of seating inside the tiny space and they use it the best they can.

If you can come back on an off-hour (I went at 12pm on a Wednesday and got the last two seats at the counter), it's very good.

Most reviews talk about the Lemon Ricotta pancakes (which I had) and the Breakfast Sandwich (which my boo ordered) and it's mainly because there isn't much else on the menu. Unless you like to order granola or porridge or yogurt for breakfast, which has never made sense to me as a restaurant patron, there's some combination of pancakes and eggs.

The good news is that they're both excellent! And those crispy potatoes are great.

I'm giving them the fifth star for two reasons:

1) They have Nueske's Bacon, which is probably my favorite stuff on the market.

2) They have a hot sauce brand I've never heard of and is made in the same zip code. I'm always so annoyed when I ask for hot sauce at a place and I get either Tapatio or Cholula, as both are unappealing to me. It's a bit of a surprise that more places don't make their own hot sauce as it's not too difficult and it's a nice touch. And the stuff at Plow? Not too watery and a great kick. Much better than the over the counter crap.
author: Brandon K.

description:
WARNING BOLD STATEMENT AHEAD:

This is the BEST brunch in San Francisco!  

I'll admit it, when it comes to mornings and me, we just don't get along.  Luckily I had returned from Massachusetts the night before AND the time changed in my direction, so I was actually awake and ready to go somewhere at 8am on a Sunday!  (according to most yelpers this place usually has a wait for brunch, and I'm an inpatient gal when it comes to gettin' my grub on)

I had the "plow" with lemon ricotta pancakes, house-made pork sausage, 2 eggs over easy (which frankly were a little underdone, but note they still get 5 stars) and the AMAZING crispy potatoes.  My bf had the breakfast sandwich.  

They were a little chintzy with the pure maple syrup, but my neighbors left their table and I stole what they had left so I had enough.

I have never had breakfast potatoes so perfect, super crispy, with caramelized onions and rosemary - and LOTS of 'em.

YUM and YUM.
author: Amy W.

description:
Is it just me or am I the only one feeling over the high prices and average quality/ service of restaurants in SF? My roommate said she heard Plow restaurant was the "it" brunch spot in SF right now. So, me and a few friends decided to have a Saturday fun day, starting with Plow. 

Such a disappointment. Sad, annoyed face. Hoping for that exchange value for time, $$$ and super mouth watering food, I was left thinking "I would pay $12 max ( I paid nearly $17) for that dish and wait 30 min max for the food/ service.

I got the "Plow" entree...Two eggs, 2 pancakes, potatoes, and sausage.  Everything was so average. The potatoes were deep fried and basically like eating greasy fries. The pancakes were forgettable. Lemon Ricotta are a personal fav and they were probably the worst I have tasted. I was so excited about the menu with so many unique options, but after trying my friends and my dishes, it was clear to me that I would never return to Plow.

I'm growing tired of the crazy prices and long waits for really average food and service. The place is cute, but not cute enough to overshadow a mediocre dining experience. 

Kudos to Plow for one thing... Humanely raised meat.
author: Laura O.

description:
This place had a line 12 people deep before it even opened on a saturday, and for a good reason. The ambiance was welcoming, with warm wood trim and tables juxtaposed with stainless steel and brushed metal accents. The windows let in the right amount of light, and made this somewhat narrow restaurant with maybe 12 tables and a counter seem bigger than it is. The open kitchen is a nice touch, too.

And the food was very good, as was the coffee. We had the cassoulet, which was something like ham hocks, duck confit, and some other meat broiled with beans in a savory broth - hearty and delicious. 'The Plow', my dish, was delicious in it's simplicity, and really just perfect. Potatoes (crispy + yum), eggs, bacon, and lemon ricotta pancakes (just the right amount of lemon, no syrup needed). 

What more can i say, except that I've found a place i will be coming back to for breakfast and brunch rather often *sigh*.
author: Vittorio L.

description:
My husband and I pop down to SF a few times a year.  He lived there for 6 years and it is his favorite city.  This was our first visit to Plow and we really enjoyed it.  We arrived at about 10:45 on Tuesday and were seated immediately.  

For breakfast, we ordered the softly scrambled eggs and the plow - two eggs, meat of your choice (we got the homemade sausage), potatoes and lemon ricotta pancakes.  We were mostly MEH about the scrambled eggs - they were good but nothing special.  The pancakes were fantastic and I wish they were like 12 inches bigger so I could just make a lemon ricotta pancake hat to wear for forever.  But the real winner was those damn potatoes.  My husband and I actively debated on how we could replicate them.  Don't think we will be able to.  

Oh, coffee and mimosas were good too. 

We will be back to Plow though I don't know if we would do a two hour wait.
author: A K.

description:
So happy I ran into this place. 

The Lemon Ricotta Pancake is a MUST TRY.
I'm not a pancake person at all and it was phenomenal.  Hands down the best pancake Iv'e ever had in my life. 

Aside from that the garlic potatoes were also amazing. 

When you enter, it's very cozy, with a homey feel.  The kitchen is open for everyone to see and they get down to business to get you a one-of-a-kind mouth watering meal. 

If this is the only place I get to visit the next time I'm in SF, that would be ok.
author: Christopher S.

description: 3 words.... GET THE PLOW!!! So amazing.. Hands down best breakfast ever. The "plow" dish is so filling and so amazing I was so happy. I wish the place had more seating because it is so popular which makes the wait time very long. Parking is super easy.. There are so many spots available on the street by the restaurant. Hostess is very good with the estimation of time as it is fun to walk around for a little while waiting. Will always be my favorite breakfast place!!!
author: Kayla F.

description:
Items selected:

Equator Coffee
Blueberry Streusel Muffin
Lemon Ricotta Pancake
French Toast with Strawberries, Mascarpone, Maple Syrup

Another day led to another breakfast near Potrero Hill, this time at Plow where Maxine Siu and a small team of four embracing the theme of "Midwest country boy meets San Francisco China girl" churned out a an eclectic list of early morning classics to a constantly packed dining room of locals and tourists alike.  With friendly service from a young woman named Kirby and a seat at the bar allowing me to watch the kitchen at work the duration of my stay was bookended with copious refills of rich Mocha Java from Equator with three plates between, the first a dense blueberry muffin stuffed with fresh berries and the latter two single orders of the restaurant's highly praised ricotta pancakes and custard soaked French Toast.  Rich and decadent, particularly after the addition of pure maple syrup, it would be a tough call as to whether the French Toast was quite as good as that at nopa but no matter which side of the fence one falls on both are in the upper echelon of their genre and unlike nopa Plow offers their breakfast all week.
author: Michael U.

description:
Eating breakfast with a 5-star restaurant experience is all the rage now days and the Plow is one of the hot-spots. My basic take-away - the food is good, much better than average, the service is reminiscence of high dining, although I think I prefer my breakfast in a more low-key friendly vibe. 

My dish was The Plow. Crispy potatoes, eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes,  and house made sausage patties. The crispy potatoes were the best home fries, cut potatoes I've had. I'm definitely a fan. The lemon ricotta pancakes were good, eggs were eggs, and the sausage was a tad dry. For $17, I wasn't impressed except by the potatoes.... and $17 to be wowed by potatoes is disappointing.

My final word: Definitely not worth the hour plus long waits on the weekend, but without a wait, I'd try it again.
author: Leona Z.

description: It was my first time here and it was delicious! I got the buttermilk biscuit. Amazing!! The butter is sweetened. I tried the eggs Benedict and French toast. Both are winners. The potatoes are a must have. It's not a large location and there is always a line, but going to Farleys down the street for coffe while you wait makes it go by fast.
author: Sonya J.

description:
Plow is one of the hottest glowing epicenters for breakfast on this earth. You can see it from space, glowing and winking--- the smell of their famous potatoes cutting through the atmosphere into your space station and causing every astronaut to salivate and pine for home. 

I'm a longtime eater, first-time writer about the majesty that is this wonderful breakfast place. They have completely captivated the majority of San Francisco and definitely don't need my help, this is just a love letter to their high level of consistency, execution, and creativity.

There has never been a time when a plow classic has thrown me off whether it'd be the lemon ricotta pancakes, egg sandwich, or "The Plow" (eggs, sausage or bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes). Each time I've had them they've tasted exactly the same, which is a very good thing. The potatoes are always amazingly flaky and moist on the inside but crispy and herbaceous on the outside. They remind me of Jonathan Waxman's famous potatoes at Barbuto, except I don't have to travel all the way to New York for them.

They also take recipes from great breakfast places all over this nation such as Joanne Chang's Flour in Boston and execute them exceptionally. Their really nailed Joanne's chocolate brioche with pastry cream recipe... I hope they do her sticky buns with goo next!

I also love it when they do their own seasonal riffs of breakfast, my favorite of all time was their "Chinese Breakfast" which had delicious red roasted pork on top of fluffy rice topped off with a fried egg. I will probably scream and jump up and down for joy when they bring it back--- it was one of the yummiest breakfasts I've ever had. *Siiigh* Those tender and aromatic pieces of pork mixed with the unctuousness of an oozing yolk on top of pristine pearly rice, oh god, it's a recipe for love potion.

My only advice is to get here as soon as they crack open their doors. Waiting an hour to eat food is pretty painful and is especially devastating when it's your first meal of the day.
author: Lisa Q.

description:
was looking for a brunch place and stumbled upon this one because apparently its so good that people eat out here in the RAIN. its quite adorable and a little crazy so i had to give it a try. Came late on a Friday afternoon around 1? was seated right away. I ordered the Fried Egg Sandwich and my bf ordered The Plow. The Fried Egg Sandwich wasn't bad - didn't realize there would be no meat in this meal but i do love aioli sauce! wished there were more. The sandwich came with crispy potatoes and grilled onions - that was really good. super crispy on the outside and the potato texture on the inside. The Plow came with your choice of meat - i believe they make it themselves? with crispy potato, 2 eggs your style, and the LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES. Those were amazing. Crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside. I believe there was cheese in there but i couldn't taste it. The lemon addition in the pancake was amazing. felt like i was eating a pastry! I dont usually like pancakes cause they're a little on the heavy side but these were so light. I will be getting an order of Lemon Ricotta Pancakes next time :)

beware - this meal comes with food coma -____- at least it did for us!
author: Kristina L.

description: Def worth the hype! I woke up at 7:30am on a Sunday and made my way to Plow with high hopes. We put our name down for a table of 4 at 8:30am, and we were seated just under an hour late. It was reassuring to know that others woke up even earlier than I did. I got The Plow: eggs, crispy potatoes, homemade pork sausage, and lemon ricotta pancakes. Everything was exceptional.The fennel in the sausage was a bit overwhelming, and I prefer links to patties. But other than that, 5 stars!
author: Benjamin A.

description:
I live in Potrero and try to support local businesses as much as I can, but I haven't gotten a lot of chances to support Plow. And this is why:
--The wait is too long. They don't take reservations and won't call you when your table is ready. My boyfriend and I have walked away three times from Plow because of this.
--No takeout on the weekends. Again, loss of potential business. 
--Over priced for the proportions. The food is good (ricotta pancakes anyone??) but it's hard for me to justify spending $15 on scrambled eggs.
author: Mel C.

description: The food is fine, but the wait is ridiculous. Definitely not worth waiting more than 20 mins for. After close to two hours, yet another avocado toast and lemon ricotta pancake just don't do it. There's nothing wrong with taking reservations. The one star is for the biscuits, which are fantastic.
author: Sam R.

description: Great breakfast menu, especially if you are a carnivore.  Service and food were great!
author: Susie S.

description:
If I could design my dream neighborhood, Plow would be in it. I dig its modern, clean lines, natural wood furnishings, high ceiling, big windows, sunlight, and its local, organic, sustainable offerings Their amiable staff are like a well oiled machine - efficient and reliable. I was impressed by how quickly they turned the tables to greet its waiting patrons. 

We had:

- Corn Millet Muffin with sweet butter * - my sharp-eyed friend noticed that the asterisked items are 'until it's gone' ~  the law of supply & demand bumped them up as a priority to consider. The muffin had a nice texture, flavor and a dash of warmth. On the other hand, its butter sidekick was cold & hard, making it awkward to spread on the delicate muffin ~ if I had a lighter, I could've softened it a bit.

- Coffee Cake * - Although it didn't stand out, it was a good, sweet compliment to our meal. 

- Pork Chops (a bit too briny for my palate, but cooked to a nice doneness). Came with crispy potatoes and eggs prepared your way - we chose scrambled.

- Eggs Benedict with Spinach and Mushrooms - My favorite. Eggs poached perfectly with a deliciously flavorful hollandaise sauce and crispy potatoes with caramelized onions (same potatoes that accompanied the Pork Chops).

Our meal was delightful ~ I couldn't stop eating. I was tempted to call the local wheelbarrow company to cart me out.
author: Cathy K.

description:
We went in on a Sunday for Brunch as a party of 7. They don't typically seat a table of 7 but after a bit of discussion they were ok with seating us outside. We put our names down and then had to wait for a little over 2-1/2 hours to get a table. At this point, it is fairly standard for all good Brunch places in San Francisco and being a large party definitely made it worse. But oh well, at least there is a nice bookstore a block away to kill some time. I also recommend stopping at Farley's and getting a croissant and coffee. 

The group ordered a medley of dishes, the lemon ricotta pancackes, the french toast, the fried egg sandwich and the Plow. I won't bore the reader with the details (800 other reviews describe them quite accurately), but they were all delicious. I especially liked the sweet stuff (the french toast and pancakes) versus the fried egg. The potatoes with the fried egg was pretty awesome but I think the egg sandwich at Mission beach cafe is just a tad bit better. 

Overall, I think it is a very good brunch place. But I am just not convinced waiting 2-1/2 - 3 hrs for brunch here is worth it. But I am loath to make other recommendations since the good ones all have a long wait. At least parking over here is not a beast.

On a side note, this place opens at 8AM so if you are up early and are interested in getting an awesome SF brunch, this is the place to go.
author: Rahul H.

description:
I've been here a handful of times now and I think I can confidently say this is my absolute favorite breakfast place in the city. We have driven here and organized our day around this place. The food is just amazing. I love the "plow" because you get a little bit of everything all on one plate - meat, eggs, potatoes and pancakes. Everything is so freakin delicious. I'm being totally serious. Not to mention, they have an awesome hot sauce that I believe is from Mavericks.

The wait can get ridiculously long, so come before 10am if you can. And they have outdoor seating so it's perfect for our little Ninja to join us every time. 

*Blankets provided to keep you nice and toasty.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Damnnnn... people in SF seriously love their brunch.  I mean sure NY-ers like their brunch too, but this town brings it to a whole new level.  Arrived at Plow at 11am and there was a 2 hour wait!  NOT A JOKE.  Ok, so since its not in the hustle and bustle part of the city and anywhere else worth it would have a similar wait, my friend and I decided to get a coffee, check out the neighb, and wait it out.

Yes, its good, but its brunch.  So while it was a delish egg and some tasty crispy potatoes (for which they are known), not sure I would repeat the madness here when you can make make reservations elsewhere.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Be prepared to wait, there's a line before they open at 7:50AM on Sunday!  To make things a bit more comfortable, Plow offers coffee in ceramic mugs to people in the line.  There's also the option of ordering mimosas or mixed drinks before you're seated.  Get your early buzz on!

The star of Plow is not the sunny dining space or the friendly staff - both of which might stand out as exceptional at a lesser restaurant.  The star is the food.  It's phenomenal!

The lemon pancakes are a thing of wonder.  I've been to Plow three times for these pancakes and it took more than a dozen experiments at home before I was able to create a reasonably similar pancake.  If you value time and sanity more than money, the best bet is head to Plow for the lemon pancakes and don't worry about making them yourself.
author: Ivan L.

description: Ok so let me just begin by saying this place lived up to the hype. I love breakfast and I am picky about how I spend my calories. I am also from New England and I know real maple syrup. That said, the lemon ricotta pancakes are maybe the best pancakes I've ever had the honor of eating. I'm not the world's biggest potato fan and the roasted home fry rosemary potatoes with the local hot sauce put this over the edge.  I got the plow with scrambled eggs and the pork sausage. My husband got the eggs Benedict with ham,  mushrooms and spinach which also came with the potatoes,  and was also quite good. The January morning air was chilly  but it was a sunny day so we opted to sit outside as the wait was much shorter. While we were waiting we were given unlimited coffee. When we actually sat down we were given blankets for out laps which was very cozy. Our server was extremely attentive and knowledgeable and kept out coffee mugs and water glasses filled.
