Start to finish this was one of the best breakfast experiences we have ever had and we will definitely be back to try the other menu items. I am sure I will be dreaming about lemon ricotta pancakes until we return.
author: Nancy N.

description:
Ambience is as important as food -- Plow delivers on both.

Outside of this quaint cafe in a sleepy part of Potrero,  a stylish crowd will wait an hour, or more, to be seated shoulder to shoulder with each other. The ambience is conversational, although the patrons don't socialize outside of their group.

Plow serves a classic American brunch menu consisting of all natural ingredients that are deliciously high in sodium. Quality meat; potatoes/bacon are extra crispy; and great for sharing.

As a fashionable diner, Plow makes my top ten list of brunch spots.
author: Balind S.

description: I'm sure if I had been attended to, the food would have been great. But at 7:15 am, with only a handful of tables occupied, someone should at least be able to greet and hand you a menu within minutes. Instead I waited 10 minutes with no acknowledgment and just walked out. The Asian lady, who was standing in front of me at the counter, continued to cut and eat a piece of the bundt cake. The two other serves just walked around aimlessly. I don't care how good your food is, customer service goes a long way.
author: tiffany p.

description:
Delicious. Came here with a couple of friends and their baby; the staff was really accommodating and wrote down our party as 3.5 people. (Note: They don't take parties larger than 6 people due to limited space inside the restaurant.) 

I ordered the soft scramble with hen of the woods mushrooms. It was perfectly seasoned and cooked just right, and served with crispy potatoes and buttered bread. Tried a bit of the lemon ricotta pancake from my friend's plate, and omg, it was amazing. I plan to go back just for those pancakes. Tried a bit of the dungeness crab scramble from my other friend's plate, also very good, but a bit too briny-tasting for me. 

Service was fine. Only downside was the wait. We got there around 10 AM and wound up waiting an hour for a table. But I will say it was worth the wait.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
Came here on a Friday around 1pm for a late brunch. Waited about 10-15 minutes before we were finally seated.

My friend and I both ordered a French toast to share. It was actually really good. The pears were so soft and sweet. The French toast was a perfect line between soggy and soft. 8.5/10 stars.

I ordered the yogurt and granola. It was probably one of the best I have ever had. It tasted so fresh and the granola was soooo good!!!

My friend ordered the plow. She liked the lemon ricotta pancakes because it didn't taste like you're eating a bunch of flour. The apple chicken sausage was pretty good too. The potatoes were okay.

We both had the fresh squeezed lemonade which was $4.50 without a refill. I was a literally turned off by that. I had to pay an extra $1 for a refill. The glass was not even that big! It was probably 8-12oz. I was like really!? Aside from that, the lemonade was actually very good and refreshing. 

Parking was fairly easy and it was free!
author: Ann Z.

description:
From the moment we arrived, we knew that an amazing experience was about to ensue. Arriving just prior to Plow opening, we parked our rental car on a San Francisco-esque  steeply-inclined side street and waited patiently for the doors to open.

Promptly at 7am we were greeted at the door by a beautiful waitress wearing a pearly-white smile. We were the first ones to be seated and had the place to ourselves. This was our final morning in San Francisco, so we were looking for an amazing meal to digest and reflect upon over the flight home. San Francisco food experiences had been quite kind to us during our stay, so the bar had been set high.

The decor, ambiance, music selection, and courteous staff were nothing short of amazing. I was also delighted to see the offering of gluten free pancakes. Progressive cities like SF make eating delicious, yet health conscious, meals so effortless. Anyways, I ordered the plow, substituting the lemon ricotta pancakes for their gluten free counterpart. Upon the arrival, first, of a french press filled with Ecuadorian coffee, then their decadent chia seed pudding. Both of which were very delightful. Next, our meals arrived. The food quality was far superior to what is attainable in our area of the East Coast. 

We ate our meal, took in the scenery, chatted with our waitress, and even bumped into a fellow Massachusetts resident who had given us the recommendation for Plow over dinner at a great Indian place just the night before.

Overall, I couldn't have been happier with our experience at Plow. It was the absolute perfect way to close our our trip. San Francisco was the most warm, inviting, and friendly city I have visited to date and Plow was the physical embodiment of the vibe which SF resonates.
author: Seth T.

description:
Just one visit was all it took for this cute little restaurant to top my list of favorite breakfast/brunch spots.  Although the cozy atmosphere was pleasant and the service standard, it was all about the food for me at Plow.  

I had the Two Eggs with Chicken Apple Sausage.  The eggs were scrambled exactly the way I like them--not dry, not runny, no browning portions, lightly salted.  The potatoes were light and crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  These are the best potatoes I've had for breakfast in a long time.  I've never had chicken sausage before so I have nothing to compare these to, but they were pretty good as well.  They were greasy (as are most sausages), but not excessively so.  Even the two pieces of toast--a part of the meal I don't usually bother with--were crunchy, warm, and lightly buttered.  The orange juice was sweet and refreshing (albeit small... even though I ordered a large glass).  

I enjoyed everything I tasted during my visit to Plow and I very much look forward to returning sometime soon.  I hear it gets extremely busy on the weekends, though, so it'll have to be another weekday morning.
author: Carol Y.

description: Great service, great food. Sit at the bar on a weekday morning and watch the magic happen
author: Badrul F.

description: One of my favorite places for breakfast. I stopped going on weekends, as the line is too long but any chance I have during the weekdays I'll try to head to Plow. Lemon Ricotta pancakes are a must try
author: Ryan K.

description:
Mr. Plow, that's my name, my name again is Mr. Plow. 

Oops. Wrong Plow. 

This Plow serves tasty food. 

I came here with Ruth C. one morning before going to the Bazaar Bizzare Craft Show downtown. After I dropped her off to find parking (an easy-by-SF-standards 10 minutes), she informed me there was an hour wait. 

Now, for good brunch, an hour is nothing. Many debates have been had in NYC brunch places (yes, I know this is SF, but you wait a similar amount of time for good brunch here!), and there have been stories of showing up 3 hours before closing (think Clinton Street Baking Company) and being told that you won't be able to get seated that day. 

The only negative experience was the wait, though. The estimated wait time and the actual are nothing alike. If you're not there when they call your name, you get skipped. And yes, that means that if your name magically gets called 15 minutes after you put it down (and you wandered off because they told you to wait an hour), you get skipped. Really, really annoying. So bring your Kindle and coat (if it's cold), and stay put.

We got seated at the counter (with rosemary plants!) with a full view of the stoves. Really fun to watch! Out of the three guys working, one looks useless. I think this is also typical. The stove master is boss, though. Watching him work though palates of eggs was super fun. 

Beverages were tasty (although I thought the mimosa overpriced for the size), and I got the Plow in order to try a bit of everything. Here's the rundown:

- Potatoes are crispy outside, soft inside, well-seasoned, and very tasty. 
- Pork sausage was the best meat option (homemade patties are delicious!)
- Ricotta pancakes were bland and had a weird ricotta cheese texture (ha!) 

I'd come back.
author: Ingrid C.

description:
I LOVE PLOW. Haven't been since early this year, but,
Believe everything that everyone else says about this place, it's as good as it gets and is worth the wait. (for the most part..depends if you're busy or not)
Lemon ricotta, I will come back for more. ;)
author: Alyssa Z.

description:
Expect at least an 1.5 hour wait! But never fear, there's a cute coffee shop just up the street where you can get coffee (or in my case an almond chai tea latte :-)). They have plenty of seating inside and a nice outdoor veranda. But enough about this coffee shop, on to Plow!

It didn't feel like we had to wait that long (but partly because we grabbed caffeine after we put our names down and before we sat down) - it was maybe a half hour wait? But the waitress/hostess was kind enough to say that we could enjoy sidewalk mimosas if we wanted to - so a definite plus!

The best thing about the menu though were the crispy potatoes! They were definitely cooked to a crisp! My mouth is watering just a little thinking about them haha. I ordered the fresh crab scramble - delish! Not too heavy and mind if I reiterate how yummers the crispy potatoes were? I think I might've licked my plate clean ...
author: Christina C.

description:
How could I not like a restaurant with a copy of the Rancho Gordo heirloom-bean cookbook on the shelf near the entrance?  Incredibly charming, with tasty San Francisco comfort food and a bubbly, Californiaesque waitstaff.

My homemade sausage patty was tasty.  My eggs over easy were a little too runny, even for me, and I like them very runny.  The bite of a donut I tried was good, but only in that way all fresh donuts are.  I'm not saying I could make this stuff, but it still reminded me a lot of my kitchen.

I would go here again, but I'd feel awkward taking people here.
author: William B.

description: Best roasted potatoes ever. I haven't had any potatoes that come remotely close to being as good as Plow. I could come here just for the potatoes.
author: Sherilyn T.

description: 2 hour wait....  No thanks.  You shouldn't have to have breakfast to hold you over while you wait in line.
author: Arthur C.

description: The food is what keeps me coming back. The potatoes are better than anywhere else i've been and the pork sausage is delicious. The waiters are great. The toughest part is getting past the hostess(es) who are rude and definitely play favorites. Be prepared for a long, cold wait. They won't let you wait inside (no room).
author: Christine T.

description:
came here for breakfast, waited for more than an hour, but looks like they are always busy.

my friend loves brunch a lot but I am not a big fan of it. Plow pleased me with their food and decoration. I felt relaxed and delightful sitting on their table. their food is not too salty, which I love the it the most.

we ordered quit a lot because we waited for an hour standing outside. there are place to sit outside, but we leave them for the senior. I have no complaint on any of their food. the chai seed pudding is very good, you will like it if you are someone like me, who doesn't like things being too sweet.

over all very good experience, except for the wait is quit long.
author: Zack Y.

description:
Let me preface this with stating that I had to wait a couple hours before I could sit down and eat.  So hunger might have made the food taste better than it should.  Food that we ordered

Crispy pig ears with a pickled egg - It comes with a chili vinaigrette but ask for the chili jam.  That chili jam is amazing and made everything taste better.  The pig ears were coated in batter and fried (ergo crispy) but the inside was melt in my mouth tender.  If you do get this, share it.  It is very rich. 

The plow - two eggs (whatever style), house made pork sausage, and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes.  This comes with a small container of real maple syrup.   This was AMAZING.  GET IT.  The pancakes are small, rich and oh my god so fluffy.  The eggs were ordered sunny side up and they were prefect.  The yolk was runny and the white is completely set. 

Soft egg scramble with goat cheese, lambsquarter and oyster mushrooms - This was decent but not my favorite.  I just didn't want to get another the plow (like my partner).  I don't regret my choice but I do think the plow was the much better idea.

Coffee - I don't know what they use but the this coffee was extremely fruity and not bitter at all.  They constantly refill the cup too.

All main came with crispy potato.  This was extremely good, especially with the chili jam. 

TLDR: If you are going to come here, bear in mind that you would need to wait at least  an hour (we got here around 11:30 on a Saturday)

Cost: You should expect to spend around $20+/person for food.
author: Jessica P.

description:
One of my favorite brunch places in SF, and I've been to a lot!! I always get The Plow and the crab omelette. The lemon ricotta pancakes are delish.

Only thing that keeps me from coming all the time is the wait, besides one time I went super early, other times have always been hour+ waits (which is pretty much the case at every decent brunch place).

Sitting outside is nice on a sunny day but it tends to get really cold & windy at times so bring a jacket!!
author: Grace H.

description:
Potatoes are my favorite food group.  Period.

So, when I read Amy C.'s review about their potatoes, I knew I had to drag my culinary soulmate, Sara P., to Plow.

We waited about 20 minutes on a Sunday morning around 10, which isn't bad.  By the time we were done, there were significantly more people sitting around outside, so I'm glad we beat the crowd.

Once seated, we had the tough job of deciding what to eat.  Everything sounded like the best thing ever, and finally, the Fried Egg Sandwich beat out Eggs Benedict juuuust a little bit.  Next time, Eggs Benny, next time.

I added bacon to my sandwich for a total of $11.75.  It was a heavenly combination of frisee, melted cheese, runny fried egg, and perfectly cooked bacon.  The only thing that would've made it better is if it had been on crunchy, crusty bread rather than a soft bun.

Totally a fan of breakfast/brunch, and this place rocked my morning.
author: Tori S.

description: Plow came as a highly recommended place from family. Waited ~40 minutes while having a coffee from a nearby shop. I do not see what the hype is about. The wait gets rather long for food I would not wait at all for. It is decent food, nothing wrong with it..but nothing spectacular and definitely not memorable. Maybe its a better lunch spot? Both my friend and I thought the breakfast was mediocre with only passable service. Maybe you'll have better luck on something other than the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and Salmon Benedict
author: Braxton D.

description: Great breakfast with great potatoes and even awesome milk! I ordered their signature the plow and my friend the egg Benedict. Also, I love the way they work because I took the counter and watched they prepare for our food. It's Super organized and clean. It's totally worth the 45min wait. Afterall a great breakfast lights up your day.
author: Robin W.

description:
I'd like to tell you that Plow is awful, that you should go somewhere else, that there's nothing to see here... move along...  I'd like to tell you that so I won't have to wait as long for my go-to breakfast in SF, hands down. 

Sure, the potatoes are amazing, the house made pork sausage is spot on, and the lemon ricotta pancakes (with house made ricotta) are a welcome delight.  But then you dig into the breakfast sandwich, the seasonal salads (chilled roasted squash on a salad?!  Hell yeah), the all too rarely available biscuit sandwich, the even more annoyingly rare (and monumentally delicate) fried chicken sandwich, the soft scramble, and the countless other brilliant strokes of refined genius that Max cranks out, and you realize that you're in the presence of understated brilliance.  

Many times after finishing brunch at another spot in the city, I find myself quietly regretting having not gone to Plow.  It should be on everyone's short list in San Francisco.  Friends and family who have visited from out of town bring up Plow, unsolicited, on phone calls.  These are people who haven't been to San Francisco for a couple of years, and they don't mention the bridges, the wine, fancy dinner places, walks on twin peaks....Nope.  The thing that sticks with them is Plow.

Go, put your name in, grab a coffee from Farley's, walk around Potrero, go back in an hour and order too much food so you can try everything.

Or don't.  Nothing to see here.  Plane Jane breakfast place.  Move along...
author: Matthew C.

description:
All brunch places have the same thing in common: It's always a 1-1.5 hour wait and they all essentially taste the same. This was no different. Buuuuuuuuuuuut, if you're gonna do brunch in SF, this is still a good choice over some of the others. Really nice setup they got going on, the staff is super friendly, and the food is pretty satisfying (even after a 1 hr wait). 

Their lemon ricotta pancake? It lived up to the hype. Super fluffy and tasty and I don't even like pancakes but I'd order this. 
Soft scramble is pretty good & hearty but it's pretty standard with what you get at brunch places. It comes with a side of crispy potatoes which are AWESOME. That's not something you get at every brunch place. 

Solid brunch spot. If you have good company to wait with, then it's worth checking out. Plus it's got a sweet view of downtown SF you can enjoy while you're waiting outside with the crowds of people
author: Diana Y.

description: I've been hearing about Plow and decided to give it a try.  The place is small and comfy with plenty of staff.  A bit pricey but I don't mind paying for great food and great service.  I ordered "the  plow" the eggs and bacon were cooked perfectly. The potatoes were deep fried crispy with a hint of salt, rosemary, onions and it was flavorful. Finally the lemon ricotta pancakes added a slight   twist from your usual pancake and they were delicious.  Definitely try it if your in the beautiful Potrero Hill area.
author: Mike A.

description:
Wow. What a brunch!

The +:
+ Ordered The Plow and the amount of food for $15 mowed me down. It was hefty and worth every bite. It was a sampler of everything like 2 eggs, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes (ok), crispy potatoes (WOW), and homemade pork sausage (yum)
+ Almond pancakes (gluten-free) were fantastic with the maple syrup. Fluffy and not a heavy sponge of carbs! We preferred these pancakes over the much-hyped lemon ricotta
 + Coffee was great. Strong and tasty
+ Staff was very pleasant and helpful. 
+ Wait is torture but at least there were wooden benches built by the wall and there are shops less than a block away to kill some time
+ Our pooches are able to join us for brunch! Outdoor seating of course.


The -:
- The Wait. For table of 2 on a Sunday at 1:30pm was at least 30 minutes. Sheesh
- Patio seating is on a Potrero Hill. So if you don't mind sitting in the shade on a tilt then you'll be fine.

Order The Plow if you want something hefty and show early to get your name on the list. Then build in time to take a short stroll before heading back to wait fo your name to be called.
author: Yiven C.

description:
I FINALLY got to try this place. I was afraid it would be a third time's a charm type mishap, but the brunch gods were in my favor. The wait was only 20 minutes my second time. =) Naturally, we waited on the cute benches attached to the side of the building. 

I wish I was living in the houses around the corner because I would be a regular! We had the French Toast... which was amazing. Literally I wanted MORE! And the The Plow, which consisted of a little bit of everything popular...house made pork sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes. I felt like the pork sausage tasted like some type of Vietnamese pork type food. The lemon ricotta pancakes were also amazing. I just wish I ordered poached eggs rather than over easy. 

I would definitely recommend this place. But don't let the hype ruin it...as many other reviewers, including myself will probably do.
author: Audrey N.

description: I stumbled across this place when I was in town on business. I was there early so I didn't have to worry about a wait. The waiter was very helpful offering suggestions on what to order. I went with the Plow which had their lemon pancakes, pork sausage, potatoes and eggs. Without hesitation I can say that this meal was in my top 3 best breakfast meals ever. I live in Austin TX and have traveled all my life for pleasure and business. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this place to anyone. Great Job! I will be back very soon!
author: Steve V.

description:
Delicious brunch here - with only a 10 minute wait for a party of 6 on a weekday! 

Ordered the Plow (crispy potatoes, eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes), pumpkin pancakes, and the breakfast sandwich. I would definitely order all 3 again. Delicious!
author: K. D.

description:
Plow has been on my bookmark for months and I finally convince the boyfriend to come here for breakfast. We left early from San Jose and arrived at Plow around 9:30am last Sunday. Street parking was abundant  We were happy to find parking within 500 ft from the restaurant but mortified once we found out that the wait could be an hour and 45 minutes. We patiently waited while it seemed to me that a lot of people gave up. 

 
Plow's dining room is bright and loaded with natural sunlight during the day. The restaurant features high ceiling, polished wood floors, and a busy open kitchen. They also have outside seating and provide blankets for those who are sleeveless and wear shorts on a cold windy spring day like last Sunday. That was very thoughtful of them.

Don't even bother counting how many calories you think you are consuming, because it is probably a lot. They serve traditional breakfast items. We got the plow and egg benedict. The food is rich and heavy, the homemade sausage is OMG delicious. Their signature potatoes are truly amazing, packed with flavors and roasted perfectly with crispy skin.

Great ambience, fantastic food, I would have given 4 stars, but customer service was unbelievably slow.

Was it worth the wait? ... A little bit.
author: Chau V.

description:
I LOVE YOU!

I would just leave it like that, but I guess you readers will want more than that. So first of, go in groups of either 2 or 4. Not 3, 5, 6, 7, 8,......If you go in groups of 2s, the wait will be cut short a lot less! For some reason, they seat pairs sooner. And if you were going to get a table for 3, come on, you have that ONE extra seat, might as well invite one more friend to enjoy delicious food (one more order for you to take a bite from!)

Parking was easy, many street parking and there's no time restriction on Saturdays and Sundays. Service was friendly, but can't say it was fully fast and efficient because the wait to order and receive our food after we were seated were longer than waiting for a table (table: 30 minutes, food: 35+ minutes). One of my friend "I'm so hungry" out loud and was overheard by the waitress. She came over to ensure us that our food was coming out next so perhaps a little whining doesn't hurt anyone?

When the food got out, all the waiting was worth it. SO WORTH IT! On our table, we have the french toast with roasted peaches, soft eggs, and the plow. I LOVE their french toast, they cut you 3 thick slices of "french" bread? Definitely not the skimpy slice of bread from a loaf. Lightly dusted with sugar powder, even the maple syrup was light! Each bite of the toast melts in my mouth, it's not oily and I finished my meal before the two hungry guys so that means something right there. I also had their homemade lemonade, it was decent, not too sweet, but the glass was pretty small.

The other guys seems to enjoy their food and one of them complimented on their potatoes. I had a up-coming culinary chef in my group and even he said he'll return to this place. The brunch did come up to about $15-$20 per person. I'm not saying you come here everyday, but maybe once every two weeks to shock your taste buds with good food.

I can't wait to return to try the rest of the menu =)
author: Elaine Y.

description:
The food was really great.  I had the "plow" breakfast, and I loved the savory, rosemary and thyme fried potatoes.  They were probably my favorite all time hash brown/potatoes in the morning situation.  I also like the concept and menu -- it's right down my alley and I drove all the way out from Nob hill by myself just to try it.

So why only 3 stars?

1. The pricing.  Out the door with 15% tip my breakfast of one 'entree'(the plow breakfast) and coffee came out to $24.  I don't even know how that is possible.  I mean -- I do know, but I can't really wrap my head around that kind of pricing.  It might be San Francisco, but this is not the ritz carlton.  I guess they are popular enough that they can get away with it, which leads me to...

2. The wait.  I came by myself at 9:30 in the morning on a saturday.  I said I didn't mind sitting anywhere, counter included.  It took 45 minutes for me to get seated.  I guess it's not their fault they are so popular, but jeebus, be prepared to wait a looonnnnggg time.

All in all, the food is good enough to give it a try once.. but I doubt I'll be going very often due to the prices.
author: Yan L.

description: The wait was worthy. We ordered the Benedict eggs and The Plow. The hollandaise sauce and poached eggs were cooked to perfection. I like spicy hot sauces but just wouldn't add anything extra to the crispy, salty, delicious potatoes. The best I have tried in my life. The breakfast ended on a high sweet note of ricotta lemon pancake. This was a meal to remember!!
author: Elizabeth L.

description: FOR ALL THAT US HOLY SPEND YOUR MONEY HERE. Seriously, ranks in the top 2 breakfast places I've ever eaten in my life. The other place is over 1,000 miles away, it's Jam Cafe in Victoria, BC. The service is great, the people are funny, kind, and with it. Eat here. You'll die and go to heaven
author: Dillan W.

description:
If you want to sit next to a bitch for a really good brunch, Plow is the place for you. Well, it was for me on a nice, cool Sunday mid-morning. The lack of star perfection wasn't due to her, it was the 1-hour wait for a table, but hey, you learn to expect that at places in SF that don't take reservations. They don't take parties greater than 6. 

Situated on a corner in Potrero Hill, Plow is small inside with just as many seats outside. The reason for the bitch, is that they have 2-person tables lined up along the wall of the restaurant and well, I had to get in to the inner table for my seat. I asked her nicely if she could move her chair in, well, she moved her butt, not moving the chair and barely at that. So basically I just shoved past her. Good thing I was sitting next to her and didn't have to stare at her sour-puss face the entire meal like DK did sitting across from her. Anyway, she made for good conversation.

Onto the food...once we were seated, our waitress took a while to bring us our waters and by then we were ready to order. You really can't go wrong with a breakfast place that has a pig sign under the name of their restaurant. Mmmm.....oink.

I had: the plow  two eggs, choice of Nueske bacon, house made pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage, two pancakes + crispy potatoes  14

DK had: max's biscuits + gravy  two buttermilk biscuits, pork sausage gravy, crispy potatoes  11

It came out fairly quickly and it was GOOD. The bacon was plentiful and was cooked just right, the pancakes had this lemony hint to them and were on the smaller size, but that's because they're not your average pancakes. They were really good though, but kind of had a french toast consistency and about the size of English muffins. The potatoes had some sort of Saffron or something on them, because they were as yellow as my egg yolks, but boy, were they good. I normally leave potatoes untouched on my plate (except for the hash brown kind), but these were awesome and just the right amount of crispy.

DK's biscuits and gravy were really good and the gravy was coma-inducing. 

I really enjoyed my breakfast, sans bitch. There's a multitude of breakfast places in SF, and many are good one-morning stands, but this one I would go on a second date with.
author: Ming-Jou C.

description:
Hands down best breakfast food in the entire city of San Francisco. They use amazing locally sourced ingredients and create outstanding meals with it. They even have gluten free pancakes that are fluffy and delicious. 
Downside, the wait time. I've waited over 2 hours already because there is really no other option in SF that has comparable food options. I've even seen people eat outside holding their own umbrellas. That is a tad outrageous! They could at least upgrade their outdoor area and add a retractable awning. 
They could also upgrade their coffee and use better coffee cups...but I'm a coffee snob, and that might be irrelevant to most people. I would also like to see better hot sauce options (organic, GF, soy free, and without citric acid). 
Worth the wait, but shhhhhhh! Don't tell anyone!
author: Sara B.

description:
Love this place, but really hate the wait!

Starting with the positives - this place has AMAZING food.  Everything on their "plow" is amazing.  The sausage and eggs work great together, their potato is made perfectly crispy on the outside and warm and toasty on the inside, and their lemon ricotta pancakes are to die for.  I usually don't even like pancakes, but I ate it all.  I've only been here twice and have been dying to try their fried egg sandwich, but I'm such  a sucker for the plow.  

Oh, and the portions are very generous.

The downside of this place  is the wait...and that it doesn't accept reservations, but good things are worth waiting for.  I will definitely be back.
author: Carrie L.

description: This was the first time ever I allowed myself to wait for a table for almost two hours. The food was truly amazing and worth waiting. But I don't think I would go back. Downside of the visit was the fact that the host forgot about us and didn't seat us until we reminded him we were waiting. And also our waitress seemed super mad/sad/or whatever the mood she was in. But again. I went there to try their food. And let me just tell you that if you decide to go there you need to order their potatoes. I know. Potatoes? Just order them and we can talk later. Enjoy!
author: Jo G.

description: This is by far one of the best breakfast spots I have found in the city. Everything I have had is delicious, totally worth the long wait. And there is a long wait.... I keep coming back over and over. Thank you for delicious food Plow!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Just eat here. It's worth it. Literally you can't go wrong with your choice. As a GF and DF person it was the best bruch I've had in ages. They even accomodated space for my 4 month old nephew who thankfully slept the entire time. It must have been all the happy adults enjoying thier food!
author: Mari M.

description:
Plow is a quintessentially cute brunch spot with a quintessential SF brunch wait to match.  My friend and I showed up at 11am and waited an hour for our table.  When we finally did get seated, they provided us with blankets since it was pretty chilly outside (points for thoughtfulness!).

We ordered the salmon egg benedict, fried egg sandwich with bacon, and a lemon ricotta pancake to share (literally one pancake).  Believe what you've read about the pancakes - ours was amazingly fluffy and lemony, with the slight tartness balanced out by the syrup.  The fried egg sandwich was good on its own, but the bacon put it over the top (this coming from someone who normally takes the bacon off everything).  It's a bit messy to eat since the yolk gets everywhere, so ladies be careful if you're trying to impress your date.  The salmon egg benedict was disappointing - nothing you couldn't get at your neighborhood diner and certainly not worth an hour long wait (for ones worth the wait, try Mission Beach Cafe).  If you opt to sit outside like we did, make sure you're a fast eater - the SF chill made our food cold and unappetizing rather quickly.

The service was delightful and never rushed us, even though there was still a long line when we left.  I'd definitely come back, though for an hour plus wait, there are better brunch spots in the city.
author: Kristina C.

description:
Cute spot for breakfast, brunch, lunch. Anytime of the day actually but I'm saying this because of the windows that line an entire wall of the corner located store, allowing a great amount of daylight into the room. That's the first thing I noticed. Came in with my sister late morning and we were seated right away! MAJOR plus! (since, I hear the wait can be terrible). I then noticed that we were seated very closely to another group of people (so close, it was as if we were all seated in one cozy table). Despite that fact, this is what gave the restaurant a social, friendly, casual, and "fun intimate" feeling. We got our waters right away and our waitress was very prompt!! 

We looked through the menu, searching for something that stood out to us. Of course, we had to choose the infamous 'plow' and also decided on the Chicken Tinga to share. Eggs over easy for both- but you can have your eggs however you want them. Also, as a heads up, being the small business that it is, they don't serve groups greater than 6! 

The menu says no cell phones allowed? (not sure what that meant or why) That didn't stop me from checking in and taking pictures of my food - I HAD TO! ;)

-Chicken Tinga tasted mucho bien! A nice crunchy corn tortilla laid beneath chipotle tomato sauce and two eggs over easy, avocado, and creme fraiche. It was fresh and flavorsome. The textures and flavors mixed very well together and the combination of breakfast and mexican worked oh so well. 
 
-Plow: Lemon ricotta pancakes were zesty and very smooth from the homemade ricotta. It was a new idea for me. I liked it with syrup which added sweetness to the zest. Potatoes added crunchiness to the plate- dipped each bite with ketchup/hot sauce, scooping up the oozing yolk from the eggs (Mmmm spicy and savory)- Eggs over easy was a genius idea, I might add! Chicken apple sausage had a smooth, sweet, spicyness. Overall the whole plate was full of dimension. In my opinion, the pancakes were very appropriate, being that the potatoes were super crunchy, the eggs oozed yolk, and the sausage added a kick! 

Both plates had different ideas but I personally liked the Chicken Tinga for flavor. 

Don't go here if you don't like loud and compact areas. I suggest you go here if you want a casual and sociable meal. Cool.
author: Maiden D.

description: When at Plow get the plow!  It's a seriously good breakfast/brunch entree that won't have you feeling overly stuffed or gross afterwards; perfect mix of savory and sweet items on your plate and just the right amount.  I got mine with two eggs sunny side up, Nueske bacon, and the standard crispy potatoes and lemon ricotta pancakes.  Nueske bacon is bacon in some of its awesomest form.  The crispy potatoes had a hint of rosemary for an added dimension of flavor.  The lemon ricotta pancakes featured a light lemon flavor and were a little dense yet still fluffy and really delicious (I really liked these pancakes).
author: Erich D.

description:
Came here last Sunday for brunch. Arrived around 11:30, put our name down, was told it would be an hour. Thankfully there are shops around so we got busy for about 30 minutes. And because we were dying of hunger, we went back to check on the wait. Reported time? Another hour! So yeah, that was heart/gut wrenching. 

But when our time finally came, there was much rejoicing. The service was quick. And their homemade sausage blew my mind. Don't get me wrong - the crispy potatoes were really good, as were the lemon ricotta pancakes (I got the Plow breakfast), but the sausage mixed with syrup mixed with egg mixed with potatoes? Yeah. I'm a fan. Minus one star for inaccurate time keeping. Cuz I'm a jerk like that.
author: Maria P.

description:
Wait for two wasn't too bad.
It was really cold outside to wait so the server asked if we wanted some coffee when we put our names down. We thought it was free and were talking about how nice they were for offering something hot for people waiting out in the cold. I barely like drinking coffee but i got it because it was hot and thought it was free but it later showed up on our bill (I literally took 2 sips and was charged without knowing. o well).

Regardless, food there was mediocre, the crispy potatoes were good though.
fried egg sandwich, was nothing out of the ordinary (very average)
and the lemon rocotta pancakes wasn't THAT great. I got sick of it after 3 bites.
author: Angela W.

description: This place is good. Really good. I had the soft scrambled eggs and it was delicious. Not 5 stars more for the brunchy scene on the weekend. Yes, I know every place in SF has a wait, but sometimes you just want diner scenery, a good cup of coffee, and some decent food. I was sitting outside on the sidewalk, freezing, eating my delicious food and--I kinda just want a bit of an easier experience for my Saturday breakfast. But yes--it was certainly tasty.
author: Mel G.

description:
I woke up early one day to run some errands with my girlfriend and as we finished up, we got hungry. She was craving some breakfast food so we yelped something close by and this popped up. As I walked in, it looked cramped but the building was nice and bright due to the fact that its lit up by the sunlight. Has a good vibe and atmosphere because everybody was socializing while enjoying their food. I ordered the plow because it seemed the most "worth it" (haha). Everything tasted so-so until I took a bite out of the pancakes. DELICIOUS OMGASDFKAWER. Will definitely be back for the pancake! I'm drooling as I'm typing up this review! If you haven't tried their pancakes, WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR?!

Service was excellent. The waitress was nice and recommended what to get. Extremely friendly.

***Parking***: Street parking only. Should be fairly easy to find in the morning/early afternoon.

Cash/Credit are accepted here.
author: Johnny G.

description: Yet another place hyped up by people who are clueless about food (yuppies and tech bros). It is WAY overrated. It's not worth the 1.5 hour wait and the money. The food is good, but nothing blew me away. Yes, the ingredients were fresh, but if you a conscious eater and you know how to cook, this place is just ordinary.  The biggest star was ricotta pancakes, which alone will not make me want to come back.
author: Kirill E.

description:
Honestly, I would give this 4.5 stars.  I had a great experience here.  I was visiting from LA and was recommended to come here.  Luckily, I was taking a Monday morning flight and able to come on an early weekday morning with no wait in line :)  First, out server was great.  She was prompt on walking by and gave some great recommendations on what to order.  
     Food....I had the soft scramble (cheese, eggs, mushrooms, etc) that came with their potatoes, and toast.  DELICIOUS!!!  Everyone says their potatoes are amazing and they were right, I loved the crunchiness of them.  My friend got the breakfast sandwich, also very good.  We split the lemon ricotta pancake, one of the best pancakes I have ever eaten (lots of flavor and not dry at all).  You get soo much food here!  Overall, great space, great food, and great service.  I will be coming back here for my next San Fran visit.
author: Jaclyn S.

description:
Plow, purely based on the food, deserves a 5 star...

My boyfriend and I came her on a saturday morning. We arrived at 10:15am on a beautiful clear morning and there was already a groups of people around the restaurant. We were quoted a 45min - 1 hour wait. Potrero Hill is one of my favorite places in the city because there is an amazing view of it on a clear day. 
Finally getting sat an hour later, we were sat at the table top where we could see the open kitchen create it's magic! Unfortuantely, it took 45 mins to get our food...was it worth it....hmmm, maybe??

Fried egg sandwich - My bf, very innovatively, order this fried egg sandwich with smoked salmon instead of the usual bacon...YUM YUM YUM!! Plow gets all their bread from ACME, so you know it's good. The fried home fries were well seasoned with a array of dried herbs (a bit on the salty side, but that's probably just me)

French toast - We ordered the 2 pieces of french toast which was more than enough for both of us. Light and fluffy. A must get. 

The food here is a must try, perhaps you will want to come real early to avoid all the wait.

As a note to the owners, you food is awesome, great concept, great flavors. But the waiting really kills it. The kitchen is too small for the restaurant. Having been in the food industry before, I have a few suggestions:
1. Take away some outside seating, or train the hosts to slow down the pace of the turnaround. The kitchen clearly cannot handle the amount of ppl who want your food. 
2. Get a bigger kitchern/look at what other stuff you can pre prep , or
3. Use aloha or a electronic ordering/paying system, It will help with inventory as well as avoid the lost ticket issue ( b/c we were sitting next to the expo, we saw you had that issue)

I wish all the best to you guys and much much success!!
author: Wendy L.

description: Excellent! Everything was excellent. The place is small but charming. Expect a steep tab, but a must experience place when in San Francisco.
author: Kathleen R.

description: Mmmm we love plow! Best breakfast place in SF. Me and my brother go here about once a week. It's so good. Everything is delicious.. can't go wrong!
author: Victoria V.

description:
Prelude: Dear Yelp - could you please change the photo that shows as their main picture?
Plow is such a cozy little brunch spot in San Francisco.  Their French Toast with fresh strawberries & mascarpone is my favorite.  The wait can be long, but I find the wait totally worth it!
author: Lindsey O.

description:
Okay, so I am giving this place a 5 cuz I don't like putting the wait or other factors into my reviews, but do want to preface this with the fact that you are in for an hour wait with this place since it has gotten so popular...

The food was simply amazing... I had the breakfast sandwich - I thought it would be boring, but I still fantasize about this sandwich... Just go... There's also a cafe down the street you can get coffee and a snack from while you wait...
author: Denise B.

description:
Yes, the wait here is ridiculous, there's no pleasant place to sit and you can't sit inside because it's a small place. That's just how it is. If you come with this mindset, you'll be okay waiting, if not, then you'll probably be miserable. Although, a few times when I've come and I know the wait will be more than 30 minutes, I'll just leave and go to Farley's to hang out there for a while and come back with a hot cup of coffee in hand. 

The potatoes here are always amazing. I love how they fry them, I love how they come with beautiful sprigs of rosemary, and sometimes when I come here I get a side order with my meal because the amount of potatoes that come with the dish just aren't enough! I usually get something with eggs here (eg. soft scrambled eggs) and I've always loved what I order. The last time I visited plow my boyfriend ordered the crab scramble and he said he didn't like it at all though. He described it as too watery and the taste was lackluster. He usually gets the plow and is always satisfied with that, so I think for him it was matter of ordering. I've tried their monkey bread, which was just okay and tasted more like a cinnamon roll. I've also tried their pop tart, which was pretty good, but I feel like I could home make pop tarts just as good and not for $5 a piece. 

I like plow a lot and is my go to breakfast place, but just there is a ridiculous wait, but the food is very solidly good. The waitstaff is alright, nothing to really say about them. Some people find them rude, but they're usually attentive and that's all I care about.
author: Victoria J.

description:
Good stuff! The food was really good, and their hot sauce, I think its call "Youks" was off the hook. It packed a punch alng with a ton of flavor. A great combination for a hot sauce. I know this review is supposed to be about Plow, but I already said their food was great didnt I?

;)
author: Vivek N.

description:
So delicious!!! I LOVE brunch, but Plow takes it to a whole new level! Or maybe it was simply because it was a near 2-hour wait and at that point, anything tasted like heaven. 

Came here on a Sunday around 12:00pm, and was not seated until a little before 2pm. Yes, it's THAT good. I feel like I was never so happy to finally see food, but have the food taste even better than I had ever expected. I ordered The Plow, which came with two small lemon ricotta pancake, apple smoked sausages, sunny-side up eggs, and seasoned fried potatoes. The pancakes are absolutely divine, with a burst of lemon and ricotta flavors with each bite, and the rest of the plate was done so well to complement. You actually get the choice in between the sausage patty or the apple smoked sausage, and I am glad I chose the apple smoked sausages. Highly recommend! On the other hand, the bf ordered the egg sandwich and he devoured that thing in a mattered of seconds. I also though he was going to lick his plates! 

The bottom line is, although the wait was unattractive, the meal was definitely worth it. The good thing is, while you are waiting, you can assist yourself to some free coffee. 

Note: This is the same coffee you get when you order coffee during the meal, so you might as well drink up and get caffeine high for free while killing time!
author: Luby H.

description: Fluffy, gluten free lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, eggs, and bacon? SOLD. I had a hankering for some pancakes but have diet restrictions, which they gladly accommodated. The staff was friendly and attentive. Plow is located in Portrero Hill, a very quiet area that is perfect if you want to escape from the hustle and bustle of downtown.
author: Kaili K.

description:
Came here on a Sunday around 10am and had to wait over an hour for a table for 5pm. Come here early or be prepared to wait. My friend said that there is a nice coffee shop up the block called farleys which is good to grab a cup of coffee and chat while we wait. We didn't get coffee this time but looks like most ppl do do this. 

We were seated outside which was fine but it does get chilly out there so bring a jacket. My friend mentioned they supply you blankets is you ask but none of us asked for one. We all just pounded cups of hot coffee to stay warm! 

The most popular item and best entree to get here if it is your first time is to get the plow. Has a little bit of everything! The crispy potatoes, chicken apple sausage, and the lemon ricotta pancakes were oh so yummy! Definitely would recommend this as I am always torn when I go to brunch - do I want sweet or savory? The plow gives you both and you will leave satisfied. 

Overall this is a great brunch spot with flavorful and tasty brunch options. Next time I want to try their Dungeness crab scramble sounds soo yum!
author: Christine W.

description: The best meal I had while in San Francisco for vacation. Our good friend took us here for the best brunch and after a short wait for our table it did not disappoint. I ordered the Dungeness crab omelet and about died. So delicious. The fried potatoes were the most flavorful thing with fresh rosemary and thyme. Awesome. I don't even remember what the rest of the table ordered because I was so focused on stuffing my pie-hole.
author: Cristina V.

description:
Plow is seriously delicious. If you're a brunch person and you haven't been here, you're missing out. The lady and I had been hearing about this place for a while and we finally made it out. It was our lucky day because we were told that the wait would be about an hour and a half and we may possibly not get a table before closing. A lot of people gave up and it bumped down our wait time to about 20 minutes on a Saturday.

We sat at the bar where four men were working furiously behind the counter churning out pancakes, benedicts and the like in a very efficient system. Knowing either of us couldn't finish The Plow, we went for the lemon ricotta pancakes and a half portion of the french toast with a side of crispy potatoes. They do everything so well that you really can't go wrong with any of their options! Cheers!
author: David O.

description:
As an out-of-towner, I hopped on the band wagon and came to this place. It's a little far from the middle of the city, which was a bummer.

The food was pretty good though. The potatoes, I could absolutely eat all day. the lemon ricotta pancakes, didn't do a whole lot for me. I thought they were a little on the dry side, and served with real maple ( I like the fake sugary junk). Orange juice was super fresh and delicious.

It's a pretty cozy little place and sitting at the counter wasn't ideal, but did get the job done. The service was also a little slow.

I was eyeing the fried egg sandwich which I saw several people order, and will do the same, next time I have the chance.
author: Elaine J.

description: We ventured to Potrero Hill neighborhood and sought out Plow. Famous for lemon ricotta pancakes, house made sausage and the crispiest potatoes known to man. After waiting over an hour for a table I was skeptical, but Plow delivers. These are some good breakfast eats. Their potatoes are worth the wait! Everything else is just a bonus.
author: Kellee K.

description:
Pretty underwhelmed, particularly based on the glowing reviews I've read. 

Wait was quoted on a Friday for an hour, which was pretty much right on.

Were seated next to other people. I don't mind, but I think servers should always ask the party if that's ok first.

The entrance door was open and sitting next to the door was frigid cold. I asked if the door could be closed, but after 5 minutes the staff were too lazy to close it again.

The general decor is ok. Nice, basic, but pleasant.

The service is basic, a bit short staffed. I saw the waitress roll her eyes while walking away from a request of another table, which I don't particularly like to see.

I had the gluten free almond pancakes $13. Honestly again, BASIC. Slightly burnt on one side. Taste is below average, grainy, very little taste. It's literally just three small pancakes on a barren plate with a *speck* of butter. Kinda sad. It could use some fruit, or bananas, walnuts, berries, anything to make it more presentable. I've had pretty gnarly gluten free pancakes before (friggin Swingers in LA, for example), and for $13 this leaves a bit to be desired. 

The "soft scrambled eggs - asparagus, stinging nettles, oyster mushrooms, goat cheese, crispy potatoes + toast", sounds fancy but is pretty average fare. The potatoes were tasty, the scrambled eggs also ok. I would eat it again, but not particularly worth $15.

Just upon leaving, I was asked to leave the table because other people were waiting, and the waitress mumbled something about promising people a table for too long. I was offered a "glass of water" for my gesture.

Decent place, BUT:

NOT worth the wait.
NOT worth the price.
author: Mar L.

description: Wait over an hour for a table even though you arrived at 9am. Wait 15 minutes for the bathroom because there's only one. Wait wait wait. Sure the food is good but is it worth all the waiting? NOPE
author: Philip L.

description: This is a cute little french place breakfast spot. Ambience is very nice and staff is very friendly. Our table ordered several things - but what stood out to me was the sausage biscuit - it was life-changing. Absolutely the best biscuit I've had in my life. The quality of the sausage was delicious and they used homemade scratch biscuits which was topped with a local honey glaze. The Lemon and ricotta pancakes were tasty and the rosemary potatoes were so fresh and delicious. I will definitely return!!
author: Kelly F.

description:
I'd give this place 4 stars, but I'm taking one out for the 2.5 hours wait for brunch. I came here after a hike and my last meal was at 7am, so that might have been a reason why I was STARVING by the time we got seated. It helped a lot that they kept reassuring us that we weren't forgotten and apologized for the wait so I give them 5 stars for customer service.

Brunch was good. OMG...the crispy potatoes were to die for. I'm so glad it came with 3 out of 4 of our meals. We ordered 2 plows (1 with house made pork sausages and 1 with the chicken apple sausages). I highly recommend the pork sausages over the chicken sausages. It also came with their signature lemon ricotta pancakes which was fluffy and unique. I highly recommend getting the plow if you want sample a couple of the things off their menu. We also got an order of french toast and the fried egg sandwiches. The french toast was okay. It was thick and crispy. We added avocados to our fried egg sandwich which made it pretty tasty. 

Overall, the food and service is great. I just don't think it's worth a 2 hour wait when there are so many other brunch places in the city. I'd come back here again, but only if the wait is no longer than an hour.
author: Vi L.

description:
I thought Plow to be a fitting place to begin my Yelping;

Great location on corner with high ceilings, big windows, natural lighting, clean. Parking not bad for SF. Staff professional and pleasant. Has a contemporary feel w trancy music and farmhouse decor.

Breakfast was excellent, house made sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes were included and bomb, coffee and cream were highest quality.

Plow is unique for getting their products from multiple organic and small local farms.
author: Timinator77 -.

description:
My husband and I waited in line for a little over an hour to be seated (which is the norm, especially on weekends).  After finally getting a table, we both ordered the plow entree with poached eggs and got our food fairly quickly.  Without tasting the food, right away we could see the inconsistency among the two plates.  My husbands plate looked perfect, eggs cooked wonderfully and the potatoes seasoned perfectly with salt and rosemary.  The eggs on my plate were slightly undercooked and leaking of yolk when I got it.  My potatoes were slightly overcooked with no taste of rosemary.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were delicious (the only yummy item on my plate) and would highly recommend trying them.

I was fairly disappointed in the lack of consistency this place has and am not willing to wait in line for over an hour when there are way better breakfast places in the city.
author: R C.

description:
STARTING SUMMER WITH A "SUMMER-Y" KIND OF BREAKFAST. 
(4.5 stars)

Crossing this off my "yelp booked marked" items. This quaint cafe makes me want to live in Potrero Hill. I'd be blessed to come eat here every morning before work. Such a cute inspiration, if I ever become a restaurant owner, I'd love to echo a place like this. 

- Food, healthy and exquisit (organic)
- Prices, little more out of the pocket (i spent $20 for myself)
- Service, on-point
- Ambiance, simple and cute neighborhood cafe

This is a restaurant that's packed all weekend long, especially for brunch. One to come with another or a few people. I've decided to drop in at 7:30AM on a Tuesday, alone (call me a loser, i guess I am. HA!). No worries, only one other person was there and the place was empty that early in the morning (good thing for me). Typically, I would'nt come to such a place alone but I been at the gym since 4:45AM, don't have to be at work until 9AM, bored and HUNGRY.

HEFFER-STYLE STATUS

**pictures to come**

LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES ($10.50) - house made ricotta, lemon zest, and pure maple syrup. This came out with three pancakes covering the entire place, a sprinkle of powder sugar drizzled ontop, a dab of melted butter, and a side of the pure maple syrup. I must say, this was absolutely DIVINE & HEAVENLY. The pancakes were something i've never had before, definately can taste the lemon zest, and the ricotta just gave the batter that creamy-sweet taste. It was extremely delcious!!!! And the pure maple syrup, you dont need that much on the pancakes. Highly recommend trying.

CHICKEN APPLE SAUSAGE ($4) - kind of pricy for three sausage links. But it was definately needed to balance the sweet and creamy on the palate with some savory. Worth every penny after one bite. The sausages were perfectly cooked, browned on the outside and tender on the inside. 

CAMELLIA BLOSSOMED ICE TEA ($3) - it was served in a class with a lemon slice. Didn't add any sweetners and kepted it plain; taste real good with the lemon slice inside. Might not be for all palates but for those who like iced tea, this is for you.

COMPLIMENTARY H2O (Free) - love it when a restaurant brings out a chic glass bottle of water for the table. pour your own water!!!

The total of my bill was about $20 bucks. I left not feeling heavy nor gross. I left feeling refreshed and ready to start a long day in corporate america. That's a great feeling when you've ate well. 

Will I be back? Definately. I'll need to call people up to see if they'd like to wait in the long line with me on the weekend. If not, I can come back here alone and by myself at 7:30AM again. 

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description:
The quick low down on Plow is...

- Awesome corn millet muffins.
- The granola + yogurt is amazing! The granola is crunchy but not overly so, the yogurt is made fresh in-house and the honey is harvested from within the neighborhood.
- Quite possibly the best B.L.T.A. I have ever had... Perfectly toasted bread, in-season heirlooms, fresh lettuce, creamy avocado, bacon cooked just right (not too crispy, not too limp) and just the right amount of aioli. It also came with a side of perfectly seasoned, perfectly fried potatoes that did not need any ketchup.
- My peach pie was warmed just right, topped with a perfect sized dollop of whipped cream and bursting with fresh peaches.
- Friendly, knowledgeable and attentive waitstaff.

Minor flaws? The coffee should be WAY better considering how good everything else is. Doing to-order drips from either Four Barrel, Ritual or Sightglass would be more appropriate given the quality of the food. Also, please serve your butter at room temperature so that we can actually spread it on your muffins without risk of crumbling them to corn meal - cold butter does not spread well on muffins, no matter how hot they are. And I've never said this before but... get some comfortable chairs. They may look good but I felt like no matter how I was sitting I was uncomfortable.

And while it's not Plow's fault, having to listen to the banal minutia of the lives of the 40 and 50-something yuppies that populate the neighborhood while waiting for a table was pretty obnoxious. This does not factor into my rating, but I include it because it may be a factor for others amongst you.

If you like brunch at Mission Beach Cafe I would definitely check out Plow. I will be back to try their eggs and the Chinese breakfast, which if they are on par with my first experience, might push this place to five stars.
author: Dirty D.

description:
Girlfriend: "What are we doing for breakfast?"
Me: "Plow."
Girlfriend: "Ummmmmm... what?"
Me: "You heard me."

The name of this place is PLOW. If you don't see the humor in this, then I'm waaaaay too inappropriate for your liking.

ANYWAY, like any of the local weekend breakfast hotspots, we waited a little over an hour for the 4.5 of us to be seated on a Sunday morning. After we were finally seated, we were attended immediately and our orders taken, since we had already looked at the menu for the past hour. 

We ordered the The Plow (heh heh), a couple fried egg sandwiches, the ricotta pancakes, and donut holes. The sandwiches were awesome, and the ricotta pancakes were surprisingly good, as I was weary about "ricotta" pancakes. The donut holes where just ok, but the definite highlight of the breakfast... THE POTATOES. I could have easily ate a couple bowls of them, if they were to serve it as cereal. Without a doubt, some of the best potatoes I've EVER had. THAT good...

PLOW is something to definitely put on your to-do list when in the city. Heh heh heh... PLOW.
author: Gino E.

description: I love their lemon ricotta pancakes. Everything else I've had has been delicious as well. Make sure you call ahead or make a reservation, there is always a long wait.
author: Bethany M.

description:
Location is great for folks who are driving here. Lots of parking, no metered parking required. 
It's a small place and since there was 3 of us, we had to wait about 10 mins. We  were then asked if it would be ok seated on a communal table and we said why not.  Something that is getting popular nowadays which I think can be pretty cool. W e were seated with 2 guys on 5-seater table. I thought it would feel awkward but it felt like a community plus they were minding their own business. Just a lil chat with them he re and there. 
Ambiance- open, bright, like eating outside. Reminded me of eating outside in Addendum in Yountville. I'd stay here if I could, lol.  

Coffee good, but no refill?
Millet corn muffin yum
We ordered the plow, different eggs and meat. Of course I got bacon, I think.  Potatoes are yum.

Local farms all the way. Love it!
Need to ask next time what flour is used with pancake.  Or I might have to try their other pancake.  

I wanna go back.
author: Claire J.

description:
After hearing a lot about it from my friend, went to try this one. Had a 60 mins wait, which we were prepared for. With all that expectation built up, the food was just about ok. The hollondaise on the benedict (which my friend ordered) was awesome, but how hard can it to be get overeasy eggs right? Mine were just too runny and the white was undercooked.

May come back again, but disappointed.
author: Gaurav A.

description:
You know how most lazy restaurants and home cooks use pancake batter to make their waffles, even though if you think about it, great pancakes and waffles have nothing texturally in common? Well, I think Plow is doing just the opposite for their lemon ricotta pancakes. They're making a dense batter (anything with that much ricotta has to be dense), and then lightening it with whipped egg whites like you're supposed to do for waffles. Gives you a lighter texture, but still plenty of structure and a crispy exterior. Plus, waffles reheat poorly, and so did my leftover pancake. Now I could be totally off the mark, and no one but me could care about my little theory, but I like to know how things work. Especially yummy things.

The lemon ricotta pancakes were super delicious, but I wish something had been served alongside.

I also wish I had gotten some of those potatoes. I was full and getting ready to leave when the lady next to me's food came out, but the smell of the potatoes was intoxicating.

All in all, a very respectable brunch, I just recommend going on a weekday.
author: Amanda S.

description: Delicious!  I had "the plow" with almond pancakes because I have celiacs (have to eat GF) and I can't stop dreaming about that meal!  Waited for about an hour, but it was well worth it!
author: Ali H.

description: I have been anticipating eating here since it was in our San Francisco trip itinerary. I love breakfast food and this is definitely a good brunch spot as they also serve sandwiches and salads. The service was very prompt and we did not have to wait long. I definitely recommend trying the huckleberry coffee cake. The place itself is a little small, but it makes up for it in ambience. It's very quaint and cozy with a lot of natural lighting coming in from the large windows. I definitely recommend this for any breakfast lover planning their next trip to the city!
author: Amanda D.

description:
I came here with a friend of mine after a morning work out so we were hongry! that's right HONGRY. It was only 10:30AM and this place had a massive wait list which means a) their food really is that good of b) the space is too small. I have to say it was a combination of a & b and it was definitely worth the wait. We ended up waiting about 45 min before we were seated outdoors. I wanted to sit inside but the wait was going to be longer and this particular day was cold and foggy. Luckily, there were blankets. The only complaint about the seating is that we were seated on a slope so I was afraid I was going to be a klutz and somehow knock myself over (which didn't happen btw).

I ordered the Plow which included lemon ricotta pancakes topped with powdered sugar, eggs your way, bacon, and home fries. I have to say the home fries hit the spot with the grilled onions. Since it was cold, I ordered hot water and tea. The bill came out to be about $25-30/person including drinks.

I would definitely come here again however, I might come even earlier! a solid 5 stars for service, food, and location. Be prepared to stalk other people for parking...it took about 20 min to a spot!
author: Ciana P.

description: The wait is worth it. The breakfast here is always exceptional with food that is just amazing to the taste. I challenge anyone to try plow and not love it.
author: Justin B.

description: I've been here a few times over the years and the brunch is ok for San Francisco. I'm sure it's great if you're from out of town, but then aren't most highly rated SF restaurants? Not sure how their waiting list works because it's definitely not first come, first serve.  Maybe it's great to brunch here on that weekday you've ditched work. Not worth the wait on a weekend unless you're waiting for your laundry across the street.
author: K L.

description:
My favorite brunch place in SF...and that's saying a lot since I'm a San Francisco favorite and, considering brunch is my favorite meal, I have made a study of brunch venues in the city. 

In terms of food recs: I am obsessed with the breakfast potatoes (which are more like fried potatoes). They are crispy and perfectly seasoned. I also am a fan of their gluten free almond pancakes and their kale salad (when they have it). I recently had the corned beef hash topped with a poached egg, which was a little on the small side but tasted delicious. Oh yes, and they serve bottomless and wonderfully strong coffee! 

Everything they make is high quality, fresh and flavorful. The only warning is that there is ALWAYS a wait, so make sure you allot some extra time for that. But you can get coffee to sip while you wait, so that helps fight the hunger and the cold until it's time for your delicious meal.
author: Shannon R.

description: As a group of 3, there was a short wait for breakfast on a Wednesday morning - it wasn't a bad thing as we had time to check out the neighbourhood shops. I ordered the granola, which came with yogurt & chopped up chunks of fruit. The other two had the Plow. The granola was not as crunchy as I like (more chewy), it had shredded coconut, seeds, nuts (no dried fruit, for those who prefer that). I tried the lemon pancakes and they were tasty! Would return as it was an enjoyable experience.
author: Ashleigh D.

description:
Finding a place like Plow makes me love this city still more... sorry New York.. (But for shopping, I'd still hop on a plane and hit SOHO.)  Everything was absolutely delicious, with lovely ambiance and kind service.  

The only downside was the wait.  For me waiting more than 20 minutes for anything is torturous.  Over an hour wait on a Saturday morning forced my starving girlfriend and me to go over to Farley's and split a scone to ease our bitchy attitude caused by our hunger.  Four of us tried lemon ricotta pancakes, homemade pork sausage, fried egg sandwich, soft-shell crab sandwich, and doughnuts.  Eating their pork sausage makes it worth it that I'm not a vegetarian anymore. The crispy potatoes were out of this world.  

Now, If you still have room for desert, hit Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous for little scoops of heaven.
author: Sonia M.

description:
02.12.11

Brunch at Plow was an amazing start to a remarkable Saturday.  I had a friend visit from LA, who is supposedly hard to impress with food.  Thank goodness Plow came through.

The wait was about 15-20 minutes.  We lost track because of the gorgeous clear blue skies and unseasonably warm weather.  Got seated at the counter, and my coffee came right away.

I ordered the fried egg sandwich (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/A0AziPST4T6k-V3neWFRNA?select=uZldEhL0UQTJFUmoQKN7Kg).  Two eggs, Grafton cheddar, frisee, aioli and crispy potatoes.  Add dashes of hot sauce and a dollop of ketchup.  I'm in love.

If I lived closer, this would definitely make it into the rotation more.  But, parking was a cinch, so that's a huge plus.

Total damage for two: around $30.
author: Jenny L.

description:
My favorite brunch place. 

This is how I make the whole experience pleasurable:

I ride my scooter over, put my name on the list, ride back home, tell my boyfriend to get up because our names are on the list, then we go have a leisurely cup of coffee at Farleys before coming back to wait the last 10 minutes in front, or across the street in the sun. 

This is how it's done, all you waiter-haters! It's all about strategy.

I almost always order the plow with lemon ricotta pancakes and their homemade sausage patties. The crispy potatoes really are the most delicious things you could ever put into your mouth at breakfast.

Don't order the French toast here. They use French bread for some reason--it's way too thick with a stiff crust. 

Monkey bread, if they haven't run out yet, should be ordered immediately.
author: Larf P.

description:
I LOVE going out to breakfast, and this place has all the perfect elements for a most successful breakfast endeavor.  The location and building itself are so cute and cozy. it fits the food and you can see how perfectly thought out every detail is.  The napkins, salt and pepper shakers, restroom--everything was thoughtfully chosen.  It's small, and you will have to wait.  But let that waiting just be fuel for your fiery desire for awesome breakfast food.

The tea was delicious, and I got the Plow Breakfast so I could try a variety of items.  

Prepare to have all your preconceived notions of typical breakfast items blown away.  

Those.crispy.potatoes. 
 I want to cry thinking about how I have to live without them until my next visit to San Fran.  

Lemon ricotta pancakes. No brainier.  Chicken apple sausage.  Yep.  Eggs perfectly done.  I was so chubby and happy leaving this place- maybe I'm glad it's so far from me because I would clearly have to quit my job, eat here every day, and be fat and alone but SO SO happy if it was in driving distance.
author: Siara C.

description: Though this place is very good, I'm not sure it's worth standing in line. In any case, we wanted to try it once. Ordered the fried egg sandwich, corn muffin and lemon ricotta pancakes. The sandwich was very good - nice tastes with the cheese, the runny eggs and the sweet bun. The frisee added nice texture. The potatoes that came with the sandwich had too much rosemary for us. Fantastic texture, but we couldn't get over the herb overload. The pancake was very nice - soft and fluffy with a bit of texture on the outside and quite lemony. The corn muffin was good, but not great for me - it "powders" too easily.
author: Manjesh N.

description:
We were in the Portrero, waiting for Hard Knox lunch, when we saw in the Examiner that Plow had breakfast and lunch altogether.  Great! so we tried it and was it fun.  The wait was a little long to get in, but there was plenty of parking on the street, a nice neighborhood to browse, and the friendliest breakfast staff!

Breakfast was delicious, we got a soup,  farro and kale (always wanted to know how farro would be in a soup, and it was perfect for a late breakfast).  then went on to the plow breakfast, two perfect sunny side up eggs, homemade fragrant sausage patty, and the best potatoes.  Oh, and lemon ricotta pancakes, like you could make at home, but who has ricotta laying around at home?  the maple syrup was good too (could have used a side of butter).  Our other was a fried egg sandwich, really smoky bacon, distinctive cheese melted in, soft bun, and more of the potatoes.  

Not cheap, but so friendly for a morning meal, everyone's proud of the offerings, tables close together, but everyone's excited about their meal.  We liked it and will come back with friends.
author: Gary Y.

description:
Ok, after trip #2 I need to up it another star.

Tried the little gem salad w/nectarines and "the plow".. wow those lemon ricotta mini pancakes and potatoes are amazing!!!!! 

We were lucky enough to get seated at a table immediately (it being a Thurs afternoon), just wish it was like this all the time...

As usual, staff was uuber friendly. Great coffee too.
author: Melody T.

description:
Thanks to Yelp, we found Plow on our weekend in SF.  Having had breakfast two other places in SF afterward (which were both a let down) we can confidently confirm that Plow does indeed have the best breakfast in town.  In fact, Plow serves the best breakfast we've ever eaten.  No s*it.

Each morsel that entered our mouths was pure perfection, nearly a religious experience and as good as sex.  Plow's potatoes are definitely the best breakfast potatoes I've ever eaten and they've somehow managed to make an English muffin taste divine... and I'd sworn off of them many years ago.  The fresh salad greens on our plate were better than anything I've had anywhere... really.  The were huge, robust and tasted truly "farm fresh", a claim most restaurants make but, hey we know better than to believe them.

Best thing I had was the almond gluten free pancakes.  They were terrific.  I especially appreciate Plow serving real maple syrup, without asking and without extra charge.  Now that's classy and shows they care about food.

Thank you for the best breakfast ever... so depressed though that nothing will ever meet up to this experience again.
author: Danielle S.

description:
Plow is absolutely delicious! I came here for my boyfriend's birthday brunch. The wait was about 15 minutes for two on a Thursday afternoon at around 1pm. The hostess/server was very nice and assured us that we would be seated soon. Since Plow is, as they describe "modest in size" definitely expect to get seated literally inches away from some random people. Anyways! Since we looked at the menu beforehand, we received our orders within 15 minutes. Pretty fast! I also want to mention that the wait went by quickly since my boyfriend and I were watching the cooks cook/prepare the food in the open kitchen. I ordered the Plow while my boyfriend settled on the Fried Egg sandwich.

Their water was served in jugs! My favorite. :)

(From their menu)

The Plow-- two eggs, choice of Nueske bacon, house made pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes  14.5

Fried egg sandwich -- two eggs fried, aioli, frisee, Vermont cheddar, Acme bun  10.75  add Nueske bacon  12.75

The Plow was SO good! The eggs were on the watery/yolky side which I didn't mind. The bacon tasted exactly like how my mom makes it -- It was sweet and not too crispy. The lemon ricotta pancakes had a cake-like consistency and tons of flavor. My only complaint about the pancakes was that they were way too small! The potatoes? Best freaking breakfast potatoes I've ever had. They were flavorful, crispy, and oh so good! I also tasted my boyfriend's Fried Egg Sandwich was was also, very good. The total came out to be about $30 something for breakfast.. a little pricy, but totally worth it!
author: Joyce E.

description:
4 stars only because we waited for about 5 mins, (thanks Chris!), although it was in the rain.  The wait was suppose to be about 2 hours which is ridiculous because it's not that good and I would never wait for food like that.  Don't get me wrong, I definitly enjoyed my meal, (but the company was better), but like I said, not wait 2 hours good.   

It was my first time so I got The Plow with sunny side up eggs and the pork sausage.  The eggs were cooked well, the potatoes perfect, lemon ricotta pancakes were good, but the sausage was boring.  I had a mimosa with my meal and I did like how the flute curved out just a tad for that extra sip.  My husband got the spinach eggs benedict which he inhaled so it was probably good.  Our friend Chris got his usual scramble and then ate my 2nd pancake since he likes them so much and I couldn't finish.  We were out of there in about a hour.  Imagine if we waited 2 hours for that 1 hour meal.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
BEST CRISPY POTATO ON EARTH.

Everyone l've had the pleasure of eating with here loves this place.  The wait is guaranteed to be long, but it's civil and there are hardly ever any screaming children waiting with their parents.  Everything is super tasty and they make the best scrambled eggs in town.  
Personally, I'm not a fan of their famous lemon ricotta pancake, but their homemade pork sausage is fantastic.  
Take someone you love or can tolerate waiting in line with.  Better off in a party of two. 
Great date spot, cute bar seating, outdoor tables for the al fresco set.
author: Eugene X.

description:
Yummm.. We came here for one of my friends birthday brunch and it is very good brunch place.. We all started off with coffee and juices and ordered our food.  I had their classic egg breakfast with chicken apple sausage which came with some of their potatoes and bread on the side.. My friend ordered the plow which was similar to mine but also had their pancakes included in it and those pancakes were soooo good..with just a hint of lemon in them!! 
Do give their pancakes a try if you go there.. And everything they make there comes fresh from various farmers markets :-)
author: Rikki S.

description: This is one of my favorite brunch spots in SF. The wait can be maddening, but it's always worth it. My favorite dish is the lemon ricotta pancakes, but the menu has a ton of great options. The only issue I've ever had is that the bacon can be a bit fatty for my tastes, but I understand that some people like it that way. I just wish that Plow were open for dinner as well.
author: Drew C.

description:
I've been here a bunch of times and 
1. Somehow, I've never had to wait.
2. I've only ever sat at the bar. 
3. I love you


Plow is hands down, forever in my heart, deep within my soul, my favorite place to get breakfast. I eat breakfast here when I'm happy, I eat here when I want to celebrate, I eat here when I want to treat myself to something nice. I even eat here when I'm sad. (I do eat my feelings in the form of house made pork sausage.) Something tells me I'll be frequenting this place a little more nowadays. ;( :D
