I've never had anything bad here. And not even just that, because well, that's a lukewarm statement. I've only had EXCELLENT things here. The coffee is delicious, and so is the food. I most always get the Plow, which consists of lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy, crispy rosemary potatoes, eggs, and some sort of protein. I've had the soft scramble as well. Last time I was there there were oyster mushrooms, goat cheese, and stinging nettles all enveloped in soft, pillow-y, quivering eggs. freaking yum. 

And seriously, I don't mean to assume, or step on anyone's toes, but... it doesn't seem like anyone hates their job here. I know, rude of me to say. But no, really. The service is always served with a genuine smile, and I always come back because they are really, really, really nice. 

I recently went on a Saturday and even though they open at 8, the restaurant was full by 8:05. So, keep that in mind if you don't like waits! Even though I never have had to, I would because this place is a gem.
author: Rebecca N.

description:
My breakfast was fantastic and I absolutely loved watching them cook in front of me at the counter, but I will say that the service could have been better. My waitress was very rude from the moment I sat down - I told her that I had a flight to catch and was in a hurry so I'd gladly take my check upfront and she seemed offended by this. I also had trouble getting my coffee refilled and when I flagged down a different waitress and asked for more coffee she never came back with any :-/

Anyway though I had the lemon ricotta pancakes with a side of potatoes and they were delicious!

FYI lots of reviewers mention a long line - just go early when they first open and you can avoid this. There were quite a few empty tables when I went at 7:15am.
author: Karl S.

description:
Okay, so it pains me a tad to give plow such a low rating when clearly the majority of what seems to be the world loves it. but let me remind you all that two stars means "meh, I've experienced better", and that's exactly what I left thinking after eating at plow. 

I went yesterday with three friends, and after waiting for close to two hours (thank the Lord for that little coffee shop with the board games. scrabble was clutch!) we finally got a table outside. My table ordered a number of things to share: the french toast, crab scramble, some pork dish (i forget the oh so elegant name), and of course the plow. 

Me being a fan of all pancakes (just had the best sweet potato pancakes the weekend before at brenda's), I was super excited to taste the lemon ricotta pancakes as part of the plow. So when they came, and I tried them, I was definitely let down. they were.... just okay. Definitely not as flavorful as I had been hoping. Matter fact, that's how everything was. I think the highlight if anything was the potatoes. Definitely had a good little crisp going on, and when dunked in ketchup, it was bomb! 

One thing though that I liked more as an afterthought was that I left not feeling weighed down by the food. Not sure if this was because I didn't eat much of it or if the food was just very healthy/airy/light, but i did appreciate not feeling like i need to take a two hour nap afterwards to digest the food.  

so all in all... I'm glad I went to plow, and can now check it off my sf bucket list. but will likely not return, and don't really recommend it actually. there's other restaurants in the city where the food merits the wait a lot more.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
There are lots of hills in this area so I don't recommend wearing high heels going to this restaurant. Also, it's also really cold in SF and you have to wait outside for a table so bring a warm jacket.

The food was pretty good. I ordered the "The Plow" which has a little bit of everything. The potatoes were really good. They seem to be deep fried first then tossed in a pan with some caramelized onions. The home-made pork sausage patties were really good as well. The only thing I didn't care too much for was the lemon ricotta pancakes. They were a bit dense. It's probably the ricotta that makes it like that but I like my pancakes light and fluffy. 

Overall, I would definitely come back to try the rest of the menu. The service was really nice, great environment, and good food. Just bring a jacket because you will most likely have to stand outside and wait for a table.
author: Karen L.

description: Expect a wait on the weekends. Food is great, service is great. I got the plow, which comes with their lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy Yukon gold potatoes, and your choice of bacon or sausages. Their potatoes are AMAZING!! It was so good we ordered seconds. It was perfectly crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Seasoned to perfection. I also tried the French toast but it was nothing out of the ordinary for me. Mimosas are not bottomless but still delicious and $8 a glass. The ambiance is casual, if seated at the countertop, you can watch your food being prepped.
author: Cindy H.

description: I've sampled half the menu and everything has been  very fresh and delicious - PURE MAPLE SYRUP, nothing fake here!  Weekends can always expect a 45-60 minute wait (no reservations).  Gluten-free almond pancakes are good option for dietary restrictions, however would like to see non-meat side options with the main dishes like the Plow.  Mimosas, wine and beer on the menu, but no Bloody Mary and the sides above keeps Plow from reaching 5 star status.
author: Brian G.

description: Really civilized, fun. It's been getting crowds and yet the quality is still there. Very friendly staff.
author: Lu R.

description:
Plow has been on my list of "must try restaurants" for awhile.  Today when hubby and I were near the area, we decided to stop in.  Little did I know it was going to be a royal waste of time!  We showed up at 1:00 on a Saturday and were told the wait would be 30-45 minutes for 2 of us.  So frustrating to see people streaming out and several four tops (arriving after us) getting seated before us.  Problem is:  the very small restaurant is made up of mostly of four tops - so parties of 4 get priority seating.  At 50 minutes, I seriously considered cutting bait but we had come so far so we persevered, pushing past the pangs of hunger and our near-frozen fingers and toes. Had we been given an accurate estimate of the hour wait time, we would've gone elsewhere.  Like, Chez Maman - close by and has never disappointed.  

An hour later, we were finally seated at the counter.  Our server showed up almost immediately to take our drink order but took awhile to come back for our food order.  After I made eye contact with her twice (once she mouthed "I'll be right there"), she finally came back.  Hubby had The Plow and when I ordered the eggs benedict, I was told, "Oh, we're sold out.  We JUST sold the last one.  Literally a minute ago."  Really?!?  Way to add insult to injury.  We waited an hour in the cold wind, you took your sweet time with our food order and now you tell me that I just missed the last plate of eggs benedict by ONE minute?!?  Had she been more timely and efficient and showed up a minute earlier, I wouldn't have missed it.  Argh!

Unfortunately, the food wasn't good enough to rid the bad taste in my mouth I got from the wait and the couldn't-care-less attitude of the staff.  Though the food is better than average, it is in NO WAY worth the hour wait (or 2 hours for some other Yelpers who seem to have much more fortitude than I).  

I won't be going back unless they start taking reservations and upping the batch of hollandaise they make.  It's a head-scratcher for sure - they had plenty of eggs, ham/spinach/smoked salmon and english muffins (I had a side order, in fact) but they couldn't serve me eggs benedict?!?  I can only guess that they ran out of hollandaise.  How hard is it to make extra hollandaise?  Apparently this outage is a frequent occurrence - so why hasn't Plow addressed this?  Dear Plow:  Make extra hollandaise.  It doesn't cost much and you'll more than make up the cost of any potentially wasted hollandaise in the extra plates you sell.

Don't get sucked into the hype.  I wouldn't recommend going to Plow but if you absolutely must, then 1) go on a weekday, 2) go with a party of four and 3) make sure you place your order of eggs benedict ASAP (before you do anything else!).
author: Tone C.

description:
Arrived at Plow at 7:50am on a Saturday because I had heard that it's a very popular place for brunch/breakfast.  There were already about 20 people in line when I got there. 

My friend and I managed to get a spot at the bar, and we ordered a scramble and the biscuits and gravy.  Both dishes came with the infamous breakfast potatoes.  

I didn't try the scramble but it looked pretty great.  My biscuits and gravy were delicious, and a quite sizable portion.  The breakfast potatoes were really good.  Service was as attentive as it could be given the immediate onslaught of people.

I liked my breakfast a lot, but I'm unsure as to why people wait in line at this place.  If you're in the hood and prepared for a wait, then sure give it a try.
author: Margaret I.

description:
LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES & Monte Cristo.

Delicious. Can't wait to come here again to try some of their other items.

There's always a wait though.
author: Heather R.

description:
This place is good, don't get me wrong. There's just nothing here that's super creative, exciting, or over the top that people wait 2+ hours for. Another place where SF folks feel the need to stand in line for just alright brunch food. 

Again, I'm not beating up on this place....food's great, but nothing that will knock your socks off.
author: LAIKA K.

description:
My buddy and me love food, while my brother and his skater buddies think I'm a yuppie.  My brother and I flew into SFO and I requested we come straight here.  They were turned off by the yuppie seeming, oh so freshness we're in SF vibe.  They didn't say much when the food arrived.  Place is bomb.  It is expensive, but hey, they're paying SF rent.

If more places like these would take over the world, we would all be much healthier for not eating stuff that comes in a frozen package and gets heated up for you at big chains.
author: Andy B.

description: Incredibly frustrating. Came to leave my name. 90 minutes later, the hostess remembered me but had no record. Told me I would be "one of the next ones- stay close." Totally unapologetic. After 10 more 2-tops had been called, I checked again. She said it would be 30 minutes, again totally unapologetic. Busy enough not to care about any individual customer, even when they blatantly make a mistake.
author: Jesse O.

description:
Best breakfast in the city. 

That's my intro. I'm sticking to it. I actually feel I need not elaborate, but I will give some background to such a bold claim, since that's what Yelp visitors are so fanatic about reading. 

Last weekend I was happy to host my brother and his girlfriend at my flat for his birthday. 30 years
author: Seth F.

description:
Their Saturday brunch was so good, I felt like I was literally *plowing* through my food.

At 11 am, there was roughly a 20 minute wait (some counter seating opened up but we held out for a table for two.) Plow is a compact space--more long than it is wide--that surprisingly doesn't feel crowded. 

We ordered:
-- lemon ricotta pancakes ($9) to share: slightly crisp edges & fluffier in the middle. lemony but not at all tart. the ricotta gave it a nice density & almost tangy flavor. it needed a drizzle of maple syrup for some sweetness. 
-- fried egg sandwich with crispy potatoes ($8.50): i added a side of chicken apple sausage ($4.) a 10 on the Richter scale, as far as breakfast sandwiches go. the potatoes were SO crispy & had a bit of onion running through it. 
-- cider brined pork chop for the bff ($14): the bff thought it was moist & flavorful. 

Everything about Plow is charming; from our waitress with a British accent to the simple design details & right down to the cozy neighborhood. Utterly charming. I like charming. Can't get enough of it, really.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
There's this character in a fighting video game. She's generally counted to be on the side of the good guys. But land too many hits on her (when she has 5 bars), and she'll turn into the bitch from hell. My health bar waiting at Plow was at that magic pixel of life remaining, and there was one moment where that final punch landed on me, and it was on... full on Dark Phoenix sour puss bitch-face for me the rest of the meal.

Here's the tl;dr version of this review: Only eat here as a pair; not a 3-some, not a group of 4; Budda help you if you're a party of five or more. The food is better than average. The price is hipster high. And the wait is long and not worth it. The staff is friendly once you're seated.

Back to the fighting game analogy; I started off the morning at full life. Sure, we had to wake up at 7:30AM on a Sunday to drive across town to eat here; but I knew what I was getting into. This is SF, brunch waits are supposed to be brutal, but it'll all be okay in the end... I know that. I also understand that when a party of four shows up, we'll have to wait for a space to free up to get seated. But when MULTIPLE groups of pairs and THREE people parties were being seated ahead of my four-person party, my life bar took a hit. Why couldn't they just wait for 2 pairs seated near each other to leave and push those two tables together for us? I guess the business sense I gathered from this experience was: In the long run, it's okay to piss off a group of four customers, if you've already made 10 other customers happy. You still end up +6 overall.

When we were finally were given a table (an hour later after being initially told a 30 minute wait... you know, because we were the 3rd on the list arriving at 8:15AM), my lifebar took another big hit when I saw that a family group of four (parents plus 2 kids) who DEFINITELY came by after us were already seated and getting their order taken. How did this other four person party have priority over us?

Life's at a pixel now. The final blow? A pair who came later than us and who was seated before us finished their meal. Their table was cleared but was intentionally kept empty and not filled by the exponentially growing line behind us. When the second couple who sat adjacent to the now empty table left, the tables were cleared and the two tables pushed together to seat an incoming party of four. Why didn't this happen for us? 

"I can't control it!" And that was it. Even if they brought out food blessed by Alice Waters herself, it still wouldn't erase the bitterness and sour taste already in my mouth.

I will say that the actual service of the waitstaff after we were seated was exceptionally friendly and kind. The food? The best food item for me were their potatoes. Top tier. The lemon ricotta pancakes were good, but not food nirvana like most of the reviews seem to think. Solid high tier. The eggs were prepared fine, but who really messes up scrambled eggs, you know? Mid-tier. The sausage was a bit dry and the bacon a bit flimsy. Low tier.

I'm sure if things didn't start off on the wrong foot, I may have enjoyed my meal better. But for the price paid, it was just not worth the effort, even if the waitstaff was nice. Pass...
author: Mercutio k.

description: I would've given this place a 5 star rating if I didn't see the blond hostess try and give my table that I've been waiting 2 hours for to her friend. Thankfully the gentlemen was there to rightfully give me the table. The food was 5 stars and I would come back if I was in the area but after the hostess incident I'm not too hot on coming back.
author: T L.

description:
Every time I've come here, I've waited at least 30-45 minutes and it's been worth it each and every time. Foods amazing here and waitstaff is always great. Fresh ingredients make the plates here just that good. I've ordered the plow which is your standard eggs, house potatoes bacon toast and it's soooo good!!!! Not boring at all. Lemon ricotta pancakes melt in your mouth, along with strong delicous coffee. You are set for the day. 
Parkings not bad. Beautiful place, great neighborhood. Love coming here
author: C. M.

description:
We had brunch at Plow with some friends today. The wait was a little over an hour but we expected that since it was the peak brunch hour. But let me tell you, it was worth the wait!

I got the fried egg sandwich (eggs were cooked perfectly) with crispy potatoes (had a hint of rosemary -- super delicious!). My husband and I split a lemon ricotta pancake, which was on point! And we tried a buttermilk biscuit that just melted in our mouths. My husband got the almond flour pancakes and he was a bit disappointed. He was under the impression that they would taste almondy but they didn't at all. They tasted good but don't get them if you want something that tastes almondy.

We would definitely go back and try other items on the menu. But we'll still get the lemon ricotta pancakes in addition to anything else we get. They.are.amazing!!!
author: Karishma B.

description: AMAZING lemon ricotta pancakes. Literally to die for. Literally. Their biscuit and potatoes are incredible as well. My server was not the friendliest, which is why I decided to give Plow 4 instead of 5 stars. I suggest either going super early or going during the weekdays if possible to avoid the 1.5hr+ wait.
author: Janet M.

description:
Who would have thought Potrero Hill would have one of the most popular brunch places in SF? Wait might be a bit lengthy but we got lucky and only waited about 15 minutes. 

The first thing I've noticed was how clean the restaurant was. Tables were immediately scrubbed down, forks and knives were sparkling and spotless and so were the cups. It made me anticipate my meal even more.

Lemon ricotta pancakes were absolutely divine. Moist, light and similar to thick eggy crepes except with a hint of lemon flavor. My hubs ordered that and I ordered the scramble. We shared both plates and it was the perfect portion for two since we both wanted a little bit of pancakes but not necessarily an entire plate to ourselves. And if you have pancakes at brunch, you must have eggs. I wanted to try their chocolate pudding but we were too stuffed to eat another bite when we finished our dishes.

I can't wait to come back here for a weekend brunch again. And you can bet we will be ordering the lemon ricotta pancakes again.
author: Esther A.

description:
Can't believe I forgot to review this place, so good.

We sat at the bar, which was a great experience seeing the cooks work the busy kitchen.  We were promptly served some coffee & tea, which was delicious and placed our orders.

I recall having the almond flour pancakes, and they were better than I had expected.  Not grainy, pretty fluffy.  Also had a couple eggs over easy on the side, cooked just right, and not super greasy.  Very nice.

I need to come back here and sample some more of their items, it all looked great as I saw it travelling around the room to other tables.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Let me set the scene here - it's Wednesday morning at 9:30am and there is a crowd outside and a 45 minute wait. Yes, a random Wednesday morning. At that point, we knew we had to be in for an incredible meal. And let me just say, we weren't disappointed. 

If you want to try everything, the Plow is a must - you get unreal bacon, delicious fluffy eggs, the world's best potatoes, and not-to-miss lemon ricotta pancakes. If you're lucky enough to steal a bite of someone else's pancakes, the goat cheese and tomato eggs were fantastic, soft scrambled so they melted in your mouth. 

Don't forget to ask for the jam to go with your toast, you won't regret it.
author: Leslie K.

description: I took my family here for Sunday brunch based on the reviews and all I can say is Plow exceeded our expectations. The Lemon Ricotta pancakes - to die for!! The service was stellar! We will definitely return.
author: Maria M.

description: 2 hour wait, food was ok. Way over priced! Not worth 2 hour wait menu options could be better. I expected more for the hype
author: Julie V.

description: I didn't get a good experience at plow. Yes the food is good and yes they are very busy with 1-1.5 hr wait during peak times, but the dining experience didn't do it for me. I could have just taken the food to go. My friends and I came in on one of those off the chart cold days in San Francisco and we were seated outside. They didn't have heaters outside and the worst, my food came out cold. I was devastated. I wanted to enjoy a warm good tasting meal but instead I only got the good tasting part. My food was cold. I'm disappointed. And, to sum it off, the hostess gave me an attitude when I asked for coffee while waiting.
author: J C.

description:
Lemon Ricotta Pancakes - I'm not the biggest breakfast person and I only like to eat pancakes about once a year, but I could have these every day. They were lemon breakfast dessert clouds of yumminess.

Crispy Potatoes - The kind of homefries that are cooked in some sort of wonderful fat. There were pieces of all sizes, but my favorite were the really small crispies that were like shavings of salty fried butter. 

The Plow - One of the people I was eating with said it best, "They took all the best parts of breakfast and put it on a humungous plate." Sausage, bacon, eggs, crispy potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes... the works.
author: Brittany B.

description:
I love Plow's:

-location (beautiful views, ample parking)
-bright and open ambiance
-friendly and attentive staff
-use of local ingredients
-flavorful and healthily portioned food

This is a family-friendly (they have a kid's menu for "little plows") AND date-perfect brunch spot.  Definitely a little gem worth traveling across town for.
author: Jenn C.

description:
After reading rave reviews, I really wanted to check this place out. 
I had read the wait on weekends was crazy, so we decided to go the day before X-mas Eve, since my guy had the day off. 

Unfortunately, there was still about a 30 minute wait. We were a group of 4, but i saw groups of 2 waiting awhile as well. 

The space is small, and feels a little cramped, but I liked being able to see the action in the kitchen, (and check out the food coming out.) 

My guy and I shared the much revered egg sandwich, and the plow. The sandwich was good, and the potatoes were as awesome as everyone says. What I REALLY loved were the mini lemon ricotta pancakes. So glad my guy and i ordered the way we did, we got to taste more things this way. 

I agree with other reviewers that the portions are smaller than a lot of breakfast places. But, all the products are sourced locally, and organic, (even the sausage is made in-house.) 
You're getting much higher quality food here than at your run-of-mill breakfast joint. 

If i lived in the neighborhood, i would be back, but not if the wait was over 30 minutes.I 'm just not that patient. 

On the day we were here, Charles Phan, and the owner of Gialina's & Ragazza, (she makes the best pizza around) were eating here too. I think that speaks volumes about the kind of food they're dishing out here.
author: Amanda G.

description:
Great little spot on Potrero Hill!  Like everyone says it does get busy so get there early and put your name in.

The picture of everyone sitting outside with umbrellas says it all!

It's that good!
author: Reggie A.

description:
I really really wanted to love this place with all my heart.... I had been dreaming of the day I could eat here - It was on my "SF Bucket List" Finally after sitting outside for 45-50 minutes on a Tuesday morning at 11 -- my rumbling tummy met with the plow... pancakes, potatoes, eggs sausage for about $15.

I got the plow and the lemon ricotta pancakes weren't phenomenal, they were sort of bready, burnt and a bit on the smaller side as a part of the combo. And the pancakes came on the same plate as the rest of my crowded plate... which meant syrup leaking into my eggs and potatoes...  The eggs, apple sausage were mediocre - I could have replicated something similar @ home. The highlight of the plate were the potatoes though -  super crispey on the outside like a fry, but soft on the inside like a baked potato. 

The service was good - the staff were upbeat and welcoming. Food wasn't brought out quickly and they seated 5 of us at a table and bench made for 4. Maybe eating with my elbow in my friends face made the food taste less good?

Overall - it's ok, but not worth 45 minutes though.
author: Christine B.

description:
the food is good. the service is bad. especially from the hostess with the mousy whiney voice.  
just another place in SF that ruins the experience by treating people that they should be lucky to be eating there. tried to shift a table over to let the party of 6 next to us have more room and they didn't let us. 
I think it would have been worth the wait if she also didn't respond to me saying I wasn't ready to order after being seated 2 seconds before by saying "well people are usually ready after waiting 2 hours"
RUDE.
author: emily k.

description: My favorite brunch place. Fried potatoes is surprisingly crispy and tasty. In store waitresses are all very friendly and cute
author: Sunny J.

description:
Two words: crispy potatoes. 

I came here for brunch after a night of drinking well tequila at a bar whose name is slipping my mind. We got here on a Tuesday around 1030 and the place was packed. Luckily we didn't have to wait long for a table for 3. The staff is friendly and attentive. 

I ordered "The Plow" which consists of 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, eggs your way, and your choice of bacon, chicken apple sausage, or the house sausage.

I cleaned my plate! This place  is awesome and I wish there was something similar to it around where I live.

I will definitely be back if I'm ever in the area. 

Go get Plowed! (Sorry, couldn't resist.)
author: Marcus B.

description:
Be prepared to wait..and wait..and wait some more.  On a Sunday, the list fills up to three or four pages, and it feels like winning the lottery when you get a table.  Still, the food was worth the wait and full of delicious brunching goodness. 

-Crispy potatoes with a chewy center
-Double thick pancakes that make you feel like you died and went to pancake heaven (I had the GF ones--but they were delicious)
-Smoky, albeit greasy bacon.
-And savory pockets of deliciousness called breakfast sausage

Would I go here for brunch again?  It would not hurt to live down the street and show up at the door when they open, but I will definitely hold future pancake places to the Plow standard.
author: Liaty Z.

description:
One word...wow.  :)  

Get their lemon ricotta pancakes or "The Plow."  If they have buttermilk biscuits, don't miss 'em!
author: Thomas B.

description:
Right off the bat, I liked Plow. It looked like a crazy wait outside and the hostess told us it would be a 20 minute wait. They had this self-serve coffee section inside so we sipped some coffee and were seated within 10 minutes. Thank you for not lying to us and telling us it's a 20 minute wait when really it's 40 minutes like some other brunch places out there....

We got the fried egg sandwich and "the plow" which had everything. Fried egg sandwich was tasty, but didn't exactly meet my requirements to be called "heavenly". However, the lemon ricotta pancakes with the citrus-y syrup was deeelicious! I actually dipped my bacon, and then my potatoes when the bacon ran out, into that maple syrup and cleaned up 2 mini pitchers of it. Everything else was great but not spectacular. 

Just an fyi though, I totally thought that the coffee everyone got waiting for a table was free...like a "Thank you for waking up at 7:30am on a Sunday morning to brunch here only to have to wait outside in the cold anyways" type of free coffee, which I thought was so sweet of Plow. But then I saw a $4/cup charge on my bill. hmph...
author: Kate Y.

description:
The potatoes are amazing. I guess if you fry anything it tastes good, but these are special. I've been here on weekdays twice now, which is great because there is no line (though it is still crowded). First let me address the fact that you get to eat brunch every day of the week - that's awesome. But the food is really really excellent, including their baked good selection, which can sometimes be a throw away item on the menu. The sausage patties are perfectly flavored and seasoned, and the scrambled eggs are insanely fluffy.

Only downside? I have yet to try the Chinese breakfast, despite being there by 9 am. What time do I need to get there to try this item??

Cannot wait to go back.
author: Ruchi M.

description: Ricotta lemon pancakes were so delicious. The coffee was great and wait staff attentive. The wait for a table is a bit too long and the food is a bit heavy on the butter, otherwise I would give 5 stars.
author: Catherine W.

description:
Every once in a while I get a craving for some hearty breakfast food, and Plow hits the spot!  The brunch menu isn't extensive, but everything on it sounds positively scrumptious...I had a hard time deciding between the lemon ricotta pancakes and the eggs benedict. We sat at the counter and were able to watch the food being prepared, which after the long wait time, only made us hungrier.  Every plate that left the kitchen looked amazing. We ended up with the eggs benedict with ham, and an egg sandwich. The farm fresh ingredients they use make everything taste better, right down to the eggs.  

The only downside of this place is that like every other popular breakfast/brunch place in the city, there is always a line. We came around 11:30 on a Saturday, and were told it would be a 45 minute to an hour wait. Also, the food took a while to get to the counter; it looked like they miss-timed some of the orders and were backed up. On the whole, I'm glad we decided to wait it out--the service was friendly and welcoming, and parking was relatively easy to find in this neighborhood.
author: Lisa N.

description:
I had never been to this neighborhood west of Dogpatch and enjoyed discovering this area of San Francisco. Landing at Plow, I waited in the breeziness of this hilly area for a table which seemed to go fast, maybe half an hour, and sat in the staggered benches going up the contour of the hills implanted into the outside of the restaurant. A very nice touch in planning for patrons to be comfortable during the wait. Makes for a great touristy, artsy photo op. 

We were seated at the first table and the breeziness stayed with us throughout our meal.  Kinda chilly with everyone coming and going in and out of Plow.  There is a constant flow of hipster people hooked to their smartphones and wearing Tom's shoes.

Then it was time to eat the lemon ricotta pancakes-a must.
Hash- beans and vegetables but no corned beef
Smashed potatoes-very delicious
French toast- bread pudding like
Tomato bread soup-fresh flavors
Sausage paddies- had a kick
Coffee-full bodied

One of my favorite things about eating breakfast here is watching the subtle antics of the white lab in the garden/lighting store across the street. The doggy appears through the windowed door that seems to be custom made for this sweet looking dog. Charming!
author: Rebecca B.

description: The food is very good. I recommend you either get a reservation or put your name on the list and return after half an hour. I came before 9 and still a twenty min wait - 1 person sit by the counter has a very short wait. The service is good. Very very loud though.
author: Gilad P.

description: Longer wait than they told us, but it was worth it and I wish I lived here so I could eat here more often! Everything that our party of four ordered was heavenly! The conversation stopped completely, haha.
author: S Y.

description:
Why this place does not have 5 stars is amazing to me. 
Yes you have a long wait BUT every second is worth it. 
The food is great. Our group of six five had the Plow their signature dish.. And it was awesome ! The potatoes perfect the lemon pancakes WOW ! 
Something everyone should try!! 
Your missing out if you do not try it.
author: Richard D.

description: Every time I come to San Francisco I can't leave without a breakfast at plow! This spot is so yummy and it's always at the top of my list. Place is small and very popular so I suggest early arrival, and the wait is well worth it! The plow is always my favorite thing to order with mimosas of course (;
author: Danica C.

description: Hands down the best brunch I have ever had! I ordered the plow, a side of the market fruit & a grapefruit mimosa. Everything was amazing & the service was very friendly. My husband & I did have to wait about an hour or more to get a table, but it was well worth it! Go & wait for a table! You won't regret it!
author: Molly M.

description: For breakfast, the lemony pancake was very fluffy, tasty. The crab scrambled had plenty of fresh crab but such a small serving but loads of side potato. French toast was ok, wrong texture of bread, it was too thick but got soggy once the syrup intervened. Eggs were organic. Mimosa is good. But it wasn't worth 2.5 hours of wait. It was just ok for me!
author: Vee V.

description:
A great brunch place with your girlfriends! 

Food: Brunch food with a something a little extra. Favorite: fried egg sandwich
Quantity: Plenty
Price: Average
Ambience: Casual. Nice place on a sunny day
Noise: Moderate. 
Attire: Pajamas
Service: Always great
Parking: Surrounded by houses, but parking is available if you just look around.
Recommendations: Fried egg sandwich (duh), french toast and the lemon ricotta pancakes. Coffee is always good. Prepare to wait if you go on peak brunch hours of 9:30-11:30. I say go there as soon as they open. 

Overall: solid 4
author: Annie T.

description:
Warm and inviting, from the place itself to the staff and proprietors. Sat at the bar and had the breakfast sandwich. Delicious. Got to witness all the different meals being made, and realize I will have to come back and try some more offerings.

 I ate like the animal on the sign.
author: Dan B.

description:
The Venue:  Very bright with natural lighting.  Simple and clean looking.  

The Price:  A little on the high end for breakfast.

The wait:  I've driven by quite a few times and it's always packed.  So we decided to go when they opened.  8am.  There are no reservations so you may have to wait.  The bad thing about coming first thing is you get the first wave wait.  It wasn't as bad as some places, but it beats waiting outside or standing.  :)

The neighborhood:  It's in Potrero Hill/ Dogpatch area so everywhere around there is pretty cute and quaint.

The food:  They have a great menu and everything sounds awesome.  
We had The Plow:  eggs, sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes.
 Pretty basic for an arm and a leg.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were pretty tasty.  The eggs and bacon were cooked perfectly but the crispy potatoes... weren't so crispy.
We also had the egg sandwich with bacon.  MMMMM delicious!  The bacon was nice and thick, the egg was cooked perfectly and the bun they use is acme, so, can't go wrong there.  The whole sandwich was melt in your mouth perfect.

I would definitely come again and will so that I can try out all of there other delicious menu items.
author: Delilah B.

description:
Sunday 21st April 2013

Goal: Lemon Ricotta Pancakes. 

Destination: Plow

Time and distance to destination: 15 minutes, 2.1 miles. 

Its time. 

Been hearing the reviews about this baby and decided on a late sunday afternoon to go get me some pancakes. Weather was sunny and i only had to wait for 20 minutes, give or take. Be sure to check the wait every now and then cause the server had almost cross my name because they forgot to check the page that had my name. 

Nevertheless, i absolutely loved the pancakes. It was soft, and the right amount of layers(some pancakes are so thick in SF) that i can never finish it. I was GLAD to finish mine in a serving. Also, the crab dungeness scramble is a must try! Other than that i think the menu is a pretty standard weekend brunch. Service was great, always got my water filled, and the server was polite and knows a lot about the menu. 

Decor wise, i love the wood tables, thats a plus, any place with wooden tables, i absolutely love it. Love the big windows...but i do think they should at least make a separate restroom for the men and women. Just for hygienic sake....

Destination complete. 
Im in pursuit of the perfect pancake in SF, 
till next time. Over and out.
author: Cavin T.

description:
I loved this place... the vibe, the good food, you name it. Until one day the manager followed my 61 year old father across the street to scream at him in front of a large crowd of people. 

My father had been a loyal customer for nearly two years, eating at Plow about three or more times a week. He had a friendly relationship with all of the waiters, as well as the owners. One day he wandered in for a quick breakfast (note: if you need to get somewhere and only have a short time to eat, this is not the place for you). He made if clear several times to the waiter that he was in a rush and asked repeatedly if they had time to make him his dish. The waiter and chef reassured him several times that there would be plenty of time. After not being able to get the waiter's attention for 30 minutes, and no sign of the meal anywhere, he signaled that he had to leave for his appointment. The waiter acknowledged him, and he got up and walked across the street. The manager of the restaurant ran after him, screaming and cursing in front of a group of people, and telling him how disrespectful it was for him to leave. 

When I found out that this had happened, I couldn't help but ask myself: Doesn't someone working in a restaurant always learn that the customer is always right? I though that was a basic rule of the restaurant business. I was shocked that the manager would talk that way to not only someone who has been such a loyal customer, but would speak to anyone that way. It makes me sad because I loved this place, yet I can't justify going back when they have treated my father with such disrespect and poor taste.
author: Aislinn C.

description: Simply the best. I only ever get the aptly named "The Plow" dish. Best Lemon Ricotta pancakes around
author: Seth D.

description:
This is one of the saddest, most frustrating reviews I've ever had to write. I discovered Plow in its first months and I was so excited. It had been forever since a really awesome new breakfast place knocked my socks off in SF. Everything was amazing, the restaurant was quaint and busy and clean, the service was impeccable. I came here again and again, and recommended it to my friends enthusiastically. I never wanted to yelp it because, selfishly, I hoped that it wouldn't become *too* popular. Of course, it did become popular, and the lines on the weekends got longer. Even so, I got up at 7am many a Saturday or Sunday morning to make it by 8am and beat the line. It was worth it. 

I first noticed things slipping in March 2012. I came with 2 other people, waited for an hour+ (wasn't surprised, I knew we'd have to wait). Then we were seated at a 4-top. However, the host informed us that really, we were only allowed to have one half of the table, and they were going to put a chair on the long end and seat another party in the other two seats. Yes, a table for 2 people (a standard 2-top) with a chair pushed onto a longside (in the tiny aisle). We couldn't even fit 3 plates of food and our water glasses on the table. We asked if we could wait for a larger table and were told no. Apparently, they only seat 3 people at tables for 2. OK. Even though it was expensive, and we were squished and basically sharing our table with strangers, I came back again and again anyway because the food was delicious, and aside from the seating issues, the service was good. 

I had been craving their lemon ricotta pancakes, and dragged my husband out of bed early yesterday morning. I was so excited to get there and be first in line when the doors opened. 

We both ordered a coffee (they are $3.75 a piece, btw). Of course, it was 8am, and I drank my first cup in 5 minutes. Nobody came by to ask if I wanted a refill, so after trying to get someone's attention for 10 minutes, I got up and poured a refill myself. Remember, I was the first table in the restaurant. Nobody could possibly have been in the weeds yet. 

The food came, and my bacon was practically raw. The waitress had set our food down and began taking the order of the table next to us. I waited until they were done and then tried to get her attention politely. I was probably too quiet and she didn't hear me. I said excuse me a little louder. And a little louder. I wasn't trying to be rude, just wanted to get her attention before she walked away since she hadn't been attentive and I didn't want to eat cold food. She seemed incredibly annoyed, even though I was nothing but polite about it. I thanked her profusely. She still hadn't offered me a single refill, so when she brought the bacon back, I asked for one. This also seemed to irritate her. Can I say it again? It was 8am. There's no reason for anything to be off with your first table of the day!

Alone, that would be just bad service. But the food wasn't good. Like, not even diner-level good. My scrambled eggs were passable. The bacon came back fine. My lemon-ricotta pancakes were cold and rubbery. They tasted like they were day-old and had been sitting on the plate for an hour. My husband's eggs benedict (his usual favorite) was watery -- like the eggs hadn't been dried off before they were dropped on the spinach. And there was the tiniest serving of hollandaise sauce -- a smattering on top. These items used to be amazing. They were not just less-than amazing, they were subpar. If the waitress had been even the tiniest bit attentive, I might have pointed these things out to her. But at that point, I could feel her irritation, and I didn't want to complain to her about basically everything, particularly considering she was annoyed that I wanted a coffee refill.

I wouldn't return to eat that food. Combine that with the irritated service from the waitress whose long hair wasn't tied back, but hanging over her shoulder. And the fact that this cost us $50. Two coffees and two breakfasts. 

Minus 1 star each for the food, the service, the wait and the price that adds insult to injury. I'm sorry, Plow. It was good when it was good. Now, I'm just happy to never return.
author: Marissa K.

description:
I was here a couple weeks ago on a Sunday,
around 11 AM, for the first time. I ordered the plow and the best part of it where the lemon ricotta pancakes; I only wish they were bigger. I waited literally two hours, myself another person, so we were only a small party of two .I don't think I'd go back because of this. Maybe I didn't order the right thing but the food was (only) pretty, good and the service was good, but the wait kind of killed it for me.
author: R J.

description:
OK, let's get that bad stuff out of the way.  The wait. Ok, that's it for the bad.

The good? Well, everything. From the service, the ambiance to especially the food! The gluten free almond flour pancake was AWESOME!!! The bacon was cooked to a extra crispy perfection! The grapefruit juice squeezed fresh, the dungeness scramble AMAZING! The brined pork chop cooked to perfection and the potatoes just RAD! I don't know if you could tell, but I'm a fan!

Oh yeah, careful with gravity when you sit outside on the sloping side of the street, just sayin'....
author: Rob L.

description: drool*  The lemon ricotta pancake is amazing.  Who would think that ricotta would go so well in a pancake.  No doubt my favorite item here, despite the crispy potatoes (which are also amazing) being on the 7x7 big eats list.  Also got the fried egg sandwich.  I'm completely biased here since I've pretty much never had a fried egg sandwich in SF that wasn't amazing.  Thinking about this is making me hungry!
author: Tiffany C.

description: On your mark, get set...wait. Yes, I have waited several times in front of Plow with other hungry members of the community, waiting for their awesome fried egg and bacon sandwich, lemon ricotta pancakes and a host of other excellent breakfast and lunch items--most all of which is sourced locally. Even on cold days it's worth it, because the interior is warm and friendly, and the coffee's damn good. Is it even worth sitting outside when the cold Potrero winds whip down 18th street? Damn right it is!
author: Tom M.

description:
It's rare that both of us are awake before 8 on a Saturday so when we found ourselves up and starving at 7:30, we hopped in the car and headed over to Plow.  Got there just in time for the doors to open so there was no wait.  Good thing too because the restaurant filled up very quickly.  It's a really cute space and they had tables and chairs set-up outside too.  

We started with the donut holes filled with an awesome lemon curd.  The lemon curd had a tart kick but was smooth and creamy inside some hot fried dough.  I had the french toast with vanilla-poached pears.  It was sweet and savory and satisfying.  Husband at The Plow and it did not disappoint.  LOVED the fried potatoes and the lemon ricotta pancakes were yummy.  

The quality of the food was excellent and they get fresh and local ingredients from vendors I recognize from the farmer's market nearby.
author: Nina L.

description: The Lemon Ricotta pancakes are my favorite! Love the atmosphere and friendly staff. There is often a long wait, but the food is worth it!
author: Lisa K.

description: Amazing atmosphere, really friendly staff. You Most get the plow!!!  FYI...the home fries are out of this world.  One caveat, food preparation is unique to say the least.
author: Miguel C.

description: Great food.  Terrible customer service.  Oder came incomplete.  Waitress did not bother to check in.  Flagged her down and she seemed bothered. Won't go back.
author: L H.

description:
I'm now ruined for all other potatoes. Are they deep fried? The texture is soft in the center and crispy in the outside with perfect seasoning. As for three rest of "The Plow" (everyone should begin the day with a good plow), the lemon ricotta pancakes are delicious. The eggs were good, but nothing special. Good coffee, also nothing special.

What I found confusing was how this place could be full with a waiting list at 10:30am on a weekday morning. I can't even imagine what the weekend must be like.
author: Hester B.

description:
3.5 
Waited for like 40 freaking minutes just to get seated. 

The food was alright, but not anything worth waiting for.  It's also pretty pricey for breakfast food. I got the plate with the pancakes, bacon, potatoes. 

The potatoes were the only thing that is a 5 star. I would go there just for the potatoes.. if the wait wasn't too long. 

Nothing else really stood out for me.
author: Suzie B.

description:
This place is cute! I say PETITE if I were to describe a person teehee! :P

I love breakfast food. So when I saw pancakes, bacon, sausage, potatoes in the menu ...I got so excited!

Im not sure if it was because it was New Year's when we came but we had to wait about 30 mins to be seated. 

The service is good ... and food is good too. Nothing really that I would crave for. BUT it IS reliable.... isnt that what matters to most people? ;)
author: RED C.

description:
Happy, happy, happy tummy!

Most people can wait for a table without wanting to wail in misery. Not me. I LOATHE a wait. Honestly, I just. Don't. Do. It.  But I had plans immediately afterwards with my friends who'd underestimated the wait. By an HOUR. So I was trapped. UGH!!! Luckily a friend got there 30 minutes before me, but still...a 90 minute wait for a meal is stupid. I'm glad the restaurant is doing well. I just question the sanity of people willing to wait. Wait to spend money. Why would people do that?? Get a scone from Farley's and go home, ya'll!

Anyway, my misery over the wait isn't Plow's fault. In fact, once we were seated, they seemed to move things forward at a good pace. 

I had the fried egg sandwich with bacon, as did one other in our party. A third person had the ricotta pancakes. The fourth had the soft scramble. I also ordered a side salad, which was just lettuce. The salad, if you can call just lettuce a salad, was fine. The greens were fresh and the dressing was good. The sandwich was delicious, and the pillow-soft brioche bun really made it fabulous. The crispy potatoes were excellent, too. Ketchup would have been blasphemous. My friends enjoyed their meals, also. The creme fraiche pumpkin muffin was just okay. 

All in all, I'd go back for SURE if I ever catch this place without a wait.
author: Karen Z.

description: Only reason I'm giving this place four stars is because of the wait time, otherwise it would have been a 5. Also, the outside seating was a bit harsh for the day's weather, but they did provide us with two blankets (we had to wait a bit for them to free up). However, it was pretty fun eating on a hill.The homemade sausage patties are to die for! There was also a corn muffin that was pretty awesome. My husband and I enjoyed our meals, we both opted for the plow, he had the sausage which was also good and we ordered a side of bacon. The mimosas were good as well.
author: Sheira C.

description: This place in a WORD PROBABLY THE BEST BREAKFAST in SOMA and MAYBE SAN FRANCISCO.  JOEL is a BREAKFAST and FRESH FOOD KING.  We had heard the LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES were AWESOME and people ARE RIGHT THEY ARE!!!! PERFECT!!!!  However our waitress Was PERFECT in the suggestions.  The day started off with a LONG WALK from NOB HILL (California/JONES) hey we knew we were going to eat a lot!!!  After our sojourn through SOMA, we found this casual and comforting spot known as PLOW.  The place is not large but the host and hostess(SOMA residents) make it work.  There are a few outside tables as well.  NOW for the STAR the food.  We started with a perfectly balanced MIMOSA ($11) to pass the 30 minute wait time pleasantly enough.  After we were seated we ordered based on the waitress selections (THE PLOW $17) trust me order it you will finish and love it.) also ordered French Toast(2 THICK SLICES $12) also NEUSKES bacon (side).  ALL in ALL a perfect breakfast for 3 total was $55.00.  Plus we included a visit to ANCHOR STEAM BREWERY-just around the corner at DE HARO/MARIPOSA to buy some cold ones for the UBER ride home- hey we walked here c'mon)
author: Tim R.

description:
Every time I pass by, there's always a line. People are willing to wait more than an hour for a seat? Peaked my interest, but I don't have time for that. Seriously.

This time, we were lucky. Got parking, and got seated for two in less than 5 minutes. Had to get The Plow, which seemed to have a little bit of everything on the menu, and it was delicious! Had we waited more than 30 minutes for a table, my expectations would be higher. The crispy potatoes were a bit salty, but the ketchup saved it. The lemon ricotta pancakes were the best, and I, of course, saved it for last.

Right when we left, there were about 15 people waiting out the door for a seat.
author: Zell C.

description: We picked Plow as our restaurant excursion before heading into Outsidelands, they don't take reservations (at least not on weekends) and there is quite a wait to get a table since they don't have an abundance of seating.  I think we waited 2 hours but will say once we got in the food and service was great!   We'd had so much time to review the menu I think I changed my mind three times and someone ordered the Strawberry French Toast with Mascapone right before we got seated so I ordered that with a side of the Lemon Ricotta Pancake (infamous) and I was not disappointed!  While waiting we ordered Mimosas and enjoyed catching up.   The wait is long do be prepared.
author: Michele R.

description: We knew going in that we would have a long wait for breakfast, so we came prepared to stroll over to a coffee shop to grab some caffein and view the neighborhood.  When we were seated our server was friendly and efficient, and our meal came quickly.....and everyone ate way too much.  The lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing, and the fried egg sandwich is wonderful, but best of all was the bacon, and I don't eat bacon.  Everyone at our table raved about it so much that I gave it a try.  I'm so glad I did.  We also ordered the delicious biscuits to take home.  There was no way we were going to be able to eat them there.  The portions are very generous!
author: Marie C.

description:
Plow hostess: "Oh you think you might have 1 more person coming? (To a 3 person party) We can't seat you until they're here".

Scanning the room. It's 8:30 am on a weekday, there's only 6 other people in about a 20 person capacity room, nobody else waiting, and tables come in 2's and 4's.

Get over yourself Plow. You're not THAT good. In a town with 100s of excellent restaurants, good customer service and the ability to adapt to the situation is of greater value to me. 

Your rule makes sense on a weekend with a line out the door but is silly otherwise.
author: Christina A.

description: Potato is the beeeeesssttt I ever eat in my life. Although maybe need to wait one n half hour, but I think it won't let u disappointed even will back again n again.
author: Joyce C.

description:
Only three stars you ask?  Well 3 stars in my book means that a place was good but not extraordinary.  My wife and I went this past weekend and we had to wait for about an hour outside which wasn't ideal.  We thought the meal was going to be amazing though and like I said it was good.  

We sat at the counter and was able to see all of the goodness being made.  We started with the fried doughnut holes which were good but crispier than I thought they were going to be.  I had the plow and it was a lot of food but very good.  I got it with the housemade pork sausage which was delicious.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were very light and tasty and were probably the best thing I had.

The meal was good and place pretty cool but I think there are other breakfast places I'd rather wait an hour for.
author: Blake B.

description:
Simply amazing! I almost want to not write a review for this place because I don't want to see it get any more crowded than it already is, but I think they definitely deserve the accolades.

This is easily the best brunch that I've had so far in the city. I could definitely taste the quality of the ingredients in my fried egg sandwich. It just screamed "local, organic, Californian cuisine brunch". Their pancakes were the best I've ever had -- it was sweet with a hint of lemon flavor in their batter. The home made sausages were tasty, as well.

Definitely making a return trip here.. and another.. and another!
author: Kazu O.

description: We had the plow and the fired egg sandwich with a side of sausage. The food was really good, but be prepared for a wait. We got there at 8:30 and there was already a 45 minute wait.
author: Ragen C.

description:
I enrolled in a Sunday morning Plow class offered by the San Francisco Cooking School and had the wonderful experience of cooking several of Plow's menu items with the owners, Maxine and Joel. I have never been to their restaurant but after reading all the wonderful reviews I thought, "what a great opportunity!" 
 First and for most, the owners of Plow are incredibly nice people.  It's was very obvious while speaking with them that they have a love and passion for what they do: making delicious food, using fresh ingredients, and quality over quantity. 

The class made the following menu items: 
 Pecan streusel muffins
 Lemon ricotta pancakes (and for those who don't know, the ricotta is home made, not store bough...talk about fresh)
 Shirred eggs with tomato and gruyere
 Biscuits and gravy
 Quiche
 Chinese breakfast (caramelized pork shoulder with eggs over rice)
 Plow potatoes 
 Smoked trout salad

 Breakfast is my favorite meal; I love it all and was so impressed with the meal we made! The pork shoulder in the Chinese breakfast was mouthwatering. The tomato sauce for the shirred eggs...so fresh, a taste you would expect from an Italian restaurant. The savory sausage gravy over perfected buttermilk biscuits...amazing! And of course the lemon ricotta pancakes and the plow potatoes that I have read so much about were better than I expected. I am very picky about home fries/hash browns, and often find most restaurants just miss the mark, but Plow's technique of cooking their potatoes ensures every bite is full of flavor. 

I can not say enough about my breakfast experience!! I will soon make a trip to the city with my husband so he can experience the goodness of Plow.
author: Kristen T.

description: The wait was about 15 minutes for a table outside on Saturday at 9:30 am. I ordered the plow with chicken apple sausage. My favorite was, surprisingly, their potatoes. I devoured them. A tad too salty, but fried to absolute perfection. My lemon ricotta pancakes were also fluffy and delicious, with just enough lemon. Did not care for their chicken apple sausage though- only thing I didn't finish on my plate. My husband also enjoyed his ham eggs benedict.
author: Sophia B.

description: Fried Egg sandwich with bacon was deicious!! This place was packed even for brunch on a random Tuesday. Obviously this place has a following. The potatoes were delicious and you must get those with whatever you are ordering.
author: Celia T.

description: First off I want to say the food was amazing !! There was four of us and a toddler in a high chair. We did specifically ask to sit outside because we had a doggie with us too. The wait was 2 HOURS! (Minus One Star). then at the end we wanted to get a second round of drinks and finish our food , but the food was cleared without consent, before we were done ! Then when we asked for our second round of drinks they said yes , but we would have to enjoy them standing up and give up our table due to the wait, of maybe 3 parties.... So we declined on the next round. Such a bad ending to a great meal. Just expected they would give us time since we waited so long and patiently for a table .. Won't go back due to that . Disappointed
author: Hannah B.

description:
This is the best brunch spot I've been to in the city.

I have lived in Boulder, CO and grew up in the Midwest. It has the best of both worlds. I had "The Plow" which was exactly like a midwest breakfast but with the healthy, organic touch that I'm familiar with in Boulder.

My reviews are base on food.

Expect long waits 30min -1hr. They also didn't have a liquor menu incase you like drinks with your brunch. Definitely the first place brunch spot I'd take my friends when they are in town.
author: Justin H.

description:
Pretty good place to have brunch.  The inside of this place looks pretty nice, but just a bit small, which will result in a long wait.  We had to wait a little over an hour to be seat, but that's probably because we had a party of 7.  We were fine with it because it was a nice place to hang out, with a view of SF down the street.  We were seated outside, and I ordered The Plow, which included: 2 pancakes, 3 pieces of bacon, 2 eggs, and some potatoes.  In addition, I ordered some chicken sausages on the side.  The pancakes had this orange taste to it, which was interesting and pretty good compared to any pancake I've ever had, the bacon and eggs were standard, but the potatoes were cooked to perfection and I enjoyed every pieces even the crumbs of the potato skins.  The chicken sausages were pretty good, probably wouldn't get it next time thought, it's just typical sausages.  Honestly, for $15 for the The Plow alone, the portion was pretty small so I probably won't eat here again next time.

The long wait for a high priced small portion meal was disappointing.
author: Bryant D.

description: Really tasty and cute brunch spot. The wait can be painful (3 hours one time i went, 1 hour the other). If you live close by it works out well because you can just put your name down and come back later. The lemon ricotta pancakes are delicious. Also really liked the baked biscuit.
author: David M.

description: I have been in this area for months on business & I go to plow almost every weekend. Food is great as well as service. Always packed & can be long wait times but WELL worth the wait. A little on the spendy side but better to pay for great food then not so great. Lemon ricotta pancakes are the balm a must try.
author: Janna W.

description:
What a difference a couple years makes. I wrote a review of Plow a little over 3 years ago and after many more visits, I feel compelled to update my review. 

THE FOOD: Still good, sometimes great. I often find myself craving their lemon ricotta pancakes and when that happens, nothing else will do. They really are that good. And other dishes are reliably good in a way where you can't really go wrong. BUT...my husband and eating partner-in-crime pretty much always orders eggs benedict at Plow and at any other breakfast/brunch establishment. The past maybe 5-7 trips to Plow have resulted in unpredictably cooked eggs on this dish. About 50% of the time, one or both of the eggs in his eggs benedict have been overcooked and either partially or completely lack a runny yolk...total bummer for an eggs benedict lover. We began to sort of hold our breath as he'd cut into his eggs, not really knowing what to expect. Otherwise, the food has continued to be reliably good for the most part.

THE SERVICE: Sadly, it's the service that's prompted me to update my humble review. And let me say that I'm not taking to my computer after one negative experience like some crazy hothead. Being totally reasonable, I can appreciate Plow having an "off" day. It's only after this started to become the norm that I took notice. Here are a couple examples of recent experiences:

- Husband and I recently sat at the counter just on the other side of the glass from Maxine, the owner. We placed our typical huge order: coffee, orange juice, pastry of the day and cold-smoked salmon toast to share, lemon ricotta pancakes, and eggs benedict. (Told you - major fatties.) About 5 minutes after placing our order, we decided we wanted a side of bacon. So we asked our server if we could add this and were told it would be no problem. I mean, it's bacon, right? That should be pretty easy to toss in. So our food starts to come out and we dig in. First the pastry and salmon toast, then the pancakes and eggs benedict. No bacon in sight. We don't want to be jerks so we don't say anything just thinking that it'll show up soon. Well, fast forward to the end of our meal. We are to the point where our plates are empty and the server is asking us if she can clear them. We say Of Course! and also toss in that the bacon never arrived and that we don't need it at this point. Maxine overheard this and it immediately throws herself into our interaction by saying, "It's coming out right now" with what felt like a snippy tone. I sort of felt like we were in trouble but still managed to sheepishly say, "But we're all done with our food. I mean, our plates are being taken away," to which Maxine  curtly replied, "So you don't want it then?" Maybe it's just me but it's not fun going out to eat and then feeling getting scolded by the owner and being made to feel like you've done something wrong. Actually, we were sort of expecting an apology when she jumped into the conversation. When she first started to speak, what I was expecting was more of a "I'm so sorry! It looks like you guys are done eating. Do you still want the bacon even though it's late? Totally fine if you don't." 

- Last weekend we had some family in town and wanted to take them to Plow as we definitely enjoy the food. Knowing that a monster wait develops almost immediately, we got there at 7:30am to ensure we were the first people in line. As we stood there waiting, we all took turns studying the menu hanging on the front door planning what we were going to get. My husband, of course, was telling our family how he always gets the eggs benedict and that it's his favorite. So my mother decides she wants to try it too. The door opens at 8am and in we go. My mom orders first and requests the eggs benedict. The server quickly says, "I'm so sorry but the eggs benedict isn't available yet." And we're all crestfallen. Half of our party was planning to order eggs benedict and it's really the one breakfast thing my husband will eat. So my husband politely asks, "What does that mean - 'not ready'?" She says their hollandaise sauce isn't ready yet and that it should take about 30 minutes. So we ask for a few minutes to figure out our plan. We decide we've got plenty of time and decide to wait the 30 minutes with some extra smaller plates to start. When the server returns, we tell her we're going to wait for the eggs benedict but order a few smaller things in the meantime. She says, "I can't do that and have you hold the table that long." We go back and forth and then my husband asks why it takes so long to make hollandaise. He tells her it only takes a few minutes to do and that he doesn't understand. She says she doesn't know how it's made but she'll go ask and is clearly miffed with us. She returns quickly and says, "Okay, they'll do it. It's ready." But we definitely feel the brunt of her irritation and again feel like we're in the  Principal's office and have done something wrong. Major mood-killer and unnecessary.
author: Amy K.

description:
The first time I went to Plow the hostess told me, "There are 43 tables ahead of yours, but stay close, because you never know."

The second time I went to Plow I ate the food. It was fine.
author: J. R.

description:
I think this place is way over rated. The good is too fatty... The waiting staff deserve 6 stars for their kindness .. I have eaten there a couple of times with one of my friend who is a chef and I have good knowledge of food and prices from eating every where in the city & opening a café myself...The prices they charge are not worth it for the high calorie foods offered on the menu..
In the winter time it is so unbearably cold if you're seated close to the door.. 
In the business sense I hope they keep doing well but i wont be coming back..
author: Pedro D.

description: I love this place! Even if we have to wait each time about 20-30 minutes in line it's worth it!! The gluten free almond pancakes are bomb! Wish they could bring the blood sausage back or start having organ meats as an option on the menu! Great place, great ambiance, great location with plenty of parking! Oh, if you sit outside they provide you with a blanket!!
author: Kat J.

description:
Brunch was awesome.  Thought we came early (10am) but trust me, there's a bunch of others waiting before you.  Even though they said 1.5-2hours wait for the 5 of us, I think we only waited 45mins.  You have a choice of seating inside or outside...or both.  We just wanted to eat so when outdoor settings became available, we took it.  

If you sit outdoor, bring a blanket or a nice warm jacket, it's super cold. 
The plow was good but I like the egg Benedict with salmon/spinach shroom more.  
Their coffee is way better than the drip coffee half a block away.
author: Anna W.

description:
"Good, fresh food, but don't arrive on an empty stomach because you could wait for over one and a half hours for brunch."

Our party of three was seated for Sunday brunch at 12:05 after having given our names in at 10:30.  The line was consistently long the entire time we were in the neighborhood, so unless you come substantially earlier I don't think there's any avoiding the queue.  You can grab a coffee from them (a nice brew) while you're in line, but I would eat something before coming, anticipating that brunch could actually become lunch before you know it.

The food at Plow is very fresh and quite tasty.  I had the lemon ricotta pancakes, which were nice and syrupy, but not sickeningly sweet.  My friends had the soft egg scramble (smelled great) and the 9-grain muffin (toasted perfectly) with homemade peanut butter and honey, which were also both delicious.  The market fruit platter consists of a tiny portion of grapes and berries and a sliver of a mango for $6; the other items we ordered were on the pricey side but not unreasonable.

Overall, I think that eating at Plow could have been a  great experience, but, feeling faint and starving after the long wait, I devoured my food and didn't have a chance to enjoy the flavors or the ambiance.  If you have a scout who can get your name on the list early or want to wander around the pretty Potrero Hill neighborhood for a while on a lazy, sunny Sunday, Plow is a great place to eat.  But I wouldn't recommend taking it in on an empty stomach.
author: Vijay N.

description:
Plow slipped a little in this outing.  While the soft scrambled eggs were excellent, the sausage was too dry and i didn't finish it.  

This is a really crowded, relatively small place.  The hostess is really nice, however, and comes outside to find you when its your time to eat.  They'll set you up with coffee while you wait, as well.
author: Jack K.

description: I now understand the hype about Plow though the wait is ridiculous! We had a friend thankfully who lived nearby Plow so she put in our names two hours ahead of time for weekend brunch - we were a table of six. Otherwise I'm not sure if I would have waited that day - while Plow provides tea and coffee while you wait you are outside and it was drizzling that day so would have been miserable. The space is small and there is only one unisex bathroom behind a curtain. I ordered The Plow and couldn't help myself but to devour the entirety of it. The potatoes lived up to the hype and the lemon ricotta pancakes were a divine finish to the meal though the housemade pork sausage patties were probably my least favorite - they lacked salt or a kick in my opinion. Plus coffee is bottomless so caffeinate away! I'd love to try the breakfast sandwich next time or some other things - everything looked so delicious.
author: Teresa T.

description:
Eggs Benedict (ham option) Everything tasted fresh, the hollandaise was perfectly made, was not overpowering, and complemented the other items on the plate. Eggs were poached correctly, and english muffin was not dry or burnt. The accompaniment of home potatoes! I die.... best potatoes I've had in SF so far. small amount of herbs and perfect in texture. there was a crunch in the beginning, followed by a burst of flavor, with a smooth potato center to finnish off the bite.

Cherry Scone: its more than 3 bucks, but worth it. It is accompanied by some fresh lemon curd. which was again, made to perfection. Scone was moist and crumbly and flavorful. Im a total lemon curd lover, so i asked for a bit more and was not denied my request. :)

lemon ricota pancakes: I was a little miffed when I had these bad boys, they were lacking in flavor. A little on the dull side and dry/ doughy. (hence -1 star)

You will be waiting a long time in the middle of brunch hours. (party of 2=one hour) 

Clean restrooms.

Amazing: knowledgable staff. Prompt service too. :)
author: Art N.

description: Rating based on service and originality. French toast sucked, ive had better. It was more cheesy and soggy than others that ive had, if they have alternative sweet brunch, i would probably consider it! And the french toast lacked something else? I never typically use syrup but I did this time around!
author: Alaric S.

description:
I found this place from Yelp.. and I am so happy I did. 

Here is a quick run down: 

We  went for an early breakfast and were quickly seated.

The coffee was excellent.

The service was amazing. 

The egg sandwich is an absolute MUST. I got mine with bacon and avocado... and it was runny and juicy and delicious. 

The potatoes it came with I would eat daily if I could... crispy, not greasy and with the right amount of salt.

all in all... i was a very happy girl.
author: Lollie S.

description: Very worth the potential 90 minute wait. The crispy potatoes are incredible. You're doing yourself an injustice if you don't get them: crispy, salty rosemary goodness. I also love the almond flour pancakes. I recommend going an hour earlier than you'd like to eat to put your name on the list and walk around the neighborhood to check out it's gorgeous views. The counter seats are your best opportunities to see the real stars of Plow at work!
author: Ashly O.

description:
If it weren't for the one hour and fifteen minute wait before being seated, I would rate this place five stars. I had their signature brunch item,  "the plow." I loved the crispy potatoes, and the chicken apple sausage was also tasty.  I ordered my eggs scrambled, and wasn't too satisfied - while they were certainly well-cooked,  they were rather bland and tasteless. 

The highlight of the meal was certainly the lemon ricotta pancakes, which I advise you save for last! They were just the right size, moist, and flavorful. The maple syrup is also fantastic. 

I'd probably return, but I'd make sure to get there right when it opens at 8 am to get a seat immediately.
author: Crystal J.

description:
The girls were in the area for some jewelry repair and needed to get lunch so we decided to make it an adventure.  The hostess was incredibly sweet and rather than the attitude you get at a lot of places with a big following she told us she'd seat us asap since we had little ones in tow.

I had the "Plow" which has the works:  eggs, bacon, potatoes and the famed lemon ricotta pancakes.  Every component was awesome and cooked to perfection.  The potatoes were seriously amazingly crisp and savory.  

Our server was really sweet and efficient.  This is definitely a kid-friendly place...they have a kid's menu and crayons that kept the girls occupied.  Parking is also easy and free.  

Can't wait to bring the males back to try it out :)
author: Chris K.

description:
Cute brunch place with delicious food!

what my friends and I ordered: 

the plow (two eggs (any style), crispy potatoes, bacon or chicken-apple sausage, two (smaller than the full-plate option) lemon ricotta pancakes: amazing combination! I get a little bit of everything which is perfect. the lemon ricotta pancakes were good but I had a bite of my friend's almond pancakes and those were AMAZING (just the perfect hint of almond flavor- not overbearing but lingers in your mouth long enough for you to crave more!)

I highly recommend going on a weekday. my friends and i arrived on a friday morning around 9:30am and waited ~20 minutes for seats in front of the restaurant (longer wait if you want to sit inside). 

you should definitely check this place out if you like brunch and you're willing to wait!
author: Patricia K.

description: The wait is long, but food soooo worth it, get the plow a little bit of everything and soo good and the lemon ricotta pancakes were BomB!
author: jonathan g.

description: Worth the wait, bring a deck of cards or something to keep you busy! The waiting area is also stocked with blankets so it's not too horrible...and the food is absolutely amazing!
author: Hannah M.

description:
There's always a line. The restaurant has about 15 tables or so, some inside, some outside. The outside ones have a view of the skyline.

GOOD:
Friendly service. Coffee cup is always full. Their breakfast menu items are your typical american breakfasts but raised up a notch. Ordered the Egg Sandwich w/ Bacon. Potatoes were extremely delicious.

BAD:
At 9a on Saturday, still waited 45mins. But this means people like this place. Breakfast is about $13/entree.

FAV:
Potatoes
Anything Bacon.

1-star: I've had hemorrhoids more pleasant than this. 
2-star: I would rather avoid this place. 
3-star: On par with other similar establishments. 
4-star: Will return as often as possible. 
5-star: I refuse to find a better place.
author: Caleb F.

description:
wow got here before 9am and the wait is an hour and a half? are you kidding me? luckily my friend lived close by and so we ran some errands and came back just in time for our name to be called. we ordered: 
- soft scrambled eggs - this dish sounds so normal but is so good. i'll take it over normal scrambled eggs any day 
- the plow - eggs, bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes - everything on this dish was amazing! pancakes i normally don't like but these ones were amazing. i even wished they were bigger. and the potatoes - so crispy and yum!
- smoked salmon toast - it was good cause i love smoked salmon but wasn't anything special, if you have to chose the first two are better. 
i just wish they had bloody mary's on the menu. but i guess i'll settle for a mimosa ;) not sure if i would come often since the wait is soo long but if the occasion calls for it, i would. the food IS good!
author: Jen S.

description:
Any place with an oinker (pig sign) at the door is A-ok with me!

I came here for brunch about a week ago.  It was my first time and my friend told me to prepare for a wait because it's a small restaurant (very nice decor).  This much is true.  Lucky for us, it was a perfect SF day (and there is a store across the street where you can buy some, ahem, adult bevos to consume while you wait).

As for food, thumbs up.  We ordered the doughnut holes as an appetizer (perfect couple of bites of freshly fried dough with powered sugar dusted on top to prep me for the main dish).  I ordered the duck hash.  It was excellent!  The hash consisted of sweet potatoes which was a nice change to a traditional hash.  It was the perfect sized portion; i was full, but didn't feel as tough I over did it.  I would like to come back to try other brunch dishes.
author: Ann N.

description:
We noticed this place with a long line at 11-ish on a rainy Saturday a few weeks ago when we went to Chez Papa Bistro and we were wondering what the big deal is.  The menu describes pretty commonplace American fare (didnt pay attention to the credits to the local farms and suppliers).

So on this sunny-yet-freezing morning we decided to join the crowd and put our names on the waiting list.  1 hour wait....hmmm... if it werent so
nice out there and we had all the time to spare I would have suggested we go elsewhere.

An hour later we returned and found that there were just a few parties ahead of us.  Got seated @ the counter where we can get a glimpse of the action and we were greeted by our super-model-like-drop-dead-gorgeous and super-friendly waitress Ashley.  Ashley gave us the right touch of attention and YES she wrote down exactly the way we liked our dishes done (Joel and Maxine give her a raise please!).

What?  No cappuccino machine?  Never mind,  drip coffee with milk will do.  The food definitely did not disappoint.
We had a scramble with chicken apple sausage, a citrus beet salad with feta cheese, and a biscuit.  Eggs were fluffy and NOT salty (as with most places).  The crispy potatoes were evil.

Price is very fair for the location, decor, and most importantly the quality of food.  Yes, the freshness of each ingredient does come through.

Clientele is full of yuppies and hipsters.  Yes even VCs have to wait in line ( yes! I saw you!  hope you are reading this).

We'll be back!
