author: avalon e.

description:
Every time I visit SF, my sister brings me to a "must try" place. This past weekend she brought me here for breakfast. We got around the area around 8:30 am and parking was easy to find and best of all no wait to get seated. My sister did warn me on the weekend, however, the wait can be over an hour so I am glad we were there on a Friday. 

They have great options on their menu but I had my sister decide what to get. We decided on The Plow and the Fried egg sandwich. The Plow comes with two eggs, crispy potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes and a choice of meat. We chose the plate with chicken apple sausage. 

Both plates were delicious. The freshness in the ingredients were there. The Plow is a great option if you want a hearty breakfast. The lemon ricotta pancakes are fluffy, although i usually don't opt for anything lemon-y, these were really good and I did eat it all. The eggs were perfectly cooked to my liking. I really wish I can mimic their crispy potatoes because they are the BEST breakfast potatoes I ever eaten; it is extra crispy on the outside, but not at all over cooked on the inside. The chicken apple sausage was yummy too. Everything on the plate complimented well with one another. The fried egg sandwich has frisee, cheese and two friend eggs between a soft warm bun. I don't really like frisee but it really worked well with the cheese and the saltiness of the egg. The sandwich also comes with crispy potatoes. 

Service was friendly and quick. It is very cozy in there...just the way I like it in this type of places especially in the Bay. Can't wait to return.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
I felt a little guilty eating brunch at this cute, neighborhood restaurant. We sat outside among the passing joggers and even the table next to us had just finished a morning run. We had just rolled out of bed and wanted to gorge on a delicious brunch! 

And Plow delivered. The lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing. I don't usually order pancakes, but these had a great texture and tasted amazing! They're perhaps on the sweet side when you add the syrup, but sinfully good. I also tried the chicken tinga and I loved the sauce tomato chipotle sauce. This plate was light and refreshing, but packed a punch of flavor. The only falter was the bacon. I loved the taste but it arrived luke warm and SO greasy (see pic). Even the plate it came on was splattered in grease. I loved our server though - she was very friendly and kept the coffee coming!
author: Vicente G.

description: I was not a huge fan of this place.  It was okay, but not worth waiting 2 hours to sit at a 4 top table with another couple we did not know.  The food was good - not great. Maybe I set my expectations too high or did not order the right thing (even though I did try a lemon ricotta pancake).  I say go if you know there wont be a wait, otherwise choose somewhere else.
author: Danielle S.

description:
Lemon. Ricotta. Pancakes.

Light, fluffy and almost cake-like, Plow's ingenius twist on this familiar breakfast item makes the trip (and the wait) worth it. 

Tucked away into the Potrero hillside overlooking the city, Plow is just so freakin' charming. On any given weekend, you'll find a small crowd of people waiting for their name to be called, gathered near the dog-toting brunchers and young couples taking residence on their streetside tables. get there by 2pm, get your name on the list and be prepared for a bit of a wait.

My sister and I snagged a couple of seats at the bar. Mimosa for me, lemonade for her. We split the crab scramble and the lemon ricotta pancakes with light and crispy house potatoes. The crab was a bit grey-looking and lacked flavor, but I'm certain it's not reflective of the overall menu because everything else was fantastic. And our server was sweet and prompt. I would definitely go back to try other items on the menu.
author: Mariela D.

description:
I walked up a series of really, really steep hills to get to Plow. But it was absolutely worth it. I had the most deliciously greasy fried egg sandwich, and my dining partner had the amazing lemon ricotta pancakes. I also really enjoyed the breakfast potatoes. Their not-so-secret ingredient in those seemed to be thyme. In my opinion, they were dangerously close to having too much thyme, but I love thyme so that didn't bother me.

The space is cute and unique. All around, one of my favorite brunch spots in San Francisco.
author: Mike S.

description: Its decadence and home style feel,gives this breakfast spot a trip worth making.The eggs were moist and cooked perfect,the pancakes fluffy and moist with a hint of lemon.Bacon bar none.Visit when in San Fran
author: Casey K.

description:
I'll start off saying, I am probably slightly biased because 1. I LOVE brunch and 2. I live in potrero hill. This place often has up to or over a 2 hour wait for weekend brunch, so for me I can out my name in, go home and get ready then come back to eat. The great thing is, they let you come back after your name was called and move to the top of the list (supporting locals basically-which is great!!).
On to the food-delicious. Though they don't always have them the sausage patties with the biscuits are a great starter. The crispy potatoes-wow (so perfectly cooked and seasoned-live up to the hype). The eggs Benedict is not by any means the best I've had-but it is delicious! To finish it off with a sweetness he lemon ricotta pancakes are also amazing (though I will say for all the hype they got, I've had just as good of lemon ricotta pancakes other places.)
For a brunch day with the girls-I would certainly wait, grab a coffee down the street at Farleys and hang out with the crowd in sunny potrero!!
author: Sarah F.

description:
Those damn lemon ricotta pancakes are TO. DIE. FOR.

Currently in my kitchen coming up with my own recipe for them...would love to eat them for lunch and dinner too!

Gotta order these if you come here!!!
author: Alex T.

description:
OMG I love this place!! Get there right away when they open to get a table! 

We went in mid June when we visited the city. 

I ordered the lemon ricotta pancakes. They are crave-worthy. If I lived in the city again, we would be going here at least twice a month for them.

My husband ordered the breakfast sandwich. It was delicious and the potatoes were perfect. My daughter had the kids eggs, sausage, and potatoes and ate more than she normally does at any given meal time.

I'll be visiting again next time I'm in town!
author: Katie D.

description:
Although I moved to the neighborhood about 9 months ago, I hadn't yet tried this place because the wait is JUST. SO. LONG.  

Today I thought I would pop in by myself for a late lunch at the counter, and ohmygod now I understand. 

In the interest of tasting as many items as possible - I got the Plow breakfast, with lemon ricotta pancakes, pork sausage, scrambled eggs, and their revered crispy potatoes. 

This might be the most perfect breakfast I have ever eaten. Thank you Plow for MAKING MY DAY!

The eggs were a totally even and perfect soft scramble.  The housemade pork sausage with fennel flavor was legit.  The potatoes were chunky and smashed to deliver extra crispy surface area with a soft center ... and the most intoxicating aroma of rosemary.  And the lemon ricotta pancakes were just a hint of sweet which I really appreciate. 

All of this deliciousness, delivered with smiling and thoughtful service.  

I can't wait to go back! (except, ahem, I will have to...)
author: Allison V.

description: Top three favorite brunch spots in SF! I usually get the Plow with ricotta pancakes and house made sausage, or the breakfast sandwich. All of the food looks amazing and is simply delicious. Warning the wait is 1-1.5 hours, so just put you name on the list and walk around the cute neighborhood.
author: Jordana C.

description: Put our name down for a table of four at 11:15 on a Saturday, went to the gym for an hour, came back and got seated at 12:30. Prepare for a wait, but it's WORTH it. I got the breakfast sandwich with bacon and it was amazingggg...as are the crispy potatoes and lemon ricotta pancakes. This place is the bomb.
author: Erica L.

description:
I've eaten at Plow a few times and the food is lovely. The breakfast potatoes are perfect, and love that they have a gluten free option for pancakes. I have no complaints about the food however, my last experience there with the service was dissappointing.

 I've worked in the service industry for 9 years, I've been a host, busser, runner, expo, server, manager - you name it. A few Sunday's ago I was meeting a friend for brunch. I put my name in with the host and went to Farley's for it was to be about an hour and a half wait. When I came back they called my name and I was seated, my friend was taking the bus and would be arriving shortly. A few minutes go by and one of the hosts comes by and asks me where the rest of my party is, I let her know that she'll be arriving shortly. She goes and talks to the other host and comes back and tells me that they don't seat people until all their party has arrived but since it was "their mistake" they would "let [me] stay and get [me] some water." It was super awkward and uncomfortable. 

My most recent job was as a host and I'm sure I've gotten a bad yelp review maybe for not smiling enough. You probably shouldn't go up to a partially seated table and say this - this is something you ask before you seat the party. I had mixed feelings about writing this review, it was Sunday brunch and I get what that feels like. I've worked Sunday brunch for at least the past year - it effing blows, it really does. I understand people who work in service are human beings (duh) and deserve the same respect any person working any job deserves. I get how stressful and shitty brunch shifts and hungover 20-30-somethings demanding more alcohol can be, and I also get how much working as a host totally sucks. This experience totally sucked. The food is excellent, the runner/busser who looked like he loved his job and loved the music (EnVogue Pandora) was great, the servers are fine, but this interaction with the host was pretty bad. I'll come back because the food, music, and most of the staff rocks but I hope my next experience isn't so uncomfortable.
author: Kati K.

description:
The brunch we had was amazing! We went here for my husband's birthday brunch. The wait was long (which is to expected for any brunch spot with 600+ reviews), but the wait was totally worth it. One great thing is that there are multiple options for vegetarians, and all sounded delicious. Another huge bonus for us was the gluten-free pancakes, since my husband is allergic to wheat. He hasn't had pancakes in years, and these were not just wheat-free... they were wheat-free and delicious! 

My one star deduction is due to 2 things:

1. The uncomfortable seating. I found the chairs to be incredibly uncomfortable, and it's a little disheartening to be eating something so delicious, but not be fully enjoying it because you are uncomfortable. 

2. It is not fully accessible to people in wheelchairs. Everyone should be able to eat here with ease, and it's always unfortunate when planning does not take this into consideration, or make it a priority.
author: Eileen N.

description:
This place serves one of the best brunches I have had anywhere. It can be a bit of a wait but it is more than worth it. The portions are large but not crazy. The service is very friendly and the open kitchen is fun to watch. 

It's a bit of hike to get here but that makes it all the more worthwhile!
author: Liam S.

description:
Probably the best almond gluten free pancakes in the city. Bacon was perfection and potatoes were amazing. 

We waited 90 minutes on a Sunday morning...totally worth it, but be prepared. I have a toddler and they were very accommodating to seating him. He ate everything we put in front of him, which says a lot about how tasty this place is.
author: Jolene B.

description:
BEST PANCAKES I HAVE HAD IN MY LIFE

BEST PANCAKES I HAVE HAD IN MY LIFE

BEST PANCAKES I HAVE HAD IN MY LIFE

I mean really, there's not much else to say. The lemon-ricotta pancakes are insanely, insanely delicious and are worth the wait to get a table.

Arrive early so you don't have to wait for a table - they open at 8, get there at least 15 minutes early to stand in line, and you'll get seated immediately. 

I wish I was eating the pancakes again, right now :|
author: Kim C.

description:
Had to wait like 20 minutes on a random Friday lunch. Don't people work around here?

Anyway, we were seated outdoors, balancing on the sloping sidewalk, but it was nice out so we could watch the 22 MUNI roll on by.

Hubs got the Plow ($15) plate which comes with 2 eggs, meat of your choice (i.e. bacon, apple chicken sausage, etc), 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes.

I ordered the Fried Egg Sandwich ($11), 2 eggs over easy so that yolk is still runny, with a slice of cheese, frisee greens in a soft bun. Side of potatoes too. My sandwich was on the bland side, since I didn't add bacon (+$2). Even avocados would have been an add on. Too bad. I think they should just offer it on for more texture and taste. But I sprinkled some hot sauce and ketchup and that helped. 

The potatoes were really the stand out though. They must use a blend of small potatoes and sweet ones, with skin on and deep fried, then tossed in seasoning. Very savory and flavorful. First time I polished off my potatoes since I'm not a big potato starch fan.

The lemon ricotta pancakes were delish too. Thicker and more dense, the light lemon flavor was a nice surprise. And with a dab or two of maple syrup, it was great. Just wished the pancakes were bigger. These were about the size of a woman's palm. Could have easily had 1 more on the plate. 

Overall, cute place, with food done well.
author: Cindy W.

description:
As everyone knows, the wait is long. Few places are worth it, but I gave it a try. 

Lemon ricotta pancakes are impressive. While you wait, they serve coffee! WIN. I sat at the bar and witnessed the kitchen working- it was ran like a well oiled machine. The food is cooked well and quite delicious.
author: Coco C.

description:
THE best breakfast of my life. I got "The Plow" with house made pork sausages and poached eggs. Boyfriend got corned beef hash (the best he has ever had). Amazing breakfast potatoes, crispy and ton of fresh herbs. For the quantity and QUALITY of ingredients, it is totally well priced. The wait staff were wonderful and recommended we get a Bloody Mary down the street that def put hair on our chest. 

This is the kind of spot that I will take out of town guests and/or recommend to others.
author: Adele A.

description:
Hubby took us here for Mom's Day.  Arriving at 9AM, the wait was 1.5 hrs.  So, we idled our time away, waiting... just like all the other folks.
This time, Hubby tried The Plow,$15 and refllls of coffee, $3.50.  He especially liked te homemade sausage patties. lemon ricotta pancakes and fried chunks of potatoes, seasoned with herb, salt/pepper.
I ordered the Dungeness crab scramble, $17.  Didn't like the scramble so much even 'tho it had chunks of crab in it with sliced asparagus.  The 2 sm slices of Acme bread, fried potatoes were the best part of the breakfast.
My Arnold Palmer, $3.75 was so sour.  I had to add 2 spoons of sugar to it.  Wouldn't order either one again.
Jr. Yelper had a glass of OJ, $3.75 and corned beef hash, $15.  Shredded pieces of corned beef with potatoes, 2 slices of bread which were good.

If you have time to kill and wait 1-1.5hrs for a table, I'd vote to have the lemon ricotta pancakes, fried potatoes.  Will have to try to come back on a weekday to try the Chinese breakfast which isn't served on weekends.
author: Ry T.

description:
Even though its a tiny place with a ginourmous wait time and you have to walk up the hill to get to it, Plow is worth it. I went for Saturday brunch with a friend, and I believe our wait was an hour so (arrived at 11am). We grabbed coffee and walked around to kill time. We were then seated with another party at a table for 4 -- because the place is so small, they maximize it in whatever way they can. Seating at the bar, seating different parties together, and super fast turnaround. 

The food itself was all that a brunch is supposed to be. The fried egg sandwich reminded me of my Southern childhood somehow. Next time, I'd like to try the signature Plow dish. 

The interior boasts beautiful hardwood floors and big open windows and high ceilings. It will get loud though because it's small -- something to keep in mind if you're sensitive to crowds.

The space feels very nouveau American with dishes to match. It lives up to the hype.
author: Nene K.

description: I have been coming here for years. Food is always delicious and never disappoints. "The Plow" is always great, be sure to get the bacon and order a side of the sausage. Almond pancakes are amazing. Some of the best pancakes I have ever had - Gluten free people will rejoice. Don't be frightened by the long wait, well worth it. Go to Farley's and grab some coffee and enjoy the unique and amazing view of San Francisco.
author: Mark H.

description: This food was amazing. The biscuit was great, and the lemon ricotta pancakes. Wow. I got the pork sausage which was very tasty and had a lot of flavor. And their potatoes are very crisp.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Man this place is so good, I get sad when I want some brunch but I can't eat here.

The softshell crab sandwich was the best I've ever had in my life!!!  Everything here was freaking tasty.  My wife especially loved the ricotta pancakes.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Steven H.

description:
The best breakfast I have had in SF for a number of years!  
5 stars based on food and service 
2 stars based on wait time

Be prepared for a wait before seating!  We went on a weekday, and even then there was a 10 minute wait for seats at the bar.   If you go on a weekend, be prepared for a much longer wait!

We ordered The Plow which offers a variety of house favorites - eggs, sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes - and watched from the bar as our food was prepared.  The kitchen was clean, efficient, and smelled wonderful.  
Food arrived quickly, everything was perfectly prepared, and the meal was out of this world.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were especially amazing.

If you have the time, definitely a must visit!
author: Kim R.

description:
It takes great effort for me to come here, as I don't live in San Francisco any more, and I'm 45min away in the burbs... I finally made it on a Wednesday at around 1pm, which I still had to wait. It's a very small place.

I ordered the plow (eggs, bacon, potatoes with 2 lemon ricotta pancakes) and everything was yummy, except for the pancakes which I had actually come here for. With all the hype and raves, I was ready to devour it all and plead for the recipe. However, they were too doughy for my taste. It tasted gritty, like oats or some kind of mealy grain. Needless to say, I left them half eaten. 

But the potatoes were the best! crispy all around and so flavorful. Don't know what/how they make them but you've got to try these. and I'm not even a potato fan.

Service was attentive. 

Parking is difficult around the crowded neighborhood. 

May return another day to try other breakfast items.
author: Lil D.

description: Long wait (1 hour 45 min) for just average overpriced food. Never again. Ricotta pancake and smoked salmon toast were just average. You can get better food elsewhere.
author: Marco F.

description:
Hooray for another San Franciscan brunch place! Really enjoyed the ambiance and the location of the restaurant. 

We ordered "the plow" which came with eggs, sausages, fried potato (their version of home fries) and lemon ricotta pancakes.  The eggs and sausage were fine, the usual.  The fried potato was nice and crispy but a bit salty.  The pancakes were definitely good, but i feel it can only be appreciated by lemon enthusiasts.

We also ordered the French toast.  A lot different from other brunch places due to the unique bread.  Bread was thick but had a lot of holes inside but that was good cause it kept the syrup inside.  It was garnished with apricots which are always good.

Overall a good brunch spot and a welcome addition to the SF area.
author: Joyce L.

description:
This place is popular. My girlfriend and I arrived for brunch and there was about a 30 minute wait. Once seated, it was easy because we had 3 dogs with us and we were able to sit outside. 

Service was good, our server was upbeat and fun. It was pretty busy, so our water refills were a bit slow, but other than it was good. Our server told us about the homemade dog treats create by the chef and brought some out for the pups. 

The food was totally yummy. We ordered the Eggs Benedict, the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes with crispy potatoes, eggs, bacon and sausage. 

The hollandaise received my approval, but I wasn't that impressed with the ham. 

The crispy potatoes were addictive, and are best described and breakfast-french-fries. Perfect with the over-medium eggs. 

The pancakes were so delicious, again, I'm not a big fan on pancakes but they were light and really really good. 

The bacon was the BEST part of the meal, when we told our server she actually let us know that the owner is from Wisconsin and the Nueske bacon is smoked bacon from their home-state. 

The breakfast sausage was also really good and fennel-y. 

We will be back for more and more and more.
author: Meredith S.

description:
One hour wait later...happy tummies!

We sat outside since I brought my little Peanut along (this place is dog friendly).  Everyone in my crew ordered the "plow" so we can sample a bit of everything - 2 eggs, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, sausages (or bacon), and potatoes.  It did not disappoint.  The eggs over easy were definitely on the "easy" side.  Next time I'll know to ask for eggs over medium instead.  We tried the lemon ricotta and almond flour pancakes and both were absolutely delish!  Potatoes were seasoned and done just right!

I will definitely be coming back!  (Another plus is the plentiful parking!)
author: Jennifer I.

description: I'm giving this place 4 stars because the food was divine especially the lemon ricotta pancakes. However, Angelica, our server was a complete sarcastic bitch. We waited almost 3 hours because the place is pretty small and there were a lot of people so be prepared to write your name down and get coffee somewhere else (Farleys is right next door and is really cute) or go shopping.
author: Page F.

description: Urghmagawd the lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes were amazing. The eggs were delicious, as was the apple chicken sausage. The only complaints I had were that it had a large line and the coffee was kinda mediocre.
author: Sean W.

description:
We showed up close to Noon.  They told us it was a 90 min wait, but it only took abot an hour.  
Once we got a seat, the staff was super friendly and fast to our table.  I got "The Plow" and my wife got a fried egg sandwich.  After an awesome and filling brunch, and a mimosa a piece, we headed back home.   I'm writing this review upon waking up from my post-brunch nap.
Pro's - Food is fantastic.  My lemon ricotta pancakes were perfectly done, the crispy potatoes were wonderous and the homemade sausage was flavorful.  The staff is friendly and the vibe is upbeat.  
Cons - It's a small place and you'll sit close to your neighbor (we were ok with this).  And this spot is not a secret so expect a wait.
author: Justin W.

description:
So I think Plow is definitely a solid 4 but nothing more than that. Which was a bit of a let down for me because I had heard SO much about this place -- even some of my foodie friends calling it their favorite brunch in the city. I was hesitant on going there on a weekend because I knew the wait would be crazy but my friend who was visiting me had a car and down to drive us and was adamant on trying a new place which was perfect for me since Plow had been on my bucket list for so long. 

We got there and were greeted with a FAT line out the door. The host told us the wait for 2 was easily an hour. Expecting that, we put our names down and headed around the neighborhood to scope it out while we waited (and Potrero Hill is very cute I might add). We came back exactly an hour later and were seated inside. The spot is super cute but it's also very small which totally explains why the wait is always so long. We both already knew we wanted the Plow (little bit of everything!) and got the buttered bread and homemade preserves as a starter. The bread was definitely tasty but the jam was honestly nothing mind blowing (it was mixed berry). Also it was a super small portion so each of us got only 2 tiny baguette pieces. I guess it's meant to be only for one. 

Anyways, another good thing was that the food came out relatively fast. Here's my breakdown on each of the parts of the dish:
- Eggs: MIND blowing for SURE. You could tell in an instant that these eggs were farm fresh and organic. I loved them.
- Chicken apple sausage: Very average IMO. The nice thing was that they got our dishes mixed up and actually brought both of us bacon but when we told them they brought us five sausages each -- which was more than enough!
- Bacon: Super average. Sweet Maple's is 100X better.
- Country potatoes: Definitely good but I thought they were a little too fried. They could have been just regular potatoes and still been just as good without being overly crispy. But I still enjoyed!
- Pancakes: Good too but I was super sad to realize they didn't blow my mind. Now just a disclaimer -- if you like anything lemony then you will LOVE this -- because the texture is bomb, the portion is perfect, and the consistency is great (not too dry, not too soppy). But sadly I'm just really not a lemon person (never been into any lemony desserts either), but I LOVE my pancakes. So I enjoyed these but I wasn't blown away. My friend on the other hand loved them. I also should have known I probably wouldn't be obsessed, but my friends had told you could barely taste the lemon (which is not true). 

All in all, excellent dining experience, ambiance, and service. You could tell the food was fresh too -- but I just wasn't blown away which is what I expected from a place with Plow's reputation. Not to say that's bad, I think a solid 4 is awesome, but I'm always in search of a 5 for brunching because I'm such a tough critic with it. (Olea still has my heart at #1). But I definitely loved my meal at Plow and do not regret going for 1 second!
author: Naseem K.

description:
I was surprised with their take on classic American. Yes, pleasantly.

Had:
Crispy potatoes (double-fried?)
Biscuits & gravy
Lemon ricotta pancakes
Bacon
author: James G.

description:
I have been to Plow before with friends and, sure, the wait was long but we were prepared for it. I remembered loving their crispy potatoes and savoring our brunch. I was dying to take my potato-loving boyfriend to Plow to introduce him to the delights of their breakfast potatoes. 

Alas, every time we've tried to go for the last year and half, it has been an hour+ wait. Boyfriend is not one to wait around. We usually end up somewhere nearby and have explored many delicious restaurant alternatives as a result (a plus after all?). Well, we finally got our opportunity over a recent ridiculously rainy weekend. It was a downpour. My boyfriend woke me up at 7am on a Sunday and said, "Plow opens at 8! Let's go today. It's our best chance." Look at the things we do for love!

We went (though I dragged my feet getting out of bed) and arrived around 8:30. The wait was going to be between 1 to 1.5 hours. (!!!!!) WTF?!? We decided to wait. I banked on the fact that everyone who put their names down ahead of us likely didn't want to wait around in the rain. As luck would have it, we were seated after about 30 minutes. We ordered quickly -- two coffees, two dungeness crab scrambles, one side order of lemon ricotta pancakes, please! 

And then we waited for an hour. We watched all the people around us get their food and begin eating. Our server came over to explain there had been a snafu in the kitchen and our food was just being fired. No apologies. No offer of something to put in our stomachs in the meantime to offset the three cups of coffee we had been drinking during the wait. We watched the people who were seated after us finish and pay their bill before our meals arrived. And then when it did arrive, it was fine... fine as in mediocre, not fine as in "all is right in the world." Our scrambles were pretty salty and we got one tiny pancake to split... perhaps we could have asked for more info on what the "side" of pancakes consisted of.

When we got our tab, we still got no apologies, nothing comped off of our bill, and no fulfillment from our experience. After a year and half of trying to return to Plow, it was a bust in the end. We left with a sour taste in our mouths and confusion as to why so many people keep coming back and waiting that long. Chez Maman is a half block away and has a lovely brunch. You'll find us there.
author: Kelly N.

description:
You MUST get The Plow. You'll thank me later.

It comes with lemon ricotta cheese pancakes, eggs, sausage and potatoes. It's AMAZING.
author: P. L.

description: This place is ok kid of experience and there is a wait because it's a small place. I loved the banana cake bread . Everything else is ok
author: Victorious R.

description:
I told myself that I would only review restaurants I've visited at least twice, but I think I liked it enough not to wait... aaaand San Francisco is far-ish :(

One of my friends took me here for a weekend brunch so we could catch up. We got there at about 12:40 (I got to the city 30 minutes late and my friend got lost on the way there. You live in SF and you've been there countless times before, HOW DO YOU GET LOST??) when it was packed, giving us a 45-60 minute wait. I didn't mind at all; I'm a really patient person and we ended up spending that time in a nearby bookstore anyway. We got back and opted to eat outside on a beautiful day in the city. It was kind of awkward eating on a slanted plane, but it wasn't terribly uncomfortable. And the pigeons walking around the tables got a little bothersome (but not in an annoying way, if that makes sense), but that's also a risk you take sitting outside. And the blankets they had available were a nice touch in case it got chilly. Okay, none of y'all want to hear about this, let's talk food!

Generally I like to try what a place is known for on the first visit, which would thus be the Plow, but my friend decided to order one herself and offered to have me try some of her lemon ricotta pancakes. I easily obliged and chose a brunch favorite of mine anywhere: eggs benedict with ham. First of all, I loved my eggs benedict. Not too much hollandaise sauce and the english muffins were quite big, and quite deliciously fluffy. Also: I love eggs. Good choice, me. I also had a little bit of my friends' pancakes. It was then in that moment of that first bite when I promised myself I'd be back to have a whole plate of it for myself. Oh, and I can't forget:

Them crispy potatoes, tho.

I'd come back just for them, TBH. Furthermore, our waitress was super nice (and super cute) and, oh, they have Tapatio. I already liked this place from first impression, but honestly they had me at Tapatio. The coffee was decent, though I'd love to try their cold brew some time. It wasn't quite warm enough that day for it. WELP I guess that's another reason to come back huh?

Anyway, to sum up, there really wasn't anything from my experience that would deserve to have a star docked off, so 5 it is! I'll be back, it's just a matter of when at this point. Thanks!
author: Allen Mark A.

description:
Best breakie EVER! Though not cheap, the quality was the highest standards possible-
& portions were huge- so much I had to take 1/2 home w/ me. I had the breakfast sandwich w/ added avocado & bacon, my husband had the pork chop, & our 2 dining companions has the 'plow' breakfast- which included the ricotta pancake that I got to enjoy.  The only think negative was the hour wait (expected on a saturday morning @ 0900. oh & i don't recall there being champers avail ;)  all in all I can't wait to go back!
author: D B.

description: This is a wonderful quaint restaurant. The staff was very helpful and catered to me and my baby like champs!!!! The food is all locally sourced and absolutely delicious!!!! I would come back again in a heartbeat. I was visiting with an old friend and the servers didn't rush us and we were able to have a really nice brunch together. Well done!
author: Scruffy B.

description: Breakfast sandwich was pretty good. Lemon Ricotta pancakes were half way cooked. Meh.
author: Jess C.

description:
We came last week when it was sprinkling (more like misting).  No other groups wanted outside tables, so we bypassed the TWO HOUR wait and endured a little chilly drizzle over hot coffee and good food -- the smarter choice in my opinion!  Good brunch -- but really glad we didn't wait TWO HOURS.  Ambrosia from the gods would not be worth that much of my time...

I ordered the Plow ($15) -- good way to sample what they they do best.  Fresh eggs, 3 small chicken apple sausages, boatload of crispy potatoes, and 2 small lemon ricotta pancakes.  Pancakes and potatoes were the best.  I think the potatoes are flash fried or something -- amazingly crunchy, but not dripping with oil.  Best brunch potatoes I've had -- hands down.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were the perfect size (not too big - i think bottomless flapjacks is the grossest idea ever).  Texture was great and flavor was delicate and not too sweet. Yummers.

I think some claims that it's the "best brunch spot in the city" is a bit much -- but definitely a great place to try if you happen to drive by Potrero Hill and see that the line isn't too bad!
author: Kendra W.

description:
Probably the most amazing breakfast restaurant in all of San Francisco. Definitely my personal favorite. If you are going on a weekend plan on waiting at least 1 hour for a table. Plow is not very big so the wait gets really long. They have a bar and stool area that faces the kitchen and also about  25-30 seats in the dining room.  If you go on a weekday there will probably be a wait as well, but it will be about 5-15 minutes.  

My personal favorite at Plow is their friend egg sandwich with potatoes on the side. Make sure to add avocado to your sandwich for an extra punch of flavor. Its so good I actually have dreams about it. In my dream, I eat about a hundred of them back to back without gaining an ounce of weight!  Love those dreams!  I've even started making my own fried egg sandwich at home inspired by the one at Plow. Mine is damn good but still doesn't hold a candle to the one at Plow!

I've never tried their Chinese breakfast, but considering every time I go they are out of it, tells me its super popular and very good. 

They are located in Potrero Hill so parking is pretty good considering its SF.  It usually doesn't take me longer than 5 minutes to find a spot.

Highly recommend Plow!
author: Ash S.

description:
The food here is just great. I feel like I can give them 5 stars now because they're no longer a well-kept secret -- and haven't been for a long time. I live 2 blocks away and rarely get to eat here because the wait is too long. Everything here is very very good, the space is lovely, great service. But 1-2 hour waits on the weekends even if you get there early/late...oh well, it was nice while it lasted.

I guess Pot Hill needs another breakfast place. Just For You doesn't count
author: Jay B.

description:
We were advised that it would be about a 45 minute wait for an open table, 
so we put our names down and got coffees next door at Farleys.

They had given us bar seats, which was a lot of fun to be able to watch how speedy the restaurant staff was. It appeared that they had their operation down to a tee with efficiently being able to feed their busy brunching schedule with seamless fluidity

This made my experience with my eggs Benedict all the more special,
as I witnessed the finesse involved in perfectly poaching an egg, wow.  Perfection.
There was a hefty amount of delicious ham, with impeccably cooked potatoes on the side. Much enjoyed with a refreshing splash of a breakfast Mimosa to ease me through the anticipation I felt as I was approaching my last bite.
author: Ty T.

description:
Everything about this breakfast was 5 Stars.  A friend's recommendation brought my boyfriend and I here on a Friday (brunchtime-ish). Were seated promptly next to another couple at a small table in the corner. I don't mind sitting next to strangers, but I did have to get up to let them out of their seats so I am sure they felt trapped.  
Ordered the fried egg sandwhich with bacon, which was a delicious brioche bun, farm fresh eggs and crispy bacon... side of the best freakin potatoes youve ever had.  Every restaurant should take tips on their potatoes, crispy, airy, cooked all the way through, without a hint of greasiness. Heaven!  Boyfriend got the Plow with sausage. Those lemon ricotta pancakes -- flavor explosion! It was an incredible breakfast. The price was very reasonable, if not inexpensive, for the quality. Plow is a must have for every SF trip in the future now.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
This place was close to my school, so lucky to find it!!
Love the location and that it has outside seating as well. The staff is always smiling and very nice, even with the craziness of a full restaurant. 
My mouth has been watering for their breakfast potatoes, house made sausage and lemon ricotta pancakes!!!!
And the décor is perfect, feel like your in someone's large country home!!!
author: Quinn S.

description:
Just moved from NY, and Plow definitely makes me feel good that there are awesome brunch places in SF and that I won't need to hop on a plane any time soon whenever I need a good brunch. Went on a sunny Saturday afternoon (after 1:30PM) and waited for about 25 minutes. Perhaps that's the key for getting around the crazy peak time waits. 

We had the Fried Egg Sandwich with avocado and pork sausage... YUMMY. It fell apart though (definitely not easy to eat w/your hands), but I managed b/c it was just too yummy. Their crispy potatoes are a must, even if you are carb conscious... if you're gonna eat any kind of fried potatoes be it fries or home fries, eat these and skip all the others! So delicious.

We also tried the lemon ricotta pancakes as it seems like that is a must, and I definitely liked them a lot (not sure if it's out of this world amazing, but they were definitely very good). I'd get them again. YUM.

Come later, wait less, and eat happy.
author: Alice W.

description: The overall place was great.  Beside the fact the doorman was a Spurs fan, we may have jumped the 1.5 hour wait on a Saturday.  Food was excellent for what you pick, sadly my girlfriend and I pick similarly and we chose the eggs Benedict.  All 4 eggs were cooked perfectly (sadly that's something to rate for us).  Good ambience, good host, and a good cook.  I'm happy they sad where they got the food as well.
author: Adam K.

description:
Quality ingredients, helpful staff, but the flavors and textures didn't suit my palate. The French toast was bland, the crispy potatoes had too much Rosemary, the infamous sandwich was hardly anything to remember outside of the acme bun, the sausages (pork and chicken apple.. Were just ok).... but one thing did make my list. the lemon ricotta pancakes were the star of this meal.  Perfect combination of sweet and tart. Just really small portions of it on the plow plate.  

Was it worth the hour wait... Meh.
author: irene u.

description:
Everything was wonderful . We were especially impressed by the delicious gluten free almond flour pancakes, crispy fried potatoes, and smoked bacon. 

Wandered to Farley's for coffee during our 15 minute wait on a Saturday morning around 9:30am.
author: Rosemary H.

description:
I've heard good things about Plow, and usually when I hear good things my expectations are too high and I'm left unsatisfied. 

Not the case this time. Walked in on a Tuesday late morning hoping to skip the brunch bunch and squeeze in before the lunch crowd, but I failed.. the little restaurant is already full. Luckily, I was a lone soldier and was able to fit in between two couples at the bar.

I've been big on decor lately and Plow is another place that has me hooked. This homey, cozy place has a hint of chic mixed into it. The open kitchen makes sitting alone at the bar more enjoyable. I love watching the chefs work magic creating the seemingly simple dishes.

I must confess, I did not order the famous Fried Egg Sandwich. Seeing that I already made my own version of scrambled eggs that morning, I ordered the Fried Chicken Sandwich instead. That and a side order of the gluten free almond pancake. What caught my eye was that the sandwich would be served on an Acme Torpedo Roll (and I'm a strong believe that unless you royally screw up your food, this roll will make anything taste amazing). 

When the sandwich came out, it exceed my expectation and then some. The chicken breast was breaded just enough to give it that crispy skin without the doughy texture. The chicken was fried so perfectly that it was white but juicy throughout. No Salmonella, thank you very much. Mixed with the cole slaw, this sandwich was perfection. I ate only half and took the rest to go. And then five minutes later I finished the sandwich in my car.

You might think gluten free pancake would be gross, but this was probably the best pancake I've ever had. (Lemon ricotta would have been the first choice, but I'm lactose..) One word: FLUFFY. 

Plow wowed me. I can't wait to go back.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Assuming you're having a relaxing, weekend day and aren't in a hurry, this place is SO worth the wait!  I'm guessing it's not as busy during the week, but on the weekend, it's  not unusual to wait 45 minutes to an hour.

My boyfriend lives in Potrero and this is our favorite brunch place in the neighborhood.  Everything I've ever eaten here has been out of this world!  

They always have some yummy "starter" type items at the top of their brunch menu.  They change these up a lot, but every one I've tried has been awesome.

I don't have kids, but I saw on their website that they have a great kid's menu.  My favorite dish to get is The Plow because it has a little of everything: fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, choice of tasty meat and those crispy potatoes that made the 7x7 list.

The restaurant is focused on using local ingredients.  They even list where the food comes from on their menu.

As I mentioned, they're always busy on the weekends.  Still, I've always had prompt friendly service.  They always offer plenty of coffee refills- love their coffee!

FYI they don't take reservations and don't serve parties over 6 people.
author: Chrissy M.

description: This is a nice little breakfast Nook off the beaten path. Good coffee. I got the "plow breakfast" which consists of crispy potatoes and no you do not need to specify extra crispy because they are already very crispy. It came with two pretty small lemon ricotta pancakes which were delightful. They are served up with butter and maple syrup. You also get your choice of bacon or house made pork sausage which was fantastic and eggs. I found it to be quite a lot of food but it was also quite a lot of money but it was a very good breakfast all in all.
author: Bonnie B.

description:
The best breakfast potatoes on earth. The lemon ricotta pancakes are also something else. Go here. Order The Plow. You will be tempted by other things on the menu -- and the other things are good to be sure -- but The Plow is a life-altering dish.

Prepare to wait for ages if you come on the weekend. Come on a middle weekday instead, and then have a nap afterwards. You'll probably dream about potatoes.
author: Luke A.

description:
I very much heart this place ,for some reason this place remind me of my fav brunch restaurant in Brooklyn. Rustic room, hight celling and  gigantic window gave the room a bright natural lights.
 The food is excellent, creative, and sure to please. The potatoes  were excellent. I couldn't stop eating it and doughnut holes was great , too.
The place is small,  that's why it was a 45 +min for waiting. The waitress was nice but a bit too rushy toward the end. The host was supper friendly. 
I definitely will come back here, the ambiance is really amazing and it's worth a wait.
author: christy l.

description: this little spot is great. food is delicious and service is nice. the place is very small, so expect a wait when you go. I had The Plow and give you a taste of everything. My friend says it is the best potatoes he ever had.
author: Mae M.

description:
If you are looking for the quintessential San Francisco brunch experience, Plow may be it.

Views from Portrero Hill make you feel like you are on a movie set.

The line out the door tells you that it's a popular choice (but worth the wait, I promise).

The short-ish menu has something for just about everyone, very simply prepared to showcase the freshness and quality of the ingredients.

The interior is sunny, modern-casual, with an open kitchen, tables and counter seating, and a shelf of cookbooks and things in Ball jars to make you feel right at home.

The staff is very smiley and super nice.

You can't go wrong with whatever choice you make.  If it's your first time, go with The Plow, which is eggs, potatoes, ricotta pancakes, and meat of your choice.  Everything is prepared perfectly, and in exactly the right portions.  A little shake of Youk's hot sauce on the potatoes is a great added touch if you want a little spice.

I recently had the smoked salmon dish, and it was delicious, with tons of salmon.  

A wonderful little gem in the city, and never a disappointment.
author: Liz S.

description:
A San Francisco Brunch must!

Get here early, because the space is small and the line is long. Most importantly, you don't want the best things on the menu running out.

If it's available, fried chicken and biscuits with gravy. If not, either the fried egg sandwich or the Plow. Possibly a side of lemon ricotta pancakes.

Just don't make the chump mistake of ordering coffee here. It is sub par. Just bring a cup of blue bottle, ritual, four barrel, sightglass, etc. and enjoy =)
author: Mike M.

description: The Plow Breakfast is amazing ! Minus 1 star for the horrible wait time on the weekends..
author: Sonny S.

description: Come early to avoid the wait. Food is great service is always full of personality and fun to be around. I would definitely recommend the entire breakfast menu and that rarely happens.
author: Cameron M.

description:
This place served up a solid Sunday brunch. I like the decor and thought the ingredients really stood out here. They served one of the best blood sausages that I've had in awhile and the breakfast potatoes were cooked to perfection... crispy and well seasoned. 

My only gripe was that my dungeness crab scramble was dominated by the crazy amount of scallions that was in it. The crab was largely lost in the dish and I found myself picking off some of the scallions just to get a bit of balance.
author: Victor H.

description:
So I've been really wanting to try this place.  It's a bit out of the way for me, but I love trying new things.

So, we waited about an hour to be seated on a Saturday...ok by me if the food is good.  Plus you can order some beverages while you wait.  Relax people, have some drinks outside with friends while you wait.  It's the weekend after all so enjoy. 

So my friend and I shared two dishes. The Plow (two eggs, two pieces of bacon or sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes) and The French Toast.
The food was just delicious.  We ate every bite.  Those potatoes are crispy on the outside, soft on the inside with great flavor.  Those lemon ricotta pancakes were so delectable. French Toast was more on average but very good!  

I am definitely going to come back here again and try something else...but I may get those ricotta pancakes again..hehe.
author: S G.

description:
Wow! I was going to write a review about the long wait but then thought why bother because that's just life sometimes but getting pretty much kicked out just pushed me over the edge. 
We waited 40 minutes to be seated after having been treated quite badly by the hostess. Had a nice waitress so I was like never mind about the wait and I will let the way this experience started go. After finishing brunch which was in less than 25 minutes. We were just chatting and finishing our coffee when we were approached by another waitress who told me "we don't allow computers" and I responded " excuse me but why is that?"  We have too many people waiting. "Oh I see...we'll how about that I said." 
So we just packed up and left leaving our half cup of coffee that were 3.75 each. 
I suppose you guessed by now that we will NEVER go back to this place. 
Whoever owns this place needs to know exactly how the staff is treating customers. I would want to know this if I owned the place. An attitude like this will catch up to you especially in a small town like San Francisco. I love supporting local businesses but this one is just too undeserving. I will open my wallet somewhere where customers are not cattle being pushed through the gates. 
Good luck plow!
author: Caroline A.

description:
They lied to us on the phone. We called ahead and asked how long the wait was for three. They said "There is no wait right now." We arrived exactly ten minutes later. Five two tops and one three top on the list ahead of us, with check in times well before the ten minutes it took us to get there. When I asked the hostess about it she told me dismissively that the wait is often two hours long, so this is "basically no wait."

Doesn't seem like a big deal, but I felt lied to and then brushed off. Will not be back.
author: Dr. X.

description:
12.11.00   First Visit


Food               4 - 4 1/2 Stars


Had breakfast only here.
Nice tweek on individual items making it special.
       Smashing the potatoes before frying allow more surface to be exposed to the oil
       Seasoning it immediately helps too.
       Crispy is the right word ... almost like french style french fries traits.

The almond flour pancakes was delicious.

Super long line however the are pretty efficient so turnaround is high.

Killer moist ricotta pancakes.

Uses artisinal ingredients like zoe bacon

Good food that makes breakfast fun again.
Definately not the same humdrum with good execution ... you know perfectly cooked
     food. They also experimented and succeeded in thinking outside of the box.

You get clues that they are perfectionist by the cookbooks that line the shelf.
       They pick the ones written by best in the culinary industry. Just like I do also!
       
Planning to revisit this place soon... 

This was an old review laying around.
author: S.K. Y.

description: So I am a HUGE brunch lover. Very few things make me happier. And holy moly this place is my new favorite. I have been looking for the best brunch ever and I found it! I got the dish called the plow which comes with 2 lemon pancakes, their house sausages, 2 eggs, and their potatoe fry things that I swear we're made by god himself. Literally so good I can't even.
author: Madi N.

description: Fantastic breakfast and got in before the mad rush.  Location is quiet and I recommend having a cup of coffee while you wait.  Service was fantastic and even though there were a lot of people waiting the servers never made us feel rushed.  Food was very fresh and flavorful.  Highly recommend this neighborhood spot.  A hidden gem.
author: April M.

description: This is only a review for their side of fruit. While the food was excellent, the side of fruit was devine. Most sides of fruit contain Bullshit Fruit - melons and like maybe one good piece of fruit. But their side of fruit was exotic and had passion fruit and berries and wonderful incredible fresh fruit. Almost unheard of. Thank you, Plow, for all the fruit.
author: nate b.

description:
Hands down, one of the best breakfasts in San Francisco! 

Sat at the bar watching the happiest chefs work their magic. (I've never seen such enthusiasm in any restaurant, that these people have!!)

The lemon ricotta pancakes are light, creamy, lemony goodness! Wow!

Country potatoes.. Perfect!  Eggs... Exquisite!
author: Raleigh S.

description:
I had high expectations coming to Plow, and Plow delivered. The food is good - nothing special in my opinion. I ordered "The Plow" and had my eggs cooked over easy. The eggs were fine, the crispy potatoes were tasty, the bacon (which the server recommended) was no good, and the pancakes were decent.

I mean, at $15 for the entree, I expected it to be out of this world. I can name a dozen breakfast joints in the area with a tastier, heartier breakfast for less money.

Overall, the food is good, but I wouldn't wait more than 20 minutes to eat there.
author: Jason C.

description: Great brunch place! I had the Plow and my sister had the crab scramble. The crispy potatoes were my favorite and was not a let down. Next time I want to try the Egg Sandwich which my sister says is delicious! Try coming here on a weekday, it's not as crowded and wait is only about 20 min during peak times.
author: Sally S.

description:
plow is a hip brunch place in portrero hill.  it demands an hour wait.  friendly staff.  but mediocre food.  i cant seem to understand why people are willing to wait an hour for breakfast here.  i dont think we would come back again

first the tables were smelly.  they had accidentally left a wet rag on our chair but the table was still smelly and chair wet.  i think they need to wash those rags more.

we ordered the pulled pork sandwich, 2 soft scramble with chanterelle, nettles, and goat cheese, and also the plow which is eggs, meat, potatoes and a pancake.  i added an almond pancake to my meal because i was imagining it to be a fluffy french macaroon like thing.  

when my soft scramble came it was button mushrooms and not chanterelles.  we prompty notified our waitress who asked the kitchen which confirmed that yes they had run out of chanterelles.  at 10am.  and that they would take $1 off each soft scramble we ordered.  but if we hadnt asked?  as i left i was thinking of all the people who ordered the soft scramble with chanterelles for chanterelle price who were actually eating button mushrooms and not informed.  but they wouldnt care,  they are eating in a hip place and they are hip people.  the worst part is feeling like they were trying to trick us

next the homemade sausage patties.  i found to be bland and dry.  yuck.  the almond pacakes were gritty and mushy, like a soggy almond cookie.  so much worse that i had hoped.  i couldnt even finish.  the lemon ricotta pancakes were a step better but still not that fluffy and not that lemony or ricotta-y

the saving grace was the potatoes.  delicious.  can a restaurant survive by making good potatoes?  probably

everything else was crap
author: claudia y.

description: I'm still not a big fan of brunch, but I really enjoyed brunch at the Plow on Sunday morning. I struggled to pick one out of its various choices, so I ended up choosing the plow!
author: Nathan N.

description: Total waste of 1hr45mn wait for super boring regular food with over price. Cute place with big window was nice but just not worth the & $.
author: Reika F.

description: There are definitely better brunch places in SF. It was around a 2.5 hour wait and we ordered the plow and benedict. The plate felt like it was 1/2-3/4 full of potatoes. Now, if they were delicious crispy potatoes, then awesome! But no, they were big chunks of soggy waste-of-calories potatoes. Meh. Their lemon ricotta pancake was also very dry. So there is no reason why I would return.
author: Sandy T.

description:
ahhhhhhhhh this is a great weekend brunch spot!

Maybe it's the nice weather out, or maybe it was the company, but I had a great brunch experience at Plow.

Parking: so easy. Even if you had to park far, neighbourhood is so cute so I wouldn't have minded the walk.

Waiting: yes you have to wait. They don't take reservations.  I think  we waited 30 minutes?  It gives you a good time to chit chat with your friend and just get caught up before your brunch so the wait was totally acceptable.

Food: I had the crab scramble with toast, my friend had the egg's benedict. And of course we had to get a side of lemon ricotta pancake to taste!  

All the dishes were yummy.  Nice ciabatta toast.  Country fried potatoes that came with our dish was crisp and flavourful.  My crab scramble was tasty.  Eggs benedict was also perfectly done.

All in all we really enjoyed our brunch here.

Why not 5 stars?  Maybe minus one star for lack of creativity?  I mean the menu itself wasn't unique. They however do their food, very well.

Will definitely be back! (on a nice day of course so that I'm not waiting in the rain!)
author: Sujan H.

description: Food ok Chinese breakfast pretty good you have get here early for that one all other ok
author: Danny R.

description:
Lemon. Ricotta. Pancakes.
A delicate crisp on the outside.  Then BOOM a citrus-y cloud in yo mouf.  IN YO MOUF.

Potatoes were great, crispy with soft middles, not too salty.  But I would not say they were the best potatoes I've ever had.  (That honor goes to the duck-fat fries at The Back Abbey in Claremont.)

The dungeness crab egg scramble was delish.  Not send-me-into-orbit delicious, but the crab was fresh with good bounce, and the asparagus pieces al dente.

Camillia-blossom iced-tea: maybe my palate is too unrefined to catch what's special about this drink.  It was refreshing, but just tasted like any old iced-tea.  Would not order again.

But goddamn, those pancakes.

p.s. Went on a Thursday mid-morning...there was still a line!  Wait was about 10-15 min.
author: chelsea c.

description:
I love this place. It's probably my favorite brunch place. The atmosphere is awesome. Great bar overlooking the kitchen (so you can watch all of the food coming out), fairly high ceilings, tons of light, and a cozy row of tables. I've eaten there a number of times and I find it hard to have a favorite menu item. Their b-fast sando is high on the list. I like to add bacon and avocado. Their bun is the right amount of soft. I also love their potatoes. Perfectly crisp exterior and a nice herb flavor. Their homemade pork sausage and their blood sausage are also amazing. I'm not the biggest b-fast sweat fan, but I have tried their lemon ricotta pancakes and they are delectable. 

It can be a long wait so I try to go on the early side. I've never felt like I've waited too long for the food or the service I've received. It's also helpful that you can grab a cup of coffee when you go in to put your name on the list.
author: Daniel M.

description:
Arrived around 9 am on a Sunday for breakfast and waited for about 45 minutes for a seat at the counter.  There are a few seats on the street while you wait, and the hostess offers coffee to sip while waiting.

The interior is clean, simple and tasteful, with two large farmland-inspired prints adorning the walls.  A counter space with about 8 seats overlooks the kitchen.  We sat here and really enjoyed watching the cooks throw together the menu items.

What sets this place apart from the typical brunch fare in SF is the menu.  The oft-mentioned lemon ricotta pancakes are different and quite good (though not my personal favorite).  The pork sausage was fabulous and worth ordering.  I fried potatoes I'm sure find their way immediately to your waistline, but they are scrumptious.

We will be back on a day when we are up early so as to beat the wait!
author: Brad B.

description: Most amazing breakfast! I got the eggs and was taken in by the delectable potatoes and sourdough toast. And then I had to finish my sons French toast. This is a must and worth the wait.
author: Deborah G.

description:
First time I came here we were told it was a 1 hour wait but maybe we'd like to go to Farley's Coffee shop half a block down while we waited.  30min later we returned to check up, and we were told we had been called and our table had been given away.  There were now 2 parties ahead of us and the wait would be another 30 minutes.  A full hour later we were finally seated at the bar.

The food was good, but my egg sandwich was a little cold.  I wrote this off as a busy brunch spot and, these things happen.

I returned today for the first time in a year and was told a very simliar thing;  "The wait is 40 minutes, at *least*, why not go to Farley's while you wait?"  We wanted coffee so against my better judgement we left.  20 minutes later when the alarm I set rang, I returned, only to find they had called us and then given away our table.  Now there was one party in front of us and a 30 min wait.

I understand that wait times are not exact, but the staff at Plow have no concept of the traffic through their own restaurant, encourage you to leave, won't take a cell phone number and will put you at the end of the list when you return.

If you come to Plow, be prepared to stand outside (there's almost no waiting room inside) for an hour or more for food that isn't any better than then many other brunch spots in Potrero Hill.
author: Garth W.

description:
Great food and excellent atmosphere. I only had two complaints, so I'll get those out of the way first: my tea was obscenely weak--just warm water really, and the bill was over 50 bucks for two people who just drank coffee and tea. That's pretty pricey for a casual Saturday breakfast.
This place is popular with the early crowd. We arrived at 9 and were seated at 9:45 (on a Saturday). We sat at the center, which turned out to be fun. There's an open kitchen, and everyone in it was totally tapped into their flow, cranking out food to a synchronized rhythm. Everyone seemed to really enjoy working there.  The music was 50's and 60's rock and soul hits, which created a nice atmosphere. The employees were smiling and dancing while they worked their butts off.
The food was excellent. We had the almond flour pancakes and the corned beef hash. Delicious and totally paleo. Definitely high quality ingredients prepared well.
And our waitress Katie was so genuinely nice--perhaps the nicest waitress I've ever met in San Francisco. SF is not known for polite service, and it was great to see a departure from that. We thoroughly enjoyed sitting in her section.
I definitely recommend this place, but don't order the tea and be prepared to shell out the bucks.
author: Peter S.

description:
This is an average hipster-filled brunch place in potrero hill. Its nothing crazy special, but it is a decent place to go to if you're in the area and craving some lemon ricotta pancakes or homemade pork sausage. 

As everyone else has said, the lemon ricotta pancakes are very tasty. We got them by ordering the 'plow' which came with little medallion sized pancakes, eggs, potatoes, and choice of meat. The pancakes weren't the best I've ever tasted, though (best I ever had were in auburn, ca). The pork sausage that is more like a meat patty was a nice touch, but for some reason it was too meaty... and something was just a little off in the seasoning. I also had the egg sandwhich with the bacon. Bacon was nice and thick, but overall the sandwhich was meh. Too messy even for an egg sandwhich, best part was the buns. The house potatoes were too crispy for my liking, although they were tender inside. 
I was curious about the pumpkin bread with icing... but didn't get to try. 

With the considerable wait in mind, I didn't really understand all the hype. They do serve mimosas/alcohol/coffee while you wait which can pass the time, along with all the people who bring their cute dogs! Service is efficient and polite, interesting to watch the kitchen staff work from the counter. 
Side note - i feel like the pig emblem that they use is used in several other restaurants? =p
author: Tim B.

description: So we get seated at the counter which was awesome because we were able to see the cooks create their "goodness"! It was fun to watch, maybe I'll learn something...  My son orders the Egg Sandwich w/added bacon and a side of potatoes! It looked amazing! As soon as he took the 1st bite and the yolk started dripping down his hand I grabbed his napkin and he pushes himself away!! He says, " Mom, that's the best ever, leave it!" lol...I'll lick it off! 5 mins later his plate was clean and his belly was full and mom was happy! I ordered the lemon ricotta pancakes, they were dense but fluffy, lemony flavorful and soo good drizzled with syrup and powdered sugar. I recommended you get here early because when we left there was like 15 people outside (9:30am)!! Enjoy! Oh and they also have "as you wait coffee" just ask!
author: Carla F.

description:
Best breakfast potatoes ever! I love potatoes that have some crunch to them. More often than not, I get country style potatoes that are more on the soft side without any crispy bits -- not really to my liking. The potatoes at Plow were served deep fried and crunchy and then sauteed with onions and a little rosemary. Yum!

The potatoes were a side to their fried egg sandwich -- two eggs over easy, served on a soft Acme roll with melted Grafton cheddar, a light touch of aioli and some frisee. I'd recommend tackling the sandwich with a knife and fork and let that yummy egg yolk break on the plate and co-mingle with those potatoes. Deee-licious!

I like the location. It's a fairly small room (about 10 tables) and a counter right at the grill. Large uncovered windows face towards 18th Street and let in a lot of light. From my corner table, I could lazily stare out onto the street as I enjoyed my food and coffee. A very pleasant experience.
author: Joel A.

description: Totally overrated we waited for 2.5 hours and the food was not that good. Dont waste your day going to his place.. Absolutly not worth it
author: Maria V.

description:
A group of us had brunch at Plow over the weekend for a birthday celebration (requested by the birthday girl.)  I viewed their website in advance and was aware that they did not take reservations and were a small venue that could only accommodate up to six in a group, so we kept our group to six.   We had heard good things about Plow and we were excited to give it a try. 

We arrived on a Sunday at 9:00 a.m. and we were told that it would be an hour wait.  The wait wasn't actually that long.  It felt like 20 minutes but it was probably 40 as we were busy chatting.  We sat outside.  

As we looked at the menu, someone pointed out a sentence in italics that said something to the effect of "no modifications to the menu."  I don't have the exact wording.  Well, to start, that's a bit of a buzz kill as who doesn't modify something even a little?  I decided to order all "sides" so that I could enjoy what I wanted and not have a plate with things that I don't care for included.  Very simply put, I ordered 2 eggs scrambled, crispy potatoes and a buttermilk biscuit.  How can you go wrong with that?   No where on the menu did it say that the crispy potatoes were "rosemary crispy potatoes" and it just so happens that rosemary does not agree with me and I stay far away from it.  It spilled over into my scrambled eggs, and I could not have been more disappointed. As a group we made our own modifications, and friends shared pancakes and meat that they would not ordinarily order.  Friends enjoyed the lemon ricotta pancakes and the buttermilk biscuits and the eggs seemed to be quite fresh.  

On a more important note, the waitress that we had was anything but cheerful. She didn't appear to be overly friendly to anyone outside.  From the moment we sat down, we felt her negative energy and lack of any form of customer service.  Overall, we had a great time together, the food was good, but the service was not anything to write home about.  On the ABOUT section of their website it says " Plow is a tribute to timeless recipes coupled with California cooking and warm hospitality."   Well, the hospitality portion was definitely missing from our experience which was really unfortunate. 

My rating of 3 stars is more about the service than the menu or food experience.
author: Sharon M.

description:
A M A Z I N G

My friend and I shared:
--fried egg sandwich
--lemon ricotta pancakes
--potatoes

These people really know their eggs. And their potatoes. And by the looks of the dreamy food-heaven smiles on everyone's faces, they know a lot about yummy food in general. Definitely going back to try more of the menu. Sit at the counter if you want an up close view of how all the yummies come together.

Go early on a weekday if you want to avoid the wait. We finished at noon and people were already waiting for tables.
author: Natalie J.

description:
Don't listen to all the hype - hipsters will rave about anything where there are more than one person standing in line for...it makes them miss the lines outside of the Apple stores.

This is an ok breakfast place but it's a bit too cramped and flavors are once again 'ok' but nothing worthy of a 4 or 5 star review.
author: Rich S.

description: Bad energy. Lots of arrogance here.  The first thing we noticed is a sign on the wall saying no cell phones.  That must mean just for guests.  The cell phone is alive and well. The cook on the line actually kept leaving the line to check her cell that was plugged into the side station.  There was zero interaction with the guest, no checking on coffee, had to ask for water.  Our server was actually 2 feet from where we were sitting and we had to flag down her co-worker for water and coffee.  I could go on and on but no need this is plenty.  $40 for breakfast with one cup of coffee no refills. no thanks.
author: Niece N.

description: Picked the pork sandwich because it had jam with earl grey. I like flowers in my food. You know that. Sandwich was good. It was drippy in that way that a good burger is drippy. Good coffee.
author: Hazel F.

description:
i've been wanting to try this place for some time but i am rarely in this neighborhood and i don't know why.

my boyfriend and i woke up early and decided to eat here since there's a chance of not waiting so long because it's so early. well, when we drove by the large crowd crowding the entrance almost made us change our minds but decided to stay. the 40min wait didn't seem so long.

we sat at the bar and just watched all the cooks in action. they got skills!

i wanted to try the almond flour pancakes but i was craving for eggs so instead i ordered 'the plow', which consisted of eggs [poached], sausage and lemon ricotta pancakes. i'm not a huge fan of lemon things [exc. lemonade, lemon bundt cake], and i knew these pancakes were risky. they're ok, but i don't love them like everyone else did. 

regardless, i am definitely coming back here to try the almond pancakes, and other things on their menu! it's small but they have large windows that bring all the sunlight in!
author: Rosalee C.

description: This is just simply one of the finest and most delightful places in SF! After rolling up here probably 3 years ago and in search of a new and remarkably tasty vegan item for my boss' lunch, Plow has consistently remained at the top for their homemade everything. I love Plow and their super nice staff - all super people who care about their food and making people happy.  Plow has also graciously hosted several private dinners with elegance and creativity! I always propose a 2nd location idea to them, but Max and Joel seem content to enjoy their lives and one killer spot. I get it.
author: Ros M.

description:
My friend and I came here on a Wednesday afternoon to avoid the wait because we're not the most patient when we have to pathetically watch people eating food through a window while standing outside in the cold.  However, there was already a small crowd of people waiting outside the door, and we pledged that if the wait was more than 20 minutes, we would get it to go and eat in the car.

Luckily, we only had to wait about 10 minutes before getting a table, and it helps that the service is fast.  So many things on the menu sound amazing, but we ended up narrowing it down to a fried egg sandwich for my friend and the plow for me.

The plow was basically my dream breakfast: eggs (scrambled and cooked to perfection), chicken apple sausage, wonderfully crispy brown potatoes, and light refreshing lemon ricotta pancakes.  My friend loved her fried egg sandwich (+bacon) and raved that she could eat the potatoes for every single meal.

Overall, a wonderfully delicious brunch in a cute atmosphere.  I would highly recommend coming here (be prepared to wait), and I would love to come back to try all the other delicious menu items!
author: Carrie C.

description:
This place rules.  I was going to take a star away because wait time can sometimes exceed an hour easy, but then I thought about it and said to myself, no, f it, people wait for that sh*t because it's THAT good.  They cannot help it if they are the best.

Also, sometimes they play 80's music on Pandora which goes great with pancakes and eggs... Really, really great.
author: Jill C.

description:
So, I haven't gone to Plow in awhile because it's exploded in popularity over the past year. I live a couple houses up and ride my bike past the restaurant every day. There is always some kind of line outside the restaurant, even on weekdays! Good for them! However, that means I just haven't been in awhile because waiting in the line sucks.

Anyways, I went yesterday (Sunday) for brunch. Was quite disappointed in both the food and service we received at Plow. 

1) I ordered a duck and sweet potato hash. Sounds amazing, right? Well, the duck was fatty and flavorless. Quite gamey but not in a good way. I kept on having to add ketchup and hot sauce because it just tasted like someone had taken cubed duck breast and boiled it. There was no caramelization, no nice tasty brown spots on the meat. There were also fatty chunks on the meat that weren't rendered properly, like poorly cooked pork belly.  All of it was a dull brown-gray. The sweet potatoes fared no better. They were overcooked and disintegrated fairly quickly. I was super hungry and ate 2/3s of it, but ended picking at my friend's meals (they all got the Plow) to fill up.

2) The service! It's gotten so snobby! The blonde girl who served us (we were sitting outside) really needs to consider the fact that she's at a BREAKFAST joint, not a Michelin starred restaurant. Two incidents. First, my friend asked if they had brown sugar. He just likes the extra richness. She says, "We don't have brown sugar, we have RAW sugar" in a tone that basically said "how dare you ask for brown sugar when we have this organic local better-than-you sugar here already". Second incident, another friend asked for goat cheese instead of cheddar on her fried egg sandwich. She makes a face and says "well, I'll get that for you on the side because it probably won't taste good." Girl, have you even had goat cheese on eggs and frisee? It tastes FINE. Delicious, even! I understand if we were at a fine dining establishment, and the dish has specific ingredients that were meant to go together, but for fucks sake, we just want to switch out the cheese. 

Bottom line, probably not coming here very often anymore, especially since the wait is a huge turn off. It's expensive too, I spent $20+ on just my dish (no coffee, no extras). I'm sad because this used to be a great, friendly, local brunch restaurant, and I feel like it's just turning into the next Mission Beach Cafe with the snob factor. But with crappier food.
author: Emily H.

description: Amazing brunch spot in Potrero! Although the wait might be lengthy on the weekend you will not be disappointed! Add your name to the wait list and grab a coffee and scone while you hang around outside with your friends. It's a great time to review the menu and build up an appetite. The portion sizes are huge! Take in the sites from the top of the hill and you won't even notice that you've been waiting around for the perfect morning meal.
author: Ula K.

description:
Love Plow's brunch and would give it 5 stars if it weren't for the wait. Their lemon ricotta pancakes are the best. I'm not even a big pancake fan yet I order them every time. Their crispy potatoes are delicious too; I've tried a few times to replicate them at home but can never seem to get them just right. If you go on a weekend be prepared for a pretty lengthy wait. This place is extremely tiny and very popular. But, they do offer coffee to make the wait a little more bearable and there is a great view of the city. They also have outdoor seating and are dog friendly. 
As for food, I have gotten the breakfast sandwich, which is very tasty, but after trying the plow plate, I am a convert. It comes with all of Plow's best dishes: lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, eggs, and your choice of their yummy bacon or sausage. Definitely a must order if it's your first time at Plow.
author: Erin B.

description:
Yes- the line is a bit long... but more than worth the wait.  I think the brunch served at Plow is one of the best!  And the POTATOES are deliciouso. 

Order "The Plow", and you can't go wrong.  Actually anything on the menu, you can't go wrong.

Will be back a million more times.
author: DJ P.

description: Delicious brunch. Friendly, charming space with good food, good coffee, and a line out the door (that part's less fun). The lemon ricotta pancakes are well known, as is the "absolutely everything delicious on a plate" plate, the Plow. My friend ordered the smoked salmon breakfast, and that looked pretty awesome too.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Fantastic brunch today at Plow. Counter sat, and enjoyed our food a plenty and the cooks action. These guys work fast, I guess the constant turn over of tables and eager eaters, you gotta!
We needed about 4 more people so we could have tried more, but no reason to come only once....great location, great people!
We have the huckleberry cake, kale salad and eggs benedict. 
Next time.....pancakes, egg sando....can't wait
author: ERICA E.

description:
Great breakfast in Potrero.

The lady had the gluten free pancakes (which were lovely) but the potatoes! Good lord the potatoes.  They were perfectly crispy and tender.  oh man the potatoes.  

put those on the plate and I'll eat whatever comes with it.

Not the cheapest breakfast in town by any stretch, but a great little spot to visit.
author: Nick H.

description: Three stars just based on the ridiculous wait. The wait is stupid, I don't care how good it is. And it was good. It was delicious. We had the Plow and fried egg sandwich. The food was great but after a two hour wait only to sit at the bar, nothing is that good. We couldn't think of a single place we loved that much to wait that long and we tried hard to think of one. Anyway, good but the wait is too much.
author: Roberta J.
