description: We live and few blocks away and while it's so close we rarely get there because the line is so long... a good problem to have for a very popular restaurant!   Everything is so consistently great here.  I really can't recommend enough.  I only wish they would stay open for dinner. Even if they didn't change the menu!  I would GLADLY eat fried eggs and sausage for dinner on a Wednesday night...  (Plow: please consider it!)
author: Lucy B.

description:
For a year and a half, I have been hearing my Potrero friends rave about Plow. Actually, I've been hearing raves about Plow from friends, the blogs, and pretty much anybody who had been and weathered the wait for their tasty breakfasts. Truth be told, I am not enamored with Mission Beach Cafe or Boogaloos and didn't think that breakfast at Plow would wow me.

The breakfast wowed me. 

We started with a corn and millet muffin, freshly baked and still warm from the oven. The muffin was crumbly and a bit hard to eat but the crust on the muffin top was crunchy and the millet added crispy bits to the slightly sweet corn muffin. Seriously though, all muffins should be eaten fresh and warm from the oven. 

Next up were a la carte orders of an almond pancake (gluten-free!) and a pumpkin pancake. The pumpkin pancake was fine, similar to what I make at home, but the almond pancake was really interesting. I didn't believe it was actually gluten-free at first b/c the texture was so spot on and it wasn't heavily almond flavored. I dislike marzipan, so I was quite pleased at the neutral flavor profile of the pancake. We asked the server and she informed us that it was made with almond, oat, and coconut flour. An excellent option for the g-f people out there.

The soft scrambled eggs were the turning point for me, where I switched from liking Plow to loving Plow. Of course we've all read about the proper way to slowly scramble eggs, slow and over low heat a la Julia Child or Jacques Pepin, and I thought I had it right before. I was wrong. These eggs were so, so silky. Not runny, but perfectly silky, highlighted by fava greens, chanterelles, and goat cheese. The much lauded crispy potatoes and some levain toast (well buttered with butter you could actually taste) were also there. I don't even like eggs and I kept going back to them, passing over the crispy fried potatoes!

We also tried the Chinese Breakfast whose name manages to simultaneously bring to mind my family and Humphry Slocombe's Secret Breakfast. Anyway, of course you can't go wrong with gingery braised pork shoulder over rice, but the soft scrambled eggs are really where it's at.

All the ingredients used were obviously quality; seasoning levels and ingredient ratios were also well balanced. Loved the clean yet rustic vibe of the naturally sunny dining room. Also loved our server who understood that we were there to sample some different dishes vs eating at a traditional pace. She brought things out at a comfortable rate and was there to answer questions as needed. I can't imagine this perfect vision of what breakfast at Plow is ruined by the hoards on weekends so I guess I'll just save it for an occasional 7am weekday treat.
author: Candice L.

description:
It seems like all I give are 5 star ratings but I find that i tend to only rate places that I love and can't stop talking about. And Plow is one of those places. I am sad I found out about this brunch place late in my 3 years in SF, but it is definitely my favorite brunch spot in the city after trying places like Stacks and Zazies. 

One item: lemon ricotta pancakes. To die for. I'm usually not a big pancake person, but this makes me want to eat pancakes every day. It is a small cute pancake but full of flavor. The fried egg sandwich was delicious as well (I got to mooch off some of my brother's order) and the potatoes were amazing, a tad on the salty side, but so crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. 

One negative, the wait is usually 30 to an hour. One time, I miraculously walked up with my party of four to an open table with no wait on a Tuesday at 1100am. The highlight of my day.

I love brunch and I love SF. This place is perfect! Just be ready to wait. :)
author: Stacy C.

description: The wait is short if you get there early. The french toast and The Plow plate are good. The drinks are good too. The lemon ricotta pancakes are delicious, especially when paired with the crispy potatoes.
author: Ruby K.

description:
Saaaausaaaaage and homefries are the shitzazzile.  The best breakfast I ever had!

Tip: Get your ass there on a weekday morning. Apparently, there is a major wait on the weekends.
author: Marcelle T.

description: Lemon ricotta pancakes were dense and flavorless. I couldn't even finish one after waiting 1.5 hours to be seated! The French toast was pretty good though and the crispy potatoes were super crunchy and nicely salted.
author: S C.

description:
Wow one of the best brunch in the city!!! Anything you order here will be excellent!!

On the other hand, service could be A LOT MORE FRIENDLY!! 
Staff comes across as very pretentious and snotty

They do not take reservations and that is pretty silly.
author: Paolo E.

description:
Best breakfast ever.  

The potatoes and lemon pancakes are amazing.  Be prepared to wait or go early.  There are a couple coffee shops within walking distance so you can put your name in and go on a little walk while you wait.
author: Chad J.

description:
This is my favorite breakfast place in the city!!  You've got to go to Plow!  I've been here twice and both brunches were fabulous!  Brought my friend from LA here and she absolutely loved it.  We had to wait about half hour on a Tuesday so we took a stroll around the sunny neighborhood.  

My friend ordered the Plow which is the works with 2 eggs, bacon,  2 lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes.  I ordered the soft egg crab and asparagus scramble with crispy potatoes, buttered toast and a side order of one almond pancake.  Everything was cooked to perfection and the potatoes are out of this world!  Best crispy potatoes with a sprinkling of salt and herbs.  Mmmm!  The almond pancake was nice and fluffy.

Love the decor and service was great.
author: Sharon D.

description:
I had to take one star off because the wait is a little ridiculous. I put my name down at 10 am on a Sunday, left for 2 hrs to get my friends and wander about the city, and when I came back at noon, there were still no tables available inside. Since we were pressed for time, we ate outside. As expected in SF, it was cold, but the food was still great.

My boyfriend and I both ordered "The Plow" which consists of 2 eggs, bacon or sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes. I loved that it was a perfect balance of sweet and savory. The eggs and sausage were good, but nothing too extraordinary. The lemon ricotta pancakes had great flavor and were the perfect size. The potatoes were the best potatoes I've had in the city. I don't know want to know how they are prepared or how much butter they are fried in because denial is bliss.

Our other 2 friends got the eggs benedict and fried egg sandwich. I think they enjoyed their meals, although my friend that got the eggs benedict asked for the sauce on the side, and her meal was smothered in sauce.

I'll definitely be back  - even though the wait is pretty bad the food makes up for it. Plus, it's difficult to find too many popular brunch places in the city with less than a 2 hour wait. I find myself craving more lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes!
author: Christina L.

description:
It's a cute small neighborhood spot for brunch; however, you should expect to wait for a table or arrive early. If I lived in that neighborhood, I would eat at Plow more often; otherwise, every once in a while is good enough. 

I've been to Plow twice for brunch and both times, I got the fried egg sandwich (two eggs fried, cheddar, aioli, crispy potatoes) and you can add bacon and/or avocados for additional fee. It is pretty delicious; the bread is soft yet slightly crispy on top and the runny egg yolk tastes delicious mixed in with your crispy potatoes. 

Maybe the next time I go, I'll be willing to try something different ... The French toast did look delicious and was sold out the first time around.
author: Lori F.

description:
3.5 stars

Mmmm... was time to try another brunch place last weekend.

The order:
Soft scramble with nettles, mushroom and chives
The plow (2 eggs, meat, potatoes, and two pancakes)
Side of fruit

The reaction:
EXCELLENT PANCAKES! We substituted the almond pancakes for the lemon ricotta and absolutely loved them. The soft scramble really had a wonderful flavor except they came out a little watery which wasn't the most appealing presentation. The side of fruit had a fun presentation with a mango turned inside out but there was so little fruit on a plate that cost $6! 

Final notes:
1. Will likely go again if there is no wait
2. While it's fun to sit at the bar and watch them move through the kitchen quickly, don't, because then you'll start thinking about how much oil goes into everything.
3. GO FOR THE PANCAKES.
author: Raina B.

description:
3.5 stars. this place is so cute!  the wait was very long...  love the decor.

ordered The Plow - with scrambled eggs and house made pork sausage patties. waitress came back half an hour later saying they were out of the pork sausage (it was 12:37pm on Sunday - yes, i did check the time) got the chicken apple sausage instead. should have gotten the bacon if i knew that the chicken apple sausages are those little bfast sausage (i like the ones with apple chunks in them instead). however, i really like the scrambled eggs (so runny!!) and CRISPY potatoes. tried that one weird whey orange drink (i wasn't paying a lot of attention when the waitress was describing it, but she mentioned that they made some cheese in-house and extracted protein, add orange juice and tonic... bleh - i didn't like it). lemon ricotta pancakes - first bite had a kick to it, but it's not fluffy. i like fluffy pancakes. same problem with the almond flour pancakes. 

i would totally go back for the eggs and potatoes. the muffin looked good, too. want to try that next time.
author: Diana C.

description:
Plow was one of those places that I waited a really long time to try.  I love Potrero-Hill and there really was no excuse for putting it off for so long.

First off, I love the location and the decor!  It's very clean and warm.  The staff is super friendly and accessible.  The wait was about 40min on a Sat morning (which is about what we expected). 

Food:
--lemon ricotta pancakes: I thought these were pretty good but nothing that blew my mind.  Did I let the legend of these pancakes bolster my expectations too high?
--fried egg sandwich: Again pretty good.  The eggs tasted good and the texture of the sandwich was better than i expected.  Plus the potatoes are awesome (and I'm not a potato person)!
--Chinese Breakfast: (caramelized pork shoulder, ginger, chili paste, two fried eggs, Jasmine rice) The pork shoulder was pretty good.  I felt like it could have been a  bit more tender (sections were hard and dry) but overall a decent dish.
--Zoe's chicken apple sausage:  Another item i thought would be better, it wasn't bad perse but I guess i was expecting a more robust taste.  This wasn't that much better than the store bought stuff.

As i write this review I notice that I've overused the term 'pretty good'.  I think that's the problem.  For a place that everyone says is their favorite breakfast/brunch joint, I found the food to be only 'pretty good'.

4stars for the awesome location/decor and ambiance/friendly staff
2.5 stars for decent but overpriced food

3.5STARS
author: Anthony L.

description: It was a good brunch, but I prefer Serpentine or Outerlands. The wait for 2 on a Sat. morning was only about 30 min.
author: Katie L.

description:
This is my fave brunch spot in the history of brunch spots that I've been to. Quite extreme, I know, but you have to eat here to understand why I say this.

First of all, I always order the plow. Why? It lets you taste everything that is good and amazing at Plow. The pancakes... the best thing ever! Lemon ricotta pancakes. I haven't tried a better pancake anywhere else. They're so light and the flavour is just amazing (I eat them without syrup all the time because they taste so good). My bf and I have been trying to make them ourselves and we never get close to the quality and delicateness of Plow. 

Second, the potatoes! I love the crispy potatoes! They'd be the equivalent to homefries at any other brunch place, but these things are amazing! They're tossed in some salt, pepper and rosemary (and maybe other things that I just don't know about) and they add the perfect little crunch to the plow platter. 

The wait can be a little long since they don't have much space to seat people, but it's always worth the wait for me. I love this place! It keeps me coming back every time.
author: Leanne M.

description:
Went here for the first time for Saturday breakfast. Had the "Plow" with lemon-ricotta pancakes & pork sausage.

The stand-out of the dish was certainly the pancakes... WOW. They were fantastic! I thought the house made pork sausage was a little dry, I wish I'd ordered the bacon or chicken apple sausage instead. My poached eggs were cooked to perfection. The potatoes were good but I wish they weren't deep fried. Coffee was excellent, and they had organic sugar on the table which was a big plus.

The wait here at 830AM was 45 minutes. This place is very popular.
author: Tala D.

description:
Plow.  A longstanding brunch obstacle, because I knew the endurance it would take.  And after being burned in the past by extraordinarily long waits for brunch and less than stellar food as my reward, I have to admit, I was a little hesitant to give Plow the chance.  

But I finally did, this past weekend.  And it was worth it.  Admittedly, the wait was lengthy.  Probably about an hour or so.  But that was to be expected.  And honestly, who cares about an hour wait, if it's good weather?  Wandering around Portrero Hill, stopping into some cute shops, getting tea at Farley's - it's not a bad way to spend an hour. 

And I would say the food is worth the wait, maybe not on a regular basis, but certainly once in a while.  I got the Plow, a combination of two small lemon ricotta pancakes, two eggs, bacon or sausage and potatoes.  Those potatoes.  . . oh man.  I don't know what they put in them (rosemary?  thyme?) but they are crispy and delicious.  The only food item I would complain about - the bacon . . . while tasty, I wish I had specified crispy, because they serve it kind of floppy and under cooked.  But other than that, everything was great.
author: Jenny R.

description: This place is awesome. I'm not a fan of the wait...especially when I'm starving for breakfast, but I tough it out like a champ because "the plow" is that good to me. That's my go to order. It has a little of everything. Lemon ricotta pancakes (yuuum), eggs, meat, potatoes. Real maple syrup. The bf grew up with the real stuff so this adds a star to his list.
author: Janny N.

description:
Delicious. I enjoyed lemon ricotta pancakes and pork sausage. Hubby had the fried egg sandwich. Unfortunately, they had run out of monkey bread by the time we were brunching, so I can only conjure up the taste in my dreams. The wait on a sunny Sunday was under an hour, which was worth it...even when we got distracted at the bookstore down the street and lost our table, forced then to wait another 10 or so minutes. But the hostess was very kind and accommodating, when she could have been hostile and persnickety.

Lovely atmosphere. Great food. Mmmmmm.
author: Kiesha R.

description:
Honestly - what restaurant doesn't have mustard?!
That alone irks me from not wanting to return. 

My BF and I waited 45 minutes for brunch on a Sunday, and we're completely underwhelmed.

We both ordered "The Plow" and should have "plowed" right through it on to a different menu item.

We got the housemade sausage and it was pretty bad. SO dry and tough and overly spicy - blech. The potatoes were in such large chunks that I had to cut all of them down in order to fit them in my mouth - not a pleasant experience. The eggs were fine - can you really mess up eggs? And THANKFULLY the lemon ricotta pancakes were superb!! That seriously saved our meal and kept me full.

I do have to say that the space is adorable - inside and out and the service was really wonderful. I asked the waitress for a thousand things (including mustard!!) and she didn't even bat an eye in annoyance.

I want to like this place, I really do - and perhaps I will give it another try?

But there's a bagel joint down the road that I think we would have done a lot better off, and about $10 less.
author: Sara D.

description:
My cofounder and I have been going to Plow for lunch lately.

- They have good eggs, though at the end of the day, they aree eggs.
- They have some pretty awesome lemon ricotta pancakes
- They do an excellent job with the crispy potatoes, which are the star of the show.

They are cut small so you get to taste the outer crispy portions and aren't dealing with bland insides. Also, they are server well done - they are quite crisp.

Definitely pick something which comes with the potatoes when you are there.

- "The Plow" lets you sample the eggs, the potatoes and the pancakes in meal.
- If you are seated outside, they offer you blankets - an interesting novelty.
- I'm told they have a 2 hour wait on weekends, so weekdays might be a better option.
- I haven't tried the Chinese Breakfast - it tends to always be sold out by the time we get there.
- Its Portrero Hill, so parking isn't terrible.
author: Kartik A.

description:
Had a great breakfast last Sunday morning and got there early before the real crowd started lining up!  Had the plow and my pertner had the breakfast sammy that was delicious also!  GREAT coffee and was even poured into a FOR HERE cup as we waited outside for a few minutes for our indoor table as I was put off by dining outside on the slope and the lack of sun that morning (I can be such a Princess sometimes!). The hostess and our wait staff all were friendly and efficient and I think THE PLOW I had with the house made sausage was one of the best breakfasts I've had in this food centric CITY!
Can't wait to go back!
CHEERS!
author: Sean M.

description:
Amazingly sad, but boycott Plow!

Living just around the corner in Potrero Hill, my family of 5 absolutely loved plow. Raved about them when they opened and throughout the year. My daughters both love their pancakes and potatoes, but a weekend ago I was horribly treated, and lied to by the lead wait staff, and owner.

My family was out of town for a few months and I was missing them, so I went to eat at Plow by myself to think about the kids and to make myself happy. It was a Sunday morning, around 10:30 am. As usual it was crowded, but I put my name in for a party of 1. I asked for a counter seat towards the wall, as at the time the only open seat they had was a ridiculously tight fit for a big guy like myself.

I waited extremely patiently for an hour, watching the spot close out and get ready to open up, what would have been two counter seats.

Still waiting, an SUV pulled up, one individual jumped out and put their name in on the wait list, while the other pulled around the block for parking.

By now, it has been 70 mins.

Around 80 mins into waiting, with clear sight and eye contact from the lead host, she walked out and called the party of the SUV. Where which the corner spot was given to the two individuals.

I thought to myself, should I just accept this, or say something? A patiently waiting customer, in queue, they should have given me that seat. I must have been at least 10 parties ahead when I put my name in.

Sure enough I marched in and confronted the lead host and asked why the two SUV individuals were seated A) ahead of me B) in the spot I had wait for 90 minutes.

The host first lied and said "they were a ahead of me." I pointed out if she looked two pages back my name was at the bottom with notes of where I wanted to sit, and that I would wait. Then the host said "they're a party of two, and there were two seats." At that point with my voice raising, the owner/manager walked over and tried to lie and cover up for the host. Not even knowing the facts. As I pointed out before, I was patiently waiting (for 90mins), and came first.

After additionally explaining my family and I have been loyal patrons since their opening, and highly promoted their establishment via word of mouth and social circles, I could no longer support their business with such greedy and poor ethical intentions. 

Boycott Plow. They're really not worth the wait... or worth your money.
author: Ana A.

description: The french toast and lemon ricotta pancakes are excellent! Ran into the owner outside one day and he sent us a free biscuit, which was maybe the best thing I've eaten all month.  Plus they make a lovely mimosa, which I appreciate as much, if not more, than the food.  The fried egg sandwich was only OK, little to great of a bread to substance ratio, IMHO. Don't park out front on Wednesday, as it is street sweeping day and you will get ticket!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
So far I've been obsessed with the Roast Pork sandwich, and would love to issue Plow with yet another 5 star review - BUT my last two sandwiches consisted more of inedible pork meat than edible.  
What in the world, Plow.  I know everyone loves you and that things get hectic, but I don't like to eat hunks of fat and blood vessels.  Or picking apart my sandwich trying to figure out what I can put in my mouth or not.  Please look closer at the meat before you put it in the sandwich next time.  I want to go back to the way things were.
author: Rachelle P.

description: Always a long wait but the food here... The food here was amazing. I was so full the entire day I didn't understand how tho. Lemon ricotta pancake was one of the best I've ever had. My girl had the crab salad and she said she was full for 7 or 8 hrs too. It's kinda small but we will def go again just 20 min before they open so we don't have to wait long lol
author: Andre D.

description:
I can keep going back here day after day and not get sick of it! I love their poached tuna sandwich (not always on the menu), but if not available then I get the chicken sandwich. Seriously ... SO DELICIOUS! Their lemon ricotta pancakes are the best.

The wait  on the weekends is LONG so try to go during the week (for lunch!) if in any way possible. And if you do go on the weekend and are unlucky and have to wait for an hour ... DO IT! It's worth it!
author: Em D.

description: Happy every time. To avoid the crazy line, I go really early on a weekday. Early bird gets delicious lemon ricotta pancakes.
author: Shum S.

description:
I've been here a couple times for weekend brunch. Overall, the food is outstanding. Plow serves a fancy twist on many classic breakfast and brunch favorites such as eggs, pancakes, sausage, french toast, etc. The ingredients taste fresh and all parts of the dish are carefully and thoughtfully seasoned.

Several items stood out for me. The "crispy potatoes" are similar to hash browns, but cut bigger. I don't usually care for hash browns, but the crispy potatoes at Plow are amazing; the perfect mix of crispy and savory. The french toast also stands out; they make it with really thick slices of fresh bread. The lemon ricotta pancakes left me wishing I had just ordered fifteen of them and nothing else!

I would have given five stars, but there is a price to pay for eating at Plow --- the wait. The two times I went were during lulls; I had "late brunch" at 2pm, and I had brunch during the holidays when most people were out of town. I waited 45min and 30min respectively, and I was lucky. The 45min wait would have been much longer, but two parties ahead of us changed their minds and left. I can only imagine what the wait must be like at "normal" hours. It's typical to see a crowd of people waiting outside Plow when you walk by on the weekend. A long wait is almost part of the experience! They don't take reservations so there is no way around it. Part of me wonders whether the food tastes so good simply because I'm starved by the time I get to eat it.
author: Laurent L.

description:
Wow! I was completely shocked today by Plow. I was quite happy with the food... The wait was a bit long but otherwise we got generally good breakfast service for a place that's typically busy on a Sat. Morning.
The shock came when, after paying the bill, the waitress came out to ask me if I was unhappy with service. I said, 'No' with the obviously perplexed face when she announced, in earshot of the other outside seated patrons around me, 'cuz your tip  was sad..'. 

OKAY! WOW! I tipped exactly 15% (having used my tip app)... I can't say I had spectacular service, I can't say I received poor service... I received service which included water and my food being brought to me... But I will say that this is the FIRST time, ever, that I've ever received a comment regarding my tip. Poor gals,... They must be hard pressed for money. I can't imagine begging aloud is going to bring it in any faster.

I am inspired to walk by patrons! before I leave, and suggest they leave 18% or more. The gals working there, need it.
author: Bernadette K.

description:
Plow is probably my favorite brunch spot in SF.  The location itself is pretty small and very homely / cozy, with huge windows that allow sunlight to pour in (especially valuable for those who don't enjoy as much sunlight due to living elsewhere in SF...).  If only I could park myself here on weekdays and read a book / eat breakfast every day... (and if only I had unlimited monetary resources...)

The food itself is delightful.  During my last visit, I ordered the almond flour pancakes, which are perfectly fluffy on the inside, with the right amount of almond flavor so as to deliver a rich taste without being overwhelming.  I've also ordered the french toast with strawberry compote, mascarpone, and syrup, which was tremendous.  I'm a vegetarian so I can't comment on meat dishes, but friends whom I have gone to Plow with all rave about the dishes they've gotten (everything from The Plow to the Nicoise salad).  Plow is also one of the few places that serve Equator coffee in SF (especially now that La Boulange is being acquired by Starbucks) - while expensive at $3.75 / cup (unlimited refills), it complements a meal perfectly.  Service is great given how hectic things seem to be every time I visit (which has always been on weekends), as the staff is very friendly.

The main negative aspect, as other folks have noted here, is the wait - it can be absolutely brutal at 1-2 hours on weekends.  That wait will get you a single table for 2 if you're lucky, or perhaps a seat at a table of 4 (typically shared with other people if your party is fewer than 4 people) or at the bar.  If you show up after 10:30am on a weekend, be prepared to wait a while ... with limited breakfast / brunch options nearby if you decide that you can't stand the wait.  Plow is also quite pricey for brunch (even by SF standards) - in my opinion, it's worth it, but coupled with the long wait it's something to keep in mind.

All in all, Plow is definitely worth visiting - and if you can make it work, visit on a weekday to avoid the brutal lines (note that they're closed on Mondays).
author: Rishi N.

description: Came here on a weekday at 1pm.  There was plenty of seating outdoors, but we opted for inside since it was a little chilly.  We had to wait about 20 minutes for a table.  I definitely dig the ambiance inside.  My friend and I ordered the soft scrambled eggs, the cherry tomatoes and goat cheese for me, and the oyster mushrooms and cheddar for her.  The mister ordered the plow.  My eggs were cooked perfectly and had a lot of flavor.  I can see why people rave about the crispy potatoes because they were very good.  I tried the lemon ricotta pancakes from the mister's plate, which made me wish I ordered them.  Overall, very tasty food and good, friendly service.
author: Thi D.

description: Hands down one of the best breakfast/ brunch spot in the bay area. Never disappointed with the food or the service here. I normally do not like waiting for getting a table this place is an exception. Do not forget the potatoes those are must have.
author: Rehnish P.

description: I was happy that the 6 of us could be seated at 9 am on a weekday - it was tricky enough at that time, so I'd never want to come on a weekend. I liked the single pancake options, which allowed us to try the lemon ricotta and the almond flour pancake. I never would have ordered them even though everyone always raves about them, so that was a great way to try without committing, and I did love them both. I was a bit less impressed with the crispy potatoes, which also get raves - I found them to be good, but they didn't really elevate fried potatoes to a whole new level of deliciousness for me. For me, it's not worth all the hassle and expense, but I'd definitely go back for another weekday brunch where someone else was paying in a heartbeat.
author: Lisa K.

description:
It's true that the wait for breakfast at Plow is usually long, but the line-up there is packed because people want to eat well prepared and healthy food that is fresh, local, and organic. The demand is therefore high. If you're an early riser, I'd recommend arriving at Plow at opening time in order to avoid the wait. 

I eat rather "clean" by following a Paleo/SCD diet, which advocates avoiding starches and consuming high quality meats, vegs, and fruits. Plow serves delicious meals that easily fit in with this eating philosophy. The Two Eggs dish is a great option for people following this diet. Note that the staff can swap the potatoes with greens.

Service and atmosphere are both very good. 

Plow is not a greasy spoon, so it is not going to satisfy palates accustomed to heavier fare, but if you are hungry, the Plow dish (two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes + crispy potatoes) is a great choice for people who are not on any restricted diets.
author: Kristina P.

description:
I LUFF PLOW.
Pretty much everything about it. The name conjures up fantastically dirty thoughts, the food is always amazing, and the service is adorbz.

I am going to forgo telling you about the potatoes, which are so magically perfect they are almost certainly fried in unicorn fat. I'll ignore the eggs, which come out great whether it be the soft scramble, shirred, or in the famously sandwiched form. I'll refrain from telling you how I thought I knew what a good pancake was until I had a lemon ricotta one from Plow- thereby rendering all other pancakes paltry puddles of tasteless batter by comparison.

What I want to talk about is the homemade organic yogurt and granola. Really. I know, I know, who the fuck goes to a restaurant, waits outside in the freezing cold for a table, and then orders yogurt and granola? I never thought I would admit it, but...that person is me. It comes with seasonal fruit (just had pear and persimmon, yum!) and local honey, and is honestly the perfect portion size. Just ignore your inner fatty/hungover gut one morning (as I did) and try it. You won't regret it. I mean, they MAKE their own yogurt. How cool is that?

One thing that I am always amazed with is the fairly reasonable prices, considering the fantastic quality of the ingredients. It really puts other restaurants to shame in that department. Most ingredients on the menu are labeled with where they came from, almost always from great local farms. I don't feel like I am raping the earth when I eat here. Bravo Plow!
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Got there on a Sunday morning around 10am and the wait wasn't too bad! About 35 mins for a party of 2 which is pretty reasonable for this place.

Ordered "The Plow" since I wanted to try a few different items (Not to mention, seems like everyone orders it so I figured it must be good).

Lemon ricotta pancakes were delicious. Less fluffy and more cakey which I liked and the lemon flavor was not overpowering. The crispy potatoes were good too. My sunnyside egg was okay although the yolk part ended up getting cooked in some parts so it wasnt as runny as it should be but otherwise, decent. The chicken sausages had a strange (but not in a bad way) taste although next time I think I'll try the bacon.

Probably not worth an hour+ wait but for 30 mins, I'd come back again
author: P W.

description:
I went for brunch on a Sunday around 11am. It was a two hour wait, which I already expected based on previous Yelp reviews. There were 8 of us and they can only take groups of 6 or 7 so they seated 6 of us outside and 2 of us inside.

Food wise - I ordered the plow, which was really good. The potatoes were crispy. I loved the lemon ricotta pancakes and the chicken apple sausage. I asked for poached eggs, but I wish they put hollandaise sauce on it or even some spices would have been good. Although I loved the food, I don't know if it was worth the 2 hour wait.

Either way, I think everyone should try this spot at least once! It's located in a really cool corner, surrounded by beautiful houses.
author: Reva B.

description:
Loved the ambience here. Super cute brunch spot, good for small groups and catching up with friends on the weekends.

I started with the Equator coffee (GREAT), and ordered the Plow for brunch.  I really enjoyed the home-made sausage, the over-easy eggs (not your average supermarket eggs) and crispy potatoes!!! The lemon ricotta pancakes were good, but not amazing.  If I ever come back, I'd probably order the chicken tinga.  I pretty much forced the dude to hand over his plate midway through our meal. YOINK.

Warning: be prepared to wait longer than the quoted time. We were told it would be a 35 minute wait, but ended up getting seated an hour and 15 minutes later.
author: C T.

description: Came here unknowing that this place is hyped like crazy. I was in the neighborhood when it opened first thing in the morning and I was trying to escape the cold rain. I was sad when I ran out of the lemon ricotta pancakes but fortunately everything else on the plate tasted good. I polished everything off and spared the dishwasher from having to wash my plate.
author: John B.

description:
Plow is one of those places I don't want to tell anyone else about. So, I'm not going to tell you about how their potatoes are perfect balance of crispy and fluffy, how the eggs are always cooked perfectly no matter the style, how their selection of teas is amazing, how the lemon ricotta pancakes will blow your mind etc. etc. 

Too many already know about Plow. The wait is always at least 45 minutes. Ah well, at least parking isn't generally a bitch and this patch of SF is generally pretty sunny too. 

People, avoid Plow!! Don't eat here!! Flee!! Flee!!! 

You definitely do not want to eat here because I do, a lot.
author: Andrea L.

description: I had cornmeal pancakes w a side of house made sausage. Yum! Real maple syrup. E had soft scramble w goat cheese n nettles-perfectly cooked she said.
author: Michael O.

description:
My boyfriend and I ventured into the city from Sacramento for a day of fun. We started the day at Plow, which was a great choice! The service was friendly and efficient.

The table was set with coffee mugs, which is an automatic plus for me. After I got some special juice in me, I ordered 'The Plow.' I figured, "When in Rome," right? The meal was delicious and quite savory, but the most memorable part was the miniature, lemon-flavored pancakes. 

I would certainly return. Only tip I can offer is to be prepared to wait for a table for up to an hour, but I assure you it's worth it.
author: Matthew K.

description:
For my first visit I tried the highly rated egg sandwich.  It did not disappoint!  The textures and flavors were spot on.  The staff was personable and attentive.  
I had a seat at the counter, I caught all the action.  The guys cookin' it all did a great job. Kudos.
author: Rob F.

description: It was a very delicious breakfast and I love that it's locally sourced. You can taste the quality of the ingredients in the end result. Minus one star for the one hour wait on the weekends. I won't be going back on the weekend, but would definitely go back during the week. The hosts and the wait staff are great! Highly recommend!
author: Stacy M.

description:
Pro:  DELICIOUS!  Friendly staff and rustic ambience.
Con:  Be prepared to wait!
author: Mindy H.

description:
Still freaking awesome...their seasonal pumpkin pancake is just as awesome as their meyer lemon ricotta pancake.  We can never decide which pancake to choose so I'll get one and my boyfriend gets the other and then we have a pancake trade.

We come here anytime we're up to endure the wait.  I still love it and the wait is still worth it.
author: Becca L.

description:
Sitting atop Potrero Hill on the corner surrounded by trees and benches is Plow. It is a small, hip, and trendy brunch spot. Their menu changes weekly, so come back often. The boast fresh organic produce from local farms, which is the norm in San Francisco, but not the standard.

Their french toast is crunchy outside with a custard-like creaminess inside, delicately sweet and garnished with fresh berries and a brulee'd banana. Served with subtle sweet Vermont syrup (not too sweet, not too thick, just perfect syrup). 

Lemon ricotta pancakes is my favorite and it's one of the reasons I keep coming back. I have convinced many patrons to try their lemon ricotta pancakes when I brunch here. They are dense with pockets filled with ricotta (a light cheese, similar to mozzarella) and a subtle lemon flavor. I've tried to replicate their lemon-ricotta pancakes and while my pancakes can be similar in taste, they do not have the same thick, rich and hearty elements that Plow creates.

The eggs benedict are okay. The star of the dish is the hollandaise sauce which I feel is too zesty.  Most holllandaise sauce has a mild creamy flavor with subtle tang, however Plow's hollandaise sauce has a robust tang that overpowers the other mildly flavored components. I suspect a heavy hand in lemon juice. Poached eggs cooked to perfection. 

"The Plow" is a good way to sample all of their good things (it comes with lemon ricotta pancakes -smaller version). The potatoes are tasty but their inconsistent size makes the large pieces stand out in buttery goodness and the tiny bits too burnt to eat. Their homemade sausages are a bit dry. However, you can't go wrong with the chicken apple sausages (yum). 

The house made organic yogurt + granola with fresh fruit is not worth it. I think that it could have used more berries and less citrus fruits in my honest opinion. 

The fried egg sandwich is okay. The nueske bacon makes it a tad better. The acme bun was lovely. Everything else was standard. 

The dungenous crab scramble was tasty. It had hearty pieces of crab meat. Definitely a go to dish to try. But I think it's a bit pricey at $17. 

The almond pancake was disappointing. I didn't taste any flavor of almond. But I suppose that it is a fan for gluten-free eaters. 

The counter seating is quite small and can be uncomfortable, however that's where you get to see the magic of everything being cooked. I like sitting outside because it's quieter. Inside its warm and loud. 

Price wise, I think it's expensive. IMO, I think that brunch should be $10 and under. Many of the dishes here can be made at home for the fraction of the price. The prices here $10-$17 per meal. Not including extra such as drinks or side dishes. The coffee alone is a whopping $3.75.

Overall, I think that the food is prepared well and presented beautifully. I will return because think their lemon ricotta pancakes are delicious. However, the prices, long wait, and hit-or-miss customer service pushes the over all rating down.
author: Ellie J.

description: The 80 minute wait was worth it! I had the salmon eggs benedict with crispy potatoes (that were actually crispy) and a mimosa and it was all delicious! I appreciate a spot that can execute well known breakfast options and still preserve a little originality.
author: MissM R.

description:
Worse French toast of my life... Omg that was terrible... The rest of the family all had great food but I couldn't wait to see my plate being taken away... 

Only 25-30 min wait outside but then long wait for foods at the table
author: Julien V.

description: This place does brunch right! Lemon ricotta pancakes are a must try and the potatoes are prepared oh so crispy!  Be prepared to wait in line...
author: S. D.

description: Chicken apple sausage, crispy potatoes and most of all ALMOND FLOUR PANCAKES were all amazing
author: Nate M.

description:
If life gives you lemons....make lemon pancakes instead of lemonade.

Plow's are wait worthy delicious. The lemon flavor really stands out and gives a new twist to this breakfast standard. Huge fan of the flavor and innovation.

Fortunately they can also be ordered as side. Gives you a chance to complement with something else from the tough to decide menu. Never will turn down house granola. And this one comes with house yogurt and peaches. Good, though $8 was a bit pricey.

Not as enamored with lunch. Smoked salmon salad had a good amount of fish, but the grapefruit was missing and the dressing was an unexpected add. Wish the menu had called that out.

Space buzzes as you'd expect from such a popular destination. Solo on a Friday morning meant a 10m wait for a counter seat. The view of all the brunch creationism was pretty cool. Brunch with friends is one of life's greatest pleasures, but this is a good one to hit by yourself and the newspaper.

Save some counter space for the pancakes.
author: Jason B.

description:
Went for first visit for Sunday brunch. Can't remember the last time I waited 2 hours for food. If we didn't have our iPads it would have been super painful.

As one reviewer said it looks like going right before they close is the way to do it. Or go back during the week as I did.

Lemon ricotta pancakes are heavenly.
author: Melanie N.

description:
YES, the lemon ricotta pancakes are as good as everyone says. You might be thinking, "Really? Lemon...and ricotta? How amazing can it be?" Let me tell you. Amazing. Nearly life-changing. I couldn't stop thinking about it for the rest of the day. I'M THAT SERIOUS. And I don't even like ricotta. 

They do not skimp on the bacon either! Get "the plow" if you can't decide between sweet and savory. (But to be honest, about an hour later I wished I had gotten the full serving of the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes. SO GOOD.)

Came in on a Thursday afternoon @1pm. Got seated at the bar within 5 minutes. Score! Space is tight, but the food is worth it!

Staff is wonderful and the atmosphere is very fun. Seems very kid-friendly as I saw multiple families there with their little ones.
author: Moraia W.

description:
Four stars for potential.

My friend and I tried the lemon ricotta pancakes and the dungeness crab scrambled eggs.

The scramble was quite tasty. Although the flavor of scallions dominated the dish, I'm a fan of scallions - so it was fine by me! The scramble didn't really have a crab flavor - but there were large chunks of delectable crab meat - eminently enjoyable! 

5 stars for the breakfast potatoes as well - perfect crunch outside, soft inside.

3 stars for the lemon ricotta pancakes. They were well-cooked and the lemon flavor was subtle but good, but somehow they didn't live up to expectations (perhaps because we ate them second and they were cold).

Slight negative: they only have drip coffee. Would have loved to have had my morning latte there...

Hope to return sometime soon!
author: Helen D.

description:
We violated the cardinal rule of Sunday Brunch, which is to be a lazy bum and roll out of bed incoherently to eat at an hour where the rest of the world could have done half a day's work already. Instead we got up at 7:30 so we could avoid the line. So technically, we didn't have brunch, we had breakfast and believe it or not, if you get there at 8:30, you might still have to wait b/c they stagger the first seating (outside and inside). 

The inside has an open but farmy feel, the outside is on the sidewalk on a steep hill - VERY challenging to avoid getting a sunburn and if you are facing up the hill, its a work out just to get your head close enough to the plate to eat your food. Plus the time we got our food, half the block was a waiting area for ravenously hungry Brunch-seekers, so I'd vote to sit inside. The servers are very nice and do a good job.

- Monkey bread - don't be deceived, this is NOT banana bread - its like a cinnamon roll and french toast hybrid - tasty
- Donut - a bit dry but still a good cake donut
- Egg Sandwich - Big, messy, technically challenging to eat, and yummy
- Bacon - Its bacon, you will like it unless there is something wrong with you
- Crispy potatoes - In fact crispy but a bit bland
- Pork Sausage - Pretty light and tasty
- Lemon ricotta pancakes - Light, fluffy, lemony, one of the best pancakes I've had
- Almond flour pancakes - Also light and fluffy, but tasted like a regular pancake, not a hint of almond to be found.

While this place is tasty, its not wait-for-an-hour-and-get-a-sunburn-tasty. And don't get me started about the bathroom line - OY.
author: Snuffles B.

description:
Lemon...ricotta....pancakes. Nuff said.

Ok just a couple more things to add because I can't help myself. The food was so fantastic that I almost ate myself sick. From the starter salad with Kobucha squash to the pancakes to the Scramble dish...everything was perfect.

The food and beverage are fresh, local, and seasonal. I personally prefer a mimosa/coffee combo after a particularly intense party session.

Pain in the ass that they don't take reservations because the line is so long. However I've found that if you get there around 9ish, you're pretty good to go.
author: Lana M.

description: Great place. Highly suggested if you like fresh, locally grown great good. Not the cheapest but better food isn't.
author: John G.

description:
I'm gonna name my kid after this place. My mind was blasted and they had to clean my brain off the walls. Brunch is my favorite meal and Plow is the perfect reminder as to why I love it so much. They just know how it get it done. It's been a while since I've been blown away with delicious weekend munchies, but Plow did it to me and they're worth the hour wait. 

Biscuits and gravy, baby! That's alls I gotta say. Biscuits and gravy. Why they gotta be so good? Why everyone gotta be so nice here?? Why can't I stop eating?? Why I talkin' so funny and annoying right now?? The eggs benny had no chance. Lemon ricotta pancake scarfed down. Two words are your friend when deciding to come here.... elastic pants.
author: Jen Y.

description: Lemon ricotta pancakes and Equator coffee. Other stuff is good but the pancakes are what you go for. Honorable mention- their bread and butter is somehow amazing. I don't find their egg breakfast items to be over the top but a main staple
author: Sigorney S.

description:
Simple, yummy breakfast. 

It might sound silly, but their eggs are perfectly, lovingly scrambled. Just soft and creamy enough and oh-so-fluffy. It's my benchmark for how great a brunch place is, and this place is a winner. 

The lemon ricotta pancakes are quite delicious as well. The plow includes the pancakes, eggs, bacon, and crispy potatoes (what?!) Go to Plow and get the Plow, please.

Just one caveat: there's usually an hour-ish long wait, so be wary of that. It's the only thing that stops me from going all the time.
author: Helen Z.

description:
2-hour wait for an egg sandwich. 

Note to self: Only come to Plow in pairs. 

Dining is not just about the food but about the experience that comes along with it, and as each party of 2 came strolling in after my party of 3 and got seated first I got progressively more hungry and irritable. 

Not even the Plow potatoes could make-up for the 2-hours of my life that I will never get back! Hmph.
author: Denise L.

description: Favorite place for brunch. The almond flour pancakes are overwhelmingly mouthwatering and the chia pudding is so good too. Everything I've had is just perfect. I love the ingredients they use and the list of all the local farms they source from. That's most important to me. But I don't like to wait in lines so I don't go on the weekends
author: Cel H.

description:
The chill of being a nightmonger planted the audacity for attempting brunch at Plow. My nights consist of shifting through drunk hipsters, ugly, tipsy women, and walking through the bitter frost of the bay. These taxing experiences drifted me, my bro, L, and M to Potrero Hill for a taste of morning goodness.

In return for our wayfaring we received a 1 hour wait and a Cirque Soleil feast for our eyes. Men in sparkling jackets danced over taxi riding fatties blocking the view of two grannies that chilled like villains whilst we basked in the spontaneous San Francisco sun. If only I had had a Mimosa to sip on.

The Mimosa never came to be. Like fish we breathed 4 to 5 wine bottles of water and blew bubbles of laughter and irony about the establishment. Our waiter, the water slug, oozed herself into being for our ordering of The Plow and never fully materialized again. And to her I have one statement: "A slow to come, quick to go mantra only works in certain circumstances. It is particularly not helpful in a food serving establishment."

Our "slow to come" food was graced by one item I will never forget..... The Lemon Ricotta Pancake. This edible specimen was bred between a slice of pound cake and a lemon drop. It's deliciousness, moistiness, and solid, cake-like composure are in a league of their own. I raise a Mimosa to The Lemon Ricotta Pancake. Hip hip nom Nom NOM.

Come to Plow to get plowed by the experience and make sweet love with pancakes but go somewhere cheaper to eat with less remorse.
author: Savier M.

description:
Very cute neighborhood brunch spot. We waited for about 15 minutes before getting a table outside on a beautiful Sunday. The tables were so close together, that once one person sits, the other person behind you can't move. So, we met our friends here for some lemon ricotta pancakes, dungeness crab scramble, and fried soft shell crab sandwich thing. Originally the waitress said there was no more monkey bread left because we were just inquiring what it is. Then she came out and told us, of course, we snatched it up!! So a monkey bread is basically a cinnamon swirl bread inside out. Um...when it's nice and warm, it's quite amazing. 

So ... I had the scramble. It was pretty good, definitely a good amount of crab. I did order a side of bacon and it was over cooked. Wayyy too crispy.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Ugh!  Down to 2 stars after a series of disappointing experiences here.

I'll say up front: the menu is terrific and the food is delicious.  But the downsides:
- Long waits are common.  Really long.  Like an hour or more, even on weekdays. 
- No waiting inside - so you are out in the cold (though they do offer coffee - which is very nice).
- No heat lamps for the outdoor seating.  I'd come back if they just made this one change.  At this time of the year, the sun doesn't hit that part of the street and it was freezing on our last visit.
- Service has been slipping.  On this last visit, our server forgot to put our order in and we waited for an hour (in the cold, at our outdoor table) after also waiting for about 45 minutes to get the table.  Not fun.  At least they did give us a big discount but it was still a miserable experience.

And for all of this, you get to pay $3.75 for a cup of coffee (seriously?  I can buy a 12oz bag of Equator beans for $13) and $15+ for most of the dishes - so brunch can easily end up being close to $50 for 2 people.

Adding this all up, it's a bad value - even for San Francisco.  My go-to for Potrero now is going to be Universal Cafe.
author: Maggie L.

description: As awesome as advertised!  Everything we got was delicious.  It's a bit on the expensive side, but definitely worth it.  It's not a very big place, so try your best to go on a week day.
author: David W.

description:
3.5 stars. Plow does NOT make it easy to get to by public transportation. My fault. Catching a bus from North Beach on Giants game day is most likely the worst decision in recent SF traveling history. The bus jostled me all the way down and fortunately dropped me off only a block away, but never again - it took took me more than an hour.

Ahem, I got my order to-go (and yes, it was rather cold by the time I dug in) but from a quick glance the ambiance is super nice. Buuutt, I can see why it gets ridiculous on weekends. They really haven't much space inside for more than maybe 9 measly groups.. a couple tables outside. A bit like the old Outerlands format, but marginally larger.

I ordered the Plow since I don't expect I'd be making this trip again (why on earth are you near absolutely nothing, Plow?!) as it comes with 2 eggs any style, crispy potatoes, sausage or bacon, and those lemon ricotta pancakes. The potatoes are hot goodness. Even an hour later sitting in that compostable take-out box. Ohmy. The sausage is top-notch too, even though I don't usually order meat with my breakfast (chicken apple, if you're wondering the flavor!). The pancakes, which I was really anticipating, were not as rich as I was hoping. I guess I'm a fatty. I was hoping for a bit more creaminess/ricotta to burst out and shine, but it's very subtle. It isn't dry as some others have commented, but definitely not the best pancakes I've ever had either. They're too dense, perhaps griddle cakes would be a better term. Also, (TMI alert) I tasted lemon from when I ate it in the afternoon til I went to sleep which makes me think there must have been some kind of lemon extract or something in there cause it was way too strong.... just my opinion.

I wish I'd shared it with someone and perhaps taken in the restaurant a bit more casually, but I'd have to say the food I ate wasn't really worth coming all the way over. Glad I tried it, but not going again.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Potato, potahto, however you say the name of this tuberifous vegetable, you must eat them at Plow if you are in San Francisco. Yes, the wait on any given day is pretty crazy--odd that it is in such a residential area--but I assure you that it is worth your time.

The restaurant is small and quaint, so they are really consistent at cranking out good grub to a few people at a time. I believe that they take care in each dish, and it comes out in the offerings, primarily the potatoes.

The lemon ricotta pancake was fluffy and creamy; it boasted just a touch of sweetness balanced with a hint of lemon, to boot. The duckfat cornmeal pancake possessed this tartness from possibly buttermilk? It was just rich and fluffy, with a touch of crispness. The coffee crumbcake was just OK, unfortunately. Lots o' blueberry, but sort of a mealy texture and light flavor.

Onto the actual food. The crispy potatoes are the best I have ever had in the "roasted" category, bar none. Honestly just outrageously delicious potatoes. The soft scrambled eggs were good, but nothing fancy. But... the potatoes. Yes, they are mighty fine and just so... dang.... GOOD.

Plow falls into that category "sleek" eatery with one word with only a few letters like "Cow" or "Meat" or "Brunch." Does it match up to all of the like? 100%, yes.
author: Solomon W.

description: WARNING TOURISTS:  Although you will have a good breakfast here (everything on the menu is great, although not sure it's worth the line, given all of the good food in SF), if you arrive in a rental car or leave anything visible in your car while eating here, there is a very good chance you will have your car broken into during your meal. Every day, in broad daylight, sometimes right across the street from Plow, car thieves have been successfully breaking into cars (targeting rental cars or out of state plates) and stealing people's bags/computers/cameras/etc. Each time it seems the victims had just eaten at Plow (it attracts a lot of tourists - people who have valuables in their cars and who aren't aware of the high level of break ins in SF or who don't expect it to happen in broad daylight in front of people). Plow used to have a small sign posted but it was really small and hard to see -- and it seems as though they either took it down or it's not prominent enough for people to notice. We have asked them repeatedly to make the notice more prominent as their customers are getting robbed daily, to no avail. Almost to a person, the victims say that they didn't see any warning or else they would have hidden their stuff. This is easy to fix - if you choose to eat here, please hide your stuff.
author: Erin R.

description:
Went here last Friday for lunch. Its a great place for brunch on any day. 

Had The Plow which consisted of 2 eggs, 2 pieces of meat and pancakes (yes the Ricotta one) and those tasty potatoes. The pancakes aren't as hyped up as people make it, I thought the French Toast was substantially better. Overall, pretty good, left full. 

Otherwise, I prefer this place over a lot of other options mainly due to the quaint neighborhood, easy parking, and those tasty potatoes... Will be back soon
author: Justin L.

description:
Fast & Great Service, Well made food sourced from local farms!
Best brunches ever!

Great designed restaurant, heard it incorporated meaningful + interesting salvaged materials from the west coast (tables made from French oak barrels and floors from an old Washington State hop house)....

My most favorite thing on the menu is their "lemon ricotta pancakes".....
author: Rae R.

description: Delicious! One of the best places I ate at while visiting San Francisco. We sat outside so the wait wasn't long, but even if you do have to wait, the food is worth it. Their lemon ricotta pancakes were killer and potatoes so tasty! I can't put enough exclamation points in this review to fully articulate my experience.
author: Kevin M.

description: This place always seems to be crowded but had good food with friendly service. I wasn't blown away by any of the brunch items ordered but would definitely go back if in the area hungry and ready to wait in line.
author: Ashley F.

description:
Tasty, comfortable, reasonably priced, diverse menu, and the staff was very accomodating.  I would definitely come back to Plow, but not sure that I would go out of my way to come back here.  It's definitely one of the better brunch places I've gone to in SF though.

We ordered the "Plow"  and the Scrambled eggs and definitely were not disappointed in either dish.  But I felt like there was nothing really extraordinary about the dishes either.
author: Michael C.

description: Yes, the crispy potatoes were good.  So was the egg scramble.  My sister's egg sandwich looked good too.  But we all agreed that although the food was good, it wasn't worth the cost ($15 for scrambled eggs and potatoes) now was it worth the 1.5 hours it took me to get to the place, or the hour-and-15-min wait worth it.  They kept seating parties of 4 before us even though we'd signed in before them, and the "hostess" kept asking us if we wanted to sit outside--but it was showering already and, really, outside when it's showering?  Sorry, you could have seated us before some of those 4-somes, gotten them to sit outside.  Now, maybe you have to be one of those people who really doesn't know how to cook very well so is impressed with the food served here.  But since all 3 of us cook rather well, and I could have tossed together scrambled eggs with oyster 'srooms myself....  Yea, potatoes were good and something I don't normally eat but servings are too big (my sister and I could have shared one serving)--and I hate wasting food.  The chefs are ace though, looked like every single order they sent out was perfect.  I just don't think it's worth the time and money and is "trendy."  Since you do have to wait so long, they ought to at least offer you something while you're waiting--free coffee or something.  And anyone eating there ought to keep in mind that there are a lot of other people outside waiting--SO YOU DON'T SIT THERE GABBING FOR HOURS after you finish eating, take yourselves elsewhere if you want to continue the conversation and free up a table; this isn't the place to hog a table considering their limited business hours.  And, incidentally, there are a couple eateries along 18th St. that looked perfectly good to me, plus Goat Hill pizza is within about 3 blocks--all good alternatives to this place.
author: Kai T.

description:
Came here on the early-ish side on a weekday to avoid the lines.  Definitely the right move (yay weekday mornings off! (perks of not working a 9-5 job!!))
Lived up to the hype, food was great, service was attentive. Probably not worth an hour long wait, but honestly, what is?
author: Emma A.

description:
Maybe I'm old fashioned. I don't do trendy foodie-type places but we had friends coming in from out of town and they wanted to eat here. I should have known better.

Got there at 10:30 and put our name on the list. I heard them tell the people in front of us that the wait was an hour. Then when I asked, they told me 45 minutes. So we started to wait. One positive is that they serve free coffee while you are waiting. I ended up have 4 cups while waiting the HOUR and a HALF to be seated. Now, I don't care how great the food is.....an hour and a half for eggs and bacon is absurd.

Ok. We waited that long so the service better be extraordinary and the food exceptional. Nope. Waitress was nice but didn't listen to us nor did she go out of her way to be helpful. She asked if I wanted more coffee. I said no and ordered a beer. She brought the beer and refilled the coffee?!?!? We had a child with us. She spilled some OJ on the table and waitress literally watched us clean it up with one of the napkins from the table and didn't offer to replace the napkin. I got up and literally got one myself. We asked for her recommendation on the best 2 items on the menu and she pretty much started at the top and read every item. I'm not sure she has ever eaten anything there.

Now the food. I thought it would be great, seeing as everyone in the restaurant was taking pictures of their meals before eating them. It's BREAKFAST....how great could it be? I ordered the PLOW, which is bacon and eggs. Like I said, I'm old fashioned. Only thing I wanted was my eggs over medium. Guess what? I got runny yolks...way closer to over easy. Rest of the plate was fine. I would not have waited 10 minutes for it and won't do so again.

So overall we waited too long, got mediocre service, food was not prepared to order but was otherwise acceptable. Next time, I'm making "brunch" at home.
author: Sergei A.

description:
Picking a favorite brunch spot in San Francisco is a little like deciding which of your children you love the best.  There are many worthy contenders, hence the significance of my ordination of Plow as personal  favorite was a choice well considered.

I was primed to love this place when we drove up and saw expectant diners waiting patiently on every corner adjoining the restaurant, sipping delicious coffee on the house.  A second indication of the fine feast to come was the plump, perfectly contented pig which graces each menu and serves as the restaurant's icon.   I studied the menu carefully and greedily as we waited.

Ordering a 1/2 "appetizer" portion of the French Toast with caramelized apples, mascarpone, and maple syrup seemed like the right thing to do, and it was a good call indeed, every bite moist, rich and delightful.  

The next course for me was a combination plate that sounded and tasted too good to be true:  a festival of flavors including extraordinary lemon ricotta pancakes, perfectly crispy home fried potatoes and housemade fennel sausage.  Paired with eggs, this terrific trio took me on a non-stop flight to gastro-paradise.   

My girlfriend loved her soft scrambled eggs with merguez sausage and even conceded to the home fry perfection, quite an accomplishment given that ambivalence is generally the best a breakfast potato can hope for from her.  We both loved the fresh squeezed orange juice, too, an item I can safely say we hold to nearly-impossibly-high standards.
 
The open layout, simple decor and beautiful photography created a pleasant ambiance, and our server was a picture of attentiveness and calm amidst the bustling scene.

There will be many return visits.
author: Derek W.

description:
If you are indecisive (like me) get the plow so you can get a taste of everything. The plow is two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes + crispy potatoes.

The pancakes sound weird but they are definitely worth trying. The home fries are unique since they have both crunchy and chunky pieces. There are small pieces that are basically French fries and others that are like home fries. It is an awesome mix since you usually only get home fries for breakfast. All in all a wonderful start to my Sunday. 

Although the wait was pretty long, the service was great so I am more than willing to come back for the plow anytime.
author: Jayne A.

description: The potatoes are seriously like the best breakfast potatoes I've ever had..roughly chopped with crispy edges. I wasn't too crazy about the scrambled eggs, something about them was off. The lemon ricotta pancakes were not fluffy. I like fluffy pancakes. The biggest turn-off was that you may get stuck either sharing a table or getting seated super close to another table. Please. Can we get a little space? It's just awkward. I'm definitely going to go back for the french toast and give their other dishes another try.
author: Sawsan D.

description:
Good brunch place, very long wait! 
The food is not bad, it just doesn't worth the wait. We had egg beni and pancakes, tasty but really nothing special. I have been to many other better places.

The potato was so salty , but we finished all in a hurry since we were so hungry .
author: Ting R.

description:
Get. The. Crispy. Potatoes.

Look, everything here is outrageously delicious, fresh, and not at all overpriced, but BY GOD, you'd better include some crispy potatoes with whatever else you get. I had the plow and my wife had the almond pancakes, and both of our dishes were incredibly tasty, blah, blah -

But the potatoes? Oh man, the potatoes. I have dreams about those things. Dreams that turn into nightmares when I realize I don't actually have them. They're super-crispy, flavorful, and incredimazing. My wife broke her no-potatoes rule to eat them, and by 'them', I mean half my portion. I couldn't blame her, either - they're that good.

Also, service is nice, especially considering that it's always crowded, and yes, prepare yourself for about an hour wait on the weekends, depending. It's worth it. It's really, really worth it.
author: Matthew L.

description:
The pertinent question: "Is it worth the wait?"
......Does the pope shit in the woods?
author: C L.

description: Food was ok. Had to try the highly recommended lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes, hoping to be impressed with zesty fluffiness and savory heartiness---Disappointed. Perhaps there were high expectations, but definitely had better. 3 stars may be a bit generous.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Crispy potatoes so good that when I dropped one on the floor I thought "5 second rule!"
4 year old said, "when I finish my French toast can I order another one?" even though he had a full adult sized portion.
Go early and get a spot. This place fills up fast and has a line around the corner!
author: krystin k.

description:
Lemon ricotta pancakes were only ok. The texture was not as light and fluffy as I has hoped, but the flavor was just sweet enough and delicate. 

Their coffee cake was out of this world, though! Why I didn't see any notes on the cake is beyond me. We ordered this as an afterthought.  My cousin an I took one bite and all conversation stopped. All we could do is chew, smile, and make "mmm" sounds for like 5 minutes! 

Everything else we ordered was as good as expected, based on the other reviews.
author: Andy C.

description: One word for this spot - overrated.  You're going to wait forever, and end up with a decent breakfast that's way overpriced.  Forget about customizing your order for what you want because Plow does not do made to order - they are too self-important for that.  If you want to grab a coffee, wait in line for an hour plus, and enjoy the experience, do it one time - but if you want a great breakfast, I'd suggest you look elsewhere.
author: Adam F.

description:
I've only had breakfast here. Love their homemade sausage.The crispy potatoes are different and good! The do a lot of different things here which I really appreciate. The only issue I have is the pancakes are always under-cooked. They are still wet in the middle. I'll have to request my pancakes "well" in the future.
Nice little spot with very nice people, good food and great service.
author: Ron U.

description: De-lightful! First, I must say I've never had such pleasant service for brunch in SF. 5 stars for Katie, our server. Parking was easy, but the wait was killer, close to 2 hours, however it makes sense since the place is tiny and they don't rush you. We put our name down and made a Philz Coffee run with time to spare. Nonetheless! Loved how they had a sweet and savory option - The Plow - with 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, crispy potatoes and your choice of house made sausage patties, chicken apple sausage or bacon. Overall, a sweet neighborhood gem. Would probably come back if the wait weren't so long!
author: Lisa H.

description: Best breakfast/brunch place in the city. I met up with my boyfriend on a Saturday around just before noon. Be prepared to wait a good hour for a table in this tiny little spot. Once we tasted the food, it was no wonder there was a line. I had the lemon ricotta pancakes and my boyfriend had the soft scrambled eggs with the most delicious breakfast potatoes ever! The place was a bit cramped, we shared a table with another couple which was fine. The pancakes were to die for and the service was great. Love Plow.
author: Denisse R.

description: I guess this is what happens when you have REALLY high hopes for a place.  Brunch was good, but nothing to write home about.
author: Susan Y.

description:
I ate here a couple weeks ago with my mom and sister. Parking was pretty easy to find, but it might take a couple trips around the block. The wait was around 45 minutes as promised.. A few groups got to be seated sooner, but sadly a bunch of groups came back who had been passed up on the list earlier.

Mom and sister both got the plow, and I had some of theirs. From all of the rave reviews, I was really expecting to be "wowed" by the lemon ricotta pancakes. I found them to be yummy but nothing special. They did have very good crispy potatoes though.

I had the french toast with kumquat compote. Sadly, I was very unimpressed by this dish. It was okay, but I make better french toast. I finished it though. It was not inedible. They did have some yummy bacon which i ordered as a side.

Customer service was friendly, which is always a plus. The girl working the front door and our waitress were both very nice. As far as eating here again, I wouldn't go out of my way for it, but if the occasion arose, I wouldn't protest.
author: Alison A.

description:
French Toast doesn't get better than this.

French Toast is, most usually, the dish I order when going out to breakfast/brunch. Up until now it's been a matter of comparing dishes that are that are ok to terrible but it's not fair to even think of comparing Plow to anywhere else. The Crispy Potatoes are amazing as are the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and of the egg dises I've had, the scrambled eggs are delicious.

The excellence of the food has to, of course, be attributed to great chefs but also to the quality of the ingredients all sourced from local farms.

The only gripe I can make is about their coffee which, as one would correctly assume, is excellent but the $3 per cup (free refills) price tag is a bit steep.

Based on various other reviews here, I've never considered going on the weekend but have never had to wait more than five minutes for a table on a mid-morning weekday and have never had an issue with parking. However, if you can only make it on the weekend I would say that the wait is worth it.
author: Alasdair S.

description: Got The Plow and the ricotta pancakes was tangy and the texture was like bread pudding- so good! My fave has to be the potatoes- crunchy and soft at the same time, and perfectly seasoned! Get the plow- a bit of everything!
author: Rae C.

description:
Delicious food. Good service. Aims pancakes are amazing. 
Hate  the long wait, even during the week. Place is very small and crowded. 
Wish they had espresso drinks but their coffee is pretty good. 
Wish there were more gf options and baked goods.
author: K C.

description: Breakfast of champions! The signature 'Plow' breakfast dish was amazing. I loved the Ricotta lemon pancakes and the pork sausages were divine.
author: Eoin H.

description:
So...Where do I start? My two girlfriends and I came on a Sunday afternoon, expecting the wait. We showed up around 11, and were told it would be an hour and a half wait. Yikes. Luckily, we had a lot to catch up on and the weather was absolutely perfect for spending walking around the area. An hour passed and we managed to swipe a spot on a planter nearby to sit upon. An hour and a half passed and there was still one more party of 3 to be seated before us. Just short of two hours passed and we were seated at the bar facing the open kitchen.

The three of us knew Plow was known for their lemon ricotta pancakes and made sure we ordered those. We also decided upon the hash, soft scrambled eggs, and french toast. As a side, we ordered the heirloom tomato salad. After ordering, we waited another likely 45 minutes to be served. They were busy and there were just two cooks preparing the food for all the patrons. 

It was far too much food for three rather small women, but we gladly forced ourselves to finish it all. Our brunch wasn't cheap (all that food plus drinks for each of us), but was WELL worth it, as was the wait. I will gladly return at the next opportunity that arises. Although, hopefully that will happen earlier in the morning so as to reduce that impressive wait.
author: Lily R.

description:
A lot of care clearly goes into the dishes here.  Best evidence are the potatoes that come with the dishes: Even for very fine breakfast establishments, home fries or hash browns or whatever the accompanying spud side happens to be, is often an afterthought and underwhelming.  At Plow, the potatoes must be cooked twice.  They appear to be smashed before frying which likely means they were boiled or blanched first.  They are seasoned liberally (but not overly) with prominent rosemary.  They are ridiculously good!  This care extends to the house-made sausage patties, lemon ricotta pancakes, biscuits and perfectly runny eggs.  Ingredients are all locally-sourced and periodic wine-paired dinner events involving local vintners are a real plus.  

Plow serves as an anchor establishment in a classic San Francisco neighborhood, but, for better or worse (depending on whether you live close by, I guess), it has become one of the hottest breakfast tables in the City.  This reputation is well-deserved based on our experience.  The chef-owners' hearts are very clearly in the right place evidenced by the menu planning and preparation of the offerings.  It is very possible that the project that is Plow has taken on a life of its own, exceeding its initial space for sure and maybe even the scope that was intended.  That is certainly not the owners' fault and, yes, maybe the wait and crowds detract from the entire experience, but, in my opinion, the vision of a locally-sourced, locally-grounded restaurant that serves great food should be supported and congratulated.  Not everyone wants to own a restaurant, but, if we did, isn't this what we would hope for ourselves?
author: The K.

description: Well worth the wait!  Possibly the best breakfast I have eaten out!  Lemon Ricotta pancakes, the size of a coffee cup saucer were INCREDIBLE!!!
author: Kevin S.

description:
This urban-country localvore spot is a gem in Potrero. Plow boasts an open, airy kitchen and just handful of tables, mason jars full of herbs for decor and a small but delectable menu of farm fresh goods done well. 

We tried a veggie scramble with goat cheese, fava greens and mushrooms with a side of perfectly done potatoes and lemon ricotta pancakes. Perfect for a rainy day breakfast.

Fun fact: the sweet owners also own Ruby Wine around the corner, a great wine shop and an asset to our neighborhood.

I will be back! I can't wait to try lunch.
author: Amber K.

description: Can you say the world stopped for a second? Well that's how I felt when I took my first bite! The French toast is flavorful and puffy; just perfect. Plow will defiantly become a recurring SF breakfast spot for me! Only draw back is the size of the restaurant. It is small inside so the wait can be 30-45 minutes. They offer a cute sitting area outside so you can enjoy the weather on a nice day. The atmosphere is pleasant as well as the staff.
author: Dulcemari G.

description: OMG, this place is phenomenal! I waited outside for 45 minutes, but it was worth it. Just bring an iPad or a book. Their housemade pork sausages were a REVELATION. The service was impeccable, fast and the staff was super friendly even though they were slammed. Go!
author: Jacob W.

description:
First off, couldn't resist a "Go Aggies!"--I did not know that Plow was co-owned by a fellow Aggie, until my friend Mindy pointed it out.  Very cool to see Aggie alum out and doing what they are passionate about. :-)

I stumbled upon Plow using Yelp Nearby on my Android phone in Dec '10 when my buddies and I finished up the Anchor Steam brewery tour.  Unfortunately at that point people decided it was easier to go back to The Marina (joy.)  Since then I have been wanting to check out Plow purely for the solid reviews and the lemon ricotta pancakes! :-)

When we decided to grab breakfast in SF this weekend, I suggested it and even though it was off the beaten path, people thought we should check it out!  My buddy Richard made it on time (9:30am) when we said we would meet and put in our name for a table of 6.  A little over an hour later we sat down.  The kitchen was bustling and people seemed to be enjoying their food!

I usually order what I first put my eye on.  In this case it was "The Plow" (two of their lemon ricotta pancakes, two eggs, Nueske bacon and crispy potatoes).  This is my usual breakfast choice anyways--like pancakes but gotta have breakfast meat and potatoes or hash browns!  Even though food took some time coming out, my table was happy with our orders.
