The savory bread pudding was a hit as was the BLT, hamburger and egg sandwich.  The table also shared an order of the French toast which all seemed to enjoy and describe as a hybrid with bread pudding.  I was too full so resisted trying it.  Next time.

One of the great perks (for all coffee drinkers) is that they allow you/and even offer you coffee while you are waiting!  Didn't see if they actually ended up charging for it.  Regardless it's a nice gesture.  

Great to see business so solid, and if there was a way to get the wait down, I will be highly likely to return!
author: Christopher W.

description:
I went to Plow with two others on a Sunday morning, arriving at 8:30 am, 30 minutes after it opened.  This was a bad time to arrive, as the tables had all filled and none of those present were close to finishing yet.  So despite being relatively high on the list, we didn't get invited in from the cold street until 9:00, when we were finally seated at the bar.

This didn't work well: conversation at the bar was difficult in the loud room, so since there was nothing on the menu I wanted anyway (not my style: I'd been hoping they at least had oatmeal) I excused myself and left.

I don't blame Plow for anything: they're a victim of their own success. However be aware if you want to get a table for three (tables sit an even number of people) you may want to make sure you're there right when they open.

In the rating I assume the food is good, as the others later told me it was (assuming you like the "American breakfast" style).
author: Daniel C.

description: Delicious , perfection, foodie- must-go!!! So happy my friend introduced me to this amazing place ! I had the plow and every item was perfection
author: Tamara V.

description:
November is Month of BRUNCH.  Plow got us off to an amazing start.  I heard this was some of the best brunch in SF and I agree wholeheartedly.  

Following the Yelp reviews, we ordered up a fried egg sando w bacon, one lemon ricotta pancake and the smoked salmon and bially.  All were absolutely wonderful.

The house potatoes were the best I've ever had.  Perfectly seasoned and with onions, fried crisptacularly - wow.  On the sando, the bread was so soft and fluffy and perfectly airy that it made the whole dish for me.  The egg was cooked exactly right and it gooed all over me when I bit in.

The salmon was awesome, the cream cheese puffy and wonderful, and the onions were pickly and sour and great.

We sat at the counter and were treated to a view of what everyone else was getting, and, while the menu has a range of items on it, In 75 minutes I think we only saw like three different dishes go out - the Plow version of the Grand Slam, the sando and a friend chicken sandwich.  

The bially was a little big and bready for me, and it was oven cooked rather than toasted.  I'm sure there's a reason for this, but I prefer my toasted bread/bagel thingies crispy-toasted on the outside and chewy on the inside, and this was just like mostly warm dense bread.  

That was the only very slight miss for me in an otherwise pitch-perfect brunch to kick off the world's first Month of BRUNCH.  Go Plow!!
author: Matt S.

description:
Ok, this is the best breakfast place in the city right now.  I've been here twice and the first time was on a Sunday and we had to wait 1hour and 45 minutes!  It's that good.  The next time was today, Thursday, and we waited about 5min. 

The food is amazing.  You will lick your plate and nothing will leave you disappointed.  I get the plow because I like to try a little of everything.  The breakfast sandwich and the pork chops are also very good.  

Bacon is to die for, best potatoes in SF right now, chicken sausage very yummy, they do perfect poached eggs mmmmmmmmm, and the ricotta lemon pancakes are a must try!  They have perfectly brewed ice tea too!

I haver down all the best brunch spots in SF and this is the best right now.  Worth the 15 bucks a plate.

A little bonus, if you have seen the episode of Portlandia were they go to the crazy hip brunch spot, this place is like that on the weekend.  The hostess literally came out to tell all the patrons waiting that, "Everyone is doing really good, you're all doing really good, thanks for waiting".  I loved it, and I love PLOW.
author: Jessica H.

description: 3.5 stars.  Been here twice.  Thought it was only okay the first time, but liked my food better the 2nd time.  Cute place with easy parking.  My friend ordered the soft scrambled eggs and I ordered the chicken apple sausage and eggplant toast - caramelized onions and eggplant on toasted French bread with a side of greens.  Pretty good.  Worth returning, but still don't quite get the high ratings.
author: Vivian W.

description: This place is worth the wait. My sister and I came here last Saturday, waited for 45 minutes in the cold, and then were sat. Let me just tell you that the wait was definitely worth it. We both got the plow breakfast and it was absolutely delicious! I'd recommend this place to anyone visiting or living in the Bay Area for sure!
author: Courtney S.

description: The food is definitely great but it doesn't warrant a 2+ hour wait (on the weekend)!  Come on a week day if you'd like to be seated in 30- minutes, or early in the morning at their opening time on the weekend (no way!).  The lemon ricotta pancakes are good but not as exquisite as I anticipated, nor is the strawberry lemonade.  Overall it's very enjoyable nonetheless.
author: J L.

description:
Everything ordered for brunch was spot on! Eggs Benedict had great flavor and some of the best I've tried and the soft scrambled eggs with wild mushrooms, goat cheese and spinach was tasty and the potatoes were nice and crispy. 
I would however wait for a table inside because the outdoor tables are cramped and far from being level.
author: Chadwick C.

description: wow, a little over rated. been here 3 times, each time the potatoes i got were the left overs, not big full potatoes like people have posted, -1 star. and the food is good, but doesn't knock it out of the park like i anticipated based on reviews. its decent breakfast food and i'd go back again, but not my first choice.
author: Kassandra N.

description:
Wow - just got back.. First of all the host there is SUPER friendly.. we got there at 10am and there was a 15min wait. He chatted with us for a bit - we certainly felt welcome.. 

Both C and I got the fried egg sandwich - soooo good.. and the potatoes! Best I've ever had.. Definitely an incredible find.
author: Monica S.

description:
Was sent here by a friend who is a "brunch junkie".  He told me this is his favorite place at the moment.  I was not disappointed.

You've gotta go early to get a seat.  I hear there can be an hour plus wait on weekends.  Both times I've gone we were seated right away and there were folks waiting for seats (and our parking spaces) when we left.  

We had:  The lemon ricotta pancakes.  The pancakes were light and fluffy with bright citrus notes throughout.  The clear winner for us.  My friend had the Caramelized Banana French Toast, how can you go wrong with Bananas Foster topping on french toast and Marscapone cheese on the side?  

On my second trip we both had the two eggs special.  One with crispy bacon the other with house make pork sausage, perfectly seasoned with fennel, our favorite.  The breakfast potatoes are amazing!  Perfectly crunchy on the outside, light and fluffy on the inside.  Not one bite left on either plate...   

I'll be keeping Plow on my breakfast list too.  The space has a bright, clean, open feel, like going to a friends place for breakfast.  In fact, I'm going to meet friends there this morning.
author: Kim A.

description: Keeping my review short. The place is absolutely amazing. The guys cooking it all are in perfect ballet with each other. EAT HERE.....even if you need to wait 1 hr.
author: Jonathan A.

description: 'The Plow' at the Plow is the best breakfast ever. I am in love with those lemon ricotta pancakes.  If not for the long wait times, I would be here every weekend.
author: Akshaya M.

description: A must stop if you're in San Fran! I got "The Plow" and it was amazing. Solid portion of food for even a hungry guy like myself and the lemon ricotta pancakes were some of the best I've ever had. Be prepared to wait a bit to get a table, but it's worth it and while you wait, grab a drip coffee and some banana bread a half a block down at Farley's!
author: Taylor S.

description:
Good food, perfect for brunch!
Their bacon, eggs and french toasts are pretty good. Definitely going back soon.
author: Nathalie K.

description: This place was just A-OK. It's your basic breakfast diner-fare, but in a youthful, upbeat setting. The lemon ricotta pancakes, however, are the one thing that stuck in my mind as being inordinately good.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Plow, picture of a pig = logo.  Subliminal. Could this explain why I have spotted all pork options on the menu in .3 seconds or less, my eye drawn to them like a spinning spiral illusion? Heck no. I own the fact that I love pork. I naturally spot pork on the menu like a bullseye. That being the case, I am coming in like the Big Bad Wolf when I come to Plow...little piggies better run because they can't hide from me (note to PETA: This was written in fun, please don't come after me, I am not some crazy carnivore, I dig the veggie movement and try to limit my consumption of meat for various reasons. Did I mention I own 2 Maine Coon cats that I adore and who live in a pet friendly home full of love and attention?). 

Anyway, I've read over the menu, and it's time to make a choice. Everybody has raved about the pork sausage patties, so that is a definite yes at this point, yet how could I pass up bacon?  BOOM! Ordered both. At most places the consequence would be a 2 year stomach bomb sentence with a 6 month food coma. This place, no stomach bomb or food coma symptoms emerge, I am in the clear. BOOM! Plow's quality ingredients must be credited here, only at a place that uses great ingredients could this be explained. Apart from eating the 3 little pigs, the potatoes are a huge compliment and a hit on their own. Having mediocre potatoes with your breakfast can be as disappointing as going on a date and finding out your date is a Dodgers fan. These are SF Giant approved potatoes, so be sure to order these because they are flash fried and baked (I think), and if you've tasted potatoes prepared like this before you will be happy that you are getting some bomb potatoes! (that's a reference to EXQUISITELY Delicious, a good bomb, not a stomach bomb  ;p )

Complimenting my plate was a refreshingly chilled raspberry mimosas and a nice view of the cool hip crowd in a well lit and cool designed interior. Complimenting my experience was Randall's cheerful and genuine welcome, evolving from your typical greeting to a full on conversation and photo sharing of the 49er's last game at Candlestick (this was during playoff's, c'mon people, it deserves a shoutout). Thanks for showing us the pictures of your experience at the last game at candlestick park, awesome photos and the only thing that subdued my envy and made me feel better about missing out on such an amazing experience like Randall's was the amazing breakfast that I had the privilege of eating at this establishment!

Friendly and attentive servers and nice ambiance in addition to the great food make this one of the better brunch options in the city.
author: Mariano A.

description: Wow!  Ricotta pancakes make you forget the wait.  Wait staff very pleasant and the view to the open kitchen makes you want to tip more for their fast pace.  Don't think ordering fast will bring your food any faster - the pancakes are an art worth the wait.  As is the bacon.  I dream of going back.
author: Kevin S.

description:
With so many positive reviews... the best I can do is toss in an "I AGREE!"  Service -- awesome.  Food -- awesome (brunch, specifically).  We showed up at 11:30AM on a Saturday and found ourselves (for good reason) at the end of a 1 hour wait list.  Move yourself one block away to Bloom's Saloon...and  have a couple of drinks while you wait for your table.

We had a nice time at Bloom's, then a faboo brunch at Plow.  To do this right, you're going to blow two hours.  If you're on a rush schedule, don't bother.  If you're on a leisurely weekend, it'll be a blast.

Food at Plow is top-notch. Frankly, the best potatoes I've had in SF.  Everyone in our party loved the food.

 Drinks at Bloom's are fun :-)  Every fantastic brunch place in SF should have a symbiotic relationship with a good dive bar.  Zazie && Finnegan's.  Plow && Bloom's.  Etc.
author: Mark B.

description:
I usually don't go to brunch places that don't take reservations only because I find it very very hard to wait in line and smell all the good food and not being able to eat it (you know what I mean ;)).  Well now if you decide to try this place you are most likely going to wait for anywhere between 30-40mins. Our party of 5 arrived and had to wait nearly an hour to get our table which was outside.  Would have preferred a table inside, but after an hour of waiting, I starving and was frankly very glad to get A table. 

By the time we settled down at our table and were ready to order, they were sold out of monkey bread and huevos rancheros! The 2 two things I was going to try here. Well instead I decided to order the Eggs Benedict and decided to share "the plow" with my friend (hey don't judge me I was starving!! :D).  The Hollandaise sauce was too lemony for my taste and didn't quite compliment the poached eggs and the veggies.  On the other hand, the Lemon ricotta pancakes are to die for, they so moist.  Do not leave this place without trying the lemon ricotta pancakes.  Oh almost forgot, the Crispy Potatoes are sooooo goood. 

Frankly I have had better food at places with less of a wait time than here.
author: Nithya S.

description:
...Was so excited to see a new place to have breakfast in the neighborhood, but man was I disappointed.  We thankfully didn't have to wait for a table, no, we instead waited 40min. for cold poached eggs, potatoes and eggy, coarse textured pancakes.  We felt ignored the whole time we were there, couldn't get our server's attention and the host even checked in on the tables to our left and right but skipped out on us :/ I don't know what we could have possibly done to offend anyone but we just decided to pay and get the hell out.  As we were exiting, the host looked at me, and as I was expecting a "Thank You" or "Bye" he instead just turned around and ignored us.  

-1 star terrible food, -1 for crappy service, -1 for rude host
author: CeeLo L.

description:
Was it delicious? Yep. Was it worth waiting an hour for a table for? Absolutely not. Of course, I don't think any food in the world is worth waiting for an hour for. When I want to eat, I want to eat!

Thankfully, I was catching up with a great old friend, which made the hour a bit bearable. But come on, who waits that long for brunch? I can think of many places where I can go for an equally good (or better) brunch where I don't have to wait that long, nor do I have to pay nearly $20 for. Don't get me wrong: I'm glad that I tried it and I thoroughly enjoyed the food, but I don't think I'll return to a place where a brunch dish and coffee costs almost $20 and I have to wait an hour. 

So, the good stuff: I ordered The Plow ($15), and the lemon ricotta pancakes are just as good as everyone says. And I am always happy to see real maple syrup instead of high-fructose corn syrup crap. The eggs were also perfectly scrambled, and the homemade chicken apple sausage were smokey and sweet in a way that only homemade chicken apple sausage can be. I was pretty disappointed with the potatoes, which seemed to be more small pieces of deep fried once-potato. I like them crispy, but I still like to know they were once potatoes. The coffee was also good, but $3.75? When did coffee become a side dish?

If you can get there on a day or at a time where you don't have to wait too long, it's definitely worth a splurge or somewhere to bring an out-of-town guest. But I likely won't be a regular.
author: Amy B.

description:
fantastic food and atmosphere, probably my favorite breakfast in the City... don't say no to the lemon ricotta pancakes. trust me;-)
The only thing that kept me from giving 5 stars was the weekend wait- but it was worth it!  I went again on a weekday, no wait at all, friendly staff...great coffee, and those pancakes again- yum!
author: Spunky M.

description:
Came here with a friend for breakfast.  She likes her breakfast places, so I knew this would be good.  

Place was uncrowded when we arrived but packed when we left; good timing and good sign.  Plow is a rather narrow restaurant, but so very cute with its high ceilings and windows ushering bright natural light; its bustling open kitchen and warm wood accents to offset the stainless cold of the chairs.  

The waitress was nice, but in hindsight rather rushy towards the end.  She reminded me of a Heather Graham, say, from Boogie Nights.  I dunno.  Anyhow, we ordered the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and the Carmalized Banana French Toast.  Without a doubt, the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes were outrageous!  Clearly the winner here.  The texture was nice and heavily influenced by the ricotta.  The lemon wasn't tart but more sweet and more noticeable with every passing bite.  My friend tried to catch a glimpse of its batter being made, however the chef cleverly tipped the bowl and all is still a secret.
author: Kalani C.

description: Plow offers high quality,delicious food.Lemon ricotta pancakes were more puddingish than cakey.Smoked trout salad was tossed with the most flavorful olive oil,lemon,garlic dressing in recent memory. Fantastically delicious salad with salty smoked trout, avocado and frisee. Crispy potatoes were very nice. Mushroom and point Reyes cheese sandwich on an acme roll was outstanding. Abita root beer was refreshing...Small place.We waited 20 minutes on a Wednesday at 1:00.
author: Bleep S.

description:
Oh yum! And what luck that it's in my neighborhood! I don't know how often I will have the luxury of waiting for 45 mins-1 hour to get a table for brunch, but it sure was worth it this last weekend for the chicken tinga (eggs, tomato chipotle sauce, avocado, cheese, and creme fraiche). I was so excited and hungry that I also ordered the perfectly-prepared romanesco (broccoli-cauliflower-type item) as a side and drooled over everyone else's plates simulaneously. 

You gotta give a bonus star to any place that gives you excellent coffee while you wait and where the host gives you props on your cool purse (not my sweet diaper-bag-cum-purse, suprisingly, but my friend's bag). The servers were friendly, efficient, and knew their stuff. Worth the drive even for non-Po HIllers.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
Awesome place for breakfast on a weekday.  They are right, they are a "modest" space, and it fills up quickly but they do well with what they have.  Not only from the service in the kitchen to the servers.  All VERY friendly and can cook up some MEAN food!  

We had the following:
Chinese breakfast with pork shoulder and eggs (i demurely asked the kitchen if they would mind TERRIBLY making my eggs poached and they obliged with a smile--bonus bonus points!)...the pork was tender, a bit chunky served over white rice--couldn't tell but it's supposed to be jasmine.  

Lemon ricotta pancake--probably the best i've had...and the BF is a chef..dont tell him...lol..available on the side if you dont want a whole order...4$ each

fried egg and ham sandwitch with those amazing rice oil fried potatoes, wow--get a side of potatoes if your entree doesn't come with them

yogurt and grains standard

muffin with crunchy amaranth grain

all SO good, i wish i could have gone back for another meal.
author: Tim W.

description:
Went here for my bday brunch a few months ago.
The place is small with counter space and a handful of tables that squeeze 4 people in.
Freshly pumped oj for the mimosas and awesome chicken sausage.
You HAVE to GET their LEMON RICOTTA Pancakes.
I enjoyed watching the cooks do their thang while sitting at the counter.
I will go back, on a weekday to once again get a Lemon Ricotta Pancake or 2.
author: Grace P.

description: Another cozy little breakfast spot in SF. Great service and decor. The potatoes and eggs were good, but I would not get the sausage patties if I were to visit again. If you like lemon/citrus, get the lemon ricotta pancakes - very unique and delicious flavors.
author: Teresa M.

description:
I had no idea the hill it was located on was so steep. My friend almost flew out of her seat as she stepped out. If she weren't holding on to the steering wheel she would have hurdled into the car beside us. I love the place though. It almost seems like Mama's, but more contemporary and casual. We also didn't have to wait in line. Amazing.

The ceiling was just gigantic. It makes you feel like you're 2 feet tall. Beside us were the towering windows and everything in the restaurant made you feel welcome. Absolutely loved the service. Out waitress was so nice and came by to check it everything was well. 

Now for the food. I had the plow, which consisted of bacon, eggs, crispy potatoes (my 2nd favorite item on the plate), and the mini lemon ricotta pancakes (the best part on the plate). I don't know why, but the potatoes just stood out for me. They were perfectly crispy and had a nice herb flavor. I've wanted to try lemon ricotta pancakes for a while and I'm glad I got to try it here. They were fluffy and moist. You get the subtle underlying flavors of lemon in there, like when eating a lemon cream filled cookie. So good. 

I also got to try the french toast. Just delightful. The pure maple syrup really made it taste as good as it did, but I think the ingredient that really did it was the caramel. There was a bit of caramel on the bananas and it just made it stand out from all the other french toast that I've had before. 

I'd love to come here again. Maybe on a sunnier day, but there will probably be a long line. A bit pricey for a breakfast joint, but the ambiance is really amazing there and it's worth a try.
author: robin w.

description: I almost hate to give this 5 stars because I don't want the wait time to increase but, what else can I do? They earned them. This place serves up the best breakfast in the city. The owners have paid close attention to every detail. The food is consistently fantastic, as is the coffee and the service. It doesn't hurt that the waitstaff if easy on the eyes either. :) Try the crab and asparagus scramble or the soft scramble. Normally I don't like potatoes but theirs are sprinkled with unicorn horn or something. So good.
author: Dave F.

description:
A painful experience. 

I'd like to think the newly forming restaurant had an off day, as  it took over an hour for our brunch to come.   There was obviously a snafu, as we watched almost the entire restaurant turn over. We talked to both our server, and eventually the host, about the scenario, and while they tried to be helpful, it STILL took another 15 minutes to come.  

And here's the thing, when our food came, it was just ok ... The portions were small, and while it tasted fine, places like Slow Club beat it hands down. 

They tried to handle the situation by offering us free dessert - the last thing we wanted was to spend another 45 minutes waiting for our dessert to come. They should have pulled some of our food off the bill, but didn't - hope they read this and realize that's the right thing to do.

Finally, they don't (yet) have their liquor license - a mimosa would have helped kill the pain.  Thankfully, the Ramp helped with that.
author: Daniel W.

description:
Love Plow. Love that it came to Potrero.  If you don't live nearby, still worth the drive.  And there's always parking here so no stress.

What to order:  lemon ricotta pancakes (get an order to share with the table), biscuits and gravy or huevos rancheros if it's on the menu, and no matter what make sure you get a side of potatoes (they're the best crispy potato you'll ever have).

Come early if it's the weekend, or be ready to wait, but it's worth it.  :)
author: Tai N.

description:
I'll make this short and sweet.

- the wait is NOT WORTH IT.
- the drinks come in the size of  a baby cup.
- The food is mediocre except the potatoes. I must say... the potatoes saved this place! They were probably the best I've had. 
-Pancakes are tart. You may or may not like them depending on your taste.
author: Kathy C.

description:
Everyone raved about the lemon ricotta pancakes so even thought I'm not a fan of pancakes, I ordered 'the plow' specifically to try them. I'm still not a fan, but maybe if you're a pancake person you'll love them. the flavor is there and i could definitely taste the ricotta, but i'm glad i only ordered them through 'the plow' - you get 2 smaller versions of the normal-size panckaes - otherwise i wouldn't have been able to finish them.

I also tried the monkey bread and fried egg sandwich. Nothing blew me away as in "OMG/THIS IS TO DIE FOR" but everything is done extremely well. quality ingredients + care in preparation. I do want to come back and try the savory bread pudding, though. i sat at the counter and every few minutes the chef would slice a piece for someone's order and it looked soo amazing. didn't try it but if i hadn't asked, i would've thought it was more of a quiche. it looked so eggy and fluffy and it came with a side of huge mixed greens salad.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The food here was very good...plus there was some unique takes on things like lemon ricotta pancakes, breakfast sandwiches, biscuits and gravy (one of Alex's favorites). I would suggest "The Plow" dish for the first time....BEST BREAKFAST POTATOES EVER!!! 

The service was friendly but a little absent...of course they were all wiped from a crazy morning rush like a tsunami (we got there at 1:30). Our server made a great gesture after she had forgotten about our drink order and 15 minute wait for water.  I think they are generally good staff and the bill was well worth the value. 

The wait is HORRENDOUS! We waited almost an hour...gosh, I will go back but not on the weekend or at least much much earlier.
author: Jason P.

description:
Prepare for the lines. 

Our service was probably the best in SF. It was the light blonde nice girl. She knew it before we even thought of it. We just had to open our mouth - and the completed the sentence for us.

Food was good. Especially the salmon benedict. The lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing, the almond ones not as much.

A very good place for breakfast/brunch.

No hard alcohol - so no bloody mary's or other cocktails. Only mimosa and wine (and beer) - and their orange juice is not squeezed on location - and therefore I avoided the mimosa.
author: Too M.

description:
Went there for brunch with friends, and the food worth every penny.  

My only complaint is that we signed up on sheet at 10, and it was past 12 by the time they sat us at a table outside (while it was a freaking cold sf winter day).   Strongly discourage this place for any big groups.
author: Mandy C.

description: Plow had done some quality work with scramble egg with Dungeness crab. I really enjoyed my meal.
author: Yurika O.

description: Must try their Lemon Ricotta Pancakes sweet soft and fluffy, If u have sweet tooth this for u. Great service as well.
author: Emanula M.

description:
Worth the wait!

My wife and I went here for brunch on Saturday and it was packed. We were told the wait was two hours but only ended up waiting about an hour and twenty minutes before we were seated. There are plenty of small, interesting shops nearby to spend the time in while you're waiting so the time passed quickly. 

As far as the food, it was fantastic! I ordered the fried egg breakfast sandwich and my wife ordered the pumpkin pancakes. Both were absolutely delicious and the portions were a perfect size. We had mimosas with our brunch which were also fantastic, but a bit expensive at $8 / glass. 

The service was also great. Unlike most places that are extremely busy, the staff was friendly and not bothered when I asked how much longer the wait would be. Our server was also pleasant and attentive.

Overall, a wonderful experience and one that we'll definitely be repeating soon.
author: Adam P.

description:
The potatoes. Dear god, the potatoes. I'll probably be repeating the phrase as i die of cardiac arrest here. To elaborate, the potatoes are deep fried and tossed with onions and herbs and are incredible. 

Other than that - yes, brunch is good, but it's pretty standard brunch fare done well. We had the plow and eggs benedict - plow is a great deal! You get a little of everything. Lemon ricotta pancakes are good, but very sweet. The monkey bread is also awesome and basically pieces of a cinnamon roll smushed together in a bundt pan. 

Beware - the wait is long for brunch. Walk across the street and sun yourself in front of the mechanized bikes!
author: Nora X.

description: The first time I went I thought there was no way any brunch was worth a 90 minute wait. I was wrong. Perfect decor. Love sitting at the counter and watching the masterful chefs do their dance.
author: Mrs. E.

description:
Worth every minute of the 90 minute wait.

I believe the sign of a good breakfast joint is one that does a great job w/ the potatoes. I should be able to devour them--catsup and salt free--and want to go back for more. Good potatoes are really hard to do well if you simply don't put time into them, and I've found that time and time again any brunch joint that delivers great fried spuds will kill it with every other dish

And Plow did just that

Egg sandwich was legendary. Bacon is a must
Crispy potatoes lived up to it's name
Lemon Ricotta Pancake is where I want to die and go to heaven
author: John M.

description:
WARNING:  The wait is ridiculous.  And if you go too late, then you may get turned away, yeah, really, turned away.

It's really the only brunch spot in Potrero Hill (well, the only one that highlights their brunches) and it's new so they have the whole novelty effect going for them.  I've already made 3 attempts to brunch here and the first time they "ran out of food," the second, they gave me the brush off and said it was gonna be a long wait and they were closing at 2:30.  I went back a third time and finally got a table after waiting over 1 hour.  I guess 3rd time's the charm.

FOOD
The fried egg sandwich is pretty good but more for their use of good toasty croissant like bread.  The fillings were mediocre.  Anyone can fry an egg and add some gourmet sauces.

The scrambled eggs were a bit runny but the mushrooms and spinach were a good combo.  

The smoked trout salad was refreshing.  Good quality trout with the right about of dressing.  I wish their selection of greens was better though.  I believe it was a mesclun but it wasn't a good mix because there weren't enough leafy elements.

SERVICE
Aloof and unnecessarily so.  

The end verdict?  Plow is doing well because it's the only brunch spot on the hill...if some devoted brunch spots opened up within walking distance then they'd be in trouble.
author: Karen N.

description: We frequent this place for their lemon ricotta pancakes and the sausage option for "The Plow" is delicious. Didn't mind waiting 30 minutes to eat here.
author: Ro B.

description:
Very solid brunch spot.  The trick is to get here among the first group to be seated, likely around 7:30-7:45 on a Saturday morning - otherwise, you will be waiting for a long time.  That obviously means an early wake-up, but it's well worth it.

Had The Plow (which includes their famous pancakes) as well as the Fried Egg Sandwich.  The pancakes are as at least as good as people say, and the egg sandwich is delicious, and even the potatoes (which I normally don't eat much of) are good.  Would gladly come back here, even if I have to sacrifice a couple hours of sleep.
author: Josh Q.

description:
I'm still thinking about the crispy potatoes and the Dungeness crab scramble two days (a year) later. 

Pork sausage was good, and the lemon ricotta pancakes were good too, but it's that scramble...

what was I talking about before? totally the favorite brunch place. Totally the only brunch place I dream about or think about or compare all other brunch places to. 

Contemplating dinging it a star for ridiculous wait times. like almost 2 hours ridiculous.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Went here on a Tuesday morning with my cousin. Heard about this place from 7x7 and wanted to see if it was good.
I got the the plow and the fried egg sandwich. 
Now the plow was basically a sampler and had most of what was available on the menu. I was hoping the lemon ricotta pancakes would wow me. But it was just alright. There was something slightly off... I don't know what it is to the taste. I did like the chicken apple sausage though. My cousin was indifferent to it.
The fried egg sandwich was my favorite. It was like gout for breakfast. The egg was fried perfectly and the bit of arugula (or some kind of mixed greens) helped balance out the sandwich. I was expecting it to be super heavy but it wasn't. We also added bacon which made it pretty good.
We got a ton of potatoes. In the beginning, the potatoes were really good. But we all know that if you eat too much of something good, it becomes sorta not good. That's what happened to us.
All in all, a good place to have brunch. But there was a smell in the place that lingered. I don't know if it was saffron or something. But it stayed with me even when I left the place. That smell also was associated with the potatoes. And no, I know what potatoes smell like, but this smell was more herby or saffrony.
author: Jessica H.

description: Lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes made the two hour wait totally worth it.
author: lisa l.

description: First time here so I decided to go with the "plow" sampler -- eggs (scrambled), chicken apple sausage, crispy potatoes and two lemon ricotta pancakes. I'm getting full again even typing it out. Definitely could have fed two people. The crispy potatoes were very crispy, and I would have preferred a few more sautéed onions mixed in there to break up the starch overload. Pancakes were good, moist and with the right degree of sweetness, but not spectacular. Eggs were fluffy and yummy, probably the best part of the dish. The nice thing was that we didn't have to wait for a table during lunchtime, and that they always serve brunch for lunch on the weekdays too.
author: Joyce H.

description:
Best.  Potatoes.  I.  Have.  Ever.  Put.  In.  My.  Mouth.

So there are many, many wonderful things about playing hookey, but maybe the best thing is being able to go to a restaurant that would otherwise have an insane weekend line without having to wait in an insane line.

Thank you, Plow.  I think I'll order anything you'll serve that comes with those potatoes, please. 

(As for a review, the Plow is amazing, and the crab scramble is excellent.  Also, I love generously buttered toast.)
author: .caroline. ..

description: The wait made me crabby.  It was upwards of 90 minutes before we were sat and then the service didn't make up for it.  Surely there must be a better way to ensure guests don't have to wait so long...reservations?  The food was good but the potatoes had way too much rosemary for us.
author: heidi v.

description: Okay so I lied. I've been back many a time regardless of the long wait. I've just been back at times where the wait isn't so long. The pancakes... and those potatoes. So, so delicious. The potatoes are def. not healthy... they seem to be double fried or extra fried... but they are SO good. I just love this place and you probably will too.
author: Kimberly F.

description: Plow is one of those places you wait in line forever but the big difference is that it's something I would wait in line for again! The food is so delicious and fresh! I ordered the soft scramble and I had a mimosa as I waited to be seated. Very worth it and I'm excited to go back :)
author: Claudia L.

description:
I LOVED my meal but the bf was not as excited as I was, maybe because he's not obsessed with eggs like I am.  I had the egg sandwich, duh, but next time will consider getting "the plow" bc the portions looked huge!  

minus a star because it's super tiny, they make u share tables, and the long wait (no reservations) on the weekend.  

Had the pear french toast which was delish, but gotta go back to try the lemon ricotta pancakes.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
They open at 7 on weekdays, 8 on the weekends. Not a lot of good places open that early.

So, when I woke up bright and early on Sun of New Years weekend, starving, and walked there IN THE RAIN for breakfast, you can imagine my disappointment to find the door locked. Closed all week?! What, so the employees can spend time with their families or something? Psht. Jerks.

Jaw dropped, standing there in the rain, baffled as to my next move, probably looking like someone just ran over my puppy. Take that as a testament to how yummy it is.

At prime weekend brunch times, there's a wait. And the crowd can be a little... we'll say hip... so depending on your outlook,  annoying company or good people watching.
author: Bethany M.

description:
a little disappointed because i expected much more pork dishes.
my friend and i got the eggs benedict and lemon ricotta pancake. 
pancakes were lemony which was good! you can see the zested lemons laying around in the kitchen
eggs benedict was ok...wasnt really memorable. potatoes that came with it were very crispy

place is not too big, outside seating in a nice warm day is nice.
author: Linda T.

description: No espresso/cappuccino machine?  Sorry. Won't be back.
author: Justin R.

description: Since I was heading out of town for the holidays, I figure I'd have lunch with a few friends before I left. Having heard good things both through word of mouth and through stellar reviews, it was time to check it out. Conveniently located off the 18th/Mariposa exit off 280, it was a hop, skip and a jump from my friends work in SOMA. I have to admit the wait is kinda intense even in the mid week. Im guessing it was about 20 minutes. After getting a seat in the back we perused the menu. I ended up in a food pact with said friend to try the Cassoulet, Duck/sweet potato hash and some bacon. Very tasty and creative food but not big on portion if you're used to old school diner breakfasts. So as a big eater, you could definitely order more. However this isn't an old school diner, so you'll be getting some very high quality ingredients. It's popular enough that I noticed that Charles Phan of Slanted Door fame was sitting right behind me and my friend also pointed out that Sharon Ardiana of Ragazza/Gialina's was also there. It's the hip and happening place to be for breakfast. 4.3 stars.
author: Kim N.

description:
I got the fried egg sandwich (approx $13.00) and it was AMAZING! Everything was very tasty. I'm usually not a big fan of eggs but I wasnt in the mood for a pancake and I am sooo glad because it was again....sooo AMAZING.  I dont think we had any left overs. 

 Minus one star because we waited a long time to be seated and we kept being told we were next but others were being seated. 

Come prepared to wait but worth it. The staff was super friendly, bathroom very clean.
author: Lidia Z.

description:
Long wait, but worth it. 

Tips: get your coffee inside while you wait.

Get the plow, the pancakes were awesome.  the potato in that dish was super tasty.  French toast was really fluffy.
author: Deb L.

description: three words. lemon ricotta pancakes. 4 stars. great spot!
author: Black Frankenstien ..

description:
Love this place. I work in the neighborhood and its great to have a new place for lunch. The food is delicious, prepared with care and attention to detail. Highly recommend the BLT - absolutely fantastic. 

The new outdoor seating is a nice touch.

Service can be a bit pokey sometimes, but overall a big recommend for sure.
author: Andrew C.

description: The crispy potatoes are very good as are the almond flour pancakes.  The bacon was not crispy, but a bit blackened like it had been cooked over an oven with a lot of burnt grease.  The bacon ruined the experience for me.  I will have to avoid ordering that next time.  I think the seats at the counter are the best seats in the house, since there's a direct view of the action in the kitchen.
author: Jenny K.

description: This is the best brunch in the city, hands down. Get the Lemon Risotto Pancakes. Now.
author: Lucas C.

description:
If I wanted to impress friends visiting with the best brunch in SF, Plow would be the place I'd choose. They take brunch seriously, with a wide variety of dishes made from only the freshest local ingredients. It's one of those places where you look at the menu and think "can I have one of everything?"

I was dazzled by the chicken tinga- corn tortillas topped with chipotle sauce, braised chicken and creamy avocado. Divine!

Aside from the food, the spaces is refreshing. Lots of natural light makes for a bright space.
author: Lauren T.

description: Wow, one of the best fried chicken sandwiches I have ever had!  My mom loved The Plow dish, she was able to enjoy everything at once!  Kudos Maxine!
author: Jen C.

description: This is now my favorite breakfast/brunch spot. I would wait all morning and yes, you must be willing bc it's a wait? But it is worth it! Every insane bite. Potatoes are like crack, the lemon pancakes are insane! I have a new fav and this is it! It is clear that these folks know food and do it right. My friend who is gluten free enjoyed the Plow breakfast w/ a gluten free pancake and loved it:) So awesome!
author: Heather F.

description:
This place is ahmazing!  My sister & bro-in-law keep talking about it since their friend's sister owns it.  Exceeded my expectations.   
We waited for about 20 mins for a table for 3 on a Friday around 11am.  Yes, it was crowded believe it or not.  It's super cute, quaint restaurant with lots of windows!

I had the omelette: lamb's quarters, mushrooms, goat cheese, crispy potatoes, toast.  TO DIE...you wouldn't believe how well the egg was cooked to perfection.  Wasn't dry nor was it under cooked.  Never had a more perfect omelette egg!  And the potatoes - never had anything like them.  Super tasty as they were tossed in sea salt flakes and the crispiness is like no other.

One friend had the breakfast sandwich which looked good, and the other had the plow which looked like a classic bfast to get especially if you're undecided.  We added a short stack of the lemon ricotta pancakes which were good.  I'm more of a savory breakfast eater so I was extremely content with my bfast.  

I highly recommend and would definitely come back - preferably on a weekday.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Oh boy... REALLY surprised to have to be doing this... and REALLY SAD!!!!  This was my choice for Birthday lunch for my sister who is an executive chef!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!... the menu and decor looked great... we so wanted to like plow. So sad.

Apologies for the CAPS but I am SO BLOWN AWAY at the experience we had earlier today that it is necessary. 

The sandwiches were just okay... nothing to write home about... yummyish egg and bacon... okay tuna conserve but was meager and completely unseasoned / flavorless even with the capers and boquerones (as though they rinsed them?).

The real problem was...

Yes... that's right... it's me Chef. The guy with the ROTTEN greens and OLD DRIED OUT BROWN EDGED radicchio... CLEARLY this was NOT   'well-made food sourced from local farms'. 

And after seeing the plate:

1. You choose to argue with us.. at our table... about whether or not the greens were ROTTEN and DRIED OUT and BROWN after I carefully laid out more than a DOZEN pieces for you to see... on EACH of our plates?

2. After I actually pick up and show you several disgusting ROTTEN pieces you actually say 'well maybe THAT piece'? As though what...? One mouthful of ROTTEN greens should be fine? Then you try and tell me that they were just 'bruised' not ROTTEN?

3. You then continue to tell me they couldn't be rotten because they came in 'fresh that morning'? From where? No where local that's for sure. And... if they were... then you need to CHANGE YOUR PURVEYOR!!!!  AND / OR have your staff be MORE ATTENTIVE in washing/preparing the greeens.

4. You acted as though it was my fault that I got ROTTEN food on my plate! And then you further insult me by trying to tell me that I don't understand what a fresh properly dressed (UNROTTEN and UNBRUISED and UNBROWN) salad of fresh greens SHOULD look like? Really? Wow. What city do you think you are in??? 

5. You then try and insult us further by trying to comp our meal like we were just trying to get a free lunch... rather than see that we were trying to HELP YOU SEE THAT YOUR KITCHEN NEEDS TO BE MORE ATTENTIVE? There is nothing worse than being served ROTTEN food. 
And if you are really going to comp the meal come out and tell us why in person... admit and move on. It's that simple.

Unreal. 

And as for the comp attempt... NO THANKS... we left $40.00 cash on a $5.50 check... (original check was $25.50... so yeah... she didn't even try and comp the whole check... she left us with the charges for burned and bitter coffee... really?... so lame.) 

I hope your attentive and helpful waitstaff enjoyed the $35.00 dollar tip then...

Pros-
Nice simple decor
Friendly staff

Cons-
ROTTEN  greens
Bland sandwiches
BITTER BURNED coffee
Poor decision making by owner / chef
Condescending attitude
Sad unproffesional attempt to rectify the situation

Bummer.
author: Nomad I.

description:
It's nice to have another Brunch place on the HIll. Although it was quite crowded when we went ( a little after eight on a Saturday Morning) the space feels light and airy inside. I almost had the "the Plow" which features all the greatest hits on the menu, but opted to share the Monkey Bread (unbelievably good!) with two eggs and a side of the House-Made Sausage. I didn't finish the sausage because it was a little too spicy for me (even my friend, who is a HUGE fan of lighting her mouth on fire, said it was pretty spicy for a breakfast sausage). But I would come back again and have the French Toast.

The sweet spot for Breakfast seating seems to be about 9:00 am - if you go early as we did, you get a seat, but the kitchen gets slammed out of the gate, so you have a little wait on the food. Things shake out nicely after 9:00.

Wait staff is very friendly and efficient.
author: Kathy P.

description: I was so excited to finally dine at Plow. My friends and I didn't even mind waiting 45 minutes for the outside table next to bus stop. I ordered the PLOW breakfast plate with 2 eggs, 2 house sausage patties, 2 ricotta pancakes and home fries. I had barely tasted anything before I spotted a hair embedded in the home fries. Gross. Though they offered to replace the plate, I had lost my appetite and didn't feel like eating anything anymore. Needless to say, this dining experience was memorable for all the wrong reasons.
author: Genevieve D.

description: I live in Potrero Hill and have visited Plow several times on weekday mornings. My view of the restaurant's overall rating has gone down. The food is solidly good, but the prices are too high. The service is mediocre. We were offered coffee and requested half and half or milk and it was never brought to us. I had to grab it from the counter. We asked for our meal to be split and brought on two plates, it didn't arrive that way and it had to be sent back for that purpose. I don't intend to go here very often, most likely with a friend who hasn't been there and has read all the rave, sometimes hyped, reviews. I don't think it's worth waiting in line to eat there.
author: Pamela W.

description:
I plowed my girlfriend this weekend.

I was pretty excited to plow, but I made sure to not finish too fast. 

I took my time and savored every moment.

And she, for once, loved it.

She loved it so much, she even paid!!

I recommend the granola, salmon, and crispy potatoes.

Safe.
author: Archie R.

description:
Great breakfast spot.  Great coffee, fast service, and delicious food.  The breakfast sandwich and lemon ricotta pancakges were excellent.  The wait isn't too bad early on, but later the hipsters come out and you may be stuck for an hour or so before eating.  

Do your fellow citizens a favor though and if you've had a leisurely breakfast and see the line out the door, could you please not hold your seats for another 30 minutes while you finish the rest of your coffee and pontificate about global warming?  Yes yes, I know you're entitled to stay as a paying customer and you don't give a crap about us waiting in the cold, but does being a hipster = losing your conscience?
author: Maxine S.

description:
Love Plow. Don't like the name so much. Anyway, as all have said, expect to wait during the weekend but you can walk around on 18th while you wait for your name to be called. But the wait is worth it! 

We ordered the soft scramble and the french toast. Both were great but I liked the scramble a little more. My favorite thing was the ridiculously good potatoes. OMG - they were the best potatoes I've ever had. I dream about them. 

Service was good - friendly and no problems. Definitely one of my fave brunch places in SF.
author: Veronica H.

description: The food is outstanding.  Seriously delectable.  The service wasn't great.  They are very busy and it's a tight space, so it is understandable.  Our waitress was very sweet when we did see her.  But if I pay $2.75 for brewed coffee I'd like at least one refill.  Still, if you are foodie, this place is worth the wait.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Came for Sunday brunch. We were told it would be a 10-minute wait. We were seated after 20 minutes. The food was excellent. They're known for their crispy potatoes and they definitely were crispy. There's a gluten-free option for pancakes, which I got. Service was a bit slow, but the waitstaff was very nice - it was just crowded.

The reason I left off the last star is because they have the world's most uncomfortable chairs.
author: Green Y.

description: I was extremely excited to try plow, specifically because my mom has quite a few food allergies and is gluten free. She got the almond flour pancakes which she loved... I got the plow breakfast. The bad started when 3 waters were placed on the table automatically when we had bottled waters in front of us. Water should only be served upon request right now which really made me mad.. Then, I asked for my potatoes without onion so I could share them with my mom, who has a severe onion allergy. Luckily I spotted them in the potatoes before she ate them... I would've let our waitress know if she hadn't disappeared. We didn't see her until she left the check on our table. I might come back for the ricotta pancakes, to go. Might.
author: kristen k.

description: I had the plow and coffee.   No doubt that it was very good....but it is hard for me to justify $25 for breakfast.   Knock that down to $15 and I'd be a regular.
author: Kristin P.

description:
This place is overrated at best.  We came here for Sunday brunch and I was sorely disappointed by the food.  

The food tasted like its chef... snobby.

To be fair, the wait staff was very friendly though.

The decor and ambiance make it look like a good restaurant but the food does not live up to expectations.  As the old saying goes, you can't judge a book by it's cover.

We sat down at our table at 1pm (one hour before closing time), so maybe they were running tired and were starting to run out of ingredients.  But man, the food was sub par.

We ordered:
* lemon ricotta pancakes - 3 stars - Average taste.
* crispy pig ears - 1 star - Tasted like rubber.
* fried egg sandwich - 3 star - Average taste, but it was the best dish we had.
* "the plow" (your typical American breakfast with eggs, choice of breakfast meat, pancakes and potatoes) - 2 stars - The bacon tasted good, but then again, it's hard to mess up bacon.  Everything else tasted like what you might get from a free continental breakfast at your good ol' Best Western.  Yelp-ers seem to rave about the crispy potatoes, but the "crispy" potatoes that came with my "the plow" dish were only ok.  The potato was not even cut into pieces all the way, so I got like one big chunk of the potato.  The other dishes at other tables seemed to have smaller potato pieces (almost like home fries), but mine was one huge chunk.

Maybe they're still working out the kinks because they're new.  Maybe their lunch items are better.

But honestly, the best thing I had was the Tapatio hot sauce.
author: Richard S.

description: i think we waited for like 2.5 hours, but it was a good excuse to explore Portrero Hill and I loved it. - go to Christopher's books and Farley's for coffee while you wait. I had high expectations given the reviews and the wait and everything was perfect. I LOVED the combo meal with eggs, housemade pork sausage, crispy home fries, and mini-lemon ricotta pancakes. I love variety and this gave me everything I wanted. The raisin brioche bun - warmed up - to start rocked. For such a home-made place they should have fresh-squeezed my orange juice. Made me cringe to see it come out of a purchased gallon jug. Otherwise, impeccable.
author: Andrew K.

description: Plow has very yummy brunch.  I usually meet my sister there after her 24ers and we dine on delicious food while she deliriously tells us tales from the hospital.  Even though we usually get there early (before 9) there is always a line so be prepared to wait.  They do give out free coffee though which is a plus.  The lemon ricotta pancakes are divine and I highly recommend The Plow, which gives you a taste of sweet and savory.  The fried egg sandwhich was nice but a little runny.
author: Madeline W.

description:
I didnt want to have to write this review, but unfortunately the time has come....

if it were just for food, i would give it at least 4 stars if not 5.

As a local in the neighborhood, we love all our neighborhood spots and are happy to support them for bettering our local dining experience.  I have been here at least 2 dozen times if not more. we bring friends from all over the country when they come to visit, however....

i have once had to return a chicken sandwich for being undercooked.

next time, i was not as lucky.  I didnt return the slightly undercooked chicken sandwich and paid for it bigtime.  spent the next day on the bathroom floor curled up in the fetal position...  no more details on that, but it was AWFUL....  i have never been sicker in my life.

havent seen the chicken sandwich on there for a while...

i did not write a yelp review then, i sent them an email about how much i loved the food and that i wanted to make sure that it didnt happen to anyone else.

they wrote me back, and said let them know the next time i am in and they would comp the next meal.  fine, but i needed to wait a while before i was ready....

i finally returned, but didnt want to make a scene, although, the food was great.  the service however was not.  It was as if they knew i was the one that complained about food poisoning and wouldnt even look at me, as if i was in the wrong.  (the chef in particular)  i have met her dozens of times, spoke with her at the wine shop they used to own, and on my last 4-5 visits, she didnt as much as muster up a hello...

it is sad that in a city with such fine cuisine, and great chefs, that often times they forget the most important part of their business is not the food they serve, but the service they provide, and in my opinion, the owners and head chef, (one in the same) really just dont get it...  all it takes is a smile, a hello, how have you been....  without that, they are just another place in a big city full of restaurants....  and they have lost a big customer who brings more customers....
author: Matt V.

description: Great spot for breakfast. This place pays attention to every detail. Mimosa's were outstanding-- get the plow breakfast-- it showcases all os there work@
author: Michael S.

description: Best breakfast I've ever had!!! I live brunch and try a lot of different restaurants. This is by far the best I've eve had!!! Totally worth the hour wait!!!
author: Verne P.

description:
Been going to plow for years (before the long waits) and is my favorite place in San Francisco for brunch.  I usually avoid the weekends because of the crowds but it has been busy during the weekdays also.  Parking is normally not bad in the area.  

The food has been consistently good over the years.  Like on everyone's review, The plow is my favorite but everything is good.  Had the fried egg sandwich on my last visit which was great!  The strawberry lemonade was good but I'll stick to coffee next time.  Lemon ricotta pancakes is a favorite staple here.  

I'm not normally a breakfast/brunch person but when I want a special or something different for breakfast/brunch, it's PLOW. 

They have outside seating on the sidewalk.  I prefer sitting indoors but from what I have seen, the outdoor seating is great with people with pets, restless kids and the extra seats keeps the wait time down for everyone.  I love the picture of the people sitting outside with their umbrellas out.  

Baked is a short walk away and is a favorite place for sweet treat after brunch.
author: Rave Y.

description:
When my friend suggested Plow for breakfast instead of Brenda's (http://www.yelp.com/biz/brendas-french-soul-food-san-francisco#hrid:Akpp275qwdj3cKKvmrh1_Q), I didn't protest at all. I figured there was no way a brunch place in Potrero Hill would be open at 8 am on a Saturday, and it was easier to agree with him than to argue with him. Imagine my surprise when the place was not only open, it was actually full. I mean, sure, it was a beautiful day, but it was 8:03 am, and the place wasn't even supposed to have its grand opening until Tuesday. 

Long story short, I am really glad I got to try this place. 

Located in a large, bright space on the corner of 18th St and Texas St, Plow feels incredibly inviting. Big windows let a lot of light in, the light that shines on the huge open kitchen and typical Potrero Hill industrial chic interior. The restaurant only seats 35, and it seems as though there is a lot of underutilized space. I bet they could easily cram 50-60 people there, but they wisely chose not to do that. We'll see if they have to make a change once the lunch crowds start pouring in. 

The staff and the owner, who stopped by to talk to us, were incredibly nice, helpful and friendly. They were truly happy to see you and greeted you with a genuine smile. In response to my question "Why did you call the restaurant 'Plow,'" the owner responded "I am a hick who grew up in Northern Wisconsin." Where else would you get that kind of honesty? 

On day one of serving brunch, they were still working out the kinks. We heard them discussing whether the sandwiches needed to be cut, and they seemed to be unsure about a couple of things. Our waitress told us they didn't have wheat toast, and they only had some other toast. It sounded like "Lavigne," "Lee Vaughn" or "Love in," the way she pronounced it. I figured she meant "levain" and said that it was fine. It was actually quite good. 

We started by sharing the pastry basket. Splitting a scone, a mini muffin and a biscuit amongst the 3 of us. The scone was delicious, the other two pastries were just OK. I had the bacon with eggs and home fries and levain toast. I really liked the way they prepared the bacon, which was thick and not too crispy. The home fries had a bit too much seasoning for me, but I understand that they were probably trying to give it their own signature flavor. 

I was impressed with the Southern influences in their menu offerings, including biscuits and gravy (yes, please) and pig's ears (no, thanks). The prices are very reasonable here, but the servings aren't extremely large. They now offer a combo that includes pancakes, eggs, home fries and bacon on one plate. 

Still, for me, it's a simple formula: Gravy + bacon - pig's ears + free & easy parking + friendly attitude = many return visits.
author: Yan G.

description:
This place made me and my bf angry.  We woke up early in the morning and were one of the first few people to arrive, but was still put on the waiting list (3 groups ahead of us).  An hour later we still did not get seated, but somehow groups who arrived after us were seated.  Their wait time:  5-10 minutes.  After we did get seated, we saw all those other groups of 4 already nearly done with their meals.

I tried to put this aside and focus on our meal.  Overall I liked the sides (potatoes and eggs) more than the main dishes (pancakes and sausages).  The ricotta pancake had this weird texture, but the flavor was good.  The sausages were really dry though.  

Would I give this place another try?  No, my overall experience was tainted with the crappy service.
author: A W.

description:
Damn the yuppies and hipsters of Potrero Hill are right. Plow is a great addition to the neighborhood and has real good food.

After two and half weeks in the armpit of Virginia, Newport News any food that hadn't been deep fried, factory made or served as part of a buffet would have been wonderful but plow went far above those expectation.

I had to tried to go here on the weekend but they were always so crowded and they close early too so I was happy that at 11am on Wednesday it was only 1/2 full. 

The atmosphere is pure California cuisine as is the menu. Wood tables, open windows, the organic farms they get their produce from listed on the menu, prices mostly from 7-12 dollars, skinny hipster waitresses. It's got it all. The good thing is the food delivers.

We got the Apple cinnamon coffee cake, Anson Mills stone cut oatmeal, celery root soup and smoked trout salad. Everything was simple and everything was simply perfect.

The coffee cake is cut above your store brand coffee cake. the portion was large and moist.

The oatmeal was oatmeal and done right, it came with banana slices and two tiny bowls of nuts and brown sugar, nothing special and at a huge mark up but good.

The celery root soup was the best thing and it showed that the chef has some real skills, the crunchy croutons and creme fraiche added to an already tasty soup.

The salad was large, fresh and tasty. It would have been great to have something of a different texture since the avocado and smoked trout had a very similar texture.

Since I live in the neighborhood I will definitly be coming back here again for lunch or breakfast during the week. The crowds and visitors to our neighborhood on the weekend will make it a miss for me then.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: One of my favorite brunch spots in SF! I've been here twice-- once around 1pm for a late brunch, and waited around 30-40 minutes (for 2 people) and the second time, came around the same time, but waited over an hour for 3 people. We walked around a few blocks to get a cup of coffee while waiting and there were a few places to sit as well, so the wait wasn't too bad and it was definitely worth it. My boyfriend told me I should order "The Plow" and I would tell anyone else the same! But I probably would have ordered it without the suggestion because I was set on trying their famous lemon ricotta pancakes, BEST pancakes ever and "The Plow" comes with 2 of the pancakes, sausage or bacon, potatoes, and 2 eggs. I love it when restaurants give you an option of a sweet and savory dish. I almost always go for it because they surprisingly don't come so often. I tried the pumpkin pancakes the second time and they were just OK to me. Anyway, only downside about this place is the wait, but you can't escape that if you want to have a good brunch in SF.
author: Stephanie G.

description: The quality was fantastic. The stuffed French toast is out of this world! The organic yogurt with granola and fresh fruit was so simple yet AMAZING! this place was quality freshness and delicious taste. I wish I could go there right now!!!
author: Leya r.

description:
A breakfast place that is super delicious where i'm not thinking i can easily make this at home for $5.

Line is always ridic, so you gotta come early... or put your name down, have coffee down the street and come back in an hour.

Gotta Get:

Iced Coffee - Legit delicious coffee

Plow Breakfast - They add an extra component to each ingredient of their breakfast.  Lemon Pancakes are so good you don't really even need the maple syrup, fried potatoes are extra deep fried for an added crispy shell, their homemade sausage has lots of spices so it has lots of flavor, eggs are just regular.

French Toast - Huge thick cuts, didn't try it, but looked so amazing.
author: Steven F.

description:
- The long wait means you're not going to be eating brunch hungry.
- The Lemon Ricotta Pancakes are great.
- Poached eggs are done perfect. (Not easy, I know from experience.)
author: Mary W.

description:
Please, please, please start serving your eggs benedict during the week! (whines)

Aside from the fact that I can't get an eggs benedict during the week, this place is perfection.  The best breakfast in San Francisco, hands down.

Do you think you have eaten pancakes? I assure you have not! Not unless you have eaten the pancakes at Plow.  Ricatta and Pumpkin pancakes, so light and fluffy you'll swear they took a hacksaw to the very clouds of heaven!  Compared to the pancakes at Plow, all other breakfast cakes made in pans taste dryer than the driest cardboard. You'd spit them out, you would!  Only Plow pancakes will do.

Friendly staff, fabulous and cheerful service.  Always a pleasure to come in.  The weekends do get a crowd (and no wonder!) so don't show up on a Saturday starving to death.  During the week, seating is fast and easy.
author: Brian L.

description:
Reviewing my brunch experience here is pretty simple: great food (try the lemon ricotta pancakes!), great service, great location (there was plenty of street parking, yay!). 

A special shout-out to the pretty blond hostess who gracefully managed a long wait-list, and was extremely nice to us and everyone else it seemed.

Give it a try!
author: Naomi A.

description:
Oh.... my....holy.....breakfast.....heaven.

Had a "foodie gathering" recently with some friends old and new, and PLOW was on our list to try.  

The breakfast was excellent.  I don't usually say that often, but it shot straight to the top of my breakfast eateries with Hash House A Go Go in San Diego.  

If you're even considering trying plow, you NEED to.

Fried egg sandwich was great, potatoes were even better!
author: Jeff W.

description:
Finally, I stopped in today for a quick brunch. Table for 1 please! =) 
I really don't mind eating by myself. Alisa seated me and took my order. I had the mini lemon ricotta pancakes and they were perfect! I also ordered a side of crispy bacon and a side of their country potatoes. I swear, these are the best potatoes I've had for brunch...EVER! I asked how they were prepared and she answered my question with so much love. I mean, I was sold after she told me. And now, I'm going to share with you what the secret was! They boil and roast the potatoes with salt, pepper, olive oil and thyme and caramelized onions then they deep fry them! OMG they came out so crispy, crunchy and moist when you bite into them. *automatic drool*

I love this restaurant at first sight. I think this is one of my top 5 brunch spots in the City. I didn't have to wait for a table at 10:15 am today. There were a few customers who dined in. I did have their equator coffee and it was pretty good. 

Oh man, I can't wait to go back. Next time, I'm ordering the same exact thing but with extra butter for my pancakes. They're THAT good. Trust me.
author: Mika D.

description:
Working out the kinks, hopefully.

Decor/remodel is beautifully cozy and modern. My pork sandwich for lunch on Tuesday was well cooked, but overly aromatic for my taste. The potatoes it came with, however, were INCREDIBLE. ORDER THE POTATOES!

My companion's chicken salad had 4 pieces of cartilage, two veins, and a piece of skin. Whoever is preparing the chicken needs to be a bit more careful. Yikes.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
We got a table relatively quickly but we waited a long time for our order to come out.  The people at the table next to us were seated after us but they had already finished their meals by the time we got our food.  I was starving so this made me very unhappy but once the food came out, I was all smiles..

I got the salmon platter and the cabbage and kale soup.  The salmon platter was  standard with Acme levain bread, smoked salmon, pickled onions, capers and fromage blanc.  The soup was really delicious though.  It had so much flavor and was very hearty, with ham and barley, without being too salty.

My sister got the egg sandwich and it was also great but the yolk squirted all over anyone who tried to eat it.  Beware.
author: Seong P.

description: Come early as seating is limited.  The lemon ricotta pancakes are slendid.  You can't go wrong with anything on the menu.  Service is friendly.  Parking can be limited as it is in the neighborhood on Potrero Hill.
author: Rich K.

description:
Dreaming about lemon ricotta pancakes after eating here...

One of my fave brunches. Fine, fresh ingredients. Have not been disappointed with anything on the menu. My usual order is the goat cheese scramble and lemon ricotta pancakes. LRP's are cooked perfectly every time (just soft enough in the middle, and lightly browned around the edges). Hard to explain how good they are but they leave me speechless. Their breakfast potatoes are F&*%ing fantabulous!!! Perfectly crispy in all the right places and spiced to perfection. 

Really cute place. 4.5 stars because the wait sucks!
author: Gina H.

description:
The atmosphere is the perfect kind of San Francisco chill. The interior reminds me of a kitchen that I want to spend a lot of time in with nice, big windows allowing lots of sunlight. 

I ordered the egg sandwich with bacon -- they were all out of bacon (heresy, I know) so our server replaced it with pork sausage patties (which went phenomenal on the sandwich). The egg on the sandwich was cooked perfectly over-easy -- upon taking the first bite egg yolk rushed out the back of the sandwich -- just how I like it :-) 

The potatoes that come on the side are just, perfect. Seasoned perfectly with rosemary, a nice crispy outside, and super soft and fluffy on the inside.

It was an all around great first experience. Fantastic food, great atmosphere; I'll definitely be back to plow next time I'm in SF.
author: Alex S.

description:
I enjoyed our little adventure over to this neighborhood.  The parking on a 90 degree angle to the curb is something this NYer found more fascinating than anything else on the 75 degree angle of the street.  But Plow has a great breakfast.  Very egg centric but all delicious and super friendly service helps as well.  

I got the fried egg sandwich with the bacon and the wife got two eggs over medium with chicken apple sausage and we both got the potatoes.  We sat at the bar so we got to see the three man team in action.  We enjoyed everything.  They did run out of the delicious looking rolls for the fried egg sandwich, so I got stuck with some busted regular toast that was eh.  

Otherwise, it's worth the wait at this pleasant bustling brunch spot.
author: Caesar R.

description: Wow, their Plow breakfast is amazing.  I love their ricotta pancakes.  This place would be perfect if there wasn't such a long wait for a weekend brunch.  I think we waited almost over an hour for brunch on a Saturday.  Still, it was worth the wait.
author: Caroline S.

description: Great local brunch place. The plow breakfast is everything you want. Eggs, the best crunch potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes (currently), and sausage made in house. You will however wait an hour and a half on weekends for a table. Luckily I live around the corner...
author: Kyle J.

description: I don't often rate places 5 stars, but we had no disappointments for brunch here - awesome Yelp find. Nice, quaint, corner row house... tight accommodations, and lots of people - open kitchen with three seriously hard-working cooks. Everything we had was home-made and xclnt: lemonade, corned beef hash, pork patties, and the brined pork chop. The execution was top notch, and might be the best b'fast I've had since Sarabeth's in Key West. Why, why can't we get these places to pop up in the DC area... uh, we're not chill enough.
author: Chris C.

description:
Great concept, with lots of room for improvement in the execution.  The design of the space is outstanding - great marriage of contemporary and traditional (as you have no doubt learned from the Dwell magazine article - props to the architect!)  The menu is wonderful - plenty of variety, good mix of classic diner-ish fare (nicely updated to reflect the grooviness of the nabe) and creative cuisine.   Service was warm and knowledgeable.  

The only problem was the food.  At breakfast this Saturday, almost everything came out lukewarm.  Maybe it's a timing problem related to being newly opened; also they seem to pre-prepare a lot of dishes (if you look behind the counter you'll see a giant tray full of those heavenly potatoes, previously fried and waiting to be warmed up, along with pounds and pounds of pre-cooked bacon) which shows up in the taste and texture.  Tepid eggs, lukewarm pancakes, cool fried potatoes, and soft, flabby room temperature bacon did not match up to the restaurant's promise.   

Hopefully the opening kinks get worked out soon!  We'd love to return for a nice hot meal.
author: Katy M.

description:
A perfect quaint cafe in Potrero Hill.  Let's be honest, San Francisco is a breakfast city.  For Plow to be open for breakfast & lunch is just right.  Because it's a small cafe, the noise factor in the restaurant can get high and wait on the weekends can be discouraging as families & couples from the neighborhood make their pilgrimage to 18th Street to get smooth roasted coffee, yummy lemon ricotta pancakes, zesty chicken tinga and Nueske bacon.  We left pleasantly content, not full or overwhelmed.  If you're set on making a weekend visit, you'll need to find that sweet-spot of a time if you don't want to walk through an agility course of strollers and high-chairs to have your meal.

If you want to avoid the lines, your best bet is to go on a weekday.  Plow is open from 7am on the weekdays so you can still get your douse of a wonderful breakfast without the wait and bustle.  The staff is friendly.  Having come from the service industry myself, I'm quick to sense & appreciate it when people "like" what they do.  That makes the whole experience (and meal) that more enjoyable!
author: Shari K.

description:
Finally another b-fast place in Potrero. I went for " the plow" and the pancakes blew my mind. Dont miss a good spot for a great meal.

Housemade sausage = top notch 
Pancakes = something like creme brulee 
Potatoes = crunchy and delicious
Hot suace = careful
Eggs = if you get this wrong.....

Maybe not super kid friendly but a great breakfast addition to the hill.
author: Joseph M.

description: Lemon ricotta pancakes, sausages, and potatoes. I've got to admit they were all pretty good and the plate was huge.. BUT it wasn't extremely ravingly good. I think others might have raised my expectations to the point that when I finally tried the food, it didn't meet my expectations. The food was good nonetheless. Nothing memorable about the service or otherwise though.
author: Hannah K.

description:
Here's the problem with Plow. The food is decent (slightly better than average) and hipsters love this place, but they don't know what the hell they're doing and it's about 20% overpriced.

1. We get our name on the list. They said wait would be "around 30 minutes." The wait was 75 minutes.

2. The waitress was nice and very pretty, but after she took our order, she was NOWHERE TO BE SEEN. She never checked in on us and neither did the bus boy.

3. The couple next to us ordered their food after us, and yet, they got their food 12 minutes BEFORE US. WTF? So the pretty but clueless waitress put in the order in reverse order. Nice.

4. The water glass smelled like eggs, which means their automatic dishwasher needs to be replaced or if they're handwashing, they need to not wash their drinking glasses after they wash their breakfast dishes.

5. Again the food was slightly above average, but this experience shows that a poorly run restaurant can ruin even a decent meal.

If you want hipster brunch, I'd recommend Mission Beach Cafe or Foreign Cinema. Also, Dottie's and Brenda's are always solid.
author: Baxter L.

description:
San Francisco is truly a brunch town and Plow delivers their version in a clean and simple fashion. The menu is easy on the eyes and each dish is familiar and approachable to the everyday person. I had the French Toast, sausage patties, and a biscuit on the side. Everything came out fresh to order from the lovely open kitchen, and I had no complaints. Each item was executed as it should have been. None of the items struck me as crazy, amazing, but as noted before, they fulfilled my expectations. 

In regards to the decor and ambiance of the restaurant, I very much enjoyed the rustic, country feel of the place and really appreciated the atmosphere. I felt right at home watching the cooks work the grill top and pans. 

For a no frills, straight forward kinda brunch, Plow can do the job. Nothing done crazy enough to write home about, but good enough to ease your way into the day ahead.
author: Christina N.

description: Solid brunch spot.  The wait here is cray.  Egg whites for $5.50 is cray.  The food is good but on the expensive side.  The homemade sausage patty was delicious.  I was expecting the lemon ricotta pancakes to blow me away.  They were just good.  The chicken tinga was also pretty good.  It looks heavy but was actually pretty light with soft scrambled eggs.  Thank you for not charging SF health tax.  I would go back.
author: Fatty A.

description:
OH MY!!!!!
Hubby and I came here for a breakfast on a Wednesday morning since we had a day off. Thank god we got there bright and early... This place gets really pack no matter what time of the day you come.  We ordered a cup of coffee and glass of freshy squeeze orange juice with  theyre perfectly made french toast and chicken hash. Both were simply Delish!!! Cant wait to come back for  more...
author: Tess C.

description: What a great way to start your day. They have great food! We had "the plow" and the fried egg sandwich for breakfast and it both was delicious! We came here around 9.30am so there was a wait list already. After 20min we had a table. The service is very nice. The food looked good on every table. The savory breadpudding looked so good on our neighbors table:) I'll have it the next time. The eggs benedict also looked soooo perfect! It's a bit noisy in here but it's definitely a nice spot to have breakfast in SF!
author: Katja J.

description:
