Adorable new brunch spot in Potrero Hill. 

The staff is very personable, the interior details are charming, and their crunchy kernel-studded cornbread muffins with homemade butter and jam are melt-in-your-mouth to die for. Their smashed potatoes, quiches, and cheeses are also excellent.

If I could eat at Plow every weekend, I'd be a more pleasant person in general.
author: Jen L.

description:
When they tell you that the wait is going to be an hour and twenty minutes, they're not joking. Really. If you're not keen on waiting, I'd recommend arriving right when they open at 8am, not at 11am like normal Sunday brunchers. 

After an hour and a half chilling on the sidewalk, needless to say we were starving. In fact, I was so hungry I could barely hold a conversation. Luckily, our waitress was super sweet and took our order right away. We decided to start with the bakery basket, which came out promptly and steaming hot and fresh. There's nothing like pastries baked that morning to start a day off right, and these were no exception. The basket featured a corn millet muffin, a currant scone and a buttermilk biscuit, all of which were exceptional with oh-so-good perfect crunchiness on the top. (We might, of course, have been slightly biased by how hungry we were.)

Despite the wait to be seated, once we ordered our food it actually came out pretty quickly. The portions were the perfect size, and everything was wonderful, from the different kinds of eggs to the crispy potatoes to the pancakes to the biscuits and gravy. Oh, and not to mention the creme brulee our waitress talked us into for dessert. Even though we were stuffed, my friends and I were still nearly licking the ramekin. 

Other lovely things:
- Even though the place is tiny, there are high ceilings and big windows so it feels airier and larger than it is
- Service was delightful. There were also enough people working to keep everything moving quickly (except table turnover...)
- The kitchen is entirely open, so you can see everything as it's happening. 
- The menu is full of a million things I'd love to try, and all the ingredients are sourced fresh from local farms.

Unfortunately, because of the hour and a half wait, I don't think we'll be heading back here any time soon. I just can't wait that long for my breakfast, at least not without getting something to eat first.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Everything I was hoping for and more! 
OK, so the wait was a bit long (40 minutes) on a Sunday but boy was it worth it! We sat at the counter which was cozy and gave us a nice view of all the yummy foods coming out. I got the Plow with the chicken apple sausage which gave me a little taste of everything. EVERY SINGLE THING ON THE PLATE WAS AMAZING!
I don't know how some place can make even scrambled eggs more amazing than anywhere else, but Plow manages to make them that way. The lemon ricotta pancakes were moist and delicious. The crispy potatoes perfectly crisp and flavorful, didn't even need ketchup! And the sausage was equally to die for. What else can I say? amazing!
author: Lindsay A.

description:
Yum.  Everything there was delicious.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were amazing.  Yum yum yum.

The wait is long but oh-so-worth it!
author: Jessie F.

description:
We showed up for brunch on Sunday just before 11am with a group of four.  We expected to have to wait, but due to someone else's party not being all there, we were seated within 30 seconds of arrival!  Quite the lucky break.

The food was excellent.  Each of us ordered different things, and everyone was quite pleased.

The pancakes are delicious, albeit quite sweet.  The eggs taste amazing.  People were mixed on the bacon; it was good in food, but a bit floppy and greasy on its own.

And the potatoes!! Oh my, they are truly excellent.  Everyone scavenged every last bit off their plates.

This is definitely a great brunch spot.
author: Ryan H.

description:
Great busy brunch place. The lemon ricotta pancakes were light and a nice alternative to the typical dense sandollars that are served in greasy spoon diners or other brunch places. Homefries were a little too heavy on the rosemary but had the perfect balance of crispiness and potato.

We were quoted a 2-hr wait but somehow lucked out and grabbed a table in 1 hr. They're busy but move tables reasonably fast. Get your name on the list, stroll around 18th (it won't take long) and by the time you're back you'll be seated for brunch.
author: Anne D.

description: The best breakfast that I have had in the city yet! So BOMB! Went on a cold day and it was freezing when I sat outside but it was totally worth it!! I got the fried egg sandwich and I couldn't get enough. Their breakfast fried potatoes were the perfect mix of soft and crunchy. I'm drooling just thinking about it. I would definitely recommend.
author: Jessi G.

description: After reading the reviews, I drove to the city at 7am to try this place. I found parking right away, and the restaurant was mostly empty. I was undecided between the crab omelette and the plow, and decided to go with the latter. the homemade sausage was good but a little dry. The almond pancakes were tasty. Overall, It didn't really blow me away. Maybe I set my expectations a little high? The service was great though and they keep the place very clean.
author: Chris L.

description:
I love this place. Friendly service (although a little ditsy at times, they never bring you a spoon with your sugar, cream and coffee-people stirring away with the butt end of their forks everywhere).
The food is great. I have been at least 10 times and every single time it's great and consistent. Some of my favorites have been: The plow, the potato skin dish with an egg on top and the fried chicken sandwich. They also have great sides (seasonal) and awesome dishes to share.
You may have to wait a way, it gets busy but it's totally worth the wait.
Quality food, great ingredients!
author: Kara S.

description:
Prepare to wait for admission!  The longest wait I've experienced here was an hour and a half, but it can be as short as 45 minutes... Meeh, not so fun.

Waiting aside, I have always loved the food.  They have a constant rotating menu of unique plates and various drinks (fresh juice, mimosas, beer, & of course, coffee) available.  Their chicken apple sausage is delicious... as is the french toast, lemon ricotta pancakes, pumpkin pancakes, breakfast burrito, and the list goes on...

Outdoor seating, yes.

Indoor seating, crowded.

If you can endure putting the time in initially, you won't be disappointed.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Went there this past Saturday.  When I went in, the Hostess approached us to take our name and said that it will be about 45 minutes wait.  So, we come back after 45 minutes, and she remembered who we were and told us that we got the next table.  Good memory!

I tried the ricotta pancakes and the breakfast sandwich.  Both are very tasty and distinctive.  Their coffee was also very good.  However, the best part about Plow is the cheerful attitude of the wait staff.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Had my 3rd visit to Plow for lunch yesterday.  Got their before noon, so we were fortunate to snag a table.  Servers here are amazing.  Always a smile on their faces, efficient at what they do and all around adding value to the whole experience.  

Ordered the lamb sandwich, side of brussels, Cauliflower soup, and the aragula persimmon salad.  They were all really good, especially the sandwich.  Lots of nicely cooked lamb sliced for perfect sandwich biting.  Good aioli type of sauce and great Acme (I think) roll.  Brussels were nicely browned and full of butta'.  Everything was seasoned very well.  

I would give 4 1/2 stars overall, but I really think this place is such a good addition to the hood that I'm averaging up.
author: Aaron N.

description: These is my 3 times to come to try their eve Benedict, how ever everytime was sold out! Fine.... The main complain is, they have bad waitress, look so angry and talk to us so like mad, seems to be don't want to take our order! She just want to walk away from us!
author: Tammie L.

description: Food was really good, but can be overwhelming. Slightly mis-chose. Would have been happy with one piece instead of two of the ricotta pancakes and some meat. Wanna try one of the egg sandwiches next time.
author: Heather R.

description:
I'm not one to vouch for restaurants that often, but in Plow's case, I guarantee that you'll like it... in fact, you'll LOVE it. I should also note that I almost never rate a place 5 stars based on a first time visit, but Plow was so freakin' good, that I feel confident in giving them 5 shiny stars.

Everything at Plow tasted just as good as it looked.

Standouts included:
+Lemon Ricotta Pancakes (house made ricotta, lemon zest, pure maple syrup) 
+Tinga (chicken in tomato chipotle sauce, two crispy corn tortillas, avocado, creme fraiche, cilantro)
+Crispy Potatoes

Mid-conversation, my friend let out a big 'MMMM!!!!" when he bit into his pancakes. I couldn't have agreed more! 

I like the fact that they work w/ local purveyors such as Frog Hollow Farms, Cowgirl Creamery, Monterey Fish Co, Acme Bread & Tcho Chocolate. When you see that they work w/ such local all-stars, you know you're in for a treat. I also really enjoyed Plow's Equator coffee while I waited for our table. And that wait was long! We came in at 11:30 am and had to wait an hour until we were seated. Normally I'd shoot for a much earlier brunch time to avoid the wait, but given that I was prepared for a leisurely Sunday brunch, the wait was pretty painless.

I love the ambiance of this place. It's small, but w/ their high ceilings and all the light that shines in from their big windows, they're able to make the space work; especially decorated in its rustic, modern, simplistic fashion. I love their signage, logo and menu- all well done. They also have stool seating where you can watch the chefs work their magic (like we did!)

The host was cool and our server efficient. Parking was ample (not surprising for Portrero Hill ) and diners seemed to be all SF locals. 

Looking forward to coming back to Plow ASAP to try their Fried Egg Sandwich, The Plow (two eggs, choice of Nueske bacon, house made pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage, two pancakes & crispy potatoes), and/or a Chocolate Eclair.

This place makes me thankful for SF's amazing food scene!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
I knew I had to check this place out when I saw the sillouette of a pig with a curly tail under the sign for this new Potrero Hill establishment. To quote Anthony Bourdain quoting Homer Simpson, the pig is a magical animal.

So what did I find? As expected, a cool new place on the hill attracts the crowds, so you would expect to wait a while for a seat. I waited 45 minutes for a seat at the counter facing the kitchen, totally worth it though. These people work their butts off, and it is amazing to watch.

I got the pulled pork sandwich, which was really quite good. It's not roli roti, but it's close, and it was a very generous sized serving of that magical animal. It came with a side of potatoes that were the real magic. The waiter offered ketchup, but it really wasn't necessary. They seem to be boiled, then half squashed, and then deep fried and seasoned, giving them a half crispy half fluffy texture. So tasty!

They were already at 4+ stars when I tasted the lemon curd tart, which was perfection.

So in summary, this place is worth a visit, especially if you don't mind killing time waiting for the table by drinking some coffee from Farleys. Also, there is self serve coffee just inside the door to the right for $2.75. Come early if you have large group.
author: Marc S.

description: I wish this was walking distance from me but it's worth the short 5 min drive on a Sunday morning. I love family businesses and these two really know how to get it going in the kitchen. Cute place with creative recipes. Wait can be long but that's a good thing in this city.
author: Saf A.

description:
Plow opened in the hood I live in and on an early morning whim my husband and I decided to give it a try. I have high hopes for a place that has as nice as an ambiance as Plow - high ceilings, big bay windows, cute salt and pepper shakers (LOVED!), fun kitchen towels for napkins all with an open kitchen. 

Upon our arrival the host (good looking black dude with long hair and wearing a hat) greeted us and offered coffee while we waited. He was super friendly and accommodating. We were sat at the bar which was fun because we could watch them cook orders. I'm not going to lie - a couple of times I wanted to reach over and grab a fried something or rather and munch on it, everything looked so tasty!

I ordered the French toast and my hubby ordered the 'plow,' a little of everything - eggs, sausage, pancakes (and THAT day the pancakes were ricotta with lemon zest - they were light and zingy and tasted effortless but were completely all consuming. I wanted more...and still do... - ok I'm getting derailed) and potatoes. Yeah, kinda awesome right?! 

Speaking of potatoes - these breakfast potatoes were little nuggets of fried goodness. Crispy on the outside and warm and perfect on the inside. I could eat a bag of these poppers no problem. 

My French toast was great - I got it with bananas which really made the dish. Not as good as Bar Tartine's French toast but that's a high bar to be compared too. 

Overall this is a repeat breakfast spot we plan on dragging our friends/family too - plus, I love that it opens early. But don't be fooled - there'll be a line every weekend starting at 8am on.
author: Tarah B.

description: Great coffee. Really great pancakes. Oh and the bacon...an expensive indulgence but worth it.
author: Tracey L.

description:
This is by far our favorite brunch place if we go to San Francisco.  We've tried other restaurants in the city, but we always regret not coming back to Plow.  I want to give the restaurant 4.5 stars.  The restaurant is definitely small, so expect a 1 hour (or more) wait on the weekends (why I deducted a star).  

My go-to order is conveniently named, "The Plow" which consists of 2 eggs, potatoes, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, and your choice of breakfast meat.  The restaurant offers a slew of other items, but I can never convince myself to try anything else.  The meal never disappoints and the best part I must say are the potatoes.  Twice fried and tossed with some herbs, need I say more?  My bf loves the lemon ricotta pancakes and they are definitely the perfect size given the amount of food you get.  This time, we decided to order the Huckleberry Coffee Cake to share as well.  It was only okay for me.  The cake had a different texture than typically coffee cake (more spongy versus crumbly) and I was expecting something different.  We had to wait a good while to get our main dishes, so our waitress was nice enough to comp us on the coffee cake.  We didn't mind since we were enjoying the nice (but chilly) day, sipping our coffee.  It's a far drive for just brunch from San Jose, but definitely always worth the trek.
author: Michele L.

description:
Love, love, love this place!  Very easy access to get to off of the 280.  Cute quaint residential neighborhood.  Restaurant is at bottom of a hill. Got there at 8:30 am on a Sunday and there was already a line.  Parking was easy at that hour.  If you park on the hill, you park at 90 degrees to the curb. 
This was a birthday brunch with a girlfriend - based on review from other Yelpers and we expected a wait.  But it wasn't so bad. We were seated within a half an hour at the counter for the two of us.  No doubt about it, it's a small restaurant, but they've got their system down. The kitchen is busy and the owner and the wait staff have it down pat.  Service was quick and attentive.  We got our food quickly as well.
We both had the plow breakfast. I had it with scrambled eggs and the nueske bacon(applewood smoked bacon from Wisconsin -where the owner is from), and the best pancakes I've had in a long time. I love the lemon ricotta pancakes people have raved about!  I love the texture, flavor, and it's just amazing.  The nueske bacon was pretty good, too!  
I would definitely go back...maybe on a weekday when it may be a bit on the slower side of things.
author: Racquel R.

description:
It took me four tries to finally eat at Plow. Though they are family friendly with the high chairs and such, the line is always (and I mean ALWAYS) ou the door and not everyone has time to wait around for a table. The place is really cute, bright, and clean, but small. Very small.

That being said, I remained persistant and the fourth time was, in fact, the charm. So excited I was to be inside, that I ordered 3 (yes, 3) entrees. While both the french toast and the fried egg sandwich were great, they were completely overshadowed by my quiche. And when I say overshadowed, I mean I would be ecstatic to get that fried egg sandwich anywhere else, but when compared to the quiche, it seemed like a throwaway.

The lesson in all of this? Go to Plow when you have some time to wait and let the time build your appetite. When you do make it inside, ORDER THE QUICHE.
author: Anna G.

description: Life changing brunch. I eat here pretty much once a week. Lemon ricotta pancakes, almond milk pancakes and the dungeness crab scramble are some of my favorites. During the week is less of a wait than the weekends, but honestly it's worth the wait.
author: Leslie S.

description:
There is something magical about their potatoes :)

Hands down favorite brunch place in the city. The freshness of their ingredients tells you this is a place with integrity and they will serve you real food. The line is long, so get there early! But totally worth every single minute of wait. The food is excellent and you can hardly go wrong with anything you order. Prices are reasonable. You get a good selection of all their best if you order "The Plow". 

Lets get down to the numbers:
Service: Good, but be patient with the line :)
Food: Excellent!
Interior: Perfect for brunch
Price: Reasonable and totally worth it!
author: Ryan C.

description: This place is OK, and the setting is very nice, but it really doesn't stand out over all of the other great breakfast and brunch places that abound in San Francisco (and the East Bay). The food was just OK. It's just not something I would come back here for specifically. The service was good, but the wait time is utterly ridiculous at 1.5 hours even though we arrived at 11:10 on a Saturday morning. I was with friends, and we all wanted to try it so we hung in there. But the food really isn't worth the wait. On the food alone, especially when compared to other breakfast places, I just can't give it more than 2 stars, and I don't recommend it.
author: Maria C.

description:
Yeah, it's really good. The word's gotten out, so this place is a scene for brunch. Be sure you get there early.

I enjoyed my trout salad, but the real winner was the duck hash.

Gluten-free notes: They had a decent number of naturally gluten-free choices and were able to let you know what you can eat.
author: Ellie P.

description: This delightful, open and fresh eatery greets visitors with grace, warmth and delicious bites. The potatoes are to die for...a twinge of rosemary, heavy handed blast of salt and crunch to take you all the way to dinner. The service is spot on, available and not in your way! I loved the GF pancake, a rarity for this glutard. I was thrilled to finally try Plow and can't wait to share it with friends. This is a must dine destination!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Go early...or go on a weekday (unless you don't mind the long wait).
That said, Plow is clean and cozy, with good friendly service. Total comfort food, all sourced from the local farms.

Definitely try their corn millet muffins and lemon ricotta pancakes (both VERY filling). If you want a heftier meal, the fried egg sandwich, and "The Plow" should meet your demands. I'll have to update this review once I have their lunch sandwiches, but so far, I'm quite satisfied.
author: Sharon T.

description:
standard breakfast fare. Small portions, our neighboring table was still hungry after their meal too. Get there early or they run out of certain items. 

Long wait for table and food, but good service. 

Good parking in the area.
author: Jen Y.

description: Long wait but probably a good sign.  They do provide coffee for the wait.  My sister and I split and the Plow order and it was an amazing sampler of delectable delights including: lemon ricotta pancakes,  home made pork sausages, crispy potatoes with rosemary and two eggs any style that your heart desires. When they say crispy potatoes, they really mean crispy.  We actually got specific recommendations to get their potatoes since they are so yummy there and it was totally true.  Forget your usual limp, dry, mealy home fries, these are crunchy, crispy and delightful.  I LOVED the lemon ricotta pancakes, they were fluffy, tart and delicious! I wished I got a whole order of these lovely treats.  We were deciding between the chicken apple sausage but was easily convinced to try the pork instead they were made in house and were delicious.  They were made sans casing and were tasty and succulent.  My friend got the omelet made with spinach and oyster mushrooms and that was amazing as well.  Bottom line: the food here is great and totally worth the wait ;)
author: Vivian T.

description:
I stopped by in the middle of the week and the wait wasn't out of control. The food was something to wait for though! The fried chicken sandwich and banana cream pie we ate were heavenly.

I dreamed of the meal for days....
author: layla k.

description: What a nice breakfast!  Who knew a BLT could be so tasty.  The bread was crisp and light and the organic tomatoes & premium bacon certainly didn't hurt.   The lemon Ricotta pancakes that came w the sausage, eggs and potatoes were some of the best pancakes I've had.  I'll be back here for breakfast again soon!
author: Paul K.

description:
Went here on a Thursday around 10:15.  Already packed.  Does anyone work?  Hate to write a great review as it will just add to the lines!
Three of us had: the plow, mushroom salad and two eggs with the works.  Great stuff
Pancakes, sausage, fries - all part of either the plow or the two eggs were just awesome.  Mushroom salad is something else - fantastic.

We sat inside and watch all the things we didn't order and we will be back.
Service was great.  Busboy also kept an eye out at our water glass and kept them filled.

I hate myself for adding to the lines
author: Bill L.

description: This food is The JAM!! Soooo good!! Worth the wait! Lemon ricotta pancakes are so good but the best of everything is THE PLOW. I am obsessed with their house made sausage and wished they would someday add biscuits and gravy to the menu because their buttermilk biscuit is amazing as well!!!! The buttermilk biscuit is crunchy in the outside and soft and buttery on the inside! I've had a handful of things on their menu and have not once been disappointed. Only thing disappointing is having to wait for it!! But I'm willing to wait!
author: Kim S.

description:
This is the worst breakfast/brunch I've had in ages -- I am still traumatized that I spent time and money going to check out this place.  Of note, I had no expectations and did not read any reviews prior.  In fact, I am now even more shocked that this restaurant has so many good reviews.  The only reason I don't give Zero stars is because I can't.

The french toast was tasteless.  The pears that came with it didn't enhance the taste at all.  I also asked for bananas and since they came later, I was such a state of disbelief that I didn't even try with the french toast -- I had 3 bites and I was disgusted -- no amount of syrup or anything else could save that so called "item".

The second dish (The Plow) was also a mix of mostly flavorless items (exception being the crispy potatoes that were flavorful and crispy).

My suggestion to anyone reading this: if you want a good brunch, basically any other  place in the City will do.  If you want very good brunch, go to Tangerine, Mission Cafe, Tartine, just to name a few.  If you want an excellent brunch, WITH THE BEST FRENCH TOAST IN TOWN, THE GOLD STANDARD OF FRENCH TOATS, go to Foreing Cinema.

I've lived in the City for over 20 years and I honestly do not recall having such a horrible brunch as far as the food is concerned.  The waitress was genuinely nice and polite, but never came back to ask if the food was good.  The fact that we did leave half of the small order on the plate, and more than half of the lemon ricotta pancakes should've been a clue to anyone paying attention
author: d f.

description: So I've heard a lot about this place and I just had to try it out. Came here on a Friday afternoon and it still had an hour wait! Freaking nuts right? We ordered a breakfast sandwich, two egg platter, and french toast. I'd say overall it was pretty good. I can't say I was necessarily wow'd by the food but it wasn't bad. I've heard a lot about the potatoes and while they were tasty with the roesemary and onions, it wasn't like some secret seasoning. Perhaps I got the wrong items and need to come back again for something different. Overall, I wouldn't wait an hr for it again but I would come back.
author: edward k.

description:
The breakfast spot was awesome! Watch out where you park because the asshole neighbors will tow you! I mean know the exact legalities of parking! Because this guy preys on ppl and calls on u if u r even half a inch off! You will pay over $600! 

The owner at 1224 18th street is the grinch who has nothing better to do!
author: Angela L.

description:
Had brunch with a friend here on Sunday.  There was a 30 - 45 minutes wait at 1:30: congrats, Plow!  The place is delightfully appointed in Parisian bistro style, very bright and airy.  My friend had a huge salad with blue cheese and apples plus other stuff -- it was super yummy.  I had the ricotta pancakes -- like eating air, they were so light and fluffy.  Not substantial enough for me, having just finished running 5 miles but really tasty.

They're awaiting their wine & beer license, which will be a big plus, as well as their charge card machine.  Once they have these details ironed, I'm sure it'll be a 5 star restaurant.

Ambiance: 5 stars
Decor: 5 stars
Food: 4.5 stars
Service: 5 stars
author: Kevin M.

description: We came here on a Thursday morning, and were shocked to be able to get a table without a wait. It was our first time (apart from a failed weekend attempt where the wait was so long we decided to buy a muffin--which was excellent--and return another day). After reading the reviews, we decided to try The Plow, pumpkin pancakes, a biscuit and eggs, and a side salad. The salad never came (though we were charged for it, and had to point out that we'd never received it). The pancakes were fine, nothing special. The biscuit didn't come until really late in the meal (which is odd, as you could see them already existing by the register...) and was similarly fine, but not impressive. The muffin we'd gotten the last time around had been spectacular--it was a millet corn coconut muffin--but perhaps Plow is not as impressive on weekdays? I'm not sure what the buzz is about.
author: Californian I.

description:
Amazing food. This is the best breakfast in SF. Love the decor. Servers are terrific. The owner was incredible down to earth person who was an absolute pleasure to meet. 
Highly recommend the lemon ricotta pancakes.
author: Joe U.

description: Plan ahead...get here well before you die of hunger because the wait is long...with good reason. My favorite brunch in SF hands down. Order The Plow and tons of pancakes...lemon ricotta or almond. The crispy potatoes are other worldly!
author: HipsterChick S.

description: I ordered The Plow. Why?  Because if it's your first time at a restaurant, you can't go wrong with the dish carrying the restaurants name. Yes, it's very good. The place is a bit small, with outdoor and bar seating as well as tables. It gets real crowded on weekends and so probably not a good option for large groups. We visited during prime time for Sunday brunch and had to wait about 45 minutes. Well worth it.
author: Nathan E.

description: Honestly, they had me when our waitress noticed that I was cold and brought me a blanket!  Plus, the coffee served while we waited was excellent.  I had the french toast which was great.  My wife had the egg sandwich which she loved.
author: Ajamu S.

description:
First thing everyone should know... There's going to be a wait time. Don't expect to get there and be seated right away. It's that popular! Also make sure that your whole party is there. They won't sit you until then. 
None of these are negative traits, it's a part of business and a place so popular it's completely understandable. 

Now the food! I had the Plow which has eggs, crispy home fries (really good and actually crispy), pancakes and pork sausage. Everything was cooked to perfection except the pancakes. They were slightly burned on the outside so the burnt flavor overpowered them. Sad but still nice on the inside. 

We sat outside and it was a little cold so our food got colder faster but it was still nice to be outside. Ask for a blanket if you're too cold. They are limited and used by others so don't expect freshly clean linens. 

Will visit again, hopefully sooner than later. Not many brunch spots I can recommend, but this one I can. Visit and get some good food.
author: Andrew B.

description: Had brunch at Plow with three other friends. The wait was more than half an hour but it was worth it. We ordered 2 Plows, the biscuit and gravy and the leek/chanterelle omelet, and the baked muffins basket. Everything were great and we polished off everything, although we were so hungry at that point, we would have eaten everything.
author: Alice W.

description:
No.

This place is a scam.

We went  a few days ago for breakfast and were disappointed at every turn, so much so I can not stop thinking about it as it is not inexpensive.

The wait was not as unbearable as many discuss at least it was not for us as we opted to sit at the counter.  The stools move with ease if you are a body builder and the space between diners is aggressive on the part of who determined to pack us in.  The healthy options are scarce.  you may think that all the green lettuces etc make this healthy however if you look closely, its an overpriced diner.  
Generic eggs (meaning not organic or free range,)non organic avocados etc, the perks of sitting at the counter where you see all their food still in their store bought containers and or with their store bought stickers still on them.  Not just a tell tale sign of their purchase decisions but also makes you wonder why they dont transfer their food into chef/kitchen containers to at least hide the fact that they are cheap in the food they buy and serve.  
The other "perk" of sitting at the counter is watching the cooks BAREHANDED make the salads and then scoop up the greens and barehanded plate it.  Yes, I know, some think that wearing gloves is a thing of the past and I could get behind that if the cooks did not have BLACK DIRT UNDER THEIR NAILS.  WE CANCELLED OUR SALAD ORDER AFTER SEEING THAT.  I mean, that was gross.
No dairy free options, no soy milk (laughable since even diners now carry soy milk), no maple syrup for the oatmeal but you can have brown sugar which is worse than white sugar.
We wish we had not gone and were speaking about how at least the coffee tasted good when my my male pal in crime (already needing chiropractor from having to stay tiny so the people on either side of him didnt feel scrunched)  suggested we ask if its organic and then we both decided not to ask as I think we knew the answer and needed to salvage one thing from the place.
author: Kate S.

description:
friday morning brunch, not too bad of a wait.

just had to have the fried egg sandwich to see what all the fuss was about... it was an EGGS-plosion, literally all over my hands. loved the contrast in textures between the toasted bread, creamy yolk, and crisped egg edges. The cheese is what did it for me, what a perfect way to bring out all that egg-y goodness and nice thick sliced bacon didnt hurt it either

over easy eggs all the way!!
author: isabelle g.

description: Amazing breakfast!!! The only reason I give them 4 stars is because of the waiting time (30 mins), but sooooo worth it. I had the gluten free almond pancakes with the breakfast potatoes (crispy and yummy!!). I wish LA had a plow!! Guess I'll have to visit San Fran again :)
author: Jess R.

description: If you are going to Plow, you need to order the plow. The housemade pork sausage is TO DIE FOR. As are the rest of the components- house potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, and 2 eggs. The plate is a great combination and is the perfect amount of food to leave you satisfied and account for a breakfast and a lunch. I would not give Plow 5 stars because of the waitresses and the wait. The wait has increasingly gotten longer and it seems to be getting swamped by techies who must work in the area. Nonetheless, if you are willing to wait 1.5 hours on a Saturday morning, go to Plow.
author: Vanessa B.

description:
I came here for brunch with friends today & it was great. We did have to wait outside for about 45 minutes for a table (and it was cold out!) but the hostess was super nice. 

I ordered the arugula salad with winter squash, pomegranate, hazelnuts and ricotta salata because I'm off gluten. My friends got the Plow special (eggs, bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes) and the biscuits and gravy. We all gobbled all of our food - everyone agreed everything was delicious all around. My only real complaint is that my salad was very over-dressed. (Why do restaurants put so much dressing on salads??) My friend who ordered the biscuits and gravy said the gravy was super (too) buttery and a bit too rich. But hey, it's sausage gravy.

Also - we didn't order the fruit on the side but we should have when we saw our table neighbors'. They had gala apple and asian pear slices, fuyu persimmon slices, and half of a mango, cubed. It looked AWESOME. 1000% better than the gross melon-pineapple-grape combo with maybe a single strawberry on it that you usually see at a brunch place. 

I'd definitely come back here. The neighborhood around it is super cute as well & parking was really easy at 12:45 on a Saturday.
author: Kate W.

description: Plow's potatoes are out of this world, and yes, it's close to two hours wait, but you can have coffee or mimosa while waiting, so not too bad and you'll thank yourself in the end for waiting :)
author: Charlie M.

description:
Really, really good.

That's it.  There's not much else for me to say.  I had the scramble, which was light and fluffy and very flavorful (love those chanterelles!), although I think the best thing on the plate were the potatoes.  Next time I'm going for the fried chicken which looked delicious.

So one of the owners/managers/proprietors chatted with us and said that the space used to have an architect, but then they left and it was empty for a year or two.  So he and his buddies would sit at Bloom's across the street, drinking and talking and one day one of them said, 'we should do something with that place.'  And they did.  And it was good.
author: Eric W.

description:
Arrived around 10:30 on a Sunday, yeah, not the ideal time to arrive for Sunday brunch at a place that doesn't take reservations. The host said we would be in by 11, unfortunately we were not seated until 11:15, ouch. Luckily the food made it worth while!

I loved the decor, modern/country/homey all at the same time maybe it was, because we had been standing outside in the cold and it was raining...who knows. 

Our server was super friendly and told us about the daily specials.

We ordered the bakery basket to split between four of us, which came with a scone, a corn muffin, a biscuit, butter, jam & honey. I love scones, but enjoyed everything in the "basket", which turned out to be served on a plate.

The lemon ricotta pancakes were freaking delicious, small, but I would definitely recommend them!

The French toast looked awesome, but my brother finished it before I got a chance to try it; it must have been good.

The daily quiche special was fig, leek and egg custard, which was savory and sweet and totally delicious.

I ordered egg whites with toast, chicken apple sausage and potatoes. Everything was wonderful, like your traditional breakfast, but everything tasted fresh and natural.

Loved the food & atmosphere, not so much the wait, but I'm sure I'll be back!
author: Elaine S.

description: Just stopped by for the "limited" lunch menu on their first week.  The grilled cheese was good, complemented well by a Mexican coke.  The space is really fantastic- intimate size, but with high ceilings, nice light, and attractive tables/flooring.  Chatted a little with the husband of the married owner team, who seems like a good guy.  Definitely planning to head back and see how they expand and develop!
author: Thomas R.

description: Consistently great quality of food and service.  I've been here several times and my best bet is to go with the Plow breakfast - two eggs, sausage or bacon (I prefer the chicken apple sausage), two lemon ricotta pancakes (absolutely delicious and fluffy), and amazing potatoes.  It's worth the wait and definitely worth coming on a weekday when it's less crowded if you can!
author: Lidia L.

description:
I am so delighted that plow has come to Potrero Hill!  

As a brunch connoisseur, I am very particular about certain things:  the bacon, the potatoes and the eggs.   I am very critical of these three qualities for breakfast/brunch and. . . plow passed with flying colors!!!

The bacon. . . Nueske's apple-smoked bacon.  It's like the Porsche of Bacon.  The potatoes were yukon gold. . . parboiled ahead of time, then fried into crispy potato heaven tossed with caramelized onions and herbs.

I had the fried egg sandwich with a yummy soft bun, frissee, aioli and bacon plus a side of those fried potatoes. Breakfast perfection!

I sat at the bar and enjoyed the design of the space, the flow and rhythm of the staff. . . I especially loved watching how they handled the produce and prepped the dishes.  A nice little touch: dish towel napkins.  A lot of love and attention goes into these meals.  You can taste it!

I also appreciated the staff --- super personable and available.  They care!  They love the food!

My only complaint was that my tea wasn't strong enough. . . and that my stomach wasn't big enough to eat three more meals!
author: Freida N.

description:
This place is super charming, and their service was too. They were fast, friendly, and well, super friendly. 

That being said, I reeeeeally wanted to love my lemon pancake and didn't. I mean, it wasn't bad. But I didn't love it. 

I'll give the other foods a try sometime but not right away-it's kind of expensive for breakfast that isn't going to blow my mind...
author: L P.

description: Totally worth the 30-45 min wait. Great food, friendly staff. Arguably, one of the best egg benedict in SF
author: Marcelo P.

description:
Plow continues to be one of my favorite brunch spots in the city.  My friend and I only waited 20-25 minutes for an inside table (chalking it up to people being out of town for the holidays ;p), but we were bracing ourselves for at least a 45 min wait.  The staff was really friendly and timely with their service... as soon as we sat down our cups were filled with coffee!  Their dungeness crab scramble (with fresh crab meat!) was delicious, as well as the side of crispy potatoes.  

Even as we wrapped up our meals and continued to chat, my friend and I never felt rushed to vacate the table.  I really appreciated this because for a place like Plow where there's always a long line, you would think patrons were quickly shuttled in and out in order to accommodate all the hungry customers.  That wasn't the case; We were able to enjoy our catch up session without feeling pressure to hurry, and the staff continued to fill our coffee cups even though it was clear we were done eating.  

For their great service and outstanding, fresh food, I always include Plow on my recommended list of brunch spots in the city, even if the wait can be more than 20-25 minutes!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Not much room but the food is excellent. If you are there at breakfast (or not) you must have the Chinese breakfast. If it's lunch time - Monte Cristo. Not the healthiest in the world since it's fried but your taste buds will love you.
author: Duane R.

description: This joint is well worth the 2 hr wait. Advice: go to Blooms across the street and get totally tanked first.. And override the ham on the Benedict w/ Nueske bacon. Huge upgrade you'll thank me latr. Best brunch ever
author: Jeremy G.

description:
My first experience at Plow was very pleasant.  Starting from the friendly host who seated us to the owner (the husband, the wife is the main chef busy cooking), our waitress, the ambience, the vibrant energy at the restaurant and the food.  It's a great place for breakfast, lunch and brunch!

The menu looked interesting to me.  Immediately the Crispy Pig Ears on the menu caught my eyes.  I rarely see this dish on a western restaurant's menu and was curious about the dish so I ordered it.  I liked it a lot!  It tastes almost like fried pork chops or salt and pepper pork chops except they served this dish with vinegar.  It was tasty.  I would go back just for this dish. But try it only if you are a food adventurer.

Then we ordered an orange scone to savor prior to our brunch.  It's warm therefore tasted good, but for some reason it didn't "wow" me.  My friend on the other hand was crazy in love with it.  

I ordered the Plow from the brunch menu.  I LOVE the 2 miniture pancakes made with the cottage cheese!  They tasted really good!  It also comes with your choice of egg style.  I asked for sunny and they were good.  There are also multiple choices of meats you can chose for Plow and I decided to try their homemade sausage.  That was a bit disappointing.  I like my sausage juicy and tender, but they were dry and too dense to me.  The flavor was delicious.  One last thing worth mentioning is their potatoes.  They are really good!  I'm not a big fan of potatoes, but I finished all the potatoes given on my plate.  They were crispy and flavorful!  Delicious!  I would go back for the potatoes and the pancakes as well!

Then I think we also tried their cremebulee, but can't remember much.  I'm not sure if I was in food coma already that's why I don't remember or it wasn't memorable.  I will have to try it again next time I go to Plow and share with you later.  


Give Plow a try!
author: Gina W.

description:
Just my luck, I'm on a modified South Beach diet when I finally can get in to this place.  We were told it was a 30-40 minute wait for a party of 2, but we checked back at 20 minutes and got seated within about 5 minutes - great.

The food was delicious.  My husband had the fried egg sandwich, which looked wonderful - especially the potatoes on the side.  I had the chicken tinga, which I can only imagine would be that much more tasty if it had come with the tortillas which I had to decline due to the diet.  Also had a side of bacon - good, but how can you go wrong with bacon?

I would love to come back when I'm off this diet.
author: B. Y.

description: Arrived early (before 8am) on a Friday morning and were seated right away. We ordered The Plow [2 eggs, 2 small lemon ricotta pancakes, bacon (or sausage) and crispy potatoes], as well as an order of the French Toast (mascarpone and strawberries on top). Both were delicious! Staff was friendly and street parking was easy that early. Will be back again soon! With a pot of tea, I think our total (including tip) was about $45.
author: L S.

description:
Best brunch in San Francisco! The lemon ricotta pancakes, all of their fresh salads, the muffins, the mimosas. All awesome. 

The only weird part is that they only carry Youk's hot sauce. That stuff tastes like clogged drain. If the chef at plow could make a homemade hot sauce to go with their bomb crispy potatoes, I would be very very VERY grateful.
author: Mariposa D.

description:
So many times I write a review and wonder why I'm only giving 3 or 4 stars, not 5.  Now I know why- because a 5 star experience is one where you leave and ask for business cards, so you can make little gifts for your friends that say, "When we have free time, I want to take you HERE."
This was such the place.

We arrived at prime lunch time and had to wait about 20 minutes.  The woman ahead of us in line for a table did not have her full party, even though the other guest apparently just lived across the street.  I watched the hostess handle that delicate situation with poise, charm and humor.  She offered to go fetch the friend herself, and when that was declined then she explained that she had to give it to us instead.
I was impressed.

The room is quite charming- a great pale sage green, tons of light, great Tolex chairs & stools, lovely views from every window.  The tables are quite nice, as all the marble counters, and we liked that they hid the bathroom door with a floor to ceiling curtain.  

All service was great.  The busser recognized us from a catered event we all worked at last fall, and he made a point to say hello and welcome us.  

The food was awesome!  Seriously.  Everything we ate was delicious.
We split 3 things- the roasted lamb sandwich, the bread pudding and the trout salad.  
We inhaled everything and even got some muffins to go, for tomorrow's breakfast.

And as I said, I'm already making a list of friends I'd like to take back next time we go.  

Yay for finally having something to give 5 stars.  No doubt.
author: Alisha A.

description: We were lucky to come across this place on a recent trip to SF because it was close to where we were staying, and it was quite a find! The first time we came here it was about 10:30 and there was an hour wait. We decided not to wait and came back the next day at opening because the pictures of the food looked so good on Yelp. I'm so glad we came back! The next day we had no wait and were seated quickly once the place opened. I got "The Plow" which comes with crispy potatoes, two eggs, choice of bacon, pork sausage or chicken sausage and two lemon ricotta pancakes. I got mine with the nueske bacon and I have to say it was the best bacon I've ever had. Slightly sweet and salty and they were very generous with the portions. The crispy potatoes were also a hit and I was just disappointed I couldn't manage to finish them all. The lemon ricotta pancakes were pretty good as well. Just enough sweetness and a good lemon flavor. My only complaint is that they were a bit on the dry side and lacked fluffiness. The freshly squeezed orange juice was also a plus. The place is very small and it was completely packed when we visited. Despite this, service was great. I look forward to visiting the Plow on my next visit to SF.
author: Gema S.

description:
Great space, great food, amazing attention to detail and clients!
Maxine, thank you! And your staff too ;)
author: jet b.

description:
First off, I wish there was a half-star option because I'd use here to boost UP to 3.5 stars, as Plow was closer to good than just A-OK.

First the food: everything we ordered was great: egg scramble with fresh tomatoes, greens, goat cheese; lemon ricotta pancakes; eggs benedict with crispy potatoes; steak and scrambled eggs; and a plate of fresh nectarines, figs, plums, and melons. Our gluttonous bellies were full and satisfied when we left. We sat at the counter and watched the dishes come off the line, which was essentially food porn in action.

All the staff we interacted with were friendly and welcoming, worth a special shout out when considering the intense brunch rush in the place.

Now for the bad: the wait. The stated 45 minute wait for two people became a bit over an hour, which is ok; the ebb and flow of restaurant traffic can't be predicted sometimes. By the time we sat down, we were understandably ravenous and wired from a couple cups of coffee in line. It took ten minutes for our server to get to us, and once we ordered, it was clear that everything was going to come out together 25-30 minutes later. We managed to get our fruit plate out early, but after waiting 90 minutes, we wish the food would have been paced better to get some of our sides out. We share some of the fault on this one for not conveying how hungry we were (and in turn how long we'd already been waiting), but wish the server would have picked up on this. Maybe we wear gaunt really well?

Worth going to--plan for the heinous wait and you'll be happier.
author: Sean K.

description: Everything good you've heard about Plow is true. I can vouch for the impeccable potatoes, lemon ricatta pancakes and egg sandwich. I would be there every weekend if it weren't for the hour wait.
author: Shannon K.

description:
Best breakfast of my life!
A bit pricey, but worth every penny.
Fresh food & service!
author: Lloyd B.

description: I went here for breakfast and it was delicious!  The potatoes were phenomenal along with the rest of the food. The staff was friendly and checked in on us the perfect amount.  Great places to sit for a bit in a more casual place and enjoy a great breakfast.
author: Bobby S.

description:
I came here with a friend before Indie-Mart. She ordered the Plow plate: with eggs, lemon pancakes, sausage. I had the eggs benedict. 

We both thought our food was good but nothing memorable enough to drive from our respective neighborhoods for. If it hadn't been for Indie-Mart being walking distance, we wouldn't have tried this place out. It's a trendy spot and its awesome for the neighborhood because it needs more up and coming restaurants like Plow. But I don't consider it a destination brunch place, like Just for You cafe, or Axis cafe, both in that part of town.
author: Maria A.

description:
this place kinda nails it for me. Although I have only been there twice, they run a very tight ship and impress me with their simplicity. They handle a small dining room and large crowd in a very friendly manner, never making anyone feel like a burden as some places can do. 
The last time I dined here it was a Friday lunch rush. Our 4 top was seated within 15 minutes and were immediately served. I had the fried chicken sandwich, my friend an egg sandwich with bacon and avocado and her parents had a bowl of kale soup (really kale and farro) and a bbq pork sandwich. Everything was very well done. 
I highly recommend Plow for either breakfast, brunch or lunch.
author: Saul G.

description:
One of the best brunches I have had in a long time! My friend and I had a tough time deciding on our order because, literally, everything sounded delicious. I ultimately selected the smoked trout salad which contained tender bits of fish, perfectly dressed frisee, hefty chunks of avocado, slivers of grapefruit, all punctuated with juicy bursts of pomegranate seeds. I topped it off with a side of scrambled eggs (to make it "brunchier"), and we shared an order of their heavenly and remarkably light donut holes: just crisp around the edges but soft and warm inside and rolled in plenty of cinnamon sugar. And though I didn't have room for much more, I have an excuse to go back and try the rest!

The hostess was very honest about the wait -- "about an hour," she said -- and an hour it was. But we grabbed coffee at Farley's and took a few laps around the neighborhood, so the time passed quickly. And I would say it was well worth it!
author: Sara Y.

description: In the past few weeks, Plow has frequently become the main topic of conversation when talking about brunch. Unless you get there around 7am on weekends, you are looking at waiting over two hours which is insane if you ask me. This morning I just so happened to be in the area and drove by to see many open spots inside so I decided to stop and see what all the fuss is about. I was seated immediately and was able to get in and out of the establishment in under a half an hour which was awesome. The food was great. Worth waiting two hours for? Probably not, but then again I'm not sure any food is worth waiting two hours for. I ordered The Plow which consists of two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes. This was not cheap as the price of admission was $15.75, but it didn't fail to satisfy. The potatoes were some of the best I've had in the city, super crispy and salty. The eggs were scrambled to perfection and the pancakes may have been the highlight here. And the bacon, was well bacon. You can't really go wrong with bacon. All in all, the entire experience was enjoyable and the waitress even prevented my from getting a parking ticket as halfway through the meal she warned me there was street sweeping. The neighborhood is a little out of the way if you are just visiting, but there is a great view of the skyline from across the street. Definitely worth checking out if you've got some spare time. Would highly suggest avoiding this place on the weekends. #foodcomaking approved.
author: Food Coma K.

description: Went with the boy.  Long wait (1.5 hrs plus), but ran some errands in the meantime.  He had fried egg sandwich with avo, was above ok.  Good potatos (nice and crispy).  I had the huevos rancheros (with scrambled eggs), under impressed.  Shell was crispy, refried beans were ok, but there was no ranchero sauce or any sauce for that matter.  Was topped with avo, creme fresh and a little pico de gillo.  Mimosa was a little more OJ than champs for my taste. Service was fine.
author: Sheetal P.

description:
This is a SOLID FOUR STAR establishment.  I had breakfast with my wife this morning and it was wonderful.

My wife had "the Plow" breakfast (lemon ricotta pancakes, sausage, crispy potatoes, scrambled eggs) and I ordered the "Scramble" (chanterelles, goat cheese, scallions with salad and acme toast).

The service was excellent -- and the coffee was hot and strong.

I will be back.  Well done, this is a good new addition to the SF restaurant scene.
author: J. SOMA S.

description:
Plow has been voted by our group by a 3 to 1 ratio - a small constituency - as our favorite breakfast eatery with the best team working there, from the friendly Joe and Randall offering coffee while you wait (in actual porcelain mugs), to the amazing eggs and bacon, luscious ricotta lemon pancakes, perfectly crispy fried 'tatoes and smiley wait staff ** shout out to Ms. New Zealand, what a treasure. another time we lunched there and saw a couple of local celebs - politicos, and we all had wonderful dishes.

Another plus is easy parking. It's probably not good for groups of 4+ cause it's not a huge place. The owners also have a wine shop up the street so it's kind of home grown with people from the 'hood. Always a nice touch when they know who you are. it's very consistent, so check it out!
author: Ron W.

description: The food here is very good, especially for brunch. But be warned- the lines on the weekends are ridiculously long! If you get there before 9 it's a lot more tolerable. You can always pop over to Farley's and get some coffee while you wait. Definitely try the lemon ricotta pancakes and the house-made sausage.
author: Diana G.

description:
Had breakfast today here and can only say that everything we ordered was perfect.  As a matter of fact, I have not had a better combination breakfast plate than the eponymous "plow" - wonderful lemon ricotta pancakes, earthy, house-made pork sausage patties, freshly fried and marvelously spiced potatoes (with some caramelized onions thrown in for good measure) and fresh farm eggs - now that's a breakfast plate.
My companion - who has some decidedly southern proclivities - was immensely pleased with the biscuits served with Gravy (capital G here!) a text book version with pork.  Rich!

Naturally, the place is hopping but the solicitous staff makes sure to seat everyone as promptly as possible and service is friendly and efficient.  We sat at the counter and had the opportunity to observe the incredibly hard-working crew of three young cooks, their movements as choreographed as Bolshoi dancers, as they cooked everything fresh and perfect.  Hats off to those wonderful cooks!
author: Thor T.

description:
The staff is charming/hospitable & engaged in conversation with what seemed like every single patron - dining or waiting.  

Everything here is absolutely delicious!  If anything, go for the crispy potatoes & bakery basket.  As a savory bruncher myself - I highly recommend the cider brined pork chop - it was moist and well... delicously SAVORY. 
 
The ambiance, equally charming, consist of modern-farmhouse-style reclaimed wood tables/countertops & industrial style chairs and barstools.  Eco-friendyly note - even their salt and pepper shakers are made of recycled glass.

A definite top contender in the SF brunch scene!
author: Tina T.

description:
The Food:
1. I am gluten-free and they have options for me. That's ALWAYS a plus. On top of that, the option I chose, The Plow, was delish! I LOVE their bacon.
2. I do wish they would have had a better option for substituting out the pancakes.

The Ambiance:
1. It's a little small but doesn't seem noisy.
2. I like that they tell you up front that they can't seat parties of more than 6.

The Price:
1. Surprisingly, it was priced perfectly. I was impressed by the fact that they are mostly local and organic, and priced so well.
author: Min M.

description:
So after waking up unusually early on a Saturday morning, I came across the latest issue of SF Magazine, which happened to be the food issue.  I saw that Plow had received three stars and having long been on my "to-try" places, I decided no better time than the present (especially considering the wait would considerably be less at 8:30am than later in the day).

Turns out, there was no wait at all!  We got the last two counter seats offering excellent views of the dishes.  

Although I am definitely more savory than sweet when it comes to taste, I couldn't pass up the chance to try the famous lemon ricotta pancakes.  They were so airy and light and fortunately not too sweet at all.  Not sure what the batter secret is but I can understand the hype.  That being said, I couldn't help but crave some of the savory options that I passed up (especially the savory bread pudding, which looked amazing!)

Also had the fried egg sandwich served with frisee and optional order of bacon.  While simple in execution, it was quite delicious and served on a lightly toasted bun.  The accompanying crunchy potatoes tossed with herbs and spices were excellent.

I can see why this place gets packed (in fact, we apparently beat the rush as a wait began almost immediately after we were seated).  Crazy how people flock to this Potrero Hill outpost ... the power of good reviews, I guess.

The one BIG minus here is the smell of the water glasses.  It reeks of egg protein.  I know that some people can't smell it but for those that are sensitive to it, it's almost enough to make one lose his appetite.  The problem is that these glasses are placed in the dishwasher with all the plates that had contained egg yolk and it mixes.  It would be great if they could wash these separately or at least pre-wash those egg-tainted plates.

Service is very friendly and welcoming.   Note, not recommended for large groups because of limited seating (in fact, 6 is the max).
author: F. P.

description:
Rate: 4 Stars

Food: AMAZING. The food is simple yet very sophisticated. It's hard to beat a brunch place like this 

Reservation: none

Wait: not too bad if you go early or way late (like around 2:30pm before closing). choose wisely!

Ambiance: Simple. Enjoy watching the chefs cook at the counter area or sit outside and enjoy the weather. 

Cost: Fair

Experience: Three of us went at 9:30AM to get seated, and we waited about 30 minutes. I think the wait-list varies by day but it's best to go early if you can. Great restaurant to eat! 

Overall: Definitely go again!
author: Bee H.

description:
Epic addition to the Potrero Hill breakfast and lunch landscape. I tested their breakfast skills via the ultimate litmus test: Egg Sandwich. Sheer perfection (get it with bacon). 
Bfast-mate had pancakes - they were lemony delicious. 
Gorgeous decor and great vibe. Will return many times I am sure. 
Can't wait to try lunch.
author: steve m.

description: Quality breakfast food. A little on the heavy side.
author: Andrew H.

description: Breakfast here might make you shed a tear.  I know I did.
author: Emmanuel F.

description: The food was excellent. The crispy potatoes were amazing! I had the soft scrambled egg with asparagus and mushroom and I loved it!  The almond pancakes were good but didn't taste like almond and I would've preferred fresh fruit vs compote on it. The wait was a little too long. Overall it was a great experience.
author: Elahe H.

description:
I got the plow - pancakes, potatoes, eggs, and choice of meat (pork sausage for me).  The pancakes and potatoes are outstanding.  The pancake is super moist and fluffy and has a great flavor (lemon ricotta).  The potatoes are super crisp.  Not so into to the pork sausage - would probably do chicken apple sausage next time.  

The wait here is ridiculous though - we waited for an hour.  Parking isn't plentiful, but we were able to find some a block away.
author: Piggy S.

description:
If not for the long waits, I would give the place 6 stars for best brunch in The City.  We have waited 1+ hours to snag a table here, but it was truly worth it.  Now this husband and wife team used to work at the beloved 42 Degrees, way back when.  Fast forward 15 years, they have taken over a lovely, light-filled space on Potrero Hill.  Nothing fancy, but clean, modern, yet comfortable.  You can't help but smile even after you waited outside for an hour.  It's a cheery spot.  And that's before you take your first bite of food!

We usually order The Plow, which is a short stack of lemon-ricotta pancakes, choice of bacon or sausage, and two eggs.  Now let's talk about the potatoes for a second here.  These are the crowning glory of the place.  They literally make the experience unforgettable.  I'm not a chef, but I do cook some and it seems to me the yukon gold potatoes are fried once, smashed by hand, seasoned with salt, pepper and herbs, and then fried again to a crispy, golden brown.  I am not doing them justice thru my description.  Go ahead, wait an hour on the sidewalk and tell me these don't make you do cartwheels.  They're that crazy good.
The coffee is strong, dark, the juices freshly squeezed, the breads are artisan.  Service is so friendly, so congenial, that if they spilled my potatoes on the floor, I would still give them a warm hug.  Assuming of course, I get a fresh plate of these beauties.

I have yet to venture out and try their fried chicken sandwich, although just sighting it, it looks like it has a strong chance to be a contender against the fried chicken sandwich at Bakesale Bettys or Marlowe's.  

Another unfortunate another minus (along with the wait) is the lack of a full bar.  Sigh.  Can't have it all I suppose.  This comes pretty damn close, I guaran-damn-tee ya.
author: Angelo S.

description: Great crispy potatoes! Fried egg sandwich was amazing!
author: Kristoff F.

description:
First time eating at Plow this morning. It was awesome! My friend and I split the french toast and lemon ricotta pancakes. Both were fantastic although if I had to do it all over again I'd get the pancakes and bread pudding dish (it's a breakfast version). 

We got there at 9:30am and had to wait less than 2 minutes for a table. The host with the dreadlocks was really friendly too.

The service was perfect. We had no complaints. We'll be back!
author: Kimberly S.

description:
Worth the wait. Get there as early as possible to get your name on the list...because there will be one.

The french toast was awesome, perfectly cooked and the bananas on top were all kinds of amazing. I pretty much licked my plate clean.

We sat at the bar, which was crazy cramped, but it was a great opportunity to watch the cook staff and observe the popular food items. They were making up LOTS of the ricotta pancakes, which are definitely what i'll be ordering next time.
author: Marit S.

description:
Ah, I am so glad breakfast spots like this exist!  I was tired of greasy spoons that serve overcooked eggs in pools of canola oil.  Sometimes, you want to wake up and have some clean, fresh breakfast eggs and potatoes and you don't want to carry it around with you all day!

I went here with a big group of 8 last weekend and considering how small plow is, they were quite happy and willing to accommodate us as soon as they could (which on a beautiful Sunday took about 20 minutes).

The food is delicious.  We tried almost everything.  The breakfast basket had a warm, savory corn millet muffin that melted in my mouth.  The jams were particularly tasty as well.  The orange scone and buttermilk thingy had just the right amount of sweetness - I hate overly sugary scones!

We also got quite a few salads - now somewhere in the review list a person was freaking out about rotten greens.  In my experience, we got EVERY kind of salad and there was NO ROTTEN greens.  The arugula had dressing on it, but it was fantastic and complemented the persimmons perfectly.

Other highlights - the fried egg sandwich. It's huge, and when you bite into it, the yolk pours out.  Mmmmm.  The french toast and market omelette were fresh and tasty.  The housemade sausage patties were perfectly cooked.  And the pumpkin pancakes made me want to do a backflip.  Of course, our plow dish was filling and fun.  I love eating eggs, potatoes, and pancakes all in one!  And they're mini-pancakes so you're not overly stuffed.

Finally, we got this pumpkin cheesecake at the end. Normally, I don't like cheesecake because it's too rich and sweet, but this one had cream and pumpkin spice that blended just right.  It was all, I'll say it again, delicious.

My final say is that if you're looking for a greasy spoon, this is not the place for you.  But if you're looking for a clean, fresh breakfast/brunch with top-of-the-line ingredients (they even list the farms/food places they get their ingredients from at the bottom of the menu), then go to plow!  It feels great to leave brunch and not have a rock in your stomach.
author: Annie F.

description: My wife and I went here a couple months ago while in SF after our friends recommended it to us. One word to describe the breakfast........PHENOMENAL! The array of flavor profiles and the unique menu options set this place apart from many other breakfast spots. I had the plow which was a great mix of sweet and savory, the lemon ricotta pancakes were like dessert! My wife had the huevos rancheros and said they were amazing (that's impressive, because she has high standards for mexican food). If you are ever in SF, you HAVE to check it out. I promise you will be thanking me.
author: Josh C.

description: Love Plow, hate the wait. But, alas, I always think it's worth it after I finally get to sit down. It must be the ah-mazing potatoes. They're amazing! Actually, everything I've had on their menu has been awesome. Just get their early!
author: Christina S.

description:
I came here on NY's Eve and there was a bit of a wait but it wasn't so bad. It's a tight space that's cozy & warm with a nice intimate feel to it. Despite it being packed and crowded with people such as myself waiting to be seated, the wait staff managed to keep smiling and were friendly!

My lunch date and I only had to wait about 20 minutes before we were seated and I'm not sure if it had anything to do with it being the holidays but the wait wasn't bad. I ordered a salmon plate and my date had something I can't recall. I do recall both our plates being "ok" but not anything phenomenal that would compel us to endure the long wait for if we decide to come back. 

Our overall experience was good and we MAY come back but don't think it'll be anytime in the near future is all I'm saying.

P.S. I'm not a big fan of potatoes but I must say, their potatoes were DIVINE! :D
author: Soozie H.

description:
After my Nth attempt to try Plow, I decided to just suck it up and wait the long, long, long wait for a table.  You can expect to wait about 40-60 min for a table.  Luckily people gave up and we were seated within 45 minutes.  There's a nice coffee shop you can visit less than a block away while you wait.
 
The Food: 
The potatoes were fried to a nice crispy texture with a light seasoning of salts and spices.  The chicken-apple sausages were delicious and a nice combination of slightly sweet and salty.  The French Toast (small size comes with 2 pieces) was delicious, soft, and moist.  

The food was pretty tasty and I would recommend trying Plow at least once if you have not before and don't mind a wait.  Good luck!
author: Tina K.

description: YUM! I've been here for brunch twice now and loved loved loved it. The menu is creative but familiar which I appreciate at brunch. The wait is pretty ridiculous, but it's nice that they'll serve you coffee or mimosa while you wait!
author: WaltzingMatilda T.

description:
Gourmet country cookin.  Looks beautiful, tastes scrumptious. Menu online = drool.
http://www.eatatplow.com/menu/

Sunshine and rainbows all around.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Really great place for brunch.  Another reason why I want to live in Potrero Hill.

The restaurant has a really nice vibe inside.  The words that come to mind right now are warm, fresh, clean, comfort, and modern. Right when you walk in, you see the open kitchen with seating at the counter (they even have purse hooks underneath - love it).  Both times that I've been here for brunch on Saturdays I had less than a five minute wait (hooray).  So far everyone that I've met has been very nice and attentive (please don't lose that as you gain more notoriety).  

The first time I had the open face egg sandwich with pork sausage and crispy potatoes.  Both delicious and an adequate serving size.  

Yesterday I ordered the egg scramble and I thought it was "ok."  The eggs were good, but I was a little disappointed by the portion size of the scramble and I think this time I only got like, six small pieces of potatoes (but I got two pieces of toast, though.) Hmmm.  Very strong coffee, too.  

I'll still come back.  Next time I'll just have to order the open face egg sandwich.
author: Christie X.

description: Wow!! So worth the wait. Food is consistently amazing and we have eaten there at least a dozen times.
author: Tamara H.

description: Fanfreakingtastic. Can't wait to go back! It's tiny so the wait gets long, but definitely worth it, just grab a mimosa!
author: Alex C.

description: Breakfast sandwich, lemon recotta pancakes, and THE PLOW are delicious.  Haven't tried anymore.  Looking forward to the next breakfast there. Definitely worth stopping by.
author: Ian P.

description:
This is a really cute place with outdoor seating during the weekends.

I'll repeat what others have said - the crispy potatoes are yum!

Everything else is ok but not a standout (lemon ricotta pancakes, french toast, bacon, etc.)

If there wasn't always such a long wait I might come back as parking is easy but...I'd rather go to Zazie next time!
author: Cathy L.

description: Good breakfast & coffee.  The place is a bit small so come early for a table but if you have to wait it will be well worth it!
author: Mikky T.

description:
Went on a Saturday morning at 8:30 because they open at 8.  The place is tiny, but not packed together and not noisy.  Two big plusses.

It is on a corner and very light filled and airy.  Sort of the hip Potrero crowd.

Sat at the counter and watched all the goings on in the open kitchen.  Ordered the plow.  I agree with everything Erica S said.  The lemon ricotta pancakes are to die for.  Portions just right.

Made my best brunch list.  A real find.  We will definitely go back.
author: Alan B.

description: My favorite brunch place by far! Yes, get there before 10am (after that is loses a star for the wait time). Food is awesome, staff is nice, open kitchen is cool. Sit at the counter if you can!!
author: Alyssa M.

description:
One of the BEST places I've been to for brunch.

Come wearing comfortable shoes and bringing lots of patience on the weekend - an hour wait is not uncommon.  Thanks to the kindness of my girlfriend, who was there an hour before we had to meet, by the time I walked up to the restaurant, I only had to wait 3 minutes before her name was called.

As with all good brunch places, what to order caused some angst as there were so many delicious items on the menu.  I am not a "potatoes" person, but had heard that their potatoes were crispy on the outside and creamy on the inside so I got those along with eggs and homemade sausage and ricotta lemon pancakes.  Oh, and one order of the crème filled donut for dessert.

Oh, everything was so good!  Eyes were bigger than stomach so the donut and half of my plate went home with me.  Looking forward to yummy left overs unless my other half discovers them in the fridge.

Our waitress was very nice and the coffee was very good.  They only had one unisex restroom, which there always seem to be several people waiting in line, but it was clean and large.

I will have to go here again to try their biscuits which they ran out of.  And for the potatoes as well.

Worth the trek from Marin to San Francisco.
author: Nancy M.

description:
So, I live across the street. If nothing else, it's great to have an alternative to Hazel's for breakfast, since nothing else around here opens until 11.

But it is, on the whole, very good. I like to give most everything on the menu a try at least once when I frequent a restaurant, and so far there is nothing that I dislike. The food is simple, well-prepared fare with just enough flair to keep it interesting. The coffee isn't the best; yes, the potatoes are the best. Add grits to this menu and I'll be satisfied.

The staff is friendly, and prompt enough. I'm just not big enough of an ass to get uppity if the waitstaff doesn't prostrate themselves and lick my boots when I grace them with my presence, unlike most people. They work, thumbs up.

I adore the style of the place. Well designed, rustic looking, comfortable.

Weekend brunch is usually packed.
author: Casey M.

description:
Really loved this place!  The yelp reviews citing lemon pancakes I knew my wife would love sold me.
 We were there late morning so the wait was slightly brutal. They were kind enough to give coffee to those shivering on the sidewalk though. And it was serious coffee to boot.
The crispy home fries are outrageous and dangerous to have discovered. These are just nuts and far and away the best I've ever had  Terrific. 
Noise levels seem to be intentionally high so conversation is not really a good option. ( unless you are really into sharing )
I'll definitely be back, come earlier, and be ready for the buzz and slightly "am I hip or what" vibe.
author: Steven L.

description:
I found Plow by just typing "breakfast/brunch" into the yelp search and this was the first or second listing in the district I was in; figured I'd give it a try.

I most definitely pleased from the moment I walked in.  A small, unassuming, almost modeled after a highway breakfast joint, restaurant with one major visual difference; It's clean!!

The service is quick (I went on a tuesday in the late morning, from other reviews it seems weekends are busier), the restaurant is very quaint, and the servers are very sweet.

The menu, we were there for breakfast, was not overwhelming and each item on the menu was unique in its own way.  I decided to go with "The Plow", which is the restaurants specialty, I guess. The serving was large enough to fill my gut until late afternoon (I'm 6'0" 160 lbs) and came equipped with 2 eggs, my choice of a meat (unique to other breakfast restaurants), home fries, and the best pancakes I've ever had... Lemon Ricotta Pancakes...  My mouth is watering just thinking about them: creamy, rich, moist, with just the right mount of lemon power in them.  However, they are small if you get them with "The Plow", they may be bigger if you order just the cakes.

Overall, my only negative feedback was the price, I'm not disappointed AT ALL but I paid a lunch/dinner price for breakfast.  However, I'm from Florida so I might not be 100% attuned to the California lifestyle just yet.

Most definitely give it a try.... pancakes... /drool
author: Richard H.

description:
A simple Sunday morning excursion turned into a wonderful dining experience. Interesting menu, wonderfully throughtful space, professional greeters/staff and in the end just outstanding food. The egg sandwich was executed perfectly, the potatoes nicely crisp and the lemon pancake that I grabbed from my buddy was amazing. The portion sizes were perfect. For those of you looking for a Grand Slam 2000 calorie breakfast please go elsewhere and leave the tasty dining to the rest of us. I will be back for sure. Not good for a group over 4!

My only recommendation would be the installation of an outdoor bench for overflow waiting.
author: C K.

description: Small place but clean and looks fancy! Foods are very fresh but little pricey. I definitely go to here again when my next business trip in SF.
author: Andy A.

description: The brunch here is very good!  We came here with a group and almost every single one of us ordered the "plow" because it is a sampling of all of the good stuff - ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, chicken sausage (which was great) and eggs.  Yum!
author: Vanessa L.

description: Went here one morning (never again) and waited by far the longest time I've waited to eat anywhere in the city. The wait was 45 minutes which then became an hour and half. We tried to leave and go see the wait at other nearby places and drove around even though they had a wait, albeit shorter we figured by the time we get back it should be time. We weren't giving up and should have! We returned and still waited. It was like a game and we lost and ultimately ended up eating there. Lol  The food is descent but not good or even great. The same things can be found anywhere. The menu is small with limited options, so why does it take so long to serve up the food. Zazie's for instance has a shorter wait time and their menu is larger. The service was crap. The waitress couldn't even muster a smile, she seemed to have a bit of attitude even, maybe she was tired but that's not problem. Ugh! Never again
author: A V.

description:
Lovely atmosphere. I recently moved, but potrero hill has my heart -- and we know that the way there is through my belly.

- friendly host, owner

- absolutely delicious menu (changes frequently, but i am confident choosing my dish from the menu blindfolded...everything i've had there is fresh, simple, classic)

- super affordable, clean, unpretentious
