Get there early, eat sooner.  Park on cross streets off of 18th, plenty of spots available.
author: Nasha L.

description:
This place is delicious. I highly reccomend the lemon pancakes.  The fried egg sandwich is good but nothing I've never tasted before.  The potatoes are decadent.  The service was also great and al the staff were really friendly.  Parking was also easy.  

CONS: The wait is a little ridiculous for brunch and I don't know if I would wait again for an hour when there are a lot of good brunch places in the city.  Definitely a place to try.
author: Tamara A.

description:
Love Plow's Sunday Brunch with lovely California sunshine! The atmosphere here is so chill with friendly staff! Plow has the best crunchy potatoes I have ever had so far! The only thing is that the wait can last up to an hour on Sunday. 

 I would recommend Plow to others as long as they don't mind waiting. =)
author: Lianna D.

description:
The wait can be crazy, but if you go at the right time (between 7-8 in the morning) or at off peak lunch hours, you can usually snag a spot, at least at the counter. 

All of the food is great. I will say that Plow has the best home fries / breakfast potatoes that I have ever had. Fried until crispy, tossed with spices and herbs. They are out of control and go great with everything else Plow brings to the table.

If you have never been, get "The Plow" for breakfast. Comes with one of their lemon ricotta pancakes and house made pork sausage. Also has potatoes, eggs your style and toast. It's big, but if you're hungry, you will not be disappointed by any part of it.
author: Louis A.

description: Long wait and a little expensive, but really good breakfast. The Eggs Benedict is delicious! One of my favorite breakfast spots in SF right now.
author: Ryan N.

description: I love a breakfast special. The house plate lets you try everything and is actually a good value, which is a real stand out among popular breakfast places which are often over priced. The only thing to improve would be somehow leveling out the tables on the sidewalk slope, but that would probably involve a permitting process. Anyway, great spot!
author: Gabby G.

description: I would come here every weekend if I could wake up at the crack of dawn or were willing to wait for 1+ hr for a table. Hence only 4 stars. Their potatoes are delicious, ricotta pancakes are light & fluffy - would be even greater if they were bigger. Sitting at the counter, watching your meal being whipped up is a treat. The farmhouse, cottage decor is beautiful & fits right in with the Potrero Hill 'hood.
author: Ada L.

description: My son and I went to this restaurant after reading about them on Yelp. We had worked most of the night and decided to treat ourselves. We entered the place and the inside was very nice and seemed clean. We ordered mimosas and eggs, potatoes and DRY toast. The server brought out our drinks and there was a large bug floating in my son's drink. We let the server know and she replaced the drink. Then we got our food, they shorted my son an egg and there was a generous slathering of butter on our toast. We don't eat cow body fluids, they make us sick. Not having much time left before work, we just finished the rest of our breakfast without complaint. I left my son to pay the bill and I walked up the hill to get our car. The bill was $50. Kind of expensive for eggs even with one drink each. Later I started feeling unwell and was wondering (not sure why I did not think of it at the time I was drinking it) if my drink was poured from the same containers as my son's and if there was bug larvae swimming around in my stomach. Those concerns and the expensive bill caused me to e-mail the restaurant and ask. I got a call from someone from the Plow and after convincing him that I was not my mother (she lives in Texas???) he gave me some mealymouthed excuses about how the bug could have only come from inside the clean glass and not the champagne or orange juice. I just don't believe him, bugs like food not glass. Anyway, he said they were sorry. I guess that's taking responsibility nowadays. I say skip this one and go to anyone of a hundred other places who serve a better, cleaner, bug free and less expensive breakfast.
author: Mike E.

description: There is always a line on Sunday but there is a science to limiting the amount of time you have to wait. Who would wait over an hour for an egg sandwich? I would and I do. The potatoes are sick.
author: Michael M.

description: We came early so we didn't have to wait an hour to eat one Sat morning. The space is very cozy and small, hence the long line to eat here. I got the fried egg sandwich which was very good and not something to eat if you're on a diet. The potatoes were a little heavy, greasy, and burnt crispy for me but I ate a couple pieces. I felt like it was a good meal but it was a little pricey and far for me to come here on a regular basis.
author: Vivian L.

description: I had read so many amazing reviews about this place that I was afraid my expectations would be too high. We went last Sunday at 8:30 am with baby in tow. Even at 8:30 am we still had to wait about 15 min for a table. I ordered the plow with the house made sausages. My husband had the plow but with bacon and my friend ordered the Mexican dish (sorry can't remember what it was called but she licked the plate clean). Oh the ricotta pancakes were really good as everyone has written. Slight tang and very tasty. I have to say the meal was tasty and the service was great, but I don't think I would wait longer than 35 min. Plow is an empirically good restaurant but not extraordinary. We had a good meal and I'm glad we tried it.
author: Linda C.

description: definitely best traditional breakfast in the city. prepare to wait as there's always a lineup here but its so worth it. you know a place is good when they put effort into even their potatoes. ive been here twice so far and the food is consistent and service is great. would definitely go back.
author: Vijith N.

description:
I came here with a small group to remember a friend who used to frequent this establishment. Although he's no longer with us, I'm thankful he indirectly lured me to plow, as it was an excellent choice and I can see why he used to love coming here.

We arrived a little after 11 on a Sunday for brunch, which led to an hour-and-a-half wait -- and turned out to be completely worthwhile. When I entered the crowded doorway of this intimate space, I was promptly greeted by the incredibly gracious and cool host/front-of-house manager. Great start. A friendly, genuine smile can go a long way.

They had some coffee sitting out, to which we helped ourselves, under the impression that it was complimentary for waiting customers. Unfortunately, we misunderstood and were charged $2.75 a piece for batch drip coffee we had to serve to ourselves, and I did not get offered a mug or replenishment of my cup once seated. The coffee was excellent, and ultimately I didn't really mind paying for it, but I just wish it had been more clearly marked as something that would be added to the bill. But that was really the only downside to the experience, and in the end, the overall quality of service and food made up for it. Oh, and bonus points for the dual-flush, water-saving toilet in the restroom.

Anyway, back to the food: I had the egg sandwich -- two eggs, arugula and cheddar on an Acme bun. Delicious. The bun was grilled to perfection, and the eggs were prepared perfectly. The potatoes that accompanied the sandwich were also incredibly good; very crispy on the outside, and soft in the middle, with mildly caramelized onions. Yum.

It's rare that I make the trek out to Potrero Hill, but because of plow, I may need to come out more regularly.
author: Jamie T.

description: I almost always order the Plow with the pork sausage.  My mom had the Dungeness crab scramble when it was in season and it was good too. The only negative is the wait.  The line can be long on the weekend.  Just ask for a coffee while waiting.
author: Lenny C.

description: Probably the best brunch I've ever had in my life. I ordered the plow, which I customized to be composed of lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, two fried eggs, and chicken apple sausage. This was my first time trying lemon ricotta pancakes, which I was little apprehensive about at first, but it has probably become one of my top pancake flavor choices. I also really enjoyed the potatoes which were seasoned perfectly and had a nice hint of rosemary. I would have given this place five stars, but my party and I had to constantly keep requesting for more maple syrup and ketchup.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Delicious food, all the way around.

Equator coffee: outstanding

Coffee cake: warm, fresh, light, and delicious

Scramble: fluffy, flavorful, nice ingredient mix, tasty

Potatoes: great texture, yummy

Lemon pancakes: fantastic

Nice atmosphere, kind people, good value for an SF brunch
author: Ben T.

description:
This place was great! The downside: we literally waited 1.5 hours to be seated. In that time, my friend and I did a huge circle around Potrero, SOMA and Folsom Street to come back to wait for 30 more minutes. Sunday brunch is only for the strong and brave. 
My friend had The Plow, with which she was very pleased. I'm not a big bacon or egg person, so I ordered the French Toast. My Gosh. SOOO GOOD! The strawberry lavender compote with mascarpone... divine! It was so much food, I ordered the small and could only finish one. I took the other slice to go. The large plate, which has 3 pieces is probably best left to the hungover and those with an insatiable metabolism. The bacon was amazing and again, I'm not even a bacon person. The bacon is sourced from a farm in Wisconsin, where the owners are from. Cute little anecdote. 
The ambience is great, the food is amazing, but that wait- damn. Get up early for an early brunch or do like we did - wait it out. But highly recommended!
author: C L.

description:
I have a thing for looking at trademarks and good business names, and Plow is a great name (my favorite being Crunch gym, despite not being a customer there).  If I had a restaurant, I probably would have named it Plow, so I was very excited to come and try this place.  

There was about a 45 minute wait when we got there around 12:15 pm on a Sunday, which was ok, because we just walked up and down the hills in the neighborhood and got an awesome work out for our bums.  The food was very good - for the most part.  The salmon cakes and side order of potatoes was spot on.  The lemon ricotta pancakes, while good, were not as fluffy as they appear, and I've definitely had better (although not in SF).  I'll be back to try the salmon benedict.
author: Ernest S.

description: Great place for breakfast! We came here on a Sunday around 9:30am and there was already a one-hour wait. We were about to leave but the hostess convinced us to stay saying that we wouldn't regret it. We filled ourselves up on some coffee and tea and cornbread muffins while we waited outside. We're really happy we stayed! Our whole party ordered "The Plow" with house made pork sausages and bacon. The potatoes were so crispy and delicious. I would totally come back again!
author: Amy N.

description: Joel and Maxine are the owners of Plow and are amazing people. They are so kind, they have perfected breakfast. Without a doubt this is the best breakfast place I have been too. I ordered the plow plate and it was a little bit of everything which was perfect! I highly recommend getting the almond flour pancakes, delicious!!
author: Hayley P.

description:
Quality ingredients prepared and served with a sincere smile. 

Hands down the best bacon in town. Lemon ricotta pancakes that melt in your mouth. LOVE the potatoes !

Super friendly and attentive wait staff, and the owners go out of their way to make people feel welcome.

Word is out about their high quality eats, so it is best to go on a weekday if you don't have the patience for a long wait. OR, just walk over to Bloom's Bar for a quick mimosa while you wait !
author: B. B.

description:
You have to be ready to wait.  We got there at noon on a Saturday and were seated at 1:15pm.  Very popular.  The restaurant is very small, the staff friendly and the food very good.  The tomatoes tasted super fresh.  The spinach was divine.  The eggs were so fresh that they filled us for the whole day.  The ricotta pancakes were lovely.  

It is expensive though.
author: Sailing A.

description:
Fantastic new brunch spot! 
The ricotta lemon pancakes are a must for the table as an app.
We followed that with the beet citrus salad, lamb sandwich (which completely impressed our middle eastern friend who is very lamb-specific if you will). the chicken tiga and the breakfast sandwich.
A great way to start a beautiful Saturday in SF.
Here's to many more meals at Plow.
author: Brooke H.

description:
For someone who almost never gets excited about or craves breakfast/brunch food. I absolutely loved my meal here. The food made me happy :)

I ordered the plow:

Lemon ricotta pancakes - the ricotta gave it an amusing texture

Potatoes - !!! Best potatoes I've ever had. Hands down. Really crispy and well seasoned. Perfection.

Scrambled eggs - asked for them on the runny side - really fluffy and light - can eggs be ribbon like?

Sausage - they were good but I would want to try the bacon to see how they compare

My bf had the crab scramble which was also really good with fresh crab and well cooked eggs.

I would recommend coming early or you'll end up having to wait 1hr plus :| People were eating outside in the rain - well there was an awning at least.
author: Amy H.

description: Not impressed. After waiting forever for a table, the host seated a couple who arrived AFTER us, BEFORE us. Then when we sat down, the server took the food order for the people who sat down AFTER us, BEFORE us...even though we had been sitting there waiting to order. I got the soft scramble and both my eggs and potatoes were drenched in rosemary. It was so gross. Wish I could like this place, but forget it. It was also LOUD, like terribly loud. And the service was not good.
author: K. N.

description:
Great addition to the neighborhood!  Beautiful, welcoming space and a friendly staff.  

On the first day of weekend brunch service, everything was going smoothly despite a consistently full dining room.  The food that came out was lovely and hearty - a scrumptious egg sandwich, a very tasty pork sandwich (flavorful pork cooked beautifully with delicious pickled beans on the side), and perfectly crisped and seasoned potatoes.  

Cash only for now.  Looking forward to trying lunch and exploring everything on the menu!
author: tara l.

description:
My wife and I came to this quaint little corner establishment on a recent busy weekend. By the looks of it, we arrived just in time because we only had to wait a few minutes for a table. The restaurant is very small, but laid out as smartly as possible, with an open kitchen, counter seating, and lots of small tables with just enough space for the waitstaff to navigate. I didn't even notice the hostess, who was standing directly behind me, until she offered us a cup of coffee while we waited. This was one of many nice service-related touches at Plow. That said, the waiting area is small and not especially comfortable. So be early, or dress appropriately. Even on the inside, the entire restaurant suffered a little whenever someone opened the door.

Once seated, table service was fast and friendly. Our waitress, dressed to the nines in the finest vintage apparel, gave us the quick walkthrough of the menu. We each opted for the restaurant's namesake breakfast. It arrived not long after: Two incredible-looking plates of breakfast: poached eggs, a short stack of lemon-ricotta pancakes, bacon (for her), sausage (for me), and smashed potatoes / homefries. The pancakes were the best. They were light, not too sweet, and tart. The poached eggs and my wife's bacon were very good, too.  Unfortunately the sausage disappointed a little, and while my potatoes were great, my wife's were underseasoned. 

Given the service and the pancakes, I'm tempted to give plow my full recommendation. However, the coldness (not sure there's much  to do about that), the blandness of the sausage, and the inconsistency in the potatoes forces me to hold back a little. Still an excellent place and one that I'd love to revisit if I happen to be in San Francisco any time soon.
author: Joel R.

description: Food was a little posh, expensive, but tasty. Definitely get the Plow. It was a good amount of food and delicious.
author: Bethtina W.

description:
Saturday brunch wait around 11am - 30 minutes.  We walked around the neighborhood (Christopher's bookstore, FARLEYS, baked, and some other gift shops around the area)

You have to consistently check in with the host because I noticed that he did not come out of the restaurant to call out tables being available. With that being said, it is a bit irritating because there are plenty of opening and closing the door (there is a wind draft) too. 

We were lucky because we were offered either to sit by the open kitchen or in the back. We opted to sit by the open kitchen. 

I LOVE WATCHING CHEFS IN ACTION. 

DECOR - Modern, simple with metal high chairs and marbled counter tops. It reminds me of being in NYC because of the big sprawling windows as well.  

FOOD - I ordered the Duck Hash with leeks $14. I thought the duck didn't have much flavor. It was chopped up duck and it was prepped ahead of time already. The leek was there but I didn't taste much of the flavor. 
It came with two eggs and two pieces of toast.  The eggs were well made.

The PLOW was a standard pancake (it tasted good with a lemony flavor? i dont remember, a bit fluffy) homemade sausage patties (not too salty which is good), eggs, toast and scrumptious potatoes. 

KITCHEN STAFF - Two Mexican line cooks and probably another two in the back area cleaning the dishes.  

Everything is open so you can see the preparation.   

PARKING - easy street parking in Poterero.

SERVICE - pleasant staff 

I would come back on a less busier day.  THREE STARS FOR FOOD I HAD, FOUR STARS FOR DECOR and SERVICE
author: Jboogie L.

description:
What a memorable breakfast /brunch this was.  We ordered from the counter, and had the mixed Plow, with two small lemon ricotta pancakes, scrambled eggs, their unbelievably delicious bacon, and the home "fries".  All extremely well prepared and served.  The home fries are really special, as so often what you get in a restaurant are soggy, over greasy potatoes.  These are light and fluffy, exploding with flavor. 
Wow is all I can say.  They have really raised the breakfast bar.  Wish I lived in San Francisco, but for sure it's going to be on my "must go" list for the next visit.
author: Gail B.

description: good stuff if you can wait for it, loved my breakfast french toast lunch with caramelized bananas and thick farm style bacon. Yummy!
author: Aaron R.

description:
Had breakfast at Plow yesterday after reading the reviews on Yelp.  We showed up and the wait was an hour.  This place is teeny tiny, but I will give them credit, they had people moving in and out of there at a decent pace.  We did wait the full hour (maybe a little more), but the wait was worth it.  

I ordered The Plow, which is 2 eggs, crispy potatoes, a breakfast meat (I chose bacon), and two lemon ricotta pancakes.  The food was EPIC.  The potatoes were absolutely crispy on the outside, soft on the inside and were made with rosemary and white onions (I'm sure there were more seasonings, but I don't have the most discerning tongue).  The lemon ricotta pancakes were perfect little clouds of perfection.  They were cooked to perfection with a fantastic lemon taste.  It is my personal mission to learn how to make these.  

My friend had their salmon eggs benedict, which she basically described as the best she has ever had in her life, and that everything was cooked to perfection.  The staff was great, and they even provided free coffee for their customers waiting outside in the rain.  

Worth the wait.
author: Meranda M.

description:
The Continuing Case of the Missing Papaya Diamond: By Detective Honeybutter

"An hour wait?!" I scoffed sarcastically, dramatically raising my eyebrows to make it clear to the nearby onlookers in the small eatery that I would have none of this tomfoolery.
"My good man, I missed being knighted by the Queen herself by only three ounces of blood. Had I been conscious I would have been Sir Honeybutter!"
They did not look impressed.
"I have looked into the eyes of the devil himself..." (and then softly to a nearby horrified lady) "... granted in a carnival's haunted house ride where I nearly defecated in my pantaloons..." (and then loudly again so everyone could hear) "...but I have seen things that would make you question your own faith in humanity! I mean, have you SEEN that documentary on the Bieber maiden?" At this point I was escorted out of the building as I yelled on about respect and was asked to wait outside with the others. Whatever happened to respecting a British detective?  
A bloody rut. That's what I was in. The Case of the Missing Papaya Diamond wasn't having a lot of traction. Not for a bloody lack of trying, mind you. Imagine a montage set to a funky bass groove where I kick down doors and chase down perps in dark alleys, screaming at them for answers. And by "chase down perps in dark alleys" I mean "eat a lot of waffles" and by "kick down doors" I mean "take naps". Not sure who I was screaming at outside of the montage, either. No, this was a critical rut. 
It was a Saturday morning stroll that brought me here to Plow. That, and the aroma of bacon. But this common occurrence of having to wait an hour to be seated still baffles me. The fact that most people are fine with this means that I'm either a savage barbarian with no patience or that I'm missing a key vantage point to this observation. So I just stood there in the morning sun, waiting. Thinking about the case. Thinking about little details. Things I might have missed. Overlooked. Suspects. Locations. 
And then it struck me. That eureka moment delegated to only the greatest breakthroughs in modern science and medicine.  
By Toutatis. Of course!
It was here that they called my name and I promptly forgot about my epiphany. Plowed! You may think than an hour goes by quickly when solving mysteries, but my hot tip here is that even though they say it's an hour wait, it probably won't be. Most people don't hang around long enough so you sort of move up the list to get seated. 
I had a dish called The Plow at a place called Plow. It was a decent mix of eggs, amazing bacon (I need to go back and investigate the bacon), magical lemon ricotta pancakes (because it's 2012 and science figured out how to give us this boon to culture) and SWEET MENTAL TIDDLYWINKS THE POTATOES! 
Oh golden crunchy potatoes, wherefor doth thou embrace my taste buds so?
I took my sweet time finishing this meal and will come back soon. It was when I finally waddled away that I remembered the epiphany. 
Game on, Baxter Borneo. Game on.
author: Brevin P.

description:
I can already tell that this place is going to a staple in the SF brunch scene.  Fresh food, quality ingredients, and great space.  It is also one of those SF places that you do not want to come to with a large group.  Luckily, it was just me and the hubby.

Things that I loved: 
- The ambiance - I think they executed the farm fresh concept well.  It feels airy (bright open space) and quaint (fresh food from the farm) at the same time.  What I'm basically saying is that I was happy while I dined there, ok?
- The country potatoes - crispy edges,  but not dry.  Awesome job!
- The bacon - it's hard to go wrong with bacon, but the slices were thick and juicy
- The fresh cup of coffee less than a minute after we were seated, enough said
- Parking wasn't an issue...gotta love that in the city.

I didn't love my eggs.  The ricotta pancakes were only ok, and I can see a potential problem with the wait, which is why it's a 4 star for me.  but I'd come back on mornings that I can get out of the house before 10.
author: Wendy L.

description: This restaurant has by far the best almond flour, gluten-free pancakes I've ever experienced (they are better than my mom's pancakes!).  Everything on the menu is farm-fresh and the servers are friendly and attentive. Eating brunch here should be a priority for anyone visiting San Fran.
author: Susanne M.

description: I didn't know if it could live up to the hype but it's the best brunch in the city - well worth the wait!
author: Kelly K.

description:
I've been meaning to review Plow for a while but my computer crashed and I was sent into the dark ages for a couple of weeks.  

Walking into Plow is like walking into your Yuppie Pottery Barn-loving, Audi driving, high-tech working friend's home on the Hill.  The space is airy with amazing windows.  The owner Maxine is super nice and focused on making homey food.  She bakes the desserts herself.  As a home baker, I love that.  

The potatoes that come with entrees are delicious - fried with onions and salt.  I really enjoyed the lamb sandwich that is on the menu of late.  The lamb is sliced off a roasted leg and is perfect with the ciabiatta roll. 

I also enjoyed the smoked trout salad with pomegranates, avocado and topped with a poached egg.  This salad might be the perfect lunch.  I see this on the menu in the winter with sliced apples.  Hint, hint.
author: Monica L.

description:
Came here on a weekday.  It was already packed.  We waited about 20 minutes (not bad) and were seated at the counter.  I love their open kitchen and watching the cooks at work.

I got an egg sandwich with bacon and Vince w. got the plow.  I'm sure it's their ingredients and the farms they get their produce from because that was one yummy egg sandwich.  I'm probably so used to eating eggs from hormone injected chickens that I'm used to it!

The plow order came with some yummy pancakes.  They are dollar pancakes though, but cooked to lemony perfection.  I'm not a pancake fan, but i liked. he also got the chicken apple sausage with his order since they ran of the house made pork sausage. boo.  The chicken apple was fine, nothing out of the ordinary.

The potatoes were yum, with just a pinch of salt. 

The service was spotty as I had to get my own ketchup, but then she asked us if we needed water like 5 times. *shrugs*

Go for the eggs!
author: Genie S.

description: Breakfast Review: went early, 7 am on a weekday. The scene was calm.  Tons of soft morning light was flowing through the massive wall of windows. The coffee is delicious. I ordered "The Plow". Bacon was perfect. Almond pancakes were also pretty good....a very nice consistency, light and not too cake-y (often, gluten-free flours yield dense and chewy cakes). Great service. Pricey, as the meal with a good tip put me in at $26.
author: Brian H.

description: I really enjoy my brunch here.  We were seated pretty quickly and the service was great.  I had a breakfast sandwich which was really good and my only complaint was that the egg was runny but I didn't them tell I like my fried egg over hard.  The potatoes were to die for.  I would definitely recommend this place for a casual brunch with great food!
author: Kirsten M.

description:
Beautiful space and super tasty food. Ordered a side of potatoes to go with my pancakes and am so happy I did. They were some of the best breakfast potatoes I've ever had. Ever. I ate them all even though I didn't mean to.
Only reason I give it 4 stars is because even though I was there as a party of 2 on Friday at 9am I had to wait about 15-20 mins for a table to open up. There aren't many tables to sit at and I can't imagine what the wait would be during a more popular dining hour.
author: Mallory O.

description:
This place is very quaint in it's location, and size of the restaurant. From the outside/inside it looks quite new. They have an open kitchen when you walk in with bar seating. I have to say the food is very good, they make it a point to use local foods, and it does show in the end. This place is worth trying out if you are in the area looking for a brunch/lunch dinning. The fried apple pie is awesome for desert!
My only concern is that the waitress was kinda fast in the sense she only came for the order, and food. Granted the place was busy, but I was only with another person.
author: Nathan M.

description:
The food is delicious but the service is average. 

I've been twice and both times we had to ask several times for creamer or jam or anything else that did not come on the plate were were served.   No coffee refills offered either.  

If you can get past the service, the food is delicious.  My husband loves the plow breakfast.  The homefries are among the best I've tasted.  Love, love, love the Dungeness Crab scramble.  Toast was too hard.  If you get the plow breakfast, trade the home fries for a fruit dish and you won't be sorry.  Homemade sausage is pretty amazing too.

Go early on a weekday and you won't have to wait :)
author: Brenda B.

description:
Housemade pork sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes and addictive double-fried crispy potatoes.

Tuscan kale caesar, topped with parmesan, avocado, and crunchy walnuts.
author: around town e.

description:
Nice ambiance - lots of natural light, open kitchen (eat at the bar!), comfortable atmosphere.  Our service was very friendly and the tab for two breakfast entrees, plus two coffees was $25-30.

The food was all 4-star quality.  I'm pretty sure their house potatoes are the best I've ever had - crispy and well-seasoned on the outside, creamy & delicately sweet on the inside.  The scramble was fluffy, creamy (had goat cheese) without being undercooked.  And the lemon-ricotta pancakes (with Vermont maple!) were moist & delicious.  Great coffee, too.  My only slight gripe is that I expected the pancakes to be of the thinner variety (from photos here), but they were pretty thick.  

And, while it's becoming more of a standard in SF, I applaud them for sourcing from the local bounty when possible and listing their providers on the menu.
author: seema s.

description:
Liked this place just fine!  It's a small place and it's popular so you'll have to go expecting quite a wait... especially on weekends... but that's ok... especially on lazy sundays... we waited about 45 minutes...the same they told us the wait would be...  We got a table inside... nice... clean..... host/hostess were very cheery and nice... service was excellent... I always like that at a restaurant.  Food was very good.  I got the plow and potatoes were very tasty (I guess they'd have to be because they're deep fried?), bacon was good, eggs were done to my specification, lemon-ricotta pancakes were small and manageable and tasty.... all in all, a good experience... 

good service always equals the 5th star!
author: Easter E.

description:
My friend and I came here for lunch one day and walked in around noon - just making it in time before the lunch rush.  We got seated at the counter and was able to watch the chefs in action.  

We decided to share the Roasted kabocha squash salad (mmm chicories!) and the vegetable sandwich (grilled eggplant, zucchini, roasted red peppers, herbed goat cheese) and were very pleased by the flavors.  

I definitely plan to come back again and try their brunch menu next time.  Just another reason why I love going to Potrero Hill for eats - there's so many hidden gems!

Love the airy space.  Love the food.  Love the staff.  Love the vibe.  Absolutely love love love!
author: Carmen Y.

description:
Plow offers a clean and relaxed atmosphere to enjoy a fresh and delicious breakfast/brunch.  I came here jet lagged after getting off a trans-pacific flight, looking for a satisfying meal that features fresh ingredients.  Plow did the job for sure.  

I had "the plow" there for $13 -  "two eggs, choice of Nueske bacon, house made pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage, 2 pancakes, and crispy potatoes."  I saw the Chinese sausage there on the menu, and they allowed me to substitute that for my sausage choice.  The food came relatively quick, presented nicely on a white plate.  The server was very attentive and nice while conscious of not being bothersome.  

Overall, Plow is a place that I'd come back to as well as recommend to my friends.  It's not a great value since the price is somewhat premium for what you're getting.  But it's also very fresh and clean, so the price is fair.  Come check it out!
author: Leo C.

description:
Awesome new breakfast spot on the hill. They have the type of menu that makes for a difficult morning decision making process. Should I have the savory bread pudding, or the biscuits and skillet gravy? Whatever you choose, make sure you try the amazing bacon, and the country potatoes. 

Well worth the wait!
author: Tom C.

description:
Yeah - Plow is my new favorite breakfast place in the city. I've been there a few times now. The food consistently impresses and the service is no-nonsense. The food is exceptionally good and original while staying true to the american style breakfasts that I know and love. My only really knock on Plow is that I wish they were a little bigger so they could handle all the demand. Thankfully they open early though so treat yourself to the most important meal of the day some time before work.

On top of being an exceptional restaurant the owners are actually really nice as well. They also run the Ruby Wine store just a couple blocks down 18th which has great wine.
author: Charlie S.

description: I. LOVE. PLOW. I seriously cannot say enough gushing things about this place without making people think I'm being facetious. The way they do their crispy potatoes reminds me a little bit of Lola in Seattle; smashed and fried so they're crispy on the outside with a fluffy center. In a word, "spectacular!" I always ask for a little of their aioli to go along with it. The Plow is their "greatest hits" plate and in the past I know they had blood sausage on the menu, which was wonderfully done! The setting is also beautiful and intimate, and the service is always spot on. Every time I've been there, I've seen the husband and wife who own Plow behind the counter, talking to customers, which I think really shows how much they enjoy being involved in the business. I'll never stop loving this place and I can't wait to go back!
author: Ava J.

description:
sweet jesus!

my girlfriends treated me here to a birthday brunch and it was hands down THE BEST BREAKFAST COMBO EVER.   this is now my new favorite brunch spot.  we loved absolutely everything.  even leftovers the next day were still excellent.  service is friendly and sweet.

get:
-plow breakfast (2 eggs, lemon pancakes with real maple syrup, -potatoes and your choice of bacon or chicken/pork sausage)
-corn muffins
-beignets
-breakfast sandwich

we arrived at 10:15 and lucked out with a 15 minute wait for 3, but i heard the wait can easily be up to an hour.  to keep yourself warm grab a hot coffee or chocolate across the street at farley's.
author: Josie M.

description: I've tried a number of things from the menu and have loved all of them.  The breakfast potatoes are the BEST in the city.  And the service is friendly, helpful courteous and professional.  Definitely worth the long weekend waits but even better on a weekday when the line is shorter.  Highly recommended.
author: Amy K.

description:
it's a reallllly teeny-tiny space. i purposely came here christmas eve for brunch with a friend hoping that most people would be out of town. and... i was right! got there between 9:30 and 10am and we were seated right away. because of the size of this place, there really isn't much room for "private" conversations. we were seating almost right next to another twosome enjoying brunch. there was probably about 1 in. between our two tables, and a few inches between me and the guy sitting behind me.  but i think of this place as being cozy and not at all cramped. 

service was pretty friendly at the beginning. however, for $3, i would like to have my coffee refilled at least once before i leave. my morning dose alone is about 2-3 cups so i wasn't to happy about only having just one cup. i know, boo freakin hoo.

so unto the food. it was awesome! i got some kinda combo thing that came with bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes, 2 eggs, and idyllically cooked/tasting potatoes. my friend got the french toast. suffice it say, we enjoyed the ambiance, culture, and the food of plow. dunno why it's called plow but it probably has to do with the way people toothsomely consume their food. 

2 brunch dishes + 2 coffees = ~$42
author: Erin M.

description: I get it now. The Plow breakfast is unmatched. You can really do no better; love this place.
author: Jesse L.

description: Oh my gawd this place is uh-mazingggg.  I had the fried egg sandwich with bacon, the boyfriend had the plow.  Both were a win.  The eggs had the perfect amount of leaky yolk and the bun..omg...i mean... how fluffy can a bun get?? I wouldn't mind ordering the same items on my next visit but I'll probably try the dungeness crab scramble along with 5 orders of lemon ricotta pancakes......
author: Mimi N.

description:
Groups of three beware: Plow seats threesomes only at the bar. This means: a) longer than average waits, as the bar is quite small, and b) sucky atmosphere for chatting with friends.  Oh, and c) uncomfortable bar chairs.  

Food was fine, but we were pretty bummed to land at the bar without any communication that this would be the only spot we'd be seated in (though we figured it out during our 55 minute wait, as we watched almost everyone who arrived after us get seated at the tables).  Ironically, the bar would probably be great for a twosome (at least if you don't have lower back problems), but for three, it was virtually impossible to have a conversation.  All in all a downer and I probably won't return.
author: Cara C.

description: The Egg Benedict were perfect!  The coffee was tasty and the vibe chill.  Could not have asked for more.
author: Brian R.

description:
2 stars because food was well prepared, but service was unacceptible. 
They're too popular, they don't need their customers anymore, they've got too many as it is. Very disappointing.
author: Lisa K.

description: Awesomeness on a platter. BEST potatoes ever and my sandwich was stellar. They may have gotten a 4.5 if there was a little extra seating room. Not that I mind having lunch with complete strangers but it made for a bit of awkwardness when I was trying to have a private conversation. Otherwise just pure goodness.
author: JA R.

description: I came here for lunch with some of my friends around 1:30. I came after the rush so I didn't have to wait. Was seated right away. I ordered the grilled cider-brined pork chop + eggs. Lucked out since they gave me my order and said it was the last pork chop! Simple looking but don't let that deceive you, but worth trying! The crispy potatoes were alright, some were slightly burnt so I had to cover it with ketchup to cover up the burnt taste.  Eggs were... well eggs. Nothing too special about that. I didn't get the lemon ricotta pancake, but my friend did and I tried it... was pretty good too. Usually not a pancake person but I wouldn't mind a stack of those! Other than that, meal was decent. Clean restaurant, clean restroom, and good service.
author: Johnson S.

description:
See review and pictures here: http://www.lespetiteschoses.ca/2013/07/p-l-o-w.html

One of the places I always recommend people to come to when they pass by San Francisco is Plow. Located somewhere in Potrero, San Francisco, this little (and by little I mean seats maybe 50 people) spot servers some great breakfast/brunch. I think I may have come here about 3 times now and I have never been disappointed. Pro's of coming here? House made sausages, amazing light, great flavors, awesome potatoes, and more amazing light. What more could a photographer... I mean foodie look for? No but seriously, come here and come here early. Line ups start by 10:30am on a weekday.
author: Ng K.

description: Food was good, but portion size of "the plow" was misleading.  Menu said two eggs, choice of bacon or sausage, crispy potatoes, and two pancakes.  I'm thinking upscale grand slam breakfast at Denny's.  Pancakes were about 2 inch diameter.  Tasty, but not very filling.  Two eggs would be more correctly labeled two small eggs.  Had to grab a sandwich shortly afterward to carry me through to dinner.
author: Bryan L.

description: Just had the best breakfast ever- the soft scrambled eggs were killer. We showed up at 10:30 on a Friday and were seated at the counter immediately. Great service, great food, great coffee.
author: Tatiana N.

description:
wow, what a great breakfast place!
I had the "plow" which is eggs, bacon or sausage, potatoes and two small lemon ricotta pancakes - all delish.  hubby had the breakfast sandwich which he loved.  excellent coffee.
the only demerit, and the reason I'm not giving plow 5 stars is because of the side order of "market fruit" that we got.  for $5, you get about a quarter of an apple sliced thin, a quarter of a pear sliced thin and about 8 grapes.  when they brought it to the table, I thought it might be a garnish and not the fruit plate we had ordered.  I asked, and sure enough, our waitress confirmed that was the market fruit.  
a minor complaint in light of everything else that was outstanding.  but seriously, if you're going to put a fruit plate on the menu and charge $5 for it, make it a real fruit plate and not something that could be mistaken for a garnish.
we'll be back though!!
author: char s.

description: Fresh food with a flare! Enjoyed brunch on a wednesday!
author: Betty B.

description: long wait, had the lemon ricotta pancakes. Not even close to being as good as zazie. Generally good food, but nothing memorable.
author: Caroline D.

description:
What a great idea for brunch, and when we finally got seated, it was scrumptious.  We were a party of 5, so if you also have a party of 5, be prepared to wait a while as pretty much the only accommodation is at the bench in the back of the place.  It was a freezing cold Sunday morning, and with a very small waiting area, be prepared to wait outside.  What else is new in the city.  Coffee is provided to help temper the masses.  The staff were very friendly and helpful and the food was savory.  We had the donuts, the lemon ricotta pancakes, Max's buttermilk biscuits and gravy, the plow and the eggs Benedict.  All of the ingredients were distinctive and flavorful and their combination's symphonic.  

Although I froze my arse off waiting for a table, the view of downtown and the Bay waterfront was relaxing.  You gotta go experience this place!
author: Grant T.

description: Great food! Luckily we were staying with family that lives close so we put our name in and then could wait in the comfort of our own home. food is pretty pricey ... there was 3 of us and our breakfast bill with tip came to $70 (coffee is like $3.50!!) but at least the quality of the food is worth it.
author: Karen S.

description:
I waited until my second trip to write a review - My first experience was certainly worthy of 5 stars, but I wanted to see if they could deliver consistently.  My conclusion: Abso-freakin-lutely.

The atmosphere is wonderful. It's friendly, unpretentious, and everybody working the tables or in the kitchen is smiling.  The coffee is perfect, and my cup has never been empty.  The food? Whoa, it's good - like seriously good.  The fried egg sandwich with Gruyere, bacon, and frisee is delicious, the traditional fare (eggs/bacon/potatoes) are all done wonderfully, and the eggs Benedict I just devoured was awesome.  And as an added bonus, the prices are totally cheap.

This is hands-down my new favorite brunch in the City.
author: Matt S.

description:
Move over Zazie, Brenda's and Dottie's.  Plow has become our new favorite brunch spot!  It seems that the only main complaint in past reviews is the wait.  The space is small, but it is worth the wait, and who minds waiting if you are able to sip coffee or a mimosa while doing so?  

Everything I have tried has been exceptional.  Plow by far has the best potatoes.  Hands down.  They are crispy and salty and all kinds of delicious.  The service is prompt and friendly; the chefs couldn't work any harder but are friendly if you are sitting at the counter.  The prices are reasonable for brunch in San Francisco, and parking is easy.
author: Amanda H.

description: Great food. Absurd prices. I have never paid 15 dollars for pancakes. Unless I win the lottery, I will not return to Plow. It should be a crime to make breakfast food so expensive.
author: Athena K.

description: Went there with a friend for Sunday brunch.  The wait was INCREDIBLE.....Get there early, but I can see why!  The breakfast was to die for, and you must try their bacon.   I could have eaten a whole plate of it.
author: Douglas P.

description:
This place had been on my list for a while but my husband isn't a fan of waiting an hour to eat somewhere so we always avoided it. One sunday we were up early enough that I convinced him to go with me. We got there right at 9am and the timing seemed to be good, got busier after that. There were tables outside that were open but it was pretty cold, so we waited for inside. The wait was about 20 minutes or so, didn't seem too bad. 

I got the dungeness crab scramble which was delish, and as others have said, the potatoes are awesome. My husband got the Plow, which is great because you get to try a bit of everything, including the famous lemon ricotta pancakes. My husband isn't a huge lemon fan, but this was just a slight lemon flavor so he (and I) really liked them. The fresh OJ is great too.

Service once inside was quick and I felt the food was worth it. Not sure we'd make it a regular thing considering the wait, but it is a great spot.
author: Lauren M.

description: My first impression wa horrible, as we walked in one of the waitresses said "oh god!"  As in great more people for breakast!  Then when ordering our waitress was incredibly rude and refused to cook my eggs the way I requested, all I asked for was for them to be scrambled but cooked omelet style, she flat out refused without giving an explain action or offering to check with the kitchen staff, she just said"no we're not going to do that!"  I'm appalled at the service and will never go back!
author: Heidi W.

description: Pure deliciousness. Impressed my parents (Mom has  high food standards! She treats restaurants like celebrities - irreverence, critical, doesn't like their hair, ever) and my husband (who would just as soon eat at IHOP if not for his snobby wife). Just really well done. It's a wait, though, so be prepared. But enjoy it. Food as it should be, brunch perfectly done.
author: Jess H.

description:
I wish I could give this brunch place more stars, especially since it's in my neighborhood. 

I ordered the soft eggs with fried potatoes and housemade pork sausage. The eggs and sausage were nice, light and fluffy. The potatoes had a crusty outer shell and soft inside, but they were also greasy. The plate came with great bread that was heavily buttered for more grease. 

The result was that I finished the eggs but left bread and potatoes behind. I noticed that the lady sitting next to me did the same thing. 

Then there's the service. My waitress was friendly enough, and during the course of my meal, the wait staff got together frequently to laugh and giggle. But ... I told her I would like cream and sugar with my coffee and I only got sugar. The bread came without jam; the bus boy helped out with that. 

So, all in all, for a $20 brunch, I've experienced better. I'd highly recommend Mission Local Eatery instead.
author: Greg T.

description:
I love everything about this place!

The decor, service, food and location (my neighborhood!) were exceptional. 

The french toast was incredible. Next time I'll try the lemon ricotta pancakes and the egg sandwich - they looked delightful!
author: sally b.

description: 3 words - Lemon Ricotta Pancakes. These are as good as they get. Everything else is fabulous too, but to me these are the stars of the show. Worth the long wait!
author: M N.

description: The potatoes are as good as everyone claims. The gluten-free pancakes made my girlfriend cry, literally, because she hasn't had any so good since she got the no-gluten news. The lemon-ricotta ones are fantastic as well, something sweet to balance out the rest of the dish. ( we both got the plow) Service was great, they took in a pushy family after they had already closed, would love to go again soon.
author: John K.

description: I left so stuffed! It was too good to leave anything on my plate or wait to take it home for another meal. Be prepared for a long wait - my friend and I waited for 40 minutes on a Friday morning, but oh my - it was worth it. And the service rocked!
author: Yvonne L.

description: I had one of the best brunches of my life at this place the other day. Their menu had some really interesting choices like a Chinese breakfast with caramelized pork shoulder but they also had some very elevated basics. I had the Plow which was 2 eggs, potatoes, bacon and two lemon ricotta pancakes. Everything was very high quality but those pancakes...wow. Service was great, everyone was very nice and I can't wait to go back as soon as I get the chance.
author: Jamie C.

description: This place lives up to the hype.  We arrived this morning at 750 and the line was already long- they were full with the party right in front of us and we waited about 40 minutes.  It was worth the wait.  The sausage and lemon ricotta pancakes were amazing, my scramble was awesome, and the staff was kind and helpful with the two toddlers in our group.  One of the best breakfasts I've ever had!
author: K C.

description:
Okay, seriously Plow, if you can consistently do that thing you do inside of my mouth, that magic, that straight up no nonsense fuckery, the least you can do is figure out a way to manifest yourself a sixth star on Yelp to set yourself apart.

People think I'm straight crazy when I say my favorite restaurant in San Francisco is a breakfast joint, but seriously, did I stutter?  I'll say it again. Favorite.

And it's not entirely sentimental, though maybe a little! I went to Plow the morning I arrived in San Francisco with everything I own still in the back of my car, afraid I was going to get robbed, not yet knowing that the scariest thing to ever happen in Potrero Hill is Whole Foods being out of dried mango and stressed out of my gourd about how the hell I was going to make it in this city. I walked to Plow with my boyfriend in the pouring rain and found out there would be a wait (there's always a wait at Plow, let me get that out of the way, unless you're one of those partially-employed assholes that can manage to go early-morning on a weekday,, then you're in luck). My boyfriend and I huddled under an umbrella and the cute hostess brought us a giant mug of hot coffee to share outside on the corner. I took in the view (Plow is perched on Texas and 18th) and felt like it wouldn't be so bad after all, and that Plow was the jaunt for hooking me up with a sense of comfort. 

And that feeling has NEVER left me. Plow, you're still the jaunt. I have never been disappointed in anything I have eaten there. The breakfast potatoes shut down all previous attempts to be a breakfast potato: they're sauteed with herbs and caramelized onions. Ask for them extra crispy. I fantasize about them in a strictly not-weird kind of way. 

LIST OF NOTABLE MENU ITEMS (for people who don't want to read my bullshit, I don't blame you, just start here. You said get to the point, this is it:

*Spinach + Mushroom Eggs Benedict
*Little Gems Salad
*Olive Oil Poached Tuna Sandwich
*Lemon Ricotta Pancakes, as well as seasonal pumpkin ones
(all come with the breakfast potatoes if you ask, don't fret now)

Boyfriend likes the
*Plow (with applewood smoked sausage)
*Smoked Salmon Lox with Capers
*Olive Oil Poached Tuna Sandwich (we devour this together and hold a moment of silence when it's missing from the menu). 

That being said, their menu rotates depending on seasonal ingredients and chef preferences, so don't hesitate to go balls to the wall and try something new, you won't be disappointed, I swear on it. GO!!!
author: Erin I.

description: Bomb. It doesn't matter what you order, it is ALL good. I went for the weekend brunch and ordered The Plow because I like to get a little taste of everything. Potatoes, sausage, lemon pancakes yum, yum, yum. Even the coffee is good. I went late in the day so it was beginning to clear out however, the place is pretty tiny so I would imagine it gets packed at prime time. If you plan on going any earlier I would be prepared to wait and it would be well worth it.
author: Danielle C.

description:
Simply fantastic.  We got an early start this morning and decided this would be the day we would finally try Plow!  We made it there by 8:30 am and there was already a wait (around 10-15 people hanging around outside the restaurant).  We were seated at the counter within about 20 minutes.  Typically, I wouldn't be overly excited to sit directly next to my boyfriend, staring into the kitchen - but today, our front row seats allowed us to see some amazing cooking!

I found our waitress to be extremely friendly and knowledgeable.  There were 3 men cooking in the exposed kitchen area; they had everything down to a fine art.  It was fascinating to watch them cook throughout the entire meal.

I ordered the fava bean puree and burrata dish.  It was essentially a deconstructed sandwich that came with a piece of grilled bread, burrata, fava bean spread and a side salad.  I also decided to order a side of two scrambled eggs to make the dish feel more breakfast-y.  Everything about this dish was spot-on and very fresh.  I even had the two women next to me at the counter ask me what I ordered because they thought my entree looked so delicious!  

I cannot lie...I also had a couple of bites off of my boyfriend's plate!  I loved the potatoes (which by the way are briefly deep fried and then tossed with sea salt, thyme and rosemary).  I also had a bite of his lemon ricotta pancakes, which were decadent!

I highly suggest Plow if you're looking for solid food in San Francisco.  Be prepared to wait, as the other Yelp reviews state....  Get up early, get great food and nap later!
author: Rachel G.

description: I have visited Plow several times and have been blown away each time by the quality of the food. Every time, I get the Plow breakfast. Every time it is amazing. On my most recent visit, I discovered that you figured out how to make the potatoes even more awesome! Also important to note, the lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing. Totally worth the wait!
author: Russell P.

description: The waiting staff and cooks are incredibly efficient and professional. The owner/head chef promotes a diligent, well-mannered and focused environment for her employees. The atmosphere and aesthetics are balanced and hospitable. The food exceeded my expectations and I will definitely be visiting this piece of SF again.
author: Stephen M.

description:
After seeing the long lines and sleepy huddled masses on the corner of Texas and 18th St, I was a little confused.  What COULD make a crowd like that on an overcast morning in Potrero Hill?  

Deliciousness can, that's what.

The vibe of the place is great, without being overdone or precious.  The coffee is great, which is a baseline requirement in San Francisco.  It takes a little time for your food to get to you, but once it does, you're happy that you hung out and chatted with the people sitting next to you for a while.

Home made sausages, fluffy pancakes, crispy potatoes and lamb sandwiches are all familiar, but each has their own little unique twist, and is well executed.
author: Christine P.

description: Recommend going on a week day to avoid the line, once your in 'The Plow' is great.
author: Alison F.

description: Wow. This place. I'll go everyday for the crispy warm potatoes (YUM) and lemon ricotta pancakes. Holy cow are they good. We came on a weekday for a better chance of making it in and we had to sit at the counter but no big deal, it's like watching a show. The food is ridiculously good, the peeps are nice and the space is beautiful.
author: Kat G.

description: One of the best brunches I have has in SF. Definitely worth the drive to Potrero Hill. Get there early to avoid the long wait. Can't wait to go back!
author: Laura D.

description:
some of the best service ive had in a while.  friendly, knowledgeable, and outgoing.

the food was great as well.  breakfast sandwich + BLTs were standouts.
author: Henry H.

description:
Tasty, well-portioned meals, get here before 9am if coming for brunch so you don't have to wait in line.

Came here Sunday morning before 9am and were lucky to get some bar seats in front of all the cooks.  It was neat to see how they cooked everything.  We started off with the monkey bread and it tasted just like cinnamon buns, just not as sweet and without the sugary frosting spread all on it.  I got "the plow", which came with scrambled eggs, their homemade pork sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes.  The homemade pork sausage was slightly spicy with really good flavor, while the pancakes were super soft and tasty.  I liked how they were mini pancakes and not the huge ones you'd get at like IHOP/Denny's.  The crispy potatoes were a little too salty for me, but my bf liked them.  I might have been able to eat the whole plate of food if it weren't for the monkey bread, but I did find many couples sharing the plow, if the other person ordered something small.  My bf got the fried egg sandwich that came with two eggs fried, cheddar, frisee, aioli, crispy potatoes  and Nueske bacon.  It looked good, and was an adequate sized sandwich.  I was tempted to order their organic yogurt with granola and mixed fruit, but felt I needed to order something more substancial since it was our first time here.  Plus, you can make that at home.

Overall, one of the better brunch places I've been to and will surely come back for more.
author: Joycelyn L.

description:
I don't normally eat pork chops.

But I did.

It was yummy.

Eggs were perfect.

potatoes were great.

Lemon Riccotta Pancakes, from a person who does not like pancakes, were great.

Staff were tops!

Great SF Brunch Place.

Thanks Dave the Chef at Stanford U. for the heads up!
author: Neil S.

description:
So my husband and I have been living in the neighborhood for a few years now, but we had never stopped by for a meal at Plow. Mainly because they were always so busy, but we took this as a good sign. 
We stopped by this morning. We were there by 8:15 and it was a Wednesday, so we were seated right away. We also took this as a good sign. But, as is so often the case with small neighborhood restaurants (even the ones with great food) the service was the downfall. Although we were seated right away and we were asked if we would like coffee (we both said "yes, please") the coffee didn't come until much later and we had to ask again.
Then several parties arrived after us, were also seated right away, and then had their orders taken before we did. After several attempts to make eye contact, I finally called out to the waitress (she had her back to us and was folding napkins) and I said "Could we place our order?" She stared at me blankly and said "Oh, she just got busy." and gestured toward the other waitress. After she left, my husband said "There are still 5 empty tables in here and two waitresses. I hate to see what the service is like when there is a line outside, 'cause this really isn't busy!"
Maybe they were short-staffed and we should give them the benefit of the doubt, but we are pretty patient people and it just seemed ridiculous.
The food itself was good. I mean it is breakfast, nothing too difficult! As other people have posted the potatoes that are served on the side are probably the best I have ever had. So that was slightly uplifting. But honestly at 34.05 for two people for eggs, bacon, toast and potatoes with coffee, I think we will stick with the Just for you Cafe on 22nd!
author: Alyssa A.

description: Ricotta lemon pancakes. Salmon Benedict. Warm fast service. Wait outside may move faster than predicted!
author: Nors P.

description: Service sucks. How do you "accidentally" cross someones name off the list without calling their name, and then not even apologize, neglect to seem like you care and say, "well we don't know when you'll get seated." Forget this place. It's a shame to live so close to such a rude establishment.
author: Tiffany C.

description: I had the plow, it was ridiculously tasty! The lemon ricotta pancakes were the fluffiest, most delicious cakes I have ever had.
author: Caroline L.

description: Very good comforting traditional brunch. The lemon ricotta pancakes are great.
author: Anthony N.

description: Yes you will wait and wait some more and probably even wonder if you were forgotten or think your table may have just been mistakenly given to another party so you trust but validate that you are still on the list. You may even check with the hostess more times than you would normally check in and just when all hope is lost, you hear your name and let out a subtle PRAISE THE LARD!!!  and make way to take on what I will say is a pretty damn good breakfast. I had the plow, it was rustic, hearty and packed full of wonderful flavors. The potatoes were so good, perfectly golden crispy and made good for dipping into my over medium eggs. That's how I eat my potatoes. The sausage was absolutely smashing, both patties had a tasty caramelized exterior while the inside was full of dripping goodness. I love the taste of fennel in sausage and it was just the right amount.  The lemon ricotta cakes were a nice touch and added a perfectly sweet balance to compliment such seasonfull meal.  I want more!
author: Robert M.

description: Great Breakfast spot!  The place is in a cool neighborhood with a great view of the city which takes some of the sting out of the long wait.  I have returned twice..........The potatoes are awesome and the eggs ben. is very good.  Coffee is very good and service is top notch. I recommend sitting inside for more atmosphere.
author: Hans E.

description: My boyfriend and I came to visit the San Fransisco Bay area for Thanksgiving of last year.  We found Plow on Yelp when we were driving around.  The wait was a little long but it was well worth it.  My boyfriend had their pumpkin pancakes and we both loved it so much we ordered another one!!
author: Yeoten T.

description:
I usually try to write reviews for the under-grounders, the newly-started, the ones who have yet to hear that Yelp will make them grow (yes, they exist OUTSIDE the Bay). But when the food is as kind to my stomach as the owners are to my spirit, I can't wait to say a nice thing or two.

I'll say up front that a friend of mine is friends with the owner, so we got a little special service, like Randall, the adorable host, who brought us coffee (coffee, which btw, will make your spoon straighter than a guy from  Marin), and then they brought us complimentary fried donut holes/beignets. I never knew something fried could taste so...healthy.

I had the egg sandwich. To be honest, I think I make a little bit meaner one at home, and maybe since Joel, the owner, is so nice here, I'll give him my recipe.

And about that Joel. What a gem! Not only did he instruct me on how to make their INCREDIBLE house potatoes (truly, these potatoes are the crispy breakfast potatoes to end all breakfast potatoes), but he let me know to use rice bran oil (what the use in the fryer at Plow) or peanut oil rather than olive oil (which smokes the oven at high temps), but he checked on us throughout the meal and made sure that his friend (my friend) and the four of us weren't too cold (we were sitting by the front door) and that our coffees were always topped.

At the end of the meal, Joel extended his kindness one step further. He took care of the bill. Now this had nothing to do with the fact that I said I'd write him a review, and only had to do with the fact that one of my breakfast mates was his good friend and was babysitting for him that night, but that is a forgotten art and was a classy move on his part.

Not only do I love the atmosphere, the style of the place, the natural light. But also the hooks for your purse under the counter. And how you can watch the magic cooking by the guys in the kitchen. And that your coffee is always topped like in the best little roadside diner. And that they'll even hang your coat. Yes, you will have to wait a long time, but you will get a breakfast that you will crave and service with so many smiles. And the potatoes...oh, those potatoes. They are so addictive that I took my best friend this weekend, just to introduce her to said potatoes, and she let me lick the crispy crumbs of her plate.
author: Amanda C.

description: I came here with a friend yesterday and pretty much died and went to food heaven. Hands down one of the best brunches I have ever tasted and I dine out a lot! Everything on the plate ( I had the plow with bacon and scrambled eggs) was perfectly seasoned, I didn't know what to indulge in first! The creamy eggs were so flavorful and no additional salt needed and the lemon ricotta pancakes were heavenly! I was tempted to lick my plate but contained myself! Sure their was a wait but well worth it on the cute benches soaking up the march sun. I've waited longer in line for mediocre brunch at other places and in SF it is to be expected. Pop your name on the list, go grab a coffee and treat yourself to this hidden gem in Potrero hill, you won't regret it :-)
author: Kirsty E.

description: Plow was a great local neighborhood spot for breakfast!  I'm a huge breakfast fan and this place is one to checkout if you are too.  I've often seen my sibling post on facebook that they are here, so when I visited SF last week we had to check it out.  We beat the rush early on Sunday morning and that's a good idea if you don't like to wait.  Food was well prepared, fresh ingredients with great flavor.  I was amazed that they serve Neuske bacon, which you normally only see in the Midwest.  Staff was very inviting and chatted us up about what we were doing that day which makes you feel good.  Highly recommend.
author: Mike C.

description: Yes even after waiting over an hour for a group of three to be seating, this place still deserves 5 stars.  I also had the expectation that we would be waiting a while to get in so my expectations were properly set.   What I didn't believe was how good the food was going to be.  I thought it was EXCELLENT.  I got the lemon ricotta pancakes, sausage, eggs and crispy potatoes.  Oh, I could really use that meal in front of me right now.  I've been craving it ever since and it's been three days.  It also fills you up.  I ate at 1pm and didn't want to eat anything else the rest of the day.   Stop by this bruch place, you won't be disappointed.
author: Brad S.

description: Small, but brightly lit neighborhood place on Potrero Hill that features locally produced yummy food. Nice feel with the open kitchen.   Everyone starts to line up 30 mins before opening and the taxis begin dropping people off from all around the City.  Must have the house made breakfast sausage.  THE PLOW is the breakfast combo that features 2 eggs, choice of meat, potatoes and the lemon ricotta pancakes.  Everything is truly outstanding.  Friendly service with Equator coffee.
author: John K.

description: Great and hearty breakfast. The Eggs Benedict was delicious. The Plow is a great way to start a very active day - all the parts are good, but too much food for me! Service is great too, even though they are always busy. I also like the open kitchen and sitting at the bar watching the cooks do their magic.
author: Jess L.

description: Sorry, I totally don't get the hype? Why would you wait 1-2 hours in line starting at opening hour just for food you can replicate at home? I'm pretty sure local businesses appreciate the brunch traffic coming into this place, because I bump into fellow queue mates at the nearby Farleys and gift shops. The dishes are unoriginal, but taste pretty good. Not blow-my-mind amazing. Ingredients are high quality, which may or may not justify the very high prices. Simple dishes like an omelet run around $15-18. Portions are sufficient enough (this is no diner). One notable item is the home fried potatoes, which accompanies most breakfast dishes- definitely the best potatoes I've had in the city. Beyond crisp crust, piping hot, tender center, well seasoned/ spiced, and organic.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I'll KIS..great food, great service.  I had the french toast and my little guy ordered the pancakes which he never finishes so I had a taste of each.

Service was spot-on without hovering or constantly asking me a question.  Coffee was good to very good, not the best, and the prices  are a bit high thus 4-of-5.

This 'Hood needed a Plow-like place.  Matter of fact SF can absorb about 20 more good breakfast/brunch spots so I wouldn't have to factor in a 30 minute+ wait every Sat/Sun.
author: John D.

description: Amazing place for breakfast.  Worth waiting for 1 hour & 1/2.  Monkey bread, lemon ricotta pancakes, breakfast potatoes.  Everything has a unique taste, can't imagine any better.  The coffee is also strong and perfect with the food they serve.
author: F J.

description:
Came here for brunch on thursday morning and it was still crowded! me plus 4 more didnt have to wait long for a table although they dont seat larger parties of 6 due to the size.  The kitchen is open with a bar like seating in front. i ordered the herloom tomato salad, fruit cup and the side order of crispy potatoes....to the demand of my friend who adamantly raved about their potatoes.  I have to say it was the best crispy potatoes ive ever had and i dont even like potatoes.  They didnt have the overly dipped in oil kinda taste nor was it so starchy you couldnt eat the rest of your meal.  yum. the fruits were not standard fruit cup (thank god), rather i had pears, figs, grapes.  double yum. anddd lastly the heirloom tomatoes which ive been dying to order at a restaurant since their now in season, was sliced, drizzled in olive oil with avocados on top.  Didnt seem like much but it was pretty filling and i was completely satisfied with my mini meals for brunch.  The ambiance was bright and relaxing for a chilly morning.  

if i still ate meat, i would definitely recommend the plow plate:  two eggs, choice of meat, and a side of crispy potatoes and pancake.  I definitely stood out of my table of 4 plow plates and one vegetarian dish. =)
author: Justina F.

description:
Love this place on a mid week morning , short line , big food . 
 Grab a seat at the bar and watch the show. It is so much fun to see the chef calmly perform her routine , poetry in motion . And the pancakes .....
author: Will W.

description:
Very cute place. Took a day off from work so I came on a weekday morning. 

Everything looked great on the menu and it was a hard decision but we settled on the following:

1) Lemon Ricotta Pancakes: So good. Soft and fluffy with little bits of ricotta throughout. 

2) Soft scrambled eggs w/goat cheese: Solid dish. Tastes exactly like you'd imagine but better. Simple and comforting.

3) Blood sausage: The best dish we had that morning. Everyone loved it.

The crispy potatoes that came with most dishes were great too. Still dreaming about the blood sausage... and all the cute little piggy artifacts throughout the restaurant!
author: Julie C.

description:
wowza..!!! fried egg sandwich with Avo.. CHECK!
Lemon ricotta pancakes CHECK
the plow.. with sausage.. CHECK!
best brunch I have had in a WHILE!
author: S R.

description: absolutely my favorite breakfast joint!  menu is seasonally delicious but the "the plow" is the stapple breakfast and a must have even if it's just for the table.  The wait is outrageously long  but worth it.  Discover the neightbourhood while you wait.  Or drive down to philz for a cup of joe first.
author: Marilyn K.

description:
Docked a star because they mistakenly sat someone right before us and skipped over our name causing an even longer wait than normal. When we were taken I was overly hungry and annoyed, but once I we got the food it was well worth it. I had the soft scramble, which was amazing. We also, started with some sort of pumpkin muffin that was very good. 
Try and check it out on a weekday to avoid the crazy wait.
author: Mariela B.

description: Awesome brunch. The crispy potatoes were phenomenal. The almond pancakes were great too, preferred them to the lemon ricotta. 5 stars!
author: michael q.

description: Dont miss the lemon ricotta pancakes. Hate the long weekend lines, try to go on weekdays.
author: Anand P.

description: I have been coming to Plow for a few years now for weekend brunch, and it really is one of my favorite brunch spots.  No matter what dish I order, it is always soooo good.  the last time I was there, I got eggs, sausage, potatoes and a side of toast.  And, of course, a mimosa.  The food tastes home made.  The service has always been really amazing - they are VERY nice and, considering the small space, they are very patient.  The coffee is also very very good.  The only 'negative' is that you will most definitely wait 45 min/1 hour, but that doesn't bother me, I know what to expect, and usually I'll just go for a coffee while I wait.  And most good brunch places have long waits anyway.  I really do love this place :)
author: Sofia G.

description:
Mr. Plow that's my name.

Do yourself a favor. The chicken apple sausages are worth the wait.
author: David B.

description: Four stars for great food, service, and atmosphere. Minus one star because our wait for Sunday brunch at 11am was 1 hour and 45 mins. I ordered poached eggs, sausage, ricotta pancakes, and fried potatoes. Everything was amazeballs. You gotta try this place.
author: Rachel S.

description: Really good breakfast and brunch in Potrero Hill. Wait can be a bit long and they close earlyish but it's worth it. I had their salmon egg Benedict which was very good...was Some of the best I've had. They came with crunchy tasty potatoes. Nice fresh oj and decent coffee closed the deal.
author: Grendizer H.

description:
Went there for brunch there with a girlfriend recently.  Really good food, decent service.  

Main downside was the wait/line outside, which was ridiculously long ... so look out for that next time you do a walk-in!
author: Shruti Y.

description: The lemon-ricotta pancakes are unbelievably good and their homeade sausage is a close second.  One of my two favorite brunch spots (Mision Beach Cafe is the other).  As with all good things, you'd better have plenty of time to wait.
author: Matt G.

description:
My favorite place for breakfast!  The food is AMAZING.  

The best stuff is on the weekend menu.  I could eat their eggs Benedict everyday, it is so good!  I like it with the spinach and mushrooms.  Flavorful mushrooms, spinach is not too wet and not overwhelming like it has been at other places I have been to.  They'll also make it with any breakfast meat they have available if you ask.

Since I found this place, I have been going frequently, and gone through most of the menu.  There is not a single bad thing on the menu.  Pancakes, egg sandwich, salmon with toast, biscuits and gravy, I even tried the fried chicken.  Not a bad dish in the lot!  The worst plow gets is "merely good".  I would classify their scramble and oatmeal as "merely good".  

Be warned, there is a wait on weekends (as good places in the city tend to have), but there is usually no wait on weekdays.  They open early, so pop in before work, and treat yourself.  It does make the rest of the day seam easier!
author: C H.

description: We got together with another family and tried to go to Plow last Sunday. As we got there early, there was clearly space for us 8 (4 adults and 4 kids under 6) but not one great table. The host showed absolutely no interest in trying to welcome us and complained that he could not put the tables together and host us. This was a very poor experience in a neighborhood (Potrero) where there are a lot of kids. Sad!!!
author: Reza M.

description:
very solid breakfast, brunch lines can be up to an hour.
the main dish to order here is the plow:
two eggs any style (i usually get poached), two small lemon ricotta pancakes, chicken apple or pork sausage (probably not necessary), and perfect breakfast potatoes -- just the right amount of salt and rosemary.
the potatoes are crispy because of partially deep frying.
the pancakes have great flavor, fluffy, almost taste like muffins.
also tried the duck and sweet potato hash with crispy lotus root and poached eggs.  lots of diced duck bits with the fat and diced sweet potato, but definitely was longing for more crispy potato
locally sourced ingredients, nothing too creative, just stuff done well.
author: Rob C.

description: I ordered The Plow brunch and was not disappointed. The potatoes and lemon ricotta pancakes are incredible. Service was very friendly and accomodating. This was my first time here and I will definitely go back for weekend brunch.
author: Carl N.

description: Wow, crazy long lines.  What have I been missing...?  I went early on a Friday morning, expecting to find out what all the lines were about.  Unfortunately, I'm left scratching my head.  The coffee cake was great, everything else we ordered was unremarkable.  Not bad -- overall I'd give the food 3.5 stars -- but merely "good."  Oh, and minus 0.5 stars because Plow is a fancy breakfast place ... without an espresso machine??  I expect that from Denny's, not a place that charges what Plow does for food.  Potrero Hill residents (of which I am one) and visitors to our fine 'hood... you get one star for your foolish willingness to wait in lines.  Like the great Chuck D said... don't believe the hype.
author: Adam G.

description: Mmm nom nom nom ... this place is great .. I love when I get a chance to catch some breakfast here before work ... The locations is great right on the hill nice sun even on foggy Soma days ... the food from the pancakes to the egg sandwich and Chinese breakfast is all great ... fresh, organic, and just quite pleasant ...  the fried chicken and all the lunch specials are tasty as well .. Staff is friendly and that head chef back there .. mmm she just knows how to get it done ... I will be back as soon as I can for one of my favorite morning meals .. well done Plow
author: Anthony S.

description: I had brunch here several months back and enjoyed the food very much. It was a sunny & warm day so the outside sidewalk seating was great. Service was good and the (traditional American) brunch food very appetizing.  Not sure they take reservations and it seemed to be quite the popular place in the area so be prepared to wait a while and/or get there early.
author: Kent W.
