description: Oh.  My.  Gosh.  The food at this place was amazing!  Let me start by getting the only negatives out of the way.  It was very busy but we got seated quickly at 9:30am  right next to another table.  When I say right next to another table, I mean our tables were tops 1-2 inches apart.  Our waitress was not the greatest or nicest (just give me my extra syrup w/out the judgement!)  Maybe it's because she knows they are so busy that she doesn't have to be.  I'd ding a star for it but the food was just too good!  Now, onto the food!  I had "The Plow" which was 2 eggs served any way you'd like, 2 strips of delicious cooked to perfection bacon (actually I had 3 by some happy accident), 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes.  It is a tie between the pancakes and potatoes as far as my favorite.  Each bite of potato was amazingly crispy (with no oil at all) on the outside but so soft and delicious once you bite into it.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were mind blowing.  I don't even really favor pancakes, I normally opt for french toast or waffles but these were far superior.  The light taste of lemon mixed with sweet was amazing.  Maybe they use magic.  UGHH! SO GOOD!
author: Kristie R.

description: I love breakfast food more than anything. 5 stars for Plow.  Great breakfast - best fries I have tasted in a long time.
author: Yeni L.

description:
Finally a place devoted to breakfast/brunch on top of Potrero!  We went on Saturday morning.  The dinning room is sunny and crisply decorated.  The staff is well-oiled for a newly opened establishment.  The food was simple, fresh, and original.  I had the fried egg sandwich.  It was served on sliced Acme bread with thick shards of aged cheese and greens.  The menu had said it was served on an English muffin; I welcomed the alternative.  Not a bad deal for $7 (more if you get bacon).  The best part, though, was the potatoes on the side.  They hand crush cooked potatoes, deep fry them, and toss them with salt and herbs.  Great crispy texture.  

Wifey got the granola with fruit and house-made yogurt.  The fruit was figs and cantaloupe.  She opted against figs and asked for alternate fruit.  They could not offer any, and just doubled up on the cantaloupe.  No big deal until we noted they were slicing up juicy apples to top a salad on the menu.  It would have been nice if they'd offered her apples as a fig alternate.  Oh well.  She enjoyed it nonetheless.  Not the best deal for $8.             

Also, our party of two waited nearly an hour for seat.  That was after the host had told us we'd wait about 30 minutes.  Perhaps it will cool down after the initial opening rush.  

All in all, it was a great experience and we will be back.
author: Jon B.

description: Waited for an hour on a Saturday, and the wait was worth it! We sat at the counter and had eggs benedict. The hollandaise was lemony and acidic, and was a perfect compliment to the flavorful ham and chewy English muffin. The potatoes were fried and crispy and salty (wayyyyy better than frozen hashbrowns or any country potatoes). The cooks were so fun to watch that we bought them a round of beers, and will most definitely be back!
author: Nichole V.

description: Lemon ricotta pancakes are delicious! The staff is very helpful. There was no line at 7:30 in the morning, but it's better to go there by car!
author: Kyoko T.

description:
sheer. 

perfection. 

I am tempted to simply leave my review at that, but being a long-winded know-it-all, I simply cannot. 

Sunny, quiet and quite practically perfect in every way was the day. We stepped in at about 9 and were promptly seated in the most quaint and lovely Farmhouse-esque setting. Beautiful wooden tables, great large windows for viewing clean little Potreo Hill. 

Enough about that fluff. The vitals. So gorgeous in it's simplicity, so delicious in literally every bite. The menu is small, but crafted in such a way that anyone could find something to fit their tastes to a tee. For me? The Plow. 

This includes your choice of breakfast meat, 2 eggs any way, potatoes and pancakes. Sounds like a standard from anywhere. But here, that's just not fair nor accurate. Those eggs, so fresh, that bacon - so full of actual ham flavor - but those potatoes. NO ONE does potatoes correctly when eating out. They need to be tender inside, extremely crispy outside and have the right amount of seasoning, no grease and if you're lucky, accompanied by great caramelized onions. I thought only my Mom could make this magic. She must have divulged her secret to the Chefs at Plow. Never were potatoes so right OUTSIDE of my Mother's kitchen. 
Let's not though, forget those pancakes. These are light, airy, moist. These are LEMON. Lemon ricotta pancakes that are so subtle and meek in their own little corner of your plate, you would never expect them to absolutely wow you, as they are certain to do. 

People are funny about their breakfasts, they all know what's the best and where to get said "best," but unless they are speaking of Plow, they are just wrong. 

However, maybe they are smarter than me and telling you other places to go so as not to form a line at Plow... 
shit.
author: Katie W.

description:
i really want to give plow a 3.5 stars.  but, the food just wasn't as amazing as everyone thinks.  especially for the 30 min wait we had.

i had the duck hash, and i have to say it wasn't bad.  far from mindblowing though.  served with two small pieces of bread (certainly not enough to sop up the hash) and a (supposed) poached egg.  my egg came out pretty over done though.

the upside is the staff.  the girl that greeted us was really nice, and our waitress even noticed that my egg was overdone and offered to take it back.  i humbly declined but more than appreciated the offer (no substitute for great service!)  the other upside is that the crispy potatoes are pretty awesome.

i hope i can come back again sometime and be wowed by a different dish.
author: dan a.

description: The lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing, the place is beautiful and small. The downside of it being very popular is that they cram patrons into each other, there is almost always a line and very long wait, and it's on the expensive side for small portions.
author: King O.

description:
The lemon ricotta pancakes are as good as everyone says they are!  I could barely finish even one because they are so filling.  They are, by far, the best pancakes I have ever had!  This should be a new SF destination point for breakfast!

The service was also amazing. The staff is totally on their game checking in with you to make sure all is great -and frankly, all is fantastic!  Definitely try this spot out!
author: Laura Z.

description:
best fried chicken sandwich in SF.
fresh produce, long waits, menu changes daily.
author: TVAT T.

description: I can't write a review of the food and service - because we've never been able to get in!  Maybe that's a testament to the good food, or great service, but we'll never know.  The three times we've tried, the snappish server taking names was VERY MUCH less than pleasant. We've lived on the Hill for years, and have seen many restaurants come and go...we had high hopes for this, the menu looked good - but with the attitude we've experienced, we'll go places where our business seems to actually be wanted. Sally's Cafe, anyone?
author: R.B. W.

description: It was a delicious breakfast, and the place looks great.  The owners do a nice job with this and Ruby (their wine shop) (and Bell and Trunk Flowers).  If I worked on the Hill, I think it would be great to come here more often.  On the weekends, it's a production to eat here because it is so popular.  Still, it's a good spot.
author: Laurel B.

description: I always return to Plow hoping that my experience will be different from the last. I think that the food there is great and well executed when it is available.  On my last visit my friend and I had been seated and it took a little while for someone to come over to the table. Enough time had passed before someone greeted us that we had already decided on what we wanted.  Like previous visits they were out and failed to tell us until after we ordered our food.  I can understand that popularity of certain dishes can cause a shortage, but when a place is out of 3 items on the menu it just looks bad. We were there at 10:30am, not even late into the afternoon so it was a bit frustrating. I feel like I've given this place enough tries and decided to not return. I'm sure they won't be missing my business because the place is always packed.
author: Julie D.

description: Almost 5 stars but not quite. Very reasonably priced and everything was very good. It just wasn't mind-blowing good. My expectations were a little too high b/c of what I had heard and also that ridiculous line. We got there at 7:45 AM and there were probably 12 people in front of us and 40 behind us by the time we walked in at 8 and got a table. This is a very good brunch but not worth waiting an hour for which fortunately we didn't have to do.
author: Ben L.

description: Only annoyance about this place is that they don't take reservations and the wait can be long--go on the early side if you can. Other than that this is a great brunch because the food is awesome!
author: E L.

description: Best breakfast on 18th anywhere between Mississippi and Texas hands down.  I kid, I kid.  Randomly biked over here on a Thursday morning to meet a friend before work and had an amazing meal.  Been dying to come back for a proper weekend brunch.  It's a small restaurant so I'd imagine the wait is pretty epic, but thats kind of the cost of doin business in San Francisco at good brunch spots.
author: Michael N.

description: You're going to have to wait, but it's definitely worth it. Pork belly sandwich is awesome, so are all the basics, if that's breakfast for you. Service was great. They obviously know you had to wait to eat there, so they're extra nice once you're seated.
author: Michael R.

description: The food is good, but always expect an hour or more wait. This place is small and people take their sweet time for brunch. Don't fear, just head up to Farleys for your coffee and chat with friends while you wait for your name to be called. You will most likely be done with your coffee, run out of things to say and be starving by the time you sit, but it will be worth it. Or at least this one time.
author: Bianca R.

description: Fantastic find. Really cool spot in Potrero Hill with great service, nice atmosphere and phenomenal food. I'm still thinking about the soft scrambled eggs I had that were completely delicious. Without a doubt the best brunch I have ever had.
author: Angie F.

description: I'm drooling just thinking about what to write. This is a tiny, cozy, quaint place...very European. You'll be rubbing elbows with strangers but it's worth it after you take your first bite of lemon ricotta pancakes! Oh and the bacon!! I'm convinced they butcher pigs out back it taste so fresh! Best coffee in San Francisco by far. Friendly casual setting...but stylish and cute at the same time. Serve you water out of recycled wine bottles. Honestly one of my top 5 best breakfast spots in my whole life all over the world! You'll prob wait, but it's so worth it!!
author: Nellene W.

description: I live in the neighborhood and finallly made it to plow  one sunday afternoon only to be disappointed by the whole experience. The place was packed and we were told we'd have to wait 10 minutes for a table. Unfortunately 10 minutes was far from a good guesstimate ...30 minutes was more like it (there goes one star). We had salmon locks, an omlette and french toast. The food was average nothing extraordinary (there goes another star). Now for the part that got to me ...  a dirty coffee mug brought to our table. I pointed it out to the waitress before she poured fresh coffee and she  replaced it (there goes the third star).   In gorgeous Potrero hill, Plow has lots of room for improvement.
author: Rochelle P.

description: The tuna sandwich is beyond any you have ever tasted!  The service is solid and the baked goods rule!  Yum, yum, yum.
author: Bethany P.

description:
Plow continues to be awesome. 

Have a look at the Yelp history of the posters who bash it. Notice any recurring themes? LOL.
author: kenny k.

description:
cute place for brunch in potrero hill.  i loved the ambiance and open kitchen, but because of its size, be prepared to wait for awhile during prime time for brunch/lunch.  

eats:
bakery basket: an assortment of a scone, biscuit, and cornbread muffin.  (a great idea to share if you want to tried their baked goods.  the biscuit stood out the most to me).

mushroom eggs benedict: i was salivating when i saw this order being brought out to other patrons.  sadly, by the time we got seated, they ran out of hollandaise sauce and i opted for cheese instead.  it was still really good, but it probably would have tasted better with the sauce and with less chard.

pumpkin pancakes: they were very delicate and light, but not the best pancakes i've ever had.

i will definitely be back here for brunch.
author: Carli F.

description: I have never written a review on yelp before, but this place gave me such bad service and mediocre food... it was called for an actual review. We went there a few months back on a saturday morning and waited 45 mins (three of us) since it was packed, I understand that we had to wait (I've waited longer for other brunch places). Then we got seated and literally 20 mins later we finally get the waitress over so we can order. Ok, already unsatisfied with how long we had to wait for the waitress to take our order, it took another 45 mins to get our food. We were disappointed and unsatisfied at that point. I honestly don't remember what my friend and boyfriend ordered but I had the Lemon Ricotta pancakes - it was OK, the first pancake was full of flavor (very good), then the next 2 tasted like plain pancakes... i paid $10.00 for one good pancake and bad service. What a bad experience overall. The table next to us did not even get their food after our food came and they came in around the same time as us. Overall... it took us more than 3 1/2 hours to get out of there with one good pancake in my tummy, what a waste of my time. I'm giving one extra star for that one good pancake because it was yummy!
author: Tracy M.

description: Great restaurant!  Had to wait an hour +, but it was totally worth it.  Got The Plow with almond flour pancakes.  So good.  BF got the pork chop; equally as good.  Want to go back now.
author: S G.

description: Delectable, well-portioned food, okay service. Order coffee or mimosa while you wait ( there is often a minimum 45 mins-1 hr wait). RECOMMENDED ITEM: lemon ricotta pancakes
author: aj s.

description: WOW! I almost am afraid to yelp this because we had to wait for an hour for our table. It was an hour well spent. It was the most delious, clean, fabulous breakfast Ive ever had. I had the egg sandwich, I changed it to egg whites, and it was still amazing. Three of us ate and we were all amazed and could not wait to go back. The street it is on is reaally cute too. We walked around and shopped before and after in the surrounding blocks and had a great morning. Everyone should try this place....a different menu printed up everyday. The owners should be very proud.
author: Barbara L.

description: 5 star food, but minus a star for high prices and for not taking reservations (and corresponding long wait times).  All the food I've had here has been outstanding.  In particular they do home fries right.  They are crispy, salty, and have a burst of rosemary flavor.  MMMMM.  They are the perfect accompaniment to the crispy egg sandwich.  To round out your meal, they make a mean cup of Joe.
author: Paul T.

description: i would say the food is good, but not for the wait.  i've tried to come on a wknd before, but the wait is outrageous, so since i was in the city on a fri, we decided to come for lunch.  we got here just after noon and were told the wait would be 25-30 min.  in reality, it was about 35 minutes, and once we sat, it took another 20 min to order and get our food.  i got the egg sandwich, and my husband got the plow but w/ salad rather than a breakfast meat.  the sandwich was fine, and his plow was good, but if i had to drive across town and wait 2 hours for it, i would not do it.
author: Helen T.

description:
This was my first visit at the Plow and let me tell u the food was so fresh, tasty, and delicious it had me saying OH MY GOD after every bite. 
(forgot to take pics of our meal but not to worry since I will be back for more!)

Highly recommend!
author: Michelle B.

description:
Not so excited about Plow. I like the idea of it, getting produce and meat from local farms. The simple menu and ambiance are a refreshing change form most overcrowded restaurants and over processed foods. I went on a bright and warm SF morning for brunch. I expected the ait to be long based on the previous reviews I read while I was browsing through on my phone. My part and I were offered coffee during our wait. We were seated about 45 minutes after our arrival. We opted to eat outside on account of the beautiful day. We were handed menu but waited an additional 20-25 minutes until our order was actually taken. I ordered 'The Plow' with bacon and added eggs and denied the toast and pancakes to fit my diet. My friends and I chit chat and it took absolutely forever to actually get our meals. I want to say it was at least 30 minutes, either way it was enough time for me to get borderline 'slap a b**ch I'm so hungry' crazy.

I wasn't crazy about my food. My scrambled eggs were overcooked and I thought I could have at least gotten a few more pieces of bacon. Call me crazy, I'm not asking for a crazy Cheescake Factory amount of food when it's quality but I fell Plow was lacking in Quality. I could have gone on an off day so I will definitely give it another chance.
author: Alia D.

description: Didn't sleep just to be awake and avoid lines for this lil gem. What a treat it was. Love their french toast and the earth defying crispy potatoes. These two things will keep me coming back for more.
author: Karen H.

description:
the only reason it doesn't get 5 stars...the wait..and the wait...and we came on a day where it was cold out...and i had lost my voice...and the hostess asked me 3 times if we were willing to take a table outside.  uh...i guess the notation that we only wanted inside was lost?!  also, people who are NOT there when their name is called really shouldn't be able to get the next table.  seriously?!
however, it's about the food...and it really is good.  fried egg sammie...and crispy potatoes.  YUM...more than YUM.  good service...great food.
author: Sonia C.

description: I was horribly disappointed with the brunch at Plow.  First, we were a party of three that was seated at a table that only comfortably seats two.  Other parties of three who were in line behind us for the first seating at 8am were seated at tables that could seat 4.  Why were we discriminated against?  Now for the food.  I ordered the egg scramble with goat cheese, oyster mushroom, and nettles.  The eggs were watery, the nettles and mushrooms were stringy and tough.  There were clumps of goat cheese throughout.  The worst about the eggs was that it was extremely salty.  It was impossible to eat and I left 3/4 of the eggs  on my plate.  My husband ordered the Plow which was edible.  The bacon came out all clumped together as if the cook had just thrown it on the plate.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were heavy.  As you can tell, we will not be back.  So not worth it!!
author: Anita G.

description:
Plow, serving breakfast is plain hard. The cards are stacked against you. People are cranky about their adventures the night before, the wait is long, the food has to be hot and fresh or ecchhh.

So here's what you do right: the food is fresh and delicious and prepared with care. You've nailed the egg sandwich, the riccota pancakes, and the dungeness crab omelette. No easy feat, and done well over time. Kudos are in order. I rate Plow as the best breakfast per se in SF.

The downside is fame. People lined up, willing to wait for an hour or two for breakfast. One waits forever in the wind to sit and then you are informed that you may be seated at the bar or the communal table. Plow, some of us are not chatty for breakfast. Give us a choice of tables, not a choice to wait yet longer for a table.

Acknowledge that this is the priciest breakfast around. Yes, the food is exemplary, but no attitude, please. Serve re-fills of coffee without being chased down, check that all is ok with the meal, and go the extra mile for your customer. We wait, we pay a gazillion dollars for pancakes, so make it a dining experience. Slow down to 95 mph. 

Here you are, at a crossroads. Don't coast on fame, please. Think about the experience and not just the food. You won't get away with not caring about your customer. 

We, your public, are rooting for you. We want you to be as good each time we visit you. Slow down. Make sure that the experience, like the food, is exemplary.
author: Bill G.

description: Stopped by for breakfast twice while visiting San Francisco. Everything is amazingly delicious. I don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu.  Potatoes are spectacular. You absolutely have to try them!
author: Irina N.

description: amazing eggs benedict and potatoes! unfortunately the wait is very long on the weekend!
author: Velvet C.

description: First and foremost....the potatoes here are a-ma-zing. So crispy and seasoned, great texture great taste. I was full, but I kept eating them. I like the flexibility of the menu, you can get benedict with mushrooms, meats, spinach, etc. You see the chefs making everything right in front of you, which, to me, is consoling. Great food, good coffee, worth the wait, and great service. This is definitely on my favorites list.
author: Zara S.

description: The food here is great. High quality food, great service. The only downside is the line, but the best things come to those who wait.
author: Lindsi K.

description:
plow has quickly been rising in the ranks as a staple brunch place in SF, so I can't believe it's taken me this long to remember to review it.
This place is GOOD. It's in a somewhat random location for me (meaning, when we walked around after our meal, there were only other restaurants to look at.. e.g. Chez Papa Bistrot down the block), but the upside of this is that the parking is SO much better than the rest of the city. 
Our friend came an hour early before our meeting time for the wait on a Saturday morning, so that tells you how poppin' this place is. The place overall is quaint and airy, with a handful of tables and a counter facing the open kitchen, with very modern decor.
The Equator coffee was strong to my liking, and you can even sip on it while you're waiting in line outside.
We tried the cinnamon sugar donuts (not on the menu currently), which reminded me of freshly fried beignets. SO GOOD. I'm bummed I won't get to try these again anytime soon.
I had the eggs benedict with mushroom/spinach and ham (the two add-ons), which was delicious. The eggs were cooked to perfection, and the crispy potatoes lived up to their name.
Overall, a great brunch place to add to my list of go-to's. I will mos def be back!
author: Jen T.

description:
This may be somewhat of an unconventional review, but I feel its my duty as a rational, reasonable human being to chime in. I actually just got a Yelp account for the specific purpose of defending Plow against a scathing Yelp attack a few reviews down by Nomad I. 

First off, I have no connection with the good people at Plow. It just so happens however, that I was in the restaurant, sitting right next to Nomad on the particular day when he he was at Plow. He just happened to have been one of the rudest, most thoughtless and immature, ignorant customers there could possibly be. 

I, along with my friend, sat in sheer disgust and amazement as this guy berated the chef, despite having absolutely no leg to stand on. Meanwhile, the chef was as professional and as nice as could be. It didn't matter what the chef said; he was just one of those persons that would have cussed out Mother Theresa. 

And you should have seen what he was arguing about! He said the lettuce was rotten. Truth is, it was far from it. I had the same exact salad. It was arugula, which often turns a bit translucent when it is dressed with oil. This jackass, however, raised a ridiculous stink, which actually made me embarrassed for him. 

The craziest thing of it all, is that he wasn't charged a dime, yet lied, and said they charged him. 

I have no problem with negative reviews if warranted, but  this guy was certifiable, and his entire review is lies.

Not that it truly matters, I just felt the pubic deserved the TRUTH on this review.  

Great food, great prices, by the way.
author: Bobby D.

description: This place is but a treat to me! I have been here a few times already and everytime I have gone I am always satisfied and full. The staff is friendly and provides excellent service. If your looking for a very tasty, delicious and scrumptious breakfast this is the place to dine. I have had the Plow, the two eggs and the french toast...ALL very good and freshly cooked. As I type this review I cannot help but drool as I think about the dishes I ate from them LoL! =)
author: Grace V.

description: I wanted this to be a great restaurant as it's near our home.  Unfortunately, it was nothing remarkable.  Eggs were runny, toast was hard and served with nothing, potatoes were overcooked.  The young waitress showed little interest in her role.  The owners are working hard to make this a good spot, perhaps in time the food will get there.
author: Jason J.

description: Couldn't wait to get to this place - had heard such great things about it. Must say, have never had better scrambled eggs. I'm not kidding - they were heavenly and the crispy potatoes to die for.. BUT the noise level is atrocious. The staff slams and bangs glasses and plates. The pass through to the dishwasher was placed directly facing the dining room and sends out even more noise. It is ear splitting. Cannot take it. Bring ear plugs.
author: T F.

description: Great food and even better service! We were staying in the area and stumbled upon this brunch spot, so happy we did!! We were very impressed with the customer service from both the host and our waitress, both seemed genuinely happy to be there and happy to have us! Also the food was excellent! Lemon ricotta pancakes, so good!
author: Christy N.

description: Very small space way out in Potrero Hill, but the food is worth the trip. Their Plow special with lemon ricotta pancakes, house sausage, eggs and potatoes is amazing.
author: Holly C.

description:
i really want to like this place but the restaurant needs to work on some things before it can be a stellar spot on the hill. ill start with the positives :)

pros.
-pretty well designed space
-yummy coffee
-fried potatoes
-friendly owner

cons
-the fried egg sandwich is inconsistent..ive had it twice and the first time was tasty but was lacking an egg (it shd come with 2), second time. i had it..the sandwich was dry..eggs were hard..gruyere cheese was cold.
-my wifes fritata was cold - we saw it sitting for a while since we had counter seats,  - it was also quite dry. 
-service is lackluster and unattentive..server on both occasions forgot to bring ketchup/cream/water/salt and pepper. i also saw several customers bring their checks because they were waiting long.

i hope that you get your act together....soon
author: Christian S.

description: The lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing. Have had them twice so far. Like no other pancakes I've ever had. The staff is great as well. I'll be back many times.
author: John E.

description:
came here for brunch with my cousins, so glad that I waited because it was so worth it. we each had our own dish but also did the family style sharing.. nom nom nom ... i'm supposed to eat gluten free and lets just say all the food was stomachache worthy

lemon ricotta pancakes- so fluffly and light 

fried egg sandwich with bacon --mmmm

eclaire- we got the last one and it was so worth it even though we were so stuffed already
author: Bon N.

description: Very pricey for small portions. But great pumpkin pancakes and friendly service.
author: Vicki L.

description: omg, i can't believe Chez Mama has better "yelp" reviews than this place.  The food here and quality of ingredients used in the food here at Plow is as good as it gets.
author: Carl H.

description: Lemon ricotta pancakes = perfection.  Potatoes= best I have ever had.  Pancakes + potatoes = many returns!
author: Emily O.

description:
had the plow and my friend had the chinese breakfast.  everything was delish!  the pork sausage was house made and it showed.  the rosemary infused potatoes seemed almost deep fried in a good way.  it felt like eating kettle chips at some parts and home fries at others.  the lemon pancakes were tiny, but fluffy, moist and packed with sweet (meyer?) lemon flavor.  the fatty pork in the chinese breakfast had the perfect blend of sugar, acidity, and saltiness.

grapefruit juice wasn't too sweet.  the selection of teas and other drinks seemed thoughtful sourced and made.

this has definitely made it to my favorite brunch places in sf list.  just watch out for the wait.  there was a sizable line even on a friday morning..
author: beverly l.

description: One of the best brunches I have ever had. Everything from the crispy potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes and Benedict was AMAZING! The service and the atmosphere made it even better. Can't wait to go back.
author: Au N.

description: I came to Plow today with a friend after having been told this was probably one of the best brunch places in the city. In spite of being Superbowl Sunday, we still wound up waiting about an hour to sit at the bar, which wasn't really a big deal as all good brunches places force you to suffer hunger for extra time before allowing you to indulge.  We both ordered the Plow, which is their little-bit-of-everything (2 eggs, meat of your choice, potatoes and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes).  I actually asked to switch the potatoes for a slice of French toast, which I think is somewhat unheard of given the confusion it caused the line cooks (who we were watching the entire time).  The service is top notch, as our waitress caught the cooks on a couple occasions to make sure the plates came out as ordered.  The pancakes were fresh but didn't really taste strongly of lemon and were underwhelming, which made me glad that I had solid-but-not-spectacular french toast to compensate.  The house-made pork sausage was decent but could've used a much heavier hand of sage to make it really like breakfast sausage (for those of you who don't like the flavor of breakfast sausage, then this is perfect for you).  I stole a piece of potato from my friend, which was essentially smashed (as opposed to cut) potatoes thrown into a deep fryer to attain great crispy texture throughout.  Overall the ambience is clean and comfortable, and I wasn't feeling overly greased from the meal (always a good thing).  I'll be back to order other things off the menu next time (they look like they put a ton of Dungeness crab into their scrambled eggs), but I'm also still on the look-out for a better brunch place in SF.
author: Gene C.

description: I liked it a lot. Hearty brunch food in a  down-to-earth relaxed environment. No complaints here.
author: David W.

description: YUM. This place has such delicious food... Their breakfast potatoes are possibly the best in the world (or at least in the bay area). Only downside is there is often a super long wait, and the food is on the pricey side.
author: Nina R.

description:
I wish I could summarize the tastiness of the food at p l o w in a few words, or even tell you which dish is the best, but it just isn't possible. Everything I've ordered there has been flavorful. The portions are perfect. This morning I veered from my "usual" (the plow) and ordered the Chicken Tinga - ORDER IT! Delicious! Just the right amount of heat. And if you go, be sure to get the breakfast potatoes. Oh, and the homemade biscuits. To. Die. For.
Nice work, p l o w !!
author: Tracy M.

description: The food was average but the service is amazing. They are so warm, welcoming, and personable. If I have to recommend an item for brunch, it would definitely be the lemon ricotta pancakes. The crowd is full of sophisticated educated folks, so it's nice to be surrounded by intelligent talk.
author: archiee n.

description:
this place in new to the neighborhood and was very much worth the wait.  the staff were very welcoming and the high ceilings and wall of windows make for a very bright, charming atmosphere. 

i had the little gems salad and gnocchi. 

the salad was so fresh and crisp and the gorgonzola was super creamy and not too strong. just right with the sweet apples and walnuts.  

the gnocchi was not like gnocchi i have seen before. instead of little potato dumplings it is made with semolina flour and it baked in a pan and then sliced into squares, served with some delicious tomato sauce and parmesan cheese. it was seriously melt in your mouth good.  

i already have plans to go back to try out the weekend brunch menu.

(plus they have mexican coke!!! can't beat that!)
author: Ale M.

description: I got there around 7:05 on a Thursday morning and was the first one in the place. I was greeted by a friendly lady and sat at the counter. After a cup of coffee, I ordered some bacon and French toast. The bacon was delicious, not overly salty at all. The French toast was crisp on the outside and almost custard-like in the interior portions. Some of the better French toast I have ever had. If you come early on a weekday morning, you can grab some breakfast without the wait that the other reviewers mention. The service was friendly and attentive without being overbearing. Overall, I can definitely recommend Plow.
author: Karey K.

description: The food and the service = I'm a raving fan. Not often you find places with this atmosphere.
author: Mattias G.

description: This is a cute restaurant, but the wait is too long.  I really like their fried chicken sandwich.  Other menu items are pretty ordinary though.
author: Elena L.

description:
THE PERFECT BRUNCH PLACE.

On Saturday we arrived at 11am for brunch. We waited over an hour for a group of 3. The wait was TOTALLY worth it. 

Ambience is definitely perfect - just like the reviewer prior said, it's like a big kitchen you want to spend a lot of time in, with big beautiful windows and generous sunlight. 

And the food...ohhh the food. I had the scramble with egg whites. Perfect mix of spinach, jalapenos, chives and goat cheese in the scramble. Potatoes are seasoned deliciously and perfectly crisp. Tasted my friend's lemon ricotta pancakes - pretty good. The toast was prebuttered and yummy as well.

Friendly and fun service. 

I can't wait to go back!
author: Latte Queen W.

description: Brunch was the name of the game. I came here on a holiday and it was prime time for brunch/lunch. We scored awesome parking up on the hill. We walked in and put our name on the list and took a nice stroll in the neighborhood. I never get a chance to visit this side of town. After a 35 minute wait, we were seated. We shared the butternut squash soup and the plow. The soup was flavorful, you can taste the spices. The plow came with 2 pancakes, choice of sausage, potato chunks and eggs. I'm just glad we shared the meal, that would be too much food for me.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were to die for. The best I've had, the pancakes were light and fluffy. The equator coffee was a good companion to the brunch, definitely strong. Would come back for more pancakes and crunchy potatoes.
author: Candace F.

description:
fried egg sandwich - two eggs, cheddar, frisee, aioli, crispy potatoes 
house made organic yogurt + granola + market fruit + Potrero Hill honey

seated at the counter facing the workers
watching them mix, chop, flame, plate the magic.
it's no secret that plow only uses fresh, wholesome ingredients
in every single dish they offer.
sip on coffee or a mimosa during your wait
as they take no reservations in advance.
author: Anna K.

description:
Hands down best breakfast i have ever had! I am not a "hipster" as other reviews with 3 stars have said. I just love to f*cking eat! I got the Plow and O M G it was delicious! The definition of comfort food exactly the way you dream of it! The fact that it is prepared so carefully with so much attention to detail is so unexpected- sets the bar for breakfast pretty high! The sign out front should say "heaven this way"

Lemon Ricotta pancakes cannot be missed!!
author: Sasha D.

description: Ordered the "Plow" which was filling with tasty home potatoes, ricotta pancakes, eggs to order,  as well as a meat of choice.  Good food with friends.  Beware of the very limited seating, so plan ahead for the first-come first-serve policy.  good for parties of 4 or less.
author: Gino R.

description:
french toast: they make it using a baguette rather than toast. topped with roasted peaches and marscapone... different and delicious!

the plow: typical breakfast, but good fresh flavors. their potatoes are different though, super crispy and fresh fluffy potato-goodness inside! 

chicken tinga: good textures with the soft egg and crispy tortilla... reminds me of breakfast in puerto vallarta, but with SF's finest ingredients :)

* corn millet muffin, peach pie, chinese breakfast, and tomato soup was sold out and we got there around 1:30pm.
author: Tea Lyves ..

description:
Found a seat at the counter afte a 30 minute wait - cramped without a place to put your jacket, but it does have a front row view of the open kitchen and the bustling chefs.

My go-to breakfast item consists of something sweet and savory, so I immediately gravitated towards the plow.  The chicken apple sausages were juicy with a nice sweet counterbalance, but not particularly noteworthy.  The much lauded potatoes were indeed perfectly crispy without being too greasy.  The highlight, however were the lemon ricotta pancakes - texture-wise it was more like a cake.  Light, tangy, and fluffy - definitely the best pancakes I've had in the bay, and two of them were not enough.
author: Jeremy C.

description: Good food... Not the best service. Went there on a Sunday, I think there was only one waitress for inside and one for outside. There was was something in the creme for my coffee but the waitress was too busy running around and decided to not wait for her...
author: Monica R B.

description: Had the lemon-ricotta pancakes and pork sausage and coffee. I was there early on a Sunday and by myself and was able to get a seat at the counter right away but the line outside was loooong. Have a snack before breakfast if you go there in a group. Most importantly, food was great, waitress was really nice, the place is really cool and I like the open kitchen -- always fun to have something to look at when you're having brunch alone.
author: Allison B.

description: We read about this place on Yelp and decided to try it since it was a short walk from my sister's condo where we were staying.  We were skeptical when we arrived around 11am and saw a big line of people outside but put our names on the list anyway.  We were only a party of 2 and after 5 minutes we were seated!  My girlfriend had the Scramble and I had the Two Eggs, both of which were generous portions and were excellent.  Our coffee cups were never empty with Equator coffee, the service was phenomenal!  We are definitely going back!
author: Dr B.

description:
A good, casual breakfast place.  The food is above average and the atmosphere is good.   Service was adequate, quick, but not overly friendly.

There does tend to a wait if you go later on a weekend.  Otherwise, you will be find on a weekday.   The pancakes are a favorite.
author: Jason B.

description: One of my favorite brunch places in the city. Time your visit or you'll have to wait.
author: Guillermo K.

description:
Delicious food.  Pumpkin pancakes were absolutely amazing.  Easily #1 or #2 most tasty pancake I've ever had.  And I eat way too many pancakes.
Unfortunately, I feel like our group was really mismanaged with regard to table wait time.  We arrived just before 10 on Saturday morning (prime brunch time, I know) and were told it would be about an hour wait.  Fine.  We returned within an hour, waited another 15 mins, asked about our table and were told that it would be 5 more minutes.  30 minutes later we were seated.  Our group couldn't help but feel like we were sort of being strung along and each of us was becoming increasingly "hangry."
I'd go again, but definitely not on on a weekend.
author: A K.

description: Hands down my favorite brunch spot! The fried egg sandwich is excellent and their pancakes are to die for! I do however, wonder how many calories I consume by eating here. Anyway, if it weren't for the long wait, this place would be a perfect 5!
author: Eric L.

description:
my friend, Awesome Ize, and i equally dislike waiting so we decided to hit up Plow in the wee hours of a saturday morning. 8am to be exact, the exact moment which they open. we practically had the restaurant to ourselves. it was a nice way to start the weekend. 

the place has a homey yet modern feel to it.  the ceilings are high and the windows stretch from practically the ceiling to the floor, letting in all the nice natural light. 

the breakfast egg sandwich with bacon was really tasty. i credit the aioli and the nice Acme bun. the potatoes that came with it were really good. they were obviously deep fried but didn't taste overly oily and were paired with carmelized onions. the french toast was just okay.
author: Regina C.

description:
A staple go to place when guests are in town.  Says something about a place that only serves breakfast/lunch/brunch, and can demand a solid wait every weekend.  Fresh and well made food, done right.  You'll wait 45 min minimum, but it's so worth it.  The menu changes quite frequently (they stopped with the bread basket...i hate muffins and crap, but devour the ones here...i'm sure they have some other amazing bread/pastry tho).  Every dish is unique, well prepped and ingredients dont taste like it they came from Safeway...isn't this why we pay for food?..to eat at places you that you can't mimic at home?  Breads/muffins, egg sandwich, Plow special, scrambled egg dishes, crazy potatoes (another item I can do without, but here I devour)...never had a bad meal, and always left completely satisfied.  I should write a bad review so you don't go, but I'd feel horrible if that led to this place shutting down haha.

Staff is super friendly, the guy managing the line on weekends is hilarious, and this place is simply a gem.

Comparable place would be Foreign Cinema, but this is much more do-able as an every weekend eatery.
author: A A.

description: I absolutely loved this place for breakfast! The lemon-ricotta pancakes...well many people have written about how delicious they are. My son had eggs with blood sausage, which he loved. It was too intense a taste for me, but if you like it, you should try theirs. Also, there's a lovely wait staff: friendly and relaxed, which is amazing in a place that is so busy.
author: Susan G.

description:
Rolling out of bed on a beautiful Sunday morning, I really wanted a hardy breakfast. I made the short trip up the hill and stopped at the restaurant with a pig on its sign. What I found was the BEST breakfast food that I've ever had.
     The "plow" breakfast was great. The home-made pork sausage was juicy, well-spiced, and well cooked. The mini lemon ricotta pancakes (I really do mean mini) had a nice crisp on the edges with a creamy center. The lemon flavor was bold without being overpowering. My eggs were cooked to my liking. But the star of this dish was the crispy potatoes. MAN these are GOOD. They grill moderate sized potatoes with onions, smash the potatoes, deep fry them, and toss them in salt and thyme. You get a hybrid concoction of homefries with the crisp of hashbrowns. VERY GOOD.
     The tuna sandwich is hands down the BEST I've ever had. The tuna is tossed in olive oil, lightly salted, mixed with capers,  and extremely fresh. The boquerones (white anchovies in olive oil and vinegar) added an extra dimension of flavor to the sandwich. Add a little hard boiled egg and put it on bread from Acme, and you have a Masterpiece.
     Unfortunately the portion sizes are bad. I can't really "plow" into a breakfast plate when there is not much food on it. I love eating and I'm willing to spend top dollar for top food. However, I feel that I should've been more satisfied after signing the check. It was really disappointing to watch the line cook throw a pile of crispy potatoes onto a plate only to have the head chef take some off and throw it back into the mixing bowl. The poor form ruined what was otherwise an AMAZING dining experience.
author: Siao W.

description: The wait was long and the counter seat was cramped but it was totally worth it. Perhaps the best breakfast sandwich I've ever had and definitely the tastiest breakfast potatoes. Oh yeah, the coffee was really good, too. Will definitely go back but might try to get there when they open.
author: Deanna G.

description: It's Plow, just go.  You won't be disappointed (except by the wait, so go early!).
author: Andrew K.

description:
best brunch for the $ since i have lived here (4 years). 

pros: get coffee while you wait for the table, friendly staff, well appointed environs, fresh and visually pleasing dishes, moderate prices, GET ANYTHING THAT HAS THE CRISPY POTATOES!, definitely get the homemade patty sausage.

cons: usual SF brunch wait, cramped if you get sat at the bar.

make yourself happy this weekend. make it your new favourite!!!

to the owners: great job bringing a classy, tasty, friendly establishment to my neighborhood.
author: neil c.

description: Thanks, Ashley for the tip on this place!  Booked a last minute tour at Anchor Brewery this morning and met some nice people who knew the area--they introduced me to this gem which is basically around the block.  I had the soft scrambled eggs with spinach, shallots and goat cheese-y goodness and those potatoes.. THOSE POTATOES!  Boiled then fried then tossed with seasoning and onions... so delicious.  Definitely worth a trip if you're in the area.  Also, who doesn't appreciate a neighborhood spot that serves quality brunch M-F? The world needs more of it!!
author: Alexandra N.

description: Surprisingly disappointed by the food - portions are quite small and a bit expensive for what you are getting - lovely decor, though, however. Hopefully they will work out the kinks...
author: chloe w.

description: I had french toast but doesn't taste anything like it.  The toast was way too hard to chow.  The pancake was burn, or overdue scrubbing/cleaning of grill pan, taste nasty.  Would never go back again.
author: James L.

description:
One of the best brunch places in the city

Great atmosphere, super friendly staff and yummy dishes

Must try the lemon ricotta pancake!
author: Santiago B.

description: This place is clean and simple, and I think it's what they don't add, that makes it so special.  The first thing you notice when you walk in is that it's busy.  Good food = a wait.  Next, you notice is that the smell makes you even hungry-as-ever, it's bright with natural light, warm with body heat, excited with servers and chefs moving about, and is loud with table conversations.  It hits just about all of the senses.  The pork sausages will hit the last sense with a lot of flavor and some spice.  The lemon ricotta pancakes could be addictive, and I'm glad that they don't give you a big stack for that reason.  The only reason for 4 stars and not 5 is that, my first visit, I had an omelette with tomatoes and goat cheese and really could not find the cheese, making the breakfast kind of bland.  I'd give 4.5 stars if I could.  Overall, it's a sense-awakening breakfast and brunch spot!
author: Jen O.

description: Everything I've ever eaten here has been delicious. It is totally worth the wait on a weekend morning. Service is low-key, but excellent. I usually get an egg dish, which is always well prepared. The ever changing doughnut-type thing is a great addition for when you're feeling especially hungry. Plus, I love a relaxing morning in Potrero.
author: Todd H.

description: Fabulous food!   We had to go twice in a row.  The potatoes are unbelievable - decadent yes, but so worth it.  The almond cake - yum.   The soft scambled eggs are just the way they should be.  The thing to really notice is how conscious and calm the cooks are.  This is a place where the owner is there from 4:30 am - 3:30 pm, and you can tell.  Everything has that care and quality to it.   I'll be back again and again.  Great discovery.
author: Mindo P.

description: 100% a brunch place (lots of eggy dishes) and in the SF style, better get there early as  it's fairly small.
author: Dave B.

description: Follow the golden restaurant rule - order a dish if it shares a name with the restaurant.  At Plow that means ricotta pancakes with amazing potatoes.  Ridiculously good.  I'm glad I got there early so I had a short wait.
author: Jeffrey H.

description: Plow is great for brunch. Lemon ricotta pancakes with those crispy potatoes and mimosa...can't be beat!
author: David G.

description: Came here for breakfast today, it did not disappoint...Fried Egg Sandwich and French Toast I shared with my friend were very yummy! I can't wait to go back and try the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes & Savory Bread Pudding next :)
author: Barbra C.

description: SO not worth the hour-long wait. The food is just okay and the place is hot and humid and the wait is absurd...
author: Beth T.

description: Loved my lunch - grilled veggie sandwich and a salad.  The smashed potatoes which accompany sandwiches are ridiculously delicious.
author: Jill D.

description: As you all know I work in Potrero Hill so when I spotted this new joint I had to come for breakfast.  The service was outstanding (thanks Randall for your hospitality), but this is not the place to bring my 20 month old daughter.  This is a place to come with a girlfriend, sip on a mimosa, and catch up.  This is not the place to bring a mischievous toddler who wants to stand in her highchair, want 'up!up! out! out!', and proceed to shriek when she got bored with her crayons.  The tables are really close together so to spair the guests the sideshow, we got our order to go. The eggs bene and potatoes were awesome!  Oh, and the mimosa that I downed hit the spot too.  I will definately be back without child (bless her heart).  The owner approaching our table and apologizing it didn't work out was an extra touch.
author: anne m.

description: While visiting San Francisco, we tried to find places that were not the "tourist traps" of the city for dining.  Plow's great reviews on Yelp lead us to venture to this small, yet excellent restaurant just 10 minutes by taxi from our hotel.  When we got there, we were promptly greeted by the hostess, and got our name on the list.   The wait was about 20 minutes on a Sunday morning around 10.  The service was fantastic, and the food was even better.   What gives their dishes a final "wow" are the crispy potatoes.  Never have I had a potato fried and seasoned quite like theirs.  They were excellent.  The fried egg sandwich, while good - should only be eaten with a knife and fork.  And the Plow - is just awesome.   To top it off, when we were done, we asked the waitress where we should walk to try and hail a cab, as the restaurant is in a more residential area, and we were worried that taxis wouldn't be readily available.  She instantly offered to call one for us!   As we were waiting in front while she was on the phone, she noticed one down the street and we were able to hail that one.  It was impressive that she was going out of her way to help us, as she did more than we were expecting!  This is a definite must, and if we lived in the area, would definitely come back many more times!
author: Bryan F.

description: Wasn't worth the 1.5 hour wait. I didn't like the lemon ricotta pancakes which everyone else seem to like.  It was a disappointment for me.  I enjoyed Mission Beach Cafe more.
author: mayiask k.

description: The Lemon Ricotta Pancakes were great.  Eggs and Potatoes were terrific.  Even the coffee and orange juice was good.
author: Thomas T.

description: Awesome brunch spot.  Crazy patrons, hold your ground when trying to get your name in, people's hunger overtakes their sense of civility. the the staff is amazing.  There's a reason there's a line! A definite go.
author: scott m.

description:
We've been wanting to come here for a long time, but I like to sleep in on my weekends and don't really like to wait over an hour for brunch.  Yesterday, we had a full day of activities planned and had to be out and about early anyway, so I thought why not make the most of a Saturday morning and make a trip to Plow for breakfast?

We got there a little before 9:30 and there was already a wait, but the host assured us it would only be a 15-20 minute wait.  In the meantime, he offered us coffee. Such a small and simple gesture, but always appreciated! Exactly 20 minutes later, we were seated at the counter where we could check out all the cooking action in the small, open kitchen.  It made it so hard to decide what to get because everything coming out looked so damn good. 

So I decided on the plow, which was kinda like their combo breakfast with eggs, bacon or sausage, potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes! Hubby took a bit longer to decide and finally went with the plow as well.  I got the bacon and hubby got the home made sausage patties. The food took about 15 minutes to come out because the kitchen was so busy.  There were 3 people in the kitchen and they were hustling nonstop. Finally the food came out and it was worth the wait! My scrambled eggs were cooked perfectly, nice and delicate.  The bacon was good but I wish it was a little bit crispier. The potatoes were awesome.  They were so crispy on the outside but soft on the inside.  They were also perfectly seasoned and mixed with sauteed onions.  With a little bit of ketchup, we were all set.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were delicious, so soft, fluffy, and lemony, and came with a side of maple syrup.  I tried the homemade sausage and loved it.  They were so flavorful with all the herbs and spices.  Next time, I am so getting the sausage patties! 

We had such a good meal here.  Not only was the food so delicious, but everyone there was so friendly and nice.  I loved their decor, so simple and bright with huge windows.  It just felt like a pleasant place to spend your weekend morning.  The great thing about sitting at the counter was that we got to see all the different stuff they had, so we had good ideas about what to order next time.  I was definitely intrigued by the fried pig ears! I know it sounds weird but they looked so good - light and crispy with what looked like a side of jalapeno vinaigrette.  Oh and I must have the chocolate eclair.  So many things to try next time.  I guess I'll need to plan another early morning to go to Plow again!
author: Kat M.

description: Plow is one of my favorite breakfast places.  The wait staff are very friendly and attentive.  Then there is the food.  Fresh, flavorful food that does not dissapoint.  The lemon ricotta pancakes are one of my favs.  The lemon flavor is bright, not muted.  Yum!  The french toast is another winner.  I can't wait to try the whole menu.
author: Funk G.

description: For breakfast I think Plow is as good as it gets.  I had the eggs benedict, the hollandaise was light and lemony.  The potatoes served with it were amazing, they were like french fries for breakfast, as Epic Meal Time would say "SMART."  Go early before the hipsters are awake and the wait won't be long.
author: Kevin M.

description:
wow! what a great meal! so excited to have another fabulous restaurant in p-hill! i had the fried egg sandwich w/bacon and it was amazing! im so excited to go back!

also looking forward for that wine&beer license! YUM!
author: Art A.

description: Great fresh and local ingredients. They make everything just a little bit different and special. Try the huevos rancheros.
author: Jessica B.

description: I give this place 5 stars for excellent presentation, great ambiance, friendly and fast service, quality ingredients and quality food. A little bit of a wait will be required but it is definitely worth it.  Their fried potatoes and pancakes are off the hook.
author: JENNY P.

description:
Plow is one of those off the beaten path oh so wonderful places that SF has so many of.  I owe my discovery of this little slice of awesome to a friend who shares my love of simple food made impeccably. I have never tried to test the waters on a weekend but I can say mid-morning and lunchtime during the week likely offer up the best time to sample the fare with minimal wait.  I highly recommend sitting at the bar at least once, its always fun to watch the food come together.

The food here is solidly good. Lunch offerings are usually a few salads and sandwiches, and breakfast staples are in circulation all day, assuming they have not run out.  My first trip resulted in a so-so salad, and a pretty awesome lamb sandwich.  I have tried the breakfast potatoes which do indeed put all other potatoes to shame.  The scramble is a little slice of heaven, as is the homemade yogurt, be sure to try it.  

If you are looking for well made, simple, wholesome, locally sourced, organic eats in a wonderfully inviting and warm atmosphere then check this place out.  Plus, the owners are a husband and wife who can be found making food in the kitchen and helping visitors to their table. Well worth a try!
author: Jenny E.

description:
Good on the weekend if you have 3hrs or so to hang out.

PROS:
* Food - awesome. Heirloom tomatoes + evoo? + sea salt were great! Pancakes super fluffy.

* Parking - relatively easy.

CONS
* The wait - a full hour for Sunday brunch.

* Staff - the hostess was competent, but not nice.  The waitress was nice, but not too competent. Three tables that were seated after us, were served before us, and our orders were super simple (heirloom tomatoes), without a lot of prep time. 

* Noise - it's loud. Use your outdoor voice.

We could have been served earlier, then out earlier to make room for another customer. Those in the service know how to keep a restaurant efficiently flowing. This service was like a gridlock.

The food was awesome though, so it'd be worth a try on a weekday.
author: suzan s.

description:
I met up with a friend here a few weeks ago. And I am such a fan. I ordered the lemon ricotta pancakes. They are delicious. Slight hint of lemon. Be warned, they are a little mushier because of the ricotta. But overall, delicious! We also ordered donut holes. These are awesome! They are crisp and sweet and sprinkled with powdered sugar.

the only downside is that it's a little hefty in price. But overall worth it for the good food!
author: Margaret L.

description: Breakfast!!!!! This place is sweet! Really stylish decor with a finish attentive to detail.  Venue is bright and sunny just like their servers.  Kinda makes you think this will be an expensive meal but not bad at all.   To the food...their egg sandwich is grubbing! 2 days later and I'm still thinking about it.  Simple but they obviously use good ingredients.  The squash soup and cesar salad were on par as well. My wife had spaghetti which I also liked.  I love cheap breakfast in the Mission but this place is a great spot to go to with the wife....she needs her Mission breaks!
author: Ramon L.

description:
I was in town for a film festival and staying in Potrero Hill.  What a great find.  I don't how long this charming and delicious place has been open, but I don't remember it from last year.
From the hostess to the server, everyone was wonderful!! The food was gorgeous and super tasty.
author: La S.

description: I had been eyeing this place forever, but have always been deterred by the line.  Finally, I decided to get there right when it opened.  It's a pretty tiny place, and I felt like I was right on top of my fellow brunchers.  I don't mind cozy (like Aperto), but this was too much.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were quite yummy, but my poached eggs and potatoes were inedible-- they were soooooo salty.   I left with an unquenchable thirst and an upset tummy.   I wish I loved this place, since it's in my 'hood, but I won't be back.
author: M D.

description: Could the lemon ricotta pancakes be any better?  Unlikely.
author: Amjad S.

description: I went for breakfast and ordered the French toast and absolutely loved it. The caramelized bananas make a great topping.
author: Peter B.

description: High quality breakfast with fresh, local ingredients in small cafe setting; get there before 10 on weekends to avoid 1 hour wait times.
author: Charley K.

description: Great lemon ricotta pancakes and fish sandwich. Small space.
author: Tuhin S.

description: We went after 12 on a Sunday and the wait wasn't too bad, about 15 minutes and the host was very nice offering us some coffee while we waited.  The service was great.  The biscuits and gravy were delicious and the potatoes were nice and crispy
author: Dawn R.

description: I just went to plow for the second time with the fiancee today and I got the same thing I ordered the first time:  the fried egg sandwich.  Strange that a fried egg, some greens, and bread would be this good but it's just really tasty.  The crispy bacon I added on was perfect too.  We also love the potatoes...nicely crispy on the edges!  I tried a side of one pancake too which was also very tasty...and they serve with real maple syrup!
author: Francis S.

description:
Being that I literally live around the corner from this place, I figured I needed to give it a shot. There is always a line on the weekends -- a long one. After thinking to put my name on the list before my brunch mate met me, I was told the wait was an hour. Ouch. They weren't kidding, either. 

They allow you to have some coffee from their brewed coffee station while you wait, which makes it slightly less unpleasant. Once we were finally set, we had a hard time picking what exactly to get for brunch. THe atmosphere is adorable, which makes chatting with friends all the more enjoyable. I ended up going with the Eggs Benedict, and we both shared a side of the lemon ricotta pancakes. Oh. My. Goodness. This food is good. The potatoes that come with it are also delicious. 

I can't wait to go back and try some of the other delicious items on the menu. I'm just a little intimidated by the wait time at this point.
author: William d.

description: Came here for weekend brunch with the family.  Arrived around 930a and waited about 25 minutes or so.  Not bad, was expecting a longer wait.  Ordered a bunch of dishes and shared them.  Highlights: the plow (nice to try a little bit of everything), almond flour pancakes, corn + cheddar bun.  Cute neighborhood spot.
author: Daisy Y.

description: Plow is a great spot tucked away in Potrero hill. I seriously adored our waitress and the host. I was thrilled with the lemony, airy ambiance. It's incredibly warm and refreshing inside. I had the excellent Trout salad with pomegranate and grapefruit. It's something that anyone can enjoy.
author: Mei F.

description: This place is a great neighborhood gem! Small family owned breakfast/lunch spot. A relatively simple menu but, everything's good! The staff really seems to enjoy working there and are genuinely interested in making your experience is a good one.
author: Robert M.

description: Wait is definitely not the business, but they say Tuesday and Wednesday's aren't as busy. Everything looked so good. Got the Plow, and it was just ... mmphhh, so delicious. I really wish I got to try the eggs benedict or the fried egg sandwich. My friend got the fried egg sandwich with bacon and I drooled watching him eat it.
author: Samantha Sydnie S.

description: Along the great row of food on 18th St in Potrero Hill and just down the hill from where they filmed the far from classic "Pacific Heights". This new eatery has some great brunch chow. We had the "plow" which consisted of eggs, homemade pork sausage, potatoes and 2 ricotta lemon pancakes. My lady had the french toast which weren't as good as the pancakes. The coffee was great, and the wait staff was warm and helpful. There are long lines on the weekends, so grab a cup at Farley's and wait in line. If you where a pig suit, they will give you a free cup of coffee.
author: Mike C.

description: New favorite breakfast spot in the city (sorry Zazi). Have to go early because the place is small and it gets packed. Breakfast sandwich and machaca are fantastic. Lemon pancakes are simply delicious along with their potatoes. Love this place.
author: AM M.

description:
I live in the Dogpatch and was very excited to have a new breakfast/brunch spot in the neighborhood. It looked modern but homey and like something definitely worth a try but...that line! On any given weekend morning there will be a crowd of people hanging out outside. I started resenting Plow for taunting me with its newness while shutting me out with it's dreadful long lines. "It's already over-hyped," I secretly thought to myself. Anyway, I finally bit the bullet and tried it out last weekend. The wait time was 45 minutes for a table for three. Ugh. They offer complementary coffee inside to soften the pain of waiting but it runs out quickly and people inside are too busy to keep it replenished. It is probably good business for Farley's, the coffee shop up the street.

Anyway, we finally got seated and I have to say the ambiance is simple but nice. It's going for a clean rustic vibe to go along with it's philosophy of using local, seasonal, farm-fresh ingredients. I works for me. We shared the lemon ricotta pancakes. SUPER DELICIOUS. I got the Plow breakfast plate (I think that was the name) which included eggs, potatoes, and two pancakes. Even though it's a pretty standard dish it just tasted better than I expected. The potatoes are crispy on the outside, soft on the inside and tossed with just the right amount of salt and some nice onions too. The freshness of the ingredients really makes a difference. I tried my friend's egg benedict with spinach and mushrooms and it was cooked to perfection. All our food was seemingly simple but wonderfully delicious and memorable. The nuances of the fresh ingredients really make all the difference in the flavors in the dishes. I felt totally satisfied but not overly stuffed nor heavy after my meal at Plow. I will definitely be back, although only on a day where I have the patience to wait in a ridiculous long line. I hope they expand soon!
author: Sherene C.

description: Probably not a "destination" brunch place... but if you're in the neighborhood, I'd recommend Plow. Servers here really are amazing. So happy, smiley and charming. I would rate the food we ordered as slightly above average brunch fare. They do the classics like scrambles, biscuits, pancakes, etc. but very fresh and clean tasting. The great service and thoughtful touches like free coffee while you wait for your table heighten the experience, making the food taste better than it really is.
author: Julia G.

description: This place is absolutely delicious and the atmosphere is relaxed and cute. We were in line for Mama's for 30 min and moved about one foot before we decided to ditch Mama's and try somewhere else. So glad we did! This place had less than a 10 min wait (late breakfast). The waitress was nice, and the food arrived rather promptly. There were big glass jars of water at each table so we could refill as we liked. I ordered "the Plow" (lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and poached eggs). My bf ordered the "fried egg sandwich" which came with crispy potatoes. I'm not much of a pancake eater, but my goodness these were absolutely delicious and unique. The texture was great too--not too fluffy and not flat. The potatoes were the crispiest I've ever eaten, and my bf agrees. They are salted to perfection. I highly recommend this place. It's nestled away in a residential and hilly area. Totally worth the price (I believe our bill came out to be ~$40) including a coffee. Cute shop. Clean and packed.
author: D C.

description: It's a small place, really cute and cozy. The wait wasn't too bad, but I went on a weekday. I can only imagine the line on weekends. My friend and I both ordered the same thing, lemon ricotta pancakes and a side of bacon. The lemon ricotta pancakes were fluffy and delicious. The bacon was cut thin and cooked with just the right amount of crunch. Plow is worth the trip to and the wait.
author: Adelina W.

description: Plow, you make me wish I lived in Portrero Hill.  The space is well appointed, modern without being run-of-the-mill.  I had the roasted pork sandwich with potatoes.  The salad may sound better for you BUT the potato is something else.  It is baked, smashed, deep-fried, and then tossed with some fresh rosemary.  Ruff, ruff!  I wish I had space for dessert.  Maybe next time, because there will definitely be a next time.
author: kitty p.

description: All the press reviews are right-  Plow is a GREAT brunch spot. The ambience has a modern rustic feel- as well as the food.  It's all the staples of the best of brunch food... only kicked up a notch.  I had "The Plow" which had probably the best lemon ricotta pancakes I've ever tasted.  Everything was satisfying and was perfect to kick off a lazy Saturday afternoon.  NOTES: Theres a bit of a bustle inside, so it would be best for a more lively crowd to join you. The parking is easily found, but the wait can be a bit long.  Try to get there early to potentially avoid a rush.  I noticed people having sidewalk cocktails while waiting, which I'll be sure to remember the next time I wait.
author: Sun M.

description: Plow has a wonderful set up for such a small restaurant, the tables are extraordinarily close together but its high ceilings and huge windows looking out over the city from its Potrero Hill location make it feel larger than it is. The menu is simple, and when the waitress told me they hadn't gotten in the peaches for the dish I ordered I wasn't sure if I was prepared for their lemon ricotta pancakes. But they were outstanding! I would completely recommend it, they're not different enough from regular pancakes that kids or picky adults wouldn't like them and the lemon taste is subtle. Their hand-made sausage is also delicious. Our waitress was attentive but not hovering and the regular coffee (the only way they serve it) was absolutely wonderful, I couldn't get enough of it and our waitress was observant enough I never had an empty cup.
author: Nicole F.

description:
Love the decor - light, bright, and airy.  The potatoes are to die for - probably the best I have had in a LONG LONG time.  I had the fried chicken sandwich, which was very good, but a bit skimpy on the meat.  I like Bakesale Betty's the best still.

My friend had the Plow and I tried his pancakes.  They were awesome!  I will have to try his order next time...
author: Ling L.

description: II hesitated heaping praise on Plow because it's a bit like bringing sand to the beach. I finally decided that it would be a supreme act of selfishness to try to keep this place a secret.  All you need to do is drive by the corner 18th Street and Texas on a weekend to see a crowd outside the door spilling into street to realize the secret is out.  I have an aversion to crowds so my visits are limited to a weekday morning. There is a warmth to Plow and the food is amazing. It's another great reason to live in Portero Hill. Thanks for all your hard work.
author: Steve A.

description: LOVE everything about this place. Atmosphere is fresh and clean. The people are super nice. And the food... The potatoes are outrageously good, crispy, rosemary goodness. The pancakes, sweet, fluffy. The house made pork sausage yummers. Still working my way down the menu. I met someone at the counter who said he eats there at least 3 times a week. I totally see why. I'm so tempted to head over there right now.
author: Pamela A.

description: This place is so good!! Don't expect anything too creative or original but it's some of the best breakfast food I've ever had. The food is very simple but it all tastes really good and thats what I loved about it. I don't even normally like breakfast potatoes but these were so good and full of flavor that I could not stop eating them.... no ketchup necessary!
author: Rolo A.

description: Finally decided to check this place out- there is always a big line, but this time got in within 10 minutes. Sat at the bar and saw the amazing food, fresh food - the kitchen was really clean. The food was amazing. I had the fried agg sandwich. My husband had the pork chop and egg. YUM. The french toast looks freaking amazing.. next time.
author: Erica H.

description: Great ambiance, great ingredients.  My advice: stick with the more natural dishes (eggs, potatoes, meat, etc) as I was just "meh" about the French toast.
author: Corey C.

description:
If you go on a weekend & don't get there right as they open, you will have to wait--possibly an hour. But the food is spectacular and worth waiting for. It's fresh, it's cooked perfectly, and it's interesting without pretense. The mason jars of spices are as utilitarian as they are beautiful. I love watching the cooks pull one down occasionally to prep, though I'm still waiting to see someone use the juniper berries for something.

You have to try: The lemon ricotta pancakes, the fried egg sandwich with bacon, anything with crispy potatoes, the olive oil poached tuna sandwich, and the cold smoked salmon.

The coffee is strong and refilled frequently. The staff is friendly and usually quite attentive. It's hands down the best breakfast/brunch in Potrero Hill and it competes nicely with Chez Maman for best lunch.
author: Jerry R.

description: I could go here, eat a plate of the potatoes, and leave happy. If the potatoes happen to come with their breakfast egg sandwich on the side (add bacon please), I would leave even happier though. I wish this place continued success. They certainly have a following already and that makes me happy since one of the co-owners is from my good ol' homestate of Wisconsin... Wisconsin folks are friendly, down to earth people and that's the vibe you get here. He mentioned feeling bad about the wait but that's typical of most good brunch places in SF. I didn't mind at all and will happily endure another wait in the near future to sample more of their menu.
author: Shoshana D.

description: I had a client meeting here last Saturday morning. I came after hearing through the grapevine that the brunch was off the hook. It was so amazing! The doughnut holes were a great way to start. Our server was all over it and very cheerful. I had Duck Hash and my companion had Eggs Benedict. Now, I've never been a benedict fan in my life, until I tried this one. The eggs and sauce were perfection and the English muffin was toasted exactly the way I like it. I indulged in a Blood Orange Mimosa and it was sensational. I can't wait to go back to try the Biscuits and Gravy. Yum!
author: Erica C.

description: Great place to eat and awesome staff. Got seated right away and the waitress was super friendly and attentive. Food was awesome. I'll definitely be going back... she's kinda cute too... wish I  got her name.
author: Francisco H.

description: I went there for the first time today for brunch, and god, what an amazing food!!!!! LOVE, LOVE, LOVE everything about this place. The service was great, ambience was awesome, and above all, the FOOD!! We were seated on the counter, I got a pot of jasmine tea and it comes in this cutesy little pot, enough for 1 1/2 cup. Then ordered the dungeness crab scramble which turned out to be a little bland on the egg, but the chunks of crab meat was perfect and the egg was not overcooked, so it balanced out. Homefries that comes with the egg was AMAZING. Crunchy, well-seasoned, I mean, it was just perfect. A friend got their big breakfast plate "The Plow" which also turned out to be amazing. Comes with two eggs, freshly made pork sausage, two ricotta cheese pancakes and potatoes. The pork sausage was very nice and the eggs was done to perfection, enough liquid egg yolk to dip your pancake in! YUM! Another friend got smoked trout salad and that was very nice, too. The beetroot gave the salad a little kick and avocado mashed into frisée was nicely done, the trout tastes great. Ended up paying $60 and it was worth every penny. Very filling and satisfying first experience there. I WILL DEFINITELY be back for more! Their baked egg looks amazing and I shall put that on my list to try next time.
author: Nitta P. B.

description: Definitely a contender for best brunch in the city.  The service was friendly and energetic, and the food was very nicely prepared.
author: Stu M.

description: Love this place! Great breakfast spot on Pot Hill. Soft scramble is the bomb & potatoes are cooked to perfection. Fresh & tasty ingredients and a nice yummy selection of breakfast foods. Nice service with a smile too. Would give it five stars but a bit pricey for breakfast... but then again what isn't in SF these days?!
author: Greg G.

description: Breakfast entrees were very good. Bakery goods basket made me pause; it was one of those moments when your bar just got raised. And I have 1000 visits to Tartine in my survey.
author: Bib G.

description: Wonderful brunch. Kind of reminds me of the old Bar Tartine stuff. Everything we had was delicious and everything we didn't have looked delicious.
author: m t.

description:
oh goodness.  never has a breakfast joint revitalized my affinity for morning meals (okay, slight exaggeration but who cares).  i've recently given up breakfast out of laziness, but it's amazing what lengths you'll go to for a place like this with good company.  :]  my friends and i came here on fridays for three straight weeks to try out all the dishes that we wanted.  while some things fell flat, i was mostly pleased whenever i left.

first off:  the coffee.  tasty and a nice pick-me-up for my sleepy mornings, especially if you wake up before six just to get some grub.  and can i just gush about their granulated brown sugar?  i think they use ramekins for it as presentation, and it's the cutest thing ever.  however, the last time i was there, they had white sugar cubes instead, and it made the coffee taste a little weird.  :|
